DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 1, or the 27th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: British chemist Sir Joseph Priestley announces that he has discovered oxygen.
1834: Robert Morrison, the first English missionary to go to China and translator of the Bible into Chinese, dies.
1894: War between China and Japan over the question of Korea breaks out. The Treaty of Shimonoseki was signed the next year, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaotung Peninsula, Taiwan, and the Pescadores to Japan.
1915: The Peking government mints its silver coin, known as "Yuantatou," bearing the likeness of Yuan Shih-kai.
1926: Kwangtung University changes its name to National Sun Yat-sen University.
1927: The Chinese communists stage the Nanchang Uprising against the Nationalist government.
1928: The Central Broadcasting System is set up in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1941: American volunteer aviators form the "Flying Tigers," with Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault as commander. They help China combat Japanese air superiority in the early stages of World War II.
1943: Lin Sen, chairman of the Nationalist government, dies at the age of 76.
1949: The Office of Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang is established in Taipei.
1958: An insurance program providing 180,000 government employees with coverage for maternity leave, illness, injury, disability and death is put into effect.
1966: The Chinese Communist Party opens a plenum meeting that declares the start of the 10-year Cultural Revolution.
1971: The Tainan Giants of the Republic of China win the Little League Asian and Pacific play-offs.
1973: The Economic Planning Council (EPC) of the Executive Yuan is inaugurated. The EPC replaces the Council for International Economic Cooperation and Development.
1973: Gen. Kao Kuei-yuan takes over from Gen. Cheng Ta-ching as the Republic of China's minister of national defense.
1976: The National Reconstruction Seminar opens in Taipei with 130 local and overseas Chinese scholars participating.
1984: ROC athlete Tsai Wen-yee wins a bronze medal in weightlifting at the 1984 Olympic Games.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves a slight increase in the premium rate of laborers' occupational injury insurance. The rates for thirty-two occupations are raised.
1987: The Council of Labor Affairs is formally established under the Executive Yuan.
1989: A foreign currency call loan market designed to make the metropolis an international financial center is established in Taipei.
1992: The National Unification Council defines "one China" as "one country and two areas each ruled separately by a different political entity."
1992: The Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters, the ROC's highest security institution, is disbanded, and the Coastal Patrol General Headquarters is established under the Ministry of National Defense.
1999: The U.S. Defense Department announces the sale of two E-2T Hawkeye 2000E airborne early warning aircraft and related equipment and services to Taiwan.
2000: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh pays a visit to New Party leader Hau Lung-bin, a move Hsieh said is aimed at showing respect to the opposition.
2000: Taiwan resident Huang You-fu becomes the 10 millionth traveler to pass through Macau International Airport.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By attending to the cleanliness and purity of his person and the propriety and dignity of his dress, and in every word and act permitting nothing which is contrary to good taste and decency, that is how the ruler puts in order his personal conduct."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL ARCHITECTS WELCOME TO BID ON WORLD GAMES STADIUM: MAYOR

TEXT.P: Top-notch architectural teams from around the globe are welcome to bid for the construction of the main stadium for the 2009 World Games to be held in Kaohsiung, the acting mayor of the southern Taiwan port city said Monday.
Chen Chi-mai made the remarks at a news conference where he announced that the Kaohsiung City Government has posted an open tender for the construction project on its official Web site.

For selecting the best design team for the new stadium, Chen said the city government has organized an evaluation commission composed of six local and seven foreign experts on architecture. Foreign judges will come from the United States, the Netherlands and Japan, he added.
Covering a 19-hectare plot of land, the new stadium will have a world-class 400-meter track-and-field competition area. It will have 40,000 fixed seats plus room for 15,000 standing spectators.
With a view to helping cut global warming gas emissions, Chen said the new stadium will incorporate eco-friendly construction technology with solar-powered equipment.
Carrying a price tag of NT$5.3 billion, the stadium is scheduled for completion in January 2009 in time for the next World Games from July 16 through July 26 that year.
The winning contractor will be selected in early December this year, Chen said.
The World Games is a global athletic competition of sports not included in the Olympic Games. It will be the largest-ever international sports event ever hosted by Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iraqis Promising a Constitution by the Deadline
Under intense American pressure, Iraqi leaders agreed Sunday to finish writing Iraqi country's constitution by the middle of August, raising the possibility that they will leave unresolved some of the fiercest disagreements over the future of the Iraqi state. Among the most divisive issues are the rights of women, the role of Islam and the scope and reach of Kurdish self-rule. Keeping the political process on track is central to the Bush administration's desire to begin drawing down the number of American troops here by early spring. If the political process continues apace, a new government would be elected to a full term, under the new constitution, in December.
Wall Street Journal: Rupert Murdoch's Third Wife Seeks Stake for New Kids, Upsetting Adult Children
The marriage between News Corp. Chairman Rupert Murdoch and his third wife, Wendi Deng, in 1999, has opened a rift between Murdoch and his older children, one that throws into doubt who will control the company after the media titan's death. One of the key debates: Who should inherit the family's US$6 billion fortune and Murdoch's control of News Corp. Should it be just the media titan's adult children, as is now the arrangement, or also his two youngest children by Deng?

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' TO PUSH FOR NCC LEGISLATION IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: The legislative caucuses of the nation's two major opposition parties said Monday that they will push for a vote on a bill about the establishment of the National Communications Commission (NCC) when the Legislative Yuan begins a new session on September 13.
Caucus officials of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) called on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to show some goodwill and not filibuster the bill again.
The two parties reached the consensus when KMT Central Policy Committee Executive Director Tseng Yung-chuan called on the PFP caucus.

The DPP caucus, however, called on the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP not to insist on their "unreasonable" demand that the NCC be made up in proportion with the political party seats in the legislature. That would simply hurt the independence of the NCC, said caucus Secretary-General William C.T. Lai.

The KMT, the largest opposition party, has also attached a caveat to the passage of the NCC organic bill in an attempt to preserve the party's assets at Broadcasting Corp. of China (BCC) , according to Lai.
Most of BCC's 60-odd radio channels are no longer in use, but the KMT wants to keep them for itself, instead of releasing them for the government to redistribute for better public service, he said.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , a minority party in the same "pan-green" camp as the DPP, also wants to see the NCC bill become a law as soon as possible.
But according to TSU caucus convener Ho Min-hao, the party was also concerned that the KMT's proportional representation demand would create an "unobjective" National Communications Commission.
The DPP's Lai said if the KMT remains adamant in its unreasonable demand, people can expect a fierce battle on the legislature floor when the NCC bill gets a vote showdown in September.
The establishment of the NCC has long been a campaign promise of President Chen Shui-bian, who wants the country to have a vibrant and independent media industry, Lai said.

The latest push for the NCC bill was triggered by the Government Information Office's (GIO) decision Sunday to not renew business licenses for seven TV channels, including an all-news channel owned by Eastern Multimedia Group.

PFP Legislator Lee Yung-ping said she, like the majority of the people, was upset about the media's unprofessional and unethical reportage, but it should not be the GIO, which is controlled by the ruling party, that has the mandate to regulate media operations.

"If political force is to intervene again in how the media should work, we'll be returning to the days of 'white terror, '" said Lee, referring to the KMT's authoritarian rule before losing power in 2000.
She said the current ruling party, the DPP, is being hypocritical when it claims it wants to reform the media but at the same time boycotts the legislation of the NCC bill.

Now the DPP has gone even further by scaring the media with the renewal of licenses as many of them have voluntarily invited government officials to talk about policies free of charge, or even carry the so-called "placement ads" in delicate cooperation with the government, she said.

The birth of the NCC would strip the GIO of many of its current powers over the media. So PFP's caucus deputy convener Sun Ta-chien asked the people to watch who will be stopping the bill from being passed in the legislature when his party cooperates with the KMT in pushing for a vote.
The TSU's Ho called on the ruling and opposition parties to "negotiate in good faith" and not continue struggling so the NCC can be set up in the best possible shape.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TEXTILE EXPORTS CONTINUE LOSING STREAK

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported 1.59 million tons of textiles in the first half of this year worth US$5.95 billion, down by 18 percent and 6 percent, respectively, from the previous year's levels, the Taiwan Textile Federation reported Monday.

The domestic industry has come under mounting pressure both at home and abroad since the removal of a global quota system early this year, federation officials said, adding that soaring oil and material prices have added further pressure on them, wiping out their gross earnings.

While the domestic industry is facing a serious manpower shortage in marketing and manufacturing at home, products from China, South Korea and India have emerged as strong rivals to Taiwan-made goods in overseas markets, the officials said.

The domestic industry has in recent years been troubled by a severe workforce shortage in both management and manufacturing, which is also in part, they said, a result of a crowding-out effect of the hi-tech sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MEETS INDIANA GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received Indiana Governor Mitch Daniels Monday at the Presidential Office, saying that he hopes trade and economic ties between the two sides can be strengthened.

Thanking Daniels for making his first visit to Taiwan since his assumption of office as the governor of Indiana late last year and the state's long-term support for Taiwan, Chen said that it is a clear indication that Daniels attaches a high degree of importance to Taiwan and added that he felt deeply honored.

Taiwan and Indiana forged sisterhood ties 26 years ago and it was the first U. S. state to do so and the first to open a representative office in Taiwan, Chen said, pointing out that its imports to Taiwan totaled about US$100 million last year, making Taiwan the 19th-largest export market of the southern U. S. state.
The president expressed his hope that two-way trade and business would be further stepped up following Daniels' visit to Taiwan.
For his part, Daniels praised Taiwan's democratic, trade and hi-tech development and called President Chen's achievements a prominent hallmark not only to Taiwan but also to the rest of the world.
Daniels, the first Indiana governor to visit Taiwan, extended his invitation to Taiwan businessmen to visit his state and promised to further solidify bilateral friendships and relations.

American Institute in Taiwan Taipei Office Director Douglas Paal, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mau Kao and Vice Secretary-General to the President James Huang were also present during the meeting, along with a group of Indian lawmakers that accompanied Daniels on the current visit to Taiwan -- one of the stops of its Asian tour.

The Indiana state legislature approved resolutions in April this year supporting Taiwan in its efforts to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization and in it's desire to ink a free trade agreement between Taiwan and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO ACCEPT EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION CONDITIONALLY

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus said Monday that the party will reluctantly accept the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) proposal to convene a special legislative session as long as it only reviews a special statute on an eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.539 billion) flood-control project.

In response, Premier Frank Hsieh said it is up to the Legislative Yuan to decide which bills to review in the extra session, although he said other bills such as the arms procurement package proposal are also important.
If the legislature can pass certain key bills earlier rather than later, the people's burden will be lessened, the premier added.

Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT legislator and director of the KMT's Policy Committee, said that convening a special session is a serious matter at the constitutional level, but the DPP has convened five special sessions in its five years of rule.
It is wrong to make holding a special session a common practice, Tseng said.

As flood control concerns the public, the party is willing to accept the proposal to hold a special session, albeit reluctantly. The next regular session will be opened earlier than scheduled, and other issues can be discussed at that time, he said.

He criticized the Executive Yuan's version of the flood-control proposal for being rashly prepared and looking suspiciously like a pork-barrel policy, and he questioned whether it will effectively control flooding as claimed by the Cabinet.

The KMT has invited experts and scholars to discuss the matter and will come up with its own version of a flood-control bill, he said, although it has yet to decide whether to finance the project in special or annual budgets.
The DPP legislative caucus said it welcomed the KMT to come up with its own version of a flood-control bill.

But William Lai, a DPP whip in the legislature, said that the KMT's criticism that it is roughly prepared and could be a pork-barrel policy only shows that the party doesn't know much about the DPP's flood-control project.

The DPP appreciates the KMT's response even though it is only narrowly focused on the flood-control project, Lai said, adding that five other major bills urgently need to be passed, and there is no reason to review only one bill in the extra session, he added.

In addition to the flood-control project, the five other prioritized bills the DPP proposed are the confirmation of Control Yuan members, a NT$480 billion arms procurement package from the United States, proposed amendments to the Executive Yuan Organic Law, proposed amendments to the tobacco and liquor tax law, and a draft bill concerning the establishment of a labor pension fund monitoring committee.
Meanwhile, Legislator Sun Ta-chien of the People First Party (PFP) , an ally of the KMT, said that the PFP legislative caucus is adamant in its opposition to holding a special session.

Sun said that the DPP has proposed lumping together six bills in the extra session, and the PFP caucus couldn't possibly accept this. However, even if the extra session only reviews the flood-control project, the PFP is against holding the session.

He also said that Tseng told the PFP legislative caucus that the KMT will propose its own flood-control bill, and it will be reviewed along with the Cabinet's bill in the next legislative session. The KMT will also communicate with the PFP caucus on the content of the KMT- sponsored bill, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN CONSUMERS RESPOND FAVORABLY TO TAIWAN FRUIT

TEXT.P: Spanish consumers in Madrid have responded favorably to Taiwan lychees sold there on a trial basis, according to the Kaohsiung Agriculture Development Co., a company with investment from eight agricultural associations in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Company officials said Monday that a Taiwanese businessman operating in Spain ordered 300 kg of lychees July 18 and received favorable response. The businessman then decided to order additional Taiwan fruit, including lychees, longans and guavas.

In mid-June, the company received orders for 40 kg each of pineapples, papayas, lychees, mangoes, lemons and guavas from a Taiwan businessman operating in Hamburg and in early July, a Taiwan businessman in Britain ordered 12 kg each of avocados, dragon fruit, guavas, mangoes, papayas and pineapples.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EXPRESSES CONDOLENCES ON SAUDI KING'S DEATH

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has expressed condolences upon the death of Saudi Arabia's ruler, King Fahd, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said the government directed ROC Representative to Saudi Arabia Yang Sheng-chung to convey its condolences to the Saudi authorities earlier in the day.
Fahd died early Monday at the King Faisal Specialist Hospital in the Saudi capital of Riyadh. His brother, Crown Prince Abdullah, has been appointed the country's new monarch.
Lu said the ROC government looks forward to the continued strengthening of relations between Taiwan and Saudi Arabia under the new Saudi monarch.
"It is hoped that King Abdullah will continue to beef up the friendly relations between Taiwan and Saudi Arabia," Lu said.
Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, Saudi Arabia is a major crude oil supplier to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES MEDIA TO PRACTICE SELF-DISCIPLINE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus accused the media Monday of committing "nine great sins" including violating human rights and fabricating news, and urged media workers to reflect on themselves and to practice self-discipline.

William C.T. Lai, secretary-general of the DPP caucus, defended a Government Information Office (GIO) decision to revoke the business licenses of seven TV channels, including an all-news channel owned by the Eastern Multimedia Group.

He said TV channels are public assets and that if they are not run in the interests of the people but in such a way that they contradict the original purposes of their establishment, the GIO has a duty to correct them.

The "great sins" that he claimed the media, particularly the electronic media, have committed include too much sex and violence, too many "mock shows, " low-quality live broadcasts, interviewing abused or other unfortunate children, and abusing "scoop news."
He also accused the media of making news reports as if they are producing variety shows and of packaging advertisements in their news stories.
One after another legislator from across the political spectrum has demanded that the government do something to stop the media from producing such poor quality news programs, Lai pointed out.

Now that the GIO has finally made a bold move by revoking the seven licenses, it should be praised, he said. However, he went on, some opposition lawmakers have done the opposite by denouncing the GIO.
He said his caucus would be more gratified if the GIO had withdrawn even more licenses for all-news channels.
As to the justification for stopping the Eastern Multimedia Group's S Channel from continuing to operate, Lai said it was a decision by a group of experts that of course can be commented on.
If the TV channel does not think it was a fair decision, it can appeal through the proper channels but should not send reporters to protest at the GIO, Lai said.

Many people have reacted angrily to the terribly poor quality of the TV news, the tawdry sensationalism and the often factually incorrect reporting, and "quite a number" of news programs are watched by less than 1 percent of the viewing public, he said, adding that in the face of solid evidence, the media should not shirk its responsibilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 20 points to close at 6,297, with 13,495 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September moved up 15 points to end at 6,280, with 225 contracts traded, while December futures lost one point to finish at 6,260, with one contract traded. March futures moved up two points to close at 6,255, with 22 contracts traded, while June futures moved down 32 points to close at 6,192, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,227 for August, 6,265 for September, 6,261 for December, 6,253 for March and 6,224 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
August TE futures moved up 1.3 points to close at 262.6, with 2,858 contracts traded, while September TE futures gained 0.75 points to finish at 262.2, with 59 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

August TF futures remained unchanged at 979, with 1,505 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved down 1.6 points to end at 975.6, with 80 contracts traded. March TF futures moved down six points to close at 970, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 4.05 points to close at 6,307.93.
The bourse opened at 6,320.67 and fluctuated between 6,327.83 and 6,290.93 during trading. A total of 3.09 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$76.72 billion (US$2.43 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up at 0.2 percent.

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.7 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and paper and pulp issues both at 0.7 percent and textile stocks and banking and financial shares both at 0.2 percent.
Cement stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 521 to 327, with 135 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST UNIVERSITY ON PENGHU INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Monday presided over the inauguration ceremony for National Penghu University -- the first university located on an outlying island.
Chen expressed his hope that the university will merge with local districts, expanding into a big university town dedicated to the development of local culture and the economy.

Noting that the creation of the university was a promise he made during his visit to the outlying island off the southwestern coast of Taiwan in February last year, Chen said he is glad to see his wish fulfilled and he believes everyone feels happy with the facility.
The president said Penghu suffers from population drain due to its lack of good employment opportunities because of limited natural conditions.

Every family on Penghu has to pay at least NT$100,000 (US$3,100) a year on average for one person to receive an advanced education on the mainland island of Taiwan. With the opening of the new university, not only can residents save money, people will be needed on the island to work at the university, and could even attract people to work in Penghu, Chen said.

The president also said that with an aquacultural industrial technological development and research center, he hopes the university can help Penghu develop the aquacultural industry and other relevant businesses such as recreational fishing and biotechnology.
Chen was accompanied by Premier Frank Hsieh to make the visit to the university which was transformed from the National Penghu College of Technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD BEEFS UP SAFETY CHECKS ON FERRIES

TEXT.P: After a fire on a ferry sailing between Pingtung and the island of Hsiaoliuchiu that resulted in the death of four passengers who jumped overboard and drowned trying to escape the flames, the Coast Guard Administration's (CGA's) Taitung patrol office conducted an overall safety check Monday on all ferries operating routine voyages to Green Island.
CGA inspectors boarded every ferry to check fire fighting equipment and lifesaving facilities, CGA officials said.

The tragic accident that occurred in Pingtung a day earlier did not seem to have stopped tourists from taking the ferry to Green Island. Over 1,000 tourists packed Fukang port in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Monday morning to make the trip to Green Island.
Dozens of tourists were injured during the fire that broke out as the boat was heading from Tungkang to Hsiaoliuchiu, southwest Taiwan, and the boat's owner, Chang Chien-kun, also perished.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM ON NEW CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS SOUGHT BY 2008

TEXT.P: The goal of the second phase of constitutional reforms will be to have the reforms passed by the Legislative Yuan and by national referendum prior to 2008, the head of the Constitutional Re-engineering Office said Monday.
Lee Chun-yi made the remarks after the formal inauguration of his office earlier in the day.
A mission-oriented National Assembly passed a constitutional reform package June 7, paving the way for the next phase of constitutional reforms.
According to Lee, the most important part of President Chen Shui-bian's announcement to promote the second phase of constitutional reforms will be to expand people's participation.
He noted that seven previous rounds of constitutional reform have focused on political issues. Politicians and parties were involved in the reforms but the general public had little say in them.
The task ahead will be to expand the participation and to ask the Taiwan people what kind of constitution they would like.

It will also be necessary to promote the constitutional education from the grassroots level, Lee said, adding that the government should use easily understood language to give people easier access to constitutional reform issues. He added that the office will train seed teachers to publicize the issues islandwide.
The president feels that constitutional reform should not be top-down and that the people have to learn that such reform is closely related to them.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WILL NOT BLOCK FRUIT EXPORTS TO CHINA: DPP LEGISLATIVE WHIP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not prevent Taiwan farmers from taking advantage of the tariff-free treatment granted by Beijing by selling their fruit to China, DPP Legislative Yuan caucus Secretary-General William C.T. Lai said Monday.

Answering questions at a press conference, Lai said the government has an obligation to provide farmers with adequate information so that they can make their own judgment on what is beneficial to them.
However, he warned the farmers not to look at only the short-term benefits, claiming that they could suffer "great losses" in the future.

At a separate press conference, Tseng Yung-chuan, a legislator of the opposition Kuomintang and executive director of the party's Central Committee, urged the government to put aside political considerations and begin making all necessary preparations to help fruit farmers develop the Chinese market.

He denied news reports that the KMT is planning to set up a Cross-Taiwan Strait Agricultural Cooperation and Development Fund to handle Taiwan's fruit exports to China, describing the reports as untrue and saying the KMT "deeply deplores" the reports.

China's tariff-free treatment, which became effective Monday, was offered to Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, as a sweetener during his visit to China in late April and early May. The new measure covers 15 fruit categories: bell fruit, betel nuts, coconuts, custard apples, dates, guavas, loquats, mangoes, papayas, peaches, persimmons, pineapples, plums, pomelos and star fruit.

While the government insists that Taiwan's foreign trade arm, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), handle all matters relating to fruit exports to China, the Chinese customs authorities unilaterally announced a list of the first group of Taiwan civic organizations whose certificates of origin for exported fruit it will recognize.

The government fears that Beijing is using the tariff-free treatment for Taiwan-grown fruit as a "united front tactic" to make the government of Taiwan look like a local government of China. Beijing, however, has remained uninterested in acknowledging Taipei's authorization of TAITRA to handle the issue.

Figures released by the Council of Agriculture show that in 2004, Taiwan exported US$3.55 billion-worth of farm produce, including US$33 million-worth of fruit. Japan was Taiwan's largest market, accounting for 42 percent of Taiwan fruit exports, followed by the United States with 22 percent. China accounted for only 1 percent of Taiwan's export market.

DOC.HEADLINE: POET BECOMES TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Luo Chih-cheng, an established young poet who once served as deputy editor-in-chief of the China Times Express evening paper, was sworn in Monday as director of the Taipei city government's Information Department.
Luo, who will concurrently serve as the municipal government's spokesman, said he has great expectations for his new job.

"I'm a typical urban dweller. I have my own observations and expectations of Taipei's development. Taipei is reputed to be the capital of the creative 'Chinese-language cultural industry.' It is hoped that the city government can play a more active role in the formation of Taipei's unique urban culture and life style," Luo said.

Noting that the Information Department is an integral part of the city government's service team and a communication conduit between the city government and individual residents, Luo said he will do his utmost to fulfill his duty to help the public understand the city government's policy initiatives, stance and accomplishments.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said after handing over the official seal to Luo that he expects Luo to use his literary talent to faithfully and accurately publicize the city government's administrative achievements.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW SAUDI KING FRIENDLY TOWARD TAIWAN: MOFA

TEXT.P: Saudi Arabia's new monarch, King Abdullah bin Abdul Aziz, who is considered friendly toward Taiwan, attaches great importance to developing bilateral cooperative relations, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Monday.
The ministry said the substantive relations between Taiwan and Saudi Arabia are expected to continue and be further improved with joint efforts by the two countries.

In a press release, the ministry said the government expressed its deep condolences over the death of Saudi King Fahd, who died early Monday. The king was immediately succeeded by his half-brother Abdullah.
Saudi Arabia is a major crude oil supplier to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SAID USING FRUIT EXPORT ISSUE AS GAMBIT TO SWAY TAIWAN VOTERS

TEXT.P: China has been seeking to use the fruit export issue to launch a media war in Taiwan and win sympathy for the pro-unification "pan blue alliance" in December's local elections, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) sources claimed Monday.

While trying to use the issue to divide Taiwan and lure away DPP supporters in southern Taiwan, China is also attempting to cripple the government and downgrade Taiwan's status by shunning the government appointed Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) in bilateral farm talks, the sources said, predicting that China will use similar gambits in future if it succeeds in influencing the elections.

Issues centering on Taiwan's duty-free fruit exports to China -- one of the overtures offered by China during visits by main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong in late April and early May -- have become a hot topic for debate in recent months, they said.

As agricultural produce from Taiwan is much more expensive in China than local goods, President Chen Shui-bian is well aware that China's zero-tariff treatment is "by no means an economic matter but rather a politically charged issue, " presidential aides said.

Chen has outlined what he called his "one principle, three arrangements" to underscore the government's stance regarding the issue, the aides said, expressing worry that the government will fail to convince Taiwan farmers as they are much more mindful of their own interests than the cross-Taiwan Strait political strife.

Many city mayors and county magistrates affiliated to the DPP in southern Taiwan have said that they fear that the issue, if further fanned by the opposition, will slash the DPP's chances in the year-end city mayor and county chief elections, they said.

The "one principle" refers to Taiwan's positioning of China as only one segment of the global market for Taiwan farm exports, while the "three arrangements" refers to TAITRA's designation as the sole commissioned body responsible for farm exports to China; a team of Mainland Affairs Council and the Council of Agriculture officials set up to open two-way talks; and "round-trip, non-stop" cargo services by airlines based on the two sides, according to the aides.

After Beijing passed the Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan in mid-March, the farm export issue has become a lever for China to sway Taiwan voters in favor of the "pan blue alliance" as the local election approaches, a high-ranking DPP cadre said.
China will be very likely to adopt the same approach if it gets what it wants in the December's elections by playing the fruit export card, DPP officials claimed.
Meanwhile, China's announcement of its duty-free treatment for 15 items of Taiwan fruit took effect the same day without prior negotiations with Taiwan authorities.
Although some DPP legislators are concerned that the development will cast a shadow over the party's performance in the upcoming elections, some others are not so pessimistic.

DPP Legislator Huang Wei-jeh contended that it will have a limited impact on the party in the year-end elections or the 2008 presidential race unless the fruit overproduction problem gets worse in Taiwan.

DPP lawmaker Lin Tai-hua said that it remains to be seen whether Taiwan farmers will profit from the Chinese market because sales remain unknown and transportation costs are still expensive owing to a lack of direct links across the Taiwan Strait.
Citing government statistics, she said that the Japanese market absorbs around 40 percent of Taiwan agricultural exports, while the Chinese market only accounts for just 1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Russia Fumes Over Basayev on ABC
The Foreign Ministry summoned the U.S. Embassy's top official and politicians expressed outrage after a U.S. television network broadcast an interview with Chechen warlord Shamil Basayev, who has a $10 million bounty on his head and has claimed responsibility for the Beslan school hostage-taking and other terrorist attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAUDI KING'S DEATH WILL HAVE NO EFFECT ON TAIWAN'S OIL SUPPLY: CPC

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said Monday that the death of Saudi Arabia's King Fahd will have no effect on Taiwan's oil supply.
Saudi Arabia is the country's largest oil supplier. The CPC imports around 150,000 barrels of oil from Saudi Arabia per day, or between 20 and 25 percent of the CPC's oil imports.
CPC President Chen Pao-lang noted that Saudi Arabia is friendly toward Taiwan and said Taiwan is also a good client of Saudi Arabian oil.
King Fahd's death and Crown Prince Abdullah's succession is also not expected to affect international oil prices, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO STREAMLINE PROCEDURE FOR FOREIGN YACHTS ENTERING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An Executive Yuan committee decided Monday to promote leisure and tourism activities in Taiwan waters by streamlining the application procedure for foreign yachts entering and leaving Taiwan.

In a meeting presided over by Vice Premier Wu Rong-i, the tourism development committee of the Executive Yuan passed new operating procedures for foreign yachts applying to enter or leave international commercial ports or marinas.

Under the new rules, foreign yacht skippers can fill out cruising permits upon entry and use them to certify their mooring or berth. The yachts will then be able to enter and leave Taiwan's international harbors, marinas and 19 fishing ports open to yachts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU TO BE OPENED FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT SHIPPING: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that if all goes well, the outlying island county of Penghu may be opened for direct point-to-point shipping services across the Taiwan Strait on an experimental basis, starting in September at the earliest.
Hsieh made the remarks after attending the inaugural ceremony for National Penghu University -- the county's first university.

As the government has opened the two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu for direct point-to-point shipping service with the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian, some Penghu political figures have been urging the government to open Penghu for similar direct services with a selected Chinese port.
According to Hsieh, if the Penghu county government comes up with an application for such services, the application is very likely to be approved.

Taiwan still bans direct cross-strait transport links for national security concerns, but Hsieh said the government can give a green light to Penghu's application on an experimental basis, in line with the formula adopted for opening direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei shipping services.
Hsieh said it would take one or two months for the government to complete screening of such an application, so if all goes well, the services could kick off in September at the earliest.
After a period of experimental operations, Hsieh said, the arrangements could be formalized as long as no flaws become apparent.

Responding to Hsieh's remarks, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun said the government once allowed a group of Penghua pilgrims to make a direct voyage to Xiamen to visit several Chinese temples in 2002.
Starting in September, Liu said the government may allow Penghu residents with business interests in China to make direct voyages to Xiamen from Penghu.

As to some Penghu people's call for allowing the county to serve as a cross-strait cargo transshipment entrepot, Liu said the proposal is infeasible under the current regulations. In the future, he said, the government may revise relevant regulations to allow Penghu to be a transshipment point.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S DUTY-FREE TREATMENT FOR TAIWAN FRUIT HAS LIMITED VALUE: MAC

TEXT.P: China's duty-free privileges for 15 varieties of Taiwan fruit will have "limited" economic value, the nation's top China policy charter claimed Monday.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks as China proclaimed Monday that 15 varieties of Taiwan fruit, including pineapples, guavas and mangoes, can enter China duty-free from that day. China also recognized place of origin certification issued by the chambers of commerce of 11 cities and counties, including Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung.

Wu claimed that China's new measure will have little impact on Taiwan's economy, basing his speculation on the fact that Taiwan, before the duty-free offer was in place, exported only US$340,000-worth of fruit to China last year.
Even though the customs tariff is cut to zero, the saving will be "very limited, " according to Wu, adding that there are also non-tariff hurdles to such exports.
He claimed that further streamlining of the inspection and examination procedures, which involve public authority, can only be done through cross-strait consultation.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWAMKERS URGE CHINA TO RELEASE PRO-DEMOCRACY ACTIVIST

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers of different political stripes urged China Monday to release Wang Bingzhang, an imprisoned pro-democracy activist who is reportedly in poor health, for humanitarian reasons.

The legislators made the appeal a day after Wang's son Wang Daishi said his father's mental and physical health is very bad and that he is worried about the possibility of his father committing suicide.
Wang was arrested in China in February 2002 and sentenced to life imprisonment.

Legislator Lin Cho-shui of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said Wang's condition has caused widespread concern in the Chinese community around the world. Even major international human rights organizations have listed Wang's case as a major concern, Lin said.

From a humanitarian perspective, Lin said, China should release Wang so that he can receive medical treatment. For China's own international reputation and political development, Lin said, China should not continue to imprison Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: 100 FATHERS TO GET NEW FACES AS FATHER'S DAY GIFTS

TEXT.P: A leading plastic surgeon and his colleagues in the southern port city of Kaohsiung will offer their services to 100 fathers who wish to have wrinkles and age marks removed to give them a "new" face.

Plastic surgeon Tsao Szu-pin is calling on other plastic surgeons to join him in the activity in celebration of Father's Day in Taiwan, which falls on Aug. 8. Registration will begin Tuesday, and the first 100 fathers who respond to the offer will get the free service.
The activity is being cosponsored by two of the Rotary Club's regional chapters and Soroptimist International.

Tsao, accompanied by representatives from the civic organizations involved, will appear in the Grand Hi-Lai Hotel on the afternoon of Aug. 7 to meet with the 100 selected fathers. He will display advanced equipment such as intense pulse light and laser and show them how to get rid of crow's feet, glabellar lines and other hyperdynamic wrinkles through injections of botox or hyaluronic acid.

Tsao noted that more and more men have begun to take advantage of the new technology in plastic surgery. According to his experience, the ratio between men and women visiting his clinic has increased from 1:9 to 3:7.
He said men are more conscious than before about how they look and are resorting to plastic surgery to give themselves a "new facade."

DOC.HEADLINE: TV STATION LICENCE REVIEW PROCESS OPEN AND FAIR: GIO

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) claimed Monday that a TV station licence review carried out by a group of well-respected experts was done in an open and fair manner.
GIO chief Pasuya Yao, responding to accusations that the review committee "worked behind the scenes," demanded that the accusers come forward with evidence for their claims.

The review committee decided late Sunday not to renew business licenses for seven TV channels, including an all-news channel from the Eastern Multimedia Group, triggering strong protests by the channel's reporters.
In a statement, Eastern Multimedia questioned the criteria based on which the committee members concluded that the channel was not worthy of a renewed six-year licence to operate.

The media group also accused the GIO of violating the administrative law by having not acted in accordance with due procedure in handing down the "punishment" that totally disregards the well-being of the channel's 1,000-odd employees.

In response, Yao said the committee members took into account the media group's long-term investment. Otherwise, they would have chosen another of the group's all-news channels, which ranked No. 1 in terms of disciplinary actions over the past six years, for withdrawal of its business licence, he added.
The committee said it hoped that Eastern Multimedia will put its resources into the remaining news channel to improve its operations, according to Yao.

He also made public the name list of the review committee, including Professor Kuan Chung-hsiang of Shih Hsin University, Professor Lee Chung-hsi of Tung Hua University and Wu Chia-hui, deputy director-general of the Directorate General of Telecommunications under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications. Only two members wanted their names withheld.
Yao also said the whole review process was videotaped for the record, which can be made public.

In Penghu, Premier Frank Hsieh said the GIO carried out the review according to law. When a review is done, "we cannot guarantee that all TV stations will have their licenses renewed for another six-year term," he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, GUATEMALA INK FREE TRADE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Guatemala signed a free trade agreement (FTA) in Guatemala city on Sunday, a pact that is expected to take effect after being ratified by legislatures of both countries, according to a statement issued Monday by the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The statement said that the FTA was signed by Vice Ministry of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long and his Guatemalan counterpart Enrique Lacs after four rounds of negotiations.

The talks ran aground not long after the two countries began the negotiations because of Guatemala's request that Taiwan open its market to agricultural and industrial products from Guatemala wider than Guatemala's opening to imports from Taiwan because of Guatemala's less-developed economy, the statement said.
Thanks to intensive negotiations, the differences were eventually sorted out and both sides found common ground, according to the statement.

Under the agreement, Taiwan will offer duty-free privileges to 644 Guatemalan agricultural items immediately after the FTA goes into force, in return for similar privileges from Guatemala on 447 Taiwan agricultural products.
In terms of industrial products, Guatemala promised to open its market to 3,509 items that consist of 60 percent of Taiwan's current exports to the Central American state.

Most important of all, the statement said, Guatemala, as a signatory to the Central America Free Trade Agreement and the proposed Free Trade Agreement of America, will provide Taiwan businessmen with valuable access to the American market.
Under a chapter for investment in the Taiwan-Guatemala FTA, Taiwan businessmen can get a beachhead into the American market by investing in Guatemala, the statement said.
Taiwan and Guatemala also promised to continue their negotiations on opening their sky and sea to each other's carriers, the statement went on.
Once the open sky agreement is concluded, the statement said, air carriers of each country may fly on to third destinations via each other's airports.

Noting that Guatemala is the third-largest economy in Central America, with a gross domestic product accounting for 36 percent of the whole of Central America, the statement hailed the FTA as a milestone that will contribute significantly to Taiwan's foreign trade growth and to ties between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE CHINESE PROFESSIONALS VIOLATE RULES DURING TAIWAN VISITS

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese professionals who violate Taiwan's regulations during their stays has been rising continually in recent years, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday.
In the first seven months of this year, 125 such cases were reported, compared to 155 in the whole of 2003 and 179 in 2004.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-hsun said that in July alone, three Chinese professional groups, with a total of 20 members, were repatriated for either conducting activities inconsistent with their stated travel purposes or for making false entries on their travel documents.
Liu said the government deals with such cases strictly in accordance with the law to maintain orderly exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEACHER DONATES LOTTO WIN TO CULTURAL ORGANIZATIONS

TEXT.P: A schoolteacher has donated the entire NT$50 million of a lotto win to educational and cultural organizations -- the biggest donation to date by a sole lotto jackpot winner, the Taipei Fubon bank disclosed Monday.
The bank would not reveal any further information because the donor had asked to remain anonymous.
Statistics show that to date, 225 lotto winners have donated a total of NT$402 million to 109 charity and social welfare organizations.
Last month, an anonymous lottery jackpot winner donated NT$20 million to the Creation Social Welfare Foundation, which is dedicated to caring for comatose people from low-income families.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 2, or the 28th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: William II, known as "William Rufus," king of England from 1087, is slain by an arrow while hunting in New Forest. He was succeeded by his younger brother, who became Henry I.
1798: A 14-vessel naval squadron commanded by Rear Adm. Horatio Nelson scores a brilliant tactical victory over a French fleet of 17 vessels in the Mediterranean.
1918: British, French, and U.S. troops try to smash Lenin's communist revolution by supporting the White Russian forces and seizing Archangel.
1921: Enrico Caruso, the Neapolitan with the golden voice known as the world's greatest tenor of his time, dies at the Hotel Vesuvio in Naples at the age of 48.
1922: Alexander Graham Bell, Scottish inventor of the telephone in 1876, dies at the age of 76.
1923: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, dies in office at the age of 58. He made several misguided appointments that led to a corrupt administration.
1924: The Kwangchow government sets up the Central Bank of China with T.V. Soong (Soong Tzu-wen) as governor.
1934: Paul von Hindenburg, German general, politician, and president of the Weimar Republic, dies at the age of 86. He was succeeded by Adolf Hitler who declared himself "Der Fuhrer."
1938: Chinese troops blow up a bank along a section of the upper Yangtze River in an attempt to slow a Japanese advance.
1939: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, writes to U.S. President Roosevelt urging him to start an atomic project.
1944: Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., U.S. Navy pilot and elder brother of John F. Kennedy, is killed when his plane explodes over the Belgian coast.
1945: The Potsdam Conference, the final Allied summit of World War II, comes to an end.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Dahomey, Niger and Upper Volta.
1961: President John F. Kennedy and visiting ROC Vice President Chen Cheng issue a joint statement in Washington, D.C., opposing the admission of mainland China into the United Nations.
1964: President Lyndon B. Johnson orders a retaliatory strike after a torpedo attack on the U.S. Navy ship Maddox in the Gulf of Tonkin.
1980: The International Telecommunications Administration inaugurates direct dialing station-to-station telephone service between Taipei and major cities in Britain, France and West Germany.
1985: Kuo Yu-hsin, former member of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, dies of illness in Washington, D.C., at the age of 77.
1986: The ROC delegation to the Aug. 4 ROC-U.S. trade talks, headed by Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Vincent C. Siew, leaves for Washington, D.C.
1990: Saddam Hussein makes good on Iraq's claim to the oil-rich state of Kuwait by invading it. Thousands of heavily armed Iraqi troops quickly cut through the defenses of their tiny Gulf neighbor and gain firm control of the capital city of Kuwait City.
1996: Michel Debre, former French prime minister, dies at the age of 84. He was Charles de Gaulle's trusted aide and the architect of the Fifth Republic.
1996: Typhoon Herb roars across northern Taiwan, leaving nearly 60 people dead or missing.
1999: The ROC representative to Japan, Chuang Ming-yao, expresses his grave concern to his Japanese counterpart about a plan by a group of Japanese lawmakers to land on the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea.
2000: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan leads a delegation of senior KMT officials to pay a courtesy call on ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh at the DPP headquarters in Taipei.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records announces two of Taiwan's record-setting fathers as part of celebrations for Father's Day, which falls on Aug. 8. One of the record-breakers is Lo Tseng-wen, who has five children serving as police officers, and the other is Chang A-piao, a centenarian who is living with four generations of offspring under the same roof.
2001: The final section of the 11.307-kilometer New Kuanyin Tunnel of the North Link Railway is blasted through, making it the longest two-way railway tunnel in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By banishing all flatterers and keeping away from the society of women; holding in low estimation possession of worldly goods, but valuing moral qualities in men: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to worthy men."
