DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO INVITE OPPOSITION HEADS TO ATTEND ROC-CENTRAL AMERICA SUMMIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has decided to invite opposition leaders to join him in attending a summit with Central American heads of state to show the nation's unity in the fight against China's attempts to marginalize the ROC, a ranking official of the Presidential Office said Tuesday.

The official also said that the president's invitation also aims to show that the ruling and opposition parties both support the government's determination to expand the ROC's diplomatic relations with other countries.

According to the official, the Presidential Office will officially extend the invitations to the chairmen of the Kuomintang (KMT) , the People First Party (PFP) , the New Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union as soon as Nicaragua, the host country of the fifth ROC-Central America summit, sets a date for the meeting.
Chen is scheduled to leave Taipei in late August or early September to attend the meeting slated to be held next month.

The biennial summit gives Taiwan an opportunity to reinforce its strategic alliances with its diplomatic allies in the region and to show its willingness to serve as a capable and responsible member in the international community.

Considering China's ongoing attempts to smother Taiwan in the international community -- despite KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong's visits to the mainland earlier this year -- the president thinks that if the four main opposition party leaders can accept his invitation and go with him, it would demonstrate the nation's unity, the official further said.

The president also believes that national and diplomatic interests are certainly above the interests of political parties and that the diplomatic issue is one that has nothing to do with political ideologies, adding that no matter who is in power, Beijing's diplomatic hegemony towards Taiwan remains unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CLOSELY MONITORS CHINA'S NEW DIPLOMATIC OFFENSIVE AGAINST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: China has launched a new diplomatic offensive against Taiwan by using its growing economic clout to sway the ROC's diplomatic allies, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Tuesday.

Speaking at a regular foreign ministry news conference, Lu said China has stepped up improving trade and economic exchanges with Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central and South America in recent years with a view to sabotaging those countries' longstanding relationships with Taiwan.
Lu said the foreign ministry has noticed China's new strategy and has alerted the nation's diplomatic allies to the possible pitfalls behind China's new economic-oriented diplomatic offensive.

In the face of China's intensified efforts to "befriend" Taiwan's diplomatic allies, Lu said the foreign ministry has been striving to expand cooperation with Latin American diplomatic allies in various fields, including boosting bilateral trade and economic cooperation, increasing exchanges of visits by high-ranking government officials and assisting them in manpower training.

Moreover, Lu said diplomatic staff stationed in those countries have been working hard to inform the political leaders, journalists and business executives that China's ultimate purpose is to sabotage their countries' longstanding friendships with Taiwan.
"We have also reminded them that if China's cheap products flood their markets, their economic benefits could be at stake," Lu said.
Latin America and the Caribbean have been Taiwan's diplomatic stronghold, with nearly a half of its diplomatic allies located in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISTS LOOKING FORWARD TO NO-VISA STATUS TO JAPAN: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday thanked Japan for planning to grant permanent visa-free treatment for Taiwan tourists.
President Chen made the remarks when he received Japanese Dietman Seshiro Eto at the Presidential Office.

The president said that if Japan goes ahead and provides Taiwan tourists permanent visa waiver status after the Aichi Expo, it will not only signify bilateral friendship between the two countries, it will also be a sign that Japan values the 23 million people on Taiwan.
Earlier this year, Japan granted 90-day, visa-free entry to Taiwan visitors from March 25 through Sept. 25 in connection with the World Expo in Aichi prefecture in central Japan.
The president also said he hopes that Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's privatization of the Japanese Post is a success.
For his part, Eto expressed his admiration for the president for his dedication to the nation as well as his concerns about East Asian peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Shuttle May Get Repair in Space. Concern over two protruding pieces of heat- resistant fabric on the underside of Discovery prompted NASA on Sunday to consider a first-ever in-flight shuttle repairs that would require a spacewalk.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Smooth flow as evening toll kicks in on CTE.
For the first time in years, travelling on the north-bound Central Expressway (CTE) during the evening peak hours was a breeze.
The new two-hour toll, which came into effect between 6pm and 8pm yesterday, helped push average speeds on the CTE pass the 60kmh mark after the gantry near the Pan-Island Expressway exit.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Smooth on CTE last evening when the new ERP gate began using.
Evening Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) started along the Central Expressway on Monday and this led to some congestion along alternative routes heading north.
But traffic along the northbound CTE was relatively smoother than before.
This is the first time Singapore has the evening ERP from the ERP system set up in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: 'People power vs GMA would be a disaster'
MANILA (AFP) -- Ousting President Arroyo through another "people power" revolt over claims she rigged last year's elections would be a disaster for the Philippines, the top US official here said yesterday.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Witness links Arroyo, poll fraud, 'jueteng'
THE FIRST eyewitness account of a meeting between President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo and election officials in her home emerged yesterday during which she reportedly appealed for help to win last year's balloting and money from an illegal gambling lord was handed out after she had left.
The Philippine Star: US: GMA can still make turnaround
President Arroyo can recover from the political crisis besetting the country and her leadership if she makes "difficult decisions," pushes reforms and forms coalitions with other groups, US Embassy Charge d' Affaires Joseph Mussomeli said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Bribe witness surfaces
A former official in President Arroyo's office alleged Monday he had personal knowledge that she rigged last year's election, saying he witnessed a supporter distributing bribes to election officials in her house.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Saudi Arabia's King Fahd dies
Saudi Arabia's King Fahd died Monday after years of ill health and a turbulent reign that saw the ultraconservative Muslim Kingdom face up to a wave of deadly Islamic extremism.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: President Sends Bolton to U.N.; Bypasses Senate
U.S. President Bush bypassed the Senate and installed John R. Bolton as his ambassador to the United Nations on Monday over strong Democratic objections that he was abusing power and undermining the credibility of the United States. Bush said he had been forced to act becaus e the United States had gone for more than six months without an ambassador to the United Nations. It was the first time since the United Nations' founding in 1945 that the United States has filled that post using a recess appointment.
Wall Street Journal: New Frontier Deep Inside China, American Family Struggles to Cope
As corporate ambitions bore deeper into China, foreign companies are sending families to less-developed cities like Chongqing. Such places offer huge, untapped markets for companies. They also provide accelerated career opportunities to young executives eager to punch their ticket on the way to upper management. But the postings can feel like a detour into isolation and culture shock for some families.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHORUS PRAISED IN VIENNA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Chorus from Kaohsiung City performed in Vienna July 31 to warm praise from the audience, according to the organizer of the event.
The representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Vienna, Hwang Cheun-yen, thanked the performers for bringing a bit of Taiwan to Vienna.
Taiwan Chorus has 80 members and tours the world every year. It has been recognized by the Council of Cultural Affairs for four consecutive years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA OPERATING WITHIN THE LAW HAVE NOTHING TO FEAR: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: The government was exercising self-restraint when it decided to pull the plug on the licenses of seven TV stations, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday, adding that no media outlets will be affected as long as they operate within the law.

He made the comments in the wake of controversy over the Government Information Office's (GIO) decision Sunday to cancel the operating licenses, including one for an all-news channel owned by the Eastern Multimedia Group.

If the GIO only considered public opinion, it would have withdrawn more licenses, Hsieh said after attending a ceremony in which some government offices were cited for outstanding performance in protecting intellectual property rights.

"The existing media review system may have some glitches, but it does give the GIO a mandate to review media practices. If the GIO does not do its job, it will be charged with misprision," Hsieh said.
The government will certainly protect those who abide by the law, but government officials must carry out their duties when they feel it is necessary to do the right thing, he said.

In this case, if public opinion had prevailed, quite a few more media outlets would have had their operating licenses revoked, which had been the original intention of a number of members of the GIO review committee, he continued.

He noted that about 80 percent of the people have urged the government to "do something about" Taiwan's electronic media, many of which have been disciplined for unethical practices. Hsieh said that it was important for people to appreciate the difficult position the government is in with regard to deciding whether or not to renew a media company's license.

Asked if the government was trying to push for media mergers or restructuring, Hsieh said as long as organizations do not violate the law, the government will not intervene in the formation of media policy or media operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES JAPAN LOWER HOUSE'S APPROVAL OF VISA-FREE STATUS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is happy that the lower house of the Japanese Diet passed a bill Tuesday that would grant permanent visa-free treatment for Taiwan tourists, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said.

"We appreciate the Japanese lower house's friendly move. Hopefully, the bill can clear the upper house as soon as possible to allow for its early enactment to further boost bilateral exchanges," a MOFA official said.

The House of Representatives or lower house of the Japanese Diet passed the bill at a plenary session Tuesday afternoon. The bill will now be referred to the upper house of the Diet for approval. If it clears the upper house, Taiwan tourists will permanently be allowed to enter Japan without first obtaining a visa.
The granting of permanent visa-free status for Taiwan passport holders will mark a significant breakthrough in substantive Taiwan-Japan relations, the MOFA official said.

The bill was initiated by the head of the lower house's legal affairs committee and passed with the support of the Liberal Democratic Party and its ruling coalition partner, Komeito, and the opposition Democratic Party of Japan.

As Japan does not maintain formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan, the bill is necessary if Japan wants to offer a permanent visa waiver for Taiwan citizens. Japan's existing exit and entry regulations only authorize visa waivers for citizens from countries that maintain diplomatic ties with Japan.

Earlier this year, the Japanese parliament passed a similar special bill to grant 90-day, visa-free entry to prospective Taiwan visitors from March 25 through Sept. 25 in connection with the eco-friendly World Expo in Aichi prefecture in central Japan.
As the temporary visa waiver period will expire soon, Japanese parliamentarians decided to pass a new bill to allow for permanent visa-free status to Taiwan citizens.

Taiwan has been Japan's second-largest tourist source after South Korea. Japanese parliamentarians said they hope that the permanent visa waiver will attract even more Taiwan tourists to Japan after the Aichi World Expo and further boost bilateral cultural and commercial exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SHOULD PRESERVE ITS "SECRET WEAPON" WHILE FACING CHINA'S THREAT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should continue to treat the United States as its "secret weapon" as it faces military threats from China, a retired U.S. general who was once stationed in Beijing said Monday.

Eric A. McVadon, a former military attache of the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, made the remarks while addressing a seminar held by the "U.S.-China Policy Foundation (USCPF) " on the recent development of U.S.-China relations.

McVadon said that as described by a report released recently by the Pentagon on China's military power, the goals of the People's Liberation Army (PLA) are to prevent Taiwan from moving forward toward independence and to deter Washington from intervening in a potential cross-Taiwan Strait conflict.

The PLA has attached great importance to the build-up of its deterrence forces against U.S. military interference in the Strait, he also said, adding that the United States must study how to face China as its military strength is improving by leaps and bounds.
According to the former general, it is really difficult for Taiwan to face China's increasing military strength since the island can hardly defend an attack from the mainland by itself.
However, he said that Taiwan has a "secret weapon" -- an effective and appropriate intervention of the United States at a time when the island encounters an attack from mainland China.

Claiming that Taiwan must do whatever it can to retain such a "secret weapon" by handling its relationship with the United States well, McVadon said that U.S. President George W. Bush will be faced with a difficult decision on whether Washington should intervene in a conflict between Taiwan and China if the island is the one who provokes the conflict. "China is working on deterring the United States from intervening in a cross-strait conflict and Taiwan should not help it, " he added.
Also, the retired general also urged Taiwan to improve its relations with China.
Two former U.S. ambassadors to China, J. Stapleton Roy and James Sasser, and Chas W. Freeman, a former ranking U.S. official stationed in China, also attended the seminar.

Pointing out that it is pointless for both sides of the Strait and the United States to go to war, Freeman said that it must make those parties that might be involved in such a war understand the seriousness of the situation and then avoid a war.
The USCPF is an organization that promotes a greater understanding between American and Chinese policymakers, researchers and government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SINCERE IN INVITING OPPOSITION LEADERS TO COME ON TRIP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's invitation to opposition leaders to join him in attending a summit with Central American heads of state in Nicaragua is sincere, an official of the Presidential Office stressed Tuesday.

Chen Wen-tsung, director-general of the Department of Public Affairs, made the remarks amid a lukewarm response from the two main opposition parties - the Kuomintang (KMT) and its ally the People First Party (PFP).
The president is scheduled to leave Taipei in late August or early September to attend the meeting slated to be held next month.

Chen Wen-tsung said that as soon as Nicaragua, the host country of the fifth ROC-Central America summit, sets a date for the meeting, the Presidential Office will formally extend the invitations to the parties.

He reiterated that China will not let up on Taiwan regardless of which party is in power, and the president hopes to have opposition leaders join him to show that the nation is united in opposing Chinese' relentless efforts to marginalize Taiwan in the international community.

Asked about the difference between the latest offer and President Chen's desire to hold an inter-party summit meeting, Chen Wen-tsung said that the president's invitation is for the betterment of diplomacy, while the summit meeting will focus on domestic politics and economic issues.
KMT Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou said he has no plan to join the president on his trip abroad.
Ma, who will take over the helm of the KMT Aug. 19, said he thanks the president for the kind invitation, but "we are preoccupied with work at home, and can't make it."

Wu Yu-sheng, a KMT legislator and a key Ma aide, said the urgent task now is major national issues such as flood control and cross-strait issues, and not spending money in inviting opposition leaders to travel abroad. It is best for President Chen, who represents the nation, to attend the summit meeting, Wu said.

Cho Po-yuan, a KMT whip in the legislative caucus, said that it is odd for the president to invite opposition party leaders to visit Central America, saying that this might be his attempt to divert public attention from the government's poor handling of fruit exports to China as well as the renewal of licenses for cable TV stations.

Huang Yi-chiao, a PFP whip at the legislative caucus, said the caucus feels that it is "not necessary" to join President Chen for the trip, and will suggest to party Chairman James Soong that he decline the invitation.
Huang said that no leaders of democratic countries would have taken opposition leaders with them when visiting diplomatic allies, saying that there is no such thing "in theory" or "in practice."

But the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , are upbeat about the president's invitation, saying that their chairmen will be delighted to go with the president.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said that all parties, irrespective of their politics, should work toward raising the nation's international profile and DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang will go with the president.
Cheng Cheng-lung, Lee's counterpart in the TSU, said that President Chen's visit will help the international community learn that Taiwan is a sovereign, independent country.
As all people should work for better diplomacy, TSU Chairman Su Ching-chiang will surely join the president, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG JIN-PYNG SAYS HE HAS NO INTENTION OF SERVING AS MA'S DEPUTY
DOC.DATELINE: San, Francisco, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By Chiang Chun and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday that he has no intention of serving as the senior vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) under the party's newly elected chairman, Ma Ying-jeou, who is currently Taipei mayor.

Wang, who tendered his resignation as a vice chairman of the party to outgoing KMT Chairman Lien Chan last week after losing the party chairmanship election on July 16, is in San Francisco for a 10-day private trip with his family.
Answering questions from the media, Wang said that he would not serve as Ma's deputy even if Lien tried to persuade him to accept Ma's offer.
"I believe Mr. Lien understands my position, " he said. He pledged that he would always remain a faithful member of the KMT.

On his future plans, Wang said he will try to do a good job in the legislature and keep clear of party affairs so that Ma can have a free hand. He added that the way to show the greatest respect for Ma is to give him enough space for maneuvering without any restraints.

Wang acknowledged that he had been criticized for not accepting Ma's offer to serve as the KMT's senior vice chairman. However, he said, people should not use this to judge him to be a man of small caliber, because these two things are incomparable.
According to Wang, the best strategy for the KMT is for himself and Ma to each do their best in their own posts to help the KMT win the 2008 presidential election and become the ruling party again.

Wang and Ma fought a hard election campaign in which both camps blamed the other side for mud-slinging. A victorious Ma, who captured 70 percent of the vote in the party election, later apologized to Wang and tried to mend fences. He has obtained Lien's promise to help him make peace with Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB TO ISSUE SEA WARNING OVER APPROACHING TYPHOON

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) might issue a sea warning as soon as Wednesday afternoon as typhoon Matsa approaches Taiwan, bureau officials said Tuesday.

With a radius of 200 kilometers and packing maximum sustained winds of up to 100 kph, Matsa was centered about 1,050 km east-southeast of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi at 8 a.m. Tuesday, the CWB reported.
Meteorologists said it is still too early to tell whether the typhoon will directly affect Taiwan, but they warned that the waters along the east coast will be rough as Matsa draws near.
They also noted that northern and northeastern parts of Taiwan can expect some light rain as these areas come under the typhoon's influence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 35.61 points to close at 6,343.54.
The bourse opened at 6,344.4 and fluctuated between 6,360.43 and 6,296.78 during trading. A total of 3.47 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89.48 billion (US$2.8 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up the most at 0.9 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.8 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, textile stocks at 0.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.3 percent and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.
Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 462 to 380, with 144 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 43 points to close at 6,340, with 27,076 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September moved up 45 points to end at 6,325, with 419 contracts traded, while December futures gained 32 points to finish at 6,300, with 10 contracts traded. March futures moved up 45 points to close at 6,300, with 14 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,297 for August, 6,280 for September, 6,268 for December, 6,255 for March and 6,235 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.
August TE futures moved up one point to close at 263.6, with 4,889 contracts traded, while September TE futures gained 1.5 points to finish at 263.7, with 103 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

August TF futures gained six points to finish at 985, with 2,503 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved up 7.2 points to end at 982.8, with 79 contracts traded. December TF futures moved up 5.8 points to close at 981, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.076 to close at NT$31.844.
A total of US$708 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.920 and hit a low of NT$31.836.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXPOUNDS NEW THEORY OF 'FOUR STAGES OF ROC'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian gave a detailed explanation Tuesday of what he described as "the four stages of the Republic of China (ROC)" in an attempt to give the public a clear and definitive idea about his ideas regarding Taiwan's sovereignty and national identity.
Talking to a group of young people participating in the Ambassador Program of the Formosa Foundation of the USA, he noted that the ROC was established in China in 1912.

In 1949, the ROC "moved" to Taiwan. In the third stage, during the time when Lee Teng-hui was president (1988-2000) , "the ROC on Taiwan" was the catch-phrase used to describe the nation, according to Chen.
In the fourth stage after 2000, with the first peaceful transfer of power in the ROC's history, the new phrase should be "the ROC is Taiwan," he said.
He noted that prior to 1949, the ROC had nothing to do with Taiwan because the island was under Japanese rule from 1895 until 1945.

With that historical background in mind, he said that as the leader of Taiwan, he would like to use the title of "Chinese Taipei" to attend the informal leaders' meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) in South Korea.
He noted that Taiwan has been "in a difficult situation" for a long time and lamented that Taiwan cannot use the title it would like.

He repeated his syllogism on Taiwan's future: The ROC is an independent and sovereign country; its sovereignty belongs to the 23 million people of Taiwan; therefore, only the people have the right to make any change to Taiwan's future.
"This is the best possible interpretation of the fact that the sovereignty of Taiwan lies in the hands of its people," Chen said.
He emphasized that sovereignty is something that is inalienable, so Taiwan's sovereignty is something that cannot be shared by anybody other than the 23 million people of Taiwan.

Chen said he is aware that even though he is willing to use the title "Chinese Taipei" to attend the APEC summit in Korea -- a title that he claimed does not provoke or challenge anyone -- it will still be "extremely difficult" for him to attend the meeting in November.

The title of Chinese Taipei was accepted by Taiwan when it, Hong Kong and China joined APEC in 1991, he recalled. He added that although he and the government very much hope to use the title of Taiwan or the ROC in APEC meetings, "it's very, very difficult."
In the international community, whenever Taiwan tries to use the title "Taiwan, " China tries to suppress or sabotage Taiwan's efforts, he said.
Only when Taiwan's national status, national identity, national sovereignty and the question of who has the right to change its future are all made clear can Taiwan educate its youth, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA WELCOMES TAIWAN PRESIDENT'S VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Panama President Martin Torrijos Espino said Monday that his government would welcome a visit by Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian.
Torrijos denied that his government has ever said it would be "inconvenient" for his country to receive Chen should he wish to visit the country in September.

Torrijos made the remarks following reports that Panamanian First Vice President and Foreign Minister Sameul Lewis Navarro said Panama will not have enough time to receive Chen, as the country will be busy preparing to mark the first anniversary of Torrijos' inauguration.

After witnessing the signing of several agreements between the foreign ministers of Panama and Paraguay aimed at strengthening bilateral ties, Torrijos stressed that Chen's Panama visit should depend on the schedules of and agreements reached between the two leaders, and that Panama has never said it will be inconvenient for the country to receive Chen.

Panama and Taiwan maintain cordial and sincere relations and there has been no discord between the two countries, Lewis said, adding that Taiwan has been generous toward Panama both in extending donations and providing assistance for Panama's national development.

In addition, Lewis noted that it is necessary for Panama to strictly oversee the use of foreign aid and that the country is investigating the lack of transparency and proper supervision of Taiwan's donations, which he noted is a purely internal matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE FEAR SEXUAL OFFENSES: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly 80 percent of the respondents to a recent poll fear sexual harassment or violence, a ratio so high that it shows it is a major concern in everyday life here, according to the results of a survey released Monday.

The poll conducted by the Garden of Hope Foundation and commissioned by a local magazine shows that as high as 78 percent of the respondents were concerned that they or their families might suffer sexual harassment or violence.

Some 76 percent of the people surveyed contended that current punishments for sexual offenders are too light and have no deterrent effect, while 50 percent favored the idea of electronic tracking and living restrictions on such offenders.

Around 66 percent said that they believe sexual offenders should not be released on bail without treatment, while a similar percentage of the respondents agreed that they should receive compulsory treatment continuously until any possibility of re-offending are removed, according to the poll results.

Nearly half of the respondents said that they are in favor of the government publishing data on offenders, while most said that they would first ask for help from social workers or professional counselors if they were sexually attacked.
The public opinion poll was carried out Feb. 4 to March 7, collecting 2,006 valid questionnaires over the Internet. About 71 percent of the respondents were female.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S DUTY-FREE TREATMENT FOR TAIWAN FRUIT CONCERNS SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: China's duty-free treatment for 15 items of Taiwan fruit is likely to have a flow-on impact on South Korea, which is now concerned that its apple exports to Taiwan may be affected, according to a South Korean farm trade source.

According to an official with a South Korean government-affiliated agro-trade organization in Taipei who requested anonymity, South Korea believes Taiwan might import apples from China following China's offer of duty-free privileges.

If true, it would deal a very heavy blow to South Korean apple growers, because almost all their produce is sold to Taiwan, the source said, pointing out that only between 3 percent and 5 percent of South Korean fruit, mainly apples, pears, oranges and persimmons, is exported each year.

Although the Taiwan government contends that fruit exports to China are not necessarily profitable and that Japan is a better market, farmers in southern Tainan County, which is Taiwan's leading mango growing area, do not agree with this viewpoint.

Huang Cheng-ching, chief delegate of the Yuching Township Farmers Association, claimed that China is the best market for Taiwan farm exports, mainly due to its proximity and the variety of different fruit qualities it is prepared to accept.

Despite the fact that the government claims Taiwan should focus on rich countries such as Japan instead of what it describes as the high-risk Chinese market, Huang dismissed this concept, pointing out that only 20 percent of locally produced mangoes are qualified for export to the stringent Japanese market, while the Chinese market is much more open to a variety of qualities of fruit.
Tu Chao-yen, an economic professor at Japan-based Kokugakin University, said that it is not contradictory to approach the Japanese and Chinese markets at the same time.

While Japanese consumers are highly quality conscious, the Chinese market is larger and is rife with opportunity, Tu said, suggesting that Taiwan should sell products of various qualities to satisfy different market demands.
In addition, Tu said, Taiwan tea is also a good foreign exchange earner as long as the domestic industry devotes itself to innovation in quality and flavor over the long term.

China's duty-free treatment for 15 kinds of Taiwan fruit, including pineapples, pomelos, persimmons, mangoes, bell fruit and star fruit took effect Aug. 1, a move that has gained positive response among farmers in southern Taiwan who are traditionally strong backers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Chen Hsi-huang, a former chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) , said that China's zero-tariff offer is aimed at converting "market merchandise" into "political advantages " and claimed that Taiwan farmers' desire to further explore the Chinese market underscores the low-income problem in the domestic agricultural sector.

Citing COA statistics, he said that non-agricultural annual household incomes averaged NT$1.13 million (US$35,320) in 2003, well above the NT$873,901 average registered by agricultural families -- only 15.7 percent of which, or NT$178,111, was earned by farming.
Low income and product price fluctuations have long been a major headache for Taiwan farmers, Chen said, urging the government to resolve the issue.

COA statistics show that Taiwan farm production totaled US$3.55 billion in value last year, with exports worth US$33 million -- some 42 percent to Japan, 22 percent to the United States and just 1 percent to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO USE LOGO 'TAIPEI WONDERFUL' TO LURE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government will use the logo "Taipei Wonderful" to attract both local and foreign tourists, city government officials said Tuesday.
According to Bureau of Transportation officials, the logo was chosen through an on-line competition in which 1,282 people participated.
The author of the logo, Hsieh Yao-cho, who gained 6,056 votes from an on-line vote among 17,000 voters, will receive a prize of NT$10,000 (US$314) worth gift voucher of a department store.
The officials said the Bureau of Transportation will also hold a lucky draw among the people who participated in the vote, and will inform the 1,200 lucky voters via e-mail.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION UNIMPRESSED BY PRESIDENT'S 'FOUR STAGES OF ROC' THEORY

TEXT.P: The main opposition parties were unimpressed Tuesday by President Chen Shui-bian's new theory about what he described as the "four stages of the Republic of China" that equates Taiwan with the ROC.
Chen's expounding about national title and ideology is "meaningless, " according to the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Chen told a group of Formosa Foundation of the USA visitors that in 1912, the ROC was set up in China; in 1949, it moved to Taiwan; when Lee Teng-hui was the president, it was "the ROC on Taiwan;" since 2000, he said, when he himself became president, "the ROC is Taiwan."

To further make clear the sovereignty of Taiwan or the ROC, he repeated his syllogism: The ROC is a sovereign country; it's sovereignty belongs to Taiwan's 23 million people; only they have the right to change its future.

Pan Wei-kang, deputy secretary-general of the KMT legislative caucus, said theorizing about ideology does not help improve people's livelihoods and Chen should pay more attention to the economy, not this "meaningless" topic.
Wu Yang-chih, another caucus deputy secretary-general, agreed that taking good care of the people is more important than giving a long essay about national title and sovereignty.

"It is very clear fact that the ROC does not equal the PRC (People's Republic of China) and that the ROC has long enjoyed its own sovereignty. Therefore, President Chen's theorizing does not have any substantive meaning," Wu said.

Sun Ta-chien, deputy convener of the second-largest opposition People First Party (PFP), said any expounding on the nation's status must be based on the Constitution. "A politician should not make his personal interpretations in violation of the Constitution, " he added.

Sun said that if Chen were expressing his personal views, he and caucus members would respect them, but as a national leader, the president must be careful to say and do things in accordance with his oath to the Constitution.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) looked at the issue from a different perspective, claiming that Chen's "factual description" can help alleviate ethnic tension in Taiwan.

William C.T. Lai, secretary-general of the DPP legislative caucus, claimed that the president's "four stages" theory can satisfy people of all ages and ethnic groups and therefore will serve as a common ground to unite and integrate the nation's people.
A big problem for Taiwan is that different ethnic groups and historical backgrounds have led to different senses of identity, affecting domestic unity and national development, Lai said.

Ho Min-hao, convener of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union's legislative caucus, said the president's time would have been better used seeking a national consensus to write a new Constitution and change the country's national title.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH'S HOPE OF EARLY LIFTING OF DISEASE ALERT EVAPORATES

TEXT.P: With new cases of melioidosis reported Tuesday, the Department of Health's (DOH's) expectation of lifting an alert over the disease will have to be put off, according to health officials.

The remarks came in the wake of DOH reports of six new cases in Tainan City and Kaohsiung County. Among them, one victim came down July 28, and the alert will only be lifted Aug. 7 -- 10 days after the last reported case -- at the earliest.
Five of the six new cases are over 50, and one is 27, the youngest of all the victims reported so far.

Between July 11 and Aug. 2, 26 cases of melioidosis have been reported, seven of which have been fatal. Twenty-three out of the 26 cases live near the Er-jen creek that runs through Tainan and Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan.
Health officials suspect that the victims might have contracted the disease after recent flooding and ensuing pollution as a result of typhoon Haitang that hit Taiwan in mid-July.
They said that people with open wounds and weak immune systems are susceptible to the bacterium after touching flood debris, sewage and contaminated soil. They usually die of sepsis.
Health officials in Tainan said that with new cases reported, DOH Vice Minister Chen Tsai-chin promised to send experts there to help investigate the cause of he disease.
Although melioidosis is not a notifiable disease, people living near the Er-jen creek have become worried as to whether the bacteria is being transmitted through polluted water.

Melioidosis, also called Whitmore's disease, is an infectious disease caused by the burkholderia pseudomallei bacterium. It is predominately a disease of tropical climates, especially Southeast Asia, where it is endemic. The bacteria that causes melioidosis are found in contaminated water and soil and are spread to humans and animals through direct contact with the contaminated source.
As a new typhoon might strike Taiwan over the next few days, DOH officials have advised people to refrain from coming too close to polluted water or soil if they have open wounds.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS CONCERNED ABOUT CONTROL YUAN PLIGHT

TEXT.P: A group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators paid a visit to the Control Yuan Tuesday to express their concern about the supreme watchdog body's plight resulting mainly from political bickering.
The Control Yuan has not been functional since Feb. 1 because the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has refused to endorse President Chen Shui-bian's nominees for Control Yuan seats.

Control Yuan Secretary-General Tu Shan-liang told visiting DPP legislators that more than 10,000 petitions and political contribution cases have accumulated at the watchdog body since the previous ombudsmen finished their terms Jan. 31 this year.

Tu said those cases need to be addressed for the sake of protecting the rights of the public and he described the memberless Control Yuan as an "unprecedented strange phenomenon in the nation's constitutional history."

In response, DPP legislative whip Chao Yung-ching said the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party has long boasted of its claim that it defends the five-branch government system enshrined in the Constitution.

"The Control Yuan is an integral part of the five-branch central government to supervise the executive branch operations. It's hard to understand why the `pan-blue alliance' has boycotted the confirmation of the ombudsmen nominations. If opposition lawmakers see no need for the Control Yuan to exist, they should come up with a constitutional amendment bill for a rational debate instead of blocking discussion of the nomination list in the legislature," Chao said.

Speaking on the same occasion, William Lai, also a DPP legislative whip, said it is hoped that a planned Aug. 12 informal legislative meeting can reach a consensus on how to address the Control Yuan nomination issue.
If no consensus is reached at that meeting, Lai said he is afraid that the nomination list will remain permanently mired in uncertainty.

Chen first submitted the names of his nominees last November for the previous legislature's approval, but the opposition legislators refused to even screen the list, maintaining that most of the nominees were not up to the expectations of the public.

After the new legislature was inaugurated in February, the two "pan-blue alliance" parties, which continue to jointly control a slim majority in the legislature, asked Chen to submit a new list of nominees on the grounds that his original list was invalid in the new legislature. However, Chen resubmitted the same list, which the new opposition legislators also refused to screen.
Chen has refused to change his nominations, insisting that while opposition lawmakers can reject any of his nominees that they deem unsuitable, they should not completely refuse to screen the list.
Demanding that the president change his nominations encroaches on his right to nominate enshrined in the Constitution, a Presidential Office official said earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOWNSHIP SEEKS 30 OBESE VOLUNTEERS FOR WEIGHT-REDUCTION TESTS

TEXT.P: Kukeng township in Yunlin County is trying to recruit 30 obese volunteers to undergo tests to see whether green oranges grown in the township can help them shed some weight.

The township government announced Tuesday that the volunteers -- 15 men and 15 women -- will be given a recipe for making beverages using green oranges as the main ingredient. Examinations will be conducted after one month to see if the green oranges are effective in helping the volunteers lose weight.

A spokesman for the township government pointed out that green oranges are abundant during the harvest season from July to September. He claimed that freshly squeezed juice from green oranges, when mixed with yogurt, makes a delicious drink ideal for weight watchers.

Although the Department of Health has expressed doubts over the claims, the township still hopes to use the tests to prove the effects of the fruit in helping obese people to lose weight. Positive results from the tests could not only put an end to the dispute, but also help the township with fruit sales, the spokesman claimed.
He said that obese people who are interested in taking part in the tests can contact the township government or the Sanchi Organic Farm before Aug. 10.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Review Finds Iran Far From Nuclear Bomb; Estimate of Progress Contrasts With Administration Statements.
A major U.S. intelligence review has projected that Iran is about a decade away from manufacturing the key ingredient for a nuclear weapon, roughly doubling the previous estimate of five years, according to government sources with firsthand knowledge of the new analysis.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU OPPOSES PENGHU-CHINA LINKS

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) expressed categorical disagreement Tuesday with a government plan to allow direct shipping links between the island country of Penghu and China, citing concerns over national security.

TSU legislative whip Ho Min-hao told a news conference that the party is strongly opposed to the plan on the grounds that the current direct shipping and trade links between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and China -- popularly known as the "mini links" -- have turned out to be the prime channels for smuggling from China.

Stressing that the TSU will never agree to the government's plan until it has wiped out smuggling and criminal activities via the "mini links" and has held negotiations with China, Ho argued that Penghu's location will be more likely to invite infiltration from China should similar links be set up between the outlying island and China.

Penghu's location within the mid-line of the Taiwan Strait makes it easier than the remote islands of Kinmen and Matsu to be used by criminal elements or Chinese agents, Ho claimed, predicting that the government project will cause serious concerns to national security.
What the Penghu Island needs is greater investment to fully develop its economy and tourist industry, not simply make it a transit point in the Taiwan Strait for passing cargo ships, he claimed.

Premier Frank Hsieh said a day earlier during a visit to Penghu that the government is considering whether to permit the island to operate direct links with China on a trial basis, probably from September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DECLARES WAR AGAINST COUNTERFEITING

TEXT.P: The Cabinet carried out a publicity stunt Tuesday as a show of its determination to crack down on counterfeit discs and software, with Premier Frank Hsieh crushing 110,000 pirated CDs with aroad-roller.

Accompanied by Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh and Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin, Hsieh inspected a Ministry of Justice storehouse for fake discs in Taipei County and issued citations to outstanding law enforcement officials for their efforts in fighting counterfeiting.

Hsieh noted that the government has earmarked NT$10 billion (US$314 million) in recent years for the development of knowledge-based economy, and a fund of the Council for Economic Planning and Development will earmark another NT$20 billion next year for industries involved in digital content and culture.

According to Hsieh, among the 13,129 patent applications Taiwan people have filed in the United States in the last two years, more than 7,000 were approved, with the number of Taiwan patents approved in the U.S ranking third in that country, only behind those of Japan and Germany.

Meanwhile, Sung Hong-ti, chairwoman of the Business Software Alliance's Taiwan branch, said the counterfeiting problem in Taiwan has improved in recent years and claimed that the intellectual property rights infringement is now more of an Internet problem.
Sung urged the government to pay more heed to this type of IPR infringement.
Hsieh said that law enforcement officials will make war against counterfeiting their top priority and he warned the public not to be accomplices in crime by buying fake products.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'FOUR STAGES OF ROC' ENDANGERS CROSS-STRAIT STABILITY: KMT

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman criticized Tuesday President Chen Shui-bian's new theory of "four stages of the Republic of China" as a factor that will endanger cross-Taiwan Strait stability.
Chang Jung-kung claimed that Chen's new theory is a pro-independence one disguised with the Republic of China title.

Chen presented that day his theory, which separates the ROC into four stages, with the first in 1912, when the ROC was set up; the second in 1949, when the ROC moved to Taiwan; the third during former President Lee Teng-hui's term in which the country was called "ROC on Taiwan;" and the fourth stage since 2000, when Chen himself took power as president.

In an attempt to strengthen the public's ideas regarding the country's sovereignty and national identity, Chen announced his new theory and stressed that "ROC is Taiwan" has been the case since he assumed his post in 2000.

According to Chang, Chen's remarks were aimed at placating pro-independence groups that were extremely disappointed by Chen's recent remarks that it will be impossible to gain Taiwan independence during his tenure.
Noting that the ROC represents Taiwan proper and the outlying islands of Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu, Chang claimed that it should not serve as a cover for the Taiwan independence movement.
Chen's remarks will result in more efforts of the United States and China to prevent Taiwan's independence, which will limit ROC's development space in the world community, Chang speculated.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVAL, AIRBORNE FORCES TO CONDUCT COMBINED DRILL

TEXT.P: Naval and airborne forces will conduct a combined live-fire training drill in southern Taiwan waters Wednesday as part of the ongoing Hankuang 21 military exercises, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday.
"The drill is designed to test naval and airborne forces' combat prowess in counter-blockade, combined naval-aerial interception and air defense," MND spokesman Rear Adm. Liu Chih-chien said.
Defense Minister Lee Jye, who once served as navy commander-in-chief and as chief of the general staff, will review the whole training drill, Liu said.
According to Liu, the navy will play a key role in Wednesday's maneuvers, while the air force will play a supportive role.
"It'll be the most comprehensive naval drill in recent years. Many naval combat tactics and skills, including minesweeping, sea port counterblockade and naval-air defense, will be covered," Liu said.
As the live-fire training drill includes certain classified items, Liu said, foreign journalists will not be invited to cover the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA POST TO ISSUE SPECIAL STAMPS TO MARK ASIAN STAMP SHOW

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Post Co. will issue new stamps in connection with the 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition -- Taipei 2005 scheduled for Aug. 19-24 at the Taipei World Trade Center, a spokesman said Tuesday.

In addition to two sets of stamps featuring Taiwan's natural scenery and cultural heritage issued earlier this year, the spokesman said, Chunghwa Post will issue a third set featuring Taiwan's special flora and fauna species Aug. 19 to coincide with the opening of the show.
Between Aug. 20 and Aug. 24, the spokesman said, a specially designed set of stamps will also be issued each day.
The stamp exhibition is expected to attract 100,000 visitors, the spokesman said, adding that the event is part of the government's efforts to promote local tourism.

The indigenous Formosan black bear has been chosen in a public competition to serve as the event's mascot, while Taipei 101 -- the tallest building in the world -- has been designated to represent the event.
About 300 foreign stamp authorities, collectors and traders have registered to take part in the exhibition in which a total of 150 booths will display stamps from around the world.
Meanwhile, the Tourism Bureau and China Airlines will set up tourist information centers at the venue to coordinate a planned display of stamps concerning travel and tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUEL PRICE HIKES EXPECTED TO AFFECT ECONOMIC GROWTH: CEPD

TEXT.P: An increase in gasoline and diesel fuel prices announced separately by Formosa Petrochemical Corp. (FPC) and Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will make it more difficult for Taiwan to assure itself of 4 percent economic growth this year, a senior official of the Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Tuesday.

FPC announced that day that it would increase the wholesale prices of gasoline and diesel fuel by NT$1.5 per liter, with immediate effect. Hours later, the state-run CPC followed suit, also adding NT$1.5 per liter to the two kinds of fuel, representing a 7.6 percent increase, the highest in the past decade.

Thomas M.F. Yeh, vice chairman of the CEPD, said that according to estimates by Academia Sinica's Economic Research Institute, when the fuel prices increase 10 percent, the nation's economic rate will go down by 0.27 percent.
Yeh said the impact on the economic rate caused by the new price hikes, which became effective at 6 p.m. Tuesday, will be less than 0.27 percent.
Meanwhile, Economics Minister Ho Mei-yueh said the impact of the price hikes on the economy will be minimal.
She pointed out that CPC suffered an NT$800 million deficit in July because of international oil price hikes, which caused the price of crude to rise to US$60.09 per barrel in the past seven days.
Ho said that when informed of the price hikes, she and Premier Frank Hsieh respected the CPC's decision because the company is under financial strain.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN, TAIWAN AGREE IN ASSESSMENT OF CHINA'S MILITARY STRENGTH

TEXT.P: Japan's prediction that China will begin to prevail against Taiwan militarily from 2006 unless Taiwan engages in an aggressive military build-up is in full agreement with a forecast by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) , a ministry official said Tuesday.
Japan's prediction, carried in its 2005 National Defense White Paper, was published earlier that day in Tokyo.
The defense official, who asked to remain anonymous, said the MND has predicted that the military balance across the Taiwan Strait will begin to tilt in favor of China from 2006.

Citing an analysis conducted by the ministry, the official said the military imbalance between China and Taiwan will worsen to 1.46 to 1 in terms of combat power by 2012 even if the navy acquires much-needed Kidd-class destroyers.

Unless Taiwan builds up its military strength, this trend will continue until the gap between the two sides widens to 2.8 to 1, which will be really dangerous because it is widely believed that the offensive force is sure to win in an engagement when it commands a superior force ratio of 3 to 1 against the defense force.

In order to slow down the declining trend, the official said, the MND is trying to acquire NT$480 billion-worth of arms from the United States that will keep the power ratio between China and Taiwan at 1.67 to 1 between 2020 and 2035.

By keeping that ratio, China would not dare to embark on a military adventure against Taiwan because according to this theory, the offense will not succeed in an attack-to-seize operation with a force ratio below 2 to 1 and might suffer heavy losses.
The official said that is why Defense Minister Lee Jye claimed in the legislature that the proposed arms purchase will secure 30 years of peace for Taiwan.

He said his ministry is not surprised by Japan's prediction, but added that Taiwan is not the only country threatened by China's military buildup. All of China's neighbors should worry about China's exploding military spending, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 3, or the 29th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
216: An army led by Carthaginian General Hannibal defeats a huge Roman army, seizing its supply depot in the Battle of Cannae and killing some fifty thousand Roman soldiers.
1460: Scottish King James II is killed by the English during the siege of Roxburgh Castle.
1492: A flotilla of three ships, led by Christopher Columbus, sets sail from the Spanish port of Palos de la Frontera in search of a land called India.
1867: Stanley Baldwin, British Conservative prime minister three times between 1923 and 1937, is born.
1872: Haakon VII, Norwegian monarch who refused to surrender to the Germans in World War II, is born in Denmark.
1881: William George Fargo, American pioneer of long-distance express service, dies at his home in Buffalo, New York, at the age of 65.
1904: The Dalai Lama flees Lhasa as British troops invade Tibet. The Ching court on Aug. 26 orders the Pachen Lama to take over Tibetan affairs from the Dalai Lama.
1916: German troops launch a surprise attack on British forces in the Sinai in Egypt. Some 5,000 German soldiers are killed, while British loses amount to 1,100 men.
1929: Emile Berliner, German-born American inventor, dies in Washington D.C. at the age of 78. He greatly improved the telephone and invented the gramophone in 1887.
1940: Lithuania is formally incorporated into the Soviet Union as the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic.
1958: Nautilus, the U.S. atomic submarine, becomes the first vessel to reach the North Pole under the ice.
1959: Japan Airlines formally inaugurates its Tokyo-Taipei route.
1967: The ROC Executive Yuan decides to extend the period of compulsory education from six to nine years beginning in 1968.
1969: Minister of Economic Affairs K.T. Li (Li Kuo-ting) receives the 1968 Ramon Magsaysay Award for government service.
1972: Sheng Chin-lai is appointed dean of the Engineering College at Chiaotung University.
1972: Brig. Gen. William C. Buttows, new chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command, arrives in Taipei.
1973: The Flying Tiger Line inaugurates air freight services between Kaohsiung and New York.
1974: Economics Minister Y.S. Sun and Paraguayan Minister of Industry and Commerce D. Ugarte Centurionuan sign an agreement in Taipei to boost economic cooperation between the Republic of China and Paraguay.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives eight members of the U.S. 14th Air Force Association, including Mrs. Anna Chennault, widow of the 14th Air Force's commander, Maj. Gen. Claire Lee Chennault.
1977: A US$100 million loan agreement is signed in Taipei between the Taiwan Power Company and 17 banks from five foreign nations.
1981: President Ronald Reagan orders the firing of 12,000 striking air traffic control workers.
1986: Construction of the Synchronous Radiation Research Center under the Executive Yuan is started at the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park. It is scheduled for completion within five to six years.
1988: Mathias Rust, a West German youth who landed his light air plane near Moscow's Red Square in 1987, is released from prison and expelled from the Soviet Union.
1999: Nine renowned scientists and former intelligence and military officials send a letter to all 100 U.S. senators calling for the prompt ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to prevent the weaponization of stolen nuclear secrets by Communist China.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian directs the ROC Air Force to draw up a forward-looking blueprint for developing a new generation of warplanes to ensure supremacy in the skies over the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By extending the powers of their functions and allowing them discretion in the employment of their subordinates: that is how a ruler gives encouragement to the high ministers of state."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LIFTS BAN ON AIRCRAFT FLYING OVER CHINA'S AIRSPACE

TEXT.P: The government has decided to lift the ban on Taiwan commercial aircraft flying over China's airspace, Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday.
Taiwan carriers will now be allowed to fly over China's airspace to save fuel costs and reduce travel times, the premier said at a weekly Cabinet meeting.
"Hopefully, China can approve our air carriers' applications for flyovers as soon as possible," Hsieh said.

If China approves Taiwan carriers' applications, Hsieh said it will be a boon to both passengers and airline operators because the flying times from Taiwan to South Asia, the Middle East and Europe will be greatly reduced.
"The decision to remove the decades-old flyover ban was made out of consideration of helping carriers cut costs amid the current upward spiral in international crude oil prices," Hsieh said.
Meanwhile, Hsieh said the government has agreed to simultaneous negotiations for the opening of passenger, cargo and special-purpose charter flights across the Taiwan Strait.

As August is traditionally an export boom season, Hsieh said he has directed the Mainland Affairs Council and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to speed up contacts and negotiations with China on the opening of cross-strait cargo charter flights.

China has insisted that issues regarding the opening of cross-strait passenger charter flights should be discussed simultaneously. After a careful review, Hsieh said, the government has agreed to China's proposal.
As China refuses for political reasons to engage in direct contact with Taiwan's government, the latter has commissioned the Taipei Airline Association to mediate charter flight negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEA WARNING ISSUED FOR TYPHOON MATSA

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea warning for Typhoon Matsa at 8:30 a.m. Wednesday.
CWB meteorologists said a land warning could be issued later in the day.

As of 11 a.m. Wednesday, Typhoon Matsa was located 560 km south-southeast of Oluanpi, the southern tip of Taiwan, moving in a northwest direction at a speed at 15 km per hour, with maximum wind speeds of 126 km per hour, they reported.
They said that Typhoon Matsa could shift to a northern direction, although there is still a chance that Taiwan proper could be affected by the typhoon.
Vessels operating in waters off northern, northeastern and southeastern Taiwan and in the Bashi Channel should be on guard against the typhoon, the meteorologists said.

Meanwhile, despite the issuing of the sea warning, a total of nearly 1,000 tourists headed by ferry to Green Island or Orchid Island Wednesday morning. Many said they were traveling to the islands to experience the excitement of being near the eye of the storm.

In the past, Fukang Harbor in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, closed when a sea warning was issued. However, last month, many tourists were stranded on the two islands after a sea warning was issued for Typhoon Haitang despite the fact that waves weren't very large.
Ferry companies have since coordinated with Hualien Harbor Bureau, and the companies have been given leeway to decide whether to continue operating when a sea warning is issued.
The ferry companies said they will suspend services if and when a land warning is issued.

Meanwhile, the Mount Ali forest train in Chiayi, southern Taiwan continued operations as usual Wednesday. A decision on whether to suspend services will be made Thursday based on the weather conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOINT NAVY-AIR FORCE EXERCISE LAUNCHED OFF KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Anti-blockade, air raid and combined operations for intercepting enemy attacks will be featured in a joint navy-air force exercise, part of the annual Han Kuang No. 21 exercises, that was launched off Tsoying in southern Kaohsiung City Tuesday.
Defense Minister Lee Jye will inspect part of the process, which will see the most comprehensive naval demonstration of its combat capability in recent years, military sources said.
Participants will show off their mine detonation ability for the first time in an emulation of sinking invading landing craft.
Naval ships will also fire live torpedoes against enemy frigates, according to the sources.
In addition, S-2T anti-submarine aircraft will fire depth charges to contain enemy naval offensives. The aircraft will be joined by F-16 fighters, which will fire live ammunition at enemy targets.
Military spokesman Liu Chih-chien said the navy will be the main player in the exercise, with Cheng Kung-class, Kang Ting-class, Chin Chiang-class and Chi Yang-class ships taking part.
The ships will participate in joint operations to crush enemy efforts to seal off ports with mines, depth charges and live ammunition firing at sea and air targets.
The goal of the drill is to test the joint combat capability of the navy and air force both in terms of defense and offense.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS POSITIVE ABOUT ALLOWING TAIWAN AIRCRAFT TO FLY OVER CHINA

TEXT.P: Legislators across the party spectrum were positive Tuesday about Premier Frank Hsieh's announcement of the lifting of a ban on Taiwan commercial aircraft flying over China's airspace, with one opposition party saying that this should have been done earlier.

Hsieh said Taiwan carriers will now be allowed to fly over China's airspace to save fuel costs and reduce travel times, hoping at the same time that China will approve Taiwan air carriers' applications for overflights.

The premier also said the government has agreed to simultaneous negotiations for the opening of passenger, cargo and special-purpose charter flights across the Taiwan Strait, hoping for early consultations with China.

Chen Chin-jun, a caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive party at the Legislative Yuan, said that instead of being passive, the premier has taken the initiative to agree to the lifting of the ban, which he said is a "very good thing, " expressing the hope that China will also embark on cross-strait government-to-government talks on passenger, cargo and special-purpose charter flights.
He noted that China has always been more interested in passenger than cargo charter flights, but in fact, there is also strong demand for cross-strait cargo charter flights.
The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said the party is happy to see the announcement that will benefit the public.
KMT Legislator Pan Wei-kang, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, expressed hope that the government will deliver on its promise.
President Chen Shui-bian should also explain whether he supports the policy, she added.
The People First Party (PFP) legislative caucus said the ban on Taiwan aircraft flying over China's airspace should have been lifted a long time ago.

Huang Yi-chiao, a PFP whip in the legislature, said that lifting the ban is a step in the right direction, although he said he did not know if this policy also represents Chen's stance, claiming that DPP policy "only counts" with the endorsement of the president.

Ho Min-hao, a caucus whip of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the DPP, said his party is in favor of early cross-strait consultation with China if the talks are based on the principles of equality, mutual benefit, dignity, insistence on the stance of Taiwan sovereignty, and the premise that cross-strait charter flights are considered international flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 112.03 points to close at 6,455.57, thanks to the strong rise of the electronic shares.
The bourse opened at 6,391.68 and fluctuated between 6,455.57 and 6,379.51 during trading. A total of 4.03 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$107.05 billion (US$3.36 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics stocks moving up the most at 2.5 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.4 percent, construction shares at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks at 1.0 percent, paper and pulp shares at 0.8 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent, and textiles and foodstuffs both at 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 674 to 186, with 134 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER THANKS JAPAN FOR PERMANENT VISA-FREE TREATMENT FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh thanked Japan Wednesday for the visa-free privileges approved a day earlier by the lower house of its parliament for Taiwan tourists from Sept. 26.
Hsieh called it a goodwill gesture toward Taiwan and expressed the hope that the bill will soon clear the Diet's upper house.

The move is expected to help bring at least 1.3 million tourists from Taiwan to Japan in 2004, a 30-percent growth over the 2004 level, officials of the Japan National Tourist Organization (JNTO) said, noting that 583,773 Taiwan people visited Japan in the first half of this year, up by 12.5 percent year-on-year.
Taiwan people made the second-largest number of visits to Japan last year behind only visitors from South Korea, but they were Japan's No. 1 source of tourist arrivals, JNTO official said.

According to a JNTO investigation, Taiwan tourists are attracted by Japan's beautiful and clean cities as well as the country's historic and cultural relics. Some 94 percent of Taiwan visitors said they would be willing to visit Japan again, although a large ratio also complained of Japan's high prices.

Meanwhile, Taiwan aviation companies were also upbeat about the news, saying that they are capable of transporting more Taiwan tourists to Japan now that a restriction on charter flight numbers from Taiwan to Japan has been lifted with the renewal of an aviation agreement between the two countries last year.
Taiwan-based carriers now operate regular charter flights to Tokyo, Nagoya, Osaka, Fukuoka and Sapporo.
Hsiao Bi-khim, a lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, claimed that Japan is more willing to engage with Taiwan in the face of a rising China.
Overall relations between Taiwan and Japan are quite benign for the time being despite recent fishery disputes, she pointed out.
