New York Times: Court Nominee Prizes 'Modesty,' He Tells the Senate
Judge John G. Roberts Jr. told the U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday that judges must possess " a degree of modesty and humility, " must be respectful of legal precedent and must be willing to change their minds. In his first written response to questions from the lawmakers who will review his nomination to the Supreme Court, Roberts said he places a high emphasis on "'modesty" and "stability." The nominee seeks to cast himself as a proponent of judicial restraint, a quality prized by senators at a time when conservative critics of the judiciary are bemoaning activist judges.
Wall Street Journal: Oil Politics, Cnooc Drops Offer for Unocal, Exposing U.S.-Chinese Tensions
China's Cnooc Ltd. abandoned its effort to acquire U.S. oil producer Unocal Corp., a retreat that exposes both rising Sino-American tensions and the growing pains Chinese companies face as they try to expand in the global marketplace. In reaching for Unocal, Cnooc -- considered one of China's most modern and Western-minded companies -- showed its relative inexperience in the world of Wall Street and Washington, with some strategic and political stumbles. But Cnooc also got caught up in anti-Chinese sentiment over some very different issues, ranging from textile trade to intellectual property to military spending.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF'S SON CALLS FATHER A 'TRAGIC HERO'

TEXT.P: The son of outgoing opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Tuesday that his father is "a tragic hero" whose differences from other political party leaders "can only be known when he is leaving."

Lien Sheng-wen, a newly elected delegate to the upcoming KMT convention that will see his father hand over the leadership to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, made the remarks while running for a seat on the main opposition party's Central Committee.

Commenting on his father, who will step down Aug. 19, Lien claimed that his father was the KMT chairman during its "most difficult time" of frustration and failure, and yet "fought to the last moment."
Lien said he believes the KMT will continue to dig into "the truth" behind the March 19, 2004 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu and "seek justice."
Lien Chan was defeated for the second time by Chen Shui-bian in the 2004 presidential election, a campaign that the opposition claims it lost partly because of the shooting.

During a media interview earlier in the week, Lien Chan said he was quite proud of two major legacies he will leave behind: building what he described as a "cross-Taiwan Strait bridge for peace and security;" and endorsing the first-ever direct election of party chairman.
Lien advised his successor to "be broad-minded, make as many friends as possible, steadily reform the party and do whatever should be done."
As a result of his historic visit to China last April, Lien claimed, he has "built a bridge and a road toward cross-strait peace" and whether or not to step on it is completely up to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WANTS CROSS-STRAIT CARGO CHARTER FLIGHTS TO TAKE OFF FIRST

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Wednesday it looks forward to an early start to direct cargo charter flights across the Taiwan Strait.

"While we agree to simultaneous negotiations for opening direct cross-strait passenger, cargo and special-purpose charter flights, we want cargo charter flights to be opened first, " said an MAC official who preferred anonymity.

The official made the remarks after Premier Frank Hsieh announced earlier in the day that the government has decided to lift the ban on Taiwan commercial aircraft flying over China's airspace and agreed to simultaneous negotiations for cross-strait cargo and passenger charter flights.
According to the council, the two major policy initiatives were adopted after extensive discussions with the National Security Council.

In addition to benefiting people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the official said, the two measures are also expected to convey a goodwill message to China and help improve cross-strait relations.

The decision to remove the decades-old flyover ban was made out of consideration of helping carriers cut costs amid the current upward spiral in international crude oil prices, the official said, adding that the flying times to South Asia, the Middle East and Europe will also be greatly reduced.
"If China approves our carriers' flyover applications, it will be a boon to both passengers and airline operators because the travel times and fuel costs will all be cut," the official said.
Industry sources said local carriers can each save an estimated NT$100 million in fuel costs annually if they are allowed to fly over China's airspace.

As to the opening of cross-strait charter flights, Taiwan has expressed an interest in negotiating cargo charter flights, but China is only willing to negotiate the passenger charter flights issue. As a result, no progress has been made in this regard following the smooth conclusion of special Chinese New Year charter flights for Taiwan businessmen operating in China in late January and early February this year.

With a view to pushing for an early realization of cross-strait cargo charter flights to benefit the business community, the official said the government is now advocating simultaneous negotiations for cargo and passenger charter flights.
Hopefully, the official said, China will agree to this proposal so that intermediary bodies on both sides can enter into negotiations soon.
As China refuses for political reasons to engage in direct contact with the government on Taiwan, the MAC has commissioned the Taipei Airline Association to mediate charter flight negotiations.
The official explained that the change in the government's attitude was prompted partly by a recent step forward in talks regarding allowing Chinese citizens to visit Taiwan for sightseeing purposes.
"Once the two sides finally come to term to allow Chinese citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan, there should be a market demand for cross-strait passenger charter flights," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER 'COMFORT WOMEN' TO JOIN ACTIVITIES MARKING JAPAN'S WWII DEFEAT

TEXT.P: About 30 former "comfort women, " who were forced by the Japanese government to serve as sex slaves to Japanese troops during the Second World War, will join in activities in Taiwan marking the 60th anniversary of Japan's defeat.

Wearing masks, these former comfort women, most of whom are now in their 80's, will appear in the streets of Taipei on Aug. 15, -- the anniversary of Japan's surrender to the Allied forces -- to show the world the suffering Japan forced them to endure.

A series of activities will begin from Aug. 10 throughout Taiwan until Aug. 15, including exhibitions of wartime documents and pictures in Taipei, Kaohsiung and other cities. The exhibition in Kaohsiung City will last three months.

Ninety pictures of former comfort women, each measuring 1.6 meters in length and width, and a giant mosaic picture simulating the aged face of a former comfort woman, will be put on display in two of Taipei's busiest movie streets. The mosaic picture is made with several thousand smaller photos of comfort women by photographer-artist Huang Tse-ming.
The Council for Cultural Affairs under the Cabinet will hold a discussion session in Kaohsiung on the War of Resistance Against Japanese Aggression.
The motion picture library in Kaohsiung will hold a weeklong movie festival, showing films featuring the Second World War as the theme.

During the war years, Japan forced tens of thousands of young women from South Korea, China, Taiwan, the Philippines and other Asian countries to serve as sex slaves for the Japanese troops. Of the some 2,000 comfort women from Taiwan, only about 30 are still living.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA, TAIWAN'S 2ND-LARGEST FARM EXPORT MARKET IN FIRST HALF: DGBAS

TEXT.P: China and Hong Kong together imported farm products worth US$440 million from Taiwan in the first half of this year, making it Taiwan's second-largest farm export market, according to the latest government tallies.
The statistics released Tuesday by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that the figure marks an impressive annual growth rate of 7.9 percent.

Japan was the top importer of Taiwan's agricultural goods in the same six-month period, purchasing US$620 million worth of farm produce, reflecting a 0.7 percent increase rate year on year. The United States was the third with a value of US$180 million, a 1.6 percent expansion on an annual basis.

The United States exported the highest value of farm products, worth US$1.48 billion, to Taiwan in the first six months, ahead of Australia and Japan in second place, each of which sold US$350 million worth of farm produce to Taiwan.

Taiwan's farm trade totaled US$6.52 billion in the first half of this year, growing by 4.3 percent compared to the previous year's level. Exports and imports hit US$1.79 billion and US$4.73 billion, respectively, up by 5.2 percent and down by 3.9 percent, respectively, from the previous year's level.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISING OIL PRICES DRAGGING DOWN TAIWAN'S ECONOMY: CEPD

TEXT.P: The continued rise of international crude oil prices is poised to negatively impact Taiwan's economy, as 99 percent of the island's oil supplies are imported, a Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) official said Wednesday.
Hung Juei-pin, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, made the remarks in a report on the country's economic situation in the first half.

According to an estimate by U.S. Global Insight, Inc. in July, the global economy will see a 3.2 percent growth in the second half of this year due to the strong economic momentum in North America and Asia ( except Japan) , with the United States expected to register growth of 3.6 percent and Asian countries an average of 6.4 percent.

The CEPD predicted in May that Taiwan's economy may grow by 3.07 percent and more than 4 percent in the first and second half of this year with the growth for the whole year expected to register 3.63 percent.

The report also showed that Taiwan's foreign trade grew at a slower pace in the first half, with exports and imports increasing by 6.8 percent and 11.5 percent, respectively, over the same period of last year.
In June, exports and imports grew only by 3.1 percent and 2.5 percent, respectively, over the same month of last year.
Cumulatively, Taiwan's trade surplus was US$420 million in the first half of this year, a decrease of 89.1 percent over the same period of 2004.
Taiwan's exports to six ASEAN countries increased the most at 14.8 percent in the first half of this year, while its exports to Europe posted a negative growth for the same period.

China, including Hong Kong, and Japan were the main source of Taiwan's imports, with the island's imports from the two countries registering an annual growth of 21.2 percent and 14.4 percent, respectively.

Considering the soaring oil prices and Taiwan's heavy dependence on oil imports, the CEPD official urged related agencies to draw up strategies to ensure that the country has a stable oil supply in the long run and strengthen the implementation of its energy-saving policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMOTION OF CROSS-STRAIT LINKS IS GOVERNMENT'S JOB: DPP CAUCUS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday that the establishment of direct cross-Taiwan Strait trade, postal and transportation links should be coordinated by the government and that the opposition parties should not interfere.

Chen Chin-jun, a DPP legislative caucus whip, was responding to the opposition People First Party (PFP) after it said it will push for legislation on direct cross-strait links in the next legislative session.
Chen said President Chen Shui-bian is not opposed to cross-strait links but that he wants cross-strait consultation to be based on equality, dignity and security in line with international practice.

Chen also said cross-strait links should be in the national interests and that the routes should not be downgraded to the level of a domestic route. He also said that the executive and legislative arms of the government should have their respective duties and that the opposition parties should not use their slight majority in the legislature to try to dominate executive power.

Huang Yi-chiao, a PFP legislative whip, said in a press conference that the caucus will make promotion of direct cross-strait links, targeting government corruption and incompetence, as well as revitalizing financial discipline priorities in the next legislative session.

Huang said that several multi-national enterprises are preparing to move their research and development centers from Taiwan to China, which he claimed shows the coming trend. Taiwan has seen itself marginalized and its competitive's edge weakened since the DPP came to power five years ago, he claimed.

He said direct cross-strait links are under the authority of the Executive Yuan, but added that if the government does not set them up and Taiwan businessmen's' operating costs increase as a result, then the PFP caucus will not rule out the possibility of trying to revise the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, and return the relevant authority to the Legislative Yuan.
Huang said the PFP caucus would then coordinate with the opposition Kuomintang and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union to implement the cross-strait direct links.

Huang also said that if the president does not change his list of members of the Control Yuan, the nation's top watchdog agency, and if the government insists on financing an arms procurement package with a special budget, then his caucus will continue to oppose to the two controversial proposals.
Huang said that the list is unacceptable and that if the president does not change it, the party will not confirm the members.

On the procurement of eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, Huang said that he and PFP Chairman James Soong met with U.S. figures during visits to the United States who did not request that Taiwan finance the procurement through a special budget or say that Taiwan should take responsibility if the deal does not go through.
He said that if what he claimed is a "great majority" of people was not opposed to special budget to finance the arms procurement, the PFP would never oppose it.
Chen replied that the opposition parties should at least put the arms procurement proposal to committee review.

The "pan-blue alliance " of the KMT and the PFP, which has a slight majority in the Legislative Yuan, has blocked the special budget proposal for the arms procurement since the Executive Yuan first submitted it in June 2004. The opposition parties believe the price tag is too high and that it should be included in the annual budget rather than a special budget.

On the refusal to confirm the Control Yuan members, Chen also said the legislators should confirm or veto the proposed members under the Constitution and should not simply ignore the list completely and demand that the president change it, thereby stripping the president of his right of nomination.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WELCOMES TAIPEI PROPOSAL FOR DIRECT CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By Chen-yi Liao and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council welcomed a proposal Tuesday by Taiwan to start negotiations over opening direct charter passenger and cargo flights across the Taiwan Strait.

The council reiterated Beijing's policy of promoting direct air and sea links with Taiwan, noting that China is willing to "do its utmost" for anything that is in the interest of the people of Taiwan, that helps promote cross-strait exchanges, and that helps maintain peace in the area.
The council was responding to media questions concerning ROC Premier Frank Hsieh's offer to negotiate cross-strait direct charter passenger and cargo flights.
Hsieh also announced a decision to lift the nation's ban on Taiwan's commercial aircraft flying over Chinese airspace, but the council did not comment on that.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROCEDURE FOR CHINA OVERFLIGHTS TO BE SET UP SOON

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) will complete the mapping out of procedures concerning Taiwan commercial aircraft overflights of Chinese airspace in a few days, the ministry head said Wednesday.

Vice Transportation and Communications Minister Chou Li-liang said that as the overflights will involve cross-Taiwan Strait issues, the ministry will wait for directions from the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and complete related procedures in three days before submitting them to the Executive Yuan for approval.
After approval by the Executive Yuan, the Civil Aeronautics Administration can accept applications from Taiwan carriers to make the flights, Chou said.
His words followed Premier Frank Hsieh's announcement earlier in the day that the government has decided to lift a ban on Taiwan commercial aircraft overflying China's airspace.
Taiwan carriers will now be allowed to fly over China's airspace to save fuel costs and reduce travel times, the premier said at a weekly Cabinet meeting.
Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Billy Chang said that in line with international practice, Taiwan carriers must submit flight route applications that must be approved by the CAA.
However, the carriers also have to apply to the Chinese authorities, and Chou said the MOTC hopes that China will agree to the overflights.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO PUT CROSS-STRAIT DIRECT LINKS ON LEGISLATIVE AGENDA

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party's (PFP) legislative caucus announced Wednesday its three top missions in the upcoming legislative session which will open in September: promoting the ' three links, " keeping the government honest and keeping it financially disciplined.

PFP caucus convener Hwang Yi-chiao said that after years of rule by the Democratic Progressive Party, Taiwan's international competitive edge has being eroded, citing as an example the trend of international enterprises relocating their offices in Taiwan to China.

As long as the government keeps its ban on direct cross-Taiwan Strait links, Taiwan businesses cannot enjoy predominance in the giant Chinese market due to the burden of transportation costs, the lawmaker said.

Given this, he said, his party will promote an amendment to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area to allow the legislature to map out how the opening of the "three links" can be accomplished.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD TO PROTECT TAIWAN FISHERMEN IN NORTH PACIFIC

TEXT.P: A coast guard patrol vessel will leave Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan Thursday for a three-month patrol mission in the North Pacific, the Coast Guard Administration said Wednesday.

The vessel, the "Hsunhu No. 2" will police the vast expanse of waters between 40 to 45 degrees north latitude and between 145 degrees east longitude and 165 degrees west longitude during the three-month period, CGA officials said.

The vessel will maintain order for Taiwanese fishing boats operating in the area and offer emergency rescue and relief aid, the officials said, adding that the "Hsunhu No. 2" is scheduled to return to Kaohsiung Nov. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEADER BLASTS GOV'T DECISION TO SHUT DOWN 7 CABLE TV CHANNELS

TEXT.P: The leader of Taiwan's largest opposition party Wednesday termed the government's decision to revoke the licenses of seven cable TV channels as "the greatest blemish" on Taiwan's history of democracy and freedom.

Presiding over a meeting of the Kuomintang (KMT) Central Standing Committee, KMT Chairman Lien Chan pointed out that President Chen Shui-bian has made the famous remarks that if he has to choose between freedom of the press and national security, he would rather choose the former.

Lien said that the president should put his words into action. The KMT leader, who will hand over the chairmanship to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, the chairman-elect, on Aug. 19, urged the party caucuses in the Legislative Yuan to pass legislation for the establishment of a National Communications Commission when the legislature opens its next session in September.

Late last Sunday, the Government Information Office (GIO), following the recommendations of a review committee, gave a 48-hour notice to seven cable TV channels to shut down permanently. The other channels whose licenses were renewed can continue operations for the next six years.
Among the channels that failed to have their licenses renewed were a news channel of the Eastern Multimedia Group and a movie channel.

The GIO decision triggered strong protests from the owners of the seven TV channels, as well as criticisms from the opposition parties and Taiwan's news media, blaming similar actions against the media by the Democratic Progressive Party-led government for the significant drop of Taiwan's global ranking in terms of press freedom in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER DEPLORES SHORTAGE OF FOREIGN NEWS IN TAIWAN MEDIA

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng said Tuesday that judging from the striking shortage of international news in local media, Taiwan seems to be locking itself out of the world.

Politically, Taiwan is already shut out by the United Nations and the media seems to be trying to lock the people inside the island, he said, warning that this poses a great danger to the development of the nation.
Tu was speaking at a ministry meeting in which he awarded Professor Tsai Mao-feng of Soochow University for his contributions in promoting Japanese language teaching in Taiwan.
Tu said if you read the newspapers or watch TV in Taiwan, "there is so little international news" that the people seem to be shutting their eyes to the outside world.

The minister happened to be echoing an observation by Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, who said after visiting Taiwan last year that Taiwan's political and media elite were focusing too much attention on domestic issues while ignoring what was happening outside of their country.
Tu said internationalization is critical to Taiwan's development, and to achieve that, foreign language education is an important step.
He said his ministry will choose several schools for a special program to improve foreign language education in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER'S DEFICIT TO RISE DUE TO HIKE IN OIL AND GAS PRICES

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) will suffer a deficit of NT$4.7 billion (US$147 million) this year after a rise in the price of oil and natural gas announced by the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) Tuesday, a Taipower official said Wednesday.

The state-run CPC announced an increase of 7.64 percent and 2.99 percent for the prices of its fuel oil and natural gas Tuesday to reflect soaring international crude oil prices. The move was several hours after a price hike made by the privately-owned Formosa Petrochemical Corp. earlier that day.
Taipower officials noted that the price hikes for fuel oil and natural gas will increase the cost of electricity generation by NT$1.6 billion for the company from August to December.
Taipower originally estimated that it may suffer a deficit of NT$3.1 billion this year.

Noting that Taipower's deficit will be inevitable this year due to the promise made by Premier Frank Hsieh that electricity prices will not be increased before autumn, the official urged domestic energy suppliers to take the interest of the general public into consideration before raising fuel price.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' NOT TO TRY TO DEBASE GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: A legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the opposition "pan-blue alliance" Wednesday not to try to debase the government.

Legislator William Lai made the call after the legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said earlier in the day that it will push for amendments to the existing statute governing relations across the Taiwan Strait to allow for the Legislative Yuan to map out how direct cross-strait trade, postal and transport links can be accomplished.

The PFP said it will also push for a freeze on the Government Information Office budget related to communications affairs before the establishment of the long-planned National Communications Commission.
The PFP and its "pan-blue alliance" ally of the Kuomintang (KMT) jointly control a slim majority in the legislature.

Lai said he has been worried that the "pan-blue alliance" could use their clout in the legislature to debase the DPP administration since KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong made separate visits to China between late April and early May. Both Lien and Soong met with Chinese President Hu Jintao, who concurrently heads the Communist Party of China, and reached consensus on strengthening cooperation among their parties.
Lai said the DPP administration is not opposed to the opening of direct cross-strait "three links" but it wants cross-strait engagements to be based on an equal footing.
Stressing that cross-strait links should be in the national interest, Lai said cross-strait shipping and air routes should not be downgraded to the level of domestic ones.

Lai also urged the "pan-blue alliance" to respect the five-branch government system enshrined in the Constitution and refrain from abusing their clout in the legislature to try to usurp executive power.

"The executive and legislative arms of the government have their respective duties. The opposition legislators should not try to encroach on the executive power. Otherwise, it could cause a constitutional crisis and national interests could be at stake, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROWING WARY OF ILLEGAL CHINESE ELEMENTS, CROSS-STRAIT CRIME

TEXT.P: Taiwan is increasingly growing wary of more and more illegal elements from China, promoting law enforcement agencies to consider imposing stricter punishments on human traffickers across the Taiwan Strait in the hope of clamping down on crimes in Taiwan.

Vice Minister of Justice Tang Chin-chuan told a news conference late last month that his ministry is mulling revising the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, focusing on severer legal punishments on cross-strait human cargo brokers.
But Tang did not elaborate on concrete details as to how rules will be revised and to what extent.

According to the 79th provision of the statute, those convicted of brokering Chinese to enter Taiwan or vice versa will be sentenced from one year to seven in jail and fined up to NT$1 million (US$31,250).

Due to the lack of a set of judiciary cooperative mechanisms between the two sides, more and more criminals in China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau have ganged up and committed crimes such as human smuggling, drug trafficking, fraud, money laundering and kidnapping, police said.

Cooperation between local criminals and accomplices offshore has become more and more common in recent years as a result of frequent cross-strait exchanges, posing serious risks to personal safety and social order on both sides, police said.

Two-way cooperation is critical to fighting cross-strait crimes, but political strife has hindered joint efforts, police said, pointing out that this has been the root cause behind the rampant illegal activities.

In addition, Ministry of Justice officials said, Chinese hackers also have intensified attacks against Taiwan-based Web sites in all sectors, making organized Internet crime a major concern to Taiwan authorities.
Although the Chinese public security authorities have set up a Internet-monitoring task force in Hubei province, ministry officials said that results remain to be seen.

Since early this year, Chinese hackers have systematically intruded into Taiwan's and Japan's Web sites because of various different issues, they pointed out, describing them as the leading troublemakers in cyberspace.

In contrast to China's reluctance to cooperate in wiping out Internet crime, Taiwan has been very active in assisting in such cases, the officials said, adding that in 2003, the Ministry of Justice received 32 requests for assistance filed by foreign countries and helped in 25.

In a meeting held last year in Taipei, U.S. officials from the Internet crime fighting unit under the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum (APEC) praised Taiwan's outstanding contribution in this regard and called for concerted moves by APEC member states to prevent computer crime as soon as possible, they said.

Meanwhile, officials of the ministry's Department of Prosecutorial Affairs are very likely to be invited to jointly take part in writing the APEC-sponsored "Digital Evidence Model Law" along with officials from member states such as Canada and South Korea, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 4 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, August 4:
09:00, President Chen Shui-bian will inspect the dredging work of the Tali Creek in Taichung County.
09:00, The Examination Yuan will hold its regular meeting of its members.
10:10, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the Central Taiwan Information Exhibition at the International Trade Center in Taichung City.
11:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will give an exclusive interview to CNA at the Executive Yuan.
11:00, The Fair Trade Commission will hold a news conference.
12:00, The National Science Council will hold a news conference.
14:30, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend a Physics Exhibition at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at its Taipei headquarters.
17:30, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at its headquarters in Panchiao, Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATE SEF CHAIRMAN'S FAMILY FIGHT ALLEGATIONS KOO PAID OFF A MISTRESS

TEXT.P: The children of Koo Cheng-fu, the late chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and a business tycoon, appealed to the court Wednesday to provisionally impound the apartment of a woman who claims to be Koo's former mistress as a step proceeding legal action against the woman.

A lawyer for Koo's three daughters and one son led court clerks to post stickers on the door of the apartment of the woman, Teng Hsiang-mei, 65, in Neihu, Taipei City, to indicate that it was being designated as potential collateral to a damage claim to be filed by the Koos in court against her on the ground that she defamed their father by claiming that her adult daughter, Chang Yi-hua, was fathered by him 40 years ago.

In order to dispute Tang's claim, Koo's youngest daughter, Koo Huai-ju, went to the forensic laboratory of the Criminal Investigation Bureau Wednesday to provide a DNA sample and challenged Teng and her daughter to do the same to verify their claim.

Teng and her daughter refused the request, claiming at a news conference Wednesday that the Koos have to agree in writing first that Chang will be given her share of Koo Chen-fu's property as an heir once the DNA test confirms she is Koo Chen-fu's daughter out of wedlock.
Teng claimed that her brief affair with Koo Chen-fu took place 40 years ago and ended because of Koo's concerns over his wife's feelings.

However, Teng claimed that Koo Chen-fu began to pay money to her and her daughter every month beginning in 1994 and bought them the Neihu apartment when they were in financial difficulty and asked Koo for help.
The alleged affair came to light after Koo Chen-fu died on Jan. 3 this year at the age of 88 and his family stopped the payments to Teng.

Koo's children claim the money was paid by their late elder brother, Koo Chi-yeng, who bought the apartment for Teng without the knowledge of Koo Chen-fu; therefore, the purchase was not an implicit admission of Koo Chen-fu to Teng's claims. On the contrary, they said, Koo Chen-fu denied the alleged affair during his life.

Koo's children said their elder brother paid Teng the money simply to silence her from airing her stories when Koo Cheng-fu was serving as the country's chief negotiator with China in his capacity as SEF chairman.
Branding Teng as a cunning blackmailer, they vowed to clear their father's reputation through court action and demanded the return of about NT$100 million allegedly paid by their brother to Teng.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS TAIWAN'S ACHIEVEMENT IN SCIENTIFIC OLYMPIADS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that Taiwan students' achievements in various scientific Olympiads this year has made the country proud.
Chen made the remarks while meeting a group of outstanding students who excelled in the 45th National Science Exhibition this year.

Taiwan delegations won two gold medals and two silvers in this year's International Biology Olympiad, gaining the world championship in the International Physics Olympiad 2005 in group and individual categories, and winning two gold medals and two silvers in the International Chemistry Olympiad 2005.

Chen noted that the government has been actively nurturing excellent scientific experts during recent years, and the National Science Exhibition will serve as the best venue for the students to exchange ideas.
He urged the young students to continue pursuing their excellence in science and make greater contributions to the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 4, or the 30th day of the sixth month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1578: The Portuguese King Sebastian and his court are killed in a failed crusade to Morocco.
1875: Hans Christian Anderson, Danish writer famous the world over for his fairy tales and stories, including "The Princess and the Pea" and "The Ugly Duckling," dies in Copenhagen at the age of 70.
1906: The Education Ministry of the Ching court promulgates a set of "regulations on education for women" governing the establishment of schools for women.
1914: World War I breaks out when German troops invade Belgium. Britain declares war on Germany as the United States declares its neutrality.
1916: Denmark sells the Danish Virgin Islands to the United States for US$25 million.
1922: Fighting breaks out in Italy between the fascists and the socialists.
1938: The Nationalist government moves its offices from Wuchang and Hankow to Chungking in order to cope with the lengthy War of Resistance Against Japan.
1940: Italian troops invade the country of British Somaliland in East Africa.
1942: David Russel Lange, New Zealand Labor politician, is born. He served as prime minister from 1984 to 1989 and was controversial for his refusal to allow nuclear-armed ships to dock in New Zealand.
1944: Anne Frank, a 14-year-old German Jewish diarist, and seven other Jews in hiding in Amsterdam, are captured by the Gestapo and sent to concentration camps.
1950: Gen. Douglas MacArthur dispatches a high-ranking aide to Taipei as a liaison officer as the United States begins providing military aid to Taiwan.
1954: The P-1 English Electronic Lightning, Britain's first supersonic fighter plane, makes its maiden flight.
1960: Chung Li-ho, a noted Taiwanese folk tale author, dies at the age of 45.
1963: The Foreign Ministry declares that the Republic of China will not recognize the border treaty signed between the Peking regime and Afghanistan.
1967: Malawian President Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda arrives in Taipei for an eight-day state visit.
1972: Ugandan President Idi Amin declares that his country will expel 50,000 Asians with British passports within three months.
1976: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang extends its "deepest sympathy" to victims of the earthquake that struck northern China.
1979: Ho Yen-sheng, former Saigon correspondent for the China Times of Taipei who had been stranded in Vietnam since 1975, arrives in Taipei from an isolated island in the South China Sea where he spent 70 days as a refugee.
1986: ROC-U.S. trade talks begin in Washington. During the five-day talks, the ROC agreed to abandon its use of duty tables as of Oct. 1, 1986.
1990: Iraq installs a nine-man puppet government in Kuwait and sets up a new "People's Army" to control the regime while 12 European Community nations ban oil imports from Iraq, impose an arms embargo on the country and suspend most trade with Iraq.
1993: Japan formally apologizes for the first time to women forced to serve as sex slaves for Japanese soldiers during World War II.
1993: The Japanese Cabinet resigns, ending 38 years of rule by the Liberal Democratic Party.
1999: British Defence Secretary George Robertson becomes the new secretary-general of NATO, succeeding Javier Solana.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Mayor Tarmile Ishoda of Majuro sign a pact of alliance in Taipei, making Majuro, capital of the Marshall Islands, the 44th sister city of Taiwan's capital.
2000: Government Information Office Director General Chung Chin says that the GIO is mapping out procedures for setting up exchanges across the Taiwan Strait of journalists for long-term postings.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By dealing loyally and punctually with them in all engagements which he makes with them and allowing a liberal scale of pay: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to men in the public service."
