DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Chinese Drop Takeover Bid for Unocal.
The Chinese oil company battling to buy Unocal Corp. abandoned its effort Tuesday because of what it termed "regrettable and unjustified" U.S. political opposition, ending a showdown that spotlighted American concerns about energy security.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: 'Miracle' saves all in Canada jet crash
More than 300 people made a miraculous escape Tuesday after an Air France jet that witnesses said may have been hit by lightning skidded off a rainy Toronto runway, crashed into a ravine and burst into flames.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: House suspends Garci hearing
The House of Representatives last night voted to issue an arrest warrant for former Commission on Elections (Comelec) commissioner Virgilio Garcillano even as the joint committees investigating the wiretapping scandal decided to suspend indefinitely the hearings on the controversy.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Zuce: Arroyo saw payoffs
PRESIDENT Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo could not have been unaware of the distribution of money -- allegedly from the wife of an illegal gambling lord -- to poll officials meeting in her home before last year's election, Michaelangelo Zuce said yesterday.
The Philippine Star: House eyes'creeping'Cha-cha
After creeping impeachment comes creeping Charter change. Instead of being discouraged by the latest Social Weather Stations (SWS) survey indicating that 70 percent of Filipinos see no need for Charter change at this time, Bukidnon Rep. Miguel Zubiri is pushing for federalism and regards the SWS survey results as encouraging.
The Manila Times: Trade deficit far worse
The Philippines on Wednesday drastically revised its trade deficit figures for the past three years painting a far worse picture for the country's economy and trading position than at first thought.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEW

TEXT.P: The Moscow Times: Shantsev Picked as Nizhny Governor In what could be a step to install a loyal ally as Moscow's next mayor, President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday nominated Valery Sh Shantsev, Mayor Yury Luzhkov's powerful deputy, as the next governor of Nizhny Novgorod.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: AUG 27: Presidential polls set.
The date for the presidential election has been set for Aug 27. But the man who will be Singapore's next president may well be known on Nomination Day on Aug 17.
As these key dates were announced yesterday, there was still no indication that President S R Nathan would be challenged in his bid for a second six-year term.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore Presidential Election: Nomination Day on Aug 17, Polling Day on Aug 27.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong was issued the writ for the presidential election yesterday, he announced the Nomination Day is on August 17 and the Polling Day is on August 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICAN PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By M.H. Huang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The Costa Rican presidential office announced Wednesday that President Abel Pacheco and his wife will visit Taiwan Aug. 12-16 at the invitation of the Republic of China government.

The office also said in a statement released the same day that Costa Rica and Taiwan have maintained close ties and that Taiwan has always given timely assistance to Costa Rica whenever it has met with difficulties.

During the visit, the president will also join other dignitaries from various countries around the world to attend an assembly of the Democratic Pacific Union, an organization dedicated to promoting democracy and human rights in the region, according to the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MAJOR BREAKTHROUGH IN ROC'S U.N. BID THIS YEAR: GERMAN OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A ranking official of the German delegation to the United Nations said Wednesday that he does not think that Taiwan can make any major breakthrough in its bid to join the world's leading international organization this year.
Michael von Ungern-Sternberg, chief of the political division of the delegation, made the comments while responding to a question raised by a Central News Agency reporter at a press briefing.

Under arrangements by the U.S. State Department, a group of 30 journalists from about 20 countries, including two from Taiwan's Central News Agency and Liberty Times, were invited to participate in an activity called "U.N. 101" to better their understanding of the international political situation and the issues related to reform of the U.N. Security Council.

In response to a CNA question regarding whether the international community can "save the situation" on the exclusion of democratic Taiwan from the United Nations, the German official said that because of the major influence of large countries in the organization, he doesn't foresee any changes in the situation regarding Taiwan's U.N. bid in the near future.
Many U.N. members have opposed Taiwan's bid to join the organization, although some U.N. members have expressed their support for the bid in the past few years, the official also noted.
The U.N. is scheduled to hold its annual assembly in September, and the main topic to be discussed at the gathering will be the reform of the Security Council.

According to von Ungern-Sternberg, four countries, including Brazil, Germany, India and Japan, who all want to become permanent members of the Security Council, have already raised a motion to express their position in support of increasing the number of permanent members of the council.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO WORK TOWARD PRESIDENT'S ATTENDANCE AT APEC SUMMIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will make every effort to seek President Chen Shui-bian's attendance at the annual informal leadership meetings of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, a MOFA spokesman said Thursday.
Michel Lu said that although it is a daunting task, the ministry will continue to speak up for President Chen's right to attend the meeting.

President Chen Shui-bian said last month that he is willing to attend the 2005 APEC summit -- to be held in South Korea's second largest city of Busan in November -- under the designation of the leader of "Chinese Taipei." South Korean media reported later that the chances of Chen attending the meeting are slim, if not nil.

Lu said that Taiwan is already the 17th largest economy in the world, playing a major role in promoting economic development in the Asia and Pacific region, and that there is no reason for the international community to shut Taiwan out.
He said that the major hurdle remains China's relentless obstruction of Taiwan. The South Korean government has yet to formally refuse President Chen's attendance at the APEC meeting, he added.

Liao Tung-chou, vice director general of MOFA's Department of International Organizations, said that it is a reasonable request for President Chen to attend the APEC meeting, adding that the ministry will work toward that goal.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that admits both Taipei and Beijing. Because of Beijing's opposition, the Republic of China's head of state has been unable to attend previous APEC annual informal leadership meetings and has instead had to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Insurgents Using Bigger, More Lethal Bombs, U.S. Officers Say
The explosion that killed 14 marines in Haditha yesterday was powerful enough to flip the 25-ton amphibious assault vehicle they were riding in. In recent months the roadside bombs favored by insurgents in Iraq have grown significantly in size and sophistication. The new problems facing the military were displayed more than a week earlier, on July 23, when a huge bomb buried on a road southwest of Baghdad Airport detonated an hour before dark underneath a Humvee carrying four American soldiers.
Wall Street Journal: Conflicting Advice, Islamic Justice Finds a Foothold in Heart of Europe
Across Europe, Muslims are hungry for advice about how to integrate in their new countries while remaining true to their faith. Questions range from the complex (Can I pay into a pension system that is based on interest, which is forbidden by Islam? ) to the mundane (When do sunset prayers take place during the summer solstice in Scandinavia, when the sun doesn't set? ). In response, councils, television shows and Internet sites have issued a flood of fatwas aimed at aiding the residents of Islam's newest frontier, Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG-SOONG MEETING A GOOD THING: NEW KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that he thinks that a possible meeting between Wang Jin-pyng, the speaker of the Legislative Yuan, and James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP), in the United States is a good thing.

Ma, who was elected July 16 as the opposition Kuomintang's new chairman, made the comments in response to a media report that Wang will meet with Soong before he returns to Taiwan. Both Wang and Soong are currently in the United States on vacation.
Pointing out that he has not yet had a chance to meet with Soong since the KMT chairmanship election, Ma said that he feels it is good if Wang, who is also a KMT vice chairman, can meet with Soong.
In the KMT chairmanship election, Ma defeated Wang by garnering 72.4 percent of the vote.

Ma, who will take over his new post as KMT chairman Aug. 18, also said that he fully supports an exchange of views between a KMT vice chairman and the PFP head, stressing that he will also try to meet with Soong in the future.

Promising that the KMT will work closely together with the PFP and the New Party, Ma said that cooperation is the only way for the "pan-blue alliance" to push through its policies in the legislature where it holds a slight majority.
"The pan-blue alliance cannot split, or even engage in confrontation with one another," he stressed.
Ma also urged the PFP to cooperate with the KMT and the New Party, saying that "we should cooperate and work on monitoring the ruling party effectively."

According to a recent media report, PFP legislative caucus convener Daniel Hwang has said that the PFP will take a "tough position" in dealing with matters with other political parties. Some PFP legislators have also said that they will not make compromises with the KMT simply for the sake of the unity of the "pan-blue alliance."

DOC.HEADLINE: 8,000 PEOPLE INVITED TO JOIN 'HUNGER 30' IN KAOHSIUNG AUG. 13

TEXT.P: Eight thousand people have been invited to take part in the 16th "Hunger 30" activity in Kaohsiung on Aug. 13 as a humanitarian gesture to the less fortunate of the world.
Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai Thursday thanked World Vision Taiwan for building a platform through which Taiwan has been able to show its love of the world.
Chen said through its medical assistance to the needy and financial aid to students, World Vision Taiwan has helped more than 750,000 people in 78 countries.

The upcoming "Hunger 30" activity will be held at the soccer field of National Sun Yat-sen University in the city. Chen called on the people to go and experience for themselves how it feels to be without food for 30 consecutive hours.

"When we realize what it is like to go hungry for longer than a day, when we realize the preciousness of life, then we may be more willing to contribute what we can to the world's humanitarian efforts, " he said.

In conjunction with the charity activity, World Vision Taiwan opened a photo exhibit at the Kaohsiung Cultural Center Thursday graphically showing relief efforts and children suffering from hunger in India, Ethiopia and other poor countries.
The acting mayor urged his fellow citizens to join the hunger experiencing activity to "show the port city's love and to help relieve hunger."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP: POLITICAL STRUCTURE OF NCC TO HURT PRESS FREEDOM

TEXT.P: If the National Communications Commission (NCC) members are chosen according to the proportional representation principle, that would lead to political interference in its operations and thus hurt press freedom in the nation, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus said Thursday.

Reiterating the ruling party's opposition to appointing NCC members based on political parties' number of seats in the legislature, caucus Secretary-General William C.T. Lai said the NCC is supposed to be a watchdog for media consumers whose interests must be protected by a good system.

Lai was responding to Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's criticism that the KMT and other opposition parties had made a mistake by not passing the bill to establish the NCC during the last legislative session, thereby allowing the DPP-controlled Government Information Office (GIO) to revoke media business licenses, "leaving a big stain in the history of Taiwan's democracy and freedom."
Lien has confused audience rights with press freedom, Lai claimed, adding that it is ridiculous to seek press freedom with an NCC staffed with political appointees.

Seven media outlets have had their business licenses withdrawn as a result of a GIO committee review early this week, including an all-news channel owned by the Eastern Multimedia Group, triggering debate and calls for an early establishment of the NCC.

The KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" partners, the People First Party and the New Party, who hold a majority of seats in the Legislative Yuan, have vowed to work together to pass the NCC organic bill during the next session in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WELCOMES TALKS ON CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Thursday welcomed China's willingness to open talks on cross-Taiwan Strait charter cargo and passenger flights and services and called for an early start to negotiations.

The Cabinet-level MAC said in a news release that it and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will start necessary arrangements and preparations for the planned negotiations and urged the outside world to refrain from speculating over the issue to help secure a smooth process.
The MAC, however, pointed out that it may require extra negotiations on charter passenger flights because it is an issue much more complex than the cargo service.

Premier Frank Hsieh announced during a weekly Cabinet meeting Wednesday that the government is willing to hold bilateral talks simultaneously on charter cross-strait cargo and passenger flights with China.

MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung told a news conference later the same day that the government prefers to have cargo charter flights take place before passenger flights. "We maintain high expectations and can be flexible," he noted.

Hsieh's announcement marks a compromise by Taiwan over the cross-strait direct transport issue, over which Beijing was only willing to talk about charter passenger flights initially despite Taiwan's desire to first talk about cargo links to serve Taiwan businessmen operating in China.

The government's about-turn was made in part out of a consideration to meet potential strong demand for passenger services due to a planned opening to tourists from China, government officials said, adding that it does not want to see differences over the charter passenger services stand in the way of opening talks on cargo transport.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 9.56 points to close at 6,446.01.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,481.62 and hit a low of 6,439.89 during trading. A total of 3.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$108.96 billion (US$3.42 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up at 0.4 percent and cement stocks gaining 0.2 percent.

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down at 1.1 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent and textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.2 percent.
Construction issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 439 to 411, with 140 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WILLING TO HELP TAIWAN ATTEND WHO MEETINGS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The ROC's top health official said Wednesday that the United States is willing to help Taiwan attend World Health Organization (WHO) meetings.
Ho Sheng-mao, minister of the Department of Health (DOH) , made the remarks when he met with Taiwan media stationed in Washington, D.C.

He said that public health and medical care are borderless, and it is not fair if Taiwan is shut out of the WHO, adding that if there is a loophole in the world disease control network, the results could be disastrous.

He said that during his visit, he called on U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. He didn't say if he met with other ranking officials in Washington, D.C. concerning Taiwan's bid be granted observer status at the global health organization.
He said that he had reached consensus with the United States in May that the U.S. will help Taiwan take part in WHO meetings based on the principle of application.

On China's statement that it will help Taiwan attend the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the governing body of the WHO, Ho said that when he attended this year's WHA conference in Geneva in May, he felt the obstruction of China during the entire process, citing the example that when one delegate expressed appreciation for the assistance of Taiwan's medical teams, the Chinese delegate pounded the table to protest.
During a WHO conference on tsunami disaster in Bangkok, Thailand, Taiwan medical experts hoped to contribute, but were again pressured by China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TINY LEOPARD CAT BEING NURTURED BY ANIMAL PROTECTION CENTER

TEXT.P: Since a tiny leopard cat was found by a man in central Taiwan in the wake of Typhoon Haitang on July 18, the protected animal has been well taken care of by the government's special animals protection and preservation center.
Chan Fang-tze, a veterinarian with the center in Chichi, Nantou County, said when the man accidentally discovered the cat-like animal, he contacted the center.
The baby cat was only about 10 centimeters and about two weeks old. Workers at the center suspect that it might have gotten separated from its mother during the typhoon.

After checking the white spots behind its ears, a white line on its front, and other spots on its body, the center concluded that it was a leopard cat, also called an ocelot or tiger cat (felis pardalis).

The center's staff have been feeding the leopard cat with milk. It has since doubled in size and is very lively but has yet to cut its first tooth. When confronted by strangers, it crouches as if to attack.

Chan said leopard cats mature at around 12 months of age. The center will keep feeding it until it is seven or eight months old, when it will be trained to catch wildlife before being released into the mountains, he added.
A grown leopard cat is 107 to 120 centimeters long including the tail, which is about 38 centimeters, and stands 41 to 46 centimeters at the shoulder.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO DEVELOP RENEWABLE ENERGY TO PROTECT ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: The government will develop renewable energy and carbon dioxide reduction technology as efforts to decrease the negative impact of greenhouse gas emissions on the environment, a Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) official said Thursday.

The official noted that as Taiwan's carbon dioxide emission accounts for 1 percent of the world's total, an intraministerial ad hoc group responsible for energy policy has made the decision to develop renewable energy such as hydro, wind, solar, geothermal and biomass power, hydrogen energy and other carbon dioxide reduction technologies to do less harm to the environment.

Noting that climate change was the main theme at this year's Group of Eight meeting, the official said the issue has become a global political and economic one, especially after the Kyoto Protocol took effect in February, which aims to limit the global emission of greenhouse gases.

Premier Frank Hsieh stressed in February that the country will see to environmental protection, economic development and social justice as three sides of a triangle for the country's future development, according to the official.

Citing a G-8 report, the CEPD official said climate change will pose the greatest threat to people, as can be evidenced by the fact that the world's 10 hottest years in recent memory occurred after 1991.

Bad as it will be, climate change could also represent potential trade opportunities, the official said, citing the G-8 report that the global investment in energy-efficiency and energy-saving equipment could reach US$16 trillion over the next 25 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU COMPLAINS OF INCREASED CRIME BY CHINESE BACKPACKERS
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By J. C. Hung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The inflow of Chinese backpackers might be a factor in the increase in crime in Macau, Macau Special Administrative Region Secretary for Security Cheong Kuoc Va said Thursday.

A total of 5,139 criminal cases were reported to Macau police in the first half of this year, up by 10.8 percent year to year, Cheong said, adding that it might be related to Macau's opening to individual backpackers from China.

Police have been asked to step up surveillance at immigration check points as part of the territory's efforts to prevent Chinese people from committing crimes in Macau, in particular gambling-related crime and organized burglary, Cheong said, noting that the number of illegal property possession cases surged by 23.1 percent in the first half of this year.

According to Cheong, some 2.53 million Chinese backpackers entered Macau in the first six months of the year, almost double the previous year's level of 1.44 million. During the same period, some 2,750 people (excluded individual backpackers) were repatriated for overstaying their travel documents, up by 11.2 percent on an annual basis, while the ratio among Chinese backpackers rose by 2.3-fold to 1,007, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 14 points to close at 6,445, with 23,870 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September moved down five points to end at 6,433, with 902 contracts traded, while December futures lost six points to finish at 6,414, with 15 contracts traded. March futures moved down 15 points to close at 6,400, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,431 for August, 6,438 for September, 6,420 for December, 6,415 for March and 6,395 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

August TE futures moved down 0.2 points to close at 270, with 4,564 contracts traded, while September TE futures lost 0.3 points to finish at 270, with 115 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 0.45 points to end at 269.95, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures lost 3.2 points to finish at 990, with 2,974 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved down 4.4 points to end at 986.8, with 222 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 5.4 points to close at 984.6, with four contract transactions, while March TF futures lost 4.6 points to finish at 981.2, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.073 to close at NT$31.820.
A total of US$817 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.893 and hit a low of NT$31.758.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM TAKES ONE MORE STEP TOWARD PRIVATIZATION

TEXT.P: State-run Chunghwa Telecom is taking another step toward privatization by making 290 million shares available for private and corporate investors in Taiwan from Aug. 9.

A spokesman for Chunghwa Telecom announced Thursday that altogether 290 million, or 3 percent, of its shares will be released this time, and that only citizens of Taiwan are qualified to buy these shares. This is in addition to the 37 percent of the total shares released up to the present.

The spokesman said that individual investors will be allowed to buy the shares first. Those who have an account at any stock brokerage can apply to buy 3,000 shares each, with the leftover open to corporate investors, who are allowed to purchase no more than 29 million shares each.

The price will be determined by the average market price over the 10 days before Aug. 9, and then marked down with a discount of at least 6 percent. Those who become Chunghwa Telecom's new shareholders before Aug. 12 will be able to get a NT$4.7 dividend per share.

The spokesman said that Chunghwa Telecom will release an additional 13 percent of its shares near the end of this year to overseas investors, so that the company will have fulfilled its goal of becoming a private enterprise.
Chunghwa Telecom's revenues in the first half of this year totaled NT$89.7 billion. It is Taiwan's largest telecommunications company, offering a variety of services.

Commenting on Chunghwa Telecom's latest move, Premier Frank Hsieh said that privatization is the trend for every state enterprise, and that in releasing these shares to let individual investors share its profits, Chunghwa Telecom can now disperse the fear that after privatization, the company would be controlled by financial groups.
Hsieh added that if the individual investors' demand for the shares is too big, the government may consider releasing more shares.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the opposition People First Party (PFP) blamed the premier for showing contempt to the Legislative Yuan because he ignored a resolution of the legislature requiring Chunghwa Telecom to cease all operations regarding the release of its shares.

Hwang Yi-jiao, a whip at the PFP's legislative caucus, pointed out that the previous legislature had passed a resolution introduced by the PFP, censuring Chunghwa Telecom for having sold the previous batch of its shares too cheaply to certain financial groups. The resolution has banned the company from releasing any more shares until a further decision is made by the new legislature.

Hwang acknowledged that with the new legislature still in recess, there is nothing the opposition parties can do, but he said when the next legislative session opens in September, the PFP caucus will consider a move to cut the budget of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, which has direct jurisdiction over Chunghwa Telecom.

Chen Chin-chun, a whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's caucus at the legislature, urged the opposition parties not to object to Chunghwa Telecom's decision to release more shares from Aug. 9, saying that the move is beneficial both to the company and to the general public.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PEACE TREATY, NO FLY-OVER RIGHT FOR CHINESE PLANES: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not allow Chinese commercial aircraft to fly over its airspace until a peace treaty has been signed by the two sides, Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday.
China has repeatedly threatened to attack Taiwan militarily and it is targeting missiles at Taiwan, the premier said, adding that "if Chinese airplanes can fly over us, would they need the missiles?"
Hsieh made the remarks in an exclusive interview with CNA.

His decision Wednesday to allow Taiwan's commercial aircraft to fly over Chinese airspace spurred Taiwan's stock market, but some people were concerned that China may ask for a reciprocal measure from Taiwan.

In response to these concerns, Hsieh said his answer was a clear no, because Taiwan is not preparing to "recover the mainland" with military force whereas China has claimed it is ready to invade Taiwan and is backing this up with hundreds of missiles targeting Taiwan.
The premier said Taiwan will not become an obstacle to China's plan for what Beijing calls its "peaceful rise" only on one condition -- China must renounce its military threats against Taiwan.

That's why it is important for China and Taiwan to sign a peace treaty, he said. He noted that only when such a treaty has been signed -- when China has given up its threats against Taiwan -- will the government consider allowing Chinese aircraft to fly over Taiwan. "Right now we are not even considering it," he said.

He said the government decided to let Taiwan's aircraft use Chinese airspace mainly for economic reasons -- to save flight times and fuel, thereby alleviating the pressure on Taiwan air carriers to raise ticket prices for their international services.

In dealing with cross-strait exchanges, "we have to take into account our needs and our interests, " he said. Sometimes, such exchanges may not go smoothly because "we also have to consider the other side's needs and interests," he added.

He attributed the surge in air carriers' stock prices to an "atmosphere" in which investors think that the government's policy will not change abruptly and that the government has actually been doing things to make them feel reassured.

"I believe China also needs stability, particularly when its economy is increasingly internationalized, " Hsieh said. The two sides of the Strait "have a common interest" in making it easy for people to forecast future development instead of worrying about political risks, he said.

As to the knotty issues between the two sides and how things will evolve around them, Hsieh said that "time will offer its solutions." What needs to be done by both governments for now is "to work for the wellbeing of the people on both sides of the Strait."

DOC.HEADLINE: SHAOLIN MARTIAL ARTS MONKS ALLOWED TO COME AFTER SCHEDULE CHANGE: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday Shaolin martial arts monks will be allowed to come to Taiwan after they have changed their original schedule according to the law.
The MAC made the about-face after it originally vetoed the trip by the monks to take part in a martial art demonstration and short-term kung fu class program.

A local security firm and several martial art associations had originally planned to sponsor the program that would have begun last month. The mainland monks were invited to perform islandwide for 42 days. The monks would then be scattered in 23 places around the island to provide short-term martial arts classes. More than 4,000 had registered to take part in the classes, with each of them paying NT$1,200 (US$38.09) for the privilege.
But the MAC nixed the idea, believing that the Shaolin monks had not applied to related agencies for approval to come, and the sponsors had openly advertised the martial art classes.

MAC officials also said that cross-strait professional exchanges must follow the group-in, group-out pattern, and the sponsors intended to send monks all over island to accept students of all levels and they also wanted to bring the monks over to make money -- all of these are gross violations of the law, they said.

The sponsors have now agreed to follow the views proposed by the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, rearranging the schedule to adopt a group-in, group-out pattern. MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said that after the revision, the activity has returned to the category of cross-strait professional exchanges, with no commercial activities of charging fees and no certificates given after the short-term classes, but purely cross-strait martial arts exchanges.
You said that the first group of 45 Shaolin martial arts monks will arrive in Taiwan Aug. 11, and the time of arrival of the second group of 15 monks has yet to be decided.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTER HARDWARE PRODUCTION VALUE AT US$34.4 BILLION: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The output value of Taiwan's computer hardware in the first half of this year (at home and abroad) totaled US$34.4 billion, up by 16.8 percent compared with the year-earlier level, according to statistics released Thursday by the government.

Personal computer production value accounted for the largest share of 38 percent -- worth US$13.13 billion for 20.39 million units -- tallies made public by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show.
The production value of 44.87 million monitors came second at US$8.67 billion, some 25 percent of the total, reflecting a slight decrease of 0.9 percent in annual growth rate.

PDAs yielded the largest increase rate of 97.5 percent in annual output value, hitting US$1.43 billion for the first six months, while production amounts also rose by 60.8 percent to 6.19 million units.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT TO LIFT U.S. BEEF IMPORT BAN IN A RUSH: DOH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 3 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not agree to lift a ban on U.S. beef imports in a rush, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Hou Sheng-mou said Wednesday.
Hou made the remarks in Washington following reports that tests on a third suspected case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , or mad cow disease, in the United States have proved negative.
During an informal meeting with a group of Taiwanese reporters stationed in the United States, Hou said he was happy about the news, although he was not completely informed about the reports.

Responding to queries from the U.S. about whether American beef can be exported to Taiwan again, Hou said his visit did not include the U.S. Department of Agriculture and that he has not received any pressure or information from the U.S. on the issue.

Meanwhile, the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) changed regulations in May that stipulate that all boneless beef, including that from countries affected by BSE, should not be subject to restrictions on trade in beef.

Despite the rule-change, Hou said the U.S. should respect the hygiene inspections set by each beef importing country, adding that the DOH will form an expert committee to screen future U.S. beef imports, taking into consideration the opinions and data from academic institutions such as the National Health Research Institute.
Hou said his agency will make public health its top concern.
Taiwan banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in Washington State of a single BSE case.

The island lifted the ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months in April this year, which drew tremendous criticism from opposition lawmakers after a second mad cow disease was confirmed in U.S. in June. The DOH then again suspended U.S. beef imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MENTAL ARITHMETIC YOUNGSTERS TO VISIT UNITED STATES

TEXT.P: Four mental arithmetic youngsters from Taiwan will visit five cities in the United States later this month to demonstrate how they can calculate even faster than an electronic calculator.

Tseng Chun-chao, president of the Association of Chinese Children's' Mental Arithmetic Development, said Thursday that at the invitation of the National Education Association, he will lead the four youngsters aged between nine and 17 to visit Dallas, New York, Boston, Atlanta and Los Angeles from Aug. 19-28.
The four youngsters will demonstrate their abilities in the hope of helping education officials in the U.S. promote arithmetic.

To impress their American spectators, Tseng said they welcome any Americans between the ages of 9 and 100, using calculators, to challenge Liu Yu-ming, a nine-year-old student. If they can beat him, Tseng promised NT$50,000 (US$1,587) or a free 10-day trip to Taiwan.
Liu, a second grader in an elementary school in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, has studied mental arithmetic for three years. He is able to complete 23 calculations in less than three seconds.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RULES OUT WATER PRICE HIKE FOR THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that domestic water prices will definitely not be raised this year and that power rates might also not be adjusted upward this year.
Hsieh made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency.

Following a more-than 7-percent hike in gasoline and diesel prices by Taiwan's two major oil products suppliers, many people are concerned about the possibility of the government raising water and power rates.
"For the public's general interests, the government has decided not to raise water prices this year. As for electricity rates, the government is studying the best possible options," Hsieh said.

Because of ever-growing fossil fuel costs, state-owned Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) has been facing strong pressure to raise power rates and Hsieh said Taipower originally planned to raise power rates early this year.

For the sake of maintaining economic stability and keeping inflation at bay, Hsieh said, Taipower might not raise power rates before the end of this year. He further said the government is studying various options that would allow Taipower to reflect its rising power generation costs while avoiding affecting local industries' competitive edges and ordinary citizens' interests.
Touching on the crude oil price upward spiral, Hsieh noted that the issue is a global one.

"Oil price hikes will definitely have an impact on economic growth and consumer prices. As oil price hikes are worldwide, all countries have been affected as the global economy slows down," Hsieh said.
In this era of high energy prices, Hsieh said, the public should support all energy conservation measures and reusable energy resource development projects.
On the domestic economic development, Hsieh went on, the government will not only prioritize the pursuit of economic growth but will give equal emphasis to wealth distribution.

"While sustainable economic growth is important, equitable distribution of wealth is equally important. The government should see to it that the fruits of economic growth are enjoyed by everyone. It would be meaningless if the nation registered a 4 percent or 6 percent economic growth while wages and bank deposit interest remain unchanged, " Hsieh said, adding that the government will step up reforms of tax and health insurance systems to make them fairer and more reasonable.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER: DPP CANNOT AFFORD TO LOSE ELECTION IN TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) cannot afford to lose the election for Taipei county magistrate at the end of this year because the battle in the county will be "pivotal" to the ruling party's election campaign.

In an interview with the CNA, the premier said that overall, the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- the "pan-green camp" -- are running neck and neck with the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party in the campaign for the year-end elections.
He added that although the DPP candidate for Taipei county, Luo Wen-jia, is ahead of the other candidates in opinion polls, the DPP still needs to be very careful in managing the election campaign.
"We are the ruling party. We cannot afford to lose in Taipei County," he said.

The premier calculated that the DPP will not win an overwhelming victory. "We are unlikely to win in Kinmen and Matsu (two outlying islands), and might even have problems in one or two of the eight southern Taiwan counties and cities being contested," he said.
However, he added, it is also likely that the DPP might win in one or two of the other counties and cities.
According to Hsieh, there are good opportunities for the DPP in Taichung City, Taichung County, Yunlin County and Miaoli County.
The premier seemed to draw satisfaction from the fact that his team at the Executive Yuan, with its popularity rating currently at over 50 percent, is at least not a burden to the DPP candidates.
He said the ruling party must try to be very modest and heed the voice of the people in order to win the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET NEEDS TO BOOST COMMUNICATION ABILITY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Franks Hsieh said Thursday that "tacit understanding" among his Cabinet members has improved but as a whole, the Cabinet needs to improve its communication ability so the public can better understand the government's policy initiatives.

During an exclusive interview with the CNA, the premier also talked about his relations with President Chen Shui-bian, claiming that "only outsiders" will say Chen has "hidden dissatisfaction" with him.
Over six months into his term as premier, Hsieh said there is room for improvement for his Cabinet, but "for now there is no plan for a reshuffle."
Only when there are cases of incompetency or vacancies will he consider changes to the Cabinet.
The Cabinet needs to improve is its communication ability, he said, adding that many policy initiatives the Cabinet considers "good" are opposed by many people.
He said the Ministry of Education is among the government departments with poor communication ability, citing the much-criticized tuition policy as an example.

When a university student pays NT$50,000 (US$1,570) for a semester, the government actually has to invest between NT$200,000 and NT$250,000 to support him, Hsieh claimed. If he does not even pay NT$50,000, the country certainly will be adopting a low tuition policy, he said, noting that it is the public's taxes that are used to fund college and university education.
Some critics have claimed that tuition is too high and people agree with that claim, said the premier.

Hsieh claimed that poor students are not left behind, "because we have scholarships and other academic funds totalling NT$17.4 billion a year" as incentives to those with good academic records and for loans to needy students.
Things like that "we are beginning to make clear to people this year," Hsieh said.
Another policy initiative that the government has not communicated well to the public, according to Hsieh, is health care insurance premiums.
If a patient goes to the hospital too often, accumulating big medical bills but paying very little, it is the public that foots the bills, he said.

"The money does not go into the government's pocket and yet people demand that the government pay for the patient. It isn't right for the government to pay, because the government's money comes out of the people's pockets," he said.
Turning to the interaction between Chen and the Cabinet, the premier said he regularly meets the president, who tells him how he feels about each Cabinet member and about Hsieh himself.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SUGGESTS NO PAY HIKES FOR CIVIL SERVANTS IN 2006

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that after a comprehensive review, it is not suitable for the government to raise salaries for civil servants, military personnel and public school teachers next year.
Chen made the suggestion after listening to a Cabinet report on the 2006 central government budget plan.

Premier Frank Hsieh, Minister of Finance Lin Chuan and Hsu Chang-yao, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), jointly presented the draft budget plan to Chen during a meeting at the Presidential Office.
Vice President Annette Lu, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun and National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen were also present at the meeting.

After listening to the briefing, Chen gave several suggestions, including no pay hikes for government employees, military personnel and public school teachers, but increases in research and development funding and defense and diplomatic spending.

Chen said the Cabinet should try its best to realize the goal of raising the annual R&D spending to 3 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) in 2006 to speed up Taiwan's scientific and technological development.
With a view to beefing up Taiwan's self-defense capabilities, Chen said military spending should be increased to 3 percent of the GDP in three years.

In the face of China's relentless diplomatic suppression of Taiwan and the fact that the nation's foreign aid still falls below United Nations-set standards, Chen said the diplomatic budget should be raised at an appropriate rate.
He further said the law enforcement-related budget should be raised to accentuate the government's determination to crack down on crime and maintain law and order.

Over the past five years, Chen said, government investment in expanding domestic demand and infrastructure construction have consistently registered negative growth. In order to boost economic development and increase job opportunities, he said, the Cabinet should study the feasibility of increasing spending in those fields.

According to the DGBAS-drafted budget plan, the government revenues are projected at NT$1.4 trillion and the expenditures are forecast at NT$1.59 trillion, leaving a budget deficit of NT$190 billion. Moreover, the government will have to repay NT$65 billion in outstanding debts next year. In addition to using a budget surplus of NT$21.7 billion from the previous year, the government plans to float NT$239 billion-worth of state bonds to make ends meet.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC MAKE-UP SHOULD FOLLOW NORMAL DEMOCRACIES' EXAMPLES: OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: Ruling and opposition party bickering over the make-up of the proposed National Communications Commission (NCC) continued Thursday after Premier Frank Hsieh repeated his opposition to selecting members in accordance with the number of legislative seats held by each party.
Hsieh said political parties should not be involved in such an important institution so that experts and scholars will have a free hand to regulate the country's media.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative caucus Secretary-General William C.T. Lai noted that the opposition parties' proposal to choose NCC members according to the "proportional representation" principle will hurt press freedom.

But the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) insisted that there are precedents in other democracies to appoint NCC members in proportion with political parties' parliamentary strength.

According to Huang Yi-chiao, PFP legislative caucus convener, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) of the United States "normally" is staffed according to the proportional representation principle.

If the Cabinet gets the right to choose the NCC members, it would be the same as the current Government Information Office, which controls the experts committee that reviews and decides media licenses, Huang said.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee, claimed that a proportional representation structure of the NCC best accords with public opinion and would be the "fairest" NCC structure.

He said his party was proposing the same thing as Premier Frank Hsieh -- that the NCC should be composed of scholars and experts recommended by political parties so that it will not be controlled by the government and will be a truly independent organization.

Hung Hsiu-chu, a KMT legislator, noted that all scholars and experts recommended by political parties will have to be examined by the general public, and each party will be held accountable for the integrity and professional competency of the persons it has recommended.

In order to make the NCC fair and objective, Ho Min-hao, convener of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union's legislative caucus, suggested that nominees to the NCC be elected by professional media and journalist groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER: POLITICAL PARTIES SHOULD WITHDRAW FROM MASS MEDIA

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that he supports the establishment of a National Communications Commission (NCC) to regulate media affairs, but thinks that the new body should be free from the influence of any political parties.

Hsieh told the CNA in an interview that he is opposed to the proposal that the NCC should consist of members appointed by different political parties in proportion to the number of legislative seats held by each party.

Noting that there is strong public sentiment that feels political forces should not be allowed to meddle in media affairs, Hsieh said he supports the idea that a media supervisory organization such as the NCC should be formed, borrowing experience from advanced nations.
However, he added, political parties should withdraw from media affairs and let scholars serve on the commission.

The premier defended the Government Information Office's (GIO's) decision not to renew the licenses of seven cable TV channels, saying that under the current system, the GIO is the authority in charge of such matters and that the GIO would be failing its duty if it did not enforce the law.

He denied that the government has used the TV licensing process as a way to retaliate against TV channels that frequently criticize the government. "If that had been true, at least seven or eight other channels would have had their licenses revoked," he pointed out.
Hsieh also denied media speculation that the TV licensing dispute involves a power struggle between himself and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang.

"Such speculation is groundless and irresponsible, " he said, adding that it is also an "insult" not only to the review committee that made the recommendations for the GIO decision, but also to those TV channels that had their licenses renewed, because it insinuates that they obtained their licenses not because they could present good TV programs.

Hsieh said he meets with President Chen Shui-bian at least once a week and attends the meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee regularly to keep party officials informed of the work the Executive Yuan is doing.
He added that the DPP is still committed to reforms after five years in power.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR APPROVAL OF ARMS PROCUREMENT BUDGET

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh called Thursday for the passage through the legislature of a special budget for arms purchases from the United States.
In an exclusive interview with CNA, Hsieh noted that Taiwan's difficult political situation needs the assistance of the United States but said the nation will not drag America into a war with China.
Therefore, he added, Taiwan should demonstrate its determination to provide its own defenses.

Taiwan plans to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the U.S. for a price tag of NT$480 billion but the budget has been blocked by the opposition, which claims that the price is too high and insists that the arms package be included in the annual military budget rather than in a special budget.
Hsieh said that if the purchase is included in the annual military budget, it will squeeze the budget for some 200 other military articles that the government plans to purchase annually.

In addition, the annual military budget plus the special arms budget will only account for 2.8 percent of the country's gross domestic product, less than the 3 percent proposed by President Chen Shui-bian, Hsieh added.
Hsieh urged the Legislative Yuan to convene a special session to discuss urgent bills such as the arms purchase and a flood-control bill.
The legislature went into recess at the end of May and will begin its next session in mid-September.
Noting that Taiwan has many problems to resolve and the tenure of the legislators is so short, Hsieh urged the lawmakers not to waste time and to think of the welfare of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WARNS FARMERS NOT TO WALK INTO CHINA'S `TRAP'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged Taiwanese farmers not to walk into what he claimed is "the trap" set by China when it offered tariff-free treatment for Taiwan fruit imports.

In an interview with Japanese Shincho Weekly, Chen said Taiwan businessmen should understand that their investment in China is risky, evidenced by Chi Mei Group Chairman Hsu Wen-lung, whose investment was blocked at one point by the Chinese authorities due to his pro-Taiwan independence stance.

Chen said China, which has deployed 706 missiles targeting Taiwan, is hostile toward Taiwan and he urged Taiwanese businessmen with operations in China to either bring their money back to Taiwan or put it into other countries.
Noting that although Taiwan will be the first victim of China's "military rise, " Chen said the island will not enter an arms race with China but will secure a sufficient defense capability.

Meanwhile, he expressed gratitude to the United States and Japan for their opposition to China's enactment of its "Anti-Secession Law, " which authorizes Beijing to use military force against Taiwan should the nation move toward formal independence, as well as for their objection to some European countries' proposal to lift an embargo by the European Union on military sales to China.
Chen urged the U.S. and Japan, which maintain no diplomatic ties with Taiwan, to conduct military exchanges or cooperation with Taiwan to ensure peace and stability in East Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT OFFICES IN NORTHERN TAIWAN TO CLOSE FRIDAY OVER TYPHOON

TEXT.P: City and county governments in northern Taiwan announced late Thursday that all government offices and schools will be closed Friday in anticipation of typhoon Matsa.

A Taipei city government official quoted Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reports as saying that Matsa will lash northern Taiwan with strong wind and heavy rain Friday, qualifying for the closure of government offices and schools in the city.

As a result, all central government offices as well as financial markets, including stock and currency exchanges, will be closed Friday. Meanwhile, the governments of Taipei County, Keelung City, Ilan County, Taoyuan County and Hsinchu County made similar announcements. Government offices in Hsinchu City will operate normally but all schools in the city will be closed.
At 10 p.m., the typhoon was centered in the Pacific Ocean about 220 km east of Ilan, CWB meteorologists said.
Typhoon Matsa, named after a Laotian fish, was moving north-northwest at a speed of 14 kph, packing sustained winds of 144 kph, the meteorologists said.
The CWB issued a land warning early Thursday, saying the storm is likely to bring heavy rain to the island's northern and northeastern parts.

According to CWB officials, the fringe of the typhoon could bring heavy rain to northern Taiwan late Thursday through Friday morning. They warned that mountainous regions should be prepared for torrential downpours and landslides, with a danger of flooding in low-lying areas in the north and northeast, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLANS TO VISIT PARAGUAY IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday he plans to embark on a diplomatic tour in October and may make transit stops in Japan and the United States.
Hsieh disclosed his travel plans during an exclusive interview with the CNA.
In the face of China's diplomatic embargo, Hsieh said he plans to visit one or more of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in October. However, he went on, itinerary has not been fleshed out.
Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said planning is already underway, with Paraguay the most likely destination. Paraguay is the Republic of China's only diplomatic ally in South America.

President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to visit Nicaraguay in September to attend a biennial summit meeting with the heads of state of the ROC's Central American allies. Chen may also visit several allies in the Caribbean.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTERS WITHOUT BORDERS CONCERNED ABOUT CLOSURE OF TV STATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: An influential organization fighting for press freedom around the world on Thursday called the Taiwan authorities' decision not to renew the operating licenses of seven cable TV stations a violation of press freedom and urged Premier Frank Hsieh to rescind the decision.

The government's Satellite Broadcasting Business Review Committee (SBBRC) decided July 31 not to renew the licenses of ETTV-S cable news station and six others and gave them two days to stop broadcasting.

"This decision clearly constitutes a serious press freedom violation and a disturbing signal to cable TV operators and TV executives, who will now have to work with a threat hanging over them," the Paris-based Reporters Without Borders said in a statement.
The organization demanded that the premier ensure that the licenses of the seven cable stations will be renewed.

Pointing out that it is unacceptable that the broadcast licence system should be subordinated to political interests, Reporters Without Borders said that "the Taiwanese government should put an end to such an arbitrary system and create a fully independent entity to issue licenses."

It also noted that the closure of ETTV-S, which is owned by Eastern Multimedia Group and which has never had any trouble getting its license renewed in the past, has put more than 300 employees out of work.

In response to the outcry against the decision, the premier said one day after the announcement that the SBBRC's refusal to renew the licenses was justified based on considerations of the stations' financial problems and their programming which he said included "the presence of pornographic content" and "journalistic irresponsibility" in news coverage. The premier also insisted that "everything was done according to the rules."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 5, or the first day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1100: Henry I, the youngest son of William the Conqueror, is crowned king in Westminster Abbey, three days after his brother William Rufus was killed in a hunting accident in the New Forest.
1858: The laying of the world's first transatlantic telegraph cable between Ireland and Newfoundland is completed.
1792: Frederick North, British politician known as "Lord North," dies at the age of 60. He served as prime minister (1770-1782) under George III and instituted policies that led to the rebellion of the American colonies.
1861: A national income tax is introduced in the United States, initially to fund the Civil War.
1895: Friedrich Engels, German socialist theorist and writer, dies at the age of 75. He met Karl Marx in Paris in 1844 and collaborated with him on "The Communist Manifesto" in 1848.
1930: Neil Armstrong, American astronaut and the first man on the moon, is born.
1948: The Republic of China and the United States agree to organize the Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, with Chiang Meng-lin, James Yen and Shen Chung-han from the ROC, and Dr. Raymond T. Moyer and Dr. John Earl Baker from the United States as commissioners.
1949: The United States issues a "White Paper" on Sino-American relations, blaming the Nationalist government for the occupation of the Chinese mainland by the communists.
1950: A Kuomintang Central Reform Committee is set up in Taipei.
1950: The U.S. 13th Air Force is stationed in Taiwan to help the ROC guard against possible mainland Chinese air attacks.
1952: The first Japanese Embassy in Taiwan officially opens on Taipei's Chungshan North Road following the exchange of diplomatic notes ratifying the Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Liberia.
1958: The nuclear-powered submarine Nautilus completes a historic 2,000-mile (3,200-km) underwater journey from Point Barrow in Alaska to the Greenland Sea, passing directly under the North Pole during its five-day voyage.
1958: Vice President Chen Cheng, who was appointed on July 1 to the concurrent post of Executive Yuan president, presides over a ceremony laying the foundation for the construction of the NT$3,200 million Shihmen Dam.
1971: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with the Republic of Turkey.
1973: The Hua Hsing Junior High School baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to represent the Far East in the Senior League World Series.
1974: The Republic of China Amateur Big League baseball team leaves Taipei to participate in the 1974 Amateur Big League World Series in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla.
1976: The Executive Yuan approves the extension for two years of the Sino-Panamanian pact on technical fishery cooperation.
1984: Richard Burton, Welsh-born actor and twice husband of actress Elizabeth Taylor, dies of a stroke at his home in Switzerland.
1986: The Chinese Taipei women's basketball team leaves for Moscow to compete in the 10th Women's Basketball World Championships.
1991: President Lee Teng-hui receives Fijian Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara.
1999: The 18th International Baseball Association World Amateur Big League Baseball Championship opens in Kaohsiung County with 12 teams from Cuba, Japan, South Korea, Panama, the United States and Taiwan participating.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announces the list of members for his inter-party task force on cross-strait relations, which he said will be an advisory body for the ROC president and not a policy-making unit.
2001: National Defense University President Gen. Hsia Ying-tsou says that Taiwan's first state-financed military think tank, the National Center for Strategic Studies, will be inaugurated on Sept. 1.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "By strictly limiting the time of their service and making all imposts as light as possible: that is how the ruler gives encouragement to the mass of the people."
