DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES JAPAN GRANTING PERMANENT VISA WAIVER FOR TAIWAN TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday it welcomes passage by the Japanese House of Councilors, or upper house of the Japanese Diet, earlier in the day a revised bill that grants permanent visa-free treatment for Taiwan tourists.
The House of the Representatives, or lower house of the Japanese Diet, passed the bill Tuesday.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said that the Japanese Cabinet is expected to soon announce the permanent waiver of the visa requirement for Taiwan tourists, which will be put into practice Sept. 26, or the day after the closing of Expo 2005 Aichi in central Japan.
Earlier this year, the Japanese parliament passed a special bill to grant 90-day, visa-free entry to Taiwan visitors from March 25 through Sept. 25 in connection with the Aichi expo.

With the temporary visa waiver period soon to expire, Japanese parliamentarians decided to pass a new bill to allow for permanent visa-free status for Taiwan citizens. Japan's existing exit and entry regulations only authorize visa waivers for citizens from countries that maintain formal diplomatic relations with Japan.
Lu urged Taiwan tourists to cherish the "hard-earned preferential treatment" for Taiwan and to abide by the law during their travels in Japan.

MOFA officials said that China had tried to obstruct every step of the way during the reviews of the bill and had asked that Chinese tourists be given the same visa waiver treatment. However, based on the record of Chinese tourists violating the law, Japanese lawmakers refused to budge on granting preferential treatment to mainland citizens out of concerns for law and order.

The officials said the bill's passage demonstrates that Japan attaches great importance to its relations with Taiwan. They added that the move will boost Taiwan tourist arrivals in Japan from the current figure of just over 1 million per year to between 1.3 million and 1.4 million per year. Taiwan is Japan's second-largest source of foreign tourists after South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S UPPER HOUSE PASSES VISA-FREE BILL FOR TAIWAN TOURISTS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By F.M. Chang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The upper house of the Japanese Diet passed a special bill Friday granting permanent visa-free treatment to Taiwan tourists.
The House of Representatives, or lower house of the Japanese Diet, passed the bill Tuesday.

Earlier this year, the Japanese parliament passed a special bill to grant 90-day, visa-free entry to Taiwan tourists during the period of the World Expo in Aichi prefecture from March 25 through Sept. 25.
With the temporary waiver period soon to expire, Japanese parliamentarians decided to pass a new bill to allow for permanent visa-free status for Taiwan citizens.
Following an official announcement of passage of the bill, it is expected to enter into force Sept. 26, or the day after the World Expo in Aichi concludes.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP HEAD VISITS KMT CHAIRMAN-ELECT

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung called on the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairman-elect, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, at Taipei City Hall Friday.

During their meeting, Ma, who defeated Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng in a bitter KMT chairmanship election last month, told Lin that a proposed party law ought to stipulate that the Election and Recall Law should also apply to party elections.

He noted that graft is still common in Taiwan elections, even at the level of party elections. Saying that party chairmanship elections are no less important than those for township and village chiefs, he added that the law should also apply to party elections if it is applied to township and village chief elections.
Lin expressed full support for Ma's views, saying that ridding party elections of graft is as important as rooting it out in elections for public officials.
Ma also reported to Lin on the city government's efforts to preserve local culture and heal the wounds of the 228 Incident.

He said the city is preparing to issue video discs documenting the life of Chiang Wei-shui (1891-1931) , a peaceful anti-Japanese activist, and to help establish a Lin Mao-sheng memorial in Taipei. Lin, former dean of the College of Liberal Arts of National Taiwan University, died in the 228 Incident, which broadly refers to events of late February 1947 that culminated in the systematic killing of thousands of members of the local elite.

During their meeting, Lin also presented Ma with two books he has written on mercy, hope and love, and said he was paying the visit to Ma mainly to congratulate him on his victory in the KMT chairmanship election and to express the hope that Ma can contribute to the nation in his KMT chairman position.
Lin also denied that he carried any message on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian to the Taipei mayor.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL PARTY LAW SHOULD GOVERN PARTY ASSETS: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou suggested Friday the enactment of a political party law to govern party affairs, including party assets, instead of just making a "political party assets law" that he claimed will be used to target the KMT's assets.

In response to Premier Frank Hsieh's offer to draft a statute to govern political parties' assets, Ma said it would not befit a democratic country to legislate a law that governs only political parties' assets.

He noted that once such a law has been enacted, efforts will likely be made to purge the KMT of its properties and other assets. Ma has pledged to handle the question of KMT assets when he takes over the party helm Aug. 19.

He suggested that the Executive Yuan expand the draft statute to cover all political party-related affairs, including the election of party representatives, claiming that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), like all of Taiwan's political parties, has been troubled by problems of fake memberships and vote-buying during party elections.
If the government's election law can be applied to political party elections, it would help bring about healthy party politics, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS TAKE CARE TO ENSURE NO MORE HIGHWAY FLOODING

TEXT.P: Transportation officials were paying extra care Friday to ensure that a section of the Chungshan highway near President Chen Shui-bian's hometown in southern Taiwan would not be flooded with the onslaught of typhoon Matsa.
Chen took transportation officials to task last month when he inspected the Matou section of the highway near his hometown of Kuantien, Tainan, in the wake of typhoon Haitang last month.

The president was upset by the fact that the Matou section of the highway was flooded and had to be sealed off twice in a little more than a month, saying that high-ranking transportation officials would have to step down if the area is flooded again.

Bracing for Matsa, traffic officials built up hundreds of meters of earth embankment along the section, raising the road section by laying 40 cm of asphalt and deploying extra pumping machines in case of emergency.
A traffic official said that in past flooding, the maximum rainfall in a day was nearly 300 mm, and that this time, the flood-control measures can withstand 500 mm of rain per day.

DOC.HEADLINE: LISHAN MARATHON POSTPONED TO AUG. 28

TEXT.P: The 12th Lishan marathon was postponed to Aug. 28 due to the bad weather brought by typhoon Matsa, organizers said Friday.
Lishan, a mountainous area in the central county of Taichung, is famous for producing apples and honey peaches, the organizers said, adding that the annual event is held to promote local tourism.
Because of the postponement, the registration period has been extended until Aug. 19, the organizers said.
Anyone who has already registered but cannot attend Aug. 28 can demand a refund before Aug. 19, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REGISTERS US$253.56 BILLION FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves stood at US$253.56 billion in July, down US$53 million from June, the Central Bank of China (CBC) said Friday.
The July figure, representing an increase of US$11.82 billion from the end of last year, is still the third-largest in the world after Japan and China.
CBC officials attributed the decrease to a fall in trade surplus this year, as well as increased travel expenses as July is the high season for overseas trips.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY HAILS JAPAN'S PERMANENT VISA WAIVER FOR TAIWAN TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative to Japan said Friday the Japanese government's decision to drop visa requirements for Taiwan visitors, saying the goodwill move is in the interests of both countries.

Koh Se-kai made the remarks after the Japanese House of Councilors, or the upper house of the Japanese Diet, passed a bill earlier in the day that grants permanent visa-free treatment for Taiwan tourists.

The bill had already cleared the even more powerful House of Representatives, or the lower house of the Japanese Diet, Tuesday. The Japanese government is expected to soon announce the permanent waiver of visa requirements for Taiwan tourists, which will be enforced from Sept. 26, one day after the close of the eco-friendly World Exposition in the central Japanese prefecture of Aichi.

Earlier this year, the Japanese parliament passed a special bill to grant 90-day, visa-free entry to Taiwan visitors from March 25 through Sept. 25 in connection with the Aichi expo. With the temporary visa waiver period soon to expire, Japanese parliamentarians decided to pass a new bill to allow for permanent visa-free status for Taiwan passport holders.

According to Koh, China has tried hard to block Japan from enacting the permanent visa waiver bill under the excuse of its "one China" principle. However, China failed to reach its goal because the bill will contribute to Japan's drive to double its tourist arrivals from 5.73 million in 2003 to 10 million in 2010, Koh said.

Since Japan began permitting visa-free entry for Taiwan tourists in March, Koh said, the tourists have lived up to Japan's expectations, with the number rising, no criminal cases involving Taiwan tourists reported and strong purchase power demonstrated. Each Taiwan tourist spends an average of US$170 during their stays in Japan, comparable to Japanese people's consumption level.

Noting that the enactment of permanent visa-free treatment is expected to attract even more Taiwan tourists to Japan, Koh said he looks forward to the day that substantive relations between the two countries can become closer through increased civilian exchanges and mutual understanding.
Since assuming his current post in July 2004, Koh said he has proposed to the Japanese authorities many measures to further boost bilateral relations, including the permanent visa waiver.

Koh said that in the future, he will focus on lobbying Japan to improve the bilateral engagement mechanism. Stressing that the mechanism -- formulated in 1972 following Japan's switching of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing -- has become obsolete, Koh said Japan should make an overall review and forge a more effective mechanism to facilitate bilateral exchanges.

Under the 1972 mechanism, both Taipei and Tokyo set up intermediary bodies -- the Taipei-based Association of East Asian Relations and the Tokyo-based Interchange Association -- to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of direct official contacts.

Now that Japan has explicitly singled out Taiwan Strait peace as a common strategic objective of the U.S.-Japan defense cooperation treaty, Koh said Japan should not continue resisting improvements to communication channels with Taiwan simply for fear of offending China.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONWIDE READING FESTIVAL UNDERWAY

TEXT.P: The Chengpin Reading Festival is being held around the island, with a large variety of activities underway, organizers said Friday.
Chengpin is a major bookstore chain viewed by some people in Taiwan as a "cultural arena."

The topic of the annual festival is "a new vision of the world" and to present the topic, the bookstore has organized a series of activities, including concerts, dancing, film screenings and seminars, in addition to book exhibitions.
The event will run until Aug. 21.
The bookstore was slated to sponsor an outdoor concert in Taipei City Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROP LOSSES FROM TYPHOON MATSA SURPASS NT$4 MILLION

TEXT.P: Crop losses around Taiwan caused by typhoon Matsa had hit NT$4.48 million (US$140,970) as of 11 a.m. Friday, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported.

Around 114 hectares of cropland was devastated by the second typhoon to hit Taiwan this year. COA officials said the council has informed farmers' groups to release frozen stocks to help maintain market supply.

According to the Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Co., vegetable prices were recorded at N$36.8 per kilogram on average Friday, a drop of NT$0.95 from the level of the previous day, while a total of 1,005 tons of leafy vegetables were shipped to the wholesale market in Taipei, posting a 30-ton increase over the level of a day earlier.
COA officials said the supply is stable because the major vegetable production areas of the country, located in the central and southern parts of the island, were spared by the typhoon.

Meanwhile, as of 11 a.m. Friday, 14,000 households around the island were still lacking power after supplies to 50,000 households islandwide were cut due to the typhoon, according to Taiwan Power Company.

As of 2 p.m., the typhoon was located about 240 km northeast of Taipei, moving north northwest at a speed of 14 kph, meteorologists of the Central Weather Bureau said, noting that the fringe of the storm was expected to pass Taiwan later that night.

While the typhoon brought rain to the island's northern and northeastern parts, mountainous regions south of Hsinchu should be prepared for torrential downpours and landslides, with a danger of flooding in low-lying areas in the north and northeast, the meteorologists warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON HAS PASSED BUT DANGER REMAINS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The residents of Taiwan must not let down their guard even though the brunt of Typhoon Matsa has passed the island, said Premier Frank Hsieh Friday, adding that torrential rains in central and southern Taiwan are still likely.

The premier made the comments while touring the Central Disaster Prevention and Relief Center. He said the all agencies must coordinate to effectively take care of citizens who need help in the aftermath of the typhoon, adding that consumer prices must remain stable in the near term.
The premier said past experience has shown that after a typhoon leaves Taiwan, the public becomes lax and unexpected accidents occur.

He said that the possibility of more heavy rains in the central and southern parts of the island is high and people ought to be aware of this, along with storm surges in coastal areas and mudslides in mountainous regions.

Hsieh also warned people to avoid drinking water that could be polluted from the typhoon so as not to become infected with meliodiosis, an infectious disease caused by the burkholderia pseudomallei bacterium. The bacteria are found in contaminated water and soil and are spread to humans and animals through direct contact with the contaminated source.
Seven people died and more than 20 people were hospitalized after being infected with meliodiosis in the wake of the previous typhoon, Haitang, which hit Taiwan in mid-July.
Regarding the soaring prices of vegetables after each typhoon, Hsieh said the farmers' associations have released 1,200 tons of vegetables, which he said should be sufficient for the public.
On the mudslides in the wake of the typhoon, which have contaminated water sources in Hsinchu and Taoyuan in northern Taiwan, Hsieh said that agencies should review and address the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Gref Says Oil Taxes May Be Slashed.
Raising the prospect of tax cuts for the oil sector, Economic Development and Trade Minister German Gref said Thursday that the government needed to review current tax rates by the end of the year to ensure continued growth in the sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Afghanistan Agrees To Accept Detainees; U.S. Negotiating Guantanamo Transfers.
The Bush administration is negotiating the transfer of nearly 70 percent of the detainees at the U.S. detention facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to three countries as part of a plan, officials said, to share the burden of keeping suspected terrorists behind bars.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Al Qaeda threatens to make more destructions on London.
Ayman Al-Zawahiri, Al Qaeda's No. 2, threatens to launch more terrorist attacks against Great Britain and the United States in a videotape broadcast by the Al Jazeera TV Thursday. He also warned that Iraq would become another "Vietnam" if the U.S. troops do not withdraw.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Offer by Europe Would Give Iran Nuclear Future
European negotiators have prepared a sweeping proposal to Get Iran to abandon its suspected nuclear arms ambitions.
The proposal raises the possibility of Iran acquiring nuclear reactors and fuel, and of achieving a full political and economic relationship with the West.
Western diplomats said that the proposal presented a full spectrum of relationships for Iran with the West, from technology sharing to trade preferences to security guarantees, if the Tehran government cooperates on nuclear matters, and also on improving human rights and combating terrorism.
Wall Street Journal: To Soothe Anger over Subsidies, U.S. Cotton Tries Wooing Africa
The deputy undersecretary at the U.S. Department of Agriculture met with local cotton farmers in Mali and promised American help to boost productivity.
The trip was part of an extraordinary effort to lend a hand to African cotton farmers. But the prime motivation wasn't altruistic.
West African nations, newly assertive in global trade negotiations, are agitating for the abolition of subsidies essential to the prosperity of many American farmers.
The U.S. is fending off an uprising by have-nots such as Mali and Benin, and emerging farm powers Brazil and India, which are turning the rules of the World Trade Organization to their advantage.
In February 2003, Brazil challenged a host of U.S. cotton subsidies in the WTO on the grounds that they distort trade.
Earlier this year, the WTO ruled in Brazil's favor against a U.S. subsidy that aids cotton exports, the first time an American farm subsidy has been struck down. U.S. Congress is mulling changes to the program to conform with the decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: DUTY FREE TAIWAN FRUITS ARRIVE TO MEDIA ATTENTION IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Chen-yi Liao and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The first batch of duty free Taiwan fruits were put on display at Beijing's Juntai Department Store Friday accompanied by a frenzied media circus.
Reporters from Beijing's print and electronic media swarmed to the store's special area to take a look at Taiwan's star fruits, wax apples and others. At one point, reporters outnumbered customers.

Store employees were on hand to explain to curious Beijingers how to enjoy custard apples and wax apples. People were delighted by the sales people's promotional efforts as well as the fruits themselves.
Lu Zhengyu, manager of Chunlin Import Company, said recent typhoons and the start of the "Ghost Month" Friday in Taiwan have driven up prices at the source, shrinking his profit margin.
During the lunar month of July, demand for fruit usually goes up in Taiwan as it is a custom to offer fruits and other foods to "ghost brothers" in the hope that they will not disturb humans.
Juntai Department Store began promoting the fruits from Taiwan two days ago and will continue for a couple more days, Lu said.

According to Lu, sales of Taiwan fruits in Beijing have been "better than expected." Juntai's first day sales exceeded 15,000 yuan (NT$60,000 or US$1,888), and over 50,000 yuan-worth is expected to be sold over the weekend.

Chunlin Import Company said zero-tariff treatment for Taiwan fruits has not changed the fact that they remain quite expensive in Beijing. For instance, star fruits and guavas sell for 16 yuan per jin or 32 yuan (NT$125) per kilogram.
The importer added that Taiwan papayas sell for 20 yuan (NT$78) a kilo and pineapples, 19 yuan (NT$74) a kilo. When pineapple is on sale, the price will not go below 10 yuan (NT$40) a kilo.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT BUDGET PLANNING TO BE ADJUSTED: CABINET

TEXT.P: The government has agreed to adjust its budget appropriations for a long-stalled arms procurement package in order to facilitate its passage through the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Friday.
Cho made the remarks a day after President Chen Shui-bian said certain items in the arms procurement package can be financed with funds to be appropriated from the military's regular annual budget.
Chen's remarks were seen a government concession aimed at winning support from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" for the arms procurement package.

The opposition-controlled legislative Procedure Committee has stonewalled the inclusion of two arms procurement-related bills from being put on the legislative agenda in the past two sessions, depriving other lawmakers of the opportunity to debate the critical military procurement.

The two bills in question will pave the way for procuring eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States. One bill will authorize the administration to prepare a special budget for the NT$480 billion arms procurement package over a period of 15 years, the other bill is regarding budget appropriations for the package.

Cho said the government's 2006 budget plan will be re-arranged in line with President Chen's directive. As to details regarding the items and amount, Cho said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) will figure this out later.
"The MND is studying which item or items can be included in its annual budget plan, how much money is needed and how many years the budget plan should span," Cho said.
If all three of the items are covered in the MND's regular annual budget, Cho said, it may hinder other defense development projects.
Quoting Premier Frank Hsieh, Cho said the government's total expenditure for 2006 will not exceed NT$1.6 trillion.

After listening to a briefing on the government's 2006 budget plan Thursday, President Chen said military spending should be increased to 3 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) in three years with a view to beefing up Taiwan's self-defense capabilities in the face of China's growing military threat.
Cho said the Cabinet will make an overall review of its budget plan before determining how much the defense budget can be increased next year.

Commenting on reports about the government's plan to re-arrange the budget plan for the long-stalled arms procurement package, William Lai, a legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said the Cabinet should refrain from taking the initiative to re-arrange its budget plan until after a consensus has been reached through cross-party consultations.

"Without a prior cross-party consensus, the government could risk 'falling into an abyss' if it makes any unilateral concession, " Lai cautioned. To the best of his understanding, Lai said some "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers in the Legislative Defense Committee and the Legislative Procedural Committee had suggested that submarines and anti-submarine aircraft be covered under a special budget plan while the Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries be financed by the MND's regular annual budget.
"Moreover, it would be easier for the opposition parties to accept if the special budget be cut to NT$300 billion or NT$350 billion," Lai said.

DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung, also a co-convener of the Legislative Defense Committee, echoed Lai's view, saying that unless reaching a cross-party consensus in advance, the Cabinet should refer its original NT$480 billion special budget bill to the legislature and let the opposition parties to trim the amount to their desired level.

The legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- a DPP ally -- said it would be happy to see some items of the procurement package be covered by the regular military budget. It suggested that as the United States has 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft in stock for delivery to Taiwan, they should be covered the MND's regular budget while the submarines and the Patriot anti-missile batteries can be financed by a special budget.

The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said it welcomes the DPP administration's consent to its longtime advocacy that part of the arms procurement package be covered by regular budget and part of it financed by a special budget.
Tseng Yung-chuan, a KMT legislative whip, claimed the DPP's about-face was a victory for the opposition "pan-blue alliance."
The KMT's "pan-blue alliance" ally, the People First Party (PFP), said the DPP has finally moved in the right direction as far as the arms procurement project is concerned.
Nevertheless, PFP legislative whip Huang Yi-chiao said even if the DPP administration re-arranges its budget plan, the PFP may not necessarily endorse the two arms procurement bills.
"We'll screen the bills based on a combination of factors, including the nation's overall financial situation and practical defense needs," Huang said. (By Sofia Wu) ednitem/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT THANKS ROTARY CLUBS FOR HOSTING INT'L CONFERENCE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian thanked a group of leaders of local Rotary Clubs Friday for playing host to an international conference of regional Rotaract clubs in Taiwan later this month.

In a meeting at his office with leaders of local Rotary Clubs, the president said the purposes of Rotaract Clubs, which were launched by the Rotary Club International to encourage young men and women to serve their communities, are much the same as the spirit of volunteerism that he himself has advocated for years.

He lauded the leaders of local Rotary Clubs for their success in winning the chance to host the 2005 Asia Pacific Regional Rotaract Conference which is slated to begin in Tamshui, Taipei County Aug. 26-29.

The president, who himself is a Rotarian, said he is filled with modesty and humility when he thinks of the rapid development of the Rotary Club International, which has grown from a club of four members into an international network with more than 30,000 clubs and 1.2 million members in 166 countries over a hundred years.
Volunteer workers of International Rotary Clubs have done a great deal to promote understanding and peace across the globe through their selfless service.

Noting that Taiwan Rotarians have played an active role in the Rotary family, the president said he was certain that the Taiwan Rotarians will inspire other people on the island to follow their examples in serving their communities unselfishly.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX ROSE 2.37 PERCENT YEAR-ON-YEAR IN JULY: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) posted a growth of 2.37 percent in July over the same period of last year, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Friday, ascribing the surge to the skyrocketing prices of vegetables and fruits due to floods caused by Typhoon Haitang in mid-July.

With Typhoon Matsa sweeping through Taiwan on Friday, the second typhoon passing the island this year, it's possible that food prices could stay high in August, impacting the CPI for that month, DGBAS officials said.

Besides typhoons, the fact that the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. hiked its prices for fuel oil and natural gas by 7 percent and 3 percent Tuesday could push commodity prices further up in the upcoming months, they said.

However, under an established formula, if oil prices are raised 10 percent for a time of one year, the CPI is expected to climb 0.39 percentage points, so the recent oil price hikes are not likely to push the CPI to grow more than 0.2 percentage points this year, the officials added.
The DGBAS estimates that the CPI will rise 1.7 percent this year over the previous year. A review of this estimate will be made at some time in mid-August, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION MUST ONLY ADDRESS FLOOD-CONTROL BILL: KMT

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) reiterated Friday that if an extra legislative session is held during the summer recess, it should only screen the bill regarding flood control.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng is scheduled to return from a trip to the United States Aug. 10. He already asked legislative staff to arrange for cross-party consultations Aug. 11 to discuss the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus' request to hold a special legislative session to address several long-stalled bills.
According to Wang's promise prior to his departure for the U.S., an informal legislative gathering will be held Aug. 12 to discuss issues regarding the proposed special legislative session.

KMT legislative whip Tseng Yung-chuan said Friday the KMT would not budge from its stance that the proposed special legislative session only address the Cabinet-drafted eight-year, NT$80 billion flood-control bill.
"If the DPP insists on including other bills onto the agenda, the KMT will call for a vote during the Aug. 12 informal meeting on the agenda issue," Tseng said.

The KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally, the People First Party (PFP) , jointly control a slim majority in the legislature and have boycotted the DPP's policy initiatives at every turn in the past five years.
PFP legislative whip Huang Yi-chiao said his party is opposed to holding a special legislative session during the current summer recess.

"We have on many occasions articulated our opposition to the holding of an extra legislative session. Our stance remains unchanged, " Huang said, adding that he plans to attend the Aug. 11 consultations among legislative whips of parties of different political stripes to express the party's stance.

DPP legislative whip William Lai said he will pay courtesy calls on opposition legislative caucuses before the Aug. 12 informal legislative meeting to solicit their support for the party's proposal that an extra legislative session be held to address six urgent bills, including the flood-control bill, the arms procurement package and confirmation of the Control Yuan nominations.

"We hope that the opposition parties can put the overall national interest above their partisan feelings and agree to hold an extra session to address all those long-stalled and very critical bills, " Lai said.
The DPP's ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), said it looks forward to an early passage of the flood-control bill.

"While we would be pleased to see all the six DPP-sponsored bills clear the legislative floor as early as possible, our top goal is to have the flood-control bill passed as soon as possible for the common wellbeing of the people. If the 'pan-blue alliance' insists on only addressing one bill, we hope the DPP can accept this, " TSU legislative whip Ho Min-hao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER SUPPLY TO 635,000 HOUSEHOLDS IN TAOYUAN LIMITED AFTER TYPHOON

TEXT.P: The water supply to 635,000 households in Taoyuan County will be cut to every other day because Typhoon Matsa has muddied the water in the Shihmen Reservoir, which provides water to the water purification plant in Taoyuan.

Officials from the water plant said the water provided by the reservoir was too muddy to be treated and the plant has to alternate its supply to customers ever other day beginning from Saturday because of the heavy rain brought by Matsa, which swept through Taiwan Friday.

It was the second time in two consecutive years that the operation of the plant has ground to a halt in the wake of a typhoon that brought large amounts of rainfall to the catchment of the reservoir and increased the turbidity of the water by bringing down lots of mud and stirred up the sediment on the bottom of the reservoir.
The root cause of this problem is the change of stratum in the reservoir's catchment prompted by the earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999, according to the officials.

As a result, the earth of the catchment is more vulnerable to erosion and mudslides happen more often during rainfall, not to mention that the sediment which has deposit on the bottom of the 40-year-old reservoir and has almost silted up the body of water completely.

The officials said they tried to get around the problems by building a tunnel at the bottom of the reservoir to help release the sediment and raise the water intake to near the surface but neither projects are finished.
That means the shortage of water in Taoyuan might occur again should another typhoon hit the island this year, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE MILLION PASSENGERS HAVE USED 'MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: One million people have used the "mini three links" between Kinmen and Matsu and their designated ports in China as of the end of July this year since the direct ferry service started in 2001.
The Beijing-based China News Service reported Friday that during the three-and-a-half years, 8,330 voyages were made using the Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei routes.

Passenger numbers have expanded due to more and more Taiwanese businessmen operating in not only Fujian, but also other Chinese provinces using the service, while Taiwan tour groups, cultural and economic exchanges, or sporting events in China have also attracted people to use the links, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 6 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, August 6:
10:00, The Taipei Yi-ming Festival will open at the square in front of the Taipei City Hall in Taipei City.
11:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will open the Tainan Seventh Eve International Art Festival in Tainan City.
13:00, A training camp for leaders of Taiwan's Association of Supporters of Lee Teng-hui will open at the Tienmu International Conference Center in Shihlin, Taipei City.
14: 00, The Taiwan Solidarity Union will celebrate its founding anniversary at the Ambassador Hotel in Taipei.
15:10, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a ceremony marking the founding anniversary of the Taiwan Solidarity Union at the Ambassador Hotel in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 6, or the second day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1806: Holy Roman Emperor Francis II is forced to resign due to the third defeat in the war against Bonaparte Napoleon.
1825: Bolivia declares independence from Peru.
1890: A murderer named William Kemmler is the first prison executed by electric chair in the United States.
1914: Yuan Shih-kai declares China's neutrality in World War I.
1932: The first international film festival opens in Venice, Italy with 29 motion pictures from the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Soviet Union and Italy being shown.
1945: U.S. plane drops the first atomic bomb in Hiroshima, Japan, killing more than 90,000 and injuring over 9,000.
1949: At the invitation of Korean President Syngman Rhee, President Chiang Kai-shek flies to Chinhae, Korea to discuss the formation of a Pacific alliance.
1962: Jamaica declares independence from Britain.
1997: Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman Lacayo arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1997: A South Korean Boeing 747-300 jetliner crashes in Guam, killing 234 on board.
2001: After careful planning, prayer rooms are formally opened at CKS International Airport. The three adjacent prayer rooms have one room equipped with rush mats for kneeling, another fitted with rows of chairs and still another with mattresses and a mark to show the direction of Mecca.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW KMT CHAIRMAN URGED TO PUSH FOR QUICK PASSAGE OF ARMS PACKAGE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By C.C. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Caucus in the U.S. House of Representatives recently sent a letter to opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou, urging him to work for quick passage of a special arms procurement package in the Legislative Yuan.
The letter, which was jointly signed by three co-chairs of the caucus, including Reps. Robert Wexler (D-Fla.), Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) and Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), was sent to Ma Aug. 1.

Besides congratulating Ma on his July 16 election as the new chairman of the KMT, the representatives said in the letter that they want to reassure the new KMT head that the United States is fully committed to the security, prosperity and future of the people of Taiwan.

"All of us in the Congressional Taiwan Caucus are long-time friends and supporters of Taiwan and have closely followed Taiwan's remarkable path towards a flourishing multi-party democracy that respects human rights and the rule of law," they said in the letter.

They also said that they now look to Ma, in the tradition of past KMT chairman, to join them in enhancing the long-standing partnership and economic, cultural and security cooperation between Taiwan and the United States.

"In particular, we urge you, as the new chairman of the Kuomintang, to lead efforts in Taipei to ensure that the Legislative Yuan quickly passes a special arms procurement package or increases its annual defense spending, " the representatives further said, adding that "we believe as you do that cooperation between Taipei and Washington is paramount to Taiwan's security and is in the mutual interest of both nations."
The co-chairs also said that they would like to invite Ma to visit Washington, D.C. in September to address members of the caucus and engage in a dialogue relating to Taiwan-U.S. relations.

"Given the myriad of complex and difficult issues facing the two countries in the coming years, we believe your visit will be a positive step towards enhancing this historic partnership, " they continued.

Earlier this year, a similar letter signed jointly by 33 members of the caucus was sent to KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who will step down Aug. 18, calling for him to help stop the oppositions' boycott against the passage of the arms procurement package in the legislature as soon as possible.

The arms procurement package put forward by the Ministry of National Defense has been stalled for months in the Legislative Yuan due to opposition by lawmakers of the KMT and its ally, the People First Party.
According to the ministry, the items on the procurement list include eight diesel-powered submarines, six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Major Cuts at Hospital Urged. Los Angeles County health officials Thursday recommended dramatically scaling back the services offered by Martin Luther King Jr./Drew Medical Center, including closure of patient care wards devoted to pediatrics, obstetrics and neonatology, in their latest attempt to rescue the ailing public hospital.

DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Opposition leader asks for Bank of Italy governor's explanation.
The opposition Union Party leader, Romano Prodi, urged Bank of Italy Governor Antonio Fazio Friday to expain to the public his role in a recent scandal-surrounding merger of two domestic banks. At stake is the country's credibility, he claimed.

The Japan Times: Japan's opponent-free panel OKs thorny postal reform bills
A special committee of the House of Councilors passed a package of postal privatization bills Friday, pushing Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi toward a final showdown with reform foes in his Liberal Democratic Party in Monday's plenary session.

The Straits Times: Blair gets tough.
Foreigners who preach hatred or glorify terrorism could be deported under tough new security measures that British Prime Minister Tony Blair announced yesterday.

Some local people cooperate with foreigners to promote the political position in non-violent law breaking. DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTERS WITHOUT BORDERS CAMPAIGNS FOR RELEASE OF HONG KONG REPORTER
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Reporters Without Borders, an influential organization fighting for press freedom around the world, has launched an online petition campaign for the release of Ching Cheong, a Hong Kong-based correspondent for the Singapore daily Straits Times.

According to the organization, Ching, who was arrested on April 22 in the southern city of Guangzhou in mainland China and is now being detained in Beijing, was formally charged by the Chinese state security bureau Friday with selling economic, political and military information to Taiwanese agents for millions of dollars since 2000.
The organization said in a statement released Friday that it is outraged by the charge of spying against Ching, adding that Ching faces possible life imprisonment.
It also said that so far, more than 13,000 people have signed the petition for Ching's release. The petition is available at www.petition-chingcheong.org.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICAN PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco de la Espriella, at the head of a 14-member delegation, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Aug. 12 for a six-day state visit, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

At the invitation of the ROC government, Pacheco will attend the inauguration of the Democratic Pacific Union initiated by Vice President Annette Lu, and sign a joint comunique with President Chen Shui-bian.

Pacheco first visited Taiwan in October 2002 to participate in the ROC's national day celebrations in his capacity as the Costa Rican president. He visited again in August 2003 to attend the summit of heads of state of the ROC and its Central American allies.
Pacheco's August visit will be his third to Taiwan, which reflects the cordial relations between the two countries, a MOFA official said.
Pacheco's delegation will include Costa Rican Foreign Minister Roberto TovaR, Minister of Foreign Trade Manual Gonzalez and several members of the Legislative Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI THREE LINKS' VISIT TO CHINA 'GOOD IDEA': MA

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that he currently has no plans to visit China but that he believes a visit to the mainland via the "mini three links" route would be a good idea.

Ma also reiterated his promise to enlarge the "mini three links" -- referring to the direct trade, mail, and shipping links between Taiwan's two outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou ports in Fujian Province -- which were implemented in January 2001.
Ma, who is now Taipei City mayor, made the remarks during his visit to Kinmen -- part of his around-Taiwan visit aimed at soliciting the opinions of KMT members for the future reform of the party.

Pointing out that there were a total of 20,000 visits via the "mini three links" in the first year after the opening and that the figure is expected to exceed 500,000 this year, Ma said this reflects the strong desire of the Taiwan people to visit the mainland. He added that the role of China as the "world's factory" cannot be ignored.

Ma noted that he has been promoting the "mini three links " for a long time, saying that the links can save a lot of time for Taiwan people traveling to the mainland, who in the past had to shuttle between the two sides of Taiwan Strait via Hong Kong or Macau.

Concerning the initiatives proposed by Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who was defeated by Ma in the KMT chairmanship election July 16, to further promote cross-strait exchanges, Ma said that the proposals are viable and that he will consider carrying them out.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAM ACTS TO ATTRACT TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: A delegation organized by Vietnam's Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) is scheduled to hold a workshop Aug. 11 in Taipei as part of its efforts to attract Taiwan businesses to invest in Vietnam, officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Saturday.

The delegation, to be headed by Phan Huu Thang, chief of the MPI's Foreign Investment Agency, will be made up of MPI officials and ranking executives of two state-run companies -- Vietnam Steel Corp. and Electricity of Vietnam Corp.

At the one-day workshop to be held at the Taipei International Convention Center, the group will introduce the investment environment and relevant regulations on investing in Vietnam. Taiwan businesspeople considering investing in the Southeast Asian country are welcome to attend the workshop, according to the Vietnam Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei.
Those interested can obtain more details on the upcoming event by calling the office at (02) 2516-6626, Ext. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND YET TO DECIDE ON WHICH ARMS TO BE LISTED UNDER ANNUAL BUDGET

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Saturday that it has yet to decide on which items of an arms procurement package to place in its regular annual budget as it has yet to receive directives from the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan.

MND officials were responding to media reports that in order to facilitate passage of the arms procurement package by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, the MND will not insist on all three items of the NT$480 billion (US$15.24 billion) package being financed by a special budget.

The three items in the arms procurement from the United States to be financed over a 15-year period are six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-fueled submarines, and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.
According to the media reports, the MND hopes to have the submarines and aircraft financed by a special budget, with the Patriot batteries to be included in the (ministry's) regular annual budget.

One day after President Chen Shui-bian said that certain items of the arms procurement package could be financed with funds to be appropriated for the military's regular annual budget, a spokesman of the Executive Yuan said Friday that the Cabinet will make necessary adjustments in its annual budget for next year but that the MND will study which items, the amount, and the financing period of the package to be listed in the regular annual budget.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) have blocked the arms procurement package from being put on the legislative agenda in the past two sessions, mainly because of the high price tag and the manner of financing it with a special budget.

However, a ray of hope seems to have appeared for the arms procurement package as outgoing KMT Chairman Lien Chan has said his party could accept a special budget if a proper amount of the funds for the package are included in the military's regular annual budget.
If the administration "doesn't create further trouble, " the Legislative Yuan could pass the arms procurement package in the next session, he further said.
KMT Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou said that he will not oppose the arms procurement package simply because it is listed under a special budget.

Ma, who recently received a letter from the Taiwan Caucus -- a pro-Taiwan group in the U.S. House of Representatives -- urging him to work for early passage of the arms procurement package, said that the KMT could agree to some items in the package being financed with a special budget.

Ma said he gives his "conditional support" for the arms procurement package, adding that a due amount of spending on national defense is necessary and that his party should review the issue in a rational way.

However, Sun Ta-chien, a whip of the PFP caucus in the Legislative Yuan, said that special budgets should not become common practice, especially at a time when the government's financial situation is worsening. Sun also said that lawmakers have to consider the "urgency, necessity and price tag" of each item of the arms procurement separately.

Meanwhile, PFP Legislator Lin Yu-fang said that whether to finance the arms procurement package with a special budget or in the regular annual budget is beside the point, stressing that what matters is that the KMT and the PFP make a prior assessment of defense needs, costs, and industrial cooperation deals as well as possible cross-strait tension triggered by the arms procurement.
Lin said he will soon call on KMT Chairman-elect Ma to discuss the arms procurement issues with him.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ANTI-PIRACY EFFORTS BEAR FRUIT: IPO

TEXT.P: After a year-long crackdown on commercial piracy, Taiwan has successfully had its name removed from the IFPI's watch list of 10 countries with high piracy rates, the Intellectual Property Office (IPO) said Saturday.

The IPO quoted the 2005 IFPI business piracy report as saying that Taiwan was no longer among the 31 countries that the IFPI found to have larger domestic sales of pirated music CDs than of genuine copies last year.
The IFPI represents the recording industry worldwide with over 1,450 members in 75 countries and affiliated industry associations in 48 countries.

One-third of the music CDs sold in markets around the world last year were pirated copies, representing 1.2 billion copies at a total value of US$4.6 billion -- a figure which does not include illegal downloading from the Internet, according to the IFPI report.
Besides Taiwan, Canada and South Korea were also taken off the list due to their improved piracy situation.

Meanwhile, in the latest assessment by the International Intellectual Property Alliance (IIPA) , a coalition of associations representing U.S. copyright-based industries, Taiwan saw losses of some US$320.4 million in the recording business due to piracy over the past year, for a drop of 31 percent from the previous year's figure.

The IIPA also assessed that Taiwan's movie piracy rate decreased from the 44 percent registered in 2003 to 40 percent in 2004, while the music piracy rate dropped from 42 percent to 36 percent, according to the IPO.

Encouraged by the improved records, the IPO is further expanding its intellectual property protection efforts to the software industry in the hopes of seeing Taiwan cut its software piracy rate to less than 40 percent, IPO officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO MAJOR INTRAPARTY PERSONNEL CHANGE BEFORE YEAR-END ELECTIONS: MA

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that there will be no major intraparty personnel reshuffle before the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections.

Ma, who is incumbent mayor of Taipei and is set to assume the KMT chairmanship Aug. 19, made the remarks while meeting KMT rank-and-file members on the outlying island of Kinmen, which lies closer to China than to Taiwan.
During the meeting, many party members urged Ma to push for sweeping intraparty reforms after taking over the party's helm, including direct elections of local chapter heads by rank-and-file members.
Noting that his determination to launch wide-ranging party reforms is beyond question, Ma said timing is very important to the fate of a reform program.
For instance, Ma said, the KMT's decision-making Central Standing Committee already passed a resolution in March this year requiring direct elections for local chapter heads.

"But less than four months are left before the Dec. 3 simultaneous elections for city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors and township chiefs. If I push for a major intraparty reshuffle immediately after assuming the chairmanship, it could run against the conventional wisdom of 'refraining from changing the guard before a battle, '" Ma said.
As 72 percent of KMT members have voiced support for sweeping intraparty reforms, Ma said he has always kept in mind this resounding call for a revamp of the party.

In the short term, Ma said, the party will only undergo minor personnel changes to avoid affecting the party's chances of winning in the year-end "three-in-one" elections. In the long run, Ma said, he will see to it that complementary measures are mapped out to ensure that directly-elected local chapter heads live up to party and public expectations.

Noting that his ultimate goal in participating in the KMT chairmanship election was to help the party regain the presidency in 2008, Ma said he will make every possible effort to realize that goal after he assumes office.

He also revealed certain key points to be addressed in his inaugural speech, including reaffirming the KMT's opposition to pursuing Taiwan independence and China's "one country, two systems" unification formula as well as the party's desire for improving cross-Taiwan Strait relations under the principle of "one China, separate definitions."
In his inaugural speech, Ma said, he will call for the establishment of a military confidence-building mechanism and a platform for boosting cross-strait trade and economic exchanges.
Ma further said outgoing KMT Chairman Lien Chan's major policy initiatives will be incorporated into his blueprint for the KMT's future policy lines and work agenda.
He will also propose at the party's upcoming national congress that Lien's five "visions" for cross-strait peace be enshrined as the party congress' resolution.
With a view to promoting intraparty harmony and unity, Ma said he will continue persuading Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to serve as the KMT's first vice chairman.

Both Ma and Wang are incumbent KMT vice chairmen. After suffering an embarrassing defeat in the KMT chairmanship election, Wang said he will no longer concurrently serve as KMT vice chairman and will focus on his job as legislative speaker. However, Wang also promised to serve as a lifelong volunteer for the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILAN CHILDREN'S FOLKGAME FESTIVAL FEATURES ROBOT PAVILION

TEXT.P: Several fascinating robots are being displayed at a special pavilion at the ongoing 2005 Ilan Children's Folklore and Folkgame Festival, organizers said Saturday.
Robots that can do push-ups, sommersaults, or even hip-hop dances are just some of the interesting things that await visitors to the pavilion.

To give visitors a better understanding of robots, the pavilion has been divided into many educational sections dedicated to introducing facts regarding robots and the way robots are made, the organizers said.
The festival is set to run through Aug. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG LOOKS FORWARD TO HOUSING PANDAS: MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Saturday that if the pair of pandas promised by China as a gift to Taiwan are sent to the central Taiwan city, they will be housed in the scenic spot of Takeng in northern Taichung.
Hu said that this is because Takeng, known as the "Yangmingshan of Taichung," has more bamboo, the main food of pandas.
Hu made the remarks one day after outgoing Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said at a farewell party in Taichung that if the pair of pandas come to Taiwan, they will first be housed in Taichung.

Hu said Taichung has for three-and-a-half years actively sought to house pandas from China. Noting that although Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has also actively sought to have Taipei Zoo house the pandas, Hu said that Ma has never shown any sign that he is against Taichung having the honor.

If the pandas are housed in Taichung, Hu said he will not rule out the possibility of having them shown in southern Taiwan in order to avoid the inconvenience for people in that region of traveling to Taichung to see the pandas.

China offered to send a pair of pandas to the Taiwan people as a goodwill gift at the conclusion of opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China in early May. However, the pandas have yet to be delivered as the Taiwan government says it is handling the matter cautiously.

A senior official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council said recently that the pandas can be sent to Taiwan on four conditions -- namely that appropriate application procedures are followed, that a suitable living environment for the pandas is found, the all relevant regulations on delivery are abided by, and that approval is obtained by major international conservation groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCHER SUGGESTS FOCUSING ON SHOPPING TO ATTRACT CHINESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: After Taiwan opens up to tourists from China, Taiwan tourism promoters should focus on catering to Chinese tourists' shopping habits in trying to attract more tourists from that country, a researcher from the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) suggested Saturday.

Sun Ming-teh made the remarks in his report on the consumption pattern of Chinese tourists, following the promise made by Premier Frank Hsieh in late July to start negotiations with Beijing on opening Taiwan up to tourists from the mainland.

Citing a survey conducted by the marketing information company AC Nielsen and the Tax Free World Association on 1,500 Chinese tourists from Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou who visited Asian or European countries in the last six months, Sun said the consumption patterns of Chinese tourists are quite different from those of tourists from other countries.

According to the survey, Chinese tourists rank second in the world in terms of amount of spending during a single foreign visit, trailing only Japanese tourists. However, in spending on shopping, Chinese tourists top the list at an average of US$987 per person.

Meanwhile, a survey conducted by Taiwan's Tourism Bureau in 2004 showed that 47.5 percent of spending by foreign tourists in Taiwan was on hotel accommodations, followed by spending on shopping at 21.3 percent. However, among Chinese tourists, including those from Hong Kong and Macau, spending on hotel accommodations stood at only 40.6 percent, while spending on shopping accounted for a whopping 27.2 percent of total spending per visit.

Analyzing the results, Sun said that European and American tourists generally focus on "leisure and culture" on their vacations, demanding hotels with good facilities such as swimming pools and showing more interest in cultural performances and unique local handicrafts and art work.

Chinese tourists, on the other hand, are not as concerned about the quality of hotel accommodations and are more eager to visit popular tourist spots to take photos, and tend to focus on shopping for items such as brand-name clothes, cosmetics, jewelry and electric home appliances, Sun pointed out.

Most of the Chinese tourists are people from wealthy costal areas, government officials, or employees of state enterprises, who generally tend to have higher incomes or enjoy government subsidies for air tickets, hotel accommodations and food, Sun continued.

Noting that although Taiwan's shopping environment is not superior to that of Hong Kong or Macau, and although there is still no direct transport between the two sides of Taiwan Strait, Sun said the spending of Chinese tourists in Taiwan is still high.
He suggested that domestic tourist agents focus on shopping to cater to the special tastes of Chinese tourists in order to attract greater numbers of visitors from that potentially lucrative market.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONEY PRODUCT FESTIVAL KICKS OFF IN KAOHSIUNG COUNTY

TEXT.P: A honey product festival kicked off Saturday on Takan Mountain in Kaohsiung County, with the scene of six beekeepers covered in thousands of bees being one of the most interesting spectacles.
Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing presided the opening of the festival, which will run through Aug. 14.

According to Yang, the festival, which includes honey product sampling opportunities, a photo exhibition, a packaging design show, and several competitions for both parents and kids, is the product of efforts by members of the industrial, cultural and tourist sectors, as well as environmental activists.

Yang noted that honey produced on Takan Mountain has been ranked the best in Taiwan by the government for years, adding that he hopes the festival will help improve the image of the honey industry and increase the earnings of beekeepers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS UNVEIL NEW STAMPS TO PROMOTE TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Pro-Taiwan independence unveiled a set of four commemorative stamps in Los Angeles Friday as part of a "call Taiwan, Taiwan" campaign to rectify the island's official designation.

Shen Pei-chih, secretary-general of the "Please Support Taiwan to Join the United Nations," one of the four sponsors of the activities, said that they hope to have the four kinds of commemorative postage stamps, with no monetary value, posted on mail sent around the world to raise Taiwan's international profile.

Shen said the printing of the postage stamps, including one to commemorate the 228 Incident, was inspired by the government's earlier decision to add the word "Taiwan" to Republic of China passports to avoid confusion with mainland Chinese passports.

He said that the postage stamps were printed in Taiwan and were originally meant to be unveiled in Taipei and Los Angeles simultaneously. However, the unveiling in Taipei was postponed until mid-August because of the onslaught of Typhoon Matsa. The sponsors will now rent a pavilion at the 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition in Taipei Aug.19-24 to promote the stamps.

In addition, the sponsors also designed a license plate sticker with the image of Taiwan on it, he said, urging car owners to use the stickers to show their support for the "call Taiwan, Taiwan" campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPES TO HAVE 6 KEY BILLS REVIEWED IN SPECIAL LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: A whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus in the Legislative Yuan urged again on Saturday that six prioritized bills be discussed in a proposed special session of the legislature.

William Lai made the appeal after the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) insisted that it will only agree to a special session if the session is only for reviewing the Executive Yuan's eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-prevention project.

Lai stressed that a special session should not only discuss the flood-prevention proposal, saying that the NT$480 billion arms procurement package, the confirmation of Control Yuan members, proposed amendments to the Executive Yuan Organic Law, proposed amendments to the tobacco and liquor tax law, and a draft bill concerning the establishment of a labor pension fund monitoring committee are also urgent matters that need to be dealt with.
All six bills should be reviewed in the special session and should not be left to the next regular session, Lai said.

He said that the DPP caucus will communicate with the Taiwan Solidarity Union, the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, and the KMT and its ally, the People First Party (PFP) , Monday to seek support for reviewing the six bills in a special session.
Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng is scheduled to preside over an informal meeting Aug. 12 to decide on whether to convene a special session, to which the PFP is adamantly opposed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUNDATION TEACHES DROPOUTS HOW TO HELP SELVES BY HELPING OTHERS

TEXT.P: Five high-school dropouts paid a visit to sick children at Mennonite Christian Hospital in the eastern city of Hualien Saturday in an activity organized by the Chou Ta-kuan Cultural and Educational Foundation.

The visit was organized by the foundation to bring joy to the sick children and to encourage the dropouts to strive to improve themselves by teaching them the rewards of helping others, according to Chou Chin-hua, founder of the foundation.

Last year, the five youths, abandoned by their families and schools, received scholarships from the foundation as part of a program to help school dropouts to gain confidence in themselves and to strive to make something out of their lives.

There are currently more than 13,200 high-school dropouts in Taiwan, according to Chou, who said these individuals are most in need of society's care. He said the foundation's program is aimed at changing the public's perceptions of school dropouts and at providing these abandoned youths with a hand up and with opportunities to participate in meaningful activities such as Saturday's hospital visit in order to instill in them a sense of self-worth.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOOD-CONTROL PROJECT SHOULD INCLUDE SHIHMEN RESERVOIR UPGRADE

TEXT.P: Taoyuan Magistrate Chu Li-lun said Saturday that funds for the improvement works on a reservoir in the northern county should be included in the Cabinet's proposed eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-control project.
Chu made the remarks while presiding over a meeting attended by 13 city and township chiefs and water company officials to discuss the county's water-supply problem.
Chu noted that since Typhoon Aere struck in August, 2004, the county has faced a water supply problem that he said has been aggravated by Typhoon Haitang in mid-July and Typhoon Matsa this week.

He said that he will meet with Premier Frank Hsieh next Monday to report to him about the water shortage problem and to urge him to include the improvement works on the Shihmen Reservoir in the Cabinet's flood-control project so as to solve his county's water-supply problem once and for all.

Saturday's meeting was held only a day after Typhoon Matsa brought torrential rains that polluted water sources of the Shihmen Reservoir, resulting in more than 635,000 households in Taoyuan County only having access to water on a rotational basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN VOWS TO PROTECT TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGNTY IN ENGAGEMENTS WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Saturday that ensuring Taiwan's survival and sovereign status is his administration's paramount principle for engagements across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen made the reaffirmation while attending a ceremony marking the fourth anniversary of the founding of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) which is an ally of Chen's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the legislature.

As relations between the two parties hit some snags recently over cross-strait policy and local government election affairs, Chen took the opportunity to assure TSU politicians that his administration will not waver on its insistence on Taiwan's separate identity from that of China and its pledge to protect Taiwan's sovereignty and eventually make Taiwan a "normal, complete, advanced and great" country.
Chen outlined the "one principle, " "three insistences" and "five oppositions" for his administration's engagements with China.

The "one principle" refers to protecting Taiwan's sovereign status, Chen said, adding that his administration looks forward to hold dialogue and consultations with China under the principle of "democracy, parity and peace."

With a view to achieving domestic political stability and pursuing a breakthrough in deadlocked cross-strait relations, Chen said his administration is seeking reconciliation with opposition parties and cross-strait detente.

But Chen stressed that the detente will be based on "three insistences" -- continued democratic reform, Taiwan's separate identity from that of China's, and developing Taiwan into a "normal, complete, advanced and great" country.

In the process, Chen said his administration will adhere to its "five oppositions" -- opposing Beijing's "one China" principle and its "one country, two systems" unification terms as well as the so-called "1992 consensus" which embodies the "one China" principle, any proposal that upholds unification as the only option for Taiwan's future and China's anti-secession law that codifies the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan.
In his congratulatory speech, Chen also said both the DPP and the TSU agree that China is currently the biggest threat to Taiwan's national security.
While the two parties are "ideological allies" and "action partners, " Chen said the two parties' missions and roles probably differ slightly at the moment.
As the ruling party, Chen said, the DPP cannot completely deny the history of the Republic of China's evolution.
Chen's remarks were seen a veiled effort to remind the TSU that the DPP cannot support its campaign to change Taiwan's present official designation -- the Republic of China.

Chen told TSU politicians that he recently came up with a theory of "four stages of the Republic of China (ROC)" in an attempt to give the public a clear and definitive idea about his ideas regarding Taiwan's sovereignty and national identity.

In the first stage, the ROC was established in China in 1912. In 1949, the ROC "moved" to Taiwan. In the third stage, during the time when Lee Teng-hui was president (1988-2000), "the ROC on Taiwan" was the catch-phrase used to describe the nation, according to Chen. Lee concurrently headed the then-ruing party Kuomintang, but he was ousted from the party in 2001 because of his pro-independence advocacy. Lee is now the TSU's spiritual leader.
In the fourth stage after 2000, with the first peaceful transfer of power between different political parties in the ROC's history, the new phrase should be "the ROC is Taiwan," Chen said.
He noted that prior to 1949, the ROC had nothing to do with Taiwan because the island was under Japanese rule from 1895 until 1945.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIR CONFIRMS MAC VICE CHAIR NAMED FOR SEF SECRETARY-GENERAL POST

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung confirmed Saturday that Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman You Ying-lung has been named to take over the post of SEF secretary-general from Liu Teh-hsun, who is also a MAC vice chairman.

Chang indicated that You was recommended by the MAC and national security units to serve in the post of secretary-general of the SEF, the quasi-official body dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait relations in the absence of official ties between Taiwan and China.
Pointing out that he didn't take the initiative to make the personnel change, Chang said he feels both You and Liu are suitable individuals to serve as SEF secretary-general.
The naming of You for the post must be approved by the Executive Yuan before being sent to the SEF board of directors for review, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CELEBRATES 4TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) celebrated its fourth founding anniversary Saturday.
Both President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui attended he TSU's celebration party.
In his congratulatory speech, Chen first expressed his heartfelt gratitude for the TSU's full support for his re-election bid a year ago.

As relations between the TSU and Chen's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) hit some snags recently over policy toward China and local election affairs, Chen took the opportunity to assure TSU politicians that protecting Taiwan's sovereignty will always be his administration's paramount principle for engagements with China. "The DPP administration will never waver on its insistence on Taiwan's separate identity from that of China and its pledge to protect Taiwan's sovereignty and eventually make Taiwan a 'normal, complete, advanced and great' country," Chen said.
Branding the DPP and the TSU as "ideological allies and action partners, " Chen said the two parties have shared goals of strengthening Taiwan's national identity and sustainable development.
"Any rifts between us over electoral competition should not obstruct our cooperation in pursuing our common goals," Chen said.

Speaking on the same occasion, former President Lee who is the TSU's spiritual leader urged TSU politicians to stand united and do their best to ensure that the party's nominees for the year-end "three-in-one" elections succeed in their electoral bids.
Other well-wishers included Vice President Annette Lu, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang and many pro-independence veterans.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL LOSSES FROM TYPHOON MATSA ESTIMATED AT NT$4.7 MILLION

TEXT.P: Typhoon Matsa caused an estimated NT$4.7 million in agricultural losses around Taiwan, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Saturday.

About 368 hectares of cropland was devastated by Matsa, the second typhoon to hit Taiwan this year. COA officials said. Matsa, named after a Laotian fish, battered northern Taiwan with strong winds and torrential rains Friday.
According to COA officials, banana and pear crops were hardest hit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG AIRPORT TO BE EXPANDED TO ACCOMMODATE MORE CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The first phase of expansion of the Chingchuankang Airport in the central county of Taichung will be accelerated to accommodate more charter flights, Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng said Saturday.

Chang made the remarks after an inspection tour of the Chingchuankang Airport which is located at a military air base. Chang was accompanied by Chang Jing-sen, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, and Chiu Tai-san, a former vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council who will run for Taichung County magistrateship.

To allow for central Taiwan businessmen operating in China to return for the 2006 Chinese Lunar New Year celebrations via direct cross-strait charter flights, Chang said the first phase of Chingchuankang airport expansion project will be sped up so that it can be ready in time to accommodate those special charter flights.

The airport now can only accommodate domestic flights and a limited number of medium-range international charter flights. It cannot accommodate regular international flights until after its first-phase expansion project is completed in 2008.

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Some Bombs Used in Iraq Are Made in Iran, U.S. Says
Many of the new, more sophisticated roadside bombs used to attack American and government forces in Iraq have been designed in Iran and shipped in from there, United States military and intelligence officials said Friday, raising the prospect of increased foreign help for Iraqi insurgents. The new weapons are specially designed to destroy armored vehicles, military bomb experts say.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Aug. 7:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 7, or the 3rd day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa as the capital of the Dominion of Canada.
1903: Louis Leakey, British anthropologist, is born. He uncovered crucial evidence of man's early evolution, including a 1,750,000-year-old skull.
1904: Ralph Johnson Bunche, American diplomat, is born. He helped found the United Nations and won the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the 1949 Arab-Israeli truce.
1912: Japan and Russia sign an agreement determining their spheres of influence in Manchuria and Mongolia.
1913: Samuel Cody, American aviator, becomes Britain's first air fatality when his plane crashes at Famborough.
1942: U.S. marines land on Guadalcanal in the Pacific during World War II.
1945: The Soviet Union declares war on Japan seven days before the Japanese surrender in World War II.
1948: The Yangtze River overflows its banks, forcing three million people into homelessness.
1952: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the designation of July 1, instead of January 1, as the beginning of the fiscal year.
1957: The ROC Navy sinks four Communist Chinese warships south of Kinmen.
1957: Oliver Hardy, the husky one in the Laurel and Hardy comic-duo who made more than 100 films from 1926 until 1950, dies of a stroke at the age of 65.
1959: The worst floods in more than 60 years hit central and southern Taiwan, killing 1,075 people, injuring 852, and causing more than NT$3.4 billion in property damage.
1974: Pingtung's Mei Ho Senior Little League baseball team leaves for Gary, Indiana, to participate in the 1974 Little League World Series.
1974: Paul Hogberg, president of the International Handball Federation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: Vice Foreign Minister H.K. Yang meets with President Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay.
1976: Kin Aziwa, newly-appointed deputy chief of the Japanese Interchange Association, Taipei Office, arrives to assume his post.
1983: Communist Chinese air force pilot Sun Tien-chin flies his MiG-21 jetfighter to South Korea to seek political asylum. He arrived in Taipei on Aug. 24.
1987: The leaders of Nicaragua, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Costa Rica sign a 14-page peace plan in Guatemala City aiming to settle a 10-year-old conflict in the region.
1990: President George Bush orders U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to defend against Iraq.
1992: Beijing signs an agreement with Washington promising to probe any allegations that goods produced by prison labor are being shipped to U.S. markets.
1998: Bombs explode almost at the same time outside the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing more than 80 people and injuring over one thousand others.
1999: The Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew ends a five-day visit to Macedonia after a meeting with his Macedonian counterpart Ljubco Georgievski.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng says the KMT is happy that President Chen Shui-bian has decided to hold a multiparty roundtable meeting to discuss major national issues with the heads of the opposition parties.
2001: The third cross-strait symposium about sports terms opens in Taipei, with sports representatives from Taiwan and mainland China sitting down to discuss the "unification" of various sports terms between the two sides.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."
