DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA STEEL DEVELOPS HIGH-STRENGTH STEEL FOR AUTO INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp. -- one of Taiwan's 12 state-run enterprises -- has successfully developed a new generation of steel for Taiwan's automotive industry to produce cars with reduced weight without compromising performance.

A spokesman for China Steel said Sunday that the high-strength, hot-dip galvanized steel with dual phase not only can reduce the weight of the vehicle, but also can make the frame of the car stronger and safer.

The spokesman pointed out that against the backdrop of rising international oil prices, more and more new car buyers are setting their eyes on cars that are more fuel efficient, and that one way to produce such cars is to reduce the weight of the car.

He said that China Steel's new product is an answer to the market's changing needs, and that a number of auto companies have given favorable evaluations to the product and decided to use it for their new cars.

The high-strength steel, designed to resist corrosion by being zinc coated, is easier to form and weld. It allows designers to use less material in critical components without compromising performance. Lighter cars can reduce fuel consumption by up to 10 percent, the China Steel spokesman claimed.
He said China Steel will continue to try and develop better high-strength steel sheets to help Taiwan's automotive and related industries improve their competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT THANKS THOSE WHO GIVE TO OTHERS SELFLESSLY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met members of the benevolent organization called "Education 100" Sunday to thank them for their work over the past year.

Chen said that members and supporters of "Education 100" -- which groups philanthropists from all walks of life in Taiwan -- have "cultivated" and "irrigated" the land of Taiwan with love and hope since the group's inception in July of last year.

"Education 100" includes lawyers, fruit sculptors, masters of traditional handicrafts on the verge of extinction, a man who runs backward, a blind marathoner and a number of rags-to-riches entrepreneurs. Chen said he hopes that "Education 100" will go on to spread the seeds of love to other peoples in the five continents around the world to help them find happiness.

Likening "Education 100" to Taiwan's national agricultural aid missions that have been helping others around the world for the past 40 years, Chen said that members of "Education 100" have been on grassroots missions far and wide throughout the country over the past year to help the people.
Chen said that the Taiwan people's hard-working ethics and can-do spirit are the most invaluable assets of the nation and the characteristics that have touched him the most.
Chen toasted the growth and expansion of "Education 100" over tea with all the people taking part in a gala party held at the Presidential Office Plaza marking the group's first anniversary.
Other activities in the gala included a tour of the Presidential Office and various outdoor folk concerts and art performances.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S UTILITY RATES LOWEST AMONG FOUR 'ASIAN TIGERS': DPP

TEXT.P: Taiwan's utility rates are the lowest among the four " Asian Tigers, " a legislative party whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Sunday.
William Lai said that despite spiralling international oil prices -- Taiwan is almost wholly dependant on imported oil -- the DPP administration has tried its best to keep utility rates down.

Defending the administration amid accusations that it has failed to oversee the rise of inflation and unemployment, leading the country's "misery index" to shoot up to a record high, Lai said that the rise in inflation is temporary and is due to the last two typhoons that hit the island over the past month with many areas in southern Taiwan being flooded.
Lai called for concerted efforts from both the ruling and opposition parties to jointly solve the current problems.

According to Lai, Taiwan not only has the lowest oil costs and electricity and water rates of the four "Asian Tigers " -- Taiwan, Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea -- its tap water is even cheaper than in most Southeast Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINORITY PARTIES OFFER IMPROVEMENTS TO FLOOD CONTROL BUDGET

TEXT.P: Two opposition parties Sunday said that the government-proposed NT$80 billion flood-control project must be applied to whatever areas are identified by the Water Resources Agency as in need of improvement.

The TSU and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) , another minority party in the legislature, offered their views as Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng has called a "talking session" Aug. 12 to decide whether or not to open a special summer session to discuss the government's proposal for passing the special budget to fight floods.

The NPSU, which supports the budget proposal conditionally, said conservation of land and water in upstream areas should also take a share of the special budget in order for the nation's flood-control efforts to succeed.

Lin Ping-kun, the secretary-general of the NPSU's legislative caucus, said even if the government needs to increase the special eight-year budget to NT$120 billion, his caucus will try to gain the support of other caucuses so that "the job can be done thoroughly."

Lin's TSU counterpart, Ho Min-hao, also said the government's budget proposal needs to be improved before his party will support it. Ho advised the government not to use the budget to play politics prior to the year-end county and city elections.
He noted that Taoyuan County, led by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Magistrate Chu Li-lun, has been suffering from water shortage as the Shihmen Dam has serious sedimentation problems.

Ho said he agrees that Chu's request to include Shihmen Dam as one of the targets of the program is "based on fact, " and therefore should be considered by the Water Resources Agency of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
He also cited the Mayuantou River estuary in Taichung City as a place that could be addressed by the flood control program. Taichung's mayor, Jason Hu, is also a KMT member.

KMT Legislator Chu Feng-chih from Taoyuan County said she suspects that the Ministry of Economic Affairs does not have a long-range plan to fight floods, causing people in Taoyuan to suffer again from typhoon-induced water shortages. Water is still being rationed there in the wake of Typhoon Matsa last week.
Torrential rains caused by last September's Typhoon Aere wreaked havoc with the water supply system in Taoyuan, leading to a 19-day water shortage.

Chu said dredging the Shihmen Dam and upgrading the area's water cleaning capability are huge projects beyond a county government's financial ability and they "certainly need the assistance of the central government."

DOC.HEADLINE: SLOGANS CAN'T EASE PEOPLE'S PAIN CAUSED BY RISING PRICES: TSU

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on Sunday called on the government to "do something" to ease people's discomfort caused by rising living expenses, as shouting slogans will not help.

Ho Min-hao, convener of the party's legislative caucus, pointed out that gasoline prices, tuition, air fares and so forth have been rising, and it's "an undeniable fact" that people are feeling the pinch because of it.

Water and electricity rates have not yet been adjusted, but health insurance premiums, transportation costs, university tuition and other daily necessities' prices have all "quietly gone up" while most people's salaries and wages have not risen, Ho added.

Price hikes, plus rising employment and other factors such as political fighting have increased the so-called "pain index, " but Premier Frank Hsieh has claimed that the prices of major items have been rising "by the narrowest margin in recent years" as he called on the public not to panic over oil price hikes.

Ho said people's sense of pain is a matter of "feeling" that will not be comforted by icy statistics and beautiful slogans. He urged the government to "respect people's feelings" because their pain will not go away simply because the government has made some claims.

He cheered the government for beginning to reform the nation's health care and taxation systems, but urged the government to take actions to realize social justice and fairness rather than merely increasing public relations efforts.
"The government should actively convince people and try to pass reform bills at the legislature so people can finally rest assured they've seen a shred of light at the end of the tunnel," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Tunisian charter plane crashes in the sea, at least 13 killed and two missing.
A charter plane of Tunisian airline Tuninter crashed in the sea off southern Italy Saturday. At least 13 persons were killed while another two were missing. All the 34 passengers on board are Italian.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE TENG-HUI OPPOSED TO 'MINI THREE LINKS' BETWEEN PENGHU, CHINA

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui expressed his strong opposition Sunday against the Cabinet's plan to push for direct trade, post and shipping -- referred to as the "mini three links"-- between Penghu and China.

Addressing a cadres training camp session of the Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association, Lee warned that if the Cabinet insists on pushing for the plan, he and his supporters will stage a demonstration on the streets to protest.

He criticized the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -led government for using the "mini three links" proposal to curry favor from the people after having apparently lost face for failing to stop Taiwan fruit farmers from selling to the Chinese market by taking advantage of the tariff-free treatment offered by Beijing.

Noting that the government has formulated an "active opening, effective management" policy on the exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, especially with regard to the transfer of high technology, Lee said the more he talks about this, the angrier he gets with the DPP government.
"Where is the management? You can't just do it with your mouth!" he said.

On Beijing's tariff-free treatment for Taiwan-grown fruits, Lee said the DPP government's reaction is "dumb." "Why not unite with other countries, such as Japan, and demand that China grant tariff-free treatment to all of them?"
He said that in extending the favor to Taiwan's fruit farmers, Beijing meant to let the world know that Taiwan's central government is in Beijing.

The former president, who ruled Taiwan for 12 years until 2000 while the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) was the ruling party, also said that there is no need for the people of Taiwan to fear a Chinese military invasion because to do so would take at least 10 divisions of the Chinese army -- a job he described as "impossible."

Furthermore, Lee said, the United States has eight nuclear-powered submarines patrolling the waters of the Pacific Ocean and some 2,000 nuclear warheads pointed at China -- enough to tie the hands of Beijing.

On the opposition parties' refusal to pass a budget in the legislature for procuring advanced weaponry from the United States, Lee said Taiwan should not "take a free ride" on its relationship with the United States. In his view, the U.S. government will drive this point home when Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou visits Washington in his capacity as the KMT's new chairman.

The former president, who has become a strong advocate of Taiwan independence after being ousted from the KMT chairmanship when the party lost the 2000 presidential election, reiterated his position that Taiwan must enter the United Nations, change its country name to Taiwan and adopt a new constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLINE 'SUPPORT TAIWAN'S BID TO UN' PETITION KICKS OFF
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Lu-sheng Chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An online petition -- supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations -- has been started by a group of pro-Taiwan overseas Chinese and Taiwanese residing in the greater Los Angeles area.

The online petition encourages all overseas Chinese and Taiwanese around the world to sign the petition, which urges the UN to reconsider the issue of Taiwan and its 23 million people's representation in the UN.

According to a written news release from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in L.A., the 60th U.N. General Assembly is scheduled to open Sept. 13, with issues regarding UN reforms and the strengthening and overhauling of UN organizations topping the agenda.

In light of the unfair truth that Taiwan has been excluded from the UN for decades, the group of people from the overseas Chinese and Taiwanese communities in California organized the online petition for Taiwan's cause, the news release said.

The organizers said that Taiwan is a democratic nation that respects human rights, freedom and peace. Taiwan meets all the requirements of UN membership. Taiwan stands ready to take its rightful place among the member states of the United Nations. Including Taiwan in the United Nations would make the world body more representative, comprehensive and effective, according to the news release.

It makes little sense that Taiwan is ignored when considering the fact that Taiwan serves as a model for freedom and democracy in the Asia-Pacific and a beacon of hope for those living under communist rule, especially in light of U.S. Secretary of Defense Rumsfeld's recent remarks regarding China's military rise and threat it poses to the peace and stability of the Asia-Pacific region, the organizers said.

They added that Taiwan and its 23 million people are capable of making significant contributions to many UN efforts around the globe. Taiwan is also eager to do its part to combat such international problems as regional conflict, terrorism, drug trafficking, organized crime, and environmental degradation. However, without UN membership, Taiwan is denied an important means of collaborating with international partners. This unnecessarily complicates the task at hand and hampers efforts to deal with such critical issues.

Besides, they said, the passage of the Anti-Secession Law on March 14 by the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China has been widely viewed as the legal excuse for the use of force against Taiwan, and endangers peace and stability in the East Asia region. To safeguard peace, the UN has to facilitate the necessary dialogue between Taiwan and the PRC.

The UN's exclusion of Taiwan violates the principles and spirit of the UN Charter, in particular the fundamental principle of universality, and of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the organizers claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINGCHUANKANG AIRPORT UNSUITABLE FOR INTERNATIONAL FLIGHTS: CAA

TEXT.P: Chingchuankang Airport in central Taichung county is unsuitable for international flights for the time being due to its inadequate facilities, officials of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said Sunday.

Citing a CAA assessment, the officials pointed out that it is very hard to make the airport in central Taiwan a point to serve international flights, including the Taiwan-Macau and the Taiwan-Hong Kong routes, despite the upcoming renewal of an aviation agreement between the two sides later this year.

The CAA officials made the comments a day after Chiu Tai-san, a former vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and now a hopeful of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for Taichung magistrate in December's county and city chief elections, made the request to Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Vice Chairman Chang Jing-sen and CAA Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng who made an inspection tour of the airport.

Chang Jing-sen said that the CEPD will approve the total funding of NT$1.55 billion for the expansion project Monday in the hope of meeting rising local demand for international charter flights and the Taiwan-Hong Kong and Taiwan-Macau routes.
Chang Kuo-cheng promised to start the expansion project for the airport as soon as possible as long as the funding has been secured.
Currently, Chingchuankang Airport is only available for domestic routes and various charter flights to Japan, Bali and Phuket since its operations early last year.

Residents in the Taichung area have been eager to have the airport to serve regular international flights and have repeatedly called on the government to make it able to service the Macau route after the renewal of the Taiwan-Macau aviation agreement late this year.
Taiwan and Macau forged the pact in Nov. 2000 and renewed it in Feb. 2003.
Making Chingchuankang Airport adequate to link to Hong Kong and Macau was always high on Chiu's agenda when he served as MAC vice chairman.

As the first-phase expansion for the airport is slated for completion in 2008, Chiu also asked the CAA to raise extra funds of about NT$12.9 million to help it improve its existing facilities and equipment for current international charter flight service.

An upgrading of Chingchuankang Airport, Chiu opined, will further help boost exports of opto-optical and precision machinery products from central Taiwan and will also make it easier for Taiwan businessmen operating in China to come home.

In 2004, Taiwan people paid a total of 7.78 million visits overseas, 18. 7 percent of which, or 1.45 million visits, were made by residents in central Taiwan, tallies compiled by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL BANK UNDER GROWING PRESSURE TO RAISE INTEREST RATE

TEXT.P: Pushed by continuously rising oil prices and an expected new hike in interest rates by the U. S. Federal Reserve next week, Taiwan's central bank has come under stronger pressure to raise interest rates in September, economists said Saturday.

Shih Yen, director-general of the Economic Research Department at the Central Bank of China (CBC) , said, however, that the CBC will closely watch the impact of the soaring oil prices on domestic consumer product prices before making a judgment.

Although fuel increases account for much of the consumer prices index (CPI) rises and usually leads to immediate consumer product price changes, Shih said that it remains to be seen whether electricity and public utility rates will be adjusted upward in the near term and whether a string of flow-on effects will follow.

According to the latest tallies published by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the CPI moved up by an average of 1.92 percent for the first seven months of this year, still lower than 2 percent.

In addition, the U. S. Fed's continued interest rate hikes have also put the CBC under greater pressure to follow suit in the second half of this year, a bond expert said, adding that it is very possible that key U. S. interest rates will be lifted to around 4 percent by the end of this year, exceeding the market's previous evaluation of a range between 3.5 percent and 3.75 percent.
He contended that the U. S. rate hikes will impact the CBC's monetary policy and claimed that the CBC will do so very probably in September now that domestic fuel oil prices were adjusted last week.
National Chengchi University Professor Chu Hao-min said that the historically high oil prices should be a short-term phenomenon. But even so, businesses might have passed on the costs to consumers.

Despite the fact that Taiwan's economic performance has been lackluster this year, evidenced in its slowed economic growth rate and shrinking trade surplus which squeeze the space for the CBC to make rate increases, Chu said that the central bank might opt to do so by a half quarter point in the coming months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN DOES NOT WISH TO NAME POSSIBLE SUCCESSOR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made it clear Sunday that he would not designate anyone as his successor in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in preparation for the 2008 presidential election.

Addressing a DPP leadership training camp, Chen said that he had noticed the heated discussion on the DPP leadership succession issue recently, adding that it could be genuine worry among DPP party members or news media's sensationalism.
He said his attitude on the issue has always been very clear: a national leader is formed naturally, and it is impossible for him to designate one.
"A real hero has to endure; if he cannot, then he is not a real hero," Chen said.

On the recent election for chairman in the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Chen expressed the hope that with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou as the new KMT chairman, there will be more room for rational interaction between the DPP and the KMT for the benefit of the people.
The president said he would put aside all unnecessary political calculations and reopen dialogue with all opposition parties sincerely and work for reconciliation with them.

Chen acknowledged that the DPP government has gone through a series of difficulties recently, including China's passage of the Anti-Secession Law and Beijing's attempt to alienate Taiwan by granting tariff-free treatment to the island's fruit farmers.

However, he said, the government has coped with these difficulties "rationally, cautiously and pragmatically," knowing that the international community has been watching how the DPP government exercises self-restraint and wisdom in handling these complicated issues.

On the other hand, the people in Taiwan have also been watching how the DPP government, in pushing for normalization of relations with China and maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, could safeguard Taiwan's democracy and security, while striking a new balance of power between Taiwan and China, he said.
Chen explained that the basic principle he relied on in dealing with cross-strait affairs during this period was "reconciliation without flinching; be firm without being confrontational."

"It's the same reason as when someone crouches down at the right moment to watch for possible changes and gather his strength, so that he could jump higher or farther away, " he said, adding this shows his flexibility and wits.

Chen encouraged all DPP members and government officials to win the hearts of the people by doing their best in their posts. He said there is no other way to get the people's recognition, except by giving them a excellent score card.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGER NUMBER OF SEXUAL, DOMESTIC VIOLENCE HANDLED IN TAIPEI CITY

TEXT.P: During the first six months of this year, a total of 839 sexual offense cases were reported to the Taipei city's domestic violence and sexual abuses prevention center, marking a growth of 36 percent over the previous year's level, the municipal Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics tallies showed.

While some 51 percent of the victims were youths under the age of 18, a growth of 4.38 precent year to year, 9 percent of them were children younger than 12 and those aged between 12 and 18 accounted for the largest portion of 42.64 percent, the same tallies pointed out. The vast majority of 94 percent of the total sexual offense victims were female.

Meanwhile, a total of 2,524 people who are victims of domestic violence turned to the center for help in the same six-month period, up by 34 percent compared with the year-earlier level. About 94 percent of the total was female, while 84 percent, or 2,132 victims, were women abused by their husbands -- an annual increase of 32 percent.
The number of victims aged under 18 grew by 40 percent to 238, while the number of elderly victims jumped by 58 percent to 154, the statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT REFORMS ARE NON-PARTISAN: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: Any government reform, in order to be successful, has to be carried out disregarding partisan interests, Premier Frank Hsieh said Sunday.

Speaking at a training camp organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for leaders of civic groups, the premier said a political party should brush aside its own interests while pushing for reform, or it is doomed to complicate and ruin the reform.

He said his administration is making reforms at the cost of its own power. Citing the second-phase financial reform as an example, Hsieh claimed this reform, which features the consolidation of the 12 state-run banks into six, will cut the number of chairmen his administration can named for these news banks from 12 to six.

Similar examples are the privatalization of the state-run Chinese Television System and the Taiwan Television Enterprise, Ltd., not to mention the dismantling of several ministries and agencies under the Executive Yuan according to the plan to restructure the Executive Yuan, which all limit the leverage his administration can exercise, Hsieh claimed.

The administration insists on pushing forward these reforms because they will benefit the country as a whole. However, these plans have encountered opposition at the opposition-controlled legislature because they will jeopardize the interests of the establishment.

The recent renewal of cable TV licenses is another example Hsieh said, adding that several operators of TV channels protested the government's withdrawal of their licenses and the opposition jumped at the chance to sell their version of a bill for a national communications commission which they claimed will stop the administration from abusing its power.

The premier said his administration is in favor of the idea of relegating a commission to regulate the cable industry, but couldn't go along with the opposition's proposal to have the commission be made up of members named by various political parties in proportion to their legislative seats.
Instead, Hsieh said, the commission should be free from political influence by being made up of non-partisan experts and academics.

The opposition's intention of giving themselves a voice in the proposed commission is not in the interest of the nation, Hsieh said, urging them to subordinate their partisan interests to the interests of all the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUNDATION WANTS TAIWAN TO BE FREE FROM CORPORAL PUNISHMENT

TEXT.P: More than half, or 1.84 million, of the pupils in Taiwan's primary and junior high schools, received some kind of physical punishment in academic year 2004 which ended in July, the Humanistic Education Foundation said Sunday.

In a news release, the foundation urged all schools and families to stop corporal punishment for the young generation, so that Taiwan could become "a nation where no children will be beaten by the elders."

The foundation, established in 1987, has been calling for educational reform by banning all forms of corporal punishment for children not only in schools and families, but also in reformatories and other penal institutions of Taiwan.

Figures released by the foundation in mid-June showed that from September last year to June this year, a total of 65.1 percent of primary and junior high school students had been punished physically by their teachers.
In an interview with the CNA, Hsiao Yi-min, secretary-general of the foundation, said the foundation will continue to campaign for Taiwan to become a country free from corporal punishment.

He said the foundation will call for legislation to ban physical punishment of children, beginning with Taiwan's schools and then amending the law to extend enforcement of the law to other institutions and all families.
He said the best example for Taiwan in this area is Sweden, which abolished all forms of physical punishment through legislation in 1979.

Hsiao said that representatives from the foundation will pay a visit to Premier Frank Hsieh Tuesday to seek his support for the foundation's campaign to make Taiwan a country where no children will ever be punished physically.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER EXAMINING NUCLEAR WASTE IN LANYU
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: State-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) is examining its over 97,000 barrels of low-level radioactive waste from Lanyu, also known as Orchid Island, which lies off the southeastern Taiwan coast, as the lease on its storage site has expired, Taipower sources said Sunday.

After two decades on Lanyu, Taipower began to build inspection and handling facilities on the small island two years ago, and will start removing the material once a "low-level radioactive waste storage terminal bill" clears the floor of the Legislative Yuan, Taipower officials said.
The 97,672 barrels of nuclear waste, produced from Taipower's three nuclear power plants over 20 years, are scheduled to be inspected and repacked by the end of 2010. .

Taipower has contacted authorities from home and abroad for the treatment and disposal of its nuclear waste over the past several years, including Russia, North Korea and Taiwan's offshore islet of Wuchiu.

Meanwhile, according to a nuclear waste assessment report from the Atomic Energy Council (AEC) , exposure rates in Lanyu have not exceeded 0.001 mSv in any one hour in a year, far lower than the AEC-allowed level of 0.25 mSv in any hour in a year.

Although a proposal of renewing the now-expired lease with Taipower on the land of the waste storage site has not yet approved by the Lanyu Rural Township office, some of the local residents are having second thoughts about kicking out the site.

A sixty-seven-year-old Lanyu resident surnamed Hsieh said that the Taipower station has provided adequate services to locals and he preferred that Lanyu continue to hold Taipower's nuclear waste and the lease be extended.
Another resident surnamed Chen, 78, said that so long as Taipower pays the residents compensation in cash, he does not insist that the waste must go.

Some elected representatives in Lanyu have said that as long as Taipower once again reassured the people that its waste storage is non-toxic to locals, Lanyu will consider renewing the contract. In that case, they said, the receptacle area can be built into a museum for academic research and tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE WINS TAIPEI WORLD CHINESE CULINARY CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: The Singaporean team created an amazing array of seven courses in the World Culinary Contest at the 2005 Taipei Chinese Food Festival, beating the Southern Taiwan team to win this year's "Culinary God" title Sunday.

After three days of keen competitions, the two finalists triumphed over teams from Malaysia, Japan, the United States, Northern Taiwan and elbowed out defending champion Beijing, which had won two consecutive titles.

To test the competing chefs' impromptu creativity, organizers asked that each team complete seven dishes within four hours -- appetizer, soup, seafood dish, poultry dish, livestock dish, vegetable dish and dessert with materials that were given only moments before the contest began.
The two teams were given crab, black-boned chicken, eel, baby pigeon, pork and bitter gourd.

The Singaporean team, composed of five members, each with between 22 and 26 years of experience, defeated their southern Taiwan counterparts led by Tony Kuo-jung Chang and including gold medalists in two previous Malaysian contests.

Auston Ong, who spoke for the Singaporean team that had slept for less than two hours the previous night in order to prepare for the final round, gave his team a 100-point score, claiming he was particularly proud of his own coffee flavored chicken and appetizer of cucumber with crispy beans.

Stanley Yen, an organizer, said a number of judges have been invited from various countries to enrich the meaning and content of "Chinese cuisine" in the hope that it will get even more internationalized.
An international panel of judges could also offer a new perspective for Taiwan's top chefs to think about the next stage in the development of Chinese culinary art, Ye said.
The Beijing team and the Northern Taiwan team shared the third place in the contest in which the chefs were told to cook with "heart and mouth" and stay true to Chinese culinary art.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER COMPANY SCRAMBLES TO RESTORE WATER SUPPLY IN TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Water Corporation is working around-the-clock to restore the water supply to Taoyuan county, hopefully on Monday as required by Premier Frank Hsieh, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Sunday.

Ho whose ministry oversees the operation of the state-run Taiwan Water Corporation said the water company supplied water about 80 percent or 90 percent of its usual amount in Taoyuan on Sunday and has to rotate its water supply to households on every other day simply because of concerns that customers at the end of its pipeline may not get water.
She set aside questions about whether water supply in Taoyuan will be fully restored on Monday, saying that "we are working hard toward this."

She said she has contacted Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lung who was reportedly criticizing the central government's failure to address this water shortage problem in Taoyuan yesterday. Ho said Chu understood the rather company was doing its best to solve the problem.

The minister refused to talk about the offer made by the water company's chairman Lee Wen-liang to quit to take responsibility for the problem, saying what is important right now is to resume the water supply rather than ascribe responsibility.

The water shortage was caused by the heavy rain dumped by typhoon Matsa when it swept through Taiwan on Friday. It prompted widespread mudslide in the catchment basin of Shihmen Reservoir which supplies drinking water to Taoyuan county.

The raw water taken by water company from the reservoir is to muddy be treated by the water purification plant which has to stop operation for five to seven days until the suspended particles in the water settled down.
The problem first cropped up last August when typhoon Aere hit Taiwan. Water supply to households in most Taoyuan was cut off for 19 days.
Both the chairman and the general manager of the water company resigned to take the blame at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 8, or the fourth day of the sixth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1549: France declares war on England.
1588: The Spanish Armada is defeated by the British.
1900: The first Davis Cup tennis tournament, named after Dwight Filley Davis, begins in Brookline, Massachusetts.
1901: Ernest Lawrence, the American physicist who won the Nobel Prize for physics in 1939, is born. He invented the first subatomic particle accelerator and the color television tube.
1918: The Battle of Amiens begins when Allied forces advance against 20 German divisions and take 16,000 prisoners in two hours.
1919: A peace conference between India and Afghanistan results in the signing of the Treaty of Rawalpindi.
1923: Esther Williams, the American actress and former champion swimmer, is born. She became best-known for her appearance in "Bathing Beauty."
1944: Adolf Hitler has four of his top men hanged with piano wire for attempting to assassinate him.
1945: The United States drops its second atomic bomb, "Fat Man," on the Japanese city of Nagasaki, days after devastating Hiroshima with "Little Boy," the first such device ever used.
1957: General Chow Chih-jou is appointed governor of Taiwan, succeeding C.K. Yen.
1957: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Jordan.
1961: Mei Lan-fang, noted Beijing opera actor, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 67.
1963: In one of the most audacious holdups of all time, robbers involved in "The Great Train Robbery" net an estimated 2.5 million pounds (US$4.6 million) in unused bank notes from a night mail train traveling between Glasgow and London.
1963: The United States, Britain and the USSR sign the nuclear Test Ban Treaty in the Kremlin.
1967: The "Bangkok Declaration" is signed by the foreign ministers of Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. The declaration led to the formation of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN).
1974: Richard Nixon makes history as the first U.S. president to resign from office.
1977: The Interior Ministry reports that at the end of June, the population of Taiwan reached 16,655,140 and that of Taipei hit 2,113,030.
1983: A military coup led by Defense Minister General Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores overthrows President Efrain Rios Montt of Guatemala.
1988: ROC swimmer Wang Han and a six-man team swim across the English Channel in relays in 14 hours and 31 minutes.
1988: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa announces the decision to build a new highway linking Ilan and Nankang in Taipei County.
1990: National Defense Minister Chen Li-an announces that the Red Cross Society of the ROC will handle the repatriation of illegal mainland entrants in the future.
1994: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait sign and make public a joint announcement confirming the results of the second round of talks between Chiao Jen-ho and Tang Shubei.
1999: The Fifth Asia Children's Literature Convention opens in Taipei with 300 authors of children's literature from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the Philippines, Malaysia and the ROC attending.
2000: The Asian Witness Center of the Guinness Book of World Records names 109-year-old Hu Chin-yao as Taiwan's oldest father.
2001: Officials from Taiwan and Australia gathers in Taipei to participate in a two-day conference on mineral and energy resources.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If those in authority have not the confidence of those under them, government of the people is an impossibility."

TEXT.P: Moscow, Aug. 8[CNA] The Moscow Times: Mini-Sub Crew Rescued After 3Days A British remote-controlled vehicle cut loose a Russian mini-submarine that had been snarled on undersea cables deep in the Pacific, and the mini-sub surfaced Sunday with all seven crew safe after a three-day ordeal in frigid darkness.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELEASE OF CHUNGHWA TELECOM SHARES TO PROCEED AS PLANNED: MINISTER

TEXT.P: State-run Chunghwa Telecom's release of an additional 290 million shares will proceed as scheduled from Tuesday as part of the state-run company's ongoing privatization, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Monday.

Lin said firmly that the sale of the shares -- to be available to private and corporate investors in Taiwan -- will proceed as scheduled despite Chunghwa Telecom Union's plan to stage a strike islandwide the same day to oppose what it calls "the manner in which the telecom giant is moving toward privatization."
Lin said that Chunghwa Telecom management will continue to communicate and negotiate with union members over their differences.

Chunghwa Telecom Union Chairman Chang Hsu-chung has said that the union is not opposed to Chunghwa Telecom's privatization but that the process is laced with problems that could compromise Chunghwa workers' rights and interests.

According to Chang, the strike plan was passed after Chunghwa management ignored the union's appeals for guarantees that benefits and work conditions would not be altered and that Chunghwa Telecom employees would be compensated based on terms for the country's civil servants after the company is completely privatized.

The strike will be held also to protest management's decision to go ahead with the privatization plan without reaching a consensus with the union in advance, a move, Chang claimed, that runs counter to a Legislative Yuan resolution that stipulates that Chunghwa Telecom management must reach a consensus with the union before implementing the privatization plan.

Meanwhile, Chunghwa Telecom Vice President Chang Feng-hsiung said that the company on Monday activated "emergency measures" to deal with any disruptions caused by the planned strike. He said that if a strike is unavoidable, the company will try its best to maintain the company's services.
"I guarantee that Chunghwa Telecom will do whatever it can to prevent subscribers' rights from being compromised under any circumstances," he added.

It has been learned that Chunghwa Telecom will release an additional 13 percent of its shares near the end of this year to overseas investors, thus fulfilling its goal of becoming a private enterprise.
The revenue of Taiwan's largest telecommunications company totaled NT$89.7 billion for the first half of this year.

Meanwhile, the opposition People First Party (PFP) blamed Premier Frank Hsieh last week for showing contempt for the Legislative Yuan by ignoring a resolution passed by the legislature requiring Chunghwa Telecom to cease all operations regarding the release of its shares.

PFP legislative party whip Hwang Yi-jiao pointed out that the previous legislature had passed a resolution, introduced by the PFP, censuring Chunghwa Telecom for having sold the previous batch of shares too cheaply to certain financial groups. The resolution banned the company from releasing any more shares until the new legislature made a further decision on the matter.

Hwang acknowledged that with the new legislature still in recess, there is nothing the opposition parties can do, but he said that when the next legislative session opens in September, the PFP caucus will consider a move to cut the budget of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, which has direct jurisdiction over Chunghwa Telecom.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Philippine hunt for 10 suicide bombers.
Ten Indonesian suicide bombers are on the loose in the Philippines and are believed to be planning a series of attacks in the capital and other key cities, President Gloria Arroyo's national security adviser told the Straits Times yesterday.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Six-way nuclear talks break off for recess till the end of this month.
The fourth round of the six-way talks still be a stalemate.It broke for three-week recess, and the North Korea and other five countries will return to Beijing to resume the talks in Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER SUPPORTS RATIONAL DEBATE ON ARMS PACKAGE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said in Los Angeles Sunday that he supports in-depth discussions on a long-stalled arms procurement package to address Taiwan's defense needs and China's mounting military threat.
Wang made the remarks while meeting with Taiwanese community leaders in Los Angeles.
Wang, a vice chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said the KMT's stance on the arms procurement package has been clear.
"While we support Taiwan possessing sufficient self-defense capabilities, we oppose wasteful or unsuitable arms procurements, " Wang said.

Now that outgoing KMT Chairman Lien Chan has said the long-talked-about arms procurement package should be given reasonable support, Wang said chances for the two relevant bills to be put to legislative debate should be higher.

The two bills in question will pave the way for procuring eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States. One bill will authorize the administration to prepare a special budget for the NT$480 billion arms procurement package over a period of 15 years, the other bill is regarding budget appropriations for the package.

The KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally -- the People First Party (PFP) -- have used their slim majority in the legislature to block the two bills from being put on the legislative agenda for two legislative sessions.

In his view, Wang said, the arms procurement package is very complicated and require a comprehensive evaluation. Against this backdrop, Wang said the package should be put forth for a legislative debate and in-depth discussions.
Wang, who suffered an embarrassing defeat in the KMT chairmanship election in mid-July, said he will continue his efforts to maintain KMT-PFP cooperation in the legislative process.
As the legislative speaker, Wang said, he will push for closer KMT-PFP cooperation and use their legislative clout to pass bills beneficial for national well-being.
Nearly 300 people, including senior executives of the KMT chapter in the U.S. West Coast, PFP volunteers in Los Angeles and representatives of major Taiwanese associations, attended the seminar.

Wang will wrap up his U.S. visit and leave Los Angeles for home Tuesday.
(By Sofia Wu) ednitem/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN NATION CITIZENS' HOLD RALLIES IN FIVE COUNTIES, CITIES

TEXT.P: More than 100 pro-independence activists calling themselves "citizens of the Taiwan nation" gathered Monday at a downtown park in Tainan, southern Taiwan, to join in a ceremony to raise the "national flag" of the Taiwan nation."
The rally was one of five such activities held simultaneously around the island. The other rallies took place in Taipei City, Nantou County, Hsinchu City and Pingtung City.

The Tainan event organizer indicated that the rally was a warm-up for a grand flag-raising ceremony at the Presidential Office sqare in Taipei to be held Sept. 8 to mark what they call "Taiwan Independence Day."
The flag features three vertical stripes -- blue at the top, white in the middle and green at the bottom -- overlaid with a red circle, symbolizing the sun, at the center of the flag.

Asked whether the flag's red sun will lead people to think of Japan, Chu Liu-cheh, who helped design the flag, noted that Taiwan was once a colony of Japan. He said the colors of the flag, including the blue which represents the former ruling party, the Kuomintang, and the green which represents the Democratic Progressive Party, the current ruling party, acts to remind the Taiwanese people of their history.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S TAIPEI MAYORAL CANDIDATE SHOULD BE DECIDED VIA PRIMARY: MA

TEXT.P: With speculation already circulating about who will represent the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to run in next year's Taipei mayoral election, KMT Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that all KMT candidates for local elections should be chosen through party primaries.

Ma, who won a landslide victory in the KMT chairmanship election July 16 and is scheduled to be sworn in to his new post Aug. 19, said that he welcomes all talented people who are determined to serve the city of Taipei as mayor to enter the race.

Ma denied a media report that sitting Taipei Deputy Mayor Yeh Chin-chuan is his "man in pocket" to be the KMT candidate in the next Taipei mayoral election, saying that as a party chairman, he must remain impartial. He added that he will see to it that the KMT candidate for next year's Taipei mayoral election is chosen via a party primary.

He added that the KMT has maintained a viable mechanism to produce KMT candidates for major elections. If no conclusion is reached via preliminary negotiations, primaries conducted via voting or public opinion polls should both be feasible and effective ways of producing KMT candidates, he said.

On the notion of a merger of the three pan-blue political parties -- the KMT, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party -- in order to beat the ruling Democratic Progressive Pary and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, in the next Taipei mayoral election, Ma said that it is still too early to talk about how a pan-blue candidate should be produced for the mayoral election. "The earliest time should be at the beginning of next year," he added.
Meanwhile, KMT Legislator John Chiang said Monday that he will seek the KMT candidacy for next year's Taipei mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAOYUAN COUNTY AGAIN LEFT HIGH AND DRY AS WATER RATIONING CONTINUES

TEXT.P: There is water everywhere in the Shihmen Reservoir, but not enough to drink for many nearby residents in Taoyuan County, and relief is slow in coming.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday that the turbidity in the reservoir has made purification problematic and that water supplies will have to continue on a rotational basis for the approximately 600,000 households in the county.
Some were optimistic about the situation a day earlier when Premier Frank Hsieh said that water supply would have to return to normal by Monday.
The problem came after Typhoon Matsa, which passed through Taiwan Friday, brought torrential rains and stirred up sediment and brought silt and debris into the reservoir.

Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lung is scheduled to report to the premier in the afternoon on the problem and request that Shihmen Reservoir improvement works be included in the central government's eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-control project.
The state-run Taiwan Water Corporation (TWC), which is under the economics ministry, said water supply has reached 60 percent of the normal level as of Monday.

TWC Chairman Lee Wen-liang has offered to step down from his post to take responsibility for the water supply problem in Taoyuan, but Premier Hsieh, who was in a orphanage in Liaokuei, Kaohsiung, Monday morning, said that he would travel to Taoyuan County later in the day to learn about the situation before deciding how to respond.
Meanwhile, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus in the Legislative Yuan said that the central and local governments should work together to solve the water supply problem.

William Lai, a DPP whip in the legislature, said that opposition parties should not ask Ho to step down every time a problem arises, saying that the problem stems from abusive development of hilly terrain in Taoyuan over the past decade.

Lai made the remarks after the People First Party (PFP) legislative caucus criticized Ho for being incompetent and asked that Premier Hsieh replace her before the new legislative session in September.

Sun Ta-chien, a PFP whip in the legislature, said that Taoyuan has faced water shortages since last year, and that this time it happened after only the first two typhoons of the year, adding that "negligence is to blame."

On Ho's views that water supply situation has improved this year, Sun said he felt sorry for the 1.8 million residents in Taoyuan after Ho has said that she felt that the water shortage situation was improving. Sun asked Ho to come forward and explain what exactly she meant by that statement and to tell residents what it was that she had actually done to improve the situation over the past year.
The problem with the water supply first cropped up last August when Typhoon Aere hit Taiwan. Water supplies to households in most of Taoyuan were cut off for 19 days.
Both the chairman and the general manager of the TWC subsequently resigned over the fiasco.

DOC.HEADLINE: MECHANISM ADOPTED TO WARN GANGSTERS AGAINST PRO-BASEBALL GAMBLING

TEXT.P: The nation's sports and police agencies have jointly adopted six principles for setting up a mechanism to keep gangsters from interfering in professional baseball games, officials said Monday.

A priority is establishing a long-term monitoring system to keep the underworld from "illegally intervening in professional baseball games" as the second "game throwing" and odds-betting scandal in eight years hit the nation recently.

Other principles deal with beefing up security for players and staff, strengthening the management of the league, setting up a mechanism to call up or send down players from farm teams, finding a way to more fairly pay players and studying the feasibility of building a pension system for them.
Chen Chuan-shou, minister of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, said the preventive measures are about the same in all countries; the point is how effectively to implement them.

Since it is the second time that the Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) has been hit with such a scandal, Chen said his council cannot shirk its responsibility and will definitely ask for assistance from all government agencies that may be able to provide help.
He emphasized that efforts must be made at all fronts to strike at bookies who tried to manipulate the games if the nation wants to thoroughly get rid of game-meddling underworld elements.
He also reiterated that any player found to have been involved in game-throwing and gambling will be banned from even holding a job in amateur baseball.
To show the teeth of the government-proposed anti-bookies measure, the council will ask the Ministry of Justice to increase sentences for the guilty and to hasten the trial process.

Tien Chien-tai, of the National Police Administration, said police will make more strenuous efforts in gathering evidence and will treat suspected bookies as most-wanted gangsters as a warning that they will pay dearly for their offenses.
