DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LASHES OUT AT GOV'T OVER CHUNGHWA TELECOM STRIKE PLAN

TEXT.P: Opposition parties lashed out at the administration Monday over state-run Chunghwa Telecom Union's planned strikes aimed at opposing what the union calls "the manner in which the telecom giant is moving toward privatization."

Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Monday that the release of an additional 290 million Chunghwa Telecom shares will proceed as scheduled from Tuesday as part of the state-run company's ongoing privatization.

Lin said firmly that the sale of the shares -- to be available to private and corporate investors in Taiwan -- will proceed as scheduled from Tuesday despite Chunghwa Telecom Union's plan to stage a series of strikes islandwide beginning the same day.

Commenting on Chunghwa Telecom Union's planned strikes -- scheduled to run until Aug. 12 -- Tsai Chin-lung, a legislative party whip of the opposition Kuomintang, defended the Chunghwa Telecom Union for its decision to strike.

Tsai said that it is understandable that the Chunghwa Telecom Union has called for the strikes out of fears that work opportunities of the Chunghwa Telecom workers will be compromised should the management decide to go ahead with the privatization plan without reaching a consensus with the union in advance.

Tsai said that Chunghwa Telecom management's decision on the release of the company's stocks and the issuance of global depository receipts (GDRs) in overseas markets without the approval of its staff members are moves that run counter to a Legislative Yuan resolution that stipulates that Chunghwa Telecom management must reach a consensus with the union before implementing the privatization plan.
If the strike is unavoidable, Tsai said, the administration should bear the responsibility for any repercussion that the strike may bring.

Chunghwa Telecom -- Taiwan's largest telecommunications company whose revenues totaled NT$89.7 billion for the first half of this year -- is under the direct jurisdiction of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

Chunghwa Telecom Union Chairman Chang Hsu-chung has said that the union is not opposed to Chunghwa Telecom's privatization but that the process is laced with problems that could compromise Chunghwa workers' rights and interests.

According to Chang, the strike plan was passed after Chunghwa management ignored the union's appeals for guarantees that benefits and work conditions would not be altered and that Chunghwa Telecom employees would be compensated based on terms for the country's civil servants after the company is completely privatized.

Also defending the Chunghwa Telecom Union's plans to strike, Lin Hui-kuan, a party whip of the opposition People First Party (PFP) , noted that the administration cannot evade its responsibility should Chunghwa Telecom management's decision to release GDRs in the United States without the approval by its staff members in advance cause any tension or confrontation between the Chunghwa Telecom management and the staff and between the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan.

Sun Ta-chian, another PFP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, blamed the administration for showing contempt for the Legislative Yuan by ignoring a resolution passed by the legislature requiring Chunghwa Telecom to cease all operations regarding the release of its shares.

Sun pointed out that the previous legislature had passed a resolution, introduced by the PFP, censuring Chunghwa Telecom for having sold the previous batch of shares too cheaply to certain financial groups. The resolution banned the company from releasing any more shares until the new legislature made a further decision on the matter.

Noting that with the new legislature still in recess, there is nothing the opposition parties can do, Sun said that when the next legislative session opens in September, the PFP caucus will consider a move to cut the budget of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, which has direct jurisdiction over Chunghwa Telecom, and will set much higher thresholds when it screens budget plans for the central government.

It has been learned that Chunghwa Telecom will release an additional 13 percent of its shares near the end of this year to overseas investors, thus fulfilling its goal of becoming a private enterprise.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved down 75 points to close at 6,370, with 21,271 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September moved down 71 points to end at 6,362, with 1,396 contracts traded, while December futures lost 74 points to finish at 6,340, with nine contracts traded. March futures moved down 73 points to close at 6,338, with two contracts traded, while June futures moved down 142 points to close at 6,267, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,445 for August, 6,433 for September, 6,414 for December, 6,411 for March and 6,409 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

August TE futures moved down three points to close at 267, with 3,798 contracts traded, while September TE futures lost 3.2 points to finish at 266.8, with 144 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 2.95 points to end at 267, with one contract traded, while June TE futures moved down 2.4 points to close at 266, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for March.

August TF futures lost 14.2 points to finish at 975.8, with 2,765 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved down 12.6 points to end at 974.2, with 215 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 12.2 points to close at 972.4, with seven contract transactions, while March TF futures lost six points to finish at 975.2, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 65.98 points to close at 6,380.03.
The bourse opened at 6,400.04 and fluctuated between 6,408.05 and 6,375.89 during trading. A total of 3.06 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$92.68 billion (US$2.89 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks, textile stocks and banking and financial shares all moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.1 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent and foodstuff issues and construction issues both at 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 627 to 259, with 104 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABORERS STAGE FATHER'S DAY PROTEST AGAINST GOV'T'S POPULATION POLICY

TEXT.P: A group of laborers staged a demonstration in front of the Ministry of the Interior Monday, or Father's Day in Taiwan, to protest what they called the government's misguided population policy.

Scores of members of the Republic of China Grassroots Laborers and Parents Association chanted slogans and performed skits to display their dissatisfaction with the government's current population policy which they said places a heavy burden on them as fathers.

Pointing out that many working families in Taiwan face the problems of unemployment and high costs of educating their children, the protestors lashed out at the ministry's current population policy for going the wrong way by encouraging couples to have more children at a time when many families have run out of resources to do so.

"The key point is that we must have resources to raise them before bringing them into this world, " they stressed, demanding that the government raise the tax deduction limit for bearing children and offer free medical treatment for children. They also demanded that the government offer financial support for children of unemployed parents.

The protestors urged the government to seek a remedy to the problems and reverse the current trend under which they said they are "afraid to have children, refuse to have children, or even regret having children."

An unfair distribution of social resources has led to an increase in the gap between the rich and poor, a situation that has put further pressure on working families, a spokesman for the association said.

According to a survey by a local magazine, as many as 54 percent of fathers in Taiwan are most worried about not having enough money to raise their children, while 45 percent are most concerned about not having time to spend with their children.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP WANTS GOVERNMENT FUND TO ACCOUNT FOR MONEY-LOSING INVESTMENTS

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) demanded Monday that the Development Fund under the Executive Yuan give a report on its operations in the next legislative session to clarify what the party called money-losing investments.

PFP legislative office director Chin Huei-chu told a news conference at the Legislative Yuan that the Development Fund, set up by the Executive Yuan in 1973 to help finance local industries, posted a loss of NT$18.2 billion last year for having made money-losing investments in 35 private companies with close links to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , including the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corporation.

Twenty-three of the 35 companies were in the red last year, Chin pointed out, accusing the DPP of subsidizing its political supporters with public fund. She asked the fund personnel in charge to resign.
According to Chin, the Ministry of Audit also sent a notice to the Executive Yuan asking it to improve the fund's performance.

PFP Legislator Sun Ta-chian said that he will ask the fund managers to give a report on its investment targets and policymaking process in the next legislative session which will open in September. The PFP will not agree to the fund's continued operations if the operators refuse to be questioned at the legislature, he said.
Sun stressed that the fund is by no means a cash card of the DPP and criticized the DPP for having forsaken its past ideals by giving way to its links with special interest groups.

The PFP will scrutinize every special budget allocation that the Executive Yuan tenders to the Legislative Yuan in the future should the fund managers fail to show up and elaborate on its operations at the legislature, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRAVE JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENT OVERPOWERS BANK ROBBER
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: A brave 13-year-old boy foiled a bank holdup Monday by overpowering a lone robber who had tossed a Molotov cocktail into the Talin Branch of Chiayi Fourth Credit Cooperative and then threatened tellers with a handgun while demanding money.

The adolescent, surnamed Li, is a student of Peihsin Junior Middle School in Chiayi. Local police are so grateful of his bravery that they are in contact with the school to prepare a citation for him.

A police spokesman said, however, that the police do not encourage such "brave" acts for fear that someone may get harmed. He added that the best way is for any witness to keep cool and remember the detail of what is going on and supply the information to the police later.

Li recalled that he was passing by Chiayi Fourth Credit Cooperative on abicycle at around 1 p.m. when he saw a man lighting a Molotov cocktail while walking into the bank. Immediately after that a fire broke out.

He said that without a second thought, he dashed into the bank and held the robber's neck from behind. A number of tellers rushed to the youngster's help. They jumped on the robber, overpowered him and then turned him over to the police.
According to the police, Liu Kuo-chou, 35, who had been convicted previously of robberies and possession of illegal weapons, was arrested on the spot.

Police investigation showed that before committing the crime, Liu tried to divert the attention of the police by calling the police station, claiming that a bomb had been planted at Peihsin Junior High School. Shortly after the police found this to be a hoax, they received reports about the armed bank robbery.
The police spokesman said that police have confiscated a handgun and four bullets from Liu, who is now being detained for questioning.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEW HONEY BRANDS PASS PURITY TEST: CONSUMERS' FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: It seems that most honey consumed in Taiwan is not pure, with only two of the 37 honey brands having passed a recent purity test, an official of Consumers' Foundation revealed Monday.

Among the 37 samples chosen randomly from supermarkets, traditional markets, shopping malls and organic product shops, the Consumers' Foundation found that only two samples are considered as first and second grade after passing a series of tests including amylase and cane sugar tests.
Of the 37 samples tested, two were from the United States - both failed -- and one was from France, which passed.
The official noted that the prices of honey vary widely, as some bee farmers may add fructose to disguise the mixture as pure honey in order to reap great profits.
He suggested that the bee farmers label sources and categories of the honey so that consumers will not be fooled.

Chen Pao-chi, a professor of National Taiwan University, suggested consumers use a toothpick to distinguish the purity of the honey, with pure honey causing little bubbles after being picked up by a toothpick.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SPENDS FATHER'S DAY WITH ORPHANS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh visited the Christian Mountain Children's Home in the southern township of Liukwei Monday to celebrate Father's Day with the orphans.

Hsieh arrived Monday morning and was greeted by Interior Minister Su Chia-chyuan, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, Liukuei Township chief Hsyao Hua-hsing, Legislator Yen Wen-chang, the home's director Lin Fung-ying, and the home's children, who put on two dances to welcome Hsieh's arrival.

After receiving a painting of a peony by the famous foot-painter Yang Un-diang, who once lived in the home as a child, Hsieh enjoyed the performance of the home's chorus and indicated that he had spent a pleasant time "as if he were with his own children."

Hsieh said he considered his visit meaningful and donated NT$100,000 (US$3,125) to the children's home. Magistrate Yang made a follow-up donation of NT$60,000. Both donations were received by Rev. Lin.
The Christian Mountain Children's Home, also known as "Liukwei orphanage, " was founded by Rev. Hsu Yang in 1964 to take care of aboriginal orphans. The home currently houses 94 children.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORK-FAMILY BALANCE IMPORTANT FOR MEN AGED 35 TO 44: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Working fathers between the ages of 35 and 44 seem to value their families more than those in other age groups, Chiu Wen-jen, the marketing chief of the 104 Job Bank said Monday.

A survey conducted by the 104 Job Bank May 5-9 on working people around the island showed that 24.4 percent of the male respondents in the age group between 35 and 44 think a balance between time spent on work and on family is important, while 16.6 percent of the people in the 45 to 54 age group think the same way, and 14.7 percent of the people aged between 25 and 34 have the same thought.

While the online survey founds 92 percent of female respondents said they don't want to sacrifice their job for marriage, 33.3 percent of the married female respondents said "they are allowed to seek for work achievements with the support of their husband."
Chiu said he believes that while working women act to negotiate with their families for work, their spouses are inevitably faced with the challenge of "balancing their work and family lives."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: War Plans Drafted To Counter Terror Attacks in U.S.; Domestic Effort Is Big Shift for Military.
The U.S. military has devised its first-ever war plans for guarding against and responding to terrorist attacks in the United States, envisioning 15 potential crisis scenarios and anticipating several simultaneous strikes around the country, according to officers who drafted the plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Tunisian charter plane crash probably caused by technical faults.
Preliminary investigations show that Saturday's crash of a Tunisian charter plane in the sea off Palermo was probably caused by technical problem. Experts said that it was rare the two engines of the plane failed simultaneously.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE OPTOELECTRIC COMPANY ANNOUNCES INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Japanese LCD giant ULVAC Kyushu Corp. announced Monday that it will set up plants in the Southern Taiwan Science Park to produce the new generation of LCD panels.
Once the investment is approved, ULVAC will become the 15th Japanese company with operations in the science park.
Toshiaki Fujioka, president of ULVAC, made the announcement in the administration office of the Southern Taiwan Science Park in Tainan.
According to ULVAC's Taiwan branch, the Japanese company's initial investment will exceed NT$1 billion (US$31.34 million).
Chen Tsung-hsing, chief executive officer of ULVAC Taiwan, noted that if the first stage investment results are lucrative, a second and a third stages will follow.
Most of Taiwan's panel manufacturers are clients of ULVAC, including the Chi Mei Group, an ULVAC official said.

Optoelectric products have become the main item in the Southern Taiwan Science Park, with such products accounting for 77 percent of the total business in the park in May and June, more than triple that of semiconductors.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER APOLOGIZES FOR FAILING TO RESTORE WATER TO TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh apologized to Taoyuan residents in front of Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lung Monday for failing to restore water supplies to the northern county.

The premier had originally said that water would be fully restored, but two hours of torrential rain Sunday increased the turbidity of the Shihmen reservoir -- the main water supplier to northern Taiwan -- so that water treatment plants were unable to cope with the high silt levels.

The premier, who traveled to Taoyuan after visiting an orphanage in Liuokuei, Kaohsiung earlier in the day, first listened to a briefing from the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Hsieh said he came to Taoyuan "to solve the problem," adding that water shortage problems that occurred after typhoon Aere in August 2004 disrupted the water supply in Taoyuan county for 19 days, a problem that occurred again this year. He said many problems have been left unexamined, including the overdevelopment of the reservoir's catchment area.

Chu expressed hope that Hsieh will ask the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Water Resources Agency and the Taiwan Water Cooperation to map out a timetable for water supplies, including a timetable for rotational water supplies to different areas.
He also asked the government to be aware that typhoons and torrential rain "can come at any time" and that Taoyuan should not be at the mercy of climate changes.

Meanwhile, to step up cooperation between the central and local government on law and order and flood-control, the premier convened a meeting later in the afternoon, gathering chiefs from 23 cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINI-BUSINESSES COULD HELP ADDRESS UNEMPLOYMENT: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: As rising living expenses and unemployment have led to a rise in the so-called "pain index" in Taiwan, an economist said Monday that creating more mini-businesses -- those employing fewer than five people -- could make a dent in the jobless rate as well as lower the "pain index."

Tu Ying-yi, an associate research fellow at the Chung Hua Institute for Economic Research, said the government should offer incentives for self-employed people, as mini-businesses have increasingly become a policy tool to fight unemployment in countries with advanced economies.

Writing for the electronic newspaper of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Tu said a 2001 survey found that 57.5 percent of Taiwan's manufacturing industry and 82.2 percent of its service industry were in fact mini-businesses that employed less than five people, an indication that this type of business, if expanded, could bring down unemployment.

Tu said Taiwan's economy is becoming increasingly knowledge-based, the share of the service industry in its GDP is growing, and new business models such as on-line transactions are getting more and more popular, creating an environment that will be favorable for the development of mini-businesses.

Tu suggested that the government throw more money into its "mini-business development fund" and map out other support measures to encourage more people, particularly the middle-aged and elderly, to create their own businesses.

Taiwan's 2004 unemployment rate stood at 4.44 percent and the consumer price index rose 1.62 percent year-on-year; the combined total of 6.06 percent was a new high since the second energy crisis and most people's income barely moved.
Tu said the global economic slow-down and Taiwan industries' exodus to China doubtless have raised Taiwan's jobless record.

In the West, the governments usually have a social security system to help the unemployed, but Tu claimed that giving unemployment benefits is a "negative" way of solving the problem, because in some countries, such measures have led to lower willingness to work and even chronic dependence on government checks.
A more positive and "correct" way of creating jobs would be to make loans to creative and diligent people who are motivated enough to launch their mini-businesses, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S POLITICAL TURMOIL WILL NOT AFFECT TAIPEI-TOKYO TIES: ENVOY

TEXT.P: Japan's political turmoil will not affect relations between Taiwan and Japan, the Republic of China representative to Japan said Monday.

Koh Se-kai made the remarks after Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi decided to dissolve the lower house of the Diet earlier in the day to pave the way for snap elections that could shake the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's grip on power.
Koizumi made the drastic move after the upper house of the Japanese Diet voted down legislation to split up and sell Japan's behemoth postal service.

Koh said he hopes the LDP will continue its grip on power after the lower house elections scheduled for Sept. 11 because the Koizumi Cabinet has been friendly toward Taiwan and is concerned about Taiwan Strait stability and peace.

If the opposition Democratic Party of Japan (DPJ) emerges as a victor and forms a new ruling coalition, Koh predicted that Taiwan-Japan relations will not undergo a fundamental change because Taiwan has also traditionally maintained good interaction with the DPJ.

Since assuming his current post in July 2004, Koh said he has proposed to the Japanese authorities many measures to further boost bilateral relations, including the recent bill for a permanent visa waiver for visitors from Taiwan from Sept. 26.

Koh said that in the future, he will focus on lobbying Japan to improve the bilateral engagement mechanism. Stressing that the mechanism -- formulated in 1972 following Japan's switching of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing -- has become obsolete, Koh said Japan should make an overall review and forge a more effective mechanism to facilitate bilateral exchanges.

Under the 1972 mechanism, both Taipei and Tokyo set up intermediary bodies -- the Taipei-based Association of East Asian Relations and the Tokyo-based Interchange Association, respectively -- to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of direct official contacts.

Now that Japan has explicitly singled out Taiwan Strait peace as a common strategic objective of the U.S.-Japan defense cooperation treaty, Koh said Japan should not continue resisting improvements to communication channels with Taiwan simply for fear of offending China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYAN DIPLOMATIC GROUP ARRIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A group of seven young Paraguayan diplomats arrived in Taiwan Monday for a six-day visit at the invitation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
Foreign Affairs officials said the visit will help upgrade the already substantive bilateral relations.

During their stay in Taiwan, the diplomats will visit the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Mainland Affairs Council, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Government Information Office, the National Palace Museum, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, China Steel Corp., and China Shipbuilding Corp. before leaving Aug. 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Peter Jennings, Urbane News Anchor, Dies at 67
Peter Jennings, a high school dropout from Canada who transformed himself into one of the most urbane, well-traveled and recognizable journalists on American television, died of lung cancer yesterday at home. He was 67 and lived in Manhattan. Along with the two other pillars of the so-called Big 3 - Tom Brokaw of NBC and Dan Rather of CBS - Jennings had, in the early 1980's, ushered in the era of the television news anchor as lavishly compensated, globe-trotting superstar. After Brokaw's departure from his anchor chair in December, followed by the retirement from the evening news of Mr. Rather in March, Jennings's death brings that era to a close.
Wall Street Journal: Security Alert, At America's Malls, Grim Preparations for the Unthinkable
The recent wave of suicide bombings in London's mass-transit system has heightened fears in counterterrorist circles of similar attacks in America. On July 18, Homeland Securit y sent federal agencies and state officials a collection of Central Intelligence Agency threat assessments listing malls, banks, prominent companies, and tall buildings as being soft targets most at risk of bomb attacks. The possibility of suicide attacks against the nation's 1,200 enclosed shopping centers, bustling icons of U.S. wealth and consumerism, has transformed the way private security companies, in training their guards and going about their business. The inspiration for their preparation for the unthinkable came from Israel, the country with the most experience keeping human bombs out of its shopping centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST BOOK ABOUT 'COMFORT WOMEN' LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first book about the island's "comfort women" who were forced into sexual slavery by Japanese troops in World War II, was launched Monday, the 60th anniversary of Japan's defeat by the Allies in World War II.
Three former "comfort women" attended a press conference to mark the launch and expressed hope that the book will give the public a further understanding of the truth.
The three women also demanded that the Japanese government give them a public apology and reasonable compensation.

The book, titled "Silent Scars: History of Sexual Slavery by the Japanese Military, " includes more than 200 photos featuring the women, the Japanese brothels in which they were imprisoned and articles about the feelings of these women.

According to statistics, some 20,000 women were used as sex slaves by the Japanese military during World War II, most of whom came from China, Taiwan, South Korea, the Philippines and other Asian countries. Some 2,000 came from Taiwan.
The Japanese government has consistently refused to apologize to the "comfort women."

Chen Wuan-hui, chief executive officer of the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, which helped publish the book, noted that the book, which is written in both Chinese and English, is aimed at arousing awareness about the harm that the "comfort women" system has done to Asian women.
She expressed the hope that the book will push more people to show their concern over the "comfort women" and help them file lawsuits against the Japanese government for an apology and compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALAN PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Guatemalan President Oscar Jose Rafael Berger Perdomo will lead a delegation on a visit to Taiwan Aug. 13, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday.

Berger will be accorded with full military honors upon his arrival. He will also be decorated by President Chen Shui-bian and the two leaders will sign a joint communique before Berger leaves Aug. 17.

On Aug. 13, Berger will attend the inauguration of the Democratic Pacific Union (IDU) and deliver a speech. The IDU, a brainchild of Vice President Annette Lu, aims to serve as a platform for personnel and resource exchanges around the Pacific Rim and to promote democracy, ensure peace and spread prosperity.
Berger will also attend a Guatemalan product, tourism and cultural exhibition held in front of the Taipei Railway Station.

MOFA officials noted that Berger has always been friendly to Taiwan. During his stint as mayor of Guatemala City, the nation's capital, he visited Taiwan in April 1988 and called on then-Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian. This will be the first time that Berger has visited in his capacity as president, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT RULES ON OVERFLIGHTS THROUGH CHINESE AIRSPACE COMPLETED

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) completed Monday a draft of operational rules governing the overflights of Taiwan commercial aircraft through Chinese airspace and submitted it to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council for approval.

The draft rules were prepared after Premier Frank Hsieh lifted a ban last week on Taiwan commercial aircraft overflying China's airspace in order to help the airlines reduce their fuel costs and travel time. Hsieh said the government will attempt to negotiate with the authorities in Beijing on the simultaneous opening of passenger, cargo and special-purpose charter flights across the Taiwan Strait.

An MOTC official said that after the Cabinet gives the nod to the draft, the Civil Aeronautics Administration will begin accepting flight route applications from Taiwan carriers. However, the official admitted that whether the new measure can become reality will depend on the attitude of the Chinese authorities.

China Airlines and EVA Airways -- Taiwan's two main carriers -- have been making plans to reroute their flights from Taipei to Paris, Frankfort, Hanoi and the Middle East to go through Chinese airspace. It is estimated that the new routes would allow the two airlines to save hundreds of millions of New Taiwan dollars in fuel costs each year and cut travel time for each trip by about one hour.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE IMPROVES IN JULY: MOF

TEXT.P: Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$330 million in July after incurring a deficit of US$120 million in June, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported Monday.
According to MOF statistics, Taiwan registered a total foreign trade surplus of US$750 million in the first seven months of this year, down a whopping 84.3 percent from the year-earlier level.

Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the MOF's Statistics Department, said that even though foreign trade ended up in the red in January, March and June, the nation is not expected to post an unfavorable trade imbalance this year.
"As the second half of the year is traditionally an export boom season for Taiwan, we believe our foreign trade will not end up in the red for the whole year," Hsu said.

Nevertheless, he added that the trade surplus is very likely to fall to a new low in more than 20 years because of a combination of factors, including an upward spiral of international crude oil prices and a global economic slowdown.

According to MOF tallies, Taiwan exported US$15.43 billion-worth of goods in July, while imports totaled US$15.1 billion. Compared with the same month of last year, both exports and imports posted less-than-10-percent growth.

In July, Hsu said, Taiwan's exports to the six ASEAN member states plus Hong Kong, Japan and China only posted modest gains and exports to the United States even dropped 1 percent. In contrast, imports from Hong Kong, China, Europe and the six ASEAN countries rose at double-digit rates.
However, imports from Japan increased only 2.5 percent and imports from the United States decreased 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO IMPROVE SPORTS FACILITIES FOR THE DISABLED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday the government will take active steps to protect mentally or physically challenged people's rights to sports.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with members of the "Taiwan Home Run" baseball team which is composed of visually impaired players.

The team won the championship at a world baseball tournament for the visually impaired held in Houston, Texas in late July. It was the second consecutive year that the team secured the world championship.
Chen expressed his admiration for the players' outstanding baseball skills, team spirit and perseverance in overcoming their disabilities to excel in the sport.
The captain of the team presented a special gift to the president -- a specialty baseball for the blind, with autographs of all the team members.
For his part, Chen gave a red envelope with cash to the team as an encouragement to all of its members' devotion to the promotion of the sport.

Chen told his guests that he has directed the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) to provide suitable sporting facilities for people with mental or physical disabilities. He also promised to offer financial assistance for the "Taiwan Home Run" team to take part in overseas contests in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM WORKERS THREATEN TO STRIKE

TEXT.P: Workers of the state-run Chunghwa Telecom company are gearing up for a strike in a desperate attempt to stop the government from privatizing the company, union officials said Monday.

In order to maximize the impact of the strike, leaders of the Chunghwa Telecom Labor Union have kept the date of the proposed strike secret, saying the union members will be informed of the strike order at short notice through SMS text messages.
The congress of the labor union has decided to hold a strike before Aug. 12 to protest the management's plan to sell part of the government's stake in the company.

The Ministry of Transportation and Telecommunications, which owns 65 percent of Chunghwa, is planning to sell 15 percent of its shares and therefore make the firm technically a private company, although the government will still be the majority shareholder.
The cash-strapped Democratic Progressive Party government is eager to sell Chunghwa to finance its political agenda.

Chunghwa workers who claim their welfare will be hurt by the privatization tried to disrupt a presentation organized by the company's management in Taipei Monday to solicit potential bidders for the government's stake.

Chang Feng-hsiung, a vice general manager of Chunghwa, said the workers' welfare has been safeguarded in a group working agreement concluded between the management and the labor union and claimed it is "impossible" that the privatization will be to their detriment.
However, the executive said Chunghwa is ready to compensate its customers if the threatened strike disrupts their fixed phone lines and their mobile phones.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO PRESENT TIMETABLE FOR WATER SUPPLY TO TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday she will present a timetable for a restoration of full water supplies for Taoyuan County and will take responsibility if the schedule fails.

Ho made the promise in a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan, following an apology offered earlier that day by Premier Frank Hsieh for failing to live up to his promise to fully restore water to the county.

Residents in the county -- which is served by the Shihmen reservoir -- have suffered water shortages during the last two years almost every time there is a strong typhoon, as the water treatment facilities are inadequate for dealing with the increased turbidity that occurs in heavy rain.
Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) had earlier hoped that supplies would be restored Monday.
However, heavy rain Sunday and Monday morning further increased the turbidity of the water in the Shihmen reservoir.
Cho claimed that the water shortage is due largely to natural factors but admitted that long-term negligence in administration is also to blame.

Saying that Ho has "worked hard in this regard, " Cho expressed hope that the public will give her more encouragement. He also said the government will determine who should be held responsible only after water supplies have been restored.

According to Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lung, a project costing NT$1 billion (US$31.9 million) just completed by the MOEA's Water Resources Agency and the Taiwan Water Corporation in May to catch water in the upper part of the reservoir failed when typhoon Matsa swept the country last week.
Chu suggested that the government should set up a new purifying plant near the reservoir, as well as some other construction projects related to water catchment.

DOC.HEADLINE: DATABANK NECESSARY TO FIGHT SEX CRIMES

TEXT.P: Establishing a crime databank is extremely important in the government's efforts to combat sex crimes in conjunction with a modified and stricter law that took effect Friday, according to law enforcement authorities.

According to National Police Administration (NPA) statistics, a total of 2,817 sex crimes were reported to police last year, 2,605 of which were solved and 2,535 offenders arrested. A total of 2,903 people fell victim to sex offenses, with 1,498 aged between 12 and 17 forming the largest victim group and the 18-23 age group of 426 victims coming second.

Despite the fact that a vast majority of 92 percent of last year's cases were solved, victims sometimes still live in the shadow of fear for the rest of their lives, police said, adding that to help the victims, the newly revised sex crime prevention act allows broader legal protection for victims in the investigation process.

The law also provides greater everyday protection for women by setting up stronger and more consistent mechanisms in various spectrums from community surveillance, medical treatment and public registration with the aim of effectively warding off violent sex crimes and assisting victims to build new lives, the NPA said.
The law also stipulates that sex offenders released on bail must periodically report to and register their personal data with police authorities.
Despite all these measures, it is also very important to set up a national crime databank, which the NPA has been promoting, they pointed out.

According to NPA officials, U.S. law enforcement agencies already have such a databank, which comprises criminal statistics, classifications and artificial intelligence to help police make composite judgments to break cases.

Pointing to the 130-year-old El Paso Intelligence Center (EPIC) as an example, the NPA officials said that the EPIC is both a coordination center and a crime databank that gathers and shares information on illegal activities related to drug and weapons trafficking, money laundering and smuggling.

As the EPIC is a national crime-fighting center composed of officials from the police, immigration, customs and coastal patrol authorities from 18 states, it contains more than 100 million criminal records and provides information around the clock, helping to nab criminals swiftly even across different states, they explained.

Meanwhile, with the widespread use of computers and the Internet, there is an urgent need for the government to set up a national unit responsible for investigating Internet crime and keeping evidence through digital technology, prosecution authorities said, adding that the NPA, the Investigation Bureau and forensics should work together toward that goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO, TAIWAN WORKING ON ESTABLISHING PRACTICAL EXCHANGE MECHANISM
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The participation of two Taiwanese health experts in the 6th Global Conference on Health Promotion being held in Bangkok Aug. 7-11 demonstrates that the World Health Organization (WTO) and Taiwan are working together to establish a practical exchange mechanism.

This is the first time that the WHO has invited Taiwan to take part in an important international health meeting since the organization signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with China in May of this year. Taiwan has long encountered difficulties in participating in WHO activities due to its lack of membership and to China's interference.

Although the World Health Assembly, the highest decision-making body of the WHO, agreed last May to include the "Principle of Universality" in its revised International Health Regulations (IHR) , which Taiwan believes will provide a legal basis for the island to participate in WHO activities in the future, the revised regulations do not go into effect until 2007.

According to the MOU signed by the world health body and China, the WHO can invite Taiwan health experts to participate in its technical-level meetings and can send its experts or officials to the island to deal with disease-investigation and disease-prevention matters.

WHO spokesman Iain Simpson has said that the organization has decided to invite Taiwan's experts to participate in its international health meetings based on the stipulations contained within the MOU it signed with China.

Nevertheless, Taiwan's stance of refusing to recognize the memorandum remains unchanged. The island claims that its health experts' participation in the current meeting in Bangkok has nothing to do with the memorandum, which it says downgrades Taiwan to the status of a local government.

A source from Taiwan's mission in Geneva said that Taiwan's goal is to participate in WHO activities "under the principles of equality and dignity" as well as to establish a cooperation and exchange framework with the organization.

Claiming that Taiwan's participation in the Bangkok meeting is the result of the island's own efforts, the source said that Taiwan is not interested in the WHO spokesman's comments about the MOU because the island does not recognize it.

The source did admit that Taiwan and the WHO are still in the feeling out stage in terms of finding ways to establish a stable and effective framework for future cooperation and exchanges, adding that the Bangkok meeting is at the very least a good start in this respect.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 9, or the fifth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1794: General Napoleon Bonaparte is arrested in France on suspicions of Robespierrism.
1814: Under the terms of the Treaty of Fort Jackson signed between the U.S. government and the native Creek tribe, the Creeks lose 9.3 million hectares of land -- over half of Alabama and part of southern Georgia -- to the United States.
1842: The United States signs the Webster-Ashburton Treaty with Britain, establishing the boundary between the U.S. and Canada from Maine to the Great Lakes.
1867: John Harrison Surratt is arrested for being an alleged conspirator in the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln.
1902: Edward VII, 64, is crowned King of Great Britain and Ireland after a six-week delay due to an emergency appendectomy.
1903: Giuseppe Sarto becomes Pope Pius X following the death of Pope Leo XIII.
1919: India concludes a secret pact with Britain, recognizing Britain as India's protector after Britain promised India a major role in its own government.
1928: Italian divers find precious diamonds in the wreckage of "Elizabethville," a Belgian ship sunk during World War I.
1937: Japanese troops clash with Chinese forces at Hungchiao airport in Shanghai.
1938: Rod Laver, Australian tennis star, is born. He won the singles title at Wimbledon four times.
1942: Mohandas K. Gandhi, leader of the Indian National Congress, is arrested in Britain for his "Quit India" campaign, which demands that the British should withdraw from India.
1945: Soviet troops enter Manchuria after the Soviet Union declares war on Japan.
1946: Henry Pu Yi, who was enthroned as the "Emperor of Manchukuo" in Changchun by Japanese militarists on Mar. 1, 1934, arrives in Tokyo to testify before an international court against Japanese war crimes committed during the invasion of China.
1954: The Republic of China Navy sinks 12 Communist Chinese ships at Tungshan seaport, Dongshan Island, near Fukien province.
1965: Singapore is separated from Malaysia and becomes an independent state within the Commonwealth of Nations.
1973: Ku Cheng-kang, honorary chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, leaves for Washington to attend a WACL Executive Committee meeting.
1974: Gerald R. Ford is sworn in as the 38th president of the United States after the resignation of Richard Nixon.
1979: Councilors in the English seaside town of Brighton cause a furor by agreeing to allow naturalists to bare all on "Cliff Beach," one of the less popular beaches in the district.
1990: Communist China's first airship, with a length of 40 meters, makes its maiden flight over Hupei province.
1994: The U.S. government announces trade sanctions against the ROC under the Pelly Amendment, placing a ban on imports of Taiwan wildlife products effective from August 19, 1994.
1999: The China External Trade Development Council signs a memorandum of understanding on technological cooperation with the Agency for International Development of Technology and Trade under the Trade and Industry Ministry of France.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui says the main reason he voiced the "special state-to-state relations" statement regarding cross-Taiwan Strait ties the previous month was to elucidate the fact that the Republic of China exists in the world.
2000: The Chinese International Economic Cooperation Association is established to promote Taiwan's trade and cooperation with the international community.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to gain confidence for one's authority. If a man is not trusted by one's friends, he will not gain the confidence for his authority."

The economy grew by 4 percent in the first half of the year, boosted by a creditable second quarter showing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW AIMED AT MAINTAINING STATUS QUO: S'PORE MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C.tang)

TEXT.P: Singapore Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew said in an interview with the German weekly "Der Spiegel" that he thinks the purpose of China's recent enactment of an anti-secession law is to maintain the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.

In the interview carried in the weekly's Aug. 8 issue, Lee further said that China's enactment of the law was also meant as a warning to the United States and others not to interfere in matters related to the Taiwan issue.

Lee also said that one of the goals of China's military modernization is to deal with a possible declaration of independence by Taiwan and to dissuade the United States from coming to Taiwan's defense in such a situation.

China has no intention of attacking Taiwan, according to the minister, and the passage of the anti-secession is meant to show the United States, Japan and others that it will have to go to war in the event of a declaration of independence by Taiwan.
Therefore, the aim of the anti-secession law is to maintain the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG NEW STEEL MILL PLAN IN SPOTLIGHT

TEXT.P: With Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) preparing to send an environmental impact assessment report on its project to construct a multi-billion-dollar steel mill for governmental approval this week, the question of whether the plan will pass strict official reviews has attracted public attention.

An FPG spokesman said Tuesday that the group has made all-out efforts to prepare the project for over a year while spending a lot in seeking to have the proposed plant feature the world's foremost manufacturing process in steel refinery.

If the environmental impact assessment report fails to obtain the Environmental Protection Administration's (EPA) approval, the group will have to abandon the investment project worth NT$130 billion (US$4.07 billion), the FPG official said.

The EPA's environmental assessment committee will undergo a personnel change in the next few days, meaning the FPG's steel mill project will be reviewed by a new group of environmental experts, EPA officials said. They added the environmental review of the project will take about three months to complete.
The FPG's plant, if approved, will have an annual output of 7.5 million tons of steel products.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPRESSES CONCERNS ABOUT ARREST OF HONG KONG REPORTER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug.8 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department on Monday expressed its concern about the arrest of Ching Cheong, a Hong Kong-based correspondent for the Singapore daily Straits Times, and said that it has raised the matter with Chinese authorities.

Ching, who was arrested April 12 in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou, was formally charged by the Chinese state security bureau Aug. 5 with selling economic, political and military information to Taiwan.

In response to a question raised at a daily press briefing, State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli said that the United States is concerned about Ching's arrest and is following the case closely.
Noting that freedom of press is a fundamental and internationally recognized right, Ereli said that the United States views any attempt to restrict this right with great concern.

"We have spoken to the Chinese of our concerns about the treatment of journalists in general and the important roles they play in providing information to the public, " he further said, adding: "We have also raised Mr. Ching's case and we intend to seek additional information from China."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER PROMISES RESTORED WATER SUPPLY TO TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Tuesday that water supplies to Taoyuan County on a rotational basis will continue, but claimed that supplies to the southern part of the county can be fully restored by Saturday.
Ho also said that supplies to northern Taoyuan will also return to normal if the turbidity in the catchment area of the Taoyuan river returns to a normal level.
Ho said she will take full responsibility if she fails to deliver on her promise.

Water supplies, a perennial headache for Taoyuan County, became a problem again after typhoon Matsa, which swept across Taiwan Friday, brought torrential rain and stirred up sediment, bringing silt and debris into the Shihmen reservoir, the county's main supplier. Approximately 600,000 households in Taoyuan are currently suffering from water rationing.
Meanwhile, Premier Frank Hsieh convened a meeting Tuesday with officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Water Resources Agency and the Taiwan Water Corp. (TWC).

Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai said the focus of the meeting was how to solve the water shortage problem during the two to three years until construction of new water purification plants is complete.

On who should take responsibility for the latest shortages, Cho said the premier has said it is not the time to talk about who should step down and that the more urgent task is to restore water supplies.

Meanwhile, TWC Chairman Lee Wen-liang said that despite days of torrential rain that have raised the turbidity levels in rivers in greater Kaohsiung and Taoyuan, greater Kaohsiung should have sufficient water supplies barring more unexpected rain.
But he was not optimistic about full restoration of water to Taoyuan because of the high level of turbidity in the catchment areas of the Shihmen reservoir.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOTE-SELLING FATAL TO TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY, FORMER PRESIDENT WARNS

TEXT.P: Decrying the "intolerable" situation in Taiwan of a "rich" government ruling poor people, former President Lee Teng-hui said Tuesday that vote-selling not only hurts Taiwan's democracy but will also deal it a fatal blow.

Speaking to a group of school teachers and young men and women in the southern port city, Lee, who led Taiwan from 1988 until 2000, said when he was the nation's leader, economic growth averaged 6 percent to 7 percent a year, but now the nation's GDP growth has slipped to a mere 2 percent or 3 percent.

This, which he claimed is "poor economic performance, " has been further troubled by a "higher than usual" unemployment rate, Lee said. "Once the people have trouble leading a decent life, once they're penniless, it's useless for Taiwan to have democracy only in name," he said.

He said he hopes the ruling class, once it has achieved its political ideal of getting power, will try to reach "the proletariat goal of sharing, " so that the poor will not be "forced to sell their votes" and deal a deadly blow to Taiwan's democracy.
The ruling class should also talk with other political parties over resource sharing, income distribution and any other worthy topics, Lee said.

Unless one of the parties is like the Communist Party, which holds ideology above all, "there should not be any problem that cannot be solved, " he said, emphasizing the importance of building mutual trust and discussing in good faith.
He also suggested that local Taiwanese should "understand and forgive" people who emigrated from China, and vice versa, so that the two ethnic groups can forge a "common community."

Efforts should also be made to build a solid civil society in which the ideal of "national sovereignty in the hands of the people" can be realized so that each and every citizen, irrespective of his class or vocation, can be the master of the country, Lee said.
His topic was "Who Are We? And the Road that Taiwanese in This New Era Should Take." The talk was sponsored by a civic group called "The Academy of Taiwanese Cultural Seeds."

La Repubblica: S&P lowers Italy's credit rating.
S&P lowered Italy's long-term credit rating to AA- and short-term rating to A-1+, with an outlook from stable to negative, mainly due to an increasing deficit of public debt which is estimated to top five percent next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIDDLE SCHOOL HERO AWARDED FOR FOILING BANK ROBBERY

TEXT.P: A courageous junior high school student, surnamed Li, was awarded NT$20,000 (US$ 625) by the Police Bureau of Chiayi City Tuesday in recognition of his bravery in foiling a bank robbery a day earlier.

Li, aged 13, witnessed the robbery Monday afternoon while passing by the Talin Branch of Chiayi Fourth Credit Cooperative. Without hesitation, he grabbed the robber's neck from behind to restrain him. A number of tellers then rushed to help and overpowered the man before turning him over to police. The robber had been arm with a home-made handgun.

Chiayi City Mayor Chen Li-chen, accompanied by the city's police commissioner, Chen Kuo-en, held a citation ceremony for Li at Peihsin Junior High School Tuesday morning, presenting him with the cash award.
Li's classmates expressed admiration for his bravery and quick thinking, calling him a "hero." They said that Li has always been willing to help others at school.

Li also won praise from his father, although his concerned mother suggested that he should not put his own safety at risk again if faced with a similar situation in the future. Li, however, responded by saying that he would still do what he had to if a similar situation ever arose.

According to the police investigation, the previously-convicted robber Liu Kuo-chou tried to divert the attention of police ahead of the robbery by claiming in a phone call that a bomb had been planted at Peihsin Junior High School. In ironic twist of fate, Liu's robbery attempt was foiled by a student from the very same school.
Liu remains in police custody for further questioning ahead of being formally charged by prosecutors.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT'S OPPOSITION TO PENGHU-CHINA LINKS BACKFIRES

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui's opposition to direct links between Penghu and China has backfired on the outlying island county, with local opinion leaders planning to head for Taipei next week to ask for legislative support for the links.

Lawmaker Lin Pin-kun, Penghu County Council Speaker Liu Chen Chao-ling and various other councilors made the announcement Monday at a news conference in which they said they had decided to come to Taipei Aug. 17 to demand that the Executive Yuan clarify its position on the issue and to seek backing from the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.

Expressing their dissatisfaction with Lee's threat that opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) supporters will take to the streets against a plan unveiled last week by Premier Frank Hsieh to allow direct transport and trade links between Penghu and China on a trial basis from September, they explicitly said "No" to Lee and called on local residents to unite and rally against the TSU on the streets.
They asked President Chen Shui-bian and the premier not to be distracted by Lee's political ideology and to stand firm on the planned measure that will help promote Penghu's economy.

If the TSU mobilizes supporters to block the government's plan, Penghu residents are fully entitled to voice their opinion, they argued, pointing out that Lee, when he served as president in 1997, also favored wider opening for Penghu.

Councilor Su Kun-hsiung, who is also chairman of the Penghu Tourism Association, said he strongly believes that the opening will benefit Penghu in many fields, including making the island county a transit spot for cargo ships passing through the Taiwan Strait.

Last Sunday, Lee blasted Hsieh's initiative to set up direct links for Penghu with China, criticizing it as an awkward move designed by the government to try to turn the tide of falling popularity after failing to persuade Taiwan farmers not to sell their produce to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIRWAYS HAS BENEFITED FROM COOPERATION WITH SHANGHAI AIRLINES

TEXT.P: The cargo transportation operation of EVA Airways has expanded significantly since the Taipei-based carrier began cooperation with Shanghai Airlines two years ago on a cargo flight route between Taipei and Shanghai via Macau, EVA officials said Tuesday.
With abundant cargo sources in Shanghai, EVA's Taipei-U.S. cargo shipments have risen to account for 60 percent of the company's total cargo business, EVA officials said.

According to the officials, the company's cargo aircraft takes over Shanghai Airlines deliveries in Macau, then transports them via Taipei to six major cities in the United States, including Atlanta, Dallas, Chicago, San Francisco, Los Angeles and New York.

Given the increasing shipping demands, EVA leased three MD-11 all-cargo airplanes this year to operate the U.S. cargo services, the officials said, noting that the company took delivery of its third leased aircraft in early August after introducing the first and second planes in March and April, respectively.

With the new aircraft, EVA now flies 44 all-cargo flights to the United States per week. From September -- the U.S. traditional busy season in cargo transportation -- EVA cargo flights between Taipei and Los Angeles will be further increased from the current 11 flights per week to 13, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 0.03 points to close at 6,380.
The bourse opened at 6,374.6 and fluctuated between 6,397.37 and 6,361.19 during trading. A total of 3.09 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89.06 billion (US$2.78 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Only two of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down at 0.4 percent and machinery and electronics shares losing 0.2 percent.
Cement stocks remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 430 to 421, with 155 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TAIEX Index futures for September moved up 20 points to end at 6,382, with 798 contracts traded, while December futures remained unchanged at 6,350, with two contracts traded. March futures moved down 14 points to close at 6,335, with two contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX
