A total of US$679 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.949 and fluctuated between NT$31.932 and NT$31.990.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DECISION ON HK CARRIER'S APPLICATION: MAC

TEXT.P: The government has yet to make a final decision on an application by Hong Kong Express Airways to operate charter flights between Hong Kong and the central Taiwan city of Taichung, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday.

The Cabinet-level MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward China, was responding to a media report that the MAC has rejected out of defense concerns Hong Kong Express Airways' application to operate a daily round-trip Hong Kong-Taichung charter flight from Aug. 7.

While screening the application, the report said, both the MAC and the Ministry of National Defense were reserved about the case because Taichung's Chingchuankang Airport is located on an air force base.
Commenting on the report, the MAC said in a news release that the Hong Kong carrier's application is still being deliberated and is pending a final decision.

The press statement further said it is an established policy that Chingchuankang Airport will be developed into Taiwan's third full-fledged international airport after Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport.

To realize that goal, the statement said, the government is conducting various assessment and improvement projects. When all those improvement projects are completed, it said, Chingchuankang Airport will be able to accommodate regular international flights and many more charter flights. At present, the airport can only accommodate domestic flights and a limited number of short-range international charter flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA MISSION SUGGESTS MERGER OF TAIWAN TEXTILE MAKERS IN AFRICA

TEXT.P: In the face of a deluge of Chinese textile products around the world, Taiwan textile makers operating in southern Africa should consider mergers or risk elimination amid fierce competition, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Cho Shih-chao, director-general of the MOFA's Economic and Trade Affairs Department, said at a routine news conference that the conclusion was reached in a report by a MOFA mission that recently visited Lesotho, Malawi and Swaziland to provide professional consultations to Taiwan textile and garment makers based in the three countries during an 11-day tour that began July 28.
The report will be tendered to a Taiwan-Africa task force under the ministry for reference in future policymaking, Cho said.

Wu Tao-chang, a member of the MOFA mission, urged Taiwan investors in that part of world to get ready for the change with the removal of a global quota system early this year and the appreciation of local currencies. Middle-sized Taiwan companies should consider mergers to cope with the situation or face elimination in the international market, he said.

The seven-member group of MOFA officials and textile experts visited some 20 Taiwan companies in the three countries, providing counselling and exchanging opinions on market deployment, business management and financial improvement as part of the government's efforts to extend care to Taiwan businessmen based in southern Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITUNG WARMING UP FOR AUSTRONESIAN CULTURES FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Following a news conference in Taipei, a warm-up activity was held by the Taitung county government Tuesday to promote the 2005 Austronesian Cultures Festival scheduled to kick off Saturday in the southeastern county.

The activity started with an Amei tribal elder praying for good luck for the event, after which Taitung County Magistrate Hsu Ching-yuan, wearing traditional aboriginal attire, demonstrated how to use an Amei fishing net.

Hsu noted that Taitung has the highest population of aboriginals in Taiwan. "It is the county government's wish to promote tourism in Taitung by attracting more visitors to participate in the Austronesian Cultures Festival," Hsu said.

The festival, which will run until Aug. 16, features the maritime culture of the Austronesians. It includes an international seminar, live performances and food-tastings and a number of exhibitions of aboriginal craftwork.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCTORS SAVE MAN WITH RUPTURED HEART

TEXT.P: Doctors at Kaohsiung's Veterans General Hospital joined the family of a man Tuesday to celebrate his "rebirth" from a near-fatal traffic accident in which his heart was ruptured and stopped.

More than a month ago, Chien Chao-yi was sent to the emergency unit of the hospital after a serious motorcycle accident. When he reached the hospital, doctors found that both his breathing and heartbeat had stopped.

The emergency room doctors diagnosed a ruptured heart and immediately opened the patient's chest without anaesthetic and without obtaining permission from his family to do the operation, which was successful.

Dr. Ye Wen-bin, a chief surgeon at the hospital, said he and his colleagues felt they had time to save Chien's life, so they proceeded immediately with the surgery, while Dr. Chang Hung-tai, who was one of the surgical team, said the survival rate for similar cases is less than 2 percent.
Chang and the other doctors joined Chien's family in singing happy birthday to him. Tuesday was Chien's "first birthday" since being brought back from the brink of death.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INSTRUCTS GOVERNMENT TO RESOLVE TAOYUAN WATER SHORTAGE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh issued instructions Tuesday to relevant agencies to increase the water supply from Taipei County's Pan-Hsin Water Plant to Taoyuan residents, who have suffered water shortages during the last few days.

Residents in Taoyuan County -- which is served by the Shihmen reservoir -- have suffered water shortages during the last two years almost every time there is a strong typhoon, as the water treatment facilities are inadequate for dealing with the increased turbidity that occurs after heavy rain.
Tuesday was the fourth day that Taoyuan residents had suffered water rationing after typhoon Matsa swept the country last Friday.

At a ministerial conference, Hsieh said the Pan-Hsin Water Plant, which supplies water to most parts of Taipei County, must increase its water supply from the current 110,000 tons per day to 200,000 tons, while the relevant government agencies must improve the water catchment in the upper part of the Shihmen reservoir to prevent the mud brought by typhoon Matsa and recent rainfall clogging the treatment facilities.

In the long term, he added, the central and local governments should cooperate in the construction of a high-end purification plant near the reservoir that can handle 800,000 tons of water per day, within two years.

Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said the government will earmark NT$600 million next year for water management, which will include efforts to prevent mudslides and pay for reforestation, as well as a budget of NT$1.5 billion to dredge the Shihmen reservoir and take water from different levels of the reservoir.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Luzhkov Takes on Catherine's Folly
Mayor Yury Luzhkov has been compared to a tsar many times. Now he has his eye on one tsar's folly. After agreeing with federal authorities to swap a museum for Catherine the Great's Tsaritsyno summer estate, Luzhkov is pouring 410 million rubles ($14.38 million) into the ruins and surrounding park to turn them into a major tourist attraction.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Washington Post: Oil-Food Official Pleads Guilty; Russian Is First From U.N. to Be Charged in Case.
A federal prosecutor investigating corruption in the $64 billion oil-for-food program issued the case's first criminal charges against a U.N. official, accusing a former Russian procurement officer of receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes from companies doing business with the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM UNION STAGES PROTEST AGAINST SHARE RELEASES

TEXT.P: Representatives of state-run Chunghwa Telecom staged protests in northern, central and southern Taiwan Tuesday as the company made 290 million shares available for private and corporate investors in Taiwan as part of a move toward privatization.
The 290 million shares represent 3 percent of the company's total shares.

More than 30 union members sat in front of the Jenai Road service center of Chunghwa Telecom -- Taiwan's largest telecommunications company with revenues in the first half of this year totaling NT$89.7 billion (US$2.84 billion) -- holding banner that read "defending working rights."

Union Chairman Chang Hsu-chung said the strike will be a long-term struggle and he urged the company's 28,000 staff, their families and friends to call via cell phones for five minutes at 11 a.m., 3 p.m. and 4 p.m., "to create profits for Chunghwa Telecom."

The union also supplied the phone numbers of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, which has jurisdiction over Chunghwa Telecom, and the Executive Yuan, urging the same people to call at 11 a.m. simultaneously to express their protest.
In Taichung, central Taiwan, around 100 Chunghwa Telecom union officials staged a sit-in in front of Chunghwa's Taichung branch.
Lin Hsin-mao, a spokesman for the sit-in, shouted slogans "oppose conglomerization of Chunghwa," as well as "legal strike."
Lin said that many union members joined the protest after receiving notification via text messages.

The strike was to highlight the "high-handed government, " Lin said, claiming that the cash-strapped government is eager to sell the shares to finance its arms procurement. He further claimed that this violates a resolution of the Legislative Yuan to release the shares only with full communications with the union to ensure the rights of the workers.
In Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, the strike seriously affected telecommunications services, with repair and maintenance work, as well as other services, coming to a virtual standstill.

Union members of the Chunghwa Telecom Kaohsiung branch account for two-thirds of the branch's staff, and union members from Chiayi, Tainan and Pingtung also joined their Kaohsiung counterparts for the protest.

Faced with the strike, the management of the Kaohsiung branch apologized for undermining the rights of customers, saying that they would communicate with the union. They said they would also use the limited available manpower to serve the customers and that the management will also come out to provide direct service if necessary.
Meanwhile, the Chinese Federation of Labor Unions strongly condemned Chunghwa Telecom for releasing shares at home and overseas with total disregard for the Legislative Yuan's resolution.

Lin Hui-kuan, president of the federation and an opposition People First Party Legislator, said the strike is not simply a labor-management dispute but is about whether the release of shares of a state-owned enterprise will undermine the public interest.

He noted that the Legislative Yuan passed the resolution that Chunghwa Telecom should stop releasing shares May 27, but the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) still planned to issue the American Depository Receipts (ADRs) in the United States and will release a total of 17 percent of its shares at home and overseas.

This will mean that the MOTC, which owns 65 percent of Chunghwa, will cut its share holdings to 48 percent, making the firm technically a private company, Lin said, adding that financial groups will then be able to easily take over management of Chunghwa, thereby seriously affecting the public interest.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESCUE TEAM AIRLIFTS NECESSITIES TO VILLAGES IN HSINCHU COUNTY

TEXT.P: Helicopters dropped necessities to several aboriginal villages in Hsinchu County in northern Taiwan Tuesday that have been cut off for four days since typhoon Matsa swept Taiwan last week.

Matsa caused heavy rain and blocked several roads serving Chienshih village and the Wufeng area of Hsinchu, interrupting their communication with the outside world. Several hundred residents there will soon run out of food.

According to Lin Hsiang-chin, head of the Hsinchu County Fire Department, the rescue helicopters from the National Fire Administration under the Ministry of the Interior have made 22 flights to bring out sick people and drop 2,000 kg of rescue supplies during the last few days.

Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin said he felt sorry that Chienshih and Wufeng have been ranked as "frequent victim areas" because they suffer mudslides and road collapses almost every time there is a strong typhoon.
Cheng urged the Cabinet to map out a comprehensive resolution to the problem in his county.
Meanwhile, he also extended his gratitude to Lions Clubs Taiwan for the organization's concern for aboriginal people and its donation of daily necessities worth NT$300,000 to aboriginal villages.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL INCOME UP IN JULY

TEXT.P: The national coffers collected a total of NT$95.2 billion (US$2.98 billion) in tax revenues in July, up by 4.7 percent, or NT$4.3 billion, compared with the previous year's level, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported Tuesday.

Income tax revenue showed the largest increase of 110.4 percent, or NT$3 billion, over the 2004 level, mainly due to the fact that tax payers are required to pay their income taxes to the government by the end of May, MOF officials said, noting that the combined tax revenue for the first seven months had already reached NT$972.2 billion, up by NT$92.6 billion year on year and accounting for 70.5 percent of the annual target set by the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO TALK WITH LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER ON SPECIAL SESSION

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that he will talk with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng on convening a special legislative session after Wang returns to Taiwan.

Wang, who is in the United States with his family and will return Wednesday, decided prior to the trip that he will preside over an informal meeting Friday to discuss whether to convene a special legislative session.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) requested the special session to discuss the Executive Yuan's eight-year, NT$80 billion ( US$2.54 billion) flood-prevention project and five other prioritized bills, although the Kuomintang (KMT), the main opposition party, insists that it will only agree to a special session if the only item on the agenda is the flood- control project.
With the parties deadlocked on the issue, the KMT legislative caucus said it has handed out questionnaires to KMT legislators to learn about their views.

Cho Po-yuan, a KMT caucus whip in the legislature, said there are different views within the party on whether to convene a special session, and the party will know more after the questionnaires are collected on Wednesday.

DPP officials have said that a special session should not only discuss the flood-prevention proposal, adding that the NT$480 billion arms procurement package, the confirmation of Control Yuan members, proposed amendments to the Executive Yuan Organic Law, proposed amendments to the tobacco and liquor tax law, and a draft bill concerning the establishment of a labor pension fund monitoring committee are also urgent matters that need to be dealt with.
All six bills should be reviewed in the special session and should not be left to the next regular session which is scheduled to open in September, they stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIST WARNS OF SLOWING EXPORTS

TEXT.P: An economist warned Tuesday of Taiwan's slowing exports and called on the government to craft adequate policies and make effective adjustments to improve what he described as eroding competitiveness in the face of China's fierce challenges.
Chen Po-chih, Taiwan Thinktank chairman and a former chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the comments in an interview with the CNA.

Pointing out that slowing exports, rather than shrinking trade surplus, is a clear reflection of Taiwan's falling competitive edge and deteriorating business climate, Chen urged the government to tackle the problem of Chinese products increasingly replacing Taiwan-made goods in the world market and the many possible side effects.

Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$750 million in the first seven months of this year, a plunge from the previous year's US$4.77 billion, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Finance (MOF). Vice Premier Wu Rong-i called it an issue of major concern and said that relevant authorities will do something to improve the situation.

MOF statistics show that Taiwan outbound shipments increased by only 6.6 percent in the same seven-month period year to year, lagging behind an annual 11.2 precent expansion rate in inbound shipments.

Noting that an export increase rate of 7 percent or above can be viewed as an indication that a country's competitive edge remains benign, Chen ascribed Taiwan's slowing export growth to the fact that locally made products are increasingly being edged out by Chinese merchandise in the world market and he called for government initiatives to boost exports.
Meanwhile, Taiwan exports in July hit US$15.43 billion, up by 5.3 percent over the previous year's level and an increase of 3.1 percent compared with June's level, MOF tallies show.
Taiwan imports in July expanded by an annual growth of 9.7 percent to US$15.1 billion, up from a 2.5 percent rise in June, leaving the country with a trade surplus of US$330 million for July.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CONCERNED ABOUT WATER SHORTAGE IN TAOYUAN COUNTY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged the Taoyuan county government Tuesday to cooperate with the central government in its efforts to alleviate the water shortage problems that have been plaguing local residents for years.

Lu expressed her concerns before attending a weekly meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's central standing committee in Taipei. She said that both the central and local government should review existing measures for dealing with water sources in Taoyuan.

In response to a roasting from Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun of the central government over its reluctance to help Taoyuan, the vice president, who had served as magistrate of Taoyuan County for three years, said the administration should be responsible for the problem.

During her three-year term as Taoyuan county chief, Taoyuan had the best record of water and soil conservation in the country and its Shihmen reservoir was never subject to serious silting, she claimed.

After typhoon Matsa swept Taiwan Aug. 5, bringing torrential rain to northern parts of Taiwan, Taoyuan has suffered a serious water shortage because the water in the Shihmen reservoir is too muddy to serve for household use.

Lu said that besides the Shihmen reservoir, many other reservoirs around Taiwan are also suffering from silting. She said modern technology could transform this silt into useful construction material if efforts were taken to develop such technology, she claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA BEGINS SELECTION OF PANDAS THAT COULD BE SENT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: China began a process Tuesday to select which two pandas could be sent to Taiwan as gifts, assuming that Taiwan decides to accept them.

Media reports said that a "panda selection show, " sponsored by the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council and the State Forestry Bureau, kicked off at the Wolong Nature Reserve in Sichuan province Tuesday. A score of panda experts and scholars will select a male and a female from the 17 prospective pandas, all of which were bred in captivity.

China offered a pair of pandas to opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan in early May as a goodwill gesture to the people of Taiwan, but it has not been decided if Taiwan will be willing or able to accept the pandas, despite keen interest expressed by both Taipei and Taichung to house the rare animals.

Meanwhile officials from the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said that whether Taiwan can accept the pandas will depend on four conditions. First is to find a suitable home for the animals since the wildlife conservation law stipulates that such animals must be cared for in appropriate places, such as zoos and research institutions of college and universities.

The second condition is whether the animals can be correctly provided for, including sufficient medical care. The third is whether the delivery of the pandas will conform to relevant domestic regulations; and lastly, major international conservation groups would have to have a say on whether Taiwan is able to take care of the animals.

MAC officials said that if there is no controversy concerning the entry of the pandas, and wildlife conservation groups also agree to their being shipped to Taiwan and the four conditions are also met, then the animals will likely be allowed to come to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MAKE TWO CASES FOR U.N. BID THIS YEAR: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government will make two cases for its U.N. participation this year and will bring to the world's attention China's ever-growing threat to Taiwan, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday.
Speaking during an informal meeting with local journalists, Chen said he thinks that this year is a good time for Taiwan to promote its bid to join the United Nations.

"This year marks the U.N.'s 60th anniversary. Since the goal of the U.N. is to maintain world peace, we plan to come up with a proposal to make sure that the U.N. pays attention to the situation on both sides of the Taiwan Strait," Chen said.

Since 1993, Taiwan has tried every year to ask the U.N. Steering Committee through its diplomatic allies to place Taiwan's U.N. bid on the General Assembly agenda. Taiwan has been unsuccessful every time beacuse of China's obstruction.

In addition to pushing the U.N. Steering Committee to discuss Taiwan's U.N. bid this year, Chen said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is considering putting forth another proposal urging the U.N. to take note of China's threat to Taiwan and take steps to safeguard peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Foreign ministry officials said earlier this month that the "safeguarding cross-strait peace" proposal is scheduled to be referred to the U.N. Secretariat Aug. 12, and the foreign ministry will hold a news conference at 3 p.m. that day to brief the public on the proposal.

During Tuesday's talks with local reporters, Chen said the government will tell of the Taiwan Strait situation in a rational and moderate manner to convince the world that Taiwan loves peace and wants to resolve disputes with China.
"We'll also explain our way of thinking about China's recently passed Anti-Secession Law in a calm and collected way," Chen said.
Over the past year, Chen said, China has launched an international publicity campaign aimed at projecting Taiwan in a negative light.

Chen said the trend reversed itself following China's passage of the Anti-Secession Law, which codifies the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan. Many countries criticized the law, Chen said, adding that the substantial growth in China's military spending and the unveiling of U.S. and Japanese reports on China's growing military power all point to growing international concern about Taiwan Strait security.

"Hopefully, our 'peace' proposal will arouse U.N. attention to the Taiwan Strait issue, thereby giving China a chance to understand that the world is watching the Taiwan Strait situation and thus reducing the risk of a conflict in the region, " Chen said, adding that the government will brief U.S. authorities on the key points of the "peace" proposal.
The 2005 General Assembly is scheduled to start Sept. 13 at the U.N. general headquarters in New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTIES URGE GOVERNMENT TO STABILIZE FOOD PRICES

TEXT.P: The caucuses of the two major opposition parties in the legislature Tuesday urged the government to take effective measures to stabilize vegetable and other food prices, which have soared to new highs since typhoon Matsa hit Taiwan last Friday.

Tsai Chin-lung, a whip of the Kuomintang's (KMT) legislative caucus, together with KMT Legislator Kuo Su-chun and Chin Huei-chu, a whip of the People First Party caucus, invited members of the news media to join them for a trip to Taipei City's South Gate Market to see for themselves whether vegetable prices had not gone up because of the typhoon, as Premier Frank Hsieh claimed.
The opposition legislators said the trip was made to show that Premier Hsieh knew nothing about vegetable prices and that he ought to feel the anger of housewives at soaring food prices.

On the day when Typhoon Matsa struck Taiwan last week, the premier went to a hypermarket along with a media entourage and filled a basket with eggs, carrots, grapefruits, grapes and two bundles of mater convolvulus -- a leafy vegetable that grow in water known as "kung hsin tsai" in Chinese -- with the bill coming to NT$270.
In an attempt to prove that the premier was merely putting on a show, the opposition legislators bought two heads of cabbage, two carrots and two bundles of "kung hsin tsai" at a cost of NT$303.

They criticized the premier for giving the public "wrong information" about food prices and said the government should take real measures to stabilize prices, knowing that price hikes are unavoidable because of typhoons.
Meanwhile, a spokesman for the Council of Agriculture said that vegetable prices are expected to go back to normal gradually this week as supplies increase.

The spokesman said the agriculture council hopes to keep vegetable supplies at 1,100 metric tons daily. He said that there are still 2,700 tons of refrigerated vegetable and 997 tons of frozen vegetables in warehouses -- enough to help cope with price fluctuations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Four in 9/11 Plot Are Called Tied to Qaeda in '00
More than a year before the Sept. 11 attacks, a small, highly classified military intelligence unit identified Mohammed Atta and three other future hijackers as likely members of a cell of Al Qaeda operating in the United States, according to a former defense intelligence official and a Republican member of Congressn. In the summer of 2000, the military team known as Able Danger, prepared a chart that included visa photographs of the four men and recommended to the military's Special Operations Command that the information be shared with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, but the recommendation was rejected and the information was not shared because Atta and the others were in the United States on valid entry visas. Under American law, United Sta tes citizens and green-card holders may not be singled out in intelligence-collection operations by the military or intelligence agencies.
Wall Street Journal: At Gucci, Mr. Polet's New Design Upends Rules for High Fashion
When the 50-yeaqr-old Robert Polet took the helm of Gucci Group in July last year, he has been trashing trashing luxury-industry taboos. Under its previous management, Gucci Group worshiped the cult of the all-powerful designer, a phenomenon epitomized by Tom Ford, Gucci's former creative chief. Polet, by contrast, thinks there's no reason why high-fashion houses shouldn't borrow some of the standard business practices used in other industries. He's pressing designers to keep tabs on what consumers want through research, such as focus groups. Over opposition from Ford holdovers, he's expanding Gucci into products such as flowered silk scarves and ice buckets. And while he agrees that creativity and quality are at the core of the business, he says the 82- year-old Gucci is stronger than any one designer. His approach has revitalized an age-old debate in the industry: Should you lead the consumer or follow her?

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DRAFTS RULES ON AIRCRAFT FLYING OVER CHINESE AIRSPACE

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has drafted rules governing Taiwan commercial aircraft interested in flying over Chinese airspace, officials said Tuesday.
MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said the draft rules have been sent to the Executive Yuan for approval. Once approved, Taiwan's air carriers can apply for permission to fly over Chinese airspace.
The carriers will also need approval from Chinese authorities before their passenger and cargo aircraft can fly over Chinese airspace to save fuel costs and flight times.
Premier Frank Hsieh announced on Aug. 3 that the government would allow Taiwan's international commercial aircraft to fly over China. The offer was originally made by China four year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS RESPONSIBLE FOR WATER SHORTAGES SHOULD STEP DOWN: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, angered by the recurrence of water shortages in Taoyuan County, said Tuesday any official found to be responsible for the problem should step down.
Chen made the statement while receiving a group of leaders of Lions Clubs International at the Presidential Office.

The president said he felt very sorry and was ashamed that Taoyuan County, which suffered water shortages last August after Typhoon Aere, is now in the same situation after Typhoon Matsa passed by the island last week.

Now, four days after the typhoon has gone, water supplies in Taoyuan County are still not fully restored, and the administration owes the residents an explanation as to why this problem happened again and when water supplies will be restored, the president said.
Noting that the government spent NT$1 billion last year trying to solve the problem, the president said that it appears that all the work was in vain.

"There is something wrong here and officials making apologies isn't going to make it go away, " the president said, referring to an apology made by Premier Frank Hsieh the previous day after the Taiwan Water Corporation (TWC) failed to restore water supplies in Taoyuan County on that day as the premier has said that they would be.
"The administration must find who is responsible for this and that person or persons must resign and bow to the public, " the president said.

Taoyuan County, which depends on the Shihmen Reservoir for its drinking water, has been on rotational water rationing since last Friday after Typhoon Matsa made the water in the reservoir too turbid for the purification equipment to operate properly.
The TWC said Monday that water supplies were at 60 percent of their normal levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT: REFERENDUM VETOED ANTI-MISSILE PURCHASE PLAN

TEXT.P: The outcome of the referendum on Taiwan's self defense held at the same time as last year's presidential election vetoed the idea of Taiwan purchasing anti-missile weaponry, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Chang Jung-kun said Tuesday.

Chang made the remarks amid the anger expressed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) toward the KMT's objection to an arms procurement package, in which Taiwan wants to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the U.S. for NT$480 billion.

Chang noted that the results of the referendum organized by the DPP government along with the presidential election on March 20 last year showed that the people were opposed to the government purchasing anti-missile systems.

In last year's referendum, the voters were asked whether the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons and whether the government should engage in negotiations with mainland China on the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interactions to build consensus and for the welfare of the peoples of both sides?"

Only 45.16 percent of voters cast the ballot on the first question, rendering the referendum invalid, as 50 percent had been previously determined as the threshold for the vote to be valid, although over 90 percent of those who did vote answered "yes" to both questions.
According to Chang, President Chen Shui-bian has ignored the results of the referendum, while criticizing the objections of the KMT to the arms purchase.

Concerning the reports that the World Federation of Taiwanese Associations will organize a mass demonstration on Sept. 25 calling for support for the arms procurement to strengthen Taiwan's national defense, Chang said President Chen should face the outcome of last year's referendum and make an open apology to the public for failing to respect the decision of the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENT NABBED FOR DEFRAUDING HONG KONG COED
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi County, southern Taiwan (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Police in Chiayi County arrested a junior high school student Tuesday for defrauding a Hong Kong university coed who had paid him US$1,416 for a computer he was offering on the Yahoo shopping Web site but that he didn't send her.
Police detectives, armed with a search warrant issued by the prosecutor's office, searched the student's residence in Minhsiung village and found evidence of the fraud.
The youngster, surnamed Tsai, admitted to the crime and is being prosecuted.
A police spokesman said the police station in Chiayi County received an e-mail from the university coed in Hong Kong, surnamed Peng, on June 9, reporting the fraud and demanding that justice be done.

The police station then invited the coed to come to Taiwan to provide more details and built a file on the case. Following the clues, the detectives found their suspect. They were surprised, however, that the suspect turned out to be a junior middle school student who attends a class for talented pupils at the school.

The police also found that Tsai is not only good at using the computer, but also has a good command of English, which he used to cheat the Hong Kong coed. The police said it was a shame that the youngster did not put his talent to good use, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUP TO MARCH FOR ARMS PROCUREMENT PACKAGE

TEXT.P: A pro-independence group announced Tuesday it will organize a march in Taipei Sept. 25 to push the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan to pass a long-stalled arms procurement package as early as possible to meet the nation's defense needs.

The Hand-in-Hand-to-Protect-Taiwan Alliance said the march is being organized in connection with the convening of the fifth annual congress of the World Federation of Taiwanese Associations in Taipei.

Ng Chiau-tong, the alliance's convener, said the march is aimed at urging the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) to put aside partisan bickering and pass the two arms procurement package-related bills for the sake of beefing up Taiwan's defense capabilities in the face of China's ever-growing threat.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its "pan-green" ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- both of which prioritize "Taiwan identity" in their platforms, said they will mobilize their party members to take part in the march.
Both DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang and TSU Chairman Su Jin-chiang attended the news conference hosted by Ng to threw their support behind the planned parade.

The two bills in question will pave the way for procuring eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States. One bill will authorize the administration to prepare a special budget for the NT$480 billion arms procurement package over a period of 15 years, the other bill is regarding budget appropriations for the package.
The "pan-blue alliance" has used its slim majority in the legislature to block the two bills from being put on the legislative agenda for two legislative sessions. (By Sofia Wu) ednitem/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER PUBLISHES ARTICLE PROMOTING TAIWAN'S U.N. BID

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday he has contributed an article to the Harvard International Review to promote Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.

Speaking with local journalists during an informal meeting, Chen said the article is part of his efforts to enhance international awareness of the necessity for Taiwan to have representation in the United Nations and greater presence in the international community as a whole.
"We have not done enough to promote our U.N. bid. We really need to step up international publicity to solicit more support for our cause," Chen said.
The article, titled "Joining the Global Village -- Taiwan's Participation in the International Community," carried in the 2005 summer edition of the prestigious magazine.
Chen said he listed a number of reasons in the four-page article to explain why the United Nations should not continue to shut out Taiwan.
According to Chen, the article has received warm response, with many overseas readers sending letters to him in support of his viewpoints.

The reasons outlined by Chen included that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait need a multilateral framework to ensure cross-strait peace and forge cooperation; Taiwan should be included in the global anti-terrorism mechanism because terrorist actions are borderless; Taiwan, as one of the world's six largest deep-sea fishing countries and a major maritime transport service provider, should be included in the global fishery resources and maritime environment protection mechanism; Taiwan should not be excluded from the global health and disease prevention networks; and Taiwan is willing and able to offer humanitarian aid to many needy countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ECONOMIST CALLS SHARP GROWTH OF IMPORTS HEALTHY

TEXT.P: The sharp surge of imports in the first seven months of this year is healthy, a government economist said Tuesday amid public concerns over the rapid shrinkage of the island's trade surplus during this period.

Yeh Ming-feng, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan, said the country' imports were driven up by 11.2 percent over the corresponding period of last year because of the country's purchase of aircraft as well as carriages for the high-speed railway, in addition to the increase in imported oil costs.

In a breakdown of the outlays for imports, Yeh said the rise in international oil prices has inflated the country's payments for fuel by US$2.57 billion over the same period of last year, not to mention the US$880 million for the delivery of seven Airbus planes, and US$480 million for carriages to be used on the high-speed railway.

However, all of the them are spendings for capital assets and agricultural and industrial raw materials which will in turn help the country's exports in the long term and are healthy for economic development, Yeh said.
Taiwan registered imports of US$104.3 billion, exports of US$105.1 billion and a trade surplus of US$750 million, which is the lowest in decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO HELP COMPANIES IMPLEMENT EU'S ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs will send experts to help domestic small- and medium-sized companies to conform with the European Union's environmentally friendly regulations to improve the island's competitiveness, a ministry official said Tuesday.

According to the official, many countries and multinational enterprises have begun to create legislation or map out strategies to conform with the EU's directive on Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment (WEEE) and its directive on the Restriction of the Use of Certain Hazardous Substances (RoHS) in Electrical and Electronic Equipment to explore trade opportunities in that region.
Under these guidelines, companies all over the world are required to supply non-hazardous and energy-saving equipment which can be recycled, the official stressed.

According to a survey conducted by the ministry, 37 percent of Taiwanese manufacturers are still not in compliance with WEEE regulations, while 13 percent of domestic plants do not comply with the RoHS directive.

The official from the ministry's Small and Medium Enterprise Administration noted that his agency will send experts to the plants of small- and medium-sized enterprises to show them how to conform and will hold many seminars to help the manufacturers upgrade their competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 10, or the sixth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1821: Missouri is admitted as the 24th state of the United States.
1846: The Smithsonian Institute is established in Washington as a center for scientific research with a bequest from English scientist James Smithson.
1874: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, is born. His belief in individual freedom led him to reject federal relief for unemployment during the Depression and lost him the 1932 election to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
1894: Varahagiri Venkata Giri, president of India from 1969 to 1974, is born. He was prominent in India's labor movement.
1904: During the Russo-Japanese War, the Russian fleet suffers heavy loses when the Japanese fleet blocks it from escaping from Port Arthur in the Battle of the Yellow Sea.
1913: The Treaty of Bucharest is signed, ending the second Balkan War and partitioning Macedonia among Serbia, Greece, Romania and Bulgaria.
1926: Northwest Airlines is established in Chicago.
1944: Yicheng County in Hupei Province changes its name to Chihchung County in memory of the bravery of Gen. Chang Chih-chung who died in action during the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1944: American forces recapture Guam from the Japanese after three weeks of fighting in which only 500 of the 18,000 defending Japanese troops survived and surrendered.
1945: Robert H. Goddard, American pioneer of rocket science, dies at the age of 63. He conducted the first successful launch of a liquid-propellant rocket in 1926. The rocket climbed 184 feet (56 meters) into the air at a speed of about 60 miles (97 kilometers) per hour.
1946: Gen. George C. Marshall, a special envoy of U.S. President Harry Truman to China on a mission to mediate the civil war between the Nationalists and the Chinese communists, issues a statement declaring that his efforts have failed.
1950: U.S. State Department official Karl L. Rankin arrives in Taipei as charge d'affaires of the U.S. Embassy.
1961: Britain applies to join the European Economic Community.
1966: Orbiter I, the first American moon satellite, is launched from Cape Kennedy.
1975: Flight service between the Republic of China and Japan resumes after the ROC government announced on April 20, 1974 the termination of the Taiwan-Japan flights of China Airlines and Japan Airlines.
1979: The newly completed Keelung-Suao Highway is opened to traffic.
1981: The joint meeting of the Second Asian Conference of the International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology and the First Asian Conference of the International Council of Psychologists opens in Taipei.
1990: The ROC government declares its support of a United Nations call for world sanctions against Iraq over its invasion of Kuwait.
1993: The New KMT Alliance breaks with the ruling Kuomintang and forms the New Party.
1993: Shih Yueh-po, a Chinese passenger, hijacks a mainland Chinese Boeing 767 passenger plane to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan.
1998: Some 2,000 people die in floods in China.
1998: Prince Al-Muhtadee Billah, eldest son of Sultan Hassan Bolkiah of Brunei, is proclaimed heir to the throne.
1999: The Republic of China inaugurates Asia's first flight recorder laboratory, allowing local personnel to analyze aircraft flight recorder (black box) data rather than having to send such data to a third country for analysis.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian accuses Beijing of hypocrisy in terms of its definition of "one China," and reiterates Taiwan's rejection of Beijing's demand that it embrace "one China" on Beijing's terms.
2001: After being on death row for almost 10 years, mainland Chinese hijackers Cho Chang-jen and Chiang Hung-chun are executed at the Taipei Prison for kidnap and murder.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to be trusted by one's friends. If a man does not command the obedience of the members of his family, he will not be trusted by his friends."

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO DEPRESSIONS LIKELY TO BECOME TYPHOONS: CWB

TEXT.P: Two tropical depressions that have formed from two low pressure systems in the Pacific Ocean and east of the Philippines could develop into typhoons and perhaps affect Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Wednesday.

The outer rim of one of the tropical depressions is expected to affect Taiwan beginning this Saturday, bringing downpours to the southern and southeastern parts of the island, CWB meteorologists said.

The tropical depression was located some 1,500 kilometers away from Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi, moving west-northwest towards Taiwan at a speed of 15 kilometers per hour as of 11 a.m. Wednesday, according to the CWB.
The other tropical depression, lurking near the Paracels Island and moving in a northwestern direction Wednesday morning, is less likely to affect Taiwan, the CWB meteorologists said.

Meanwhile, the meteorologists warned of high temperatures in Taiwan over the next few days, with highs of 35 degrees Celsius forecast for the northern Taiwan, 34 degrees Celsius for central and southern areas, and 33 degrees Celsius for eastern Taiwan, with afternoon thundershowers expected for mountainous areas in central and southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN LANDS ON PENGJIA ISLET TO SHOW RESOLVE IN PROTECTING TERRITORY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian landed on Pengjia Islet off the northern Taiwan coast Wednesday, making him the first Republic of China head of state to ever set foot on the nation's northernmost territory.

Chen presided over a new "Territorial Water Shield" monument unveiling ceremony on the islet to accentuate the government's resolve to maintain law and order in its northern territorial waters amid fishing disputes with Japan and frequent reports of poaching by Chinese fishing boats in the area.
During the ceremony, Chen also autographed copies a new book published by the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration to introduce Taiwan's territorial waters and 200-mile exclusive economic zones.
Pengjia Islet, located 56 kilometers northeast of Keelung Harbor, is Taiwan's northernmost territory and is guarded by military personnel and coast guard officers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CHINA CAN LEARN FROM EUROPEAN INTEGRATION: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said in an interview with the mass-circulation Russian daily "Trud" that it is worthwhile for both sides of the Taiwan Strait to learn from the European Union's integration process.

In the exclusive interview carried in the newspaper's Aug. 9 issue, the president said that the successful integration of the E.U. is based on the principles of democracy, equality, peace and economics as well as respect for each of the member state's free will.
"All E.U. members are equal and cannot resort to the use of force to solve their problems with one another," he further said.
The president also pointed out that process of Europe's integration began with the states discussing economic issues without touching on political and other ideological issues.

Saying that he would like to create an environment of peaceful development and free choice for both sides of the strait to normalize their relations, Chen stressed that he does not exclude the possibility of establishing any kind of cross-strait political relationship in the future if the people want him to do so.

However, he said that it is regrettable that China has not adhered to the four principles and spirit of the E.U.'s integration process to work on promoting cross-strait reconciliation and dialogue. "On the contrary, Beijing has dealt with matters with Taiwan by violating these principles and spirit, " he added.

Pointing out that China has violated the democratic principle and has not respected the free will and right of the 23 million people of Taiwan to determine their own future, the president said that Beijing has also disregarded the principle of equality by viewing itself as the central government while attempting to marginalize and downgrade Taiwan to the status of a local government.

He also criticized what he called China's violation of the principle of peace in handling matters with Taiwan, pointing out that Beijing has been actively building up its military and that it has refused to abandon the option of force against the island to solve cross-strait problems.
Accusing China of "not respecting the principle of economics, " Chen said that Beijing has always politicized economic issues, such as the issue of Taiwan's farm exports to the mainland.

Talking about Taiwan's future democratic process, the president said that the right to referendums is an important foundation for the island to consolidate its democracy and a concrete manifestation of the people's right to self-determination. He added that he is very proud that the Taiwan people have finally obtained this right, which he called "a basic human right and universal value."

Chen also promised that in order to make Taiwan "a normal, progressive, beautiful and great nation, " his government will continue to push for constitutional reform, expressing the hope that a new constitution can be promulgated by May 20, 2008.
"Trud, " which was founded in 1921, is Russia's second largest nationwide newspaper, with a daily circulation of 610,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT, PREMIER TO INSPECT SHIHMEN RESERVOIR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to tour the Shihmen Reservoir Wednesday afternoon in company with Premier Frank Hsieh to inspect and understand first-hand the heart of the persistent water shortage problem in Taoyuan County.
Angered by the recurrence of water shortages in the northern county, Chen said a day earlier that any official found to be responsible for the problem should step down.

Chen and Hsieh, who will be flanked by Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh, Water Resources Agency Director Chen Shen-hsien and Taiwan Water Co. Chairman Lee Wen-liang, are expected to inspect, aboard helicopter, the Shihmen Reservoir, one of the major reservoirs supplying running water to residents in northern Taiwan, its immediate catchment area and its filtering systems, according to Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai.

Taoyuan County, which suffered water shortages last August after Typhoon Aere, is now in the same situation after Typhoon Matsa passed near the island last week, bringing heavy rainfall and strong winds to the island. Nearly a week later, water supply in Taoyuan County has still not been fully restored.

Noting that the government spent NT$1 billion last year trying to solve the problem, Chen said that it appears that "all the work was in vain." He said the administration owes the residents an explanation as to why this problem has occurred again and when normal water supply will be restored.
Meanwhile, Premier Hsieh said Wednesday that he is confident that his administration will give Taoyuan residents clean water if given some time.

Hsieh said that the water shortage scourge should be tackled immediately and at its root, including water and soil conservation measures in the reservoir's catchment areas, a ban on deforestation, and an overhaul of the decades-old reservoir, including its water filtering, pumping and supplying systems. He added that it will take time to implement all these measures.

Taoyuan County, which depends on the Shihmen Reservoir for its drinking water supply, has been subjected to rotational water rationing since last Friday after rains brought by Typhoon Matsa made the water in the reservoir too muddy for the purification plant to operate properly.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAUNCHES EFFORTS TO PROMOTE ITS UN BID IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative office in Los Angeles has kicked off a two-month mission to spread the word about Taiwan's international position and political and economic development to mainstream U.S. society as part of the island's bid to gain re-entry into the United Nations (UN).

From Tuesday, officials of information affairs from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles (TECOLA) will travel to cities and towns around southern California to visit influential local groups to promote Taiwan and it's U.N. bid.
Kicking off the mission, Wang Si-hai of the TECOLA's information division arrived in the City of Industry Tuesday for a Rotary Club gathering.

At the event, Wang was invited to deliver a speech on Taiwan's political, economic and diplomatic situation. In his speech, he also talked about a series of significant historic events that resulted in Taiwan's withdrawal from the U.N. in 1971, and it's severing of diplomatic ties with the United States and Japan.

While mentioning Taiwan's political reforms launched by President Chen Shui-bian and the island's economic achievements in recent years, Wang suggested that the international community allow the country to rejoin the U. N. He also said it's important for Taiwan to have the United States' support to its U.N. bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LANDS ON PENGJIA ISLET, ASSERTS CLAIM TO TIAOYUTAIS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Taiwan's sovereignty claim to the Tiaoyutai islands Wednesday, saying the government's stance toward the issue has been clear and steadfast.

"The Tiaoyutais belong to Taiwan and our stance on the issue has never wavered or changed, " Chen said while presiding over a new "Territorial Water Shield" monument-unveiling ceremony on Pengjia, off the northern Taiwan coast.
Chen landed on the islet from a helicopter, making him the first Republic of China head of state ever to set foot on the nation's northernmost territory.

Addressing the ceremony, Chen said Pengjia sits on an important economic and strategic location, forming a chain with the neighboring Tiaoyutais to control the entrance to the East China Sea continental shelf, and that the surrounding area is one of the world's four largest fishing grounds.

In addition to boosting the morale of coast guard and military personnel stationed on the islet, Chen said his unprecedented visit was also aimed at accentuating the government's resolve to maintain law and order in its northern territorial waters amid fishing disputes with Japan and frequent reports of poaching by Chinese fishing boats in the region.

With a view to expanding its policing area and providing better protection for local fishermen, the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration plans to build new bases on Pengjia to facilitate patrol missions and monitoring of oil exploration disputes among neighboring countries, including Japan, China and South Korea.

Noting that the fishing dispute between Taiwan and Japan mainly results from the two countries' conflicting claim to the Tiaoyutais, Chen said the government has never compromised on its sovereignty claim.

The Tiaoyutais are a group of uninhabited islets in the East China Sea, located some 120 nautical miles northeast of Taiwan. The Tiaoyutais have been held by Japan since 1972, but Taiwan has never forsaken its sovereignty claim because the surrounding waters have been Taiwan's traditional fishing grounds. Over the years, Japanese coast guard patrols have often impounded Taiwan fishing boats entering the region and have fined the ship owners.
The two countries have held 15 rounds of fishery talks since 1996 but have yet to work out mutually acceptable terms.

Chen said Taiwan, as a liberal, democratic and peace-loving country, is obliged to resolve international disputes, including those resulting from overlapping economic zones and conflicting territorial claims, through negotiations in line with international law and precedents, instead of adopting any unilateral confrontational moves.

"The ROC government, while never retreating from its claim to the Tiaoyutais, has consistently delinked the sovereignty issue from its fishing right dispute with Japan," Chen said, adding that major local fishermen's associations have also thrown their support behind the government's "separate handling" stance. Chen further said his administration will do whatever it can to secure the best possible benefits for local fishermen in negotiations with Japan.

During the 15th round of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks in Tokyo July 29, Chen said the two sides agreed to form working groups to facilitate communications and interaction. "I'm convinced that this new mechanism will contribute to an eventual solution to the dispute," he added.

As part of the Pengjia monument ceremony, Chen autographed copies of a new book published by the Coast Guard Administration to introduce Taiwan's territorial waters and 200-mile exclusive economic zones.

Pengjia islet, Mienhua islet and Huaping islet are known as Taiwan's three northernmost outlying islands. Pengjia is the largest of the three, with an area of 10,014 square kilometers. Located some 56 km northeast of Keelung Harbor, Pengjia is guarded by military personnel and coast guard officers. It also boasts a helipad, a meteorological observation station and a lighthouse. Of the three islets, it is the only inhabited one.

DOC.HEADLINE: GARLIC FARMERS PROTEST COA'S SALE OF STOCKPILED PRODUCE

TEXT.P: Some 300 garlic farmers from the south-central county of Yunlin were bussed to Taipei Wednesday to protest what they claimed is the administration's "suppressing prices of domestically produced garlic."

Noting that there is no garlic supply problem in Taiwan and that current prices for domestically produced garlic are low, the farmers lashed out at the Council of Agriculture (COA) for putting stockpiled garlic on local markets, artificially disturbing prices "for no reason."
They argued that only when garlic prices surge to NT$50 (US$1.58) per kilogram or higher as a result of shortages in supply should the COA put stockpiled garlic on the market.

Defending the COA move, however, COA Department of Food and Agriculture Director Huang You-tsai pointed out that the COA released the garlic only after two typhoons drowned Taiwan with torrential rain over the last two weeks, causing vegetable prices to skyrocket, particularly that of green onions.
Huang said that the COA released the garlic in consideration that garlic can be used as an alternative to green onions.
At the same time, Huang argued, the stockpiled garlic, totaling 1.8 metric tons per day, was only equivalent to some 1.5 percent of the total amount of garlic sold in Taiwan each day.

According to Yu Yuan-fa, one of the protesting farmers, about 57,000 tons of garlic is expected to be produced in Taiwan this year. With some 9,000 tons being procured by the government -- ostensibly to help regulate prices when it is in short supply -- about 48,000 tons are expected to be sold this year on the domestic market, which, Yu said, consumes only an average of 47,000 tons annually in normal years.

In addition to the annual production totaling 57,000 tons this year, some 4,000 tons has been stockpiled since last year and Taiwan is scheduled to import 3,500 tons this year under World Trade Organization (WTO) requirements, Yu said.

Judging from these figures, Yu said, garlic prices will only be driven lower, leaving no reason for the COA to release the stockpiled produce at the time when supply is sufficient and the prices are reasonably low at between NT$33-NT$40 per kilo.
Yu, speaking on behalf of the garlic farmers, called for the COA to help export extra garlic from Taiwan to avoid a collapse in prices.
