DOC.HEADLINE: PLATFORM-EDGE DOORS TO PREVENT SUICIDES AT TAIPEI MRT STATIONS

TEXT.P: All stations on Taipei's mass rapid transit railway system (MRT) will eventually be equipped with platform-edge doors to prevent suicides and accidents, a spokesman for the Department of Rapid Transit Systems under the Taipei city government said Wednesday.

The spokesman pointed out that at present, only the Mucha Line stations have such doors and that as the number of suicides and attempted suicides keeps rising along the other lines, the department has decided to add the safety doors to all remaining stations, beginning with the Taipei Main Station and the Chunghsiao-Fuhsing Station -- the two busiest stations on the system.
He also said that stations along the two new lines under construction -- the Hsinchuang-Luchou Line and the Neihu Line -- have already had their designs modified to add the safety doors.
The operation of the doors is synchronized with the operation of the train doors. In order for them to open, they have to be correctly aligned.

The true value of the doors is in extreme climates, where they can reduce station energy costs, but some cities, such as London, where more than 100 people take their own lives by jumping onto the track each year, equip some of its metro stations with such doors to prevent suicide attempts.

Figures compiled by the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. show that since MRT began operations in 1996, 24 accidents have occurred because of passengers jumping or falling onto the track. Seven people have been killed, mostly on the Tansui Line.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WARNS LOCAL GOVERNMENTS OF BEIJING'S UNITED FRONT TACTICS

TEXT.P: Beijing has strengthened efforts to boost all kinds of exchanges with Taiwan's local governments as part of its "united front" tactics aimed at downgrading Taiwan's national status, according to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

Citing information that it received recently, the MAC said that Beijing has tried hard to create the feeling that Taiwan is a province of China by stepping up efforts to enhance exchanges and activities with Taiwan's city and county authorities.

The MAC said it has officially notified all local governments of what it claims are Beijing's "covert moves" and has always followed an instruction from President Chen Shui-bian issued more than a year ago to frequently exchange opinions and viewpoints with local authorities on China affairs.

According to MAC officials, Beijing's decision to launch a new wave of united front tactics seeks to bolster direct and close contacts with Taiwan's local governments to underscore its "one China principle" and pacify international concern after it enacted its Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan in mid-March.

For instance, the Beijing-based China Internet Information Center has contacted various local city and county governments asking them to provide relevant data and information under the excuse of editing a yearbook, the officials said, adding that the Chinese Ministry of Culture also has requested several cultural establishments in Taiwan to offer material to help it edit an art book.

In documents and letters sent by Beijing to these local authorities in Taiwan, Beijing has never failed to make the claim that they were "nationwide" activities which suggest that Taiwan is a part of China, they noted.

The developments are indications that Beijing is attempting to build a climate to make the world believe that Taiwan is a Chinese province under its sovereignty by luring Taiwan's local governments to fall into its "one China" trap, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT SPENDING CONDUCIVE TO FUTURE DEVELOPMENT: GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The record low trade surplus for the first seven months of this year is a result of added imports of capital goods, an investment that will help yield higher growth and larger revenues for the country in the coming years, a government spokesman said Wednesday.

Taiwan's trade surplus stood at US$420 million in the first half of this year, a decrease of 89.1 percent over the same period of 2004. The surplus in the first seven months is likely to fall to a new low in more than 20 years because of a combination of factors, including an upward spiral of international crude oil prices.

Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai attributed the record low trade surplus to several factors, including spiralling oil prices, the Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp.'s imports of carriages, purchases of Airbus planes by China Airlines and EVA Airways, and factory expansions by several semiconductor manufacturing companies and LCD display panel manufacturers.

Cho said this spending represents "healthy" investments conducive to future development for those major corporations and added that their investments will help create higher economic growth for the country in the long run.

He also quoted Premier Frank Hsieh as saying during a regular Executive Yuan meeting that day that the administration is confident that the unemployment rate will be controlled at 4 percent or lower for this year, although more efforts are needed to achieve that goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH EPIDEMIC-PREVENTION TEAM TO BEGIN WORK IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: An ad hoc medical team organized by the Department of Health (DOH) will begin work in late September to prevent outbreaks of various types of new epidemic in Taiwan, a DOH official said Wednesday.

Shih Wen-yi, deputy director-general of the DOH Center for Disease Control (CDC), noted that since the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Taiwan in 2003, the CDC has planned to form an ad hoc medical team to investigate the epidemic in order to prevent a further spread of the disease.

However, the team was not set up until earlier this year due to difficulty in finding the necessary medical experts, Shih said, adding that the medical team will begin its work after receiving several training courses.
Shih added that after the outbreaks of SARS, avian flu broke out in several Southeast Asian countries, while melioidosis cases occurred in southern Taiwan recently.
Noting that the role of epidemic prevention doctors is increasingly important, Shih said the team members will arrive immediately at the site of outbreaks to investigate the causes of the epidemic.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Shuttle Glides to Safe Landing; Problems Ahead
The shuttle Discovery glided back to Earth in a predawn landing in the Mojave Desert on Tuesday, after a mission of 14 days and 5.8 million miles that successfully returned NASA to human spaceflight but also added pressure on the agency to move beyond the shuttle program. The Discovery mission blended success and frustration, hope and poignancy. The launching was delayed repeatedly, and a problem with a fuel level sensor forced mission controllers to scrub a planned July 13 effort just two and a half hours before liftoff. And though modifications made to the external fuel tank resulted in far less launching debris than usual, five large pieces of foam - one weighing nearly a pound - popped off the tank, showing that a potentially fatal problem had not been corrected. NASA has said that until the foam myst ery is solved and the problem fixed, shuttles will not fly again.
Wall Street Journal: FBI Sees Big Threat From Chinese Spies; Businesses Wonder
In one of their biggest initiatives after the fight against terrorism, the FBI and Justice Department have sent hundreds of new counterintelligence agents into the bureau's 56 field offices, many with a specific focus on China. There is a cloak-and-dagger element to some of this: A principal FBI team focusing on Chinese economic espionage, including some undercover operatives, occupies an unmarked floor in a Silicon Valley office park near a popular Chinese restaurant. But this is an altoge ther different battle from the one with the Soviets. Thousands of Chinese nationals regularly come to the U.S. as students and businessmen, some working for major U.S. defense contractors. The vast majority of them are innocently working or studying. Counterespionage experts say the trouble often starts when they are contacted by Chinese government officials or one of the more than 3,000 Chinese "front compan ies" the FBI alleges have been set up in the U.S. specifically to acquire military or industrial technologies illegally. Sometimes they are wooed with cash, but often the motivation is nationalism.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Admiral Says Navy Will Buy 2 Scorpio Deep-Sea Vehicles
The Pacific Fleet commander said Tuesday that the Navy would buy two Scorpio remote-controlled underwater vehicles like the British one used Saturday to rescue seven men trapped in a mini-submarine.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Roberts Papers Being Delayed; Bush Aides Screen Pages for Surprises
Thrown on the defensive by recent revelations about Supreme Court nominee John G. Roberts Jr.'s legal work, White House aides are delaying the release of tens of thousands of documents from the Reagan administration to give themselves time to find any new surprises before they are turned into political ammunition by Democrats. (By Jorge Liu)

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH URGES PUBLIC TO HELP PREVENT POSSIBLE BIRD FLU EPIDEMIC

TEXT.P: As the World Health Organization (WHO) continues to issue alerts that avian flu in Southeast Asia could trigger a global outbreak, the Department of Health (DOH) called on the Taiwan public Wednesday to avoid contact with birds and fowls and not to eat raw poultry.
The DOH advised the public to visit a doctor as soon as possible if they have a fever and a sore throat after returning from a trip to affected areas.

The virulent H5N1 bird flu virus is still plaguing Southeast Asia and China. It is also found in Siberia. WHO data shows that the latest outbreak has infected 112 people, killing 57 of them, though it has not yet been passed among humans.
The DOH quoted academic journals as claiming that proper public health measures could drastically bring down the infection rate from 384 per thousand to 0.3 per thousand.

The DOH's Center for Disease Control said the public health infrastructures in Southeast Asian countries needs to be strengthened through international cooperation in the hope that any change in the flu virus will be detected early.

In the event of an epidemic, said the center, antibiotics should be dispensed as quickly as possible in step with other public health measures to stop the virus from spreading and prompting a global outbreak.
With that in mind, the center said Taiwan has donated 600,000 doses of anti-virus medicines to Vietnam, which center officials claimed should help stop the disease from becoming contagious.
The WHO has recommended that Asian countries adopt such strategies as suspending public gatherings, restricting travel and imposing self-quarantine measures at home.

The DOH said new flu viruses can be communicated even before carriers show symptoms of disease. Therefore, it added, if a worldwide outbreak does occur, the government will enforce its public authority to control and contain the spread.
It advised people to form good hygiene habits, eat balanced diets and exercise to boost their immune systems, in addition to paying attention to government press releases and preventive measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO UNVEIL PERSONNEL LINEUP NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that he will unveil the party's personnel lineup next week amid reports that his top campaign aide will soon take over as the party's new secretary-general.
Ma made the remarks following reports that Chan Chuen-pao, director of Ma's campaign office, is widely tipped to be named as the party's new secretary-general.
Ma said that after the lineup is finalized, he will announce it before the party congress. which is scheduled to open Aug. 19.
Outgoing KMT secretary-general Lin Feng-cheng will lead party officials in an en masse resignation Aug. 18.

The KMT's Central Standing Committee has approved the themes of the party's 17th congress as the "re-emergence of blue sky, infinite happiness -- democracy, legacy, peace and mutual benefit, " to demonstrate the party's commitment and determination to return to power in 2008. The KMT is represented by the color blue.

Lai Su-jui, director of the KMT's Department of Culture and Information, said the party chairmanship handover ceremony will be held prior to the convening of the congress. As this will be the first party chairman changeover in the nearly 110-year history of the party, there will be no witnesses but all delegates when Lien passes the party's official seal to Ma.
During the ceremony, the party will express appreciation for Lien's contributions to the party during his term.
After the handover of the party seal, a video tape documenting Lien's major activities and speeches will be aired. Lien and Ma will then give speeches, after which Lien will leave the venue.
In related news that day, the KMT Central Standing Committee passed several amendments to its party charter during a regular meeting.

The amendments stipulate that only those who pay for party membership will be eligible to select the party chairman -- one of the topics of debate in the July 16 party chairmanship election -- and other party member rights.
The amendments also lengthen the term of the KMT's central standing committee members from two years from the current one year.

The amendments also abolish an article which stipulates that party members who are disciplined or expelled will not be eligible to be listed as candidates for the KMT Central Standing Committee or party chairman. The article is generally considered to be aimed at Soong, who was expelled by the KMT for running as an independent against Lien in the 2000 presidential election. Soong later founded the People First Party (PFP).
Cheng Li-wen, a spokeswoman of the KMT, claimed that the amendments demonstrate that the party is opening its doors to all.
Upon hearing the news, Hwang Yih-jiau, a PFP caucus whip in the legislature, said that Soong took it in his stride.

Hwang said the party will not talk about whether it will return to the fold of the KMT, saying that the party will continue to serve as a loyal opposition party and will only have the people's interests in mind.
Hwang also said that he is not sure whether Soong, who is currently on an overseas trip, will return to Taiwan to attend the KMT chairman changeover ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP URGES TAIWAN, JAPAN, U.S. COOPERATION TO COPE WITH CHINA EXPANSION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that Taiwan, Japan and the United States should cooperate to cope with China's military expansion.
Lu made the remarks when she was interviewed by the Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's largest circulation national newspaper, in Taipei.

She cited a recent U.S. Pentagon report on China's military power to say that what she claimed is China's "unlimited" military expansion is not only meant to attack Taiwan, but also meant to challenge Japan and the United States, and that the three parties need to cooperate to cope with this.

She stressed the importance of the United States and Japan listing peace in the Taiwan Strait as a common strategic objective in their joint statement after a security committee consultative meeting in February and said the statement is significant in ensuring Taiwan's security.
Lu said that President Chen Shui-bian's government will never develop nuclear weapons and has no intention of engaging in an arms race with China.
She also defended President Chen's recent remarks on "four stages" of the ROC to more clearly explain its national identity after it was criticized by China.

The president said the ROC was established in China in 1912. In 1949, the ROC moved to Taiwan. In the third stage, during the time when Lee Teng-hui was president (1988-2000), "the ROC on Taiwan" was the catch-phrase used to describe the nation. In the fourth stage after 2000, with the first peaceful transfer of power in the country's history, the phrase became "the ROC is Taiwan."

Lu said that during the 2000 presidential election, Taiwan people chose the native political party of Taiwan, meaning the Democratic Progressive Party that was founded in 1986, and claimed that although the nation is officially called the ROC, a majority of people identify it as Taiwan.
China might not like it, but this is an undeniable historial fact, Lu added.

On the visits to China in April and May, respectively, by Taiwan's two main opposition leaders, Lu said that although China is showing goodwill toward the opposition parties, it still refuses to talk with Chen, which she said is a move to deny Taiwan's leadership that shows its lack of sincerity in bettering cross-strait relations.
She also expressed appreciation for the Japanese Diet's recent passage of a bill to waive visa requirements for Taiwan visitors to Japan.

On the disputed Tiaoyutai island group, over which Taiwan, Japan and China claim sovereignty, she urged Japan to focus on joint development of the islands and not allow the island group to become a flashpoint between Taiwan and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO SEEK LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER'S OPINION ON SPECIAL SESSION

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) legislative caucus is divided on whether to hold a special legislative session, and will seek Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng's opinion before making a decision, said Cho Po-yuan, a KMT whip in the legislature.

He noted that in response to the proposal of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to convene a special legislative session to review several important bills, KMT legislators were asked Tuesday what they felt about holding such a session.

The legislators had differing views, so Cho said he will explain the situation to Wang after he returns from the United States late Wednesday. He will also ask him to consult with the opposition People First Party (PFP) on the matter.

The KMT has said that it may agree to a special session if it only deals with an eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.539 billion) flood-control bill, while the PFP has said it is against convening a special session out of fear that the DPP will try to include other bills on the agenda, such as the NT$480 billion U.S. arms procurement package.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU-CHINA LINKS LEGAL, MEET PUBLIC EXPECTATIONS: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's plan to open direct links between the outlying Penghu Island and China is a legal move that also meets public expectations on the island county, Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday.

Hsieh made the remarks after hearing a report on the "mini three links, " which opened in January 2001, and the special Chinese new year holiday charter flights between Taiwan and China by Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials during a weekly Cabinet meeting.

Claiming that the existing direct trade and transport links between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and China's Fujian ports of Xiamen and Mawei -- commonly known as the "mini three links" -- have become more popular, Hsieh said that opening the links for Penghu or making the island a fishery produce distribution center are plans in line with the law that also will satisfy public demand.
He asked the MAC to continue to explain the policy to the public and improve relevant measures to create greater convenience and long-term benefits for the residents on the outlying islands.

The premier surprisingly announced his plan to open the Penghu-China "mini three links" on a trial basis from September last week during a visit to the island, but the initiative created a strong backlash from the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

Former President Lee Teng-hui, also the spiritual leader of the TSU, threatened to mobilize supporters to demonstrate on the streets against the plan. Lee called the idea an awkward move designed by the government to seek to restore public confidence in it after failing to persuade Taiwan farmers not to sell their produce to China.

The government allowed a religious voyage from Penghu to Fujian's Quanzhou in July 2001, and it has again approved an application filed recently by a religious group to make a similar trip. The voyages are screened on a case-by-case basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM FULFILLS GOAL OF PRIVATIZATION: CABINET SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The government has fulfilled its goal of privatizing Chunghwa Telecom Co., reducing its stake in the behemoth company to below 50 percent following the sales of 17 percent of its holdings at home and abroad in the past two days, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai announced Wednesday.

Despite strong protests from Chunghwa's workers union over the past few days, Cho said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) managed to sell 3 percent of its stake in Chunghwa Telecom on the domestic market Tuesday and an additional 14 percent stake was sold through American Depositary Receipts (ADR) in the United States Wednesday (Taipei time).

Cho said the MOTC had sold off a total of 52.17 percent of its stake in Chunghwa Telecom to individual and corporate investors at home and abroad, meeting the government's goal of reducing its stake in the company to below 50 percent.
Before the latest sales, the MOTC held 64.94 percent of Chunghwa Telecom shares and two other government units -- Chunghwa Post and the Labor Insurance Bureau -- jointly held a 1.59 percent stake.

"While the MOTC will remain Chunghwa Telecom's largest single shareholder, the government's stake has fallen to below 50 percent, " Cho said, adding that Chunghwa Telecom has passed the threshold of what is considered to be privatization.

Noting that the ultimate goal of privatization is to sharpen Chunghwa Telecom's competitiveness, Cho said the nation's largest single telecommunications service company is expected to continue improving its quality.
According to Cho, the government managed to raise NT$16.3 billion from local sales of Chunghwa Telecom shares and an additional NT$81.8 billion from ADR sales.

"Purchase bids for Chunghwa ADRs reached US$15 billion, but only US$2.6 billion worth of ADRs were available for sale. The brisk bids indicated that foreign investors were confident in Chunghwa Telecom's development prospects," Cho said.

The MOTC launched its Chunghwa Telecom privatization plan in 2000 to a bumpy start. In its initial public offering, only less than 3 percent of shares were sold. It managed to sell 11.5 percent to overseas investors through the issue of ADRs in July 2003. Over the past five years, the national coffers received more than NT$280 billion from Chunghwa Telecom stock sales.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER EXPECTED TO MEET WITH STAFF SOON ON FUTURE PLANS

TEXT.P: After stepping out of the political fray for over a week, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng will return to Taiwan from the United States Wednesday night and is expected over the next few days to discuss his future role in the largest opposition party with his staff, according to one of his aides.
Wang has been on a private, 10-day visit to San Francisco with his family.

The politically savvy Wang, who was overwhelmingly defeated by Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou in the July 16 election for opposition KMT chairman, might have some fresh ideas about his future direction after temporarily leaving the complex political situation behind for some time, said Chiang Min-chin, who was Wang's spokesman during the chairmanship campaign.
Wang said before he left that he would under no circumstances serve as the senior vice chairman of the KMT under Ma. Chiang said he didn't know if Wang has changed his mind.

Although Wang has asked people not to bother to greet him upon his arrival at CKS International Airport upon his return, several KMT legislators, including Cho Po-yuan, Tsai Chin-lung and Wu Chih-yang will do just that.

Mayor Ma will also be on hand, saying that he adjusted his schedule to show his sincerity in burying the hatchet after the bitter chairmanship race, in which staff from both camps traded accusations of mudslinging despite both candidates having promised to run clean campaigns.

Ma said that he will again ask Wang to serve as the party's senior vice chairman, adding that with the year-end city and county chiefs elections coming, he must work with Wang to overcome the daunting challenges ahead.
Wang is a devout Buddhist with a good heart and is a tolerant man, Ma stressed, adding, "I'm sure that I can gradually assuage any misgivings that have arisen because of the election."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTORS LOOKING NORTH TO CHINA'S YANGTZE DELTA

TEXT.P: Taiwan investors have been moving north from Guangdong province in southern China's Pearl River Delta to the Yangtze River Delta since early this year, according to an article carried in the Hong Kong Commercial Daily Wednesday.

The article, by Li Sau Hung, president of the Hong Kong Economic and Trade Association, said there are signs that the new trend is gaining momentum, with Kunshan, Suzhou, Wuxi, Hangzhou and Ningbo being the preferred cities in the Yangtze River Delta for Taiwanese enterprises.

The Yangtze River Delta refers to the triangular-shaped territory encompassing the city of Shanghai, southern Jiangsu province and northern Zhejiang province. The area lies at the heart of the region traditionally called Jiangnan, which means literally "south of the Yangtze River."

According to the article, Taiwan investors are not happy that Chinese authorities have allowed too many foreign investors into the Pearl River Delta. They have also complained that the quality of services provided by the authorities to Taiwanese enterprises has gone down, and that they are faced with increasing problems with tariffs, taxes, environmental protection hurdles, and labor and intellectual property rights issues.
In addition, Taiwan businessmen no longer feel safe in the Pearl River Delta because a number of them have been murdered or robbed in recent years.

The article said that many Taiwan businessmen have moved to the Yangtze River Delta to set up their bases in preparation for the unavoidable opening of the direct "three links" in post, trade and transportation between Taiwan and China. They foresee that the Pearl River Delta, which relies on Hong Kong and Macau as transit points, will lose its importance to the Yangtze River Delta.

The author quoted statistics as saying that there are now 450,000 Taiwanese businessmen in Shanghai, and that 60 percent of them are either "satisfied" or "very satisfied" with the city. Some 30 percent have bought houses in Shanghai, with another 40 percent planning to do so in the next year. But the Pearl River Delta is not so attractive, with much fewer Taiwan businessmen willing to settle there.

Another reason that has placed the Pearl River Delta in an unfavorable light is that Taiwan businessmen see Jiangsu and Zhejiang provinces as more advanced in the areas of education, medical services, culture and amusement, the article said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION WILL SEEK CLOSE RELATIONS WITH NEW WTO CHIEF

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's World Trade Organization (WTO) officials will keep good working relationship with the incoming WTO director-general Pascal Lamy to help him get a better understanding of Taiwan's situation, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Wednesday.

Frenchman Pascal Lamy will assume office Sept. 1, replacing Thailand's Supachai Panitchpakdi. The new chief executive's position on issues concerning China's attitude toward Taiwan is being closely watched by Taiwan's media.
In June, Taiwan blamed China for plotting to change the titles of the ROC's WTO officials in the new edition of the WTO members' directory, printed the same month.

In the directory, the titles of all Taiwan officials, except for the permanent representative and his deputy, were deleted. Such titles as counselor, first secretary and second secretary no longer appeared before the names of Taiwan's officials. Only their names and main lines of business were shown.

After lodging a protest with the WTO Secretariat for unilaterally changing the contents of the information presented by the ROC's WTO mission, Taiwan delivered an amended version of the information containing the formal title of the mission to delegations of all WTO state-members and the Secretariat. The official title is: The Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu.

Asked whether the WTO Secretariat apologized for the change, Chou Shih-chao, chief of the foreign ministry's bureau of economic and trade affairs, said the incumbent WTO director-general said he won't change the contents of the new directory for now because "he has his own considerations."
The ROC mission has already delivered another letter of protest, the official said.

Chou said that the ROC's WTO mission voted for Lamy to serve as the new WTO director-general based on the assumption that a person from the European Union is more likely to be able to resist China's political interference in Taiwan's affairs. Signs after the election show Taiwan has chosen the right person, he noted.

The ROC mission will also try to work closely with Rufus Yerxa of the United States, who is one of Lamy's four designated deputies and the only deputy WTO director-general keeping his title in the new Secretariat, Chou added, explaining that Yerxa has been deeply involving in the management of Taiwan's WTO operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RESPONSIBLE FOR RESTORING TAOYUAN'S WATER SUPPLY BY AUG. 13

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian personally apologized to Taoyuan residents Wednesday for the government's failure to ensure normal water supply and he said that Premier Frank Hsieh is responsible for ending the water shortage by Aug. 13.
Chen hinted that he may reshuffle the Cabinet after solving the water shortage caused by Typhoon Matsa last week.

"The government should raise the importance of the issue to the level of war, " he said after inspecting Shihmen Dam and other water processing facilities in Taoyuan with Hsieh, Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun and other officials.

As Taoyuan residents are still facing water rationing, Chen said he and the government "truly are very, very sorry for Taoyuan County fellow countrymen. We deeply apologize that the government has not done a good job, thus causing great inconvenience to you all."

He noted that the water in the dam was muddy because of the rain that the typhoon brought, but upstream problems are the responsibility of both the central and local governments, "so we shouldn't shirk our responsibility."

As water supply is an urgent matter affecting people's daily life, Chen said the government must launch a "water rescuing operation" which will have the highest importance, and Premier Hsieh will act as the "commander-in-chief."
He said he believes that only with the premier as the official with the most responsibility can the country come up with a real solution to the problem.

He recalled Hsieh's achievement in making Kaohsiung City's tap water drinkable when Hsieh was mayor, adding that now is the time for Hsieh to demonstrate his ability again to thoroughly resolve Taoyuan's water supply issue.
"A premier is much needed by many administrative units, but if he cannot thoroughly resolve the water supply issue, people naturally will wonder what has he been doing," Chen said.
As Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh has announced, Taoyuan residents will have normal water supply on Aug. 13 at the latest, said Chen.

"We will achieve that first of all, so that we can face the people. Then we'll see who should be responsible for this fiasco, " the president said, adding that this will include adjustments of some key positions.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL REFORM GOING BETTER THAN EXPECTED: TOP ECONOMIC PLANNER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top economic planner said Wednesday that the government's second wave of financial reforms are apparently better than expected, with the Taihsin International Bank winning the bid for the special shares offered by the Chang Hwa Bank for a merger.

Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said that he was satisfied with the smooth bidding procedure, which proved that those who did not expect the reform plan could achieve much were wrong, and that many people in the banking sector now fear that they may miss the boat.

The second wave of financial reforms, announced by President Chen Shui-bian last year, aims to cut the number of state-owned banks and financial holding companies by half by encouraging them to merge. The plan requires the joint assets of any three banks to exceed 10 percent of the total value of Taiwan's banking sector. It also plans to let at least one bank to be run by a foreign financial institution.
Hu said the reforms are necessary because Taiwan has too many small banks, which have a high percentage of bad debts and lack the ability to compete internationally.
He said the government will keep one bank to be predominantly state-owned and allow foreign banks to compete in Taiwan to strike a balance in the financial market.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4% GROWTH FORECAST IS NO EXAGGERATION: CEPD CHIEF

TEXT.P: The government's top economic planner defended the Council for Economic Planning and Development's (CEPD) 4 percent economic growth target Wednesday, saying that the forecast is no exaggeration.

Speaking in an interview with CNA, CEPD Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said that although major private economic think tanks have expressed doubts about the CEPD's 4 percent growth target, he is confident that the country can reach that goal.
"Our forecast that Taiwan will be able to register a 4 percent growth in its gross domestic product (GDP) this year is calculated in terms of a pragmatic basis," Hu explained.
While projecting the growth target, Hu said the CEPD has come up with a comprehensive package of economic revitalization plans.
So long as these projects proceed smoothly, Hu said the 4 percent growth target definitely be attained.

The CEPD-initiated programs include accelerating public infrastructure construction projects, the launch of 10 new construction projects and the eight-year, NT$80 billion flood-prevention project, expanding BOT projects, developing tourism and service industries, and a further liberalization of financial services, Hu said.

With a view to reinvigorating the domestic manufacturing sector, Hu said some military equipment will be purchased domestically. For instance, private manufacturers will be allowed to bid for production of military vehicles.

The orders in this regard will reach an estimated NT$20 billion this year and contribute to an estimated 0.2 percent to the nation's overall GDP growth, Hu said, adding that the Ministry of National Defense is expected to assist in the implementation of this program.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWS OF NEW BLOOD IN KMT RANKS PLEASES CHAIRMAN-ELECT

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) recruited more new members in the first half of this year than in the second half of last year, with chairman-elect, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, expressing his happiness about the development, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen said Wednesday.

According to Cheng, Ma was upbeat about the news after hearing a report during the party's weekly meeting of its policymaking Central Standing Committee and described it as an "encouraging event worth rejoicing about."

A total of 6,031 new members -- 2,264 men and 3,767 women -- applied to join the KMT in the first six months of this year, marking an increase of 3,255 members over the second half of last year, Cheng said, adding that Ma was particularly happy that women outnumbered men in throwing their support behind the party.

Nearly 21 percent of the new KMT members are below 30 years of age, while those younger then 40 account for 35 percent, she said and quoted Ma as saying that the KMT is poised to attract a larger number of young men and women and further reach out to people in southern Taiwan, where the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has long enjoyed greater public backing.
Ma was elected the new party boss through the first direct vote among party members July 19. He will take over the helm of the KMT from outgoing Chairman Lien Chan on Aug. 19.
Ma, who won overwhelming support among KMT members thanks to his clean image, has repeatedly vowed to stamp out the party's moneyed politics and turn the KMT into a young and democratic party.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUNDATION ADMITS ALLEGED SPY ATTENDED ITS SEMINARS

TEXT.P: A reporter with the Singapore-based Straits Times who has been in custody in China and is charged with spying for Taiwan attended seminars in Taiwan at the Foundation on International and Cross-strait Studies, the foundation admitted Wednesday.
A statement released by the foundation said that Ching Cheong attended its seminars as an expert on Chinese affairs.

As a think tank registered with the Ministry of Education, the foundation said it often exchanges views with experts on Chinese and international affairs, offers advice and undertakes studies after being commissioned to do so by clients.
This is why Ching was invited to take part in its seminars, the foundation said.

The statement neither confirmed nor denied a Tuesday news report out of Hong Kong that alleged that Ching wrote articles for the foundation's periodicals and that the foundation is closely related to the National Security Bureau (NSB) . The report also said that Ching was paid well for his services.
Ching was the Straits Times' Beijing correspondent and was arrested by Chinese authorities in April. He had not been charged until Beijing said on Aug. 5 that he was a spy for Taiwan.
Beijing's Xinhua new agency said on that day that Ching confessed to having gathered information for Taiwan's NSB since 2000 under the alias of Chen Chun-yuan and that his trial is pending.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA SHOULD MAKE MORE CONTACTS WITH OUTSIDE WORLD: NOBEL LAUREATE

TEXT.P: 2004 Nobel laureate in economics Edward Prescott on Wednesday suggested that Asian countries should adopt a policy of more engagements with other countries.
Prescott made the remarks in a forum organized by the China Trust Holding Corp.

In his speech about the inspiration of world economic perspectives on Taiwan, Prescott said Taiwan and other Asian countries should seek global protection via a free trade agreement mechanism, suggesting that Taiwan does not have to live at the mercy of other countries.
If the island makes more contact with other countries, it receives more protection from the outside world, he stressed.

Noting that China's blocking Taiwan economically by excluding the island from regional free trade agreements is expected to pose a great impact on the country, Prescott said Taiwan's current economic performance can be considered good despite all these negative factors.
Meanwhile, Prescott analyzed that the appreciation of China's renminbi can help placate the anti-China sentiment in the United States, Europe and even Mexico, hailing Beijing's policy as wise.
With the buoyant economic development in China, the country should one day lift the yuan's exchange rate control, while India, within 10 years, will become an economic superpower, Prescott stressed.

Concerning the rising oil prices, Prescott said there must be a mechanism to deal with it, saying that many alternative projects, such as solar energy, will be presented as a substitute, and the people do not have to be so worried.
Vice Premier Wu Rong-i and Council for Economic Planning and Development Minister Hu Sheng-cheng were also present as invited guests.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIA, TAIWAN SEEKING WAYS TO PROMOTE SOFTWARE COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Officials and business leaders from India and Taiwan gathered in Taipei Wednesday for the 2005 Taiwan-India Business Cooperation Forum to discuss how their software and information technology industries can work together.

Huang Kuo-chun, deputy chief executive officer of Taiwan's Institute for Information Industry (III) , said India has strong software development capabilities, a large talent pool, low production costs and a vast market.

The strengths of Taiwan's IT industry lie in its ability to integrate and a well-developed R&D and supply chain that is backed up by strong production capabilities, plus Taiwan's advantage in Chinese language and culture, Huang said.

He said if the industries in the two countries can jointly develop new products, which he believes they can do efficiently, they will create a high value-added production system through a division of labor.

President Kiran Karnik of India's National Association of Software and Services Companies (NASSCOM) pointed out that Indian companies are interested in cooperating with their Taiwanese counterparts, particularly in operating R&D platforms.

Also invited to speak were Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yin Chi-ming, Director-General Vijay Gokhale of the India-Taiwan Association and top executives of such well-known companies as Wipro, Tata Elxsi, PCS, L&T, and Crystaline.
Iflex's chief operation officer presented a case study of his company's financial integration, while BenQ executives shared their experiences in India with the participants.

III and NASSCOM signed a memorandum of understanding of cooperation in New Delhi in February last year, paving the way for future efforts for both sides. In March this year, a Taiwan delegation visited India. The forum is part of the programs both sides have agreed to pursue.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED TO ALLOW SHORTER ROUTE FOR TAIWAN'S CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to ask the Chinese authorities to allow its future charter passenger and cargo flights to fly over Cheju Island, Korea, or Okinawa, Japan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday.
Wu told the media that the proposed route would allow the charter flights to save more time and fuel, and that he hopes the Chinese side would not rule out such a possibility.

He said that the proposal was raised with the Chinese authorities when Taiwan representatives negotiated for charter flights to carry Taiwan businessmen in China back home for the Lunar New Year holiday early this year, but was turned down.

Wu said the 2005 charter flights for Taiwan businessmen were a success, and that with such a good experience, the MAC will continue to negotiate with China and push for future charter flights to take a shorter route by flying over Cheju Island or Okinawa.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL BEER POPULAR AT HOME DESPITE ROBUST FOREIGN COMPETITION

TEXT.P: Locally produced beer is enjoying a greater market share this summer in the home market despite fierce foreign competition, Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corporation (TTLC) Chairman Tung Jue-pin said Wednesday.

Tung, who took over the TTLC chairmanship a month ago, said that the variety of beer carrying the Taiwan Beer label has seized a market share of 84 percent this summer in the domestic market, a jump from last year's 78 percent. The TTLC launched a series of draft beers earlier the same day.
Amid robust competition from famous foreign brands from Japan and Europe, the TTLC-manufactured products are still the most popular in the domestic market, Tung said.
Taiwan's beer market counts for at least 7 million consumers, with a market scale amounting to NT$17.9 billion (US$56 million) per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO LOCAL CHINESE NEWSPAPERS MAY POST JOURNALISTS IN TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan will allow two Chinese media outlets to post reporters on the island, but not the two that were banned from Taiwan for allegedly filing biased stories, Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Wednesday.

The government barred two Chinese media outlets -- the state-run Xinhua News Agency and the People's Daily newspaper -- from posting journalists in Taiwan in April this year because the two were only covering rumors and opinions from the "extreme ends of Taiwan's political spectrum, " instead giving a reasonable balance to their coverage, the Government Information Office claimed.

To increase cross-strait journalistic and information exchanges, Wu said that the government will allow Guangzhou-based Nanfang City News and the Shanghai- based Xinmin Evening News to follow set procedures and apply to the Bureau of Immigration to station journalists in Taiwan.
The two newspapers would be the first local papers from China to station reporters on the island, if they agree to the offer, Wu said.
Wu said that as far as he knows, the two papers ought to be interested in taking the MAC up on the offer.
Taiwan has announced its policy, and now it will see whether China has enough sincerity to let the well-known local media come to Taiwan, Wu said.

Wu said that since the end of the 20th century, the media landscape in China has undergone dramatic changes. In addition to mainstream media such as the Xinhua News Agency and the People's Daily, many local newspapers have strived to earn a market niche. Not only has their circulations risen, but they have good reporting that has won acclaim.
Wu said he hopes that through the reporting of local Chinese journalists on Taiwan affairs, the people on China can get a better picture of what is really happening around the island.

Taiwan first allowed Chinese media to post reporters in Taiwan in late 2000. Besides Xinhua and the People's Daily, three other Chinese media outlets -- China Central Television (CCTV) , China News Agency and China National Radio -- have also posted journalists in Taiwan. Each of them is allowed to send two reporters to Taiwan, rotating them out each month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLAN FOR SETTING UP 'TAIWAN PARKS' IN INDIA, EAST EUROPE IN THE WORKS

TEXT.P: The government plans to join forces with private investors in setting up "Taiwan parks" in India and East Europe to facilitate local companies' globalization drive, the nation's top economic planner said Wednesday.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , said in an interview with CNA that the government's participation can help Taiwan investors receive better protection in the host countries.
In addition to offering updated market information, Hu said the government would be willing to assist prospective "Taiwan parks" investors in gaining access to bank loans or financing.
Hu said Taiwan and India can complement each other in information-technology industry development, as India has a booming computer software industry while Taiwan is strong in hardware production.

According to Hu, the CEPD is working on a comprehensive plan to encourage private investors to join forces with the government in building "Taiwan parks" in India to facilitate local companies' investment in that country, which boasts a vast domestic market.

Meanwhile, Hu said the government is also planning to lead local entrepreneurs to set up one or more "Taiwan parks" in a selected East European country or countries. The plan is still in the works and will be unveiled later this year, he added.

Touching on a sharp decline in the nation's foreign trade surplus in the first seven months of this year, Hu said the exodus of manufacturing companies to China has been seen a major contributing factor to that downward movement.

While China has cheap labor, Hu said it has been lax in intellectual property rights protection. He reminded Taiwan companies with interests in China to keep alert about the possibility of their core technology being stolen by Chinese competitors.
Hu also urged local companies to think globally while launching investment projects. "Concentrating investments in China is risky, " he cautioned.

Hu further said the nation's foreign trade surplus is not expected to drop further as the second half of the year has traditionally been an export boom season. The dramatic drop in trade surplus in the first half mainly resulted from soaring oil prices and the delivery of new aircraft ordered by two carriers -- China Airlines and EVA Airways.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 11, or the seventh day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1858: Christiaan Eijkman, the Dutch physician who won the 1929 Nobel Prize for medicine for his discovery of Vitamin B, is born.
1863: The French, who occupy southern Vietnam, make Cambodia a protectorate.
1919: Scottish-born American industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie dies at the age of 84. He amassed a fortune in the steel industry and donated millions of dollars for the benefit of the public.
1921: Warren G. Harding, the 29th president of the United States, formally invites China, Japan, Britain, France and Italy to join a disarmament meeting in Washington, D.C. to cope with an increasingly dangerous international situation after World War I.
1930: Britain goes broke. The United States and France each lend it US$46 million, while American bankers extend another US$111 million.
1932: Herbert Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, says it is time to scrap Prohibition. He lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt later that same year.
1936: Nationalist Chinese forces of Chiang Kai-shek enter Canton after foiling a rebellion led by Chen Chi-tang in the city in southern China.
1945: The Allies inform Japan that its surrender offer is acceptable.
1945: Communist "Yenan General Headquarters" orders Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the Republic of China government.
1950: The U.N. Security Council rejects a Soviet proposal for the immediate expulsion of the ROC delegation. The Russian delegation walks out in protest.
1960: Chad gains independence from France.
1960: The ROC recognizes the Ivory Coast and Chad.
1966: A peace treaty is signed in Jakarta, ending three years of hostilities between Malaysia and Indonesia.
1972: President Richard M. Nixon completes his "Vietnamization" of the Vietnam War by pulling out the last 92 American soldiers from the Southeast Asian country.
1973: The Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens its three-day 19th Conference in Taipei.
1975: The first meeting of the Asian and Pacific Congress on Health, Physical Education and Recreation opens in Taipei with 250 experts from 17 nations and areas attending.
1976: The industrial and commercial panel of the National Reconstruction Seminar opens a three-day meeting to make recommendations to the government.
1986: Sixteen people are killed and 87 others injured in an accidental explosion aboard the tanker SS Canari which is waiting to be scrapped in a shipwrecking yard in Kaohsiung Harbor.
1992: The United States, Canada and Mexico reach an agreement to set up a North American free-trade zone that would rank as the world's largest single trading bloc.
1993: The ROC Cable Television Law goes into effect.
1997: An international meeting called to shore up the shaky Thai economy offers loans of US$16 billion to the financial crisis-hit country.
1999: Taiwan's China Airlines signs an agreement with Boeing Co. of the United States to buy 13 B747-400 cargo planes for an estimated US$2.5 billion.
2000: A "Tzu Chi Village" in South Africa built by Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, a charity organization, is formally inaugurated. Meanwhile, the Tzu Chi Medical Center announces the 99th and 100th overseas cases in which it has supplied bone marrow for transplant operations.
2001: The Bureau of Monetary Affairs under the Finance Ministry and the Central Deposits Insurance Corp. take the initiative to put 36 faltering local financial institutions under supervision, the first phase of a "Monetary Reconstruction Fund" action to consolidate the operations of local banks and farmers as well as fishermen's cooperatives.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way to command the obedience of the members of one's family. If a man looking into his own heart is not true to himself, he will not command the obedience of the members of his family."

DOC.HEADLINE: BALANCED CROSS-STRAIT TIES KEY TO SHAPING OF NEW PACIFIC ORDER: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that a balanced relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is the key to the formation of a "new peaceful Pacific order."

Chen made the remarks at a news conference introducing the soon-to-be-inaugurated Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , which was conceived by Vice President Annette Lu to boost cooperation among Pacific Rim democracies.

In his keynote speech, Chen said he is convinced that only a normalized, constructive cross-strait relationship based on the principles of parity and pragmatism can sustain Asia-Pacific prosperity and advancement.

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Safe Landing but Fragile Future. The space shuttle Discovery made a picture- perfect landing Tuesday in the Calfornia desert , capping America's return to manned spaceflight but also reviving the debate over the safety of the decades-old spacecraft.

The half-time score on Singapore's economy is in and it looks to be fighting fit, with the Government saying the outlook for the rest of the year is improving.
A number of economists have raised their growth forecasts for this year, some to above 4.5 percent, after Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) figures showed the economy grew 5.2 percent in the second quarter.
The Lianhe Zaobao: The haze let Port Klang shutdown.
In Port Klang, a major shipping center just west of the capital Kuala Lumpur, the air pollution index shot up to 410.

COTABATO CITY -- The canvassing of votes cast in Monday's Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (ARMM) elections was completed in Maguindanao, Lanao del Sur, and Basilan yesterday, showing the ruling Lakas-CMD party bet for regional governor, Zaldy Ampatuan, leading with some 200,000 votes over his closest rival, according to Task Force HOPE.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Captain says Garci said Arroyo got P300M
Opposition Sen. Panfilo Lacson's witness Capt. Marlon Mendoza did testify, reading from his sworn statement, his main claim amounted to repeating what he said he had heard then Election Commissioner Virgilio Garcillano tell him about cheating in the 2004 election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOST IPSF CONGRESS IN 2007

TEXT.P: The International Pharmaceutical Students' Federation (IPSF) has voted for Taiwan to host its annual congress in 2007, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.

The decision was made Tuesday at the 51st IPSF Congress in Bonn, Germany, where the Pharmaceutical Students' Association of Taiwan (PSAT) represented the Republic of China in making the bid to host the 2007 event, the ministry said.
"It marks a step forward in Taiwan's bid to forge closer relations with non-governmental organizations (NGOs) , " a ministry official said.

The PSAT said it has always been in close association with the IPSF, with which it launched an "IPSF Exchange Student Program" to send Taiwan students for internships overseas at government institutions, pharmaceutical companies and hospitals to acquire professional knowledge and experience in foreign cultures.

The PSAT consists of the student unions of the pharmacy schools of Tajen University, China Medical University, Taipei Medical University, National Taiwan University, National Defense Medical Center, Kaohsiung Medical University, and Chia Nan University of Pharmacy and Science.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO LINKS BETWEEN ARMS DEAL AND CHEN'S TRANSIT STOP: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government would never link the issue of which cities Taiwan's president can transit through in the United States to movement on the island's planned arms procurement from the United States, a State Department official said Wednesday.
State Department deputy spokesman J. Adam Ereli made the remarks at a press briefing on updated U.S. foreign policy.

In response to a question on whether the United States might tie the issue of where President Chen Shui-bian can make transit stops in the United States to progress on the island's planned arms purchase, Ereli told the reporter that "you're mixing apples and oranges" by linking the two issues.
The spokesman noted that the U.S. government has consistently addressed such transit applications in terms of the safety, comfort and convenience of the traveler.
"There shouldn't be anything political read into" such arrangements, he said, adding that "it's a technical criteria that we follow."

President Chen is scheduled to make stopovers in the United States en route to and from Central America and the Caribbean for a diplomatic tour in September. Relevant Taiwan and U.S. authorities are discussing the transit arrangements.

Meanwhile, as China and Russia are set to stage their biggest-ever joint military exercises later this month, Ereli was asked whether the Bush administration is concerned about the event's implications for Taiwan's security.
Ereli responded by saying that the Chinese-Russian military exercises are matters between China and Russia.
"You know, our actions and policies are guided by the Taiwan Relations Act and the three communiques (between the United States and China," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE TO HOLD SHOWDOWN VOTE ON EXTRA SESSION

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will hold a vote Friday to determine whether to hold an extra legislative session during its current summer recess as requested by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, legislative sources said Thursday.
The showdown vote became necessary after the legislative caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties failed to reach a consensus on the "extra session" issue earlier in the day, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT SPEAKS ON DPU'S UPCOMING ESTABLISHMENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu announced in a press conference at the Presidential Office Thursday that the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) will formally be established Sunday, with democracy, peace and prosperity as the body's core values.

Lu explained that the DPU will serve as a quasi-government-to-government organization to bolster economic, technology and humanitarian cooperation among the 26 member states in line with the organization's aims of promoting human rights, democracy, law and order, regional peace, and safety for all of humankind.

The vice president expressed her belief that Taiwan will play a bigger role on the world stage in the 21st century with the opening of the DPU, which will be led by a Taiwan that features what she called "soft power" -- peace, love and technology.

The DPU's international secretariat and secretary-general will be based in Taipei, Lu said, adding that she herself will act as the representative of the Taiwan headquarters while encouraging other member nations to set up local chapters in three years.
Lu also voiced her welcome to China to participate in the DPU as an observer ahead of it transforming into a democratic nation.
She thanked President Chen Shui-bian, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and scholars for their full support and assistance since 2001 in helping set up the DPU, which is her brainchild.

The 26 DPU member states include Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Malaysia, Australia, Canada, the United States, Mexico, Guatemala, El Salvador, Costa Rica, Nicaragua. Panama, Peru, Chile and Russia.

The presidents of Costa Rica and Guatemala and the vice presidents of Nicaragua and Palau will take part in the DPU's inauguration ceremony Sunday in Taipei, with the participation of many other foreign dignitaries including parliamentarians and representatives from academic and non-governmental organizations.
President Chen Shui-bian, who also spoke at the news conference, hailed Lu's efforts in creating the DPU, which he said will allow Taiwan to project its soft power. (By Flor Wang) ENDIEM/Li

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 3.13 points to close at 6,353.71.
The bourse opened at 6,362.62 and fluctuated between 6,380.39 and 6,326.37 during trading. A total of 3.11 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$93.38 billion (US$2.92 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up at 0.9 percent and textile stocks gaining 0.4 percent.

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 0.3 percent, followed by foodstuff issues and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.2 percent and construction issues and banking and financial shares both at 0.1 percent.
Cement stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 508 to 329, with 165 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved up 44 points to close at 6,389, with 20,506 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September moved up 46 points to end at 6,388, with 2,514 contracts traded, while December futures gained 42 points to finish at 6,375, with seven contracts traded. March futures moved up 39 points to close at 6,359, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,345 for August, 6,342 for September, 6,333 for December, 6,320 for March and 6,312 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.
August TE futures moved up 1.7 points to close at 267.8, with 3,273 contracts traded, while September TE futures gained 1.7 points to finish at 267.6, with 459 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

August TF futures gained 7.8 points to finish at 974, with 1,984 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved up 4.4 points to end at 972.2, with 849 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 0.6 points to close at 965, with four contract transactions, while March TF futures gained 3.8 points to finish at 967, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italian soccer federation head criticizes court's suspension order.
Italian soccer federation chairman Franco Carraro criticized a Genoa civil court order to suspend the 2005-2006 national championship calendar Wednesday. He said that the suspension order violates his organization's autonomy, causes economic damage and jeopardizes the sporting morale. He affirmed the championship will start on Aug. 28 as scheduled. The court order was issued on the relegation of Genoa which is not part of Serie A for the season. The federation found Genoa guilty earlier this month of bribing to win its final Serie B match for advancing to the Serie A.

The Washington Post: Road Bill Reflects The Power Of Pork; White House Drops Effort to Rein In Hill.
