DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: TNK-BP Tycoon Could Be Governor
Billionaire businessman Viktor Vekselberg could be appointed governor of Kamchatka in 2007, presidential envoy Konstantin Pulikovsky said in an interview published on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG WORLD YOUTH FOOTBALL FESTIVAL TO KICK OFF SATURDAY

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taichung World Youth Football Festival is scheduled to kick off Saturday at the Taichung Football Field, the city government announced Thursday.

The announcement was jointly made by Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu, Chinese Taipei Football Association (CTFA) President Huang Shi-cheng, former CTFA Secretary-General Chang Chan-wei and Taichung Football Committee Chairman Liao Sung-po.
"This is the first time for Taichung to hold an international youth soccer festival, which will raise the status of the city both domestically and globally, " Hu said in a speech.

The festival, which has been officially endorsed by the international football federation FIFA, will feature the participation of 56 teams from several countries, including Taiwan, the United States, Japan, South Korea and Guam.

Huang expressed his gratitude to Mayor Hu for his whole-hearted support in promoting soccer in Taichung and claimed confidently that the city government's efforts will help Taiwan eventually raise to the ranks of the top 32 countries in the world in youth football.
The festival, which will run through Aug. 18, is being hosted by Taichung City Government in association with the CTFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEA WARNING ISSUED FOR TYPHOON SANVU

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea alert for Typhoon Sanvu Thursday afternoon, saying that ships operating in and around the Bashi Channel should take extra precautions.

According to the CWB, Typhoon Sanvu has been formed by a tropical depression, with its center located at 17.8 degrees north latitude and 124.1 degrees east longitude -- about 560 kilometers southeast of Oluanpi at the southernmost tip of Taiwan as of 5:30pm.
Sanvu -- the 10th typhoon this year -- has a 150 kilometer radius comparable to a seventh-grade wind. It is moving west-northwest at a speed of 25 kilometers per hour.

The CWB warned that people living in southeastern Taiwan and the Hengchun Peninsula should guard against possible heavy rain from Thursday evening, and that other parts of southern Taiwan may experience heavy rain from Friday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS NEVER BEEN PART OF SIX-PARTY TALKS OVER NORTH KOREA: US
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States has never thought of trading off Taiwan in dealing with the issue of North Korea's nuclear program, U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Christopher R. Hill said Wednesday.

Hill made the remarks while fielding questions at a press briefing on the just-concluded round of six-party talks on North Korea's nuclear future. The six participating parties in the talks were the United States, Japan, South Korea, North Korea, China and Russia.

In response to questions on whether Taiwan has been used as a tradeoff in the six-party talks or whether China has used its leverage in the talks as a tradeoff to U.S. concessions on the Taiwan issue, Hill said the Taiwan issue has never been mixed in with topics related to North Korea's nuclear ambitions.
"I've heard this issue about these, you know, the tradeoff with Taiwan, but I've only heard it in the media," he said.

The United States has talked about the Taiwan issue with China many times, but never in connection with North Korea's nuclear program, Hill said, adding that he wants to put that "tradeoff" speculation to rest right now.

DOC.HEADLINE: UC BERKELEY STUDENTS LEARN CHINESE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Students from the University of California at Berkeley visited the Ministry of Education Thursday to show off their achievements after six weeks Chinese courses in Taiwan.

Li I-hao, the leader of the team and also a Taiwanese instructor at the Department of East Asian Languages at UC Berkeley, said that 43 students signed up for the program this year and 37 of them, including two students from China, received an average of US$405 in scholarship money from the education ministry.

According to Li, Mandarin education in the U.S. has been dominated by China for years. The 'hanban' has been systematically promoting Chinese learning overseas, and many American teachers also recommend that their students learn Chinese in China.
"Hanban" is short for the Beijing-based China National Office for Teaching Chinese as a Foreign Language.
"To Chinese-learners, however, Taiwan should be preferable to China for its high-quality education and the use of traditional Chinese characters," Li said.

The course, titled "Business Chinese in Taiwan, " was offered by UC Berkeley and sponsored by the education ministry for students with a basic understanding of the Chinese language. It was first launched in 2001 and suspended in 2003 because of the outbreak of SARS.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP TO INVITE ALLIES TO OBSERVE YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that she will invite members from the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) member countries to visit Taiwan later this year to observe the island's year-end city and county chiefs elections.
Lu made the remarks at a news conference held that day about future plans of the DPU, which was initiated by Lu and will be officially inaugurated on Saturday in Taipei.

Lu noted that although the DPU is a non-governmental organization, it has a quasi-governmental function to boost democracy, peace and prosperity for the Pacific Rim democracies and offer a cooperation platform for them.

According to Lu, the DPU boasts 26 member countries, including Canada, United States, Mexico, Guatemala, Salvador, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru, Chile, Russia, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Philippines, Malaysia, Australia and New Zealand.
After observing the elections, the DPU delegations will be invited to a seminar to express their views on the elections.

In addition, the DPU will also offer scholarships to 100 students from member countries for them to pursue advanced studies in Taiwan, and subsidize 50 scholars or experts from DPU member countries for their research programs on the island.
Meanwhile, the organization also plans to establish a women's development center, a disaster-prevention center, and a legislative link around Pacific Rim countries.
Lu revealed that the union also plans to set up an online university to propagate the DPU's ideals, as well as a marine university.
In addition to the inauguration ceremony on Aug. 13, several seminars will be held Aug. 14-15.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 TAIPEI AEROSPACE AND DEFENSE TECHNOLOGY EXHIBITION OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taipei Aerospace and Defense Technology Exhibition (TADTE) opened Thursday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with 21 domestic companies and 59 from abroad displaying their advanced products at 400 booths through Sunday.

Among foreign countries, the United States has the largest number of companies participating in this year's TADTE, such as Bell Helicopter, Lockheed Martin, Northrop Grumman and Raytheon. Dassault from France and the domestic Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. are also taking part.

Products on display include aircraft components, ground support equipment, aero-engine navigation systems and facilities, flight control and monitoring equipment, defense equipment and technology, aircraft interiors and sport airplanes as well as weapons of the Republic of China armed forces, including sparrow missiles, mica missiles and harpoon missiles.

Secretary-General Chao Yung-ching of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , sponsor of the biennial event, said that the Ministry of National Defense (MND) will release business opportunities worth over NT$18 billion (US$562.5 million) covering 2,054 items to the private sector through the exhibition.

Chao called on local governments to help promote leisure aviation by providing sites and space, as a variety of air sports aircraft, like remote-control and ultralight airplanes are being exhibited at the show -- the eighth of its kind and the largest in TADTE history.

The MND also has built a mock command center in which visitors can operate simulated training systems involving the three items of a major arms procurement plan from the United States -- diesel-electric submarines, P-3C Orion anti-submarine aircraft and patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries -- in two scenarios of Chinese attacks against Taiwan.
The MND's mock war scenarios display has been widely viewed as an effort to help the major military procurement bill clear the Legislative Yuan.

The MND took the initiative to cut the price tag of the major arms procurement plan to NT$480 billion (about US$15 billion) from the original amount of NT$610.8 billion in a bid to pacify opposition lawmakers who have strongly criticized the plan as being wildly overpriced.

DOC.HEADLINE: OIL FIELD ISSUE SHOULD BE TACKLED AMONG DISPUTED NATIONS: MOFA

TEXT.P: Disputes over exploration in the Chunxiao oil and gas field in the East China Sea should be tackled by all the nations who have an interest in the area through negotiations, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Thursday.

At issue in the exploration of the Chunxiao field is the problem of differing sovereignty claims and economic interests, with both China and Japan wishing to develop the area that has potentially large reserves of oil and natural gas, Lu said.

Lu made the remarks when he was commenting on the new book, "Oceans and Seas of Taiwan, " published by the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) Wednesday, in which CGA authorities warned that Taiwan should not sit idly by any longer while China is actively preparing to exploit the area for oil and gas given that the field belongs to Taiwan.

According to the book, the Chunxiao oil/gas field, which has been named and actively developed by China, is an area officially claimed by the Republic of China government for mineral exploration. Nevertheless, the book said, Taiwan has done nothing in this area.

By comparison, the book said, the United States, Japan and China have all been competing for control over the Chunxiao field, located to the upper right of the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, which are claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.
If Taiwan continues to remain just a "bystander, " the book said, the country will lose its rights for huge ocean resources and related interests sooner or later.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG JIN-PYNG REITERATES HE WILL NOT SERVE AS MA'S DEPUTY

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng reiterated Thursday that he will not serve as the senior vice chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT) -- Taiwan's largest opposition party -- under chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou, who is currently Taipei mayor.

Wang, who returned from a 10-day trip to the United States Wednesday, disclosed that he had met with outgoing KMT Chairman Lien Chan shortly after arriving back in Taipei. After a hour-long discussion with Lien, he reaffirmed his previous decision that he would not accept Ma's offer to serve as the senior deputy chairman of the KMT.

However, Wang acknowledged that he had accepted an offer by Lien to serve as chairman of the presidium of the KMT Central Advisory Committee, and that he would follow Lien's example to serve the KMT as a volunteer for the rest of his life and make contributions to the party in his capacity as head of the KMT Central Advisory Committee.
Asked whether he will meet with Ma, Wang said that Ma's office had been in contact with his office. He said that he and Ma will likely meet before the KMT convenes its 17th congress on Aug. 17-19.

Ma is scheduled to take over the KMT chairmanship on Aug. 19. He and Wang fought a fierce election campaign in which both camps blamed the other side for mudslinging. A victorious Ma, who captured 70 percent of the vote in the party election, has apologized to Wang on anumber of occasions.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF TO SET UP 'TAISHANG' SERVICE CENTER

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will set up a new service center to strengthen services for Taiwan businessmen operating in China, known locally as "taishang, " the quasi-official body's new secretary-general said Thursday.
You Ying-lung, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks after he was confirmed in an extraordinary SEF board meeting to concurrently serve as the SEF secretary-general.

You said he will flesh out the plan for setting up a new "taishang" service center within a week. In addition, he went on, the SEF will come up a comprehensive package of measures to improve and expand services for "taishang."
The SEF is a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle exchanges with China in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL WATER SUPPLY TO SOUTHERN TAOYUAN TO BE RESTORED EARLY FRIDAY

TEXT.P: Water supplies should be fully restored to the southern part of Taoyuan County early Friday morning, six days after Typhoon Matsa swept Taiwan, a Taiwan Water Corp. official said Thursday.

Residents in the county -- which is served by the Shihmen Reservoir -- have suffered water shortages in the last two years whenever there is a strong typhoon, as water treatment facilities are inadequate for dealing with the increased turbidity that occurs with heavy rain.

Taoyuan residents have been on a rotational water supply during the last few days, with Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh promising that full water supply would be restored in southern Taoyuan by Saturday, while the water supply to the northern part of the county may also be restored should the turbidity in the catchment of the Taoyuan River drop to a normal level. Ho said she will take full responsibility if she fails to deliver on her promise.
After urgent efforts by a number of government agencies, the turbidity at the treatment plant in southern Taoyuan dropped significantly Thursday.
However, as the turbidity in the catchment of northern Taoyuan's treatment plant is still high, water supply on a rotational basis in this region will continue.

According to Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lung, a project costing NT$1 billion (US$31.9 million) just completed by the MOEA's Water Resources Agency and the Taiwan Water Corporation in May to catch water in the upper part of the reservoir failed when Typhoon Matsa swept by the country last Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IN HARDER PLACE AMID FIERCE FOREIGN COMPETITION: VICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The magnetism of the fast-growing Chinese market will put Taiwan at greater risk and the country will face fiercer competition from South Korea and Singapore, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-lung said Thursday.

Chen issued the warning while giving a speech on Taiwan's small businesses and economic development at a seminar sponsored by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lee Chun-yi in southern Tainan county.

Chen noted that Taiwan's economic development has encountered huge challenges due to the long-term diplomatic isolation that has deprived the country of many trade and investment opportunities overseas. In addition, he pointed out, more competitive Singapore and South Korea, coupled with Taiwan's growing over-reliance on the Chinese market, have put Taiwan in an even more difficult situation.

Looking to the future, an appreciating new Taiwan dollar and skyrocketing oil prices are major uncertainties affecting the domestic economy, he said, adding that to achieve sustainable growth, the government attaches equal importance to hi-tech and traditional businesses and will continue to improve infrastructure to help companies keep growing both at home and abroad.

As Taiwan has forged a free trade agreement (FTA) with Panama and is holding FTA talks with Nicaragua and Guatemala, he said that the government is also seeking FTAs with the United States, Japan, Singapore and New Zealand. An FTA with the United States, he went on, would be of particular importance to Taiwan.
Meanwhile that day, DPP Legislator Wang Tu-fa told the CNA in an interview that Taiwan businesses should diversify their investments offshore instead of eyeing only the Chinese market.

Wang said he is worried that Taiwan companies are increasingly clustering in China, a situation that he claimed will lead to shrinkage in Taiwan's trade surpluses with China and hinder Taiwan's competitive edge over the long term.

Taiwan corporations must seek greater globalization and step up industrial upgrading to ensure sustainable competitiveness, he said, adding that promoting service businesses and innovative industries would be a good way to help slow the pace of Taiwan's reduced trade surplus.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU WANTS TO BECOME TOURIST ATTRACTION FOR CHINESE

TEXT.P: A Penghu official called Thursday for the government to allow the outlying island county of Penghu to be opened to visitors from China.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, Chang Jui-tung, a senior adviser to the Penghu county government -- located in the Taiwan Strait southwest of the southern port city of Kaohsiung -- said that opening Penghu to direct trade and shipping links with China's port of Xiamen in the "mini three links" spirit is not what Penghu residents want most.

Instead, Chang said, they would like to see their island become a stopover or relay point between Taiwan and China before the implementation of direct trade, postal and transportation links between Taiwan proper and China -- better known as the "three direct links."

Taiwan opened direct trade and transport links between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and China's Fujian Province ports of Xiamen and Mawei in January 2001 -- commonly known as the "mini three links."

Meanwhile, Chang said, Penghu residents would like to see the Executive Yuan make Penghu a tourist attraction for visitors from China, given that the county is already a tourist attraction for holidaymakers from Taiwan.

Chang made the remarks at a hearing held at the Legislative Yuan, where pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmakers invited officials from the Mainland Affairs Council, the Bureau of Immigration and the Penghu county government for a discussion on Premier Frank Hsieh's recent announcement that Penghu-Xiamen "mini three links" will be opened on a trial basis from September.

Hsieh's surprising announcement, made during a visit to Penghu last week, created a backlash from the TSU. Former President Lee Teng-hui, the TSU's so-called "spiritual leader, " threatened last Sunday to mobilize supporters to demonstrate on the streets against the plan, calling it an awkward move designed by the government to seek to restore public confidence after failing to persuade Taiwan farmers not to sell their produce to China.
At Thursday's hearing, TSU party whip Ho Min-hao said the TSU opposes Hsieh's idea, even on a trial basis.

Ho said that taking a cue from the implementation of the "mini three links" for Kinmen and Matsu, where local economies were found to have not been revved up as expected, the "mini three links" program would not be good for Penghu either. Besides, he argued, opening Penghu-China "mini three links" would only make Penghu's public order deteriorate, which would in turn leave Taiwan's national security compromised.

The Executive Yuan allowed a religious voyage from Penghu to Fujian in July 2001 and it has again approved an application filed recently by a religious group to make a similar trip. The voyages are screened on a case-by-case basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PREACHES `NEW PACIFIC CENTURY'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that a balanced relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is the key to the formation of a "new peaceful Pacific order."

Chen made the remarks at a news conference to introduce the soon-to-be-inaugurated Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , which was conceived by Vice President Annette Lu to boost cooperation among Pacific Rim democracies.

In his keynote speech, Chen said he is convinced that only a normalized, constructive cross-strait relationship based on the principles of parity and pragmatism can sustain Asia-Pacific prosperity and advancement.
Noting that this year marks the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II, Chen said the world should not forget the cruelty of the war.

As undemocratic politics and a lack of transparency in policy-making could lead to armed conflict, Chen said he is convinced that "democracy and peace" are the best cure for "autocracy and brute force."

Among the 39 Asian countries, Chen said, 15 have yet to reach full democratic standards -- government leaders chosen through direct popular elections, armed forces free of political influence, full human rights protection, party politics and rule by law. Four of the world's five remaining communist regimes are in Asia.

Against this backdrop, Chen said he has come up with a new diplomatic strategic goal for Taiwan -- establishing a new balance of power across the Taiwan Strait to buttress Taiwan's young democracy and maintain cross-strait peace.

"This strategic goal contains three key points -- protecting Taiwan's young democracy from being threatened or destroyed by China's "non-peaceful means;" cooperating with members of the global 'democratic community' to assist undemocratic countries, including China, in developing democratic systems; and seeking normalization of cross-strait economic relations under a framework of peace and stability," Chen explained.
In his view, Chen said, forging a balanced cross-strait relationship is critical to shaping a "new peaceful Pacific order."
Chen urged all Pacific Rim countries to work hand-in-hand to achieve this goal featuring freedom, stability, prosperity, peace, cooperation, symbiosis and cultural renaissance.
The president also lauded Lu for her assiduous efforts in giving birth to the DPU, which will be formally inaugurated in Taipei Sunday.
The DPU, a quasi-government-to-government international body committed to promoting democracy, peace and prosperity, is seen as an attempt by Taiwan to ease its diplomatic isolation.
Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco and Guatemalan President Oscar Berger are scheduled to arrive over the weekend to attend the DPU inauguration.

The DPU will have 26 member countries, including Taiwan, Canada, the United States, Mexico, Chile, Russia, Japan, South Korea, Nicaragua, Guatemala, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Panama, Peru, the Philippine, Malaysia, Australia and New Zealand.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE TO VOTE ON EXTRA SESSION FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will hold a vote Friday to determine whether to hold an extra legislative session during its current summer recess as requested by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , legislative sources said Thursday.
The showdown vote became necessary after the legislative caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties failed to reach a consensus on the "extra session" issue earlier in the day, the sources said.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng presided over the cross-party consultation, with the participation of legislative whips from the DPP, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU).

During the meeting, KMT whip Tseng Yung-chuan said the KMT opposes the DPP proposal to hold an extraordinary session to screen what the DPP calls six urgent bills, including those related to a long-stalled arms procurement package and the eight-year NT$80 billion flood-control projects.

Instead, Tseng said, the KMT looks forward to an early start of the next legislative session scheduled to open Sept. 1. According to the KMT's plan, the legislature can invite Premier Frank Hsieh to deliver an administrative report Sept. 6 and begin to screen livelihood-related bills in the following week.
PFP whip Huang Yi-jiao echoed Tseng's view, saying the PFP is opposed to holding an extra legislative session. The KMT and the PFP jointly control a slim majority in the legislature.
DPP whip William Lai said the party caucus will mobilize all of its members to attend Friday's informal legislative session to vote on the DPP proposal to hold an extra legislative session.

"The result of the showdown vote remains unclear. We hope the 'pan-blue alliance' can stop its boycott against the DPP administration. If the opposition parties continue their antagonistic approach for partisan interests, they will eventually lose popular support," Lai said.
Over the past five years, the "pan-blue alliance" has used its clout in the legislature to boycott the DPP's policy initiatives nearly at every turn.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS CALL FOR CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS ON FESTIVALS

TEXT.P: A group of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators called at the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Thursday to push for an early start to direct cross-Taiwan Strait passenger charter flights on Chinese traditional festivals, preferably prior to the upcoming Moon Festival holiday.

Legislator John Chiang said the KMT lawmakers met with MOTC officials to assess the possibility of Taiwan's allowing direct cross-strait passenger charter flights not only for the Chinese New Year holiday but also for the three other major festivals -- Tomb-Sweeping Day, Dragon Boat Festival and Moon (Mid-Autumn) Festival.
The lawmakers also discussed with the MOTC authorities the feasibility of simplifying and accelerating direct cargo charter flights across the strait, Chiang said.

The MOTC officials responded that so long as the government gives a green light, the ministry will have no problem helping implement direct passenger and cargo charter flight services on special days.

The lawmakers visited the MOTC for first-hand information after the Executive Yuan had procrastinated over authorizing the Taipei Airline Association to negotiate charter flights with their Chinese counterparts, even though Premier Frank Hsieh announced Aug. 3 that the Executive Yuan had decided to lift the ban on Taiwan commercial aircraft flying over China's airspace and had agreed to simultaneous negotiations for cross-strait cargo and passenger charter flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: 150 TAIWAN ATHLETES TAKE PART IN 2005 UNIVERSIADE IN TURKEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is being represented by 150 athletes in the 2005 World University Games, commonly known as the Universiade, which opened in Thursday in Izmir, Turkey.

The athletes will take part in 10 competition categories at the Universiade: track and field; swimming; gymnastics; tennis; women's volleyball; women's basketball; women's football; taekwondo; archery; and wrestling.
The Universiade will run through Aug. 23.
Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng traveled to Turkey Wednesday to cheer on the Taiwan athletes. While in Turkey, he will also drum up support for Taiwan's bid to host the 2011 Universiade.

DOC.HEADLINE: 30 KOREAN UNIVERSITY STUDENTS IN TAIWAN TO STUDY MARINE SCIENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Keelung, northern Taiwan, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of 30 students from South Korea's Cheju National University received a warm welcome when they arrived in the port city of Keelung Thursday for a summer study program at National Taiwan Ocean University.
The dean and students of Taiwan Ocean University held a reception to welcome their guests, showering them with souvenirs and entertaining them with songs and music.

The Korean students will stay at their host university for 20 days to study subjects related to marine science, including environmental engineering, aquaculture, marine ecology and conservation, marine products processing, pollution control and fishery management.
The summer program is called "2005 Taiwan Marine Discovery Program" and will last from Aug. 11-29.
In addition to attending classroom lectures, the students will make field trips to different coastal areas to help them learn about Taiwan's marine science.

DOC.HEADLINE: BATTLE LINES DRAWN IN LEGISLATURE OVER EXTRA SESSION

TEXT.P: Battle lines were drawn in the legislature Thursday over whether an extra legislative session is needed, with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its political ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on one side and the two major opposition parties, the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) on the other.

The KMT, which earlier said it might agree with such a session, albeit reluctantly, decided Thursday to align with the PFP in opposing the session, and urged all party lawmakers to vote against it in a showdown Friday.
KMT legislative caucus whip Cho Poh-yuan said that according to a survey conducted by the caucus, most KMT lawmakers do not see any need for a special legislative session.

The PFP expressed its opposition to the idea as soon as the DPP asked for an extra session to review what the DPP administration calls six urgent bills, arguing that there is no urgent need for the bills as they can be acted on in a regular session.

At the other end of the political spectrum, the TSU threw its weight behind the DPP, claiming that all six bills are vital to the country, not least budget bills of NT$80 billion for flood control projects and the NT$480 billion arms purchase.

Because of the absence of consensus among the parties on the issue, a showdown vote is slated for Friday. The KMT and PFP, which together control only two votes over half the entire legislature, said they will do their best to ensure that all their lawmakers show up to cast their votes against a special legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC TO DEVELOP UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES

TEXT.P: The government-owned Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) announced Thursday that it will cooperate with two local companies to develop the unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV).

AIDC Board Chairman Sun Tao-yu made the announcement during the signing of a letter of intent with the Space-tec Co. Ltd. and Pegasus Co. at the opening of the Taipei Aerospace and Defense Technology Exhibition 2005 being held at the Taipei World Trade Center.
An AIDC official said the company plans to focus on the domestic UAV market in the initial stage, and then enter into the Asian and international markets in the future.
Noting that UAVs are not subject to civil aviation regulations in many countries, the official said now is a good time for Taiwan companies to develop the industry.

Currently in Asia, only Taiwan and South Korea have begun UAV development and the AIDC hopes to take advantage of the trade opportunities offered by the domestic and Asia-Pacific markets, the official added.

According to the AIDC, international market researchers have estimated that the market value for UAVs will total NT$531.2 billion (US$16.6 billion) over the next 10 years, with the market in Taiwan worth NT$18.6 billion.

The official said that UAVs produced abroad are still expensive, while the prices of UAVs to be manufactured by the AIDC and the two domestic firms will be half or two-thirds the price of imported ones.

The UAVs to be developed by the AIDC can be used in military anti-landing operations, as well as in civilian missions such as rescue operations, anti-crime operations, anti-smuggling operations in coastal areas, land-development planning, marine or forest data research and typhoon-monitoring.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CANNOT MONITOR AID TO OTHER COUNTRIES: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that Taiwan is not in a position to monitor the appropriations of its aid donations to its diplomatic allies.
"Our goodwill should not be misinterpreted.... We cannot possibly go to those countries to monitor the appropriations of our donations," Lu said while fielding questions at a news conference.
The news conference was held to introduce the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) -- Lu's brainchild -- which will be formally inaugurated in Taipei Sunday.
Some foreign reporters asked Lu about her views on allegations that Taiwan bribed leading politicians in some Latin American countries in exchange for their diplomatic support.
Lu responded that the government has conducted various foreign aid programs under the supervision of the legislature.

"Once the donations are offered, we cannot monitor the appropriations of the donations. Those acts are internal affairs beyond our control. We should not encroach upon our allies' sovereignty, " Lu said.
Meanwhile, Lu said one of the DPU's tasks will be promoting political reforms to wipe out official corruption and enhance government transparency.

Speaking on the same occasion, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau said all of Taiwan's aid to its diplomatic allies has been for national development assistance and carried out in line with general international practices based on the principles of "official, transparent and orderly planning."
"It's not our policy to make donations to politicians of our ally countries.... Our policy is to make transparent the donations with careful planning," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDE DENIES REPORT ABOUT PRESIDENT'S U.S. TRANSIT STOPS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's negotiations with Washington over President Chen Shui-bian's transit stops in the United States on his way to visit allies in Central American are going smoothly, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Huang Chih-fang said Thursday.

Huang dismissed as "groundless" a local newspaper report that day that Washington will not give a green light to Chen's request for transit stops on U.S. territory unless Taiwan commits itself on a controversial U.S. arms purchase.
Huang said Washington has responded positively to Taipei's approach on Chen's trip but no deal has been fixed because Chen's itinerary in Central American has not yet been finalized.
The president's transit through the United States has nothing to do with the country's proposed arms purchase from America, Huang pointed out.

Chen's administration intends to buy a package of arms with a price tag of NT$480 billion from the United States, but a budget bill for the purchase has become bogged down in the opposition-controlled legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT: CHINA'S CALL FOR DIRECT PASSENGER FLIGHTS POLITICAL TRICK

TEXT.P: China's proposal to talk with Taiwan on the start of direct passenger flights across the Taiwan Strait is a political trick, President Chen Shui-bian claimed Thursday.

In a meeting with 2004 Nobel laureate in economics Edward Prescott, Chen said his administration wants to separate economic issues from political issues in its dealings with China but "it is difficult" because, he claimed, China politicizes almost everything.

Citing the stymied negotiations on direct chartered flights between Taiwan and China as example, Chen said Taiwan prefers to start with cargo flights not only because it is urgently needed by both sides, but also because Taiwan is wary of the impact passenger flights might have on national security.

Instead of accommodating Taiwan's security concerns, Chen said, China insists on talks on passenger flights first, "obviously" on the grounds that passenger flights will generate more publicity than cargo flights therefore are more valuable for what he claimed is China's "charm offensive" on Taiwan.
Another reason behind China's refusal to discuss cargo flights is that its freight fleet is much smaller than Taiwan's and cannot compete with Taiwan in this regard, the president claimed.
As a result, Chen said, the aviation negotiations were stalled before they even started.

DOC.HEADLINE: SICK PEOPLE WHO FAIL TO FILL OUT QUESTIONNAIRE MAY FACE FINES: DOH

TEXT.P: Officials of the Department of Health (DOH) said Thursday that people who "feel sick" but fail to fill out a health questionnaire upon their arrival in Taiwan will be liable to fines.

Lin Wen-fei, quarantine session chief from the DOH's Center for Disease Control, said customs personnel at airports will take the temperatures of arriving passengers and ask people with fever to fill out a health questionnaire as an anti-epidemics effort.
However, as custom officials are unable to discover those people with symptoms such as diarrhea or dizziness, it was unclear exactly how the so-called "anti-epidemic" measure would be enforceable.

The CDC official expressed "hope" that sick passengers would fill out health questionnaires to help in quarantine operations, and said sick passengers who fail to fill out questionnaire upon arrival will face fines ranging from NT$3,000 to NT$15,000, once discovered.
Lin noted that many countries are affected by contagious diseases and warned the public to "be on alert for diseases" on their foreign tours.
According to CDC statistics, there have been 30 imported cases of intestinal disease and 40 cases of dengue fever this year so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: States Opposing Plan to Shutter Air Guard Bases
The Pentagon plans to shut, shrink or realign hundreds of military sites nationwide, and a proposed overhaul of more than two dozen Air National Guard units has ignited a political firestorm in many states. The Air Force wants to retire aging aircraft from many Guard units, but doing that would leave more than two dozen states without emergency aircraft to fight fires, recover from hurricanes and cope with other natural disasters, lawmakers say. Officials from New England to the Pacific Northwest argue that the plan would leave them vulnerable to terrorist attacks.
Wall Street Journal: To Cut Pollution, Dutch Pay a Dump in Brazil to Clean Up
Brazilian workers and the Dutch government have been brought together in an unusual partnership by the Kyoto Protocol to reduce global-warming emissions by 2012. In a big dirt pit in Brazil, workers wearing protective masks piled rocks around cement columns jutting up from rotting trash, a modern landfill. Governments and private investors ranging from Japanese and Canadian power companies to London and Parisian banks have pledged more than US$1 billion toward the purchase of greenhouse-gas credits in developing countries such as Brazil, Chile and India. The garbage pile is a gold mine in the greenhouse-gas emission "credits." Each credit that a buyer in the industrialized world purchases from a seller in a developing country reduces the buyer's obligation to clean up its act back home. In theory, the system will reduce global emissions of greenhouse gases by sending money from industrialized nations to developing ones to tackle projects that otherwise wouldn't have gotten off the ground.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 12, or the eighth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1099: The Crusaders defeat the Egyptians at Ascalon on the Palestine coast in the First Crusade.
1813: Austria declares war against Napoleon.
1848: George Stephenson, the British railway pioneer who built the first passenger railway in 1825, dies at the age of 67. He also developed the first practical steam locomotive, the "Rocket."
1877: A group of people witness a public demonstration of a new device, a phonograph that records the human voice, at Thomas Edison's "invention factory" at Menlo Park, New Jersey.
1881: Cecil B. De Mille, the American film director, is born. He is legendary for his large-scale Biblical and historical epics such as "The Ten Commandments," "Samson and Delilah" and "Cleopatra."
1898: The United States and Spain sign a protocol ending the Spanish-American War, with Spain relinquishing Cuba and ceding Puerto Rico to the United States. In addition, the Hawaiian Islands are formally annexed by the United States.
1908: The Ford Motor Co. introduces its Model T car, a sturdy, black, four-cylinder number that comes in two versions: tourer and roadster. Both retail at incredibly low prices: the roadster at US$825 and the tourer for just US$25 more.
1912: William Booth, a Methodist minister who founded the Salvation Army in London in 1865, dies of illness in London at the age of 83. The Salvation Army works to foster a love of God and to provide for the needy. It offers its services to people of any race, creed, sex or age.
1914: Britain declares war on Austria-Hungary.
1946: The stolen body of dictator Benito Mussolini is found in northern Italy.
1948: The United States recognizes South Korea.
1954: The last batch of United Nations forces in the Korean War pulls out of Korea.
1961: Chen Chia-keng, an overseas Chinese from Singapore and founder of Amoy University, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 88.
1970: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and West Germany sign a non-aggression pact in Moscow.
1970: A China Airlines (CAL) passenger plane of the Republic of China crashes into a mountain on its way from Hualien in eastern Taiwan to Taipei, killing or injuring 31 people.
1978: Taiwan's fastest electrified train, the Tzu Chiang Express, makes a test run between Taipei and Taichung.
1978: Mainland China and Japan sign a treaty of peace and friendship in Beijing.
1985: A Japan Airlines Boeing 747 Jumbo jet crashes into Mount Osutaka on its way from Tokyo to Osaka, killing all but four of the 524 people aboard.
1990: Beijing's attempt to restore its tarnished image after the slaughter in Tiananmen Square receives a severe setback. Official documentation of the disturbances now reveals that more than 450 were killed, the majority by bullets, while 750 were injured and 3,000 were detained.
1991: Two mainland journalists arrive in Taipei, marking the first-ever visit to the ROC by the mainland Chinese press.
1995: The United States government decides to stop all nuclear testing.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan departs for the Dominican Republic to attend the Aug. 16 inauguration of President Leonel Fernandez.
1999: CAL signs an agreement with Airbus Industrie of Europe for a US$1.8 billion order for seven A340-300 passenger jets, with an option for one more A340-300 and four A330-300s.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh urges mainland China to produce a president through popular elections so as to bridge the gap between the political systems and public opinion on either side of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The Taiwan Solidarity Union, a political party formed by some of former President Lee Teng-hui's followers is formally inaugurated, with a written congratulatory message from President Chen Shui-bian read out at the ceremony.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There is only one way for a man to be true to himself. If he does not know what is good, a man cannot be true to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: SECRET CRUISE MISSILE DEPLOYMENT TV REPORT 'SHEER FABRICATION': MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) spokesman on Friday referred as a "sheer fabrication" to a media report claiming that locally-built cruise missiles have secretly begun to be deployed on the island.
MND spokesman Liu Chih-chian said that the defense ministry does not comment on fabricated reports.

According to the local cable television report, the secretly deployed "Hsiungfeng 2E" cruise missiles have become the Taiwan military's first "strategic force." In the future, the report said, the MND Missile Command will set up three cruise missile squadrons, with each squadron being equipped with 18 to 24 Hsiungfeng 2E cruise missiles.
The Hsiungfeng 2E cruise missile, a modified version of the locally-built Hsiungfeng II anti-ship missile, is a mid-range land-based mobile strategic missile.
A local newspaper reported June 5 that Hsiungfeng 2E cruise missiles have been tested successfully.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: NS call-ups cut to 10 years.
In-camp training for operationally ready national servicemen (NSmen) will be shortened from 13 years to 10, from next April.
The reduction is possible as the Singapore Armed Forces relies more on superior technology and less on having large numbers of people.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Malaysia declares state of emergency in two areas as haze crisis deepens.
Malaysia declared a state of emergency in towns on its west coast as smoke from forest fires raging in Indonesia smothered parts of the country, pushing pollution levels dangerously high.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: No Relief in Sight for Gasoline Prices. Motorists got a barrelful of bad news when oil prices soared to a new high, gasoline set another record in California and the Department of Energy warned that pump prices could remain above $2 a gallon through much of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: 12 LDP chapters set to back postal rebels
The internal strife in the ruling Liberal Democatic Party continued Thursday as at least 12 of the party's prefectural chapters said they would back 18 of the 37 postal privatization opponents in the Sept. 11 House of Representatives election.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: SC rejects Meralco rates hike
The Supreme Court (SC) yesterday denied with finality the appeal of the Energy Regulatory Commission (ERC) to allow the Manila Electric Co. (Meralco) to increase its power rates by 12 centavos per kilowatt-hour.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Oil prices next Arroyo crisis
IN THE MIDST of the worst political crisis of her presidency, here comes another whammy for President Macapagal-Arroyo.
The Philippine Star: JDV vows smooth impeachment
Speaker Jose de Venecia Jr. assured the public yesterday that there would be "smooth-running" hearings on the impeachment complaint against President Arroyo starting on Tuesday.
The Manila Times: Indons linked to blasts
NATIONAL Security Adviser Norberto Gonzales said on Thursday that it was possible two Indonesians feared to be planning suicide attacks in the Philippines could be involved in the two bomb blasts in Zamboanga City on Wed-nesday which injured at least 24 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Government: Italy is out of recession.
After suffering setbacks in the two previous quarters, Italy's economy grew by 0.7 percent on a quarter-to-quarter basis in the second quarter of this year, according to a report issued Thursday by the National Institute of Statistics. The figure represents the biggest single quarter growth since 2001, the report says. The country's gross domestic product fell by 0.4 percent and 0.5 percent in the last quarter of 2004 and the first quarter of this year, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: S.E. ASIAN WORKERS, SPOUSES URGED TO HAVE HEALTH CHECKED REGULARLY

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Friday that foreign workers and spouses from Southeast Asia must have their health checked prior to arriving in Taiwan and undergo regular health check-ups during their stays in Taiwan to help prevent the outbreak of epidemic diseases, particularly dengue fever.

Lin Wen-fei, quarantine section chief from the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC), urged workers and spouses from Southeast Asia to make sure that they have health check-ups prior to departure for Taiwan; within three days of their arrival in Taiwan; and after six months, 18 months and 30 months in Taiwan.
The check-ups should include examinations for tuberculosis, HIV/AIDS, syphilis, hepatitis B, parasites and leprosy, Lin said.

Any of these people who are found to have the above-mentioned diseases -- except for parasites, for which re-examinations will be allowed -- and have failed to inform the health authorities may risk not having their visas extended, Lin said.

Noting that there have been 40 cases of dengue fever confirmed to have been brought in from Southeast Asia so far this year, Lin said that violators either risk having their visas suspended or having their Taiwan employers liable to fines ranging from NT$60,000 to NT$300,000.
An eight-year-old boy living in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, was confirmed Thursday to have contracted dengue fever during a visit to Indonesia recently with his mother, who is an Indonesian national.
Meanwhile, CDC authorities announced Thursday that people who "feel sick" but fail to fill out a health questionnaire upon their arrival in Taiwan will be subject to fines.

The CDC official expressed the hope that sick passengers would fill out health questionnaires to help in quarantine operations, and said sick passengers who fail to fill out the questionnaires upon arrival will face fines ranging from NT$3,000 to NT$15,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE REGRETS LEGISLATURE'S VOTE AGAINST EXTRA SESSION

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office regrets the opposition-controlled legislature's decision not to hold an extra legislative session during its current summer recess to screen several critical bills, a spokesman said Friday.

Yu Shyi-kun, President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff, made the remarks after lawmakers earlier in the day voted 108-100 against the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) call for the holding of an extraordinary legislative session.
"We feel deep regret over the legislature's snub because all six of the bills are urgent and have already been stalled for a long time," Yu said.
The six bills include an arms procurement package and an eight-year, NT$80 billion basket of flood-prevention projects.

Yu said the arms procurement package was referred to the legislature during his tenure as premier. More than one year has passed, but the bill has yet to be placed on the legislative agenda due to the opposition "pan-blue alliance's" stonewalling.

The long delay has prompted the U.S. administration, Congress and major American think tanks to express doubts about Taiwan's determination to defend its own security in the face of China's ever mounting military threat, Yu said.

Quoting newly released U.S. and Japanese assessments, Yu said the military balance across the Taiwan Strait has been tilting in favor of China. If Taiwan fails to beef up its military arsenal as soon as possible, Yu said, its national security will be at stake.
"Arms procurement is a non-political professional issue. Partisan bickering should not block a rational debate on the topic," Yu said.
As to the flood-prevention bill, Yu said recent typhoon damage has accentuated the importance of quick action on flood-control projects.

Yu recalled that he came up with a NT$31.6 billion special budget plan for cleaning-up the Keelung River shortly after assuming the premiership in 2002. The legislature at the time approved it in an extraordinary session.

"The Keelung River clean-up project took two years to complete and has turned out to be a success," Yu said, adding that "residents in Nankang, Hsichi, Rueifang and Keelung now feel safer when typhoons come."

In the wake of last week's Typhoon Haitang, Yu said, the eight-year, NT$80 billion flood-prevention project has become all the more urgent. "We hope the legislature can pass it as soon as possible," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 150 TAIWAN FIRMS TO PARTICIPATE IN BERLIN CONSUMER ELECTRONICS SHOW
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A total of 150 companies from Taiwan will participate in the 2005 International Consumer Electronics Exhibition scheduled to be held at the Berlin Exhibition Grounds in the German capital Sept. 2-7.
The exhibition, which is organized by Messe Berlin GmbH every two years, is the world's largest consumer electronics trade fair.
According to the organizer, a total of 1,189 companies from various countries around the world will take part in the upcoming exhibition.

Some 100,000 experts, traders and consumers are expected to visit the exhibition, where high definition television (HDTV) and products relating to "digital living, " including personal digital musical equipment and multimedia mobile phones, are expected to be major attractions, according to the organizer.
The exhibition will also feature several categories of display, including television and entertainment, personal computing and games, digital imaging, and personal communications, among others.
According to Hans-Joachim, president of the Union for German Consumer Electronics Industries, the global consumer electronics market is expected to top 20 billion euros (US$xxxx) for this year.

The Berlin exhibition presents a great opportunity for participating companies to get a slice of that pie. The 2003 exhibition attracted over 1,000 exhibitors and 273,800 visitors and generated some 2.3 billion euros worth of orders, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN NIXES REQUEST TO CONVENE SPECIAL SESSION

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan on Friday decided not to convene a special session to review a bill for an eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-control program and five other prioritized bills that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has said are crucial to the nation's development.

The DPP legislative caucus the had requested the special session, saying that the flood-prevention project, as well as the NT$480 billion U.S. arms procurement package, the confirmation of Control Yuan members, proposed amendments to the Executive Yuan Organic Law, proposed amendments to the tobacco and liquor tax law, and a draft bill concerning the establishment of a labor pension fund monitoring committee are urgent matters that need to be dealt with.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng chaired an inter-party meeting on the matter Thursday where no consensus was reached, and lawmakers met again Friday to vote on the request.

In the first round of voting, 100 legislators voted "yea, " with 107 voting " nay." The DPP then requested a second vote, which resulted in an extra "nay" vote by a lawmaker who was late to the meeting.
Upon learning of the result, the legislative caucuses of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , expressed deep regret.

Jiao Yung-ching, DPP caucus whip, said the main opposition - the Kuomintang (KMT) and its ally, the People First Party (PFP) -- has stubbornly refused its request and the DPP has waited in vain for them to come around to their way of thinking.
The KMT and the PFP once agreed to hold a special session Aug. 15 or Aug. 16, and Jiao said he felt that the party has been given the runaround.

The DPP had hoped that KMT Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou could wield some influence; however, it became clear that the KMT is still mired in its irrational opposition, Jiao said, adding that he is "pessimistic about the future of the legislature."

William Lai, a DPP whip, said that the KMT originally agreed to hold a special session to review the flood-control proposal, but it later reneged because it didn't want to contradict the stance of the PFP, and that both have partisan interests in mind.
On the KMT's request that the next regular legislative session open earlier than its scheduled late September, Lai said that the KMT was only trying to cushion the backlash of public criticism.

Ho Min-hao, a TSU caucus whip, said that the party had hoped that both the ruling and opposition parties could make concessions and that only the flood-control project could be reviewed in the special session, but the KMT and the PFP still blocked the request on the grounds that the DPP was lumping the arms procurement proposal with the flood-control project.
Ho said that the KMT and the PFP are "simply opposing for the sake of opposing."
On the other hand, Hwang Yih-jiau, PFP caucus whip, was gratified that legislators from his party were united in blocking the special session request.
Hwang said, however, that if there is consensus between the ruling and opposition parties, the legislature could choose an earlier date to open its next session.
In an earlier floor meeting of the legislature, both ruling and opposition camps stated their stance on convening a special session.

Both Jiao and Lai of the DPP said that the six bills are urgent, and that if the flood-control project bill is not passed, the nightmare of flooding will reappear. Moreover, China's military budget is growing at a double-digit pace every year, and Taiwan needs to step up its defensive capabilities, and the Control Yuan has received more than 10,000 petitions from the public but they have been left unattended because the legislature refuses to review nominated members.

David Huang, a TSU party whip, said that because of the boycott by the KMT and the PFP, the arms procurement proposal has been blocked from being listed on the procedural committee's docket 26 times and that the legislature only passed 46 bills in the previous session.

Cho Po-yuan, a KMT whip, and Hwang said that they were opposed to holding a special session because it would only rashly pass the flood-control project bill. "The money should be used on things that are most needed," they said. In addition, the government's budget has ballooned every year, and it is still requesting a special budget, even though it has not used the money it has at its disposal wisely.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS SUGGEST DIRECTLY ELECTING STANDING COMMITTEE MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Six opposition Kuomingtang (KMT) legislators said Friday that they will suggest that the KMT amend its charter and allow party representatives to directly elect members of the Standing Committee.
The legislators, who are strong supporters of KMT Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou, are Wu Yu-sheng, Chen Chieh, Lee Chia-chin, Lee Fu-hsing, Lin Hung-chih and Lai Shyh-bao.

They said at a news conference that they will raise a motion in the 17th KMT General Assembly slated to be held Aug. 19 to amend the party's charter and request that the party's representatives be allowed to elect Standing Committee members through a direct vote.

According to the proposal, 1,600 representatives of the KMT's grassroots members should first be authorized to elect 210 members of the party's Central Committee and then elect 31 members of the Standing Committee from elected members of the Central Committee.
The current rules stipulate that members of the Standing Committee can only be elected by members of the Central Committee.

Pointing out that they cannot wait for the slow pace of the current party reforms, Lee Chia-chin and Chen Chieh said that as the KMT has already allowed its members to elect their chairman directly, the members of the Standing Committee should also be elected directly. They also claimed that a direct election of the members of the Standing Committee will help smooth interactions between the party's decision-making body and KMT grassroots members and expand their participation in the party's affairs.

Wang Jin-pyng, the speaker of the Legislative Yuan and outgoing vice chairman of the KMT, declined to comment on the matter the same day, although sources close to Wang said that even if the 17th KMT General Assembly can adopt the legislators' proposal, it would still only go into effect in the next assembly set to be held by 2009.

However, an official of the KMT Organization and Development Department said that he and other staff members of the party will do their utmost to help put the proposal into effect as soon as possible if the upcoming assembly agrees to allow the party representatives to elect members of the Standing Committee directly.

Ma also proposed Wednesday that the KMT allow party representatives to directly elect Standing Committee members, but outgoing KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who will step down Aug. 19, did not respond to the suggestion.
