DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET REGRETS FAILURE TO HOLD SPECIAL LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan regrets the Legislative Yuan's decision not to hold a special session, a spokesman of the Executive Yuan said Friday.
Cho Jung-tai made the remarks after lawmakers earlier in the day voted 108-100 against the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) request to hold an extraordinary legislative session.
However, Cho said that the Executive Yuan is still hoping that the Legislative Yuan can rationally consider key bills when the new session opens in September.

Cho said that the problems of water shortages and flooding cannot wait for even one day, noting that both President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Frank Hsieh have recently expressed serious concerns over the water shortage problem in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan.

He said to facilitate the convening of a special legislative session, Premier Hsieh recently called on the legislature to explain the urgency of the NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-control proposal, setting a precedent for a premier to call on the legislature to explain a special budget.
The premier has displayed his sincerity and goodwill, and has called Legislative President Wang Jin-pyng several times, Cho said.
Until Thursday night, the premier had called caucus whips of various parties, asking them to support the flood-control proposal, but the effort had "gone down the drain."

Cho disclosed that when the premier called opposition and independent legislators, several of them responded positively, but as some KMT legislators are running for the party's Central Standing Committee seats next week, they have put the people's interests aside.

Cho said that Executive Yuan's efforts over the past months are in "response to the public's urgent needs," and there is no political maneuvering involved, saying that the project will cover 136 rivers in 22 cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR APOLOGIZES TO TAIPEI CITIZENS FOR DRINKING ALCOHOL AT LUNCH

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou apologized openly Friday for having drunk alcohol during a lunch two days ago.
Ma said he should apologize to Taipei residents for drinking at a lunch because he had made it a rule that drinking alcohol at noon is banned for all Taipei City Government staff and personnel.

Ma said that he drank because it was hard to turn down the warmth from the people he lunched with on that day, but even so, he added, it was a "bad demonstration" and he promised that he will not do it again ever during his tenure as Taipei mayor.

Meanwhile, he said, investigations into the death of an official from the Taipei City Mortuary Services Office, reportedly after drinking alcohol during lunch, have begun and the city will be informed about the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 2.81 points to close at 6,350.9.
The bourse opened at 6,389.27 and fluctuated between 6,398.72 and 6,350.9 during trading. A total of 3.6 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$91.03 billion (US$2.85 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 2.6 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.5 percent, cement stocks at 1.2 percent, foodstuff issues at 1 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.8 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent.
Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down at 1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 475 to 419, with 112 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved down 37 points to close at 6,352, with 22,653 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September moved down 28 points to end at 6,360, with 5,219 contracts traded, while December futures lost 27 points to finish at 6,348, with 11 contracts traded. March futures moved down 18 points to close at 6,341, with seven contracts traded, while June futures moved down 20 points to close at 6,336, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,389 for August, 6,388 for September, 6,375 for December, 6,359 for March and 6,356 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

August TE futures moved down 4.8 points to close at 263, with 4,507 contracts traded, while September TE futures lost 3.9 points to finish at 263.7, with 1,332 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 0.25 points to end at 266.5, with two contract traded, while June TE futures lost three points to close at 263.8, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

August TF futures gained 1.6 points to finish at 975.6, with 3,190 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved up 1.2 points to end at 973.4, with 1,385 contracts traded. December TF futures moved up 3.4 points to close at 974, with five contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.013 to close at NT$31.892.
A total of US$597 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.905 and hit a low of NT$31.871.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILDREN OF 'TAISHANG' ATTEND SUMMER CAMPS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) is sponsoring summer camps in Taipei for offspring of Taiwan business people who maintain business operations in China, commonly known as "taishang, " in an effort to provide these children with an opportunity to better know Taiwan.

The camps have drawn 247 "taishang" children and youths, aged between 9 and 14, who have been in Taiwan in groups since July 9 to attend the nine-day summer camp which will run until Aug. 14, dubbed "the Beauty of Taiwan."
The camps are co-sponsored by the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and three other government agencies.

Most of the 247 children are students from two schools for "taishang" children located in Dongguan, Guangdong province and Kunshan, Zhejiang province and some are from Beijing, Tianjing, Suzhou, Ningbo, Nanjing, Chengdu, Shenzhen and Xiamen.

The summer camps give the children lessons about Mandarin Chinese and Taiwanese history and culture. The children also visit museums, historic sites and watch folk performances, as well as go on field trips to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's culture, history and current situation.

It is the third year that the quasi-official SEF has cooperated with the Mainland Affairs Council, the Ministry of Education and the Council for Cultural Affairs to jointly sponsor summer camps for "taishang" children.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW AVIATION SAFETY COUNCIL HEAD SWORN IN

TEXT.P: New Aviation Safety Council (ASC) Chairman Wu Ching-hsiung was sworn in Friday, promising that he will put the promotion of safety aviation as his top priority.

Wu, graduated from the Department of Electrical Engineering of National Taiwan University and obtained a doctorate in electrical engineering from Cornell University, is to succeed Kay Yong, who resigned from his post on April 1.
Wu noted that Singapore Airlines and Japan Airlines are noted for their management in aviation safety, and these serve as models for Taiwan's aerospace and aviation sector.
He estimated that good management in aviation safety can prevent at least 90 percent of aviation accidents.
According to Wu, the government set up the ASC seven years ago following a series of aircraft accidents.

Now, Wu went on, Taiwan's capability of decoding cockpit voice recorders and flight data recorders, commonly known as "black boxes" is recognized by the world community. The ASC even sent coaches to Indonesia to teach people there the techniques that they have developed.
Wu said he hopes that the ASC's accident investigation report can be flawless in the future, but hopes that there are no accidents to investigate.

Noting that the ASC is an independent organization, Wu said it will keep in close contact with aircraft accident investigation agencies of other countries, as well as the International Transportation Safety Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI METRO RIDES TO REACH 2 BILLION NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: With the Taipei metro system expected to take its two billionth passenger next week, the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) is preparing a series of activities to mark the historic moment.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will attend the "Two Billion Metro Rides" event to kick off Saturday at the metro station at Tamshui in Taipei County, while the county-based legislators, including Chou Hsi-wei, will also be in attendance, TRTC officials said Friday.
The Taipei Metropolitan Rapid Transit System began operating in March 1996. Until last March, there had been 1.5 billion rides, according to the TRTC.

TRTC officials indicated that as of Thursday, the number of metro rides has hit 1.99 billion. Given the fact that the number of current daily rides is around one million, the two billion mark should be made next week, they said.
Besides the planned activities, the TRTC has also issued 3,500 sets of limited metro tickets to commemorate the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHERN, EASTERN TAIWAN WARNED AGAINST HEAVY RAIN FROM TYPHOON SANVU

TEXT.P: Typhoon Sanvu is unlikely to make landfall in Taiwan, but people living in eastern and southern parts of the island should still guard against heavy rain brought by the typhoon, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) warned Friday afternoon.

In its weather report released at 5:30 p.m., the CWB said Typhoon Sanvu's center was at 19.8 degrees north latitude and 119.2 degrees east longitude -- about 290 kilometers southwest of Oluanpi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan.

With a radius of 200 kilometers, Typhoon Sanvu is moving northwest at 20 kilometers per hour and has already entered the Bashi Channel (Luzon Strait) and the seas around the Tungsha (Pratas) Islands. Its center winds have a maximum speed of 83 kilometers per hour, with gusts reaching 108 kilometers per hour -- comparable to 11th-grade wind.
The CWB report warned ships operating in or near the Bashi Channel, the Taiwan Strait and the seas around the Tungsha Islands to be on high alert.

The report also warned that heavy rain brought by the typhoon may cause landslides and mud flows in the mountain areas of Taitung, Hualien, Kaohsiung and Pintung, and that people living in low-lying areas should take precautions against flash floods.

According to the CWB, beginning Friday evening, southern Taiwan from Tainan downward may be hit by gusts comparable to 10th and 11th grade winds, and the coastal areas in central Taiwan and Penghu -- an island off Taiwan -- may also experience 9th and 10th grade gusty winds.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER SUPPLY TO NORTHERN TAOYUAN EXPECTED TO BE RESTORED SATURDAY

TEXT.P: Water supplies should be fully restored to the northern part of Taoyuan County Saturday, Wu Yueh-hsi, secretary-general of the Water Resources Agency, said Friday.

Residents in the northern Taiwan county, who get their water from the Shihmen Reservoir, have experienced water shortages over the past two years. Whenever a powerful typhoon hits the country, water treatment facilities are unable to tackle the increased turbidity that comes with torrential rain.

Residents in the northern part of Taoyuan County have been on a rotational water supply during the past few days, Wu said, adding that because the turbidity in the catchment of the Taoyuan River is still high, full water supply to the region is impossible for the time being.

As water supplies were fully restored to the southern part of Taoyuan County early Friday morning, government agencies decided to supply water from the southern to the northern part to put an end to water rationing in the northern part of Taoyuan County Saturday, Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EFFICIENT JUNK MAIL FILTERING SOFTWARE DEVELOPED

TEXT.P: New e-mail filtering software developed by two domestic universities was launched Friday, with its creators claiming it can filter some 97 percent of junk mails, the National Chung Cheng University (NCCU) announced.

According to Kuo Yao-huang, the software, dubbed "Nopam, " was jointly developed by NCCU and National Tsinghua University, and can handle more than one million e-mails in Intel Pentium 4 computers per day, with the error margin of less than 0.01 percent.
This software will be offered to various schools or academic sectors of the country for free, Kuo said, adding that he is proud of the achievement.

NCCU Professor Lee Hsing-lin noted that the research and development of computer software is quite difficult in Taiwan, as few entrepreneurs are willing to dedicate themselves to this area, and therefore it needs long-term efforts.

Wu Sheng, director of NCCU's Internet center, said some junk mails are disguised in different versions to elude e-mail filtering software, but Nopam can compare the sources, contents, titles, the similarity, or whether they are sent in quantities to find these junk mails.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR RECEIVES VISITING SOUTH KOREAN PARLIAMENTARIAN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou met with visiting South Korean parliamentarian, Park Jin, and his wife Friday at his office.
Issues on the current regional affairs, Taiwan-South Korea ties and personal sporting habits were topics of conversation between the two politicians, who also talked about "Korea fever" in Taiwan.

Park said that he was surprised that Korean drama stars, such as Bae Yong Jun and Song Hye Kyo, enjoy widespread popularity in Taiwan, noting that the entertainers are less popular in South Korea than in Taiwan. He joked that he should have had the stars accompany him to Taipei to attract the media.

During the meeting, Park also asked Ma about his intention to run for the Republic of China presidency in 2008. Ma replied that for the time being he has no time to consider the matter because of busy city administration.
Park and his wife arrived in Taiwan Wednesday for a four-day visit. They are scheduled to leave the island Aug. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS IN HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK DECREASED IN FIRST SIX MONTHS

TEXT.P: Business transactions in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park totaled NT$446.2 billion (US$13.98 billion) in the first six months of this year, a decrease of 15 percent compared to the same period of last year, a park administration official said in Hsinchu city Friday.
Chi Kuo-chung, deputy director of the science park administration, said the decrease was due largely to declining demand for electronic products.

According to the statistics, transactions for computer and peripheral products dropped by 25 percent in the January-June period, while business for semiconductors and opto-electronic articles declined 14.7 percent and 16.8 percent, respectively.
Business transactions for the telecommunication and biotechnology industries increased 8.4 percent and 23.8 percent, respectively, over the year-earlier period.
Chi noted that the enterprises in the park are re-adjusting their operations due to the falling demand, but will improve their financial structures and increase capacity to prepare for the next boom.
As of late June, the combined paid-up capital of firms in the park had reached NT$1.82 trillion, an annual increase of 3.3 percent.

There are 14 new enterprises planning to invest in the park, with approved investment worth NT$7.62 billion, and some 58 companies are still discussing their investments, worth a combined NT$8.4 billion.

According to a recent survey, the companies in the park still have confidence in the economic prospects for the second half of this year, with firms increasing their investment by a combined NT$66.59 billion in the first half of this year, a growth of 188 percent over the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: GENDER MAINSTREAMING SHOULD BE PART OF DEVELOPMENT AGENDA: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that gender mainstreaming should be part of the nation's future development agenda so that women and men benefit equally and so that inequality will not be pertuated.
Chen made the remarks at the inaugural meeting of the Presidential Office Gender Mainstreaming Advisory Group, which was formed to promote gender equality in all areas and at all levels.

Noting that gender mainstreaming is a strategy for making the concerns and experiences of women and men an integral part of the design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies and programs in all political, economic and social spheres, Chen said the ultimate goal of mainstreaming a gender perspective is to achieve gender equality.
"The goal of mainstreaming gender equality is the transformation of unequal social and institutional structures into equal and just structures for both men and women," Chen explained.

Hopefully, Chen said, the inauguration of the Gender Mainstreaming Advisory Group will push government agencies at all levels, as well as private corporations and organizations, to bring the experience, knowledge and interests of women and men to bear on legislation, policy formulation and development agendas.

Acknowledging that Taiwan's traditional social structure discriminates against women, Chen said more institutional, financial and human resources should be devoted to bringing gender issues into the mainstream of society. In particular, Chen said, gender mainstreaming education should be reinforced to combat the direct and indirect consequences of past discrimination.

Over the past decade, Chen said, Taiwan has made progress in promoting gender equality, including the legislation of the Sexual Assault Prevention Law, the Sexual Harassment Prevention Law and the Law on Gender Equality in the Workplace. The Executive Yuan and the Ministry of Education have also set up women's rights promotion committees.

In 2004, Chen went on, Taiwan enacted a Gender Equality Education Law to accentuate its determination to move forward from simply stressing women's rights protection to mainstreaming a gender perspective.

Following the establishment of the Gender Mainstreaming Advisory Group, Chen said, all future educational and vocational training programs, civil service examinations and recruitment plans and population policy planning should feature a gender perspective.

During the advisory group's inaugural meeting, panelists You Mei-nu and Liu Chung-tung delivered special reports on the importance of gender mainstreaming in national development and population policy planning.

You suggested that the central government set up a special agency to monitor the implementation of gender mainstreaming in the operations of five government branches -- the Executive Yuan, the Legislative Yuan, the Judicial Yuan, the Examination Yuan and the Control Yuan.

For his part, Liu said a lack of gender perspectives in Taiwan's past family planning and population policy has contributed to a host of social problems and imbalances, including the disproportionately high number of male infants, the greying population, the declining birth rate, late female marriage, the growing number of foreign spouses and the rising divorce rate.
In his view, Liu said, local women have become reluctant to give birth mainly because of the heavy burden in child rearing, as men have traditionally done little in this regard.
Speaking at a news conference after the meeting, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said the new advisory group will meet once every three months.

"Experts and scholars in gender mainstreaming will be invited to speak at those meetings, " Yu said, adding that the topics will include correlations between gender mainstreaming and democratic systems, human rights protection and cultural diversity.
The Presidential Office will also invite experts to speak on relevant topics at its monthly meeting to help local and central government officials better understand the gist of gender mainstreaming.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ADOPT NEW U.N. BID STRATEGY

TEXT.P: Taiwan will adopt a new strategy in promoting its bid to join the United Nations by presenting two cases for U.N. participation, Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen said Friday.

Chen said this year's U.N. General Assembly is scheduled to start Sept. 13. Under the new strategy, 14 Republic of China allies made two proposals to U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan Thursday, urging the U.N. General Assembly to ascertain the U.N. representation of the 23 million people of Taiwan and requesting the U.N. to play an active role in safeguarding peace in the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the remarks as he explained the nation's new mindset on its bid to join the U.N.

Since 1993, Taiwan has tried every year to ask the U.N. Steering Committee, through its diplomatic allies, to place Taiwan's U.N. bid on the General Assembly agenda. This has been unsuccessful every time because of China's obstruction and because of the international reality that so few countries recognize the ROC.

He claimed there are several developments worth attention this year, including the U.N. celebration of its 60th anniversary, China's enactment of the "Anti-secession Law, " which codifies China's use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan, and Annan's suggestion in March for U.N. reform to enhance freedom through pursuit of development, security and human rights.

The ministry has decided to forego its traditional approach and pitch for a core purpose of the U.N. as a peace-maintaining organization, hoping to stand on the high moral ground of "peace" to solicit the international community's concern and efforts in safeguarding cross-strait peace, he said.

Chen went on that the U.N. representatives of 11 ROC allies -- Marshall Islands, Nauru, Palau, Solomon Islands, Burkina Faso, Chad, Gambia, Malawi, Sao Tome and Principe, Belize and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines -- proposed Taiwan's U.N. bid to Annan, asking the U.N. General Assembly to recognize Taiwan's representation in the U.N.

The U.N. representatives of 13 ROC allies -- the Marshall Islands, Nauru, Palau, Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Burkina Faso, Chad, Gambia, Malawi, Sao Tome and Principe, Guatemala, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines and Saint Kitts and Nevis also proposed to Annan at the same time that U.N. play an active role in cross-strait peace. Kiribati, which has no mission in the U.N., had its vice minister propose for Taiwan.

On the proposal urging the U.N. to play an active cross-strait role, the allies asked Annan to send an envoy or a truth investigation delegation to Taiwan to assess the security situation in the Taiwan Strait and report to the U.N. General Assembly and related agencies so that they can adopt necessary measures to encourage and assist both sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in peaceful dialogue and exchanges.
On whether the proposal will be established, Chen said he did not know how Annan would react.
He noted that China will try to block the case from being discussed by any means possible.
He said the sending of an envoy or a truth investigation delegation are only Taiwan's suggestions and that the U.N. might have its own approach.

Taiwan will also communicate privately with the United States and Japan, "hoping to listen to their views, and if they are in favor of the proposal, we hope they can intercede to assist us," Chen said.

He stressed that Taiwan's bid is not aimed at challenging any countries' rights or seats in the U.N. and that the Beijing authorities should understand that repeated obstruction to Taiwan's bid to join the international community will not be conducive to the improvement of cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANPOWER QUALITY NEEDS TO BE UPGRADED: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Friday that Taiwan's manpower quality has to be upgraded if the country wants continued economic growth.
Wu made the remarks while attending a seminar on industrial talent nurturing in central Taiwan. Industrial and government officials, as well as scholars, were invited to the seminar.

He stressed that talent nurturing has to be geared to the needs of industry or it will result in a waste of training resources. The government should also have an assessment mechanism to inform training institutes of the needs of enterprises, he said.

He cited as an example that the government attaches importance to sewage treatment construction and has appropriated budget to that end, but cannot find suitable workers, which shows that training agencies have yet to train personnel in line with the policy.
He said Taiwan's industry has to step up its transformation and upgrading if the economy is to continue to develop, adding that manpower resources are the key point.

He also reaffirmed that the government's goal of achieving 4 percent economic growth this year remains unchanged and said the government will try to create business opportunities through the BOT model, as well as cutting government personnel expenditure.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO DRILL WELLS TO EASE NORTHERN TAOYUAN WATER SHORTAGE

TEXT.P: A group of drilling technicians from the Chinese Petroleum Corp. are helping to drill wells for water to release Taoyuan from the water shortage from which the northern county has been suffering since Typhoon Matsa swept the country Aug. 5.
Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh visited the team Friday at the Tanan water plant in Taoyuan County while inspecting the facility that provides water to the county's northern area.

Given that the turbidity in the catchment area of the Taoyuan river remains too high for the water treatment plant to deal with it, Ho said they will drill five wells in the water treatment plant for water to dilute the muddy river water.

The turbidity of the Taoyuan river was at an extreme high level of 29,000 degrees and only when the turbidity drops to the level of 3,000 degrees can the water be drawn into the plant for treatment, Ho explained.

Saying that the drilling is an urgent move to ease the water shortage in the short term, the minister added that the most effective way to save the area from water shortages permanently is to allow the Panhsin water plant in Taipei County to help supply water to Taoyuan.
Water supplies to the southern part of Taoyuan have already been restored to normal.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 3,000 PEOPLE TO JOIN ROAD RUN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An annual road run organized by the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) is slated to kick off Sunday in the suburban Waishuanghsi area of Taipei, with 3,121 people having signed up for the run.
The CTOC has hosted the run since 1988, attracting around 3,000 runners every year.

The 2005 event will include three different races of four, eight and 15 km, respectively, according to the CTOC. The oldest participant will be Teng Tung-ming, 74, while the youngest will be a five-year-old named Hu Cho-ming.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP MAY JOINTLY INTRODUCE FLOOD CONTROL LEGISLATION

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) -- the two largest opposition parties in Taiwan -- might jointly introduce their own version of legislation for flood-control when the next session of the Legislative Yuan opens, the legislative caucuses of the two parties said Friday.

The two caucuses revealed through their whips at a news conference that the two parties have already drafted a flood control program and that they do not rule out the possibility for the KMT and the PFP jointly introducing the legislation.

The news conference was held after the Legislative Yuan rejected a request by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to convene a special session to consider six bills deemed by the DPP as "crucial" to the nation's development, including a bill that would set aside NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) for an eight-year flood-control program and another bill that would allow Taiwan to procure advanced weaponry from the United States.

Sun Ta-chien, deputy convener of the PFP legislative caucus, questioned the ruling party's motive of tying the arms procurement bill to the flood control bill, claiming the DPP's request for a special Legislative Yuan session to consider the flood control bill is merely a pretext and that the DPP's real purpose is to push for the passage of the arms procurement bill.

Sun urged President Chen Shui-bian to tell the nation whether he made any secret promises about the planned arms purchase to Randall G. Schriver, former U.S deputy assistant secretary general of state in charge of Taiwan affairs, during Schriver's recent visit to Taiwan.
"Was Schriver's visit a private one? Or was he in Taiwan to deliver an ultimatum regarding Taiwan's military procurement from the United States?" Sun asked.

Cho Po-yuan, a KMT caucus whip, also claimed that the DPP's real intention is not to consider the flood control bill. He pointed out that the legislature's legal affairs office -- controlled by the opposition -- has already reached the conclusion that the flood control plan drafted by the DPP is "unworkable."

Cho said the KMT has prepared its own version of the flood control legislation. However, he added, the KMT caucus has not reached a consensus yet on whether the money will come in a special budget or in the regular fiscal budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR MORE IMPORTED DENGUE FEVER CASES CONFIRMED

TEXT.P: A Taitung County Department of Health official urged the public Friday to stay alert to the danger of dengue fever while visiting Southeast Asian countries.
The official made the appeal after four members of a family from Taitung who had just returned from Indonesia were confirmed to be infected by dengue fever, a mosquito-transmitted disease.
An 8-year boy was the first of the family confirmed to have contracted dengue fever Aug. 10, while the father, the boy's younger brother and sister also tested positive Friday.
The mother, of Indonesian origin, said the family visited Indonesia from July 23-Aug. 6.
During their stay, the family were bitten by mosquitos, with her husband, the younger boy and the girl getting fever Aug. 2. They did not see any doctor.
Upon arrival in Taiwan Aug 6, the 8-year boy was found suffering from fever at airport and his blood sample was immediately tested by quarantine officials, who later confirmed dengue fever.
The DOH then tested samples from the other family members, which also proved positive.

As many Taiwan residents with foreign spouses will visit Southeast Asian countries during the summer months, the official reminded local residents to prevent mosquito bites, adding that if they feel unwell after returning home, they should seek medical care right away and inform the doctors about where they have traveled.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC NAMES PROXY TO CONTACT CHINA OVER CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday it has commissioned the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) to contact China over the opening of direct charter passenger and cargo flights across the Taiwan Strait.
MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said the TAA is expected to represent Taiwan in discussions with an as-yet unnamed Chinese organization.
The TAA is a private group composed of representatives of local air carriers.
You said the MAC is not in a position to name which Chinese organization the TAA should contact.

"I think Beijing's Civil Aviation Administration of China will designate a private association to negotiate with the TAA for the proposed opening of non-stop cross-strait charter passenger and cargo flights," You said.
Formal cross-strait contacts have been carried out by private bodies because Beijing refuses to talk directly to Taiwan's government due to its cherished "one China" principle.

Direct Taiwan-China air links have been banned since the two sides split amid civil war in 1949, although an exception was made during this year's Lunar New Year holiday, when 48 two-way, non-stop cross-strait passenger charter flights were laid on to carry Taiwan businessmen operating in China home for festival celebrations.

Premier Frank Hsieh announced Aug. 3 that the government will allow local carriers to fly over China's airspace on their way to other destinations to save travel time and fuel costs amid the current upward spiral of oil prices. In his announcement, Hsieh also proposed holding new talks with Beijing on cargo and passenger charter flights.

"As Beijing has been quick to respond positively to the premier's proposal for simultaneous talks on charter cargo and passenger flights, we have decided to commission the TAA to contact Beijing to arrange the formal negotiations," You said.

The lack of direct cross-strait air links requires passengers to transfer through a third location, usually Hong Kong or Macau. Despite the inconvenience, business links between the two sides are booming, with last year's bilateral trade volume exceeding US$60 billion.

Faced with mounting casualties and signs of d iminished support for the war, President Bush said Thursday that while the United States was making progress in Iraq, it was too soon to say when the number of American troops could be scaled back. He also signaled that, despite planning by senior Pentagon officials for a potential troop reduction as early as next spring, he was not certain Iraqis could handle their own security well enough for the United States to begin leaving anytime soon.
Wall Street Journal: Hot Bidding, In a Challenging China Market, EBay Confronts a Big New Rival
As in so many industries, China offers Internet companies a fast-growing but tricky and immature market. That would be daunting enough for eBay, which is one of China's biggest online auction companies. Yahoo Inc. said it agreed to pay US$1 billion in cash and turn over its Chinese operations to Alibaba in return for a 40 percent stake in the Chinese e-commerce company. EBay, based in San Jose, Calif., has built a potent global brand by cloning its popular Web site in 33 countries. Most of the company's users are now outside the U.S., accounting for roughly half of eBay's auction revenue.

Finally yesterday, President Bush dismissed talk of a drawdown as just "speculation and rumors" and warned against "withdrawing before the mission is complete."

DOC.HEADLINE: RAIN FROM TROPICAL STORM SANVU MAY CONTINUE FOR FIVE DAYS: CWB

TEXT.P: Central and southern parts of Taiwan might experience continuous rain over the next five days because of Tropical Storm Sanvu and that people living in these areas should guard against floods, landslides and mudflows, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) warned late Friday.

In an update on the storm's movement, the CWB said there had already been heavy rain in the Pingtung area of southern Taiwan and in areas south of Ilan in northeastern Taiwan, and that from Friday night through Saturday, there might be heavy rain in areas south of Taichung, in central Taiwan, and in areas south of Hualien, in eastern Taiwan.
The CWB urged people living in mountainous areas of Kaohsiung, Pingtung, Hualien and Taitung counties to be on high alert against landslides, mudflows and flash floods.

At 8 p.m. Friday, Sanvu's center was located 270 km southwest of Oluanpi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan. With a radius of 200 km, the storm was moving northwest through the Bashi Channel and the seas around the Tungsha (Pratas) islands at a speed of 20 kph, according to the CWB.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRITICAL PRESS ORGANIZATIONS TO BE INVITED TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Leaders of the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists and the Paris-based Reporters without Borders will be invited to visit Taiwan to learn about the country's efforts to defend press freedom after they criticized the Taiwan authorities for revoking the licenses of seven cable TV stations, Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao said Friday.

According to Yao, the two international organizations, both of which have years of wide-ranging experience of press curtailment all over the globe, had "obviously misunderstood" the licence-withdrawals and the reasons behind them, and claimed that they "do not understand" that the environment in which local TV stations operate is "quite different" from that of the United States.
Instead of trying to bring the TV stations to heel, Yao said, the government is simply pushing them to live up to their responsibility to the public.

He made the statement after the Committee to Protect Journalists joined Reporters Without Borders in condemning the Taiwan government's suspension of licenses to the news stations ETTV-S and six other entertainment-based cable stations and its placing of all other cable news stations under a three-month "probationary period."
The committee said in a news release Thursday that it is deeply concerned by the Taiwan government's censorship of ETTV-S and its chilling effect on other news stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. URGED TO TAKE STEPS TO AVERT CROSS-STRAIT CONFLICT

TEXT.P: More than 10 Republic of China diplomatic allies filed a request with U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan Thursday urging him to appoint either an envoy or a task force to look into the Taiwan Strait situation.

According to Andrew L.Y. Hsia, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, the request reflected the "international community's expectations" that the United Nations take steps to safeguard cross-strait peace and avert any conflict in the region.

Noting that the United Nations passed Resolution 57/337 in July 2003 on the prevention of armed conflict, Hsia said Annan should take necessary measures to encourage and assist the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in peaceful dialogue and exchanges.

In the U.N. charter, Hsia went on, prevention of war and conflict is one of the most important obligations of U.N. members. Since the Taiwan Strait is widely seen as a potential flashpoint, he said, the United Nations is obliged to assist in resolving cross-strait disputes and preventing armed conflict.
"This year marks the U.N.'s 60th founding anniversary. Annan has come up with many U.N. reform programs. We think that our diplomatic allies' request bears special meaning," Hsia said.

Also Thursday, Taiwan's diplomatic allies presented another request asking the U.N. to address the representation of the 23 million Taiwan people in the world body. This is the 13th consecutive year that the ROC has, through its allies, asked the United Nations to consider its membership bid.

The ROC, a U.N. founding member, lost the "China" U.N. seat to Beijing's communist government in 1971, and since 1993 has launched annual bids to get back into the organization. The past 12 bids were quashed by China and the prospects for this year's campaign remain "unclear."

China's former Kuomintang (KMT) government lost a civil war to the communists in 1949 and fled to Taiwan, where it claimed to be the legitimate Chinese government. But it disavowed the claim in 1991 and Taiwan's leaders have drifted toward a separate Taiwanese identity.
However, China claims Taiwan as part of its territory and passed legislation in March this year codifying the use of force if Taiwan moves toward formal independence.

This year's U.N. General Assembly is scheduled to start Sept. 13. The ROC allies that filed the two requests were the Marshall Islands, Nauru, Palau, the Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Burkina Faso, Chad, Gambia, Malawi, Sao Tome and Principe, Guatemala, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Saint Kitts and Nevis and Kiribati.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 13, or the ninth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The British formally take over the colony at the Cape of Good Hope, located at the southernmost tip of the African continent, from the Dutch.
1860: Annie Oakley, the American sharpshooter who could hit the edge of a playing card at 30 paces, is born as Phoebe Anne Oakley Moses.
1898: American forces led by George Dewey capture Manila during the Spanish-American War.
1899: Hollywood film director Alfred Hitchcock is born in England. He directed such classics as "Psycho" and "The Birds."
1910: Florence Nightingale, the British nurse known as "the Lady with the Lamp," dies at the age of 90. She organized and directed a unit of field nurses during the Crimean War and is considered the founder of modern nursing.
1923: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk is elected president of Turkey.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander in chief of China's Nationalist Revolutionary Forces, resigns in order to bring about solidarity between the Nanking and Hankow factions of the Kuomintang.
1927: Japanese troops launch a major attack on Shanghai and are met with stiff resistance from Chinese defenders.
1942: The United States and Britain decide to carry out joint research on the atomic bomb.
1949: Mao Zedong names Beijing as Communist China's capital.
1960: The Central African Republic gains independence from France.
1961: Communist East Germany begins the erection of the Berlin Wall, drawing strong protests from Western nations.
1967: Fifteen grand justices nominated by President Chiang Kai-shek are approved by the Republic of China's Control Yuan.
1969: Communist China and the Soviet Union accuse each other of sending troops across their Central Asian border and inflicting heavy casualties.
1974: Mort Young, deputy editor-in-chief of Hearst Newspapers in the United States, arrives in Taipei for a two-week visit.
1975: An eight-member Taiwan dance troupe leaves for La Paz to perform at celebrations marking Bolivia's independence day.
1976: Over 140 youths from 20 nations join in the opening ceremony of the International Youth Recreation Tour to the Republic of China sponsored by the China Youth Corps.
1976: The ROC Cabinet approves extension of the Sino-Uruguayan Agreement on Agricultural Cooperation for two years.
1978: A building serving as the Beirut headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Front and containing the offices of their rivals, Al-Fatah, is ripped apart by a bomb, leaving some 150 people dead.
1984: Six mainland Chinese freedom seekers freed by the Korean government arrive in Taipei. The six hijacked a Communist Chinese Trident plane from Shenyang, Manchuria, to Seoul, South Korea, on May 5, 1983.
1989: Two hot air balloons collide in the worst-ever hot air balloon disaster in Australia, with one of the balloons plunging 182 meters to the ground, killing 12 people.
1993: A hotel collapses in Thailand, killing over 120 people.
1999: The Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan estimates that the ROC's economic growth rate will reach 5.5 percent for the year.
2000: President Chen Shui-bian and his 200-member entourage leave Taipei, beginning a 13-day visit to six states in the Caribbean, Central America and Africa.
2001: Academia Sinica member George C. Tiao becomes the first scholar and the first ethnic Chinese to receive both the prestigious Wilks Memorial Award and the Julius Shiskin Award in statistics in the same year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Trust is the law of God. Acquired truth is the law of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE WANT TO BE THEIR OWN MASTERS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday expounded on the issues of the nation's identity, cross-strait policy and the nation's future, stressing that the aspiration of the Taiwanese people to be their own masters is unstoppable.
The president made the remarks when he addressed via teleconference the 32nd annual conference of the World Federation of Taiwanese Associations which was held in Brisbane, Australia.

The president noted that despite twists and turns during Taiwan's process in pursuit of democratization, the island has been blessed so that democracy has been achieved without bloody revolution. For this, Taiwan cannot possibly be severed from its past, he added.

Chen noted that he referred to the official name of the country as "the Republic of China (Taiwan) " during his overseas visits and that the nation's name on the Web site of the Presidential Office has also been changed to "the Republic of China (Taiwan)."

He said he knows that some people might not be satisfied, but they should know that the transfer of power between two political parties is not revolution and that Taiwan cannot be severed from its history, adding that as a national leader, he has a responsibility to history and the Taiwan people.

He noted that he recently expounded "the four stages of the Republic of China, " with an aim of giving the public a clear and definitive idea about his ideas regarding Taiwan's sovereignty and national identity.

Chen said that the ROC was established in China in 1912. Between 1912 and 1949, the ROC was on the mainland of China. After 1949, the ROC "moved" to Taiwan. In the third stage, during the time when Lee Teng-hui was president (1988-2000) , "the ROC on Taiwan" was the catch-phrase used to describe the nation.
In the fourth stage after 2000, with the first peaceful transfer of power in the ROC's history, the new phrase should be "the ROC is Taiwan," according to Chen.
The president said that "the People's Republic of China is China, and that the ROC is Taiwan, not China, " urging the public to make a clear distinction between the two.

On the future of the nation, the president reaffirmed that the ROC is a sovereign independent country, the nation's sovereignty lies with the 23 million people on Taiwan and any changes concerning Taiwan's future will be decided by the 23 million people on Taiwan alone.

He continued that the biggest challenge for Taiwan is not which name it should call itself, but China on the other side of the Taiwan Strait, which he said has used every possible means to try to totally deny the rights and fact of Taiwan as a sovereign independent country.

He noted that the U.S. Defense Department in a report on China's military power last month said clearly that with China's continued military buildup, the cross-strait military balance is now tilting toward China.

The report said that China has used diplomatic, economic, legal, physiological and military means to try to influence the domestic political situation in Taiwan. China has stressed cross-strait historical, ethnic and cultural links in an attempt to spread the idea of unification within Taiwan, Chen said.

The report also said that China, using diplomatic means and verbal intimidation, tried without success to prevent President Chen from winning a second term in 2004, and that it issued a warning on May 17 -- three days before Chen's inauguration for a second term -- on the consequences Taiwan will face if it pursues separatism.
Faced with a series of "hostile and splitist moves from China, " the president reiterated his cross-strait guidelines of "one principle, three insistences and five oppositions."
"The 'one principle' is to engage in dialogue, consultation and negotiation with China under the principle of democracy, equality and peace," Chen said.

For the sake of political stability and a breakthrough in cross-strait relations, the ruling and the opposition parties must reconcile, and the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should also reconcile, although the reconciliation must be based on the "three insistences," he continued.

"Our insistence on the ideals of democratic reform will not change, our insistence on the mainstream path of national identity will not change, and our insistence on the mission of transforming Taiwan into a normal, complete, great and progressive country will not change," he said.

The "five oppositions" refer to the government opposing Beijing's "one China" policy, Chen said, adding that it is China's goal to make Taiwan a part of China. The government also opposes the "one country, two systems" framework that would make Taiwan follow in Hong Kong or Macau's footsteps, he continued.

"We also oppose the '1992 consensus' placed within the context of 'one China' or 'one country, two systems, ' and reject any proposal that is premised on 'unification,' or makes it the only option," Chen said.
"And we firmly oppose Beijing's so-called anti-secession law, which codifies the use of 'non-peaceful means' against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence," the president added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. URGED TO HEED ROC'S RIGHTS AND INTERESTS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By C.Y. Tseng and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Gambia's envoy to the United Nations urged the organization Friday to pay proper heed to the rights and interests of the Republic of China as well as the representation in the international community of the 23 million people of Taiwan.

Gambia's representative Crispin Grey-Johnson made the appeal while attending a press conference held by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York to explain the new proposals made by the ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs in its 13th bid to join the world body.

The press conference drew a lot of attention from local and international press, including CNN and the Deutsche Press-Agentur GmbH (DPA) . Jim Wurst, new chairman of the U.N. Correspondents Association, also attended the gathering.

According to ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chen Tan Sun, who launched the bid earlier in the day, Taiwan has decided to raise two proposals in its U.N. bid this year -- calling for the U.N. to address the representation of the 23 million people of Taiwan in the organization and asking the organization to play an active role in maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Pointing out that his country and other diplomatic allies of Taiwan have raised motions in the U.N. over the past years to request that the organization look after Taiwan's rights and interests without bias, the envoy said that they represent a voice of justice.

More than ten ROC diplomatic allies, including Gambia, filed a request with U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan Thursday to appoint a special envoy or delegation to look into the Taiwan Strait tensions.

Regardless of whether Beijing defines the "cross-strait peace issue" as an "internal affair" or an "international affair, " the threat it has posed to Taiwan is a fact, Grey-Johnson said, stressing that the U.N. should not turn a blind eye to such threats.

Meanwhile, Andrew L.Y. Hsia, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, said that although 94 U.N. members opposed the island's bid to become a U.N. member last year, most of them were in support of peaceful dialogue between the two sides of the strait.

This is why the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs suggested in its U.N. bid this year that under the premise of maintaining peace, the U.N. can focus on concerns from the international community over maintaining security in the Taiwan Strait, the director said.

He added that the organization should play a more active role in the issue of cross-strait peace following Beijing's passage earlier this year of an anti-secession law that has encountered opposition from various countries around the world.

Touching on the U.N.'s recent "absurd move" of replacing "the Republic of China" with "the People's Republic of China" on a document on the organization's founding on display at the U.N. headquarters, Hsieh said that those who know history know that the PRC did not even exist when the organization was founded.
Pointing out that the United Nations and the international community have no right to deny history, he said his office will lodge a strong protest against such conduct.
This year's U.N. General Assembly is slated to begin Sept. 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONCERT ORGANIZER DISCIPLINED FOR INVITING CHEN TO SING AT CONCERT

TEXT.P: A concert organizer was reportedly disciplined Saturday by the administration of the National Theater and Concert Hall in Taipei for inviting President Chen Shui-bian to sing at concert July 30.

In response to the report, Chen Wen-chung, director-general of the Presidential Office's department of public affairs, expressed regret at the outcome, saying that the office was not aware in advance of the regulations stipulating that all performing activities at the National Theater and Concert Hall be censored before being taken to the stage.

At the music concert held to commemorate the 100th birth anniversary of late Taiwanese composer Teng Yu-hsien, President Chen sang with concert performers a song composed by Teng, "Yearning of Spring, " under the organizer's warm invitation, as the performers got an encore.

The president's aid said he feels regret that the organizer failed to reach agreement with the concert hall administration regarding the invitation before the music event took place. Nevertheless, no one should be spared in respect to the regulations, not even the president himself, he noted.
The organizer, a private artistic organization, was reported to be banned from holding activities at the National Theater and Concert Hall in the Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center for three months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., JAPAN SURE TO DEFEND TAIWAN: SECURITY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The United States and Japan are sure to come to Taiwan's defense if the island is attacked by China, because Taiwan's security is their common objective, a security official said Saturday in Chiayi, southern Taiwan.

Parris Hsu-cheng Chang, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, told a group of civil leaders who attended a training program organized by the Ketagalan Institute that war with China is the last thing that Taiwan wants to see. However, he added that Taiwan would be able to put up significant resistance and inflict substantial damage on China in such a conflict.

Citing a joint statement issued by the United States and Japan on Feb. 19 which said the peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait is one of their common strategic objectives, Chang claimed this is a promise to defend Taiwan from an attack by China.
The strong international disapproval of the use of force to settle disputes between states is also a deterrent against Beijing pursuing any such military adventures, Chang said.

He said that China has therefore tried to isolate Taiwan in the international community while at the same time engaging in a charm offensive to win the hearts of the Taiwan people through such moves as offering duty-free access for the island's fruit exports.

However, Chang warned, such preferential treatment could have a price for Taiwan as China might ask for similar treatment under the framework of the World Trade Organization of which both Taiwan and China are members.

Meanwhile, Chang also raised doubts about China's capability to use force against Taiwan in light of the fact that China is plagued by domestic problems such as poverty, uneven distribution of wealth, and social unrest prompted by a lack of freedom and democracy.
The security official said Taiwan can turn the tables on Beijing by encouraging the Chinese people to push their government to move on the path toward democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CENTRAL STANDING COMMITTEE ELECTION CHANGES PROPOSED

TEXT.P: Many representatives of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) have proposed that members of the party's Central Standing Committee be directly elected by party representatives, according to a high-ranking official of the KMT.

Cho Po-yuan, a KMT legislative caucus whip, said that the KMT has seen its complete democratization, especially after its party chairmanship election last month, and that the different voices represent a normal situation in a democratic party.
In July's KMT chairmanship election, Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou soundly defeated Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng by garnering 72.4 percent of the vote.

Legislator Wu Yu-sheng, who is one of Ma's confidants, is also among those who support a change in the Central Standing Committee election process. Wu will present a proposal at the party's upcoming 17th congress scheduled for Aug. 19.

Wu and several other KMT legislators have proposed an amendment to the KMT charter, calling for two-stage elections, with the 1,600 party representatives choosing the 210 members of Central Committee in the first stage, and then electing the 31 members of the Central Standing Committee from the 210 elected Central Committee members in the second stage.
Currently, the KMT's Central Standing Committee members are chosen by the members of Central Committee among themselves.

According to the KMT charter, an amendment requires the endorsement of one-tenth of the party representatives and must obtain the support of two-thirds of the party representatives present at the congress to be passed.

It was reported that Ma's camp has encouraged many local government chiefs to vie for Central Standing Committee and Central Committee membership to diversify the make-up of the policy-making body which is now packed with lawmakers.
In response to the reports, Wu said that Ma is glad to see different voices in the policy-making organization and an increase in the pluralistic representation in the committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES U.N. TO HEED REPRESENTATION OF PEOPLE OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday urged United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan and all the U.N. member states to pay attention to the issue of the representation of the 23 million people of Taiwan as well as peace in the Taiwan Strait.
The president made the remarks during talks with visiting Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco de la Espriella at the Presidential Office.

President Chen expressed his appreciation for the Costa Rican government and people's long-term support of Taiwan, saying that President Pacheco has given his full support to Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization, the United Nations and other international organizations and that he has spoken up for Taiwan's cause several times in the U.N.

Chen also thanked Pacheco for coming to Taiwan to attend and deliver a speech at the inauguration of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) set for Sunday. The DPU, a brainchild of Vice President Annette Lu, aims to serve as a platform for personnel and resource exchanges around the Pacific Rim and to promote democracy, ensure peace and spread prosperity.
The inauguration of the DPU is especially significant because this is the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II, Chen said.

He also reaffirmed the will of the 23 million people of Taiwan to join the United Nations, saying that U.N. Resolution 2758, which gave the Republic of China's U.N. seat to the People's Republic of China, solved the question of the representation of the people of the PRC but not the representation of the people of Taiwan.

Under the principle of universality, which is enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations, Taiwan people should not be stripped of their right to be apart of the U.N., Chen said, adding that no other country can represent the people of Taiwan and that only the Taiwan people can represent themselves.

He also said that cross-strait peace is a major basis of cross-strait stability and world peace, and that the United Nations, as an organization that champions peace, should not ignore the 700 missiles deployed along China's coastal areas against Taiwan and Beijing's enactment in March of an anti-secession law that codifies the use of "non-peaceful means" against the island should it move toward formal independence.

As the U.N. General Assembly is scheduled to begin next month, he urged all U.N. members to heed the issue of cross-strait peace and that President Pacheco will continue to support Taiwan's bid to the U.N.

Pacheco earlier was accorded full military honors at a ceremony held in front of the National Theater Hall at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall. He received a 21-gun salute, and the two heads of state then inspected the honorary guards from the ROC's armed forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Oil price hike pushes inflation.
The international oil price hit a new record of US$67 per barrel Friday. The continuous oil price hike has caused worries about inflation. The government mulls to freeze gas and electricity prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT HOPES DPU TO SERVE AS A BRIDGE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu expressed the hope Saturday that the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) will serve as a platform that bridges the Eastern Pacific and Western Pacific and one that connects the Northern and Southern Hemispheres.

Lu made the remarks in a speech at a pre-inauguration meeting at the Grand Hotel in Taipei for the DPU, which is set to be formally inaugurated Sunday, the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II. Nicaraguan Vice President Jose Rizo Constellon was also on hand.
The DPU, a brainchild of Lu, aims to serve as a platform for exchanges around the Pacific Rim and to endorse democracy, peace, and prosperity as the common values for Pacific regional development.

Lu said that President Chen Shui-bian, Guatemalan President Ocar Berger Perdomo, Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco as well as dignitaries from other countries will attend the inauguration of the DPU Sunday. Three major seminars surrounding the themes of democracy, peace and prosperity will be held over the next two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 2ND IN E. ASIA IN HIGH-TECH PRODUCTS VALUE-ADDED RATE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's high technology products rank second in East Asia in terms of value-added rate, trailing only those of Japan, according to the latest report by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The four East Asian countries -- Japan, Taiwan, South Korea and China -- have been sparing no efforts to develop their information and communications industries since the late 1990s when a revolution in information and communications centered on the computer occurred, according to the CEPD report.

Since August 2000, Taiwan has been making efforts in various areas, such as infrastructure, manpower supply and governmental administration, to build an environment for a "knowledge-based economy" on the island as part of the country's preparations for future economic development in the era of the "new economy" in which the information and communications sectors will serve as one of the key pillars.
The report said that in the information and communications technological race among Taiwan and its neighbors, the winner will be the one that produces the most high value-added high-technology goods.

It cited the Japanese Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry's latest report on the international economy and trade as saying that the four East Asian countries have witnessed obvious changes in terms of their respective single-item price indexes (single-item price of exports divided by that of imports) for high-tech products in the 1995-2003 period.

According to the Japanese ministry's report, the value-added rate of Japan's high-tech products was the highest among the four East Asian countries. The ratio of its high-tech products with a single-item price index greater than 1 grew to 65.6 percent in 2003 from 58.6 percent in 1995.

In Taiwan, the figure increased from 20.4 percent in 1995 to 27.2 percent in 2003, while the figure for South Korea dropped from 25.7 percent to 24.7 percent and that for China declined from 37.9 percent to 24.2 percent.
These numbers show that Taiwan's efforts to raise its industrial technological level have borne fruit, CEPD officials said.

However, they noted that the growth of Taiwan's information and communications output has been slowing in recent years as the island faces strong competition from countries like China and India, whose production costs are relatively low and whose technological growth rates are high.

The CEPD officials suggested that the government encourage local manufacturers to step up their efforts in research and development capabilities and to create independent brand names to increase the competitiveness of their exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA CHIEF: MEDIA IS SPOILING GOVERNMENT'S PLAN ON FRUIT EXPORTS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) official said Saturday that the government has made no mistake in its handling of Taiwan fruit exports to China but the media is spoiling the government's plan.

TAITRA Chairman Hsu Chih-jen made the remarks at a forum on exports of agricultural products to China organized by the Ketagalan Institute, an institute founded by President Chen Shui-bian to cultivate future leaders of the country.
In response to the media's criticism that the government has been blocking Taiwan fruit exports to China, Hsu said he has seen no farmers being impeded from exporting fruits to the mainland.

Domestic farmers are eager to introduce their fruits to the mainland to cash in on the trade opportunities offered by the Chinese government, which announced in May that it would grant tariff-free treatment to 15 categories of Taiwan fruits.

Stressing that the Taiwan government has not impeded fruit exports to China, Hsu said the government has only cautioned farmers that the sale of their fruits in the mainland may bear risks, such as false advertising of agricultural products from uncertain sources as being grown in Taiwan as well as demands by Beijing for agricultural technology cooperation with Taiwan or reciprocal preferential treatment for mainland agricultural exports to the island.

Taiwan authorities have yet to engage in formal talks with Beijing regarding Taiwan fruit exports to China, arguing that the Chinese government has given no clear indication on whether it will talk with TAITRA, the sole organization designated by the DPP government to negotiate with Beijing on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HOPES FOR EARLY OPENING OF NEXT LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) caucus in the Legislative Yuan on Saturday expressed the hope for an early opening of the next legislative session.

Tseng Yuan-chuan, KMT legislator and executive director of the party's Policy Committee, made the remarks as Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng is scheduled to convene an inter-party consultation meeting next week to decide on the opening day of the next session after a request by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to convene a special session during the summer recess was voted down by the legislature Friday.

Tseng said that even before the vote, the KMT caucus had advocated that legislators report for the next session on Sept. 1 or Sept. 2 and that the legislature invite Premier Frank Hsieh to give an administrative report and answer questions Sept. 6. He added that after that, lawmakers can choose one day every two weeks to review bills.

Tseng said that a draft bill on the organic law of the National Communications Commission (NCC) is a prioritized bill and that legislators should vote on the bill after the Sept. 25 deadline for inter-party consultations.

He said that the NT$48 billion (US$1.52 billion) special budget for the arms procurement plan as well as the confirmation of Control Yuan members, which the DPP deems as prioritized bills, can wait until late September for review.
The legislators usually report to the legislature in early September and then usually open the regular session in mid to late September, barring major issues that require immediate attention.

William Lai, a DPP caucus whip in the legislature, said that the DPP supports an early opening of the next session and full-house meetings to review bills. However, he added that the door to inter-party consultations and procedure committee should be open, otherwise, the KMT's proposed early opening will only serve to cushion the public criticism of its opposition to a special session.
Lai said that the opening day of the next session can be left for the KMT and its ally People First Party to decide.
However, a caucus whip of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the DPP, said the opening day should be Sept. 13.

Ho Min-hao said that the legislature usually opens in late September, and the KMT's proposal of opening on Sept. 6 is an attempt to cover the "scandal" it created in vetoing the request for a special session, adding: "Why should we have to toe the KMT's line every time?"

Ho also said that after the opening of the next session, four priority bills should be reviewed -- namely the flood-control project, major arms procurement package, confirmation of Control Yuan members, and the proposed amendments to the Executive Yuan Organic Law -- expressing the hope that the KMT and the PFP will not boycott them.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MRT SET TO WELCOME 2 BILLIONTH PASSENGER

TEXT.P: The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) held a series of celebrations Saturday at the Tamsui MRT Station to mark the system's two billionth passenger expected some time next week.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou noted that the mass rapid transit system has become an important part of daily life for citizens of both Taipei City and Taipei County, expressing the hope that construction on the MRT lines connecting Taipei County can be completed soon for the welfare of the citizens.

According to Ma, when he assumed his post seven years ago, the MRT had 190,000 passengers daily, with the figure now standing at an average of 970,000 passengers per day and rising to 1.1 million on Fridays.
Ma noted that the total length of the MRT network will be extended from the current 69 kilometers to 130 kilometers within seven years, with daily passenger capacity reaching 2.3 million.

Noting that Taipei's MRT system ranks with those of cities in advanced countries, Ma said he hopes the TRTC can further improve the system by reducing the frequency of accidents, shortening the waiting time for trains and improving access for bicycles.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO STEP UP EDUCATIONAL CAMPAIGN ON FRUIT EXPORTS TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Lee Chin-lung said Saturday that in addition to consultations with China on Taiwan fruit exports, the council will also diversify export markets, and step up an educational campaign aimed at farmers and the media.

Lee made the remarks while attending a seminar on Taiwan's agricultural exports to China sponsored by the Ketagalan Academy, a school founded by President Chen Shui-bian to nurture future leaders of the nation. Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng, Taiwan External Trade Development Council Chairman Hsu Chih-jen and Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-dji also attended the seminar.

Lee noted that a few media reports have said the government's "impeding of" fruit exports to China demonstrates that it is not taking care of farmers, but he stressed that the allegation is "unfounded."

He noted that some media have also said that Taiwan's increased fruit exports to China have led to price hikes of domestic fruits, but he pointed out that the truth is that the number of fruit exports to China is limited and that the main cause of increased prices at home is decreased production.

He said that although China announced zero-tariff treatment for 15 categories of Taiwan fruits Aug. 1, nine of those categories already see major imports from Southeast Asian countries, and several other categories, such as peaches and persimmon, are not produced in large quantities in Taiwan.

Lee said that Taiwan exported 32 tons of fruits between Aug. 1 and Aug. 10 to China, and it is estimated that monthly exports to China will be around 96 tons, or only around 10 tons more than before the duty-free measures were implemented.
The benefits of zero-tariff policy are limited, Lee said, saying that the main beneficiaries will be Chinese consumers and that Taiwan farmers will not see any significant increase in revenues.

Lee said that the measures may have negative consequences, including overreliance on the Chinese market and demands by Beijing for reciprocal treatment for its agricultural products. If cheap agricultural produce from China is exported to Taiwan, this will have a very detrimental impact on the production and distribution of Taiwan's agricultural produce, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LU ELECTED TO CHAIR DEMOCRATIC PACIFIC UNION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu was elected Saturday to chair the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , an international organization initiated by Lu herself which will be officially established in Taipei Sunday.
Lu described her election as a milestone in Taiwan's diplomatic history.

Under the union's platform, the chairperson is authorized to form the DPU secretariat, whose headquarters will be located in Taipei. An announcement on the person to head the facility will be made Sunday, according to the DPU.

Besides Lu, three vice chairmen were also elected to oversee the union's operations in the American, Asian and South Pacific regions. They are Dr. Muladi of Indonesia's Habibie Center, Canadian Senator Mac Harb, and Ian Sinclair of the Australia-Taiwan Business Council.

The DPU inaugural meeting kicked off Saturday at Taipei's Grand Hotel and will run through Monday. Over 70 guests from 26 DPU member states are attending the three-day event to witness the new organization's establishment and to exchange opinions regarding the development of democracy, peace, and prosperity.
Guests include the presidents of Costa Rica, Guatemala, Nicaragua and Palau, as well as high ranking government officials, professionals, academics, and representatives of major NGOs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA NOT CONTROLLED BY GOVERNMENT: GIO HEAD

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao said Saturday that the media is not controlled by the government, claiming that fierce competition for ratings, the personal preferences of media business owners and several other factors influence the independence of the media.
Yao made the remarks in a speech delivered on the second day of the 2005 National Youth Conference meeting at the Chinese Culture University organized by the National Youth Commission.
In his speech on the media and culture, Yao presented many ideas on how to improve the quality of the media.

Yao revealed that when the GIO has come under strong criticism from the public for refusing to renew the operating licenses of seven cable TV stations, he tried to solicit the support of several women's groups and lawmakers who had criticized the "chaos" in the media and had called for decrease in numbers of media outlets. However, they chose not to stand up for a variety of reasons, Yao added.

Citing several examples of journalists' stories being "edited" beyond recognition by their supervisors according to the supervisors' political bias, Yao urged the "first-line reporters" to unite in insisting on high standards of journalistic professionalism.

Yao's remarks were echoed by Lu Tung-hsi, chairman of the Association of Taiwan Journalists, who said that journalists will only be respected by the public when they establish professionalism in news coverage.

Los Angeles Times: Bush Says Iraq Exit Timetable Is "Speculation"
President Bush on Thursday dismissed as "speculation" recent statement by senior U.S. generals in Iraq that the Pentagon could begin withdrawing troops by spring, saying that an exit timetable would be based solely on political and military progress.
