DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 14, or the tenth day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1811: The British occupy Java.
1811: Paraguay proclaims independence from Spain.
1900: Forces of eight powers -- Britain, Japan, the United States, Germany, Russia, France, Austria and Italy -- march from Tientsin and scale the walls of Beijing, relieving the foreign legation besieged there since the start of the Boxer Uprising two months earlier.
1917: The Beijing government declares war on Germany and Austro-Hungary.
1937: The Republic of China Air Force shoots down nine of 18 Japanese aircraft which are bombing Hangchow, capital of Chekiang Province in eastern China.
1945: Japan surrenders unconditionally, ending World War II.
1945: The Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance is signed in Moscow.
1945: Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek invites Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong to come to Chungking for a conference.
1947: Pakistan gains independence from Britain.
1949: Konrad Adenauer becomes the first chancellor of West Germany.
1951: Randolph W. Hearst, the newspaper publisher known as the king of America's "yellow press," dies at the age of 88. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire comprising 28 major newspapers.
1951: Seamen aboard the Ta Han, a 2,000-ton mainland Chinese freighter, defect to Taiwan, sailing their ship to the port of Kaohsiung.
1958: The ROC Air Force shoots down three Communist Chinese MiG-17s over Matsu.
1958: The United States decides to maintain an embargo on trade with Communist China, North Korea and North Vietnam, despite NATO's announcement of a relaxation of trade restrictions with the Soviet bloc and Communist China.
1971: Ground for the construction of Taiwan's north-south freeway is broken near Linkou.
1973: Over 300 Chinese and foreign computer scientists meet at the Academia Sinica for the First International Symposium on Computers.
1974: The Taipei Century Symphony Orchestra leaves for the United States on a three-week goodwill tour.
1977: The ROC Air Force celebrates the 40th anniversary of its victory over the Japanese at Hangchow, with Gen. Szetu Fu presiding.
1979: Wang Yun-wu, senior advisor to the president of the Republic of China, dies of heart failure at Veterans General Hospital at the age of 92.
1980: More than 360 scholars from home and abroad take part in the International Conference on Sinology at the Academia Sinica.
1985: The ROC Executive Yuan issues a report on the investigation of official administrative responsibilities regarding the 10th Credit Cooperative scandal. Fifteen financial officials are reprimanded, given demerits or dismissed.
1988: Major racial conflict breaks out in the African country of Burundi, with more than 24,000 people being killed in the conflict.
1999: The United States defeats Chinese-Taipei 10-9 to win the 18th International Baseball Association Big League Championship in Kaohsiung.
2000: Premier Tang Fei instructs the Ministry of Justice to review and revise relevant laws and regulations so as to enable the government to effectively crack down on the types of crimes that are increasingly harming Taiwan society.
2001: Former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias Sanchez, a 1987 Nobel Peace Prize winner, says in Kinmen that Taiwan and mainland China should engage in dialogue to ease the tension across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who intuitively apprehends truth is one who, without effort, hits what is right, and without thinking understands what he wants to know; whose life is easily and naturally in harmony with the moral law. Such a one is what we call a saint or a man of divine nature."

NEW YORK (AFP) -- Oil futures surpassed a record 67 dollars a barrel in New York Friday to extend a startling rally fueled by massive global demand and production problems at strained refineries, dealers said.

WITH CRUDE oil prices gushing to higher peaks almost every day in the world market, Malacanang is dimming its lights and shutting off its air-conditioning system early.

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Redistricting Back on Ballot. The California Supreme Court handed Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger a major victory Friday, Putting back on the Nov. 8 ballot his initiative to change how legislative district lines are drawn.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIGITAL CENTERS HELP GET QUAKE-AFFECTED AREAS WIRED

TEXT.P: Eight "digital opportunity centers" established in four counties that were hardest hit by the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake are contributing to narrowing the digital gap between recovering rural townships and urban areas, Vice Education Minister Fan Sun-lu said Sunday.

Fan, who visited two of the eight digital centers recently on a fact-finding tour, said that some residents have turned from "computer illiterates" into electronic literates who can even design their own Web pages.

After the devastating earthquake, which killed nearly 2,400 people and damaged numerous cities and townships in central Taiwan, the Ministry of Education, with financing from the Executive Yuan, established the digital centers in the rural townships in Miaoli, Taichung, Chiayi and Nantou counties.

Fan and Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), visited the Chingyun community in Hsinyi rural township in Nantou County, and the Meilin community in Kuohsing rural township, also in Nantou County, to check out how the locals have been using the digital centers to learn how to use computers and related applications.

The centers began with training volunteers and "seed" computer teachers, who then taught the local residents -- mostly Bunun aboriginal people in the Chingyun community and Han farmers in the Meilin community -- about computer and Internet skills, Fan said.
The residents learn basic computer skills, e-commerce and Web applications, free of charge.
According to Chen, with the help of computers, farmers in the Meilin community are marketing the area's specialty -- lemon grass oil and related products -- to other cities and even abroad.

Noting that the digital divide is one of the factors affecting a nation's international competitiveness, Chen said the CLA provides information technology training to some 10,000 blue-color workers each year in an attempt to narrow the digital gap and raise Taiwan's overall competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO IMMEDIATE PLANS TO RAISE GASOLINE PRICES: CPC

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said Sunday it does not have any immediate plans to raise gasoline prices, despite the recent dramatic international crude oil hikes.

CPC President Chen Pao-lang made the remarks in response to media speculation that the state-run oil company might raise its oil product prices again as international crude oil prices have surged to new highs since CPC raised its gasoline and diesel prices by NT$1.5 per liter Aug. 2.

"The reports were untrue. Even though the recent fast surge in crude oil prices has exacted great pressure on our production costs, we won't adjust our product prices again for the time being, " Chen said.

According to Chen, CPC imports an average of 16 million barrels of crude oil per month. Therefore, whenever international crude oil prices rise by US$1 a barrel, CPC's monthly procurement cost soars by US$16 million, or NT$500 million.

When CPC raised its gasoline and diesel prices Aug.2, the average international crude oil price was about US$60 a barrel. As of Friday, crude oil prices had skyrocketed to US$67. CPC's procurement costs have thus increased by more than NT$3 billion.

Chen said CPC incurred a loss of NT$3.7 billion from its oil product trade in July. The Aug. 2 adjustment was upset when international crude prices reached US$63 per barrel, Chen said, adding that the dramatic price increases in the last few days was like "rubbing salt into a wound" and will make CPC's oil product trade deficit deteriorate further.

As CPC is a state-owned enterprise, Chen said, its top priority should be taking good care of people's livelihoods rather than making money. For the sake of maintaining domestic consumer price stability, Chen said, CPC is not expected to come up with any proposal to raise gasoline prices at the moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY TO USHER PACIFIC RIM COUNTRIES INTO BETTER FUTURE

TEXT.P: Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo stressed the significance of democracy Sunday, claiming that democratization will help create jobs and equally distribute wealth, eventually ushering the Pacific Rim countries into a better future.

Addressing the inauguration of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) -- a non-governmental organization designed to serve as a platform for exchanges among the Pacific Rim countries in the promotion of democracy, peace and prosperity and other common values -- Berger offered his admiration for Taiwan for its achievements and stressed the importance of democratization for all countries.

Berger said democratization should be a paradigm for all governments to emulate and that all countries should strive to build democratic political systems to allow the people to take part in policy making.
Only when the people can participate in the formation and execution of national policies can political rulers perceive what the people want and don't want, Berger said.
Based on this concept, Berger said, the Guatemalan government chose to be a member of the DPU Preparatory Conference that helped pave the way for the establishment of the DPU.

All the DPU members are democracy and peace-loving countries who believe cooperation is better than confrontation and who engage in cooperation based on a framework of freedom and democracy, Berger said.

He praised the Republic of China government -- which established the DPU and advocates DPU values -- for its outstanding performance in efforts to create jobs, end illiteracy and build Taiwan into a multicultural society, which he claimed makes the country a role model for all DPU member countries.

The Guatemalan president was one of the heads of state who delivered speeches at the DPU inauguration ceremony in which governmental and political delegates from 26 countries around the Pacific Rim took part.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMEN HAD FIRST BIRTH AT 27.4 YEARS OF AGE IN 2004: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's women gave birth for the first time at an average age of 27.4 years in 2004, up by 1.5 years compared with the 1994 average, according to the latest statistics released by the government Sunday.

The tallies compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that 37.5 percent of the women who gave birth last year were aged between 25-29, followed by 27.8 percent aged from 30 to 34.

Compared with the level recorded 10 years ago, the birth rate posted by the 25-29 age group was down by 4.8 percentage points compared with the level of a decade ago. Meanwhile, women over the age of 30 accounted for more births, an indication, according to DGBAS officials, that women in Taiwan are increasingly having their first child at an older age and fewer children overall.

According to the same statistics, women in the 30-34 and 35-39 age groups registered increase rates of 4.6 percentage points and 3.6 percentage points in their respective birth rates over the 1994 levels, while those above 40 posted a birth rate of 1.2 percent, a growth of 0.7 percentage points.
Last year, there were a total of 218,000 newborns, a majority of 52 percent of whom were the first child, with 36 percent and 12 percent as the second and third children, respectively.

According to a survey by the U. S. Bureau of the Census on the global population, child-bearing women around the world had 2.8 children on average last year, with those in developed countries averaging 1.6 -- still higher than Taiwan's 1.2, which was lower than Hong Kong's 0.9 but at a similar level to those of Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT WARNS OF CHINA THREAT IN PACIFIC AT DPU OPENING

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called Sunday for democracy, peace and prosperity in the Pacific Rim and for building the region into a "blue bridge" linking east and west, north and south.

Lu issued the call at the opening ceremony of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU), her brainchild since 2001, which is designed to serve as a quasi-government-to-government organization and comprises 26 member states, including the United States, Canada, Japan, South Korea and various Republic of China diplomatic allies in Central America and the Pacific to advocate democracy, peace and prosperity in the region.

Noting that World War Two -- the most devastating war in human history -- officially ended on that day 60 years ago after Japan surrendered to the Allies, Lu warned that China is threatening not just Taiwan but every corner of the Pacific region with its fast-growing military expansion -- one of the remnants of the Cold War despite globalization and the information revolution which have led to economic prosperity in the Pacific.

As the Pacific covers one-third of the earth's surface and is home to the 40 percent of the world's population in 30 countries, the ocean has become the most important lifeline for mankind and the region's security, stability and prosperity is of extremely vital importance to the entire world, she said.

She expressed the hope that the peace-loving leaders of the Pacific Rim countries will reflect on past errors made by mankind and join forces in building a bright future for the region through what she called a "soft-powered Pacific" featuring the DPU's three core values in the 21st Century.

President Chen Shui-bian, along with Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo and Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco, as well as the vice presidents of Nicaragua and Palau, also took part in the ceremony in Taipei. Other foreign dignities included parliamentarians and representatives from academic and non-governmental organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICAN PRESIDENT URGES COOPERATION FOR SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco de la Espriella said Sunday that Costa Rica fully supports the founding of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) to create societies of peace, freedom and prosperity under collective cooperation.

Addressing delegates from 26 Pacific Rim countries at the inauguration ceremony of the DPU in Taipei, Pacheco said Costa Rica, a staunch supporter and a diplomatic ally of the Republic of China, supports the DPU's goals.

The DPU, initiated by Vice President Annette Lu, aims at treasuring and conserving natural resources; creating environments for sustainable development for generations to come; preventing ocean resources from being abused or poached; spreading the concept that the Pacific's natural resources should be shared; eradicating poverty, confrontation and military threats; and helping create multicultural societies under equality and justice in the region, Pacheco said.

The DPU inauguration ceremony -- held on the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II -- called together government and political leaders from 26 countries around the Pacific Rim, including the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Mexico, Honduras, Guatemala, El Salvador, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru, Chile, Russia, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, East Timor, Marshal Islands, Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Kiribati, Palau and Taiwan.

Three heads of states -- President Chen Shui-bian, Pacheco and Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo -- and other political leaders, including DPU founder Lu, delivered speeches at the inauguration ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO FORM SPECIAL PANEL TO ADDRESS FUTURE WATER CRISES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will form a special panel to facilitate coordination in the event of future water supply crises, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Sunday.

Ho made the remarks after presiding over a meeting to review the recent water supply problem in the northern county of Taoyuan, where residents suffered many days of water shortages after Typhoon Matsa brought torrential rain, silt and debris into the Shihmen reservoir -- the county's main drinking water supply source -- increasing turbidity to the point that filtration systems were unable to cope.

To prevent future recurrences, Ho said, the panel will be charged with coordinating relevant government agencies to tackle future water supply problems in the wake of typhoons or other natural disasters.
The panel will be headed by a vice minister of economic affairs, with the heads of the Water Resources Agency and state-run Taiwan Water Corp. as key members, Ho said.

"In the future, the panel must strengthen contacts and coordination among relevant government agencies at all levels in addressing water supply problems amid typhoons or other disasters, " Ho said, adding that the panel will be required to draft a comprehensive package of measures to improve handling of post-disaster water supply crises.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-PFP INTERACTION KEY TO 'PAN BLUE' CONSOLIDATION: OBSERVERS

TEXT.P: With opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou slated to take the helm as the party boss next week, interaction between the KMT and its ally the People First Party (PFP) in the legislature will be the benchmark for future consolidation of the "pan blue alliance," observers said Sunday.

The role of Legislative Speaker Wang Jing-pyng, a KMT vice chairman who was favored by PFP Chairman James Soong but who was defeated by Ma in the KMT chairmanship race, will be the key gauge in KMT-PFP cooperation, political watchers said.

As various disputed and urgent bills are waiting to be screened in the next legislative session that will open in September, it will be worth watching how Wang and Soong exercise their leverage in the legislature amid strong pressure from the "pan green alliance" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union to approve the key bills, they said.

As Wang has repeatedly made clear that he will not continue to serve as a KMT vice chairman after Ma takes over the party helm from outgoing Chairman Lien Chan Aug. 19, he will be the KMT's central figure in cooperating with the PFP in the legislature, they explained.

At the same time, it will be a big test of Soong's political acumen, as he and Ma overlap a great deal in the "pan blue" voting base, setting the stage for strong competition between the two men that will be underscored as the December city and county chief elections approach, the observers pointed out.

Although it remains unclear whether the two parties will keep collaborating in the next legislative session, KMT legislative whip Cho Po-yuan said that he is very optimistic that the two parties will continue to do so, citing their shared ideology and political stance in terms of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
PFP legislative whip Huang Yih-jiau echoed Cho's view, stressing that the two parties share common ground on cross-strait issues and their anti-Taiwan independence stance.

Their remarks might upset President Chen Shui-bian, who said several times prior to the KMT chairman election that he was hoping for better ties between the ruling and opposition camps with the leadership change in the KMT, to help push through controversial bills on a major arms procurement plan, the approval of a presidential nomination list of Control Yuan members and a flood-control project, they said.
The KMT and the PFP collaborated again last week in the vetoing of a proposal to hold an extra legislative session to discuss the various key bills during the current summer recess.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT WILL RECOVER FROM EYE DISCOMFORT: DOCTORS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu, who received treatment for her recurring dry eye syndrome Sunday, will recover soon, according to a medical team of the National University Hospital.
Lu left the venue of the inaugural meeting of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) that afternoon to have her eyes examined after complaining about being over-sensitive to light.

Chen Yao-chang, who led the team of doctors who treated Lu, explained that photographers' flashlights had caused Lu's dry eye syndrome to recur. He said the vice president is expected to recover soon and that she can continue to participate in the DPU activities Monday as scheduled.

Despite her discomfort, Lu spent Sunday morning presiding over the inaugural ceremony of the DPU, which was founded upon her initiative. However, when introducing the delegates from 26 countries in her capacity as host, she was seen wearing a pair of dark glasses.

She continued to receive DPU delegates and parliamentarians from the United States, Australia and South Korea early Sunday afternoon in a dimly lit room before going to the hospital to have her eyes treated.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER SAYS NO TO ANOTHER PRICE HIKE BY CPC

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Ho Mei-yueh said Sunday that she would not support the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) to increase its gasoline and diesel fuel prices again after CPC had already made an adjustment early this month.

Ho said the recent fluctuations in oil prices were due to the same factors that triggered the price hike in early August, and that she does not believe the CPC should adjust the fuel prices twice because of the same factors.
As the international oil price broke US$67 per barrel, there was speculation that the CPC might raise its fuel prices again.

The economics minister said that although rising international oil price has caused the CPC's cost of purchase to go up, she still does not believe the CPC should raise its fuel prices, even if Formosa Petrochemical Corp. (PFC) readjusts its wholesale prices.

On Aug. 2, the FPC increased its gasoline and diesel fuel prices by NT$1.5 per liter, with the CPC following suit hours later by adding also NT$1.5 per liter to the two kinds of fuel, representing a 7.6 percent increase, the highest in the past decade.

Ho said that information in her possession shows the recent wave of oil price hikes would not persist and that most of the forecasts also say the international oil price is unlikely to have another big increase.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'GREAT LOVE' AWARDS HONOR EXTRAORDINARY PARENTS, GRANDPARENTS

TEXT.P: Ten local families were cited Sunday for volunteering their services for needy people in addition to caring for their own disabled children.
It is the eighth consecutive year that the Chinese Mercy Love Association has organized the Great Love Awards in recognition of the parents of physically or mentally challenged children.
A total of 32 families were recommended by city or county governments and social welfare groups around the country to take part in the contest.

The award winners were either parents or grandparents of children with serious physical disabilities or rare diseases. They have given their youngsters endless love and attentive care, and all of them have struggled to ensure that their children receive normal opportunities to study and learn skills. More admiringly, they take time out of their busy schedules and heavy workloads to volunteer their services for other people.

The oldest recipient was Hou-Chen Chao-se, an 80-year-old woman from a rural township in the southern county of Chiayi who has assisted her eldest child Hou Cheng-ping in overcoming his physical disability and psychological despair.

Hou Cheng-ping became paralyzed from the waist down after an accidental fall 37 years ago. Under her mother's concentrating care and passionate encouragement, Hou Cheng-ping went out of the abyss of despair and learned vocational skills. In 1995, he formed an association of people of spinal injuries in Chiayi to help the handicapped to enter mainstream society.

Also cited was Wen Chien-ling, a 70-year-old woman who has over the past 18 years cared for her granddaughter Wen Hsiao-yun, a victim of congenital cerebral palsy. Wen has assumed the duty of caring for Hsiao-yun since her birth so that Hsiao-yun's parents can continue their careers. When Hsiao-yun finally could enter an elementary school, Wen carried her granddaughter to school piggyback everyday and waited outside the classroom to offer Hsiao-yun timely help. Over the years, Wen also volunteered her services at the school, assisting in handling student affairs and offered counseling for other parents with physically or mentally challenged kids.

The award recipient also included a couple -- Wu Chin-hui and Chou Li-ling -- both of whose two children are victims of an incurable rare ailment known as Niemann-Pick Disease. The couple have turned their grief into strength. For years, they have taken their children to see doctors periodically for medication and examination. They have even accompanied their children to West Africa to take part in charitable activities for helping impoverished African children. By so doing, the couple said they hope their children can learn to love and treasure life.

The Niemann-Pick Disease refers to a group of inherited metabolic disorders known as the leukodystrophies whose symptoms include a lack of muscle coordination, brain degeneration and learning problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPU EXPECTED TO PUSH FOR PACIFIC COMMON MARKET: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday he looks forward to the day when a new Pacific balance of power based on a balanced relationship across the Taiwan Strait is accomplished.
Chen made the remarks in a speech delivered at a luncheon in honor of delegates to the inaugural conference of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) at Grand Hotel in Taipei.

To realize that goal, Chen said the DPU is expected to promote the signing of free trade agreements and the creation of customs alliance and the Pacific common market among Pacific Rim countries as well as push for the convening of DPU leadership meeting.

As a peace promoter, Chen said he is well aware of the world expectation that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait peacefully resolve their disputes. Therefore, he said, Taiwan is actively seeking international support for the establishment of a new cross-strait balance of power that can buttress Taiwan's democracy and sustain cross-strait peace.
He also suggested that the DPU help promote the establishment of a new Pacific balance of power on the basis of a new cross-strait balance of power.

In the process, Chen said, the DPU can play the role of "connector" to link up Pacific east and west coasts, eliminate geographic barriers and step up Pacific cultural renaissance through increased political, economic, social and cultural exchanges.

The DPU can also help integrate North and South Pacific economy and narrow economic gaps by forging free trade agreements, customs alliance and a Pacific common market, Chen said, adding that such efforts will contribute to the upgrading of living standards throughout the Pacific Rim.

Moreover, Chen said, the DPU is expected to play the role of "accelerator, " helping promote globalization, narrow the digital technology gap, boost information-technology education and establish an environment for fair competition.

In the years ahead, Chen sad the DPU can learn from the experiences of the European Union to reinforce cooperation among its member countries by setting up various regional development funds and assisting member states in pursuing balanced and sustainable development.

The DPU, initiated by Vice President Annette Lu, is comprised of 26 member countries, including the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Mexico, Honduras, Guatemala, El Salvador, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru, Chile, Russia, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, East Timor, Marshal Islands, Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Kiribati, Palau and Taiwan.
The non-governmental organization will serve as a platform for exchanges among the Pacific Rim countries in the promotion of their common ideals.
More than 500 delegates from 26 member states attended the inaugural conference held at Grand Hotel in the morning. Notably absent from the meeting were China and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICAN PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco de la Espriella signed a joint communique Sunday, reaffirming their commitment to further promoting exchanges and cooperation between the two countries.
The joint communique was signed prior to a state dinner hosted by Chen at West Lake Resort Hotel in Miaoli County in northern Taiwan in horno of Pacheco.

Chen and Pacheco said in the join communique that the Republic of China and Costa Rica will further expand cooperation in medical service, health care, education, technological and economic development based on their 60-year friendship.
The two leaders also expressed their common hope that the two countries will begin negotiations for the signing of a free trade agreement to boost bilateral trade and economic cooperation.

Pacheco, who arrived in Taipei Friday for a state visit, attended the inaugural ceremony for the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) earlier in the day. The DPU groups 26 Pacific Rim countries to promote regional peace, freedom, democracy and prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 15, or the 11th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1057: Macbeth, King of Scotland who ascended to the throne after killing his cousin King Duncan in battle in 1040, is killed by Duncan's son Malcolm at Lumphanan, near Aberdeen. The legend of his rise to power and his reign are the basis of Shakespeare's tragedy "Macbeth."
1769: Napoleon Bonaparte, military leader and the emperor of France from 1804 to 1815, is born in Ajaccio, Corsica.
1900: The Kuang Hsu Emperor and his aunt, the Empress Dowager Tzu-hsi, flee to northwestern China from Beijing as the capital is captured by the forces of eight foreign powers during the Boxer Uprising.
1914: The 82-km-long Panama Canal, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, is opened after 35 years of construction.
1945: The Republic of China Legislative Yuan unanimously approves the United Nations Charter.
1947: India gains independence from Britain with Jawaharlal Nehru as the first prime minister.
1948: President Syngman Rhee formally proclaims South Korea as the Republic of Korea.
1949: A Southeast China Governor's Office is established in Taipei with Gen. Chen Cheng as governor.
1959: The ROC Army receives Nike-Hercules surface-to-air missiles from the United States under a military aid program.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan rules that, according to Article 77 of the ROC Constitution, courts of all levels shall be placed under the jurisdiction of the Judicial Yuan.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes the Congo (Brazzaville) Republic.
1962: The Netherlands signs a treaty agreeing to Indonesian rule of Irian Jaya (Netherlands New Guinea).
1967: Kung Hsiang-hsi, former ROC premier and finance minister, dies in the United States at the age of 88.
1974: South Korean President Park Chung Hee's wife is shot dead by an assassin in an attempt on Park's life.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo urges college students to contribute their wisdom and energy to the country as he presides over the closing ceremony of the summer vacation military training program of college students at the Cheng-kung base in Taichung.
1979: Direct dialing service to the United States, Hong Kong and Singapore is initiated by the Taiwan Telecommunications Administration.
1980: The wreckage of the Titanic, the British luxury liner which sank after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York on April 14, 1912, is found laying on the ocean floor 3,657 meters below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean.
1981: The First ROC-Indian Cultural and Economic Seminar on India's 34th Independence Day is held in Taipei.
1981: The Republic of China and Saint Vincent establish formal diplomatic relations.
1985: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa accepts the resignation of Finance Minister Loh Jen-kong.
1986: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa, in an interview with Saudi Arabian journalists from the Okaz Daily and Al-Bilad Daily, points out that the achievements of the ROC over the past thirty-odd years has won the nation international recognition and made it an indispensable force against communist expansion in the Asia-Pacific region.
1990: President Mikhail Gorbachev restores Soviet citizenship to Nobel Prize-winning author Alexander Solshenitsyn, who was exiled to the West in 1974 for his novels attacking Stalinism.
1995: The Chinese mainland begins eleven days of tactical guided missile exercises by firing live artillery shells into the sea 136 kilometers north of Taiwan.
1999: Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Commission, donates US$100,000 and 20 computers to the Chinese Benevolent Federation in San Francisco.
2000: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture announces that beef imports from Argentina and Paraguay will be temporarily banned due to an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in the two South American countries.
2001: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party formally establishes the Taiwan-Japan Goodwill Association to further bolster bilateral ties between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who acquires truth is one who finds out what is good and holds fast to it."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIWAN 'COMFORT WOMEN' RENEW PROTEST AGAINST JAPAN

TEXT.P: A group of women's rights activists and former "comfort women" who were forced into sexual slavery by Japanese troops in World War II renewed their protest against Japan by staging a march and roadside skits Monday, the 60th anniversary of the end of the war.

Several aged and frail former "comfort women, " accompanied by activists from the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, lodged a protest in front of the Interchange Association, Taipei Office -- the de facto Japanese embassy in Taiwan -- demanding a speedy public apology from the Japanese government.
The group also demanded that the Japanese government give the former Taiwanese "comfort women" reasonable compensation for the suffering they endured during the war.

A foundation spokeswoman said that although most ordinary Taiwanese people are over the bad memories of World War II, these surviving "comfort women" are still living with nightmares of what they had experienced during the war.
The spokeswoman said that "the frail ladies pulled themselves together to take part in the protest for the pursuit of belated justice and Japan's facing of its responsibility.

She said that similar protest activities were being launched simultaneously in South Korea, Indonesia, the Philippines and Germany Monday to demand that the Japanese government admit Japan's wrongs, apologize and pay compensation.

According to statistics, some 20,000 women were used as sex slaves by the Japanese military during World War II, most of whom came from China, Taiwan, South Korea, the Philippines and other Asian countries. Some 2,000 came from Taiwan.
The Japanese government has consistently refused to apologize to the "comfort women."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA POSES THREAT TO TAIWAN, U.S., JAPAN: FORMER U.S. LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A former leader of the U.S. House of Representatives said Sunday that China has become a world power and poses a threat to Japan, Taiwan and the United States, calling for other nations to work together to promote world peace and face the Chinese threat through the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU).

Benjamin Gilman, former chairman of the Committee on International Relations of the House of Representatives, made the remarks while addressing a forum, held at the Grand Hotel following the inauguration of the DPU earlier in the day, to discuss issues related to peace and democracy.

The DPU, initiated by Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu, is a non-governmental organization designed to serve as a platform for its members to exchange views on how to promote their common ideals and democracy in the Pacific Rim countries.

Questioning the claim of liberals in the United States that helping China develop its economy and strengthen its interactions with the international community will promote democracy in that country and that a democratic China would ensure peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, Gilman said that although China has become an economic power, it has not yet been become a democratic country.

"On the contrary, China poses a greater threat to Japan, Taiwan and the United States. China also hopes to become a military power and treats other Asian countries as its subordinates as it did before," he added.

He also quoted U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld as recently saying that China's military buildup has threatened neighboring countries and that China seems to have the intention of forming an alliance with Russia in order to fight against the U.S-Japan alliance, which he said might affect security in the Asia-Pacific region.
According to the lawmaker, China will stage a military exercise Aug. 18-25 along its northeastern coast to test its military power as well as reactions from Japan and the United States.

The pragmatists in the United States have said that faced with the threat of China's growing military might, the only way to check that country's expansionist ambitions is for the United States to possess a superior military force and for all free, democratic and peace-loving countries to unite to promote world peace, he continued.

Gilman said that the DPU, which is also designed to establish a collective cooperation and consultation mechanism for the Asia-Pacific region, can play an important role in the fight against the threat posed by China. He added that the organization can also help effectively safeguard peace and stability in the region and in the world as well as establish a democratic, peaceful and prosperous Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, KIRIBATI SIGN HEALTH COOPERATION ACCORD

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the Republic of Kiribati signed an official accord Monday on bilateral cooperation in public health affairs.

Republic of China Health Minister Hou Sheng-mao and his Kiribatian counterpart, Natanaera Kirata, signed the bilateral accord in Taipei. Kiribati, located in the South Pacific, maintains formal diplomatic relations with the ROC on Taiwan.
The accord includes future cooperation in several areas, including medical exchanges, health education, and participation in international organizations.

Kirata, who arrived in Taiwan Sunday, said that the public health cooperation accord with Taiwan is the first ever of its kind that his country has signed. He added that he appreciates Taiwan's assistance in helping Kiribati improve its health care system.

According to the World Health Organization, there are only three physicians and 24 nurses serving in Kiribati, an island nation with a population of about 90,000. Under the Taiwan-Kiribati health accord, the two countries will make efforts to enhance professional medical personnel exchanges, with Taiwan to provide educational training programs and medical assistance as part of efforts to further improve the quality of Kiribati's health care system.

Taiwan and Kiribati forged diplomatic ties in 2003. In the South Pacific island state consisting of about 32 atolls and one island named Banaba, the most challenging health problems are AIDS, diabetes and hypertension.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICA FULLY SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S UN BID: PRESIDENT PACHECO

TEXT.P: Costa Rica staunchly supports Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations because the rights of Taiwan's 23 million people should be respected by all countries, visiting Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco de la Espriella said Monday.

Commenting on Taiwan's renewed efforts this year in its bid to join the UN -- including urging the UN to reconsider the issue of Taiwan's representation and asking the UN to play an active role in the Taiwan Strait issue -- Pacheco said that Costa Rica supports and will speak for Taiwan on every possible occasion to facilitate Taiwan's UN bid.

During an exclusive interview with CNA, Pacheco, who arrived in Taipei Friday mainly to attend the inaugural ceremony for the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) Sunday, said that Costa Rica will fully support Taiwan in its unswerving resolve to pursue peace, democracy and an identity for its people.
On the development of thorny cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Pacheco said that the best scenario is that the two sides resolve their differences through dialogue and negotiations.

Pacheco added that although Costa Rica has no right to interfere in other country's legislation, such as Beijing's passage of its Anti-Secession Law, which legalizes "non-peaceful means" should Taiwan move toward formal independence, he will try his utmost to help Taiwan.

In the face of stronger voices in his country's business sector calling for Costa Rica's closer economic and trade ties with China, Pacheco said that the Costa Rican government has remained firm in its position. "So far, Costa Rica-China relations have been restricted in economy and trade and it is impossible, at least presently, that Costa Rica will establish formal diplomatic relations with China," he reiterated.

Meanwhile, Pacheco noted, Costa Rica and Taiwan have begun to talk about signing a free trade agreement (FTA) . Nevertheless, he pointed out, these efforts should be made in a prudent and even calculating manner to make the agreement as perfect as possible.
A Taiwan-Costa Rica FTA could also cover not only economic and trade affairs, but also encompass exchanges in the fields of humanities, sciences and arts, Pacheco added.

Pacheco signed a joint communique with President Chen Shui-bian Sunday, reaffirming their commitment to further promoting exchanges and cooperation between the two countries. The two heads of state said in the joint communique that the Republic of China and Costa Rica will further expand cooperation in medical services, health care, education, and technological and economic development based on their 60-year friendship.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Deal Is Elusive in Iraqi Talks. Iraqi negotiators worked down to the wire Saturday to hammer out details of a draft constitution, but mounting frustrations over contentious issues raised the specter of a Sunni Arab walkout just one day before Monday's deadline.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPU MEMBERS SHOULD SUPPORT U.N. ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: NSC

TEXT.P: A senior Republic of China national security official has urged the member states of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) to help push the United Nations to accept a proposal which was raised by the island recently to request that the world body play an active role in maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Parris Chang, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, made the appeal while meeting with representatives from the 26 member states of the DPU, a non-governmental organization designed to serve as a platform for exchanges among Pacific Rim countries in the promotion of democracy, at a forum held Sunday at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.

Pointing out that the purpose of establishing the United Nations was to protect and maintain world peace, Chang said that the organization at least should serve as an arbitrator on issues related to Taiwan; however, the United Nations has long absented itself from dealing with the issue.

In the run-up to the nation's 13th bid to join the United Nations, the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs raised a proposal through its diplomatic allies to request that the organization play an active role in maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait and expressed the hope that the proposal will be placed on the agenda of this year's U.N. General Assembly scheduled to be held in September for debate and eventually be accepted by the organization.

Calling for the representatives of DPU members to persuade their governments to support the proposal, the official also expressed the hope that Australia, the United States, South Korea and El Salvador will clearly voice their support for the proposal.

He also urged the United Nations to shoulder its responsibility in dealing with the Taiwan issue and respond to Taiwan and the international community's expectations of a peaceful resolution on differences in the Strait.

in response to Chang's appeal, Benjamin Gilman, former chairman of the Committee on International Relations of the U.S. House of Representatives, who also attended the gathering, said that each time the U.N. discusses issues related to Taiwan, such as Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization and trade issues, China always does whatever it can to put pressure on other U.N. members who support Taiwan to prevent the passage of all resolutions in favor of Taiwan's U.N. bid.

Saying that only a few U.N. members would like to support the island within the organization, Gilman suggested that it is necessary for Taiwan and its allies find a better way to persuade more developing countries to support the island.

Meanwhile, Uliran T. Joaquin, vice chairman of the Committee of Foreign Affairs of the Filipino House of Representatives, also said that Taiwan must be patient if it wants the U.N. to recognize it, urging the DPU members to advise China not to prevent Taiwan from participating in the world health body and not to turn a blind eye to the health of the 23 million people of Taiwan.

Ralph A. Cossa, chairman of the Pacific Forum of the U.S. Center for Strategic and International Studies, also said that excluding Taiwan from many international organizations is unfair, stressing that the DPU can help Taiwan express its opinion and that world peace can be ensured through bilateral and multilateral cooperation and dialogue pushed by the organization.

The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.902 and fluctuated between NT$31.900 and NT$31.971.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved down 112 points to close at 6,240, with 32,474 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September moved down 121 points to end at 6,239, with 19,328 contracts traded, while December futures lost 127 points to finish at 6,221, with 49 contracts traded. March futures moved down 104 points to close at 6,237, with 21 contracts traded, while June futures moved down 116 points to close at 6,220, with nine contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,352 for August, 6,360 for September, 6,348 for December, 6,341 for March and 6,336 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

August TE futures moved down 5.65 points to close at 257.35, with 4,810 contracts traded, while September TE futures lost 6.7 points to finish at 257, with 2,480 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 8.1 points to end at 258.4, with three contracts traded, while June TE futures moved down 4.6 points to finish at 257.2, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

August TF futures lost 11 points to finish at 964.6, with 3,593 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved down 8.6 points to end at 964.8, with 2,777 contracts traded. March TF futures moved down 5.8 points to close at 964.4, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 105.77 points to close at 6,245.13.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,344.88 and hit a low of 6,238.02 during trading. A total of 3.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$76.45 billion (US$2.39 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2.6 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 2.2 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.7 percent, construction issues at 1.3 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.7 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 755 to 146, with 102 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 U.S. STUDENTS TO STUDY LANGUAGE IN TAIWAN UNDER TUSA SCHOLARSHIP

TEXT.P: Twelve students from the United States have been selected to study language and culture in Taiwan for three months this year under the Taiwan-United States Sister Relations Alliance (TUSA) Language Enrichment Scholarship, officials from the Ministry of Education said Monday.

This is the first time that the education ministry has cooperated with the TUSA -- a Little Rock, Arkansas-based non-profit, non-governmental organization devoted to promoting closer friendship and understanding between the people of the United States and the people of Taiwan -- in an effort to allow Americans to study language and culture in Taiwan during the summer.

In a thank-you letter to the Ministry of Education, TUSA Board Chairman Jimmie Lou Fisher said that the TUSA Language Enrichment Scholarship -- awarded to 12 Americans aged between 17 and 37 -- is contributing to further enhancing bilateral ties between the United States and Taiwan through cultural and educational efforts.

Meanwhile, education ministry authorities offered their appreciation to Taiwan members of the Rotary Club International for their generosity in providing home stays for the 12 American students during their studies in Taiwan.

According to the officials, the Ministry of Education has made more than 100 scholarships, including the TUSA Scholarships, available this year for selected students from 16 countries to study language and culture in Taiwan.

: The Straits Times: Israel begins historic pullout from Gaza.
Thousands of Israeli police blocked approaches to Gaza to keep back radical Jewish protesters as they began an evacuation of Israeli settlers from the occupied territory.
The Lianhe Zaobao: PM: Singaporean has three reasons to optimistic about the country's future.
Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong gave three reasons yesterday to optimistic about the country's future in his National Day speech to his Marine Parade constituents.
The Senior Minister said the global fight against terrorism may be reaching a turning point because the US now knows that military might alone cannot win the war.
Turning to the global environment, Mr Goh said it was now more complex. But Singapore's future remained bright because it had remade its economy in response to change like the rise of China and India.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CALLS TAIWAN'S 1895-1945 HISTORY 'JAPANESE COLONIAL RULE'

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Monday termed Japan's 1895-1945 rule of Taiwan as "colonial and aggressive, " stressing that from Taiwan's point of view, Taiwan was indeed "occupied" during that period.
This is the first time the DDP has tried to shed its previous ambiguity about Japan's role in shaping Taiwan's modern history while making a distinction between Taiwan's and China's aspirations.

In a draft report jointly prepared by the party's departments of culture and communications, ethnic affairs and international affairs, the DPP said that that half century of Taiwan's history can neither be simply called Japan's "neutral" rule, as some people think, nor be described as having been "ceded by China, " as feudalistic Chinese imperialists see it.

The draft report was the result of five rounds of discussions by the three departments with the participation of the Department of China Affairs and the party's Policy Research Committee, focusing on the theme of looking at the issue from the perspectives of universal values and multi-culturalism.
It said Taiwan's modernization during Japan's colonial occupation should not be exaggerated or distorted, and neither should it be minimized.

"Efforts should be made to write a history of Taiwan people resisting Japanese aggression as they sought autonomy. Efforts should also be made to criticize the nature of colonization and suppression that was common in both the post-war [Kuomintang] rule of Taiwan and the Japanese occupational regime," it said.

Yang Chang-chen, director of the DPP's Department of Ethnic Affairs, who coordinated the drafting of the report, cited the example of Nationalists China's war of resistance against Japanese aggression, which started on July 7, 1937 with the "Marco Polo Bridge Incident."

The spirit of "war against aggression" has no borders, Yang said, adding that therefore mainland-born Taiwan people's painful memory of China's war against Japanese invasion and China's civil war between the Kuomintang and the Communist Party should not be dismissed as "their memory."
Rather, he continued, the memory should be regarded as a critical component of Taiwan's spirit of anti-aggression.

The report said the DPP respects and understands why China has since long ago demanded Japan apologize for its World War II aggression, but hopes that the two Asian countries will not give up any chance of exchanges that will help promote goodwill and friendship between them.

Based on the same reasoning, the report hopes that China will try to "universalize" the values of anti-colonialism and anti-aggression and seriously reflect on its relations with neighboring tribes and countries -- particularly its relations with East Turkistan and Mongolia.

Only when China can truly honor universal values and think deeply about its relations with surrounding peoples can the rest of the world be convinced that China's rise will not be tainted with expansionism and hegemony, it said.
It pointed out that Taiwan's China-resisting efforts should not be seen as aimed at playing down Japan's colonial aggression and war responsibilities.

Also, the report said, Taiwan's efforts to build good relations with Japan based on their common objective of maintaining peace and promoting democratic values should not be interpreted as "anti-China" or "hating China."

DOC.HEADLINE: CGA TO LOOK INTO CHINESE FISHING BOAT INTRUSIONS NEAR MATSU

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) will investigate whether local units were derelict in their duties in trying to protect the rights of fishermen near the outlying island of Matsu as a media report insinuated, a senior official said Monday.

CGA Minister Shi Hwei-yow was responding to a report saying that Taiwanese fishermen's rights and national security have been jeopardized by Chinese fishing vessels, which have recently been intruding into waters near Matsu more often than ever. Matsu is an island group that lies closer to the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian than to Taiwan proper.

According to the report, Chinese fishermen not only traversed into waters close to Matsu to fish but also went ashore to rest. The report quoted a member of a Matsu fishing association as claiming that the phenomenon has been going on for a long time but that the situation has gotten worse than ever because of the CGA's sloppy management.

The claim was that some Chinese fishing boats caught by CGA patrols were released after giving out bribes of high-quality fish catches. He added that the association had spent two months getting footage of intrusions by Chinese fishing boats in waters off Matsu.

Commenting on the report, Shi said he has directed CGA Deputy Minister Chung Tung-sheng to head a team to Matsu on a field survey. Team members include officials from coastal patrol and government ethics departments.

In addition to investigating whether CGA staff were derelict about their official duties or indeed took bribes from Chinese fishermen as reported, Shi said the team is also expected to map out appropriate measures to address the Matsu offshore waters security problems.

Any staff member who is found guilty of corruption or dereliction of duty will be given harsh penalties in accordance with the law, Shi said, adding that the CGA will publish a report on the team's investigative results and the CGA's response as soon as possible.

With a view to upgrading working efficiency, Shi said, the CGA has implemented a new integrated operational system since July 1 and has made Matsu its 11th patrol region. The new system accentuates integration of coastal and deep-sea patrols and information gathering to enhance efficiency, he explained.

The Seventh Moscow Aviation and Space Show, MAKS 2005, kicks off Tuesday at the Zhukovsky airfield in the Moscow region, with this year's event boasting a record number of exhibitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT GROUP HEADS FOR CHINA FOR TALKS ON DIRECT CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: A group of main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) officials and lawmakers left for China Monday to hold talks with the Chinese side on direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait.

KMT Central Policy Committee head Tseng Yung-chuan, who led the group, said that they will talk over the issue Tuesday in Beijing with Chinese officials from the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council and the Civil Aviation Administration of China and that they will return to Taiwan later the same day.

Stating that direct charter cargo and passenger flights between Taiwan and China are urgently needed due to close bilateral trade and economic relations, Tseng said that the KMT is very willing to act as a bridge and a go-between in helping forging mutual benefits and creating a win-win situation.

Although Premier Frank Hsieh said earlier this month that Taiwan is preparing to open the talks, Tseng said that the government has made no concrete moves, noting that it has not responded to an invitation by the KMT group to send officials to participate in the talks.

KMT lawmaker John Chiang criticized the government for its inactivity on the issue, with only one month away from the Moon Festival -- one of the major traditional holidays for Chinese people around the world to return home and visit their families.
Chiang also urged the government to broaden its charter passenger service beyond Taiwan businessmen to other occupations of Taiwan people.
KMT lawmaker Chu Fong-chih expressed the hope that China will open airports in Shanghai and Guangdong to serve direct links to Taiwan.

The private sector is eager to see the talks start off as soon as possible based on the success of the Chinese New Year charter flights earlier this year that were conducted in line with the "non-stop, round-trip" principle by carriers from the two sides.

The Taipei Airlines Association, which was appointed again last week by the government as its proxy to conduct the charter passenger and cargo talks with China, said that they have to wait patiently for the time being until the Mainland Affairs Council gives further instruction.

EVA Airways Corporation -- Taiwan's second-largest carrier after China Airlines (CAL) -- said that brisk cross-strait cargo business enjoyed at present by Taiwan's carriers via Hong Kong or Macau will last no more than two years. Taiwan carriers are set to face a plunge in their business after foreign aviation companies complete their deployment in the Chinese market, it pointed out.

China opened its skies to U.S.-based carriers last year, promoting Federal Express and UPS to set up transshipment centers in China, while airlines from other Asian and European countries are jockeying for position in forming cooperation ventures with Chinese carriers in cargo transport.
CAL is slated to own 18 Boeing 747-400 all-cargo planes by the end of this year, making it the world's No. 1 all-cargo Boeing 747-400 fleet.

Despite the fact that no breakthrough has so far been made in cross-strait transport links, business sources said that CAL is optimistic about business prospects by having ordered new airplanes to serve that end; however, there is not much time left for Taiwan-based carriers to wait amid aggressive foreign competition as Taiwan has more to ask from the Chinese side in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BRANDS MAKE A SPLASH WITH NEW PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The fine porcelain producer from Taiwan, Franz Collection, Inc., has begun marketing new items this summer after it gained exclusive authorization from the National Palace Museum to reproduce historic Chinese treasures earlier this year.
The company has 5,500 global outlets and won Taiwan's National Product Image Gold Award this year.
Meanwhile, the autumn/winter collection of Taiwan's Miss Sofi footwear has been released.
The new line of lady's shoes, named "magic high heels, " are in five different styles. The high-quality shoes are making inroad into the international markets, corporate sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 11 INSTITUTIONS AWARDED BY THE EPA FOR RECYCLING

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) announced Monday that it would award 11 government and private institutions for their recycling efforts.
The institutions, which range from hospitals to high-tech manufacturers, were selected by an EPA panel to encourage the public to reduce and recycle their waste.

Yao Wen-huei, an agent at the EPA's Department of Waste Management, was quoted as saying that poultry droppings and cow manure is a good source of fertilizer for plants as they contain nitrogen, phosphorous, and potassium.
One award-winning compost factory confirmed Yao's assessment by utilizing used tea leaves, coffee beans, cow manure and farm waste to produce the organic, odor-free fertilizer.

People can also make their own compost at home by collecting their kitchen waste and processing it with special fungi, Yao said. The juice produced by the fungi, according to him, is nutritious enough to be used as liquid fertilizer or to keep sewers from being clogged by dirt or being infested with cockroaches.

This is the third year for the EPA awards and 38 government institutions and private companies have been recognized. The EPA said it would hold a conference this year to demonstrate how schools and the public can benefit from reducing and recycling their waste.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN BLOOD DONOR ENCOURAGES MIDDLE-AGED TO DONATE BLOOD MORE OFTEN

TEXT.P: The woman who has donated more blood in Taiwan than any other female said Monday that middle-aged people should get into the act to help enrich the nations blood banks.
Wang Chiu-chiung, 47, who began to donate blood at the age of 28 in 1986, said that she has regularly given blood even though she is now middle aged. She has donated 758 times over the past 19 years.
Wang said that there is a mistaken belief that older people should not donate blood because blood donations are harmful to health.
Wang said that she donates blood under one single purpose -- to help people. Because she is not rich, Wang said, she has chosen to donate blood as if donating cash to the needy.
In order to donate blood repeatly, Wang said she has forced herself to lead a healthy lifestyle -- eating and drinking right, getting enough sleep and exercising regularly.

According to officials from the Taipei Blood Organization, the blood bank regularly suffers blood shortages during summer and it found that most of the blood donors in Taiwan are students or young people aged between 17 and 30. The number of donors decreases with age, the officials said.
Encouraging middle-aged people to donate blood more often, Wang stressed that blood donations should not be the exclusive right of the young.
Wang's husband, who previously was opposed to blood donations, is now also a regular donor. Wang said her child will be a devoted donor too after he turns 17.

New York Times: Iraqis Consider Bypassing Sunnis on Constitution
Iraqi leaders remained deadlocked Sunday over major issues in the country's new constitution. With several questions unresolved, Shiite leaders said Sunday that they were considering asking the National Assembly to approve the document without the agreement of the country's Sunni leaders. If the deadline is not met nor the interim constitution successfully amended successfully, the law appears to require dissolving the National Assembly and holding new election.
