In the wake of the deadly July 7 bombings in London and the abortive attacks two weeks later, Britain has begun to rethink its tolerant approach to Islamic extremism. The roots of Britain's probelm is said to stretch back to the 1990s, when the British capital became known as "Londonistan" and radical clerics gained a dangererous power over the minds of many people.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO URGENT NEED FOR DIALOGUE WITH HU JINTAO: KMT CHAIRMAN-ELECT MA

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, the chairman-elect of Taiwan's largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), said Monday there is no urgent need for him to have a face-to-face talk with Communist Party of China (CPC) leader Hu Jintao.

Commenting on news reports that the CPC is seeking direct dialogue between its leaders and the KMT, Ma said the Mainland Affairs Department of the KMT Central Committee has been the party's channel of communications with China, and that outgoing KMT Chairman Lien Chan already paid a visit to China in late April and reached a consensus with Hu on five major subjects.
Therefore, Ma said, there is "no immediate or urgent need" at present to hold talks between himself and Hu, general secretary of the CPC Central Committee, who is also the president of China.

Asked about the remarks made by Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng Monday that after winning the election for KMT chairman, Ma has become the KMT's candidate for the 2008 presidential election, Ma disagreed, saying that the election for party chairman has not produced a nominee for the presidential election, and that as of now, anyone is qualified to be a candidate, including Wang.

Ma, who is currently Taipei mayor, said people often misrepresented him when he said his chief objective in running for KMT chairman was to make the KMT the ruling party again in 2008, as they think that he wants to run for president in 2008.
Ma explained that actually his biggest concern is to place the KMT in a favorable position through reforms, so that the party can lead in the presidential election campaign all the way until 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BORN VETERANS CALL FOR SHRINE FOR UNSUNG HEROES

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan-born veterans who have gone through Japanese and Chinese rule called on the government to give them justice and build a "martyrs shrine" dedicated to some 50,000 Taiwanese soldiers who died in World War II, the Korean War and China's civil war.

Hsu Chao-jung and Hsu Teng-kuang were invited by the Kaohsiung City Government to tell their stories in conjunction with the publication of a history book about the war and the life experiences of Taiwanese veterans.

Hsu, 77, and a native of Pingtung in southern Taiwan, volunteered to serve in the Japanese Imperial Navy and was later recruited by the Republic of China Navy and sent to the United States on a mission to sail a navy vessel back to Taiwan.

It was during that mission when he read a book titled, "The Tenth Anniversary of the Taiwan Independence Movement, " a taboo at the time. Because of that, he was jailed for 10 years on Green Island off Taitung.

After being released from prison, Hsu was monitored all the time. He decided to exile himself abroad. He is now chairman of the board of directors of the Association of the ROC Soldiers and their Bereaved Families.

His personal experiences motivated him to gather as much information as possible, through "oral history" compilations, about Taiwan-born soldiers who had been "tricked" into joining the Nationalist Army, many of whom died as a result of the civil war between the Kuomintang and the Communist Party from 1945 to 1949.

Hsu, 75, speaks with a Suzhou, Zhejiang province accent though he is a Hakka from Hualien, eastern Taiwan. Soon after Japan's defeat in 1945, he joined the ROC Army, serving as a platoon leader in the 278th Regiment of the 70th Division.
He fought in many skirmishes in China with the Chinese Communists, including the major Hsupang Battle. He then became a prisoner of war.

While many of his fellow soldiers came to Taiwan with the Chiang Kai-shek government, he was stranded in China for 43 years. In 1996, with the assistance of some tourists from Taiwan, he returned to his hometown in Hualien, only to encounter another downturn in his life -- he wasn't given any compensation by the ROC government; he has since been making a living by collecting garbage.

Hsu said the ROC government did not even issue him a certificate of discharge from military service so he would be entitled to some veterans benefits. Now he is almost a misfit, and a burden to his family.

On the 60th anniversary of the end of WWII, Hsu Teng-kuang and Hsu Chao-jung said they are concerned about thousands of Taiwan-born veterans who are still in China. They also said they care very much about the tens of thousands of others who have died fighting in different wars on Pacific islands, the Korean Peninsula and China.
They urged the government to build a monument or a shrine dedicated to those unsung heroes to give them basic justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI WORKER KILLED IN MAILIAO IN BRAWL WITH FELLOW THAI EMPLOYEE

TEXT.P: A Thai worker at Formosa Plastics Group's (FPG) petrochemical complex in Mailiao, Yunlin County in southeastern Taiwan was allegedly murdered by his colleague Monday.

The alleged murder happened at FPG's dormitory where two Thai workers grappled and fought with each other after they got drunk. One of them, named Phopkhunthot Suchin, allegedly stabbed his colleague with a sharp knife five times in the chest.
The victim, identified as Normmul Sittichai, was pronounced dead on arrival at hospital.
Suchin, who said he didn't know why he did what he did, is in police custody for further questioning ahead of being formally charged by prosecutors.

DOC.HEADLINE: FATE OF TWO WATER OFFICIALS RESTS WITH CABINET: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Two officials who offered to resign after being criticized for water shortages in Taoyuan County were backed Monday by Minister of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Ho Mei-yueh as "doing a good job, " but she added that their fate rests in the hands of the Executive Yuan.

Ho was referring to Water Resources Agency Director Chen Sheng-hsien and Taiwan Water Corp. Chairman Lee Wen-liang, adding that both have insisted on stepping down to take responsibility for the recent water shortages.

She lauded the two for their excellent ability to execute tasks, but said that she would report to the Executive Yuan about their intention to leave their posts and let the Executive Yuan decide whether they should go.

After Typhoon Matsa battered Taiwan in early August, bringing strong winds and torrential rains, the water supply to Taoyuan was disrupted. Water to northern Taoyuan was not fully restored until Aug. 13.

President Chen Shui-bian was angry about the recurrence of water shortages -- Taoyuan has been routinely hit with a lack of potable water after typhoons in the last couple of years -- and inspected the Shihmen Reservoir himself last week. The ministry convened a review meeting Sunday, with Ho finalizing the review report Monday.

Ho said that the report centers on issues that the public is most concerned about, adding that after the typhoons last year, a second pumping station was installed at Shihmen, but it was not able to cope this year with the mud and silt that entered the reservoir after the first two typhoons.
She said that the review report will examine each of the problems, and will mete out discipline if negligence is discovered. She did not disclose the list of names under review.

Premier Hsieh said earlier that a vice economic minister was not at Taoyuan to keep abreast of the latest developments in the water shortage crisis, and the media has speculated that the person in question was Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming who is responsible for water resources.
Ho said Yiin in fact was involved during the entire process, but because the ministry was busy at the time, the public couldn't possibly have seen her and Yiin at the same time and place.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, GUATEMALA PRESIDENTS VISIT TAROKO NATIONAL PARK

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian accompanied visiting Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo and Berger's wife Monday on a sightseeing tour to Taroko National Park in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.
During the trip, Berger said that in his country there are landscapes similar to those in the park, noting he hopes to see Taiwan people visit his country.
After getting an introduction from the national park administration, the group of dignitaries was entertained by dancing and music by local aboriginal groups.
President Chen, who had visited the national park several times, served as the tour guide for his Guatemalan counterpart.
Berger is visiting Taiwan to attend the inaugural conference of the Democratic Pacific Union, which took place Aug. 13-15 at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12-YEAR-OLD GIRL CHARGED WITH INTIMIDATING SWAZI AMBASSADOR

TEXT.P: A 12-year-old girl charged with intimidating Swazi Ambassador Njabuliso Gwebu over the telephone Aug. 3 has been referred to a juvenile court in Taipei, a spokesman for the Shihlin District police precinct said Monday.

The girl, surnamed Lu, is a seventh-grade student at a school for foreign nationals. A police task force established specifically to investigate the case traced a series of threatening calls to the girl's mobile phone.

According to the police, the girl admitted having made the phone calls, which she said were intended for a classmate who had stood her up a few days earlier. She said she dialed a number of times within five minutes from her bedroom.

The girl also admitted that during the first phone call, she threatened the person on the other end of the line in English while trying to impersonate a male voice. In the following calls, she remained silent.

Members of the police task force who checked the phone number of Lu's classmate found that there is only a one-digit difference between that number and the phone number of the Swazi ambassador. The task force concluded that the girl probably dialed the wrong number while trying to play a trick on her classmate.
Although the girl's mother pleaded that she be forgiven for the unintended hoax, the police nevertheless referred the case to the juvenile court.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPU TO PROMOTE DEMOCRACY, PEACE AND PROSPERITY: VICE PRESIDENT LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Monday that the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) will dedicate itself to the promotion of democracy, peace and prosperity.
The DPU is a non-governmental organization and is a platform for exchanges among Pacific Rim countries. Lu made the remarks at the closing lunch of the organization's first meeting.

Lu, who was elected chairperson of the union on Saturday, wore a pair of dark glasses and still has her right eye covered with a bandage after receiving treatment for recurrent dry eye syndrome Sunday. She said that the union will promote democracy, peace and prosperity over the next two years, and push for political, economic, social, gender and international justice.

She also said that Taiwan's five "soft strengths" -- human rights, democracy, peace, love and technical development -- are the result of the 23 million people on Taiwan over the past five decades, and the country is willing to share these with the world.
Speaking on the same occasion, Premier Frank Hsieh expressed his admiration for Lu's promotion of the DPU.

The premier said that although the members of the DPU come from different countries, they share the same ideals of being in the Pacific Rim region, a love of democracy and upholding freedom and human rights.
Hsieh pointed out that President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that Taiwan's democracy is faced with threats, and that the members should increase cooperation and exchanges for a better future.

The DPU is comprised of 26 member countries, including the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Mexico, Honduras, Guatemala, El Salvador, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru, Chile, Russia, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, East Timor, the Marshal Islands, the Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Kiribati, Palau and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FUNDS MAJOR DRIVING FORCE IN CHINESE EXPORT SECTOR: REPORT

TEXT.P: More than half of the 100 largest exporters in China are foreign-funded hi-tech companies, with most of the capital coming from Taiwan, according to a recent report by Lehman Brothers, a U.S.-based investment bank.

Among the top 100 largest exporters in China, the number of foreign-funded corporations rose to 53 in 2004 from 48 in 2003, the report said, adding that 21 of the 53 electronics or information industry companies were set up with funds from Taiwan, a development that the bank called a reflection of Taiwan businesses' success in setting up an export platform in China.

Of the other 32 concerns, 11 and 10 are funded by capital from the United States and South Korea, respectively, while seven were established with Japanese investment. Two account for investment from Holland, while Germany and Finland are owners in each of the remaining two companies, according to the report.

Hi-tech exports surged to make up some 33 percent of China's total outbound shipments in the first half of this year, more than double the 15 percent posted in the first half in 2000, thanks to a large amount of outsourcing business, the report said, adding that it has created many job opportunities in China and has helped introduce new value-added technologies.

Foreign-owned corporations are playing a bigger role in the booming Chinese export sector, with the number reaching 60 percent of the total this year, up from 48 percent in 2000 and 32 percent in 1995.
The Chinese export sector recorded an annual growth rate of 32 percent in the first half of this year, two-thirds of which was contributed by foreign-invested businesses, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LAUDS DPU'S `SOFT POWER'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu claimed Monday that China is donning the mask of a "peaceful rise," but in fact, the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) she initiated will "emerge softly."

Lu made the remarks in a press conference after the conclusion of the three-day DPU conference, which included its inauguration and three seminars centering on the themes of the organization -- democracy, peace and prosperity.
According to Lu, all the DPU representatives have formed a "big Pacific family" and will now spread the DPU's three ideals when they return to their home countries.

The DPU is comprised of 26 member countries -- the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Mexico, Honduras, Guatemala, El Salvador, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru, Chile, Russia, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, East Timor, the Marshall Islands, the Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Kiribati, Palau and Taiwan.

She said the aim of the DPU will be welcomed by peace-loving countries and expressed the hope that Chinese people will soon enjoy the basic rights of DPU countries, including the right to choose their national leaders, adding that when that day comes, she will welcome China as a good partner.

On the plight of Taiwan in the international community, Lu said the United Nations is unfair to Taiwan, claiming that although Taiwan is eligible to attend any international organizations from any angle, it is shut out because it has an unfriendly neighbor -- China.
She expressed the hope that all "friends who love democracy and freedom" can tell China's leaders to cast away their set ideas and allow Taiwan a chance to take part in international organizations.

Noting that China advocates 'peaceful emergence," Lu claimed that Beijing is donning a mask, citing a U.S. Defense Department report that China's continued military buildup has caused uneasiness and misgivings among many countries.
Lu also claimed that Taiwan will "never be invaded by any countries" because of its superb strategic position, which she likened to an unsinkable aircraft carrier.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI LINKS' TRAFFIC VOLUME ON RISE: DGBAS

TEXT.P: More than 139,000 passengers traveled via the "mini three links" in the first half of this year, reflecting an annual growth rate of 50.8 percent, according to statistics released Monday by the government.

According to the tallies published by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), 2,173 voyages were made in the six-month period between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and China's Fujian province ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou, marking an increase of 56.8 percent in number over the previous year's level.

The Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Fuzhou links, popularly known as the "mini three links, " were set up in January 2001 to compensate for the long-term absence of direct transport, trade and postal links between Taiwan proper and China and to help bolster economic development on the two outlying islands.
A total of 6,445 passengers traveled from Matsu to Fuzhou during the six-month period, an astounding jump of 94.1 percent year on year, the same tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LOOKING FORWARD TO TRANSIT STOPS IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has expressed his desire for visits or transit stops in Australia in a recent interview with Australia's largest newspaper, and has urged Canberra to end its 33-year ban on Taiwanese leaders visiting the country.

In the interview with The Australian daily, Chen also appealed for Australia's diplomatic help, asking Prime Minister John Howard to push his case for an invitation to next month's informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, to be held in South Korea.

Chen was interviewed by the paper's international news section editor Greg Sheridan in Taipei last week. After publishing an article on Chen in its weekend edition, the newspaper carried two more related articles and an editorial in its Monday issue.

Australia has barred visits from Taiwanese leaders since 1972, when Canberra established diplomatic relations with Beijing. Chen was quoted as having said in the interview that he respects Australia's diplomatic ties with China but believes this should not prevent practical cooperation between Taipei and Canberra.

Chen said he looks forward to visiting Australia -- or at least being allowed to make transit stops in major Australian cities such as Brisbane and Sydney -- on his way to visit the Republic of China's six diplomatic allies in the South Pacific. Chen has managed to make transit stops in the United States and Fiji, neither of which maintain formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Noting that Australia has offered enormous support and aid for many South Pacific countries, Chen said he believes Taiwan and Australia can forge a partnership in assisting those countries in the future.
He also took the opportunity to make his case for an invitation to the upcoming APEC summit meeting, claiming that APEC could be used as a conduit for resolving disputes across the Taiwan Strait.

"I believe that if justice and equality exist in international society, the Australian government should speak in favor of Taiwan" and allow Taiwan's president to participate in APEC alongside leaders of other APEC member states, Chen said.
At a time when the U.S. government wants a peaceful resolution of the Taiwan Strait issue, Chen said he believes APEC can serve as the best site for discussion of the issue.
He called for broader international involvement in the cross-strait issue. With regard to the nuclear issue involving North Korea, Chen noted that many nations came together in the six-party talks.
"I believe the dispute in the Taiwan Strait should also be considered a regional issue," he said.
On Taiwan's future, Chen said he does not rule out cross-strait unification as an option, but he insisted that Taiwan's sovereignty rests with its 23 million people and no-one else.
Under the principles of popular sovereignty and national self-determination, Chen said it is up to the Taiwan people to decide whether Taiwan should unify with China.
Reaffirming his resolve to defend Taiwan's sovereign status, Chen said the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China are different and separately ruled countries.

In the face of China's ever-growing military threat, Chen said Taiwan will strive to maintain sufficient self-defense capabilities. He said optimistically that his administration's long-stalled arms procurement plan will clear the legislature in the not-too-distant future.

He was referring to a plan to purchase three advanced weaponry items from the United States, including eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PACIII anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft. The plan has been consistently stonewalled by the opposition, which holds a legislative majority.
In the interview, Chen praised Australia as "a great power" in the Pacific and expressed gratitude for Canberra's diplomatic assistance in the past.

"We are very well aware that without the assistance of Australia we would not have such participation in world affairs, " Chen said. "Our successful accession into the World Trade Organization was a result of the fruitful assistance of the Australian government, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DESCRIBES CHINA'S MILITARY RISE AS THREAT

TEXT.P: Present Chen Shui-bian warned that China's military expansion and modernization is not only a threat against Taiwan, but also the entire international community.
Chen made the remarks during an interview published Monday in the newspaper, Australian, in reply to the question of why China is boosting its military build-up.
Chen said that "their (China's) main aim is to become a hegemony in the Pacific Ocean."
Chen cited U.S. Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld as saying that there's no reason for China to engage in a military build-up when no countries in the world are threatening its national security.

Despite this fact, China's military spending has been assessed to be undergoing double-digit growth annually in the past 17 consecutive years, according to Japan's 2005 defense white paper released early August, he said.

However, because China has never revealed its military budget, the authorities in both the United States and Japan believe the country's actual military spending could be two or three-time larger than the estimated military budget, Chen added, adding that China's rapid military expansion has ambitions far beyond Taiwan.
He warned that China's rise is not for maintaining peace but for its military ambition.

DOC.HEADLINE: HALT ORDERED TO SHIPBREAKING OF PANAMA-REGISTERED VESSEL

TEXT.P: The Marine Bureau of the Kaohsiung city government ordered Monday that all shipbreaking operations on the "Royal Pacific, " a Panama-registered passenger liner that sank in Kaohsiung Harbor in June after catching fire, should cease immediately because fuel leaking from the vessel is polluting the waters in and around the harbor.

A spokesman for the bureau said that an investigation by bureau officials has found that the shipbreaking operations were unauthorized and that light diesel fuel and heavy fuel oil leaking from the vessel has polluted the harbor.

The spokesman stressed that legal procedure must be followed in order to obtain permission for any shipbreaking and that the job must be done by an authorized shipyard to ensure no damage is done to the environment.

The 9,800-ton ship capsized in Kaohsiung Harbor June 30 after a fire broke out below decks a day earlier while the vessel was undergoing maintenance at Wharf No. 54. More than half of the ship's 26 tanks still had oil in them, posing a considerable pollution hazard.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MAJOR AIRLINERS TO APPLY TO OVERFLY CHINA FOR 11 DESTINATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two major airlines are expected to apply to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) soon to overfly Chinese airspace with passenger and cargo flights to 11 destinations, MOTC officials said Monday.
China Airlines (CAL) will apply to overfly China on its flights to Frankfurt, Abu Dhabi, New Delhi and Hanoi, and is expected to save NT$260 million (US$8.25 million) annually on fuel costs.
EVA Airways will apply to overfly on its flights to Paris, Mumbai, New Delhi, Hanoi, Vientiane, Dubai and Bangkok, and is expected to save more than NT$100 million annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO DOCTORS CHARGED WITH PROFESSIONAL ERROR CAUSING GIRL'S DEATH

TEXT.P: Taipei district prosecutors charged two Jen Ai Hospital doctors Monday with "professional error leading to the death" of a young girl who was beaten up by her father, who has already been prosecuted.

The five-year-old girl with the family name of Chiu, after being hurt by her father, was first sent to Taipei's Jen Ai Hospital, where doctors Liu Chi-hua and Lin Chih-nan were on duty at the emergency unit.

The prosecutors quoted a Department of Health report as saying that the girl was in deep coma when she arrived at the hospital. She was refused treatment and had to be transferred to a Taichung County hospital some 200 km away, where she later died.
The DOH report said the worsening of her condition and eventual death cannot be conclusively linked to the two Ren Ai doctors' failure to offer timely medical treatment.
Still, the prosecution said, not only did the two doctors fail to diagnose the girl's injury but they also forged the records of her medical history.

Forgery is a clear violation of the medical profession's ethical guidelines, said the prosecutors, who decided to indict the two doctors on charges of making a professional error that led to the death of a patient.
The girl's father, Chiu Kuang-jen, was charged with violent beating and manslaughter, an offense that the prosecution said is punishable by a 12-year jail sentence.
The girl's injury and death created a storm in local society, which demanded soul searching on the part of social workers and doctors.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT OF COAST GUARD'S DERELICTION OF DUTY NOT TRUE: CGA

TEXT.P: A media report that coast guard staff on the outlying island of Matsu are corrupt and derelict in their duty in protecting the nation's fishery resources and fishermen is untrue, the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) claimed Monday.
Responding to the report, the CGA said, it sent a team of officials to Matsu earlier in the day on a field survey.
The team, headed by CGA Deputy Minister Chung Tung-sheng, said that the report was not substantiated.

According to the report, Chinese fishing boats have intruded into waters near Matsu more often than ever. Worse still, the report said, Chinese fishermen not only enter waters close to Matsu to fish but also go ashore to rest.

The report also quoted a member of a Matsu fishing association as claiming that some Chinese fishing boats caught by CGA patrols were released after paying bribes in the form of fish. He added that the association spent two months getting footage of intrusions by Chinese fishing boats in waters off Matsu -- an island group that lies closer to the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian than to Taiwan proper.

Chung said after his return from the half-day field survey that the footage provided by the association only shows individual Chinese fishing boats operating in waters near Matsu. None of photos, he claimed, substantiated the claim of intrusions by a large number of Chinese fishing boats.

Initial investigations also show that on the day the footage was shot, the CGA unit in Matsu sent patrols to the area upon receiving information about the intrusions. Due to the distance and "other factors, " the boats had already fled when CGA patrols reached the region.
As to the claim that CGA officers have received fish bribes, Chung said none of the Matsu fishing association members interviewed by the team could produce evidence to back the claim.
However, with a view to maintaining law and order and protecting fishery resources in waters off Matsu and Kinmen, Chung said the CGA will deploy more patrols in the region in the future.

Since July 1, Chung said, the CGA has implemented a new integrated operational system to upgrade working efficiency and has made Matsu its 11th patrol region. The new system accentuates integration of coastal and deep-sea patrols and information gathering to enhance efficiency, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: URBAN REVITALIZATION SAID TO BRING IN NT$500 B IN PRIVATE INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: An urban rejuvenization project is expected to bring in over NT$500 billion (US$15.87 billion) in private investment that will provide a substantive and positive boost to economic growth, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Monday.
The project was passed by the CEPD in a meeting Monday.

CEPD Secretary-General Huang Chao-hsi said population growth in Taiwan is slowing down and that the number of houses available has exceeded the number of households. The number of houses over 40 years old totals 1.75 million, or a quarter of the total households.
For this reason, it is necessary to review and improve the function and environmental quality of urban areas.
Under the project, the CEPD will choose over 100 sites where public land accounts for the majority of the total land area and will invite land developers to develop them within three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-PALAU TIES GETTING CLOSER: PALAU VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Palau Vice President Elias Camsek Chin said Monday that ties between Taiwan and Palau is getting closer based on the opened communication channels between the two countries.

Chin, who was in Taipei to attend the inaugural conference of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) Sunday, also praised Vice President Annette Lu, who initiated the DPU, for her charisma, intelligence and candidness.
According to Lu, the DPU is a non-governmental organization aimed at boosting democracy, peace and prosperity for the Pacific Rim democracies and offering a cooperation platform for them.

The DPU boasts 26 member countries, including Canada, the United States, Mexico, Guatemala, El Salvador, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru, Chile, Russia, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, the Philippines, Malaysia, Australia and New Zealand.
Noting that he admires Lu's leadership, Chin congratulated her for being elected as the first chairwoman of the DPU.
Palau, which has a territory of 494 square kilometers and a population of 20,000, is noted as a tourist attraction. Currently, Taiwan has replaced Japan as the largest source of tourists for Palau.
Since its establishment of diplomatic ties with the Republic of China in 1999, Palau has extended its full support for Taiwan's bids to enter the United Nations almost every year.
In the first half of this year, President Chen Shui-bian and Lu visited Palau separately, with Lu describing Palau as Taiwan's closest and nearest ally.
Saying he felt at home during his Taiwan visit thanks to the hospitality shown by Chen, Lu and the people of Taiwan, Chin expressed hope that more Taiwan people will visit Palau.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER WILL NOT SERVE AS KMT VICE CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jyn-ping formally declined Monday an invitation from Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, the chairman-elect of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), to serve as senior KMT vice chairman.

Ma visited Wang at his residence that day and talked with him for more than 50 minutes in their first formal meeting since Ma won a sweeping victory over Wang in a fiercely contested election for the party chairmanship in July.

Both Ma and Wang told reporters that the atmosphere during their meeting was "congenial" and that they reached consensus that the topic of whether Wang should serve as Ma's deputy will not be raised any more in the future.
However, Ma unexpectedly added that the position of senior KMT vice chairman will remain vacant in case Wang changes his mind.
Asked by the media to comment on Ma's remark, Wang said he took it as a pleasantry from Ma.
Wang pledged to remain in the legislature to assist the KMT in his capacity as Legislative Yuan president.
He said he does not wish to serve as the senior KMT vice chairman because he wants Ma to have more room to maneuver in his new post.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIC PACIFIC UNION HAS GLOBAL VISION: NICARAGUA VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Nicaragua Vice President Rizo Castellon hailed the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) Monday as having global vision, which he said will play an important role in the future.

Castellon, who was in Taipei to attend the inaugural conference of the DPU -- initiated by Vice President Annette Lu -- said the DPU is a completely new experience for Nicaragua, as the country has focused its relations with Atlantic nations in the past but now realizes that it can develop new ties with the Pacific countries via the DPU.
Castellon expressed hope that the organization can emphasize scientific cooperation, extend more assistance in disaster prevention to Nicaragua and offer scholarships to students in his country.
Noting that Nicaragua and the Republic of China have maintained close relations over the years, Castellon said his country will continue to support Taiwan's bids to enter the United Nations.
He also urged Taiwan entrepreneurs to invest in Nicaragua, as the country is geographically close to the United States and will soon sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with the U.S.
According to Castellon, Nicaragua and Taiwan are ready to negotiate a FTA soon.
During his Taiwan visit, the seventh of its kind, Castellon said the only thing that has not changed in Taiwan is the hospitality shown by its people.

Concerning an upcoming summit between ROC and Central American heads of state in Nicaragua in September, Castellon noted that all the Central American countries have high expectations of the summit, as it will serve as a direct cooperation platform for both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAVERICK DPP POLITICIAN INTENDS TO RUN FOR TAIPEI MAYORSHIP

TEXT.P: Former Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party confirmed Monday that he met with President Chen Shui-bian recently to express his intention of running for the Taipei mayorship in 2006.
Shen, a physician-turned-politician known for his eloquency, humor and independent-thinking, said Chen gave a positive response toward his bid for the Taipei mayoral post.

Recent media reports revealed a short list of candidates handpicked by Chen to represent the DPP in next year's Taipei mayoral race, including Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan, DPP Legislator Tsai Ing-wen and Yeh Chu-lan, a national policy adviser who has previously served as a legislator, minister of transportation and vice premier.
Amid the reports, Shen said he felt compelled to meet with Chen to express his keen interest in joining the race. Otherwise, Shen said, he was afraid that the DPP might forget his intention to run.
Shen said his relations with Chen are not as bad as some people think, describing his meeting with Chen at the Presidential Office a few weeks ago as "amiable and cordial."

Shen's relationship with Chen was believed to have dropped to a low ebb in the run-up to the 2004 presidential election due to political contribution allegations involving first lady Wu Shu-chen and Shen's high school classmate Chen You-hao, one of Taiwan's 10 most-wanted white-collar criminals.

Responding to Shen's announcement, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said the DPP has yet to begin mulling its favorite candidate for the Taipei mayoral race because the election is still more than a year away.
Cheng said the party's nominee will be selected through its established democratic primary mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY PUSHES FOR `FREEDOM OF HAIRSTYLE' FOR STUDENTS

TEXT.P: All education chiefs of local governments contacted by the Ministry of Education (MOE) have voiced support for the ministry's decision to give students freedom to decide upon their hairstyles, Vice Minister of Education Fan Sun-lu said Monday.
Fan said her office had contacted the education chiefs of 19 out of 25 cities and counties around the country by last Friday, all of whom are in favor of the abolishment of regulations on hairstyles.
The ministry is still trying to seek the opinion of education chiefs from the other six cities and counties, Fan said.

The vice minister admitted, however, that the school principals are the key persons who can make or break the ministry's policy, and she said her ministry is trying to convince them to give their students the right to determine their own hairstyles.

Describing the hairstyle regulations as a relic of past authoritarianism, Fan said the it was abandoned -- at least on paper -- by the Ministry of Education (MOE) in 1987, but the students of most elementary and middle schools still have to follow certain guidelines on what hairstyle they can wear, with crewcuts the most common styles imposed by most schools on their male students.

Today, Fan said, students are more assertive about their right to determine their attire and hairstyles than they were 18 years ago and have united recently via the Internet in questioning the legitimacy of school regulations about hairstyles. The school authorities should accommodate their wishes or risk inviting criticism from liberal-minded people outside schools, she said.

In a democracy, students should be given the right to choose their own hairstyle, which is a vital part of school training aimed at teaching students to be responsible members of society by making decisions for themselves and thinking on their own, Fan went on.
In a bulletin issued last month, the MOE has forbidden public elementary and middle schools to regulate hairstyles in any form from the next school semester beginning in September.

The announcement has caused uproar among school principals, many of whom have called it a "travesty of education under the disguise of democracy" and have vowed to maintain their own regulations for what they called "hygiene and health reasons."
Citing education laws, the opponents also argued that hairstyles fall within the school's authority rather than the MOE.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 16 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, August 16:
10:00, The Ministry of Defense will hold a news conference at its Taipei headquarters.
10:30, Premier Frank Hsieh will honor a group of "small consumer protectors" at the Executive Yuan.
10:30, Ministry of Foreign Affairs will give a news briefing at its Taipei headquarters.
10:30, The opposition Kuomintang will present Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou with his certificate of election as party chairman at the party's headquarters.
11:00, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will attend a seminar at National Taiwan University on the privatization of state-owned enterprises.
11:50, Guatemalan President Ocar Berger Perdomo will decorate Premier Frank Hsieh at the Taipei Guest Hall.
16:00, President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu will receive a group of guests who attended the just-concluded Democratic Pacific Union meeting.
16:30, President Chen Shui-bian and Guatemalan President Ocar Berger Perdomo will sign a communique at the Presidential Office.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will give a news briefing at its Taipei headquarters.
17:00, President Chen Shui-bian will see Guatemalan President Ocar Berger Perdomo off with military honors at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 16, or the 12th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: Americans led by Gen. John Stark defeat the British at the Battle of Bennington during the American Revolution.
1825: Bolivia declares its independence from Spain.
1909: Japanese Chutaro Kido discovers an iron mine in Anshan, Liaoning Province, located in Manchuria, where Japan has extensive economic privileges. The Southern Manchuria Railway later sets up a steel plant in Anshan.
1913: Menachem Begin, Israeli prime minister from 1977 to 1983, is born in Russia. He shared the 1978 Nobel Peace Prize with Anwar Sadat of Egypt.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who had participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty, organizes a revolt in Tahu, Hsinchu County, against Japanese rule of Taiwan in the so-called Miaoli Incident. He was executed after the uprising failed.
1923: Lee Kuan Yew, prime minister of Singapore from 1959 to 1990, is born.
1923: Shimon Peres, Israeli prime minister from 1984 to 1986, is born in Poland.
1937: The Supreme National Defense Council decides at a meeting that the Nationalist government should authorize Chiang Kai-shek as generalisimo to lead the Republic of China armed forces in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1948: George Herman Ruth, known as "Babe" Ruth, the most famous baseball player of all time, dies in New York City at the age of 53. He broke the Major League home run record in three consecutive seasons (1919-21), and then again in 1927 with a staggering 60 home runs.
1949: Margaret Mitchell, the author of "Gone with the Wind," dies after being hit by a car two days earlier. She was 49.
1950: Taiwan, formerly comprising eight counties and nine cities, is re-divided into 16 counties and five cities.
1960: The new republic of Cyprus comes into being, with Archbishop Makarios as its first president.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Gabon.
1968: The first Poseidon missile is launched.
1974: Wu Kuan-hsiung, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council, and Ahmad Sowaidi, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of Qatar, sign a trade cooperation memorandum.
1975: The Republic of China and Nauru sign a civil aviation agreement.
1977: Elvis Presley, the king of rock and roll, dies of heart failure at the age of 42 after collapsing in his mansion in Memphis, Tenn.
1978: Cardinal Yu Pin dies of a heart attack in Rome at the age of 77.
1979: John G. Diefenbaker, Canadian politician who served as prime minister from 1957 to 1963, dies at the age of 84. The Progressive Conservative government he headed lost the 1963 general elections because of opposition to his proposals to build nuclear weapons in Canada.
1990: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq warns U.S. President George Bush that thousands of the troops he has sent to the Gulf will return home in coffins.
1996: Leonel Fernandez becomes the 100th president of the Dominican Republic.
1999: Two Republic of China warships, the Hui Yang and the Han Yang, are decommissioned after almost 30 years of service, bringing to 10 the total number of naval vessels decommissioned by the ROC.
2000: Visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation take part in the inauguration of Dominican Republic President Hipolito Mejia held at the Parliament Building.
2000: ROC Premier Tang Fei unveils a proposal to transform Taiwan into a knowledge-based economy that is on par with those of the world's most advanced nations within ten years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In order to acquire truth, it is necessary to obtain a wide and extensive knowledge of what has been said and done in the world; to critically inquire into it; to carefully ponder over it; to clearly sift it; and to earnestly carry it out."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Israel Begins Gaza Pulout. Israeli troops fanned out in the Jewish settlements of the Gaza Strip before dawn today , engaging in scattered clashes with protesters as they inaugurated a landmark withdrawal from the silver of seaside territory Israel has occupied for 38 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Protect the Constitution -- GMA
President Arroyo yesterday ordered newly installed Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) chief of staff Lt. Gen. Generoso Senga to protect the Constitution and the chain of command against groups out to undermine the military's integrity.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Teves: Deferring VAT will hurt poor
DEFERRING the implementation of the 10-percent value-added tax (VAT) amid surging international crude oil prices will just bring more pain to the people, Finance Secretary Margarito "Gary" Teves said yesterday.
The Philippine Star: Senga: Spare AFP from politics
Erstwhile Army chief Lt. Gen. Generoso Senga took over as chief of the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) yesterday and urged soldiers not to get involved in politics as President Arroyo grapples with the most serious crisis to rock her administration.
