MALACAnANG on Monday rejected the proposal of one of its top economic managers to defer the implementation of the expanded value-added tax if the Supreme Court lifts the temporary restraining order on the new law.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Koizumi repeats apology
Marking the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi expressed regret Monday for Japan's past deeds against its Asian neighbors and vowed to make sure they never happen again.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN URGES NICARAGUA TO SIGN FTA WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged Nicaragua Monday to work on signing a free trade agreement with Taiwan as soon as possible, saying that such an agreement is important to the economic and trade development of the two countries.

The president, who made the appeal while receiving Nicaraguan Vice President Rizo Castellon at the Presidential Office, also said that an FTA would contribute significantly to economic and trade cooperation between the two countries as well as help Nicaragua attract Taiwan business investment.

Pointing out that the Taiwan-Panama FTA which came into effect at the beginning of last year has doubled the trade volume between the two countries, Chen said that this proves the importance of such agreements to a nation's economic and trade development.

In response to the appeal, Castellon said that a high-ranking economic affairs official of his country is currently discussing with his counterpart in Taiwan matters related to the signing of an FTA, stressing that Nicaragua can serve as a spring board for Taiwan businesses to expand their markets in the United States after that country signs an FTA with Central American countries.

Saying that he will attend the 5th ROC-Central America Summit scheduled to be held in September in the Nicaraguan capital of Managua, Chen added that he would like to express his gratitude for the Nicaraguan ruling and opposition parties' support and assistance for hosting the meeting.
The president also expressed his gratitude for Nicaragua's longstanding support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TAIWAN CITIZENS INJURED IN EARTHQUAKE IN JAPAN: MOFA

TEXT.P: No Taiwan tourists or expatriates were injured in the magnitude 6.8 earthquake that hit northeastern Japan earlier in the day, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Tuesday.

Lu said the Republic of China's representative office in Tokyo has submitted an initial report to the ministry about the earthquake that shows that no Taiwan citizens or expatriates were injured in the temblor.

According to foreign wire service reports, the quake hit at around 11: 46 a.m. (10: 46 a.m. Taipei Time) and was centered 20 kilometers below the ocean floor about 80 kilometers off the coast of Miyagi prefecture in northeastern Japan.
Authorities in the prefecture were still assessing damage in the area, local government official Masami Oshima said, adding that it was premature to give any estimates on the extent of the damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN-ELECT AIMS AT LEADING PARTY BACK TO POWER IN 2008

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou on Tuesday expressed the hope of creating favorable conditions for the party to be able to return to power in the 2008 presidential election.

Ma made the remarks after receiving his election certificate from Chiu Chuan-huan, chairman of KMT's Central Advisory Committee Presidium at the party's headquarters. Witnessing the ceremony were KMT heavyweights Sun Yun-suan, Hau Pei-tsun, Lee Huan and Chiang Chung-lin.
Ma said he accepts the certificate with humility and a strong sense of mission, expressing appreciation to outgoing Chairman Lien Chan as well as for the support of the party members.
He vowed to make the nearly 110-year-old party a clean, efficient and competitive party, with the hope of making the KMT the best choice for the people.

Ma also said that his running for party chairman was aimed at creating favorable conditions for the party to return to power, adding that the KMT has lost in the last two presidential elections and that it can't afford another defeat.

Chiu said that the KMT, after being swept out of power in 2000, has faced a series of difficulties, expressing the hope that the party, under Ma's leadership, will be able to rise from defeat and move on to victory in the 2008 election.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who was defeated by Ma in the July 16 party chairmanship election, expressed the hope that the party will be even better and win back power under Ma's leadership.

Meanwhile, William Lai, a caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , congratulated Ma on his election and expressed the hope that he will help assuage the rivalry between the ruling and opposition parties.

Addressing Ma's remarks earlier in the day that the public is "in misery" under the rule of the DPP and that they are hoping for the KMT's return to power, Lai said the source of the public's misery is actually the constant bickering between the ruling and the opposition parties in the legislature.

Lai said that because of the inter-party rivalry, such major bills as the NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood-control project, the arms procurement package from the United States and the confirmation of Control Yuan members have been stalled in the legislature.
If Ma continues the boycott mindset of the outgoing KMT Chairman Lien Chan, it will be just "empty talk" to say that he wants to relieve the people's misery, Lai said.
He expressed the hope that the KMT under Ma can engage in rational discussion so that the review process for the long-stalled bills in the legislature can be started.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WISHES ISRAEL, PALESTINE WELL IN GAZA HANDOVER PLAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that if regional peace and stability can be promoted through Israel's withdrawal from Gaza and handing it over to the Palestinians, the world should wish them well.

Commenting on Israel's action to hand over the 278 kilometer strip of land to the Palestinian government, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said that as a member of the global village, Taiwan must be concerned about all major events of the world.

Since the Israeli government started pulling out from Gaza on Monday, both the Israeli and Palestinian governments have been watching carefully, hoping that the plan will be carried out without a hitch so that it will pave the way for the successful creation of a Palestinian state and thus create a new era of Middle East peace, Lu said.
He noted that peaceful means must be pursued to settle any international differences. "Dialogue and negotiations are the way to resolve disputes," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Leaders in Iraq Extend Deadline on Constitution
The Iraqi political process descended toward paralysis on Monday, when leaders failed to meet the deadline for completing the new constitution and voted to give themselves another week to resolve fundamental disagreements over the future and identity of this fractious land. For now, the date for the nationwide referendum on the constitution, Oct. 15, and for parliamentary elections, on Dec. 15, remain unchanged. Yet some Iraqi leaders were already discussing the possibility of dissolving Iraq's National Assembly and holding fresh elections if they fail to agree on a constitution by Monday.
Wall Street Journal: Cash Injection, As Universities Get Billions in Grants, Some See Abuses
Cornell University had received a five-year, US$23 million grant from the National Institutes of Health for a center conducting studies of children's diseases. But several research projects Cornell had said it would carry out existed only on paper. In a statement, Cornell says the a recent case didn't involve any misuse of data or other violations of scientific integrity. The school's lead outside counsel, Stephen Immelt, says the NIH's grant gave Cornell broad discretion in how to spend the money.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAOYUAN WATER CRISIS REVIEW FREE OF POLITICAL CONSIDERATIONS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that the Executive Yuan review of the recent water supply crisis in the northern county of Taoyuan has been "free of any political considerations."

Hsieh made the remarks a day after Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming said that the review of accountability for the Taoyuan water problem should not "sacrifice civil servants" for political reasons.
The premier said he fully agrees with the view that administrative accountability reviews should not be influenced by any political considerations.
"By the same token, we should not hesitate because of political considerations to hold someone accountable for any administrative negligence," he added.

After Typhoon Matsa lashed Taiwan in early August, bringing strong winds and torrential rains, the water supply in Taoyuan was disrupted. The water supply in the northern part of the county was not fully restored until Aug. 13.

At one point during the crisis, Hsieh said, he wondered why no vice minister of economic affairs had come forward to coordinate a government response. Local news media have speculated that the person to be held responsible will be Yiin Chii-ming, a senior vice economic affairs minister responsible for water resources.
Asked whether Yiin will be held accountable, Hsieh only said that the name list of officials to be disciplined over the Taoyuan water crisis will be announced Wednesday.

Three senior officials -- Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, Water Resources Agency (WRA) Chen Shen-hsien and Taiwan Water Corp. Chairman Lee Wen-liang -- have offered to resign over the Taoyuan water problem.

Meanwhile, a former WRA official contributed an article to a local newspaper saying that the water catchment facility atop the Shihmen Reservoir -- Taoyuan's main water supply source -- may eventually cause the Shihmen Reservoir to collapse.
Commenting on the article, Hsieh said a professional assessment is needed to determine whether their is any validity to the former WRA official's concerns.
"Basically, water resources management units see little possibility for such a scenario. Nevertheless, we should keep monitoring and take precautionary measures," Hsieh said.

He further said some catchment facilities are not for regular use and will be reserved for emergency use only. "For example, we are planning to drill wells in preparation for any future droughts or post-disaster relief," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA CONCERNED ABOUT IMPACT OF ARMS DEAL ON CROSS-STRAIT SITUATION

TEXT.P: A legislator said Tuesday that Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou is particularly concerned about the possible impact of the arms procurement package on the cross-Taiwan Strait situation.

Lin Yu-Fang, a legislator from the opposition People First Party (PFP) , who made the remarks in response to a media question, also said that he paid Ma courtesy call Monday during which he also briefed the new KMT head on the ramifications of the arms procurement from the United States.
The arms procurement package put forward by the Ministry of National Defense has been stalled for months by the Legislative Yuan due to opposition by lawmakers of the KMT and the PFP.
According to the ministry, the items on the procurement list include eight diesel-powered submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

During the briefing, Lin said he suggests that Ma pay proper heed to the five important elements of the arms deal -- the island's defensive requirements, price, quantity, reciprocity in industry between the two countries and impact on the cross-strait situation.
Among the five elements, Ma has special concerns about the possible influence of the arms deal on the situation in the Strait, the legislator added.

He further said that Ma and other political leaders of the "pan-blue alliance" should set up a working group to come up with a strategy to deal with the arms procurement issue, although he did not propose during the meeting that Ma do so.
Ma, who is also Taipei mayor, will take over his post as the KMT chairman Aug. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA ACTIVELY PLANNING PUBLICITY CAMPAIGN FOR TAIWAN'S U.N. BID

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is actively planning an international publicity campaign to raise support and concern in the international community for Taiwan's bid to re-enter the United Nations, a spokesman said Tuesday.
MOFA spokesman Michel Lu made the remarks as the U.N. General Assembly is scheduled to open Sept. 13 in New York.

Lu noted that President Chen Shui-bian made the case for Taiwan's U.N. bid in an interview with the United Nations Correspondents Association (UNCA) in New York via teleconference last September, which he said has borne fruit.
Lu didn't respond directly if there will be a similar teleconference with the UNCA as last year, which was held after strong obstruction from Beijing.
Lu said Taiwan will adopt a new strategy in promoting its bid to join the United Nations by presenting two cases for U.N. participation.

Under the new strategy, 14 Republic of China allies have put forward two proposals to U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan, urging the U.N. General Assembly to affirm U.N. representation for the 23 million people of Taiwan and requesting that the U.N. play an active role in safeguarding peace in the Taiwan Strait.
Lu noted that Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen said recently that "we have not done enough in our publicity campaigns before, and this time, we'll have to work harder."
On the progress of the publicity campaign for the U.N. bid, Lu only said that related government agencies are now planning the details.

He also said that the ministry will engage in good communications, including letting the international community know why it has to let Taiwan join the United Nations and why it is unfair to shut the island out of the body, and will also point out the importance to the U.N. members of the organization helping to safeguard peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Lu said that the publicity campaign will be conducted through the channels of ROC missions overseas, international media and the U.N. General Assembly where world leaders will converge for the gathering.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRACY THIELE ASSUMES HEAD OF AIT KAOHSIUNG BRANCH

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) announced Tuesday that Tracy Thiele took up her duties as the chief of the American Institute in Taiwan Kaohsiung branch office Aug. 8.
Thiele, who graduated from Chatham College with a dual major in history and political science, joined the U.S. Foreign Service in 1990.

She first served with the United States Information Agency (1990-1999) , and then became an employee of the U.S. Department of State in 2000. Prior to joining AIT, she spent a year as a National Security Affairs Fellow at the Hoover Institution, Stanford University.

While overseas with the United States Information Agency, she served as the Public Affairs Officer at the U.S. Embassy in Hanoi, Vietnam (1998-2000) ; as the Assistant Public Affairs Officer at the U.S. Embassy in Singapore (1993-97); and as the Branch Public Affairs Officer at the U.S. Consulate in Chengdu, Sichuan province, People's Republic of China (1991-93).

Thiele's domestic assignments for the State Department have included positions in Washington on the Board of Examiners (2002-2003) and in the Office of Public Diplomacy, Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs (2000-2002).
Thiele is the recipient of a Department of State Superior Honor Award and of two Meritorious Honor Awards from the United States Information Agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CALLS JAPANESE PM'S APOLOGY 'CONSTRUCTIVE'

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman on Tuesday praised Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's apology made a day earlier for Japan's atrocities committed during World War II as a positive and constructive move.

At a televised service to honor Japan's estimated 3 million war dead, Koizumi expressed "deep reflection and heartfelt apology" for Japan's wartime aggression and pledged that his country would never forget the "terrible lessons" of the war, which ended Aug. 15, 1945.

Commenting on Koizumi's words, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said at a routine news conference in Taipei that he believes "history is a mirror which allows people to see clearly the consequences of a deed."
Koizumi's apology and his decision not to visit the controversial Yasukumi Shrine in Tokyo are moves with a "diplomatic meaning, " Lu said.
He noted that Japan recovered quickly from its defeat in WWII and that it now makes great contributions to the world in politics, economics, technology and peace.

In the era of globalization, all countries should seek cooperation and partnerships with others, he said, adding that although the lessons of the past should always be kept in mind, people should still take a broad view of the future and make efforts to seek for common benefits.

He indicated Taiwan has been sparing no efforts to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait region. Under the efforts, Taiwan hopes for Japan's continued involvement and cooperation in the region's security and the maintenance of peace, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 2.73 points to close at 6,242.4.
The bourse opened at 6,262.87 and fluctuated between 6,266.33 and 6,207.58 during trading. A total of 2.77 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$64.58 billion (US$2.01 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up at 0.2 percent.

Seven other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by construction issues at 1 percent, cement stocks at 0.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent and textile stocks and banking and financial shares both at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 525 to 323, with 161 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for August moved down five points to close at 6,235, with 22,290 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for September moved down one point to end at 6,238, with 16,769 contracts traded, while December futures lost 31 points to finish at 6,190, with 16 contracts traded. March futures moved up nine points to close at 6,235, with four contracts traded, while June futures moved down 33 points to close at 6,206, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,240 for August, 6,239 for September, 6,221 for December, 6,226 for March and 6,239 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

August TE futures moved up 0.25 points to close at 257.6, with 3,569 contracts traded, while September TE futures gained 0.2 points to finish at 257.2, with 3,068 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 1.45 points to end at 255.8, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

August TF futures remained unchanged at 964.6, with 2,711 contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved down three points to end at 961.8, with 2,655 contracts traded. March TF futures moved down 2.4 points to close at 960, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Israelis begin to withdraw from Gaza Strip.
Isreali settlers began to withdraw from Gaza Strip Monday. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon described the pullout as a painful but essential step for Israel's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Armed police patrol trains.
Curious stares followed the four men as they walked through the train carriage.
The passengers were gawking at their uniforms -- dark blue shirts and trousers and blue berets -- and the Taurus revolvers that were hanging on their hips.
That's because yesterday marked the first day of patrols by the Police MRT Unit (PMU), adding another layer of security to Singapore's Mass Rapid Transit system.
The Lianhe Zaobao: The PMU begins MRT patrols.
The Police MRT Unit (PMU), set up to handle security incidents on the MRT system by Singapore Police Force began, have begun their patrols.
While patrols by police officers at MRT stations are not new, these officers from the Police MRT Unit have been specially selected and trained to deal with security incidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMUGGLING, POACHING STILL RAMPANT NEAR OFFSHORE ISLANDS: MAC

TEXT.P: Intrusions and poaching by Chinese fishing boats and smuggling in waters near Taiwan's Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu islands remain rampant, although Taiwan has asked the Chinese side to improve the situation, a spokesman for the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials said late Monday.

According to the MAC official, the council has a good understanding of the issue and it has requested the Straits Exchange Foundation to relay its stance to the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to avoid unnecessary conflict. However, limited improvements have been made so far, he said.

Even though the situation is somewhat improved, the root cause remains, he acknowledged, pointing out that the MAC and the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) will discuss countermeasures with the local island authorities to stem illegal activities, such as poaching and smuggling, arising from the "mini three links" maintained between Kinmen and Matsu and China.

Since the direct trade and transport links were set up in January 2001 between Taiwan-held Kinmen and Matsu islands and China's Fujian ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou, commonly known as the "mini three link, " more and more Chinese fishing vessels have poached or smuggled in waters near Taiwan's remote islands, including Matsu, which lies closer to Fujian than to Taiwan proper.

The "mini three links" were established in part to help put an end to illegal trade between the two sides, but the situation has deteriorated and become more complicated since the opening, Matsu residents said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI POLL TO LEARN ABOUT APPROVAL RATING FOR LAW AND ORDER

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) is conducting a second round of surveys to gauge the public's feeling over the past three months about law and order.
The results will indicate if local governments' resolve to improve the situation around the island have succeeded, MOI officials said.
The poll will be conducted between Aug. 17 and 26, and the results will be published in September, the officials added.

The MOI last conducted a poll May 20-28 on the approval rating of social order in Taiwan's 23 cities and counties between March and May that showed that the average approval rating was 55.86 percent, although over half of the cities and counties had an approval rating of more than 60 percent.
The top three counties with the highest approval ratings were Penghu, Taitung and Ilan in that order, while the lowest approval ratings were in Taichung City, Taipei County, and Taichung County.

The Executive Yuan invited local chiefs earlier this year to meet and join a campaign to improve social order on the island and the poll was one of the results of the efforts put forth by various cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMERS MUST UNITE TO PROTECT RIGHTS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said at a Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) award presentation ceremony Tuesday in Taipei that consumers must stand united to defend their rights.

The ceremony was for winners of a writing contest organized by the CPC under the Executive Yuan in which elementary school students were invited to submit compositions on the topics of wise shopping and how consumers can protect their rights.

Echoing the spirit of the contest, Hsieh pointed out that consumers should unite to counter surging vegetable prices. "If consumers collectively refuse to buy onions for three days, then onion prices will immediately drop to NT$10," he said.

Vegetable supplies have been affected by two major typhoons this summer that have hit the island's agricultural sector hard. Many consumers have criticized the government for failing to address skyrocketing prices and urged it to deal with the problem immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ANNOUNCE CASE CLOSED ON 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: The Supreme Prosecutor's Office will announce Wednesday that the case involving the March 19, 2004 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu is closed.
The Supreme Prosecutor's Office said Tuesday it will hold a news conference at the Judicial Yuan building at 10:00 a.m. Wednesday with State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao presiding.

Key members of the ad hoc investigative group, including Liu Wei-tzung, a former Tainan district chief prosecutor, directors Wang Sen-jung and Kuo Chen-ni of the Tainan District Court Prosecutors' Office, Commissioner Hou You-yi of the Criminal Investigation Bureau of the Ministry of the Interior, and forensic medical expert Shih Tai-ping, will also be present.

They will explain to the media how investigation into the shooting was done, the process of double-checking the evidence, the facts and all data related to the evidence. They will also take questions from the media.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAR THEFT RING HITS DEAD END IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Police in Kaohsiung City busted a car theft ring Tuesday and arrested six suspects who allegedly stole more than 30 cars throughout Taiwan and exported the disassembled parts in containers to China.

A police spokesman said the ringleader, surnamed Wu, 38, and five other suspects were arrested at the Kaohsiung Linyuan Industrial Park, where they had set up a chop shop. Police officers who discovered the operation said they were surprised to learn that the car thieves could take apart a car in only half an hour.
The police found that some of the car parts had already been sold in China, netting a profit of more than NT$10 million for the group. The parts were labeled as "materials for recycling."
According to police, Honda CRV sport utility vehicles were the cars of choice because of the great demand for them in China.
The suspects also said that they looked forward to typhoon days to target cars since most people were indoors taking cover.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.026 to close at NT$31.992.
A total of US$1.03 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.998 and fluctuated between NT$31.970 and NT$32.030.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS IN NEIHU AND NANKANG SCIENCE PARKS REACHES NT$1.69 TRILLION

TEXT.P: Business transactions in Taipei's Neihu and Nankang science parks totaled NT$1.69 trillion (US$52.9 billion) last year, with the number of employees reaching 85,400 by the end of May, according to statistics from Taipei City Government.

An official from the Taipei City Government's Bureau of Commerce and Economy said that the employees hired in these two science parks were engaged in manufacturing, wholesaling and retailing, as well as technology services.
In the Neihu science park alone, business transactions reached NT$1.51 trillion last year, an increase of 29 percent over the previous year, with the number of employees totalling 73,300.

The employees hired for manufacturing, wholesaling and retailing, as well as technology services accounted for 80 percent of the total number of the employees hired in the Neihu science park, with their transactions accounting for 90 percent of the total.
Meanwhile, the transactions in the Nankang Software Park totaled NT$170 billion in 2004, with the number of employees reaching 12,000.
The official noted that the main attractions of the two science parks are their sound infrastructures, convenient transport, low cost for land and buildings, and high potential for expansion.
However, entrepreneurs with operations in the two science parks also asked for more shuttle buses, convenient living facility and incentives for their operations, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS TWO MEDALS IN 2005 UNIVERSIADE IN TURKEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan won its first medals -- a gold and a bronze -- Tuesday in the 2005 World University Games, also known as the Universiade, which is taking place in Izmir, Turkey.

Huang Yi-hsue, 23, a graduate school student at National College of Physical Education and Sports won the gold medal in the men's vault. It was the first medal win for Taiwan at the Games, and before Huang, no Taiwan athlets have ever gained a Universiade gold medal.
Lin Hsiang-wei, 20, from National Taiwan Normal University took the bronze medal in the men's pommel horse. He finished sixth in the same event in the 2003 Universiade in Daegu, South Korea.
The event will run from Aug. 11 through Aug. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TCHOUKBALL ASSOCIATION VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An elementary school tchoukball team, led by Hong Kong Tchoukball Association (HKTA) Deputy Chairman Wong Wing Yip, arrived in Kaohsiung Tuesday for a series of training sessions and friendlies with local teams.
Wong and the team's nine players were greeted by Huang Ching-cheng, secretary-general to the Asia Tchoukball Association (ATA) in Taiwan, upon their arrival at the Kaohsiung International Airport.

The Hong Kong team is scheduled to play two friendlies with the local schools during their three-day stay in Taiwan. It will also receive training from famous coach Fan Shen-sz Thursday at Yuanchung Elementary School in Kaohsiung City.

Wong said the HKTA admires Taiwan's success as a leading tchoukball team in the international arena, and that it organized several summer camps, including their visit to Taiwan, for children to explore the world of tchoukball since June this year. The HKTA will also hold its first tchoukball championships on Aug. 20 this year, Wong added.
Taiwan has been promoting tchoukball games since 1980 and won last year's Brandt Cup International Youth Tchoukball Championship. Seven countries have sent their teams to learn from the Taiwan side.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT OFFICIALS TO OFFER CONSULAR SERVICES IN TAICHUNG AUG. 24

TEXT.P: The United States' representative office on the island, the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), will open a "mini branch" in Taichung, central Taiwan, on Aug. 24 to deal with consular operations, according to the AIT's news release Tuesday.

The news release reminded American citizens wishing to file applications for U.S. passports or to add pages to U.S. passports, and all persons requiring the services of a notary public for U.S. purposes, may come to the American Corner located in the National Taichung Library at 291-3, Jingwu Road, Taichung City from 9: 00 am to 11: 00 am for these services.

For those people who want to know any detailed information on the AIT's citizen services, they can contact the AIT's Taipei Office at 02-2162-2000 ext. 2306, or visit the institute's Web site at http: //www.ait.org.tw/en/uscitizens/. AIT has two offices in the country, which are the Taipei office in northern Taiwan and the Kaohsiung office in the southern part of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER STANDS BEHIND DECISION TO STEP DOWN

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Tuesday she it is appropriate for her to take political responsibility for the water shortages in Taoyuan County.
Ho submitted her resignation to Premier Frank Hsieh Monday over the ministry's failure to keep water supplies flowing to residents in Taoyuan after recent typhoons.
Top officials at the ministry's Water Resources Agency and Taiwan Water Corp. have also tendered their resignations.
Hsieh is expected to announce Wednesday who should be culpable for the problem.

Ho told the media that the issue of muddy water in the Shihmen Reservoir, which supplies water to area households, is not simple as upstream landslides are apparently one of the causes for the water shortages.
She said her ministry had put forward a set of measures to solve the muddy water issue last year, which supposedly would also work for this year's typhoon-related problems.

"However, " she said, "things are not that simple, as one typhoon after another, such as Haitang and Matsa, forced us to realize that more back-up systems and facilities were needed to really solve the problem."

She stressed that this year the island has been confronted with "complicated and dynamic" situations, adding, "I cannot assure that if a typhoon were to hit tomorrow, we would not have to go into water-rationing mode."

She said the Water Resources Agency and Taiwan Water Corp. did their utmost to prepare for the aftermath of typhoons by taking the best possible technical measures to ensure normal water supplies for the people of Taoyuan.

Still, people expect the government not to let them down, she said. Now that the ministry has failed the people and created an "expectation gap," she said accepting the political responsibility is something that is "very appropriate for her to do."
She insisted that her policy decisions and recommendations for solving the problem were correct. Now, having tendered her resignation, she said she felt "very good."

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH OIL PRICES MAKE ECONOMIC GROWTH PREDICTIONS HARD TO ACHIEVE

TEXT.P: It will be difficult for Taiwan to maintain its expected 3 percent economic growth if the average oil price of this year exceeds US$60 per barrel, a researcher from the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) said Tuesday.

Oil prices hit a high of US$67 per barrel on the international market recently, with the International Energy Agency cautioning that an average oil price above the level of US$50 will drag down global economic growth by 0.8 percent.

TIER researcher Yang Chia-yen estimated that if the average oil price registers US$50 per barrel this year, which will represent an increase of 35 percent over last year, Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) will decrease by NT$15.93 billion (US$499 million) , with the economic growth for the year declining from the 3.31 percent originally estimated by TIER to 3.15 percent.

Under this situation, the volume of Taiwan's exports will shrink by NT$8.61 billion this year, a decrease of 0.12 percent over 2004, while the price of imports will increase by NT$10.64 billion, a growth of 0.16 percent.

However, if the average oil price tops US$60 per barrel this year, an increase of 62 percent over last year, Taiwan's GDP will decrease by NT$25.17 billion, with economic growth dropping from the originally expected 3.31 percent to 3.06 percent

If this happens, the volume of Taiwan's exports will decrease by NT$13.6 billion, or an annual drop of 0.2 percent, while the price of its imports will increase by NT$16.81 billion, a growth of 0.26 percent over last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO KEEP AN EYE ON UPCOMING CHINA-RUSSIA WAR GAMES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will closely monitor China-Russia war games scheduled to start Thursday, military spokesman Liu Chih-chien said Tuesday.
In his view, Liu said, the maneuvers are a step short of a joint military exercise because they will not have a common command platform.
Judging from the number of troops and high-tech military equipment to be mobilized by Russia in the drills, Liu said, the event is mainly aimed at showing off Russia's advanced arsenal.
The drills are also designed to deepen the two countries' mutual trust and beef up their abilities to fight terrorism, Liu added.

The unusual joint exercises will run until Aug. 25, Liu said. They will be conducted in three stages, including a computerized war simulation at the Russian port of Vladivostok, anti-terrorist maneuvers and amphibious landing on China's Jiaodong peninsula.
Meanwhile, the U.S. government said Monday it hopes the exercises will not de-stabilize the region.
State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said that both Beijing and Moscow had informed Washington about the exercises.
"We are following the exercises," McCormack said. "We expect them to be conducted in a manner that supports some mutual goal of regional stability shared by the United States, China and Russia."

McCormack further said the United States will not have any observers at the war games. "But we would hope that anything that they do is not something that would be disruptive to the current atmosphere in the region," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO KIDD-CLASS DESTROYERS EXPECTED TO JOIN NAVY BY YEAR'S END

TEXT.P: Two of four Kidd-class destroyers purchased from the United States are expected to be delivered to Taiwan by the end of the year, an official of Navy General Headquarters said Tuesday.

Rear Adm. Lee Hao, deputy chief of staff for Combat Readiness and Training, made the remarks at a press conference held at the Ministry of National Defense to explain the progress of the four destroyers purchased at a cost of NT$24 billion in June 2003.

Lee said that military officers and seed instructors, as well as repair and maintenance technicians are receiving training in the United States to prepare for the delivery of the two de-mothballed destroyers, which are undergoing sea trials and weaponry system tests.
The ships are entering the final tactical test and evaluation stage and are scheduled to undergo SM-2 fire tests in October and depart from the U.S. in early November.
The other two destroyers are expected by March 2007.

Lee said the navy hopes that after the commissioning of the four destroyers, they will form the outer peripheral of the fleet, while the navy's Perry-class, Knox-class and Lafayette-class frigates will play an inner circle role.
The Kidd-class destroyers will target enemy planes that have fired missiles, leaving other vessels to deal with the incoming missiles.

The Taiwan authorities submitted a shopping list in 2001 that included top-of-the-line U.S. destroyers of the Arleigh Burke class equipped with the Aegis radar system, but the Bush administration later approved the sale of only the much older Kidd-class destroyers.

The purchase was embroiled in a fierce debate. Opponents of the purchase included members of the legislature's powerful defense committee, which made several attempts to block the sale. Critics cited ships' age -- they were built in the late 1970s -- and their high cost, and suggested that Taiwan should push the U.S. to release the Aegis system sooner.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALA SEEKING TAIWAN'S HELP IN INVESTIGATING CORRUPTION CASE

TEXT.P: Guatemalan President Ocar Berger Perdomo said here Tuesday that his government has formally requested help from the government of Taiwan in investigating an alleged corruption case involving former Guatemalan President Alfonso Portillo.

In an interview with the CNA, Berger disclosed that his government has gone through diplomatic channels to ask the government to provide detailed information about three donations it made to the Guatemalan government in 2000.

Berger, who is visiting Taiwan to attend the inaugural conference of the Democratic Pacific Union, said Guatemalan Foreign Minister Jorge Briz Abularach, who is with Berger on the trip, has delivered a note from the justice department of Guatemala, asking the government to specify to whom the three checks were made payable, on what dates the checks were issued and for what purposes.
After receiving the information, the justice department of Guatemala will determine whether it is necessary to prosecute Portillo, Berger said.
Taiwan donated three checks totaling US$1.5 million through its ambassador to Guatemala about five years ago.

Taiwanese ambassador to Guatemala Francisco Ou acknowledged early this year that US$500,000 was donated to Guatemala in June 2000 to print teachers' manuals and that the check was made out to Portillo personally at the request of the Guatemalan government.
Ou also said that after the donation, the Guatemalan government gave several copies of the teachers' manuals to the embassy as proof that the money had been used properly.
Portillo, who was Guatemala's president from 2000, fled to Mexico in February 2004 amid corruption charges against him.

The public prosecutor's office of Guatemala issued a warrant for Portillo's arrest in July. He is wanted over the disappearance of US$15.7 million earmarked for the defense ministry. He has denied all the allegations, saying that he fled because he could not get a fair trial in Guatemala.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARGO LINKS MUST NOT HINDER PASSENGER SERVICES: KMT OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By C. Y. Liao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Bilateral talks on Taiwan-China charter cargo links must not hinder the opening of direct charter passenger services between the two sides that took place for the Chinese New Year holiday early this year, a Kuomintang (KMT) official said here Tuesday.

Tseng Yung-chuan, the head of the Taiwan's main opposition party's Central Policy Committee who led a KMT group to clear the way for negotiations in Beijing on charter airlinks with Chinese civil aviation officials, made the remarks during a meeting with Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council.

Although the KMT hopes to help cross-Taiwan Strait cargo flights take off as soon as possible, Tseng pointed out, however, that the party does not want to see passenger services affected by the ongoing cargo talks during the approach of the Sept. 18 Moon Festival -- a major traditional holiday for Chinese around the world to return home and get together with their families.

As long as charter passenger flights are in place, it would help if some cargo transport could be carried out, Tseng said, suggesting that China allow Dalian, Beijing, Shanghai, Nanjing, Guangzhou, Xiamen, Xian and Chengdu to have direct links with Taiwan.

KMT Legislator John Chiang further proposed that the two sides ply "cross-strait tourist charter flights, " recommending links from Beijing, Shanghai, Dalian, Qingdao, Guangzhou, Wuhan, Chongqing, Nanjing, Xian, Hainan Island and Urumqi.
He also called for the opening of point-to-point shipping links between Taiwan and Shanghai and Shenzhen on the grounds that the two sides should program their cargo and shipping links as a whole.
According to Chiang, it is very important to have charter services in place for Taiwan businessmen on the day of the Moon Festival.

He claimed this would mark the "very first step" toward the realization of direct cross-strait charter passenger services for Taiwan businessmen on weekends and major holidays prior to the eventual opening of full links.
In fact, charter flights have operated for two previous Chinese New Year holidays. The first such cross-strait charter flights were made with stopovers in Hong Kong or Macau.

It is understood that the Chinese side only showed willingness to increase destinations and broaden the service scope beyond Taiwan businessmen for charter passenger services in the talks, sources said, adding that Chinese officials decided to discuss the tourist charter service proposal with Taipei Airlines Association representatives at a later date.
The association was appointed again by the Taiwan government as its proxy to conduct direct charter links with China.

Premier Frank Hsieh announced early this month that the Taiwan government is willing to hold bilateral talks simultaneously on direct charter passenger flights and cargo service with China amid repeated calls from the private sector.

Hsieh's announcement marked a compromise by Taiwan over the cross-strait direct transport issue, over which Beijing was only willing to talk about charter passenger flights initially despite Taiwan's desire to first talk about the cargo links to serve Taiwan businessmen operating in China.

The Taiwan government's change in attitude on the issue was made in part out of a consideration to meet potential strong demand for passenger services due to a planned opening to tourists from China. The opening is expected to help boost Taiwan's economy and create many businesses and job opportunities.
The KMT group, which had no authority from the elected government to represent Taiwan in the talks with China, is slated to fly back to Taiwan later the same day after concluding the talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VICE MINISTER HEADS FOR JAPAN TO LURE INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming left for Japan Tuesday at the head of a ministerial group to woo Japanese investment in Taiwan, according to a ministry spokesman.

The group is slated to visit prominent Japanese companies including SONY, NEC, Fujitsu, Chisso, QB Net, Showa Denko, Asahi Glass and various leading research institutes before returning to Taiwan Saturday, the spokesman said.

Apart from seeking to bolster bilateral investment and promote two-way technology cooperation, the official said the ministry will send a trade promotion and investment-boosting group to the United States in the fourth quarter of this year.
The ministry also is planning to set up a unit to take charge of recruiting foreign capital from around the world by offering more handsome incentives.
Japan has always been one of Taiwan's major trading partners, with the neighboring country enjoying a large amount of trade surplus with Taiwan every year over a long term.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Disease Tests for Expats Reviewed
Facing an uproar from foreigners who are being required to be tested for leprosy and five other diseases to obtain work permits, the government has expanded the number of clinics permitted to carry out the tests and is reviewing the new rules altogether.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, GUATEMALA EXPECTED TO INK FREE TRADE ACCORD BEFORE OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Visiting Guatemalan President Oscar Berger said Tuesday that he expects a Taiwan-Guatemala free trade accord (FTA) to be signed in September or October.
Berger made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the CNA.

As soon as the FTA is passed by the legislatures of the two nations, it will be submitted for signing, he said, adding that a summit meeting between the Republic of China and its Central American allies that will be held in Nicaragua in September will be a good occasion for the signing.
Berger said Guatemala looks forward to the FTA as it will reduce the country's large trade deficit with Taiwan.
Guatemala exports about US$4 million-worth of products to Taiwan annually, while Taiwan's exports to the Central American country have reached over US$100 million, he said.

Berger arrived in Taiwan Aug. 14 for the inaugural conference of the Democratic Pacific Union. He left Tuesday after signing a communique with President Chen Shui-bian that states the cooperative plans of the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Roberts Unlikely To Face Big Fight; Many Democrats See Battle as Futile.
Democrats have decided that unless there is an unexpected development in the weeks ahead, they will not launch a major fight to block the Supreme Court nomination of John G. Roberts Jr., according to legislators, Senate aides and party strategists.

DOC.HEADLINE: WAN-AN AIR-RAID DRILL TO BE HELD IN CENTRAL TAIWAN WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: An air-raid drill will be held in central Taiwan Wednesday as part of the annual Wan-An series of civil defense exercises, the, Ministry of National Defense announced Tuesday.
The exercise, code-named Wan An 28, aims to test city and county governments' abilities to respond to such emergencies as fires, terrorist attacks and nuclear incidents, the ministry said.

The air-raid drill will start at 2 p.m. simultaneously in eight cities and counties in the central part of the island, including Taichung City, Taichung County, Changhua County, Nantou County, Miaoli County, Yunlin County and Chiayi County, the ministry said.

During the drill, all cars and passengers must follow police directions to take shelter. Trains and mass rapid transit cars will run as usual, but alighting passengers will have to evacuate to designated places.
Freeway traffic will be controlled at all entrances -- only exiting will be permitted and no cars will be allowed to enter the freeway.

Civilian airliners will take off and land as usual, but again, alighting passengers will have to follow police directions to designated shelter area. At seaports, all docking ships will have to remain silent.
Public offices and private businesses will operate as usual, except that all doors and windows will have to be shut and the people inside the buildings will have to remain inside.
Those who do not follow police orders during the exercise will be slapped with fines ranging between NT$30,000 (US$937) and NT$150,000 (US$4,686).
Similar drills took place in the outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu in July and early August. A drill scheduled for that time in northern Taiwan was postponed due to a typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEW SUSPECTS IN 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: As the government prepares to announce the closure of the case involving the March 19, 2004 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, the police investigation has concluded that Tainan resident Chen Yi-hsiung remains the main suspect.

The government still needs to convince the public how it is sure that Chen killed himself 10 days after committing the crime. The government will also need to explain how the police are sure about the gun the suspect used to fire two shots at the president and the vice president, despite not having found the weapon.
Chen, 63, was found dead in Anping harbor in Tainan City March 29, 2004.

The Supreme Prosecutor's Office will make public a 100,000-word report Wednesday that is divided into two parts, one on forensic examinations and the other on the criminal investigation, senior police officers said.
Investigators claim they were right to have "traced the two bullets to the (type of) gun that fired them" and then have "traced the (type of) gun to the man that fired the two shots."

Chinese American forensic expert Henry Lee, whose expertise the government has sought to help resolve the case, has pointed out that the police would have done a more convincing job if they could have found the gun that they claim Chen used.

Police probes and interviews have found that Chen was disgruntled with the nation's politics, so he planned to vent his anger through the shooting, but then committed suicide for fear of facing the justice system.
The so-called "facts and evidence" about his actions appear to belie the opposition theory that the president staged the shooting incident in a bid to swing the election results.

The election-eve shooting has polarized the nation, as the defeated "pan-blue alliance" candidates filed lawsuits to claim the vote invalid and opposition lawmakers pushed through a special committee to investigate the truth behind the shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGED NOT TO HURT NATIONAL INTERESTS IN ENGAGEMENTS WITH CPC

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should exercise prudence and self-restraint in its engagements with the Communist Party of China (CPC) to avoid hurting Taiwan's national interests, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Tuesday.
MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung made the call after outgoing KMT Chairman Lien Chan announced earlier in the day that the KMT and the CPC will begin party-to-party cadre exchanges from late August.

According to Lien, exchange programs between KMT cadres in six cities, including Keelung, Taichung and Tainan and their CPC counterparts from six Chinese cities, including Fuzhou, Ningpo and Xiamen, will be launched in the first stage of KMT-CPC exchanges. The second stage will include KMT cadres from 10 cities, with the third-stage extending to Taipei City and Kaohsiung City.
In the face of the upcoming exchanges, You said the MAC must remind the KMT and the general public that the CPC is not a democratic party.

"The CPC is a communist totalitarian party that has wielded one-party despotic rule in China for 56 years, " You said. The CPC defeated the KMT in a bloody civil war in the late 1940s, forcing the KMT to flee to Taiwan in 1949.

Referring to the KMT-CPC exchanges as engagements between Taiwan's opposition party and the People's Republic of China's (PRC's) ruling party, You said the KMT should be prudent in dealing with the CPC, as the PRC remains hostile toward Taiwan.

"We hope the KMT will put national interests and the people's well-being above its own partisan interests in its engagements with the Chinese communists, " You said, adding that the MAC will keep an eye on the exchanges in light of national interests and legal provisions.

Meanwhile, William Lai, a legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said the exchanges are part of the KMT's strategy to reclaim power in Taiwan in the 2008 presidential election and bears no relevance to Taiwan's development.

"It seems to me that the KMT has forgotten how it lost control of the Chinese mainland. While forging cooperative ties with the CPC under its 'Chinese-centered ideology, ' the KMT is believed to continue its antagonistic strategy toward the DPP administration and its boycotting of the DPP's policy initiatives at every turn, " Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TRADE FAIR TO PROMOTE EXPORTS OF TAIWAN-GROWN FRUIT

TEXT.P: A trade fair to promote exports of Taiwan-grown fruit will open Aug. 19 at the Taipei World Trade Center under the joint sponsorship of the Council of Agriculture (COA) and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).
Fruit growers and suppliers from 21 counties and cities will display a wide range of summer fruits, including mangoes, papayas, lychees, guavas, pineapples, grapefruit, star fruit and bell fruit.
A COA spokesman said the exhibition is intended to help Taiwan's fruit growers and suppliers establish long-standing business relationships with major foreign importers.

TAITRA's overseas offices in Northeast Asia and Southeast Asia have invited potential buyers from Japan, South Korea, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore to the exhibition, according to a TAITRA spokesman.
He said a total of 101 one-on-one meetings have been arranged between fruit suppliers and their potential customers.

Among the foreign import companies invited to send representatives to the show are the Union Co. in Tokyo, which bought US$300.7 million-worth of fruit last year; Jinwon Trading Co. of South Korea, whose fruit sales reached US$18 million in 2004; China Resources Vanguard Co. in Hong Kong, which sold US$2.96 billion-worth of fruit last year; and Indonesia's largest fruit store, Anugerah Buana Utama, which imports 300-400 containers of fruit every year, the TAITRA spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO BEGIN EXCHANGES WITH COMMUNIST PARTY OF CHINA

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Tuesday that his party will begin soon cadre exchanges with the Communist Party of China (CPC) , the party that defeated the KMT in a civil war in China, causing the KMT to move to Taiwan in 1949.

Lien said the exchanges will be in three stages, with the first beginning in late August between KMT cadres in six counties and cities, including Keelung City, Taichung City and Tainan City and CPC cadres from six Chinese cities, including Ningbo, Fuzhou and Xiamen.
The second-stage will include KMT cadres from 10 counties and cities, with the third-stage extending to Taipei City and Kaohsiung City.

The movement is the follow-up of a historic visit by Lien to China in late April, where he met with CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao and agreed with Hu to strengthen ties between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.
Lien and Hu also promised to promote a cross-strait peace accord and a common market, as well as a KMT-CPC cooperation platform with bilateral dialogue every half year in China or Taiwan.
Lien expressed hope that the KMT-CPC cadre exchanges will not only be aimed at strengthening communications and friendship, but will also promote cross-strait exchanges in culture and goods.
Lien added that the three-stage visits are just a beginning and that further exchange programs will follow.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO SUPPORT ARMS PURCHASE IF GOVERNMENT MAKES THE BUDGET CLEAR

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Tuesday that the KMT will support an adequate arsenal for Taiwan as long as the government makes the arms procurement budget clearer.

Lien made the remarks in an apparent attempt to counter President Chen Shui-bian, who told an Australian daily recently that Lien opposes everything Chen does due to his being defeated twice by Chen in presidential elections.

The government plans to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the U.S. with a special military budget of NT$480 billion.

Lien, who has served as premier and vice president, claimed that he does not oppose the arms purchase, "evidenced" by his approval of several missile and submarine procurement plans during his tenure as premier.

According to Lien, the "first thing" was when former U.S. President Bill Clinton was unwilling to agree to the arms sale to Taiwan during the KMT administration, followed by what he claimed was the "exaggerated rise" of the special military budget from NT$280 billion to NT$480, with the figure once surging to NT$610.8 billion.
In addition, the outcome of a referendum on Taiwan's self defense held along with last year's presidential election vetoed the idea that Taiwan purchase anti-missile weaponry, Lien claimed.

In the referendum, the voters were asked whether the government should acquire more advanced anti-missile weapons and whether the government should engage in negotiations with China on the establishment of a peace and stability framework for cross-strait interactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, GUATEMALAN HEADS OF STATE EXCHANGE PLEDGES OF SUPPORT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and his Guatemalan counterpart Ocar Berger Perdomo pledged to support each other Tuesday in a comunique signed at the end of Berger's visit to Taiwan.
In the comunique, Berger reiterated his country's support for Taiwan's bids to enter various international organizations, and invited Chen to visit Guatemala.
Meanwhile, Chen pledged to help Guatemala to develop a highway network. The first phase of the three-phase project is already underway, according to the comunique.

The two heads of state expressed satisfaction with the progress of bilateral talks on a free trade agreement, pledging to do their best to get the results of the talks approved by their respective legislatures as soon as possible.
They also agreed to beef up bilateral transportation by air and sea, promote bilateral trade, tourism and economic growth, and enter into wide-ranging and more effective cooperation.

After the inking of the comunique, Chen bade farewell to Berger and his entourage with military honors at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, although Berger was not scheduled to leave until the following morning.
Berger arrived in Taiwan Aug. 13 for a five day visit during which he gave a speech at the inauguration of the Democratic Pacific Union on Aug. 14 and met with various government leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CALLS FOR EARLY START TO CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT TALKS

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday it hopes China will honor its promise to start talks with Taiwan as soon as possible on the opening of charter cargo and passenger flights across the Taiwan Strait.

The MAC made the remarks after Chen Yulin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, said earlier in the day that cross-strait charter cargo and passenger flight talks can be conducted in line with the formula set forth in the previous "Macau talks" that led to the opening of 48 direct cross-strait passenger flights during the Chinese New Year holiday earlier this year for Taiwan businessmen operating in China -- known locally as "taishang" -- to return for festival celebrations.

The Cabinet-level council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward China, said in a news release that it has commissioned the Taipei Airlines Association to contact its Chinese counterpart on the arrangements for bilateral talks on technical details regarding the proposed direct charter cargo and passenger flights.

The MAC said it has also joined forces with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to map out steps to pave the way for direct cross-strait charter flights on a regular basis and passenger flights during major holiday periods or other special occasions.

As issues to be addressed in the proposed talks are far more complicated than those involved in the Lunar New Year charter flights, a senior MAC official said, it is hoped that more relevant officials can be allowed to take part in the negotiations.

"It would be perfect if MAC officials could be allowed to take part in the talks. Should that be the case, more topics can be discussed, " said Fu Dong-cheng, director of the MAC's economic affairs department.
In the "Macau talks, " only civil aviation officials, including Chang Kuo-cheng, director of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, were allowed at the negotiating table.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINES FOR ILLEGAL INVESTMENT IN CHINA TO BE INCREASED: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The fines for illegal investment in China will be increased as part of the government's efforts to tighten control on capital outflow there, an economic official said Tuesday.

Huang Ching-tang, executive secretary of the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said that under a revised regulation that will take force after being promulgated soon the fine for illegal investment will be increased from 2 percent of the invested fund to 4 percent.
However, he said, the government's policy of "active opening, effective management" with regard to Taiwanese investment in China has not changed.

Noting that the goverment allows local businessment to invest in most manufacturing, agricultural and service industries in China, Huang said only 102 IC- and petroleum-related manufacturing industries, as well as service industries such as postal services, telecommunication, banking and security are off-limits to them.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 17 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, August 17:
09:00, The Cabinet will begin its weekly meeting at the Executive Yuan.
10:00, The Presidential Office will hold its Sun Yat-sen Monthly Memorial Meeting.

10: 30, The lawmakers of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party will give their views on the outcome of the police investigation into the March 19, 2004 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan.
10:30, The Chunghua Post Co., Ltd. will hold a news conference on the 2005 Asian International Stamp Exhibition at the Taipei Post Office.
11:00, President Chen Shui-bian will meet with former South Korean Premier Lee Han Dong at the Presidential Office.
12: 20, The Ministry of the Interior will hold an operation-reviewing meeting.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at ministry headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 17, or the 13th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1424: The English defeat the Scots and the French at the Battle of Verneuil during the Hundred Years' War.
1786: Davy Crockett, American frontiersman and politician, is born. He was a U.S. representative from Tennessee who joined with Texan revolutionaries fighting against Mexico. He died at the siege of the Alamo in 1836.
1892: Mae West, American comedy actress and international sex symbol known for her sultry stage persona during the 1930s, is born. She wrote most of her own stage productions and film scripts.
1896: A massive influx of prospectors to the Yukon Territory of Canada is expected after the discovery of a major gold field at Bonanza Creek on the Klondike River.
1896: The first pedestrian to be killed by a car is knocked down in Croydon, England, by a car traveling at just 6.4 kilometers per hour.
1908: The world's first animated cartoon premiers in Paris.
1943: U.S. forces under Gen. George S. Patton liberate Messina, Italy, arriving just hours ahead of Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army.
1945: After the end of Japanese occupation, Indonesia declares itself a republic under the leadership of Dr. Sukarno.
1946: After ordering Chinese communist troops to start an all-out revolt against the government on Aug. 11, 1945, the communist Yenan General Headquarters issues a second mobilization order instructing all communist forces to launch a full-scale war against the Nationalists.
1960: Gabon gains independence from France.
1961: The polio vaccine developed by American researcher Albert B. Sarbin is approved for use in the United States.
1975: Europe's first particle accelerator is formally inaugurated in Geneva, Switzerland.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Mindanao in the Philippines, killing some 8,000 people.
1982: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement urging the United States to recognize Beijing's ambitious attempt to take over Taiwan, following the issue of the "Aug. 17 Joint Communique" by the United States and mainland China. The ministry also asks the United States to implement the Taiwan Relations Act.
1987: Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's close friend and deputy leader of the Nazi party, commits suicide in his cell in Spandau Prison in West Berlin at the age of 93.
1988: Gen. Zia ul-Haq, Pakistan's iron-fisted ruler for the previous 11 years, dies at the age of 64 when his camouflaged C-130 Hercules plane crashes shortly after takeoff from Bahawalpur.
1989: An Australian airliner becomes the first commercial plane to fly nonstop from London to Sydney.
1993: The ROC and Australia sign two memoranda, one protecting industrial property rights and the second promoting investment and technical cooperation.
1995: A French supersonic jetliner completes a round-the-globe trip in 31 hours 27 minutes and 49 seconds, faster than the previous record by one hour and 20 minutes.
1995: ROC Control Yuan President Chen Li-an announces his candidacy for the 1996 presidential election, one day before renouncing his KMT membership, which he has held for 42 years.
2000: Chen Yi-song, leader of the Agriculture Technical Mission to the Republic of the Gambia, says that ROC agriculture technologists have transformed the Gambia River basin, which used to yield nothing but peanuts, into the "rice bowl of West Africa" over a period of five years.
2001: Taiwan's two major paper makers -- Yuen Foong Yu Paper and Chung Hwa Pulp -- sign a merger agreement and promise that there will be no layoffs in the new company.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you learn, but once learning a thing, you must never give it up until you have mastered it."

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES STAGE 'LIEN HSING' JOINT EXERCISE ON NORTHWEST COAST

TEXT.P: A joint military exercise was conducted in a village of Linkou on Taiwan's northwestern coast Wednesday to test the Navy's amphibious landing capabilities and the Army's counter-strike and counter-invasion abilities, the Naval Fleet Command reported.

Some 3,000 troops, including members of the marine corps, several jet fighters, and an armor brigade took part in the "Lien Hsing 94-1" exercise to hone their skills in countering a Chinese landing attack and blockade.

According to organizers of the military exercise, members of the marine corps staged a mock surprise landing invasion at Linkou beach with LTV landing boats and under the cover of jet fighters. Infantry from the Army's Sixth Armor Brigade launched a counter strike against the invading forces.

The Naval Fleet Command authorities said the staging of the joint operation drill had nothing to do with the current state of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, describing the drill as a "regular, annual exercise."

The Japan Times: DPJ's platform vows troop pullout
The Democratic Party of Japan on Tuesday unveiled its platform for the Sept. 11 election, pledging to pull the Ground Self-Defense Force out of Iraq by December if it comes to power.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING KMT CHAIRMAN 'IN A GOOD MOOD'

TEXT.P: Outgoing opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Wednesday while arriving at the KMT headquarters to preside over the last meeting of the party's Standing Committee during his tenure that "he is in a good mood."
Lien will hand over the KMT chairmanship to new KMT head Ma Ying-jeou at the party's 17th National General Assembly scheduled to be held Friday in Taipei.
During the assembly, which is held every four years, the party representatives will elect members of the Central Committee.
Lien said that he would deliver a speech at a farewell reception to be held in his honor after the Standing Committee meeting.

In response to media questions, both Ma and Wang Jing-Pyng, speaker of the Legislative Yuan, who also attended the Standing Committee meeting, highly lauded Lien's contributions to the KMT and to the Taiwan people.

Promising that he will officially affirm Lien's contributions to the KMT at the right time, the new KMT chairman said that Lien has overseen the biggest set of reforms within the party since the party moved its headquarters from the mainland to Taiwan.

He also praised the outgoing chairman's "peaceful visit to China" in May this year, saying that the visit which was "filled with wisdom and courage" has eased tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as well as facilitated Taiwan farm exports to the mainland, Chinese tourists' visits to the island and the establishment of cross-strait air cargo links.

Meanwhile, Wang said that as Lien will say farewell to the Standing Committee and will serve as an honorable chairman of the party, he hopes that the outgoing chairman will continue to give good advice and assistance to the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

The Straits Times: Singapore gets cutting-edge biomed plant.
Singapore confirmed its place on the pharmaceutical frontier yesterday when it was announced that one of the world's most advanced biomedical most advanced biomedical plants will be built here.
The plant, which could cost up to US$ 400 million to build and equip, will make biologics -- highly sophisticated drugs derived from living cells.
Switzerland's Lonza Group, the world's No. 3 drug-ingredient maker, will build the contract manufacturing facility in a joint venture with Bio*One Capital, the biomedical investment arm of Economic Development Board (EDB).
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore help Indonesia to seed clouds in Sumatra.
A Singapore Armed Force's plane C-130 trasport is due to leave for Sumatra to help Indonesian authorities seed clouds and combat the forest fires raging there, Minister for the Environment and Water Resources Yaacob Ibrahim said yesterday.
