DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REITERATES WISH TO ATTEND APEC INFORMAL LEADERSHIP SUMMIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian told former South Korean Prime Minister Lee Han-dong Wednesday that he is very much looking forward to taking part in next month's informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Busan, South Korea.
Chen reiterated his wish while meeting with Lee at the Presidential Office.

The president said Taiwan is very grateful to the government of the Republic of Korea for its "political wisdom and skillful handling" in pushing for Taiwan's entry into the regional economic organization in 1991 along with China and Hong Kong.

Chen said he hopes that the friendly neighbor, the 2005 APEC meeting host, can continue its support for Taiwan, using the same political wisdom and skillful handling to make possible his participation in the APEC summit, an occasion which Taiwan's head of state has been absent from in previous years due to China's opposition.

During the meeting, the president also expressed his hope for the resumption of Taiwan-South Korea ministerial meetings on trade and economic affairs, and that the two countries can work in an active manner for the formation of a Taiwan-South Korean free trade agreement.

Chen also told his visitor that the two countries have maintained close and friendly relations in recent years, referring to the resumption of direct Taiwan-South Korean flight services and the exchange of visa-free privileges.

Taiwan also opened a representative office in Busan in January, a move that marks the restoration of the friendship between the two countries after it was damaged in 1992 when Seoul severed its diplomatic ties with Taipei to establish formal relations with Beijing, Chen noted.

He also indicated that bilateral trade between Taiwan and South Korea reached a historic high of US$16.9 billion last year, with South Korea registering a trade surplus of US$6.3 billion. The figure was the second largest in terms of Taiwan's foreign trade deficits.
The number of people in the two countries traveling to the other side also surged to a record high of 45,000 last year, with 32,000 of that total being Taiwan visitors to South Korea, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIR INVITES NEW KMT HEAD TO ENGAGE IN CONSTRUCTIVE COMPETITION

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang on Wednesday appealed to the new chairman of the Kuomintang (KMT) to lead Taiwan's major opposition party to engage in "constructive competition" with the ruling DPP.

Su expressed his keen expectation that Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou -- KMT chairman-elect who is scheduled to be sworn in to his new post Friday -- will have new vision to lead the KMT to become a strong and helpful opposition party which will help pass legislation beneficial to the people's wellbeing.
Su called for Ma to lead the KMT into constructive competition with the ruling DPP rather than resuming "unnecessary boycotts and political fighting with the DPP."
Ma won a landslide victory in the KMT chairmanship election July 16.

Meanwhile, Su called for the opposition, including the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) , to accept with open-mindedness the results of the official investigations and final court rulings regarding the March 19, 2004 election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
Su urged the opposition parties to "trust in professional judgments made by specialists, instead of opposing all the results simply for the sake of opposition."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MEMBERS URGED TO FIGHT FOR PARTY'S FUTURE

TEXT.P: Outgoing opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien China urged all KMT members Wednesday to continue to fight under the leadership of new KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou for the party's future and promised that he himself will continue to serve the party as a "volunteer."
He made the appeal in a speech at a farewell reception held in his honor after he presided earlier in the day over the last meeting of the party's Standing Committee of his tenure.
Describing his mood by citing the poetry of one of China's greatest Tang Dynasty poets, Li Po, Lien said that although he is going to leave office, he will always be a member of the party.
Lien will hand over the KMT chairmanship to Ma, who is also Taipei Mayor, at the party's 17th National General Assembly scheduled to be held Friday.
During the gathering, party representatives will also elect members of the KMT Central Committee.

In the speech, which moved many KMT officials to tears, Lien also described the time he has served the KMT as a chairman since 2000 as the toughest time in the party's history. "Despite the fact that many people were pessimistic about us, with the efforts, dedication and sacrifices of the party members and other people in Taiwan, we have overcome our difficulties," he said.

Claiming that recent public opinion polls and media reports have shown that the KMT has become a political party filled with a bright future and excellent prospects, Lien expressed his gratitude for the contributions of all party members to the party and the support of the Taiwan people.
He also said he will look at KMT issues from "the people's point of view "which he said might help him see them "clearly and thoroughly."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange dropped slightly Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 0.48 points to close at 6,241.92.
The bourse opened at 6,216.08 and fluctuated between 6,256.11 and 6,213.59 during trading. A total of 2.65 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$68.61 billion (US$2.15 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics, as well as paper and pulp stocks moving up the most at 0.4 percent.

Four categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.6 percent, banking and financial stocks at 0.5 percent and textile shares at 0.1 percent.
Construction and foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 479 to 364, with 164 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RESPECTS RESULTS OF ELECTION-EVE SHOOTING PROBE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he respects the results of the probe into last year's election-eve shooting of him and Vice President Annette Lu, an incident that injured Chen and Lu only slightly but triggered months of political upheaval.
Chen made the remarks after the State Public Prosecutor-General's Office announced earlier in the day the close of the investigation.
Noting that the investigation panel has devoted a great deal of manpower and resources to investigate the case, Chen said all the investigators have done their utmost.

"I respect the investigative results and I'm hopeful that all social quarters can likewise respect the results, which have been achieved through professional, objective and independent inquiries, " Chen said.
The president also expressed his gratitude to all the investigators for their efforts.
Lu also expressed her admiration for the investigators' work on the case.

"There is only one truth. We must have clear and solid evidence to convince others about the investigative results. I cannot make any comments until after I read the complete investigative report, " Lu added.

Speaking at a news conference, State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao confirmed investigators' findings that Chen Yi-hsiung, a 50-something outspoken supporter of the opposition "pan-blue alliance," was the most likely suspect in the election-eve shooting.

Chen Yi-hsiung died shortly after the March 19, 2004 shooting in an apparent suicide. According to the investigators, he targeted the president and vice president because of unhappiness over the nation's economic situation.
Chen and Lu were riding in an open-top Jeep when they were shot while campaigning in the southern city of Tainan. A bullet grazed Chen's stomach and Lu was hit in the knee.
The next day, Chen defeated his presidential opponent, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, by a razor-thin margin.
Lien and his running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong, contested the electoral results, claiming the shooting was rigged to gain sympathy votes and boost Chen's re-election bid.
A vote recount confirmed Chen's narrow victory, and the courts ruled the election valid.
The presidential election was followed by a week of protests that sometimes turned violent, but since legislative elections last December, political tensions have subsided.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPIDEMICS COULD JEOPARDIZE NATIONAL SECURITY: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Major epidemics in Taiwan could result in repercussions affecting the country's national security, a professor from Central Police University said Wednesday.

Professor Chang Chung-yung of the Central Police University's Public Security Department said that should major epidemic diseases, such as bird flu, occur in a country, the fallout would directly affect national security and have a tremendous impact on the economic, social and political aspects.
Chang made the remarks when he spoke at a colloquium titled "Prevention of Large-scale Epidemic Diseases and Countermeasures" sponsored by the Foundation on International & Cross-Strait Studies.

He quoted the World Bank as estimating that economically, countries seriously affected by AIDS tend to suffer a 1 percent decline in gross domestic product (GDP) , while malaria-affected countries can witness a decline of 2 percent in GDP, in addition to decreases in revenues from tourism and foreign investment.

From the social point of view, he said, major epidemics result in heavy fatalities, plummeting of the labor force, the creation of many orphans, a much heavier burden on the national coffers, an increase of single-parent families and the collapse of core family values.

On the political aspect, he added, governmental hierarchy reshuffles might occur often and political unrest will easily occur, particularly in developing countries as a result of competition for limited resources.
Chang noted that major epidemics could also be used by global terrorist organizations and hostile countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAISHANG' CENTER TO BE SET UP BEFORE AUGUST: SEF CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will set up a new service center to strengthen services for Taiwan businessmen operating in China, known locally as "taishang, " no later than Aug. 31, SEF Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.

Soon after the establishment of the service center, Chang said, the SEF -- a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle exchanges with China in the absence of official ties -- will come up with a comprehensive package of measures to improve and expand services for taishang.
The SEF's Chinese counterpart is the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
Meanwhile, Chang said he expects the center to expand its operations to China "someday" to provide direct and first-hand services to Taiwan businessmen operating there.
He added his hope that ARATS will one day establish posts in Taiwan to further enhance bilateral exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECT'S SON: FATHER NOT INVOLVED IN 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: The second son of Chen Yi-hsiung, who police say is the only suspect in the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, denied Wednesday that his father was the would-be assassin.

Chen Chien-chou made the statement after the Supreme Prosecutor's Office announced the close of the investigation into the March 19, 2004 shooting of the president and the vice president, invoking a new wave of media interest in the case.
"No direct evidence points to my father as a suspect, so in my mind, my father absolutely was not involved, " he told the media.

He said the police have not found the gun they claim his father used to fire two shots at the president and vice president, questioned why the government was announcing an end to the investigation and said his family refused to accept the results.

He admitted that he did not know what his father meant in his will when he wrote: "What I have done, I myself will handle." Police have used the statement as indirect proof of his father having planned and executed the attempted assassination.
Chen Yi-hsiung, 63, was found drowned in Anping harbor in Tainan City 10 days after the shooting, in an apparent suicide.
When his wife was asked Wednesday if she was being coerced by the authorities when she made an apology to society for her husband's alleged act, she did not respond.

The investigative team's final report, released earlier in the day, said that after Chen's death, the bereaved family tried to cover up everything that might indicate Chen's involvement in the incident.
The report quoted Chen's wife as telling police that he acted in a strange manner in the days after the shooting, such as altering his hair style and destroying a jacket.
This, according to the report, led investigators to conclude that the two actions were Chen's way of "hinting to his family that he had committed the crime."

Other pieces of evidence that the investigative team cited to substantiate its charges include a family meeting in which they decided not to mention Chen's involvement in the shooting, to incinerate Chen's body instead of burying it for fear the police might in the future re-open the coffin to gather further forensic evidence. The family members were apparently also heard reminding one another over the phone not to leave any possible evidence behind.
"These indicate that even Chen's own family members believe he was the man who fired the shots," said the report.

Chu Chao-liang, Tainan District chief prosecutor, admitted that the team has no direct evidence but claimed that forensic examinations and testimonies by family members all point to Chen Yi-hsiung as the sole suspect.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS CLOSE ELECTION-EVE SHOOTING PROBE

TEXT.P: State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao on Wednesday announced the closure of the investigation into the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu last year.

Wu announced the close of the high-profile case after nearly 17 months at a press conference at the Judicial Yuan. Accompanying him were the key members of the ad hoc investigation team, including Kuo Jen-ni, chief prosecutor in Tainan, Hou Yu-ih, commissioner of the Criminal Investigation Bureau and forensic expert Shih Tai-ping.

The shooting was generally believed to have polarized Taiwan society, with opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, Chen's defeated election rival, filing two separate suits to challenge the result of the election and seek a new election.
Wu expressed the hope that the closure of the case will help assuage the misgivings and upheaval in society so that social harmony and tranquility can return.

The prosecutors turned over a 300-page report on the case, listing Chen Yi-hsiung as the only suspect, with no other accomplices in the case. Chen died 10 days after the March 19, 2004 shooting in an apparent suicide.

The report said that Chen, 63, obtained a remodeled gun and bullets via his brother-in-law from a criminal ring led by Tang Shou-yi, the maker of two bullets used in the shooting. The gun has not been found.

The report cited five reasons for identifying Chen as the sole suspect, including that his image appeared in the "hot zone, " where the perpetrator of the shooting was most likely to have fired the shots when the president and vice president were campaigning in an open-topped jeep in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

Chen also had motive, according to the investigators. He is alleged to have been venting his resentment over the political situation and to have committed suicide by drowning in the Anping fishing harbor in Tainan on March 29. His family claim to have burned an alleged suicide note he supposedly left behind.
According to the report, the shooting was not staged by the president with the intention of winning sympathy votes in the bitterly contested election, one of the opposition's claims.
The report also specifically rules out the possibility of the president's wound having been faked by security or hospital staff.

It is impossible for President Chen to stage a gunshot wound in other places. It is also unlikely for security personnel in the same vehicle to have fired shots at close range at the president during the motorcade parade, or that Chen's wound was created by hospital staff, the report said.
The president's injury to his abdomen was a fresh gunshot wound, the report also said.

The State Public Prosecutor General's Office solicited the assistance of internationally renowned forensic expert Henry Lee, who was invited by then-State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa to help the investigation.
U.S.-based Lee led a group of experts to Taiwan in April 2004 and worked with the ad hoc investigation team examining the president's wounds and reconstructing the crime scene as best he could.

Lee unveiled his report in late August 2004, confirming that the wound suffered by the president to his abdomen was caused by a bullet and that the bullets retrieved were not fired from a regular handgun but from a remodeled replica.
His report concluded that the two bullets retrieved at the shooting scene were fired either from the same gun or from two guns with barrels cut from the same piece of tubing.
From the suspect's military record, he could have possessed the shooting ability.

The suspect was said to have a simple lifestyle with a small coterie of friends. He had no extraordinary communications after the shooting and there was no abnormal capital flow or remittance after the shooting, which the report claims is an indication that there was no ring behind Chen's shooting and that he was the lone shooter.

DOC.HEADLINE: LACK OF GUN IN ASSASSINATION PROBE REGRETTABLE: TOP PROSECUTOR

TEXT.P: State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao said Wednesday that he regrets not being able to find the handgun used in the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu last year.

Wu made the remarks after announcing earlier in the day the closure of the controversial case after a nearly 17-month probe concluding that President Chen Shui-bian did not stage the shooting -- as claimed by the opposition -- to gain the advantage in the bitterly contested election and that key suspect Chen Yi-hsiung was the sole perpetrator of the shooting.

"We can say that we have not let the public down after the case comes to a close, " Wu said, expressing the hope that "there will be continued efforts to find the gun so that the case can be ended perfectly."
The closure of the investigation into the March 19, 2004 shooting was the first major criminal case to be closed since he assumed his post last September, Wu said.

He noted that there will be an anti-graft campaign during the year-end city and county chief elections and a crackdown on gangsters, especially criminals from China who commit crimes in Taiwan, which he said are waiting to be solved.

Wu was positive about the work done by the investigators, including the ad hoc investigation group and internationally renowned forensic expert Henry Lee, claiming that they have "answered in detail" all the public misgivings and that all "unfounded speculation" can be put to rest.

DOC.HEADLINE: MODEL SPOKESWOMAN FOR ASIAN INTERNATIONAL STAMP EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: Local model Lin Chi-ling will serve as spokeswoman for the 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition that will be held in Taipei Aug. 19-24, Chunghwa Post Co. President Huang Shui-cheng announced Wednesday.
The fair will be the first international event that Chunghwa Post has hosted after it transformed from a government agency into a state-owned company in 2003.

Huang said that Chunghwa Post will also launch a charity sale of packages of Lin's personalized stamps and postcards to raise funds for children living in poverty in Chiayi and Yunlin counties in southern Taiwan.
The six-day exhibition at the Taipei World Trade Center will have no entrance fee.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE FISHING BOATS SEIZED FOR INTRUDING INTO TAIWAN WATERS

TEXT.P: Four fishing boats from China were seized by Taichung Coast Guard officials off Miaoli in northern Taiwan Wednesday after they were discovered poaching in Taiwan waters.
Twenty-seven fishermen aboard the vessels were detained in Taichung County for questioning, while their fishing gear and catches were confiscated, Coast Guard officials said.
There was no evidence to suggest that they were smuggling or tried to illegally enter Taiwan, they noted.

Under the "Ching Hai" mission aimed at "pacifying" the seas surrounding Taiwan, the Taichung squad drove a total of 150 Chinese fishing boats out of Taiwan waters during the January-July period and seized 75 Chinese vessels.
Most of the Chinese fishermen claimed to have been unaware they had entered Taiwan waters, according to the Coast Guard officers.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION REFUSES TO ACCEPT CLOSE OF 319 SHOOTING PROBE

TEXT.P: The legislative caucuses of the two major opposition parties Wednesday rejected the decision by the State Public Prosecutor General's Office to close the investigation into the March 19, 2004 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
At a news conference held in the Legislative Yuan, the caucuses of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) vowed to form another "investigation commission" to pursue the case.

Cho Po-yuan, a KMT caucus whip, noted that the decision of the Prosecutor General's Office was announced on the day outgoing KMT Chairman Lien Chan presided over his last KMT Central Standing Committee meeting and suggested that this was intentional.

Cho claimed that "political forces" have "clearly intervened" in the investigation process of the 319 shooting and that the decision of the Prosecutor General's Office to close the case is apparently a political one because there is no direct evidence to prove that the sole suspect, suicide victim Lin Yi-hsiung, was involved in the shooting.

"A dead man cannot defend himself. There is neither a murder weapon nor a confession from the suspect. If the case is closed like this, the nation's criminal law can be rewritten, " Cho said, describing the decision as "ridiculous, flippant and irresponsible."

PFP legislative whip Huang Yi-chao claimed that the general public are not convinced by the conclusion and that the truth about the case will only come out if the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party win power in the 2008 presidential election.

Also commenting on the ending of the case at a separate occasion, Chao Yung-ching, legislative caucus convener of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), praised the work of the police and the prosecutors in pursuing the case over the past 17 months.
He said the DPP legislative caucus supports an amendment to the relevant law to allow the formation of an investigation commission that would allow participation by opposition parties.

The "pan-blue" opposition parties, which hold a slight majority in the legislature, established an investigation commission in August last year to conduct its own probe into the shooting, but DPP legislators refused to join them as the commission was "unconstitutional".

The shooting occurred the day before the 2004 presidential election when Chen and Lu were shot while campaigning in a jeep in Tainan. The opposition believes the incident generated sympathy votes for Chen and Lu and helped them to win the election by a mere 29,500 votes.

The "truth commission" formed by the opposition parties claims that the incident was staged and the wounds "self-inflicted" in order to influence the election, but the claims were dismissed by internationally reknowned U.S. forensics expert Henry Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PACKAGE TO BE PARTIALLY FINANCED BY REGULAR MILITARY BUDGET

TEXT.P: The controversial U.S. arms procurement package can be partly funded from the government's regular budget instead of from appropriations from a special budget, the Cabinet decided Wednesday.
The Cabinet passed a draft budget plan for next year that included NT$7 billion for the special arms procurement project.
Of that amount, NT$350 million will be contributed by the Cabinet and the remaining will be from the Ministry of National Defense's regular budget.

As a result, the nation's overall defense spending for 2006 will be NT$253.8 billion, a NT$4.1 billion increase from the 2005 level and accounting for 15.9 percent of the government's total annual expenditure.

The special arms procurement project refers to a plan to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States. The package will call for an outlay of NT$480 billion. The government originally planned to finance it with a special budget plan to span a period of 15 years.
The bill has been held up in the legislature because of opposition parties' feeling that the cost of the weaponry is too expensive and that any payments ought not come from a special budget.
The Cabinet approved the government's 2006 budget plan at its weekly meeting earlier in the day, which projects annual total revenues to be NT$1.4 trillion and annual expenditures of NT$1.6 trillion.

"The budgetary gap is less than in 2005, " a budget planning official said, adding that in addition to using its previous budget surplus, the government will have to float NT$239 billion in state bonds, or 14.8 percent of its total spending, to make ends meet.
Compared with the 2005 budget plan, 2006 government expenditures will mark a 0.5 percent decrease.

Speaking at the weekly Cabinet meeting, Premier Frank Hsieh said that although the government's budget will not increase next year, the Cabinet has adjusted its spending structure in line with its overall national development plans.

In the 2006 budget plan, Hsieh said, disbursements related to the upgrading of national competitiveness and industrial technological development will grow substantially, and spending on the upgrading of living quality and public safety, including physical education, health care, community services, fighting crime and ethnic diversity, will also increase.
"Our 2006 budget plan has given balanced emphasis on economic development, social justice, environmental protection and cultural renaissance," Hsieh said.
According to the Cabinet-drafted budget bill, NT$84.3 billion will be appropriated for technological development projects, marking all-time-high growth of 19.7 percent from the year-earlier level.

NT$11.5 billion will be earmarked for a "six-star" community development project, marking 14.2 percent in annual growth; the spending for fighting crime will surge 6.5 percent; expenditures for welfare services for minority ethnic groups will post a 10.8 percent rise.

Meanwhile, the budget for the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports will register a whopping 82 percent growth to reach NT$4.9 billion and the National Youth Commission's budget will increase to NT$520 million, up 19.2 percent.

By category, spending on education, science, technology and culture will account for the largest share of the government's 2006 expenditures, making up 22 percent of the total; social welfare spending will account for 18.5 percent of the total; and spending on economic development projects will make up 12.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD TO RETURN HOME NEXT WEEK, MEET KMT LEADERS: AIDE

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will meet outgoing opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan as soon as he returns to Taiwan next week from the United States, PFP Policy Research Center Director Chang Hsien-yao said Wednesday.

Soong will also meet with KMT Chairman-elect Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to exchange opinions on a major arms procurement bill that has been held up by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan during the last two sessions, Chang said.

He added that Soong is also expected to discuss issues surrounding the city and county chief elections in December with Ma, who will take over the KMT's helm from Lien Friday to become the main opposition party chairman.

Following these meetings, the PFP head will immediately start a tour to campaign for PFP candidates in nine constituencies, including Keelung city, Taichung city, Changhua county, Chiayi city, Lienchiang county, Miaoli county and Hsinchu county for the year-end elections, he added.

Cooperation is imperative among the KMT, the PFP and the New Party -- the "pan blue alliance" -- to score victories in the coming local elections, which are widely seen as a major gauge of the opposition alliance's chances in the 2008 presidential election against the "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).
However, it remains unclear whether the three parties will collaborate in the December elections to lay a sound foundation for bilateral cooperation in the next presidential election.

Huang Pan-gung, head of the PFP's Organization Affairs Department, said last Sunday that the KMT, as the largest opposition party, should allow the PFP to run on its own in five or six out of the country's total 23 cities and counties -- a "one-fourth clause" put forward by Huang in proportion to the number of legislative seats held by the two parties.

If the KMT is willing to do this, it would help the "pan blue alliance" expand its voter base in order to gain an advantage in the 2008 presidential election, PFP aides said, stressing that the PFP candidate for Keelung mayor, Liu Wen-hsiung, and Changhua county magistrate candidate Hsieh Chang-chieh, are charismatic competitors capable of swaying voters to win over aspirants fielded by the "pan green camp."

Should the KMT and the PFP be able to implement a "coalition rule" in local governments, it would help lead to a further consolidation between the two parties ahead of the 2008 presidential race, PFP aides said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION'S ENGAGEMENT WITH CHINA WILL AFFECT DIPLOMATIC WORK: FM

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen said Wednesday that engagement with China by the opposition parties will affect the nation's diplomatic work.

Chen made the remarks during an interview with CNA in which he said Beijing has been soliciting engagement with Taiwan opposition parties ever since its March 14 enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, which codifies the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence.

Since then, the leaders of the two main opposition parties -- the Kuomintang and the People First Party -- have visited China in April and May, respectively, followed by visits by delegations from both parties.
Chen noted that the Republic of China is a sovereign state, which is why it has a Ministry of Foreign Affairs, adding that diplomacy has sovereignty significance connotations.
He complained that he is barred from visiting many other counties because of their "one China" policy.

He pointed out that the ROC currently has 26 diplomatic allies and that if the opposition parties continue to engage with China, others might think the opposition parties "are not taking the sovereignty issue seriously."

If that is the impression given, it could "undermine the nation's relations with its allies," as the approach of the opposition parties is contradictory to the perception of the country's allies that "Taiwan is a sovereign state."
Even if this does not affect diplomatic work, the ruling and opposition parties should be as of one mind in terms of the nation's diplomatic policy, he said.
If there is no uniform diplomatic policy, "then it will be easily divided by others," Chen said.
He said the people of Taiwan need to stand firm in their belief and act in unison, and that national interests should take precedence over partisan interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SEEKS SWISS SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN'S WHO BID

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian appealed to Switzerland Wednesday to support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer.

Taking the advantage of a meeting at his office with visiting Switzerland Federal Assembly Speaker Bruno Frick, the president said Bern should opt for abstention rather than vote against Taiwan's bid as it did last year at the WHA, which is the governing body of the World Health Organization (WHO).

Just as pandemics know no boundaries, the WHO's battle against disease should not be limited by political boundaries by excluding a country like Taiwan, that is why the European Parliament has repeatedly voiced its support for Taiwan's inclusion in the WHA, Chen said.
As a state of Europe, it is regrettable that Switzerland flew in the face of the European Parliament's decision by voting against Taiwan last year.
The president also urged Frick to help Taiwan rename its representative office in Bern, saying it has run into problems. The president didn't elaborate.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX MAINLANDERS ARRESTED AMONG LOCALS RUNNING ILLEGAL BETTING STATION
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua County, central Taiwan (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The 23 members of an illegal ring arrested Tuesday night for running a betting station for an online gambling site include six Chinese nationals who entered Taiwan on student visas, a spokesman for Changhua County police said Wednesday.

The spokesman said that police precincts in central Taiwan dispatched 11 teams of detectives to search suspected locations in Taichung City and Chunghua County. They arrested three ringleaders and 20 members of the ring, including the six Chinese nationals who were in charge of maintenance and service of the computers and gambling equipment of the betting station.
Shih Chia-chin, one of the ringleaders, told the police that the gambling Web site is located in China, and that the betting station in Taiwan was only taking bets from gamblers.

Customers could bet on a wide variety of games, including China's soccer matches, the lotteries in Hong Kong and Taiwan, baccarat, bingo, the underground Hong Kong Mark Six Lottery, and America's professional baseball games.
The betting station has been in operation for about four months, with its weekly turnover reaching NT$100 million, according to the police spokesman.
He said police believe that the six Chinese nationals were training on the betting station so that they could eventually go back to China to open similar betting stations.

All 23 suspects were referred to the Changhua District Attorney's Office on charges of gambling and money laundering. The six mainlanders will face an additional charge of violating the regulations governing the relationship between the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S GRANTING OF VISA-FREE TREATMENT PRIDE OF TAIWAN PEOPLE: MOFA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Wednesday that Japan's granting permanent visa-free treatment for Taiwan tourists is the "pride of the 23 million people on Taiwan."
Chen made the remarks when he was interviewed by CNA, noting that it was a major breakthrough in Taiwan-Japan relations.

Chen said that if both countries have diplomatic relations, then it will be a small thing to waive visa requirements, adding that Japan has no diplomatic relations with Taiwan, but it is allowing visa-free treatment, while Japan has diplomatic relations with China, but it is denying the same privilege to China.
"Judging from this, one can clearly see that the standard of a nation and its performance in various aspects are the basis of the nation's diplomatic works," Chen said.

He noted that if a country has failed to live up to the standard, and that its nationals are overstaying their visas, then they will be despised by the visiting countries and unable to obtain the same preferential visa treatment, indirectly referring to China. The Japanese House of Councilors, or upper house of the Japanese Diet, revised a bill earlier this month to allow the permanent waiver of the visa requirement for Taiwan tourists.
Chen said that Taiwan has been pushing for visa-free treatment for years, and that Taiwan originally worried that the latest round of Taiwan-Japanese fishery talks last month could derail the matter.

He pointed out that even though neither side has made headway in the past fishery talks, the government has insisted on maintaining the nation's sovereignty, although it worried that disagreements in the talks might affect the lifting of the visa requirement. Japan's new move will be put into practice Sept. 26, or the day after the closing of Expo 2005 Aichi in central Japan.
Earlier this year, the Japanese parliament passed a special bill to grant 90-day, visa-free entry to Taiwan visitors from March 25 through Sept. 25 in connection with the Aichi expo.
With the temporary visa waiver period soon to expire, Japanese parliamentarians decided to pass a new bill to allow for permanent visa-free status for Taiwan citizens.

The move will boost Taiwan tourist arrivals to Japan from the current figure of just over one million per year to between 1.3 million and 1.4 million per year. Taiwan is Japan's second-largest source of foreign tourists after South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TRADE COUNCIL OPPOSES CHINA'S PLOT TO UNDERMINE DPP ADMINISTRATION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: China's attempts to use trade as a mechanism for undermining Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party administration is hampering further liberalization and progress towards the normalization of cross-strait trade relations, the US-Taiwan Business Council warned recently.

In an statement about China's recent detente with Taiwan's two opposition parties, Kuomintang and People First Party, the council's President Rupert Hammond-Chambers expressed concern that any process to undermine Chen Shui-bian administration's authority over trade negotiations will result in a political backlash in Taiwan that will slow or even halt incremental trade liberalization across the Taiwan Strait.
Hammond-Chambers said his council welcomes dialogue between China and Taiwan.

However, he noted that the unilateral announcement by the Chinese government that it will offer tariff-free treatment to certain agricultural products from Taiwan, following the China visits by several Taiwan opposition leaders, is aimed at luring away President Chen Shui-bian's supporters, such as fruit farmers in southern Taiwan, and planting the seeds of doubt about the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) ability to handle cross-Taiwan Strait trade.
While the council welcomes dialogue between China and Taiwan, it is clear that these initiatives are designed to undermine the position of Chen and the DPP, the statement said.

"If the DPP is to proceed with further liberalization in areas such as chip packaging and testing as well as 0.18-micron chip manufacturing, it will require a level of control over the process," it said.

According to Hammond-Chambers, the Chen administration has become more cautious with regard to economic interactions with China, and will pursue policies to address the seemingly incremental erosion of its authority over cross-strait trade matters.

"The U.S.-Taiwan Business Council believes that normalized trade across the Taiwan Strait will result in reductions in cross-strait political tension, increased efficiencies for Taiwan companies, and therefore price, quality, and time of delivery improvements for the myriad of U.S. companies that participate in the integrated technology supply chain that links the U.S., Taiwan and China, " Hammond-Chambers said.

"In addition, economic integration should also contribute greatly to bridging the political gap that remains between the two, and offer positive momentum to a relationship that has undergone an extended period of strain," he added.

The U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, which comprises a large network of companies involved in business between Taiwan and the United States, gives members access to people and information to help them succeed in their Taiwan endeavors.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Israeli Troops Persuade, and Force, Settlers to Leave
Israeli soldiers moved into the Jewish settlements in larger numbers this morning, persuaded some reluctant residents to leave their homes voluntarily, and forced out others. There were no signs of serious violence, and it seemed that many residents were coming to terms with the pullout. Some 14,000 troops entered five Jewish settlements: Neve Dekalim, Morag, Bedolah, Ganei Tal and Tel Katifa. Security officials said the goal was to clear out the 21 Gaza settlements in just a few days. Since Monday it has been illegal for Israeli civilians to be here, and Tuesday was the last day they could leave on their own, with belongings.
Wall Street Journal: War Wounds, Breaking a Taboo, Army Confronts Guilt after Combat
Not long ago Maj. Peter Kilner posted on an Army-sponsored Web site a short essay he had written on the morality of killing in combat. Maj. Kilner's writings -- which encourage officers to talk to their troops about the morality of killing in combat and the guilt that often comes with taking another's life -- have begun gathering a wide audience. Maj. Kilner is pushing America's current crop of Army officers to help their soldiers confront the morality of killing on a personal level. Failure to address these issues in training, Maj. Kilner argues, can sometimes disable soldiers in combat, and leave them more prone to psychological traumas after the battle is finished. There is no established program or training for commanders who want to talk with their soldiers about killing and its aftermath, leaving soldiers and commanders to cobble together their own solutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS PUBLICITY CAMPAIGN FOR U.N. BID: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs to launch a successful international publicity campaign and to seek the support of influential countries like the United States and Japan for its bid to re-enter the United Nations , Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Wednesday.
Chen made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency. He noted that as of now, the U.S. has not yet make clear its position on whether or not to support Taiwan's U.N. bid.

Chen indicated that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Government Information Office have been tasked to map out an integrated plan to carry out the international publicity campaign in five directions.
First, he explained, is to seek the support of foreign political leaders and influential citizens via Taiwan's overseas posts.
Second is to mobilize the friends of Taiwan to hold publicity activities in the U.S. and Japan two weeks before the opening of the regular yearly session of the U.N. General Assembly.

Third, assess the possibility of sending diplomatic missions to the U.S., Japan and European countries to make clear the case why they have to let Taiwan join the U.N. and why it's unfair to shut the island out of the international body, and to dress home to U.N. members the importance for the organization to help safeguard peace in the Taiwan Strait.
Fourth, try to arrange a teleconference like the one held last September for President Chen Shui-bian to be interviewed by the U.N. Correspondents Association in New York.
Fifth, invite influential media personnel to visit Taiwan and meet with ranking government officials.
This is the 13th year Taiwan will try to re-join the U.N.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION'S DIALOGUE WITH CHINA NOT HAMPERING CHEN'S POSITION: KMT

TEXT.P: Dialogue between opposition parties and Chinese authorities are aimed at assisting the government in strengthening cross-Taiwan Strait ties and have not undermined the position of President Chen Shui-bian and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker said Wednesday.

Pan Wei-kang, the deputy secretary-general of KMT's legislative caucus, made the remarks in response to a statement made by the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council that China's attempts to use trade as a mechanism for undermining president Chen and the DPP will prompt backlash.
Pan stressed that the dialogue between opposition leaders and Chinese authorities are conducted for the sake of the nation's interest and are made under the government's framework.

Noting that opposition leaders have conducted their China visits while abiding by the rules and have not said anything to the detriment of President Chen, Pan said that history will give them the credit they deserve.

Following KMT Chairman Lien Chan and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong's visits to the mainland in late April and early May, China has presented a series of trade initiatives to Taiwan, including tariff-free treatment for certain categories of agricultural products from the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACCOUNTABILITY REVIEW AIMS TO IMPROVE WATER MANAGEMENT: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday the Cabinet's review of accountability for the recent water supply shortfalls in the northern county of Taoyuan is mainly aimed at improving water resources management rather than at faulting anyone.
Hsieh made the remarks after a Cabinet meeting during which he announced disciplinary measures for a shortlist of officials who are being held responsible for the Taoyuan water problems.

The premier said although Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, Water Resources Agency (WRA) Director Chen Shen-hsien and Taiwan Water Corp. (TWC) Chairman Lee Wen-liang all tendered written resignations, a crucial problem worthy of review is that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) lacks a vice minister versed in hydraulic power issues.

After Typhoon Matsa lashed Taiwan in early August bringing strong winds and torrential rains, the water supply in Taoyuan was disrupted because of the high turbidity in the Shihmen Reservoir -- the county's main water source. The water supply in the northern part of the county was not fully restored until Aug. 13.
Hsieh said he has approved TWC Corp. Chairman Lee's resignation, but he asked Lee not to leave the post until after a broken main at the Nanhua Dam in the southern county of Tainan is repaired.

Lee assumed his current post late last year. Hsieh acknowledged that some of the flawed Shihmen Reservoir catchment and purification facilities were designed before Lee took the TWC helm. "But as a political appointee, Lee has to take the blame. He has to set an example for all politically appointed officials," Hsieh said.
Meanwhile, Hsieh said he wants WRA Director Chen Shen-hsien to remain at the post because the MOEA needs his professional expertise in carrying out many new flood-control programs around the country.

"Chen is a civil servant. Unless he commits a crime, he need not leave public service. We can only adjust his official duties. As the Legislative Yuan will soon screen a special flood-prevention statute, the WRA has become very important. If Chen leaves now, it might hinder implementation of some flood-control projects," Hsieh said.
Pointing out that none of the three sitting vice economic affairs ministers are familiar with water problems, Hsieh said their jobs might have to be adjusted.
Hsieh said the economics ministry needs a water resources expert to serve as its vice minister to assist in addressing water management problems.
At present, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yiin Chii-ming serves as convener of the ministry's water resources screening committee and water resources coordination committee.

"Even though Yiin is a senior civil servant, we cannot ask him to resign. He has not offered to resign. But I think his official duties should be adjusted. We'll make an appropriate adjustment in the near future," Hsieh said.
The premier already rejected Minister Ho's resignation a few days ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH-SPEED RAIL SCHEDULED TO OPEN IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's high-speed rail is scheduled to open in October although details of the train schedule and operation plans will not be known until mid-September, Chou Li-liang, vice minister of transportation and communications, said Wednesday.

Chou said the 345-kilometer rail line between Taipei and Kaohsiung -- Taiwan's two largest cities -- will undergo test runs beginning with 120 kph from Aug. 23. The train speed will be increased by 10 kph during each test run until it eventually reaches 200 kph in late August or early September.

He said that according to the ministry's standard, the train will have to run at 200 kph while being operated by the rail system, instead by a human driver. If everything goes smoothly, the Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp. will be able to announce before Sept. 10 the schedule and other details. By Han Nai-kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-CHINA TALKS ON CHARTER LINKS LIKELY: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan-China talks on cross-Taiwan Strait direct charter links seems likely to happen, judging from the current developments, and the government will try its best to safeguard national interests by making a detailed proposal to the Chinese side, a ranking Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Wednesday.

According to the MAC official, the government will put forward a well-crafted proposal covering comprehensive and concrete details regarding destinations, routes and passenger capacities to help crystallize both the charter cargo and passenger flights across the Strait.

The MAC has commissioned the Taipei Airlines Association to make necessary arrangements with its Chinese counterpart and bilateral talks should open as soon as possible based on the model set earlier this year when the two sides held talks on Chinese New Year holiday charter flights -- the first direct cross-strait flights that were operated in the form of "non-stop, round trip" by Taiwanese and Chinese airlines, the official said.

The MAC is determined to gain maximum benefits for the country and the people of Taiwan in the negotiations, he stressed, although he also admitted that talks on regular charter services are much more complicated than the talks on Chinese New Year holiday charter flights.
"We will be waiting for a concrete timetable for the talks to be worked out, " he said, expressing the hope that the MAC can offer more to help broaden two-way participation in the negotiations.

Meanwhile, members of a main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) group told a news conference after returning from a trip to Beijing earlier the same day that China is willing to negotiate direct charter cargo and passenger links with Taiwan for mutual benefits.

KMT Central Policy Committee Director Tseng Yung-chuan, who led the group to help arrange the talks with Chinese civil aviation officials Tuesday in Beijing, said that China has agreed to hold talks simultaneously on direct charter links for cargo and passenger transport with Taiwan to launch the two services at the same time.

According to Tseng, the Chinese side has authorized the Cross-Straits Shipping Exchange Association to have technical talks regarding the issue with the Taipei Airlines Association -- a civil group appointed by the government on Taiwan to serve that purpose in the absence of government-to government contacts between Taiwan and China.

The Chinese side also agreed to increase destinations and broaden the service scope for charter passenger flights and made it clear again that it stands firm on its pledge to allow Taiwan-based airlines to fly over its skies en route to Europe, Tseng said.

KMT Legislator John Chiang, who advocates "cross-strait tourist charter flights," pointed out that Chen Yunlin, Taiwan Affairs Office director under the Beijing-based State Council, also agreed to talk over the issue in the next round of negotiations.

Chiang is high optimistic about the prospects of the "cross-strait tourist charter flights, " claiming that business will be brisk as people on the two sides exchange at least 3.5 million visits each year and suggested links from Beijing, Nanjing, Shanghai, Dalian, Qingdao, Guangzhou, Wuhan, Chongqing, Xian, Urumqi and Hainan Island to Taiwan.
The KMT keenly hopes to help push for regular cargo and passenger charter flights to serve all the Taiwan people, not just businessmen operating in China, party spokesman Chang Jung-kung said.
The KMT group, which had no authority from the government to get involved in the charter service talks, flew to Beijing Monday and returned early this morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Forced Removal of Gaza Settlers Begins; Every Front Yard Becomes a Stage in Emotionally Charged Human Drama.
Police and soldiers moved through nine settlements in the Gaza Strip Wednesday morning and methodically began the process of evacuating recalcitrant settlers from their homes, kicking down doors where necessary and filling up tour buses for the ride out of Gaza.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 18, or the 14th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1227: The Mongol ruler Genghis Khan, who through conquest created a vast empire that extended from the Pacific to the Dnieper River, dies after falling from his horse. He was 65.
1503: Pope Alexander VI, originally Rodrigo Borgia, Spanish-born pontiff since 1492, dies in Rome at the age of 72 after succumbing to a fever. He was noted as a patron of the arts and for his corrupt papacy.
1759: The British led by Adm. Boscowen defeat a French fleet at Lagos, Portugal.
1825: Scottish explorer Alexander Gordon Laing becomes the first European to reach Timbuktu, located in present-day Mali.
1830: Franz-Joseph I, the Austro-Hungarian emperor who invaded Serbia and helped initiate World War 1, is born.
1917: Casper Weinberger, American statesman and secretary of defense for President Ronald Reagan, is born.
1932: Scottish aviator Jim Mollison makes the first westbound transatlantic solo flight, from Portmarnock, Ireland, to Pennfield, New Brunswick.
1945: Henry Pu Yi steps down as emperor of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed in China by the Japanese in 1932. He was nabbed by Russian troops two days later.
1946: Albert Einstein, German-born American theoretical physicist, declares that he had written a memo to President Franklin D. Roosevelt asking the president not to use the atomic bomb against Japan.
1966: Some one million Red Guards hold a huge demonstration in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in celebration of the "great proletarian cultural revolution" launched by Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong.
1974: Taiwan baseball teams for the first time win the Little League, Senior League and Big League world titles in the same year.
1984: South Africa is banned from taking part in the Olympic Games because of its policy of apartheid.
1985: A ship sinks near Harbin in northeastern China, leaving 171 people dead or missing.
1987: Terrorists throw grenades into the Congress of Sri Lanka, killing two people and injuring 16 others, including Prime Minister Ranasinghe Premadasa.
1988: The Mainland Affairs Task Force is established under the Republic of China Executive Yuan.
1989: Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan is assassinated. The Colombian government takes immediate action by launching a nationwide crackdown on drug dealers.
1991: Vice President Li Yuan-zu of the Republic of China leaves for a state visit to Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Honduras and to attend the 23rd Plenary Meeting of the World League for Freedom and Democracy in San Jose, Costa Rica.
1992: The Department of Anti-Corruption is established under the ROC Ministry of Justice.
1994: An earthquake rocks the Mascara region of western Algeria, killing more than 120 people.
1995: A referendum is held in Bermuda, with 73 percent of the voters in the British dependency voting against independence.
1997: Typhoon Winnie hits Taiwan, killing some 40 people and injuring 81 others.
2000: The Paraguayan embassy in Taipei requests that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs lift an import ban on beef from Paraguay, saying that there have been no cases of foot-and-mouth disease reported among the country's livestock.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you inquire into, but when you inquire into a thing, you must never give it up until you have thoroughly understood it."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The China Times:
Only 19% accept '319 shooting' report.
The United Daily News:
Investigators conclude that Chen Yi-hsiung is entirely responsible for the '319 shooting' as probes officially closed.
The Liberty Times:
Security at Tsoying military naval base is at stake.
The Taiwan Daily:
Investigators of '319 shooting' have done their utmost, says forensic expert.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEXT LEGISLATIVE SESSION TO START SEPT. 13

TEXT.P: The next legislative session will formally start Sept. 13, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng announced Thursday.

Wang made the remarks after presiding over a cross-party consultative meeting of the legislative caucus whips of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the Kuomintang, the People First Party, the Taiwan Solidarity Union and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union.

"Party whips from across the political spectrum have unanimously agreed that the next legislative session will formally open Sept. 13 after legislators report for duty Sept. 1 in accordance with the constitutional provisions," Wang said.

Once the session begins, all Cabinet members must field questions at the legislative plenary session. All the party caucuses have also agreed that lawmakers will pick one day every two weeks to screen legislative bills related to the people's livelihood, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: V.P. URGES U.S. TO PERSUADE JAPAN TO ADOPT A 'TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu has urged the United States to encourage Japan to adopt a law similar to the U.S. Taiwan Relations Act to facilitate efforts in handling relations between Japan and Taiwan.

In an interview with the U.S. quarterly Foreign Policy, Lu said that it would be "most helpful" if the United States could encourage Japan to pass a law like the Taiwan Relations Act to regulate the relationship between Japan and Taiwan even in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.

Lu said that thanks to the Taiwan Relations Act signed into law by U.S. President Jimmy Carter in 1979, the substantial relationship between the United States and Taiwan has been sustained. "Currently the parliament in Canada is debating such a bill. So it is time to encourage Japan to adopt such a formula," she added.
The Taiwan Relations Act is the bedrock of relations between Taiwan and the United States. The U.S. law stipulates clearly that differences across the Taiwan Strait must be resolved peacefully.
Following are excerpts of other questions that Foreign Policy asked Lu during the interview, which is carried in the quarterly's latest issue.
FP: Is there a difference between what you think should happen and what will happen with cross-strait relations with China in the coming years?

Lu: The relationship requires mutual understanding and trust. The best way to define the relationship is that culturally and ethnically, Taiwan and China are relatives, and geographically, we are neighbors. As relatives, we should not fight against each other. As neighbors, we should peacefully coexist and cooperate. The mainland says, "Yes, we are relatives, but we are one country, not neighbors." They say we are one family. But they have to prove it, because they treat us more like enemies.
FP: China has proposed sending two pandas to Taiwan as a goodwill gesture. Do you support accepting them?

Lu: In the interest of the pandas, we worry about whether we can really take care of them properly. Everything should be done in accordance with international norms regarding the care of endangered species. But if the mainland people are truly in favor of sending the pandas, I wouldn't mind. Perhaps the best option is to have the KMT take care of the pandas. The KMT is so rich, so why not?

FP: There is a growing concern in some quarters that the hundreds of thousands of Taiwanese businessmen who live and work in mainland China are developing a greater affinity for China. To what extent do you share this concern?

Lu: I'm certainly concerned. It's ironic that as economic ties become tighter, political relations become tenser. We understand that many Taiwanese people go to China for investment opportunities and are in a bit of a dilemma over how to uphold their patriotism to Taiwan. Balancing this is a challenge for us.

FP: Some say that because of China's growing economic and military power, in a few decades it will be too powerful to be deterred. Is there a time window in which cross-strait issues need to be peacefully settled before China gets too powerful for anyone to stop?

Lu: The key is the definition of the status quo. Some people say that the status quo means no independence, no force. The facts are on the contrary. Taiwan has been independent for decades, with or without recognition. We are independent, and there is no peace at all. China's communists in the past decade have spent so much money to build up their military power. Everybody knows that. So the status quo is that Taiwan has been independent and that China is militant.
FP: What is Taiwan's greatest challenge aside from cross-strait relations?

Lu: The most urgent priority is reconciliation between the ruling party government and the opposition. Our opponents still refuse to recognize the legitimacy of President Chen Shui-bian. Last year, we were nearly assassinated. It was a miracle that both President Chen and I survived. [Chen and Lu were shot during a campaign event the day before the presidential election, which they won by a 0.2 percent margin.] However, our opponents refuse to recognize that we were elected in accordance with the law. So they refuse to cooperate with us in the Legislative Yuan, making everything difficult.
FP: Are you considering running for president in 2008?
Lu: That is a sensitive question that I won't answer. It's too early to say.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC TO ISSUE SILVER COINS MARKING 18TH ASIAN STAMP EXHIBIT

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) is set to issue a total of 21,200 commemorative silver coins to mark the Taipei 2005 Stamp Exhibition and the 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition slated to be held in Taipei Aug. 19-24, CBC authorities said Thursday.

The commemorative silver coin bears a picture of flying geese and the 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition on the front side and a picture of the Taipei 101 tower -- the tallest building in the world -- and a commemorative stamp marking the stamp exhibition on the reverse side.
The Bank of Taiwan has been chosen by the Central Bank of China to deal with the sale of 20,000 of the coins.
Chunghwa Post has been authorized to market the remaining 1,200 coins at the venue of the Taipei 2005 Stamp Exhibition and the 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition.
The coins will be priced at NT$1,000, with customers being restricted to purchasing just one coin per visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW VICE ECONOMIC MINISTER TO BE CHOSEN THIS WEEK

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday he is scouting for a new vice economic affairs minister versed in water resources management and flood-control technology.
Hsieh made the remarks after attending the closing ceremony for a national conference on industrial technological development strategies.
In the past few days, Hsieh said he has consulted many hydraulic power specialists and scholars regarding water resources management and flood-prevention.

Hsieh said he is determined to recruit an expert in water resources management to take one of the three vice economic affairs minister positions because none of the three incumbents are professional in the field.
"I hope a new vice minister can be named this week," Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CONCERNED ABOUT CHINA-RUSSIA JOINT MILITARY EXERCISES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) voiced a high degree of concern Thursday over an ongoing China-Russia joint military exercise and urged China to withdraw its 700-odd missiles aimed at Taiwan.

Peace and security in the Taiwan Strait is of extremely vital importance to the Asia-Pacific region and the rest of the world, and no country in the region is allowed to do anything that threatens regional peace and stability, foreign ministry spokesman Michel Lu told reporters.

Lu called on China to withdraw the more than 700 missiles deployed in its southeastern coastal region targeting Taiwan as soon as possible, adding that the foreign ministry will closely watch the first-ever joint war games between the two countries, which kicked off the same day on the Chinese Shandong peninsula near South Korea and Japan.

The China-Russia joint military drills are set to involve 10,000 troops from land, sea and air forces during an eight-day period, in which the participation of Russia-made Tu-95 strategic bombers and Tu-22M long-range bombers have drawn the attention of many observers. Analysts pointed out that they are advanced warplanes that usually do not take part in a peace-time operations.
Both Beijing and Moscow have said that the demonstration of their military might is not aimed at any third country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 36.83 points to close at 6,205.09.
The bourse opened at 6,252.32 and fluctuated between 6,260.28 and 6,204.42 during trading. A total of 3.14 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$73.15 billion (US$2.27 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, construction issues and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.6 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, cement stocks at 0.3 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 558 to 318, with 142 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE DEFENSE COMMITTEE MISSION TO VISIT JAPAN

TEXT.P: In a bid to understand Japan's stance on China's military buildup and possible conflict in the Taiwan Strait, a Legislative Defense Committee mission is scheduled to depart for Tokyo Aug. 22 for a series of meetings with Japanese lawmakers.

According to the committee, the delegation will meet several members of the Japanese Diet, including prominent lawmaker Koki Kobayashi, to exchange views and ideas on cross-strait relations and the role of the U.S.-Japan Mutual Defense Treaty.

The members of the mission will also attend two forums, held by a Japanese think-tank and the Defense Research Center under the Japan Defense Agency, respectively, on Aug. 24 following a briefing on Japan's national defense in relation to its neighboring countries at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Tokyo a day earlier.

Members of the mission will include the committee's co-conveners Lu Hsiu-yen and Lin Yu-fang; Democratic Progressive Party Legislators Lee Wen-chung, Tang Huo-sheng and Shen Fa-huei; Kuomintang lawmakers Ting Shou-chung and Liao Wan-ju; People First Party Legislator Ku Chung-lien; and Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Ho Ming-hao.
