DOC.HEADLINE: SCI-TECH MEETING CONCLUSIONS TO BECOME POLICY GOALS: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday experts' recommendations at a science and technology strategy meeting will be adopted to improve the people's living standard.

Speaking at the closing ceremony of this year's Strategic Review Board ( SRB) meeting, the premier said if all government offices can change to white-light LED products within 10 years, Taiwan will be in a better position to tell the world that it has been implementing the Kyoto Protocol.

The SBR meeting was sponsored by the Cabinet's Science and Technology Advisory Group (STAG) , which coordinates government and private sector efforts to promote the nation's science and technological development.

Hsieh said the government will work harder to train sci-tech manpower, coordinate interdisciplinary research, promote the application of science and technology in daily life, and identify leading strategies to help commercialize and popularize the nation's research results.
He noted that the government could go as far as coordinating support for nanotechnology, flexible electronics and radio frequency identification technology (RFID).
Hsieh said Taiwan is the world leader in the manufacture of organic light emitting diode (OLED) products, but is behind South Korea in production technology.

Therefore, he said he has asked Minister-without-Portfolio Lin Feng-ching to form an industry group that will focus on commercializing research in this area to help the industry improve its manufacturing technology.

He hoped that within 10 years, all government offices will be using Taiwan-made white-light LED products, thus saving a lot of energy, an achievement that could be presented to the world in the post-Kyoto Protocol era.

On the application of RFID technology, which used to be concentrated in the military, he said it can also be used by the government's customs, the private sector's department stores and even ordinary households.
For instance, he said when he was mayor of Kaohsiung City, he encouraged parents to install RFID chips in the school bags of their children so they could keep track of their whereabouts.

The premier disclosed that the government's sci-tech spending will go up next year even as the total budget goes down, advancing the government schedule of spending 3 percent of the GDP on science and technology R&D by 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO IMPROVE WELFARE SERVICES FOR THE DISADVANTAGED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed the government's commitment Thursday to offering better care and benefits for disadvantaged groups, including aborigines, foreign spouses and impoverished families.
Chen made the comments while receiving some 100 aboriginal schoolchildren from the southern counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung who were in Taipei on an "experiencing urban life" trip.
To deliver on the commitment, Chen said his administration has offered subsidies for five-year-old aboriginal children to receive pre-school education since Aug. 1 this year.

In addition, Chen said, the government has also earmarked an additional outlay of NT$20 million to finance training for language, reading and to help those with learning disabilities under the Ministry of the Interior's 2005 social welfare fund.
Since 2000, Chen said the government has offered more than NT$230 million to subsidize aboriginal communities to build 24 day-care centers and renovate facilities at 59 existing ones.
In the future, Chen said the government will continue to set aside more funds to improve welfare services for the disadvantaged.
The aboriginal schoolchildren sang their tribal songs and danced to express their pleasure at having met with the president.

Noting that the young visitors come from different indigenous tribes, including Bunun, Paiwan, Rukai and Tsou, and 15 of them were born to mothers from the Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia and South Africa, Chen said they embody Taiwan's ethnic and cultural diversity.

Over the past 400-plus years, Chen said, Taiwan has seen many major waves of migrants. From the Dutch-Spanish colonial rule periods to Ming-Ching dynasties to the Japanese colonial rule to the Nationalist government period, many new migrants settled in Taiwan. In recent years, foreign brides and laborers have instilled new vitality into Taiwan's life tapestry.
"Ethnic and cultural diversity has been Taiwan's important asset and a major driving force behind Taiwan's social progress and international competitiveness," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'LONGEVITY TOWNSHIP' TO HOLD PARTY FOR 818 LONG-MARRIED COUPLES

TEXT.P: The Liujiao township government in the southern county of Chiayi will sponsor a special party Aug. 26 for the town's 818 couples who have been married for more than 50 years, a spokesman said Thursday.
According to the spokesman, Liujiao township has been known locally as "longevity town" because it has many centenarians.
To show its respect for its senior residents, the township government will organize celebration activities Aug. 26 for the 818 couples to mark their golden or diamond wedding anniversary.
Liujiao, which stands for six legs in Chinese, is a typical rural township in Taiwan, with rice, peanuts, sorghum and asparagus as its main produce.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE OCEAN SURVEY VESSEL CHASED OUT OF TAIWAN WATERS

TEXT.P: A Chinese ocean survey vessel was chased out of Taiwan waters Thursday by two patrol ships from the Coast Guard Administration (CGA), a CGA official said.
The Chinese vessel, the "Striving 4, " was spotted Wednesday mid-morning operating in Taiwan waters about 100 nautical miles west of Kaohsiung, in southern Taiwan.
The CGA sent a patrol ship to drive it away and asked the air force to keep an eye on the ship from its surveillance airplanes.

The patrol ship found the Chinese vessel at sea some 110 nautical miles west of Kaohsiung Wednesday night and monitored its operations from a distance. A second CGA ship arrived at the scene Thursday morning and asked the "Struggling 4" to leave.

At the same time, the Strait Exchange Foundation in Taipei was alerted to the intrusion of the Chinese vessel and relayed a request from the CGA to the Chinese authorities for the survey vessel to leave.

The "Striving 4" left the area Thursday afternoon as the weather at sea was worsening. The vessel had intruded into Taiwan waters in May and operated near the Taiwan-claimed Pratas Islands in the South China Sea. It left reluctantly after confronting Taiwan patrol ships for four days.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS ADJUSTS ECONOMIC GROWTH FORECAST UPWARD TO 3.65%

TEXT.P: The Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) adjusted Thursday its economic growth forecast for this year slightly upward to 3.65 percent.

The DGBAS also announced that the gross domestic product (GDP) posted a 3.03 percent growth in the second quarter of this year and predicted that the nation's per capita gross national product will reach US$15,156 this year.
According to the latest DGBAS forecast, the nation's GDP growth rate will rise to 4.03 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR TAIWAN COMMUNITIES GAIN SAFETY ACCREDITATION FROM WHO

TEXT.P: Four Taiwan communities have been granted safety accreditation from the World Health Organization's Collaborating Center on Community Safety Promotion (CCCSP), officials of the Department of Health said Thursday.

Those communities include Neihu in the northern city of Taipei, Alishan in the southern county of Chiayi, Tungshi in the central county of Taichung and Fengpin in the eastern county of Hualien, the officials said.

Taiwan is the third Asian country to gain the accreditation, the officials said, adding that Taiwan also has become the first country in the world to gain the accreditation by successfully promoting four different community types: urban for Neihu, agricultural for Tungshi, mountainous for Alishan and coastal for Fengpin, they said.

The chairman of the CCCSP is slated to visit Taiwan to present safety accreditation logos Oct. 15-19 to the four communities, thus making the four officially enter the international safety community network, they added.
The CCCSP is an organization dedicated to community safety promotion, injury-, violence- and suicide prevention which covers all age groups, gender and areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-INDIA COOPERATION SAID STRONG ENOUGH TO TAP WORLD MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan-India cooperation, particularly in the information technology field, has a huge potential to make the two countries invincible around the world, Taiwan and Indian officials claimed Wednesday.

Speaking at a seminar sponsored by the CNA on Taiwan-India business prospects and challenges, India-Taipei Association Chairman Vijay Gokhale said that India, which is undergoing a "profound and incredible" transformation since economic opening in 1991, provides enormous business and investment opportunities.

Thanks to the Indian government's stable economic policy, the country now counts a middle class of more than 100 million people, a number that is expected to quadruple by 2015, Gokhale said, encouraging Taiwan people to visit India.

Wu Hsin-hua, deputy director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , said t that he ministry has listed India as one of its nine foreign markets worthy of exploration by Taiwan companies. The ministry sent two trade promotion missions to India last year, while India also dispatched a group to Taiwan, he noted.

According to Wu, some 1.24 million of India's 1 billion population are customers with strong purchasing power, while 37 million families are capable of buying durable goods, making India a market attractive to foreign traders.

The MOEA will be very happy to see cooperative ventures forged between Taiwanese and Indian enterprises, in particular in the IT sector, he said, adding that the two countries will be able "to sweep through the whole world" if they team up to tap the global market.

Wang Hsi-mong, a deputy director at the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council, said that the two countries stand a good chance of breaking into other fields such as electronics and automobile parts and accessories.

Citing government statistics, Wang reported that Taiwan exports to India hit more than US$1.07 million last year, while imports from totaled US$860 million. Two-way Taiwan-India trade exceeded the combined level of Taiwan's trade with Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and Pakistan, he noted.

Claiming that India offers a tremendous potential market for Taiwan businesses keen to diversify, he suggested that domestic companies make the Indian market a target in their strategic market deployment plans to pursue new horizons.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS EXERCISE LESS THAN FOREIGN COUNTERPARTS: POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's elementary and junior high school students exercise less than their foreign counterparts, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by the Ministry of Education (MOE).

In U.S. grade schools and high schools, students have physical education class every day, according to the MOE report. In comparison, the weekly physical education time is only 90 minutes in Taiwan's junior high schools and 80 minutes in elementary schools, far less than the 250 minutes in French high schools and 200 minutes in French elementary schools.
Taiwan also lags behind China and Japan in terms of the weekly physical education hours in high schools and elementary schools, the MOE report said.
According to the MOE survey, local people aged over 15 spend two hours and 20 minutes watching television per day, about 50 minutes reading newspapers or resting, and only 19 minutes exercising.
In advanced countries, students who exercise regularly account for 50 percent to 60 percent of total students, compared to only 22 percent in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-GROWN PAPAYAS BOUND FOR CANADIAN MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin County, southern Taiwan (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's famous Lingnei papayas, grown in the rural township of Lingnei in southern Yunlin County, have found new customers in Canada, with a batch of 500 boxes of the fruit set to be shipped Aug. 23 for the first time.

The tropical fruit is now in season. While growers used to worry that a bountiful harvest would result in glut, there is now hope that their fruit can compete with Hawaii-grown papayas in the North American market.
Papaya is a major item of Yunlin County's agricultural produce, with 150 hectares of orchards yielding 12,600 metric tons of papayas annually, of which 66 percent are grown in Lingnei township.

In recent years, agricultural experts from the Council of Agriculture and Chunghsin University have helped the township set aside 20 hectares specifically to grow papayas for export. These orchards are netted to prevent fruit flies and plant diseases from affecting the fruit.
The harvested fruit will be strictly graded according to international standards and kept refrigerated for shipping to overseas markets.
The Yunlin county government and the Farmers Association of Lingnei township jointly held a workshop Thursday to explain to fruit growers how to supply the export market.

Speaking at the workshop, Li Ching-yung, acting Yunlin county magistrate, described the export of papayas to Canada as a milestone in the county's agricultural development and said there are more challenges ahead in promoting the county's other farm produce such as pineapples and tea.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Soldiers Surround Synagogues as Gaza Evacuation Continues
Hundreds of teenagers and other young people barricaded themselves into synagogue complexes in Jewish settlement, as soldiers and the police vowed to move in and evacuate them. Thousands of soldiers entered the hard-line settlement at dawn, on the second day of the forcible removal of Jewish settlers from the Gaza Strip. They quickly surrounded the heavily fortified synagogues and nearby buildings, and moved into nearby homes after the attempt at negotiations with the residents failed.
Wall Street Journal: High Life Behind Zooming Condo Prices: New Demographics or a Bubble?
As condominium prices reach never-before-seen heights, a debate is brewing over whether a fundamental demographic shift is driving the trend or whether this is simply the latest speculative bubble in a corner of the real-estate market that has seen plenty of them. Demographic changes in the middle class can explain some of this. The ideal of the two-parent family with 2.2 children living in a suburban house is being supplanted by an array of arrangements, including single professionals, divorcees, active retirees and single parents. For many of these people, an urban condo is both more luxurious and convenient than a house with a yard. But economists and housing experts are increasingly concerned that too many people, trying to cash in on the phenomenon, are buying speculatively, causing prices to rise faster than economic fundamentals can support.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORSS-STRAIT FINANCIAL, ECONOMIC FORUM TO OPEN IN CHINA

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers, businessmen and academics will meet their Chinese counterparts in a forum to discuss financial and economic issues from Aug. 21-25, according to a statement issued Thursday by Legislator Christina Liu of the opposition People First Party.

Liu, who is one of the organizers of the event, said the 2005 Cross-Strait Financial and Economic Forum will open Aug. 21 in Shanghai to discuss capital markets before moving on to Yangzhou in Jiangsu Province to discuss Chinese companies' ventures in the world market and Nanjing also in Jiangsu Province to discuss monetary markets.
Each discussion will be followed by a seminar, according to the statement.
The Taiwan participants will also visit the Shanghai Branch of the People's Bank of China, the Shanghai Stock Exchange and a security firm in Shanghai.
The forum is co-organized by Taiwan's Financial & Economic Bills Research Association, Shanghai's Jiao Tong University and Nanjing University, Liu said.
Six lawmakers and around 30 academics and businessmen from Taiwan will take part in the forum, according to Liu's statement.
DPP Legislator Gao Jyh-peng had intended to join the delegation but dropped out after President Chen Shui-bian expressed opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S WHO ROLE BUT REJECTS TAIWAN AFFAIRS ACT
DOC.DATELINE: Vancouver, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Ho Feng-yun and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Pierre Pettigrew said Thursday that Canada supports Taiwan's right to join the World Health Organization (WHO) but opposes a private member's bill that would formalize bilateral relations.
During an interview in Vancouver, Pettigrew said the proposed Taiwan Affairs Act contradicts Canada's one-China policy and will not be in the interests of the people of the three countries.

He said Canada has built constructive relations with Taiwan under the "one China" principle. As the proposed Taiwan Affairs Act, which aims to "provide for an improved framework for economic, trade, cultural and other initiatives between the people of Canada and the people of Taiwan, " could seriously damage Canada's ties with China, both his ministry and the federal government are against it, he said.

On the other hand, he went on, because the people of Taiwan have a right to information and services from the WHO and to contribute to the world community through participating in WHO activities, Canada supports Taiwan's bid to join the WHO as an observer.

He noted that supporting Taiwan's WHO status and opposing the Taiwan Affairs Act are not self-contradictory -- the former will help the people of Taiwan acquire assistance from the WHO, whereas the latter will touch on the nerves of Beijing and Taipei in their sovereignty dispute.
Jim Abbot, a member of parliament of the opposition Conservative Party, put forward the bill, which passed its first reading in April, angering Chinese diplomats based in Ottawa.

As Canada's ruling Liberal Party does not enjoy a majority in the House of Commons, both the Liberal government and the Chinese government were nervous that the bill might become law, given the prevailing sympathy of opposition lawmakers toward Taiwan.
Pettigrew said the bill is being reviewed by the House's Foreign Affairs Committee, which will decide whether or not to make any amendments before putting it to a second reading.
Stephen Harper, Conservative Party leader, told Chinese-language media in Toronto last month that the chances of a private member's bill becoming a law are very slim.
Harper said he expected the bill to be put to the second reading in November at the earliest, by which time, he added, it might have been altered or, if put to a vote, blocked.
He added that his party's platform recognizes only one China but the party is very willing to maintain good trade ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 18TH ASIAN INTERNATIONAL STAMP EXHIBITION TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Taipei 2005 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition will open at the Taipei World Trade Center Friday, with more than 1,500 frames of stamps from 22 countries on show.
Among them, 1,415 are in the competitive class while 141 are in the non-competitive class, according to Chunghwa Post Co., sponsor of the event.
The exhibition, the first large international stamp show to be held in Taiwan since the Directorate General of Posts was transformed in January 2003 into Chunghwa Post, will run through Aug. 24.

The theme of the exhibition is "tourism and stamps," with the aim that through the combination of stamps and sightseeing, Taiwan's beauty can be seen by all. The Formosan black bear -- an indigenous animal -- has been chosen as the mascot of the event.
The logo of the exhibition is Taipei 101, the world's tallest skyscraper, located near the exhibition venue, which the sponsor hopes will demonstrate Taiwan's new vibrancy.

The exhibition features several valuable stamps deemed "jewels of the nation's stamps" -- the surcharged issue of Flying Geese stamps from around the early 1950s and the unique Flying Dragon stamps for express mail from the Qing dynasty, as well as the red revenue stamps temporarily surcharged at one dollar, which are estimated to be worth around NT$10 million (US$312,500).

To publicize and celebrate the occasion, Chunghwa Post is issuing a series of eight separate souvenir sheets. The first and second -- Taiwan landscape and Taiwan Culture -- were released Aug. 27, 2004 and April 19, 2005, respectively. The third to the eighth -- Taiwan Conservation, Taiwan Technology, Taiwan Flowers and Fruits, Taiwan Festivals, Taiwan Cuisine and Taiwan Ocean Life -- will be released during each day of the exhibition. Each sheet consists of one NT$5 stamp and one NT$25 stamp.

To commemorate the show, Chunghwa Post is also releasing a set of four "Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition Commemorative Postage Labels, " each of which features a different section of the ancient painting of cranes titled "taisiantu" from the National Palace Museum collection. The numbered postage labels will be printed with four different designs in consecutive order in a roll.

The "taisiantu" was painted by the Ming painter Bian Wen-jin. The scroll depicts 136 cranes, flying, making calls, pecking, fighting, swimming -- in every pose imaginable and all rendered beautifully. The crane is a symbol of longevity.
The set will be available at the exhibition venue and at all locations equipped with postage label vending machines around the island starting Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUSHING JAPAN TO ENACT TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT PRIORITY: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that urging Japan to enact a law similar to the U.S. Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) is one of the ministry's priorities.

Lin Sung-huan, director-general of the Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, made the remarks after U.S. quarterly Foreign Policy published an interview with Vice President Annette Lu in which she said it would be "most helpful" if the United States could encourage Japan to pass a law like the TRA to regulate relations between Japan and Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Lu said that thanks to the TRA signed into law by former U.S. President Jimmy Carter in 1979, relations between the United States and Taiwan have been sustained. "Currently, Canada's Parliament is debating such a bill," she claimed. "So it is time to encourage Japan to adopt such a formula," she added.
Lin said that as the law will require approval by the majority of the Japanese Diet, the ministry will continue to push for the cause after the parliament elections next month.
Lin also said Japan supports a proposal that the United Nations should play a role in safeguarding peace in the Taiwan Strait.

He noted that Taiwan is adopting a new strategy to enter the United Nations this year. Under the new strategy, 14 Republic of China allies, recently made two proposals to U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan urging the U.N. General Assembly to ascertain the U.N. representation of the 23 million people of Taiwan and requesting the U.N. to play a role in safeguarding peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen also said that with the nation's 13th consecutive bid to enter the U.N., Taiwan needs to step up an international publicity campaign to solicit the support of such countries as Japan and the United States.

Lin said that although Tokyo has yet to formally express its stance, the ministry has learned from initial communications that Japan thinks peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait is a mutual concern of the U.S. and Japan and that the U.N.'s part in safeguarding peace in the Taiwan Strait should get international community attention.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTORS WELCOME IN INDIA'S SPECIAL ECONOMIC ZONES

TEXT.P: Taiwan investors are welcome to set up footholds in India's special economic zones, which levy lower investment taxes than China's zones, India-Taipei Association Chairman Vijay Gokhale said Wednesday.
Gokhale extended a welcome at a seminar sponsored by the CNA on Taiwan-India business prospects and challenges, in which about 20 trade officials and experts of the two countries participated.

Since the Indian government enacted its Special Economic Zone Bill in May this year, 11 such zones have been set up so far, while 30 another have applied to do so, Gokhale said, adding that foreign investors will be provided with handsome incentives and good services.

India's economic opening from 1991 has pushed the country to brace for foreign investment, including from Taiwan, he said, adding that Taiwan businessmen are welcome to make long-term strategic investments in India.

According to the top Indian trade official stationed in Taipei, his country is rife with trade and business opportunities given that it has a middle class of more than 100 million people and counts a larger number of young people than Brazil, China or Russia -- the three other BRIC countries.
Gokhale expressed hope that more people in Taiwan will visit India as his country becomes more and more globalized.

E.K. Bharat Bhushan, a deputy tourism minister from Kerala State in southwest India, suggested that Taiwan businessmen consider exploring India's tourism and hotel industries at a time when travel-related sectors have become the major engine behind the country's economic development.

Although India has a long history and possesses abundant cultural and natural resources, Bhushan pointed out that there are not enough large tourism hotels in India and that Taiwan enterprises are welcome to invest in this sector.

Lin Chih-huei, a deputy sales manager at China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier, said businessmen account for about 30 percent of the passengers traveling on the route between Taipei and New Delhi operated by CAL three times a week -- the sole direct air links between the two countries.

According to Lin, only a little over 10,000 people from Taiwan traveled to India last year, while around 11,000 people from India visited Taiwan -- an indication that there is ample room for the development of two-way business and tourism activities.

Claiming that an adequate government policy coupled with private sector promotion will help serve that end, Lin called for government subsidies to help finance charter flight services as a way to step up bilateral tourist exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA HEAD WILL NOT SEEK ANOTHER TERM

TEXT.P: Lee Yuan-tseh, president of Academia Sinica, the nation's highest academic institute, has no intention of serving another term after his current one expires in October 2006, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng revealed Thursday.
Wang made the remarks after he met with the Nobel laureate earlier in the day.
Lee did not say what he wants to do after stepping down from the post or whether he will continue to live in Taiwan, according to Wang.

Lee returned to Taiwan in 1994 after staying in the United States for more than three decades to head the prestigious institute. He concurrently serves as a convener of a reform committee under the Executive Yuan to promote controversial education reforms.
Lee visited Wang mainly to push for an early passage through the Legislative Yuan of a revised draft bill of the organic law of the Academia Sinica.

The organic law stipulates that Academia Sinica chief is selected by a screening committee of members and appointed by the president, while the revised draft law would have a screening committee to select a list of three candidates for the president to select his choice.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LEGISLATOR WITHDRAWS FROM JAPAN DELEGATION

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition People First Party (PFP) announced Thursday his withdrawal from a fact-finding mission of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee set to visit Japan from Aug. 22, in protest over a scheduled meeting with an ultra-rightist Japanese politician.

Legislator Lin Yu-fang, a co-convener of the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee, said in a news release that he is "extremely unhappy" that the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has included in the mission's itinerary a meeting with former Japanese Justice Minister Shigeto Nagano -- a controversial figure known for his attempts in 1994 to whitewash Japanese atrocities during the Second World War.
Lin demanded an apology from the MND, which arranged the itinerary after consulting with Taiwan's representative office in Japan.

"By allowing the representative office in Japan to make such an arrangement, you are failing those soldiers who sacrificed their lives resisting Japanese aggression and those innocent Asian people murdered by Japanese troops," he said.
Lin claimed that if the MND fails to apologize, it will become an "endless issue" for the next Legislative Yuan session, which begins Sept. 13.
The PFP lawmaker pointed out that Nagano is on record as saying that the Pacific War launched by Japan was "a war of liberation" and that the Nanjing Massacre of 1937-38 was a "fabrication."

Nagano made the assertions during an interview with Japan's Mainichi newspaper shortly after he was appointed justice minister in 1994. He was forced to resign under mounting domestic and international pressure only 10 days after taking office.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEALTH GAP NARROWING: GOVERNMENT STATISTICS

TEXT.P: The gap between rich and poor in Taiwan is narrowing, thanks to the government's generous social welfare programs, according to statistics released Thursday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Executive Yuan.

The statistics show that the richest 20 percent of the population earned an average of NT$1.79 million in 2004, which is 6.03 times the average of NT$297,000 earned by the poorest 20 percent of the population.

The gap is narrower than the 6.07 times of the previous year, mainly because of the government's welfare programs, not least a raise from NT$3,000 to NT$4,000 in the government's monthly pension to elderly farmers and low-income laborers, the DGBAS said in a statement accompanying the statistics.

The difference of 6.03 times is higher than the 4.8 times in Japan and 5.8 percent in Germany, but lower than the 6.8 times in South Korea, 9.8 times in the United States, 17.7 times in Hong Kong and 20.9 times in Singapore.
On average, each household earned NT$1.12 million in 2004, or NT$94,000 per month, which is 1 percent more than that of the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING KMT CHIEF ENCOURAGES PARTY REJUVENATION

TEXT.P: Outgoing opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, who is set to hand over the party's reins to his successor Ma Ying-jeou Friday, will encourage his party comrades to rejuvenate and reform the party in his farewell address, according to an advance copy of his address released Thursday.

Lien will express thanks for the party's support during his five-year tenure, during which, he said, he was devoted to reviving the party's soul and spirit and clearly reaffirming the party's loyalty to the Republic of China.

Owing to the party's courageous defense of the Constitution and its relentless criticism of what he described as the government's "shoddy policies, " Lien claimed the party's popularity among the public had risen to more than 60 percent in a recent survey, which bodes well for the party's ambition to win back power in 2008.

The handover will take place before the opening of the party's congress, which is timed to open one day before the date when Sun Yat-sen founded the Tungmeng Association -- a fore-runner of the KMT -- 100 years ago. Lien will urge party members to keep the torch passed down by Sun and offer voters a different option in the next presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 19, or the 15th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Blaise Pascal, the French mathematician, physicist and religious philosopher, dies in Paris at the age of 39.
1871: Orville Wright, the American aviation pioneer, who, with his brother Wilbur, made the first powered and controlled flight, is born.
1878: Manuel Luis Quezon y Molina, first president of the Philippines Commonwealth established under U.S. tutelage in 1935, is born.
1901: Shang Tai, the last monarch of the Ryukyu Kingdom, dies in Tokyo at the age of 58.
1904: Japanese troops launch a disastrous attack on Russian-held Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China during the Russo-Japanese War. Of the 51,000 troops involved, only about 35,000 survived.
1934: Nearly 90 percent of Germans vote to give Adolf Hitler the presidency in addition to his position as chancellor.
1936: Kwangsi rebels in China set up an independent regime in Kweilin.
1936: A total of 16 senior members of the Soviet Communist Party are executed after Josef Stalin orders a purge of the party to get rid of followers of Leon Trotsky, a leader of the Bolshevik Revolution.
1945: Forces led by Ho Chi Minh and the Viet Minh begin the August Revolution against French colonial rule in Vietnam.
1946: Chinese Communist Party leader Mao Tse-tung announces that communist forces will launch a full-scale war against the Chinese government.
1946: Bill Clinton, the 42nd president of the United States, is born. He served as governor of Arkansas from 1978 to 1980 and again from 1982 until he was elected U.S. president in November 1992.
1960: The Soviet Union sentences U-2 spy plane pilot Gary Powers to 10 years in detention.
1966: An earthquake rocks eastern Turkey, killing more than 2,000 people.
1979: Pol Pot, ex-dictator of Cambodia, is sentenced to death in absentia for genocide by the Cambodian government.
1989: Poland becomes the first country in Eastern Europe to end one-party rule, as Solidarity's Tadeuz Mazowiecki takes office as prime minister.
1990: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein offers to release all Western hostages in exchange for a U.S. withdrawal from the Gulf region and an end to the blockade.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev, the Soviet leader who gave a nervous world two words of hope -- "glasnost" and "perestroika" -- is toppled, just one day short of the scheduled signing of the Union Treaty, a document hated by the hardliners because it signals the beginning of the end of the Soviet empire they know and love.
1995: The Republic of China Foreign Ministry issues a position paper entitled "Why the U.N. Resolution No. 2758 Adopted in 1971 Should be Re-examined Today." The paper stresses that the resolution, which excluded the ROC from the United Nations, is obsolete and unjust.
1996: ROC Vice President and Premier Lien Chan visits the Ukraine.
1996: Niger switches diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
1999: The Taiwan Independence Party nominates its chairman, Cheng Pang-chen, as its candidate for the ROC's next presidential election slated for March 2000.
2000: An agreement sending International Cooperation and Development volunteers from the ROC to Nicaragua is passed during a regular meeting of the Executive Yuan.
2001: A 36-hour course on conducting election campaigns launched by the newly-established Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Taiwan's 95th political party, begins at the Grand Hotel Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to figure out, but once you try to figure out a thing, you must never give it up until you have got what you want."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPES TO FILL VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER VACANCY WITHIN WEEK

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh hopes to fill the vacant vice economic affairs minister post within a week, an Executive Yuan spokesman said Friday.

Cho Jung-tai said that in reviewing accountability for the recent water supply problem in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, the premier had expressed the hope of soliciting a water supply expert to replace Yiin Chii-ming, vice economic affairs minister who served as convener of the ministry's water resources screening committee and water resources coordination committee before being demoted Wednesday over the Taoyuan water supply problem.

After Typhoon Matsa battered Taiwan in early August bringing strong winds and torrential rains, water supply in Taoyuan was disrupted because of the high turbidity in the Shihmen Reservoir -- the county's main water source. The water supply in the northern part of the county was not fully restored until Aug. 13.

Cho said the premier has talked with nearly 10 former officials, hydraulic power scholars, and experts on how to solve the persistent water problems in Taoyuan County, although he has yet to inquire about their intention to serve as vice economic affairs minister.

Cho also said that during a regular weekly meeting with President Chen Shui-bian Thursday, the premier also exchanged views with the president on how to promote hydraulic works, and that the president had given no instructions on who should fill the post left open by Yiin.
The premier had recently pointed out that none of the three sitting vice economic affairs ministers are water experts, and that their "jobs might have to be adjusted."
