Roberts Jr. consistently opposed legal and legislative attempts to strengthen women's rights during his years as a legal adviser in the Reagan White House, disparaging what he called "the purported gender gap" and, at one point, questioning "whether encouraging homemakers to become lawyers contributes to the common good."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOUSE ARMED SERVICE COMMITTEE MEMBERS CONSIDERING VISITING TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Several members of the U.S. House of Representatives Armed Services Committee have been talking about possibly visiting Taiwan to exchange views with Taiwan's opposition lawmakers on the long-stalled special arms procurement bill.

The Bush administration has offered to sell eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft to Taiwan to beef up the island's self-defense capabilities.

Members of the House Armed Services Committee are scheduled to embark on an Asian tour in September, and some have suggested detouring to Taiwan for talks with Taiwan's legislators to push for passage of the arms procurement bill in the new session of the Legislative Yuan which is set to open early next month.

Most of the committee members have expressed high expectations about Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is set to take over the chairmanship of the main opposition Kuomintang Friday, being able to improve interactions between the opposition parties and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and thereby facilitating passage of the arms procurement bill.

The bill's prospects seem to have improved recently with legislators from both sides moving closer on the issue by suggesting that some of the items in the arms procurement package could be listed in the military's regular annual budget instead of being financed by a special budget.

As to making a stop in Taiwan, several of the members of the U.S. House Armed Services Committee have said they feel it has become necessary, particularly following the recent release by the Pentagon of its latest report on China's military.

In the report issued July 19, 2005, the U.S. Defense Department stated that "the cross-strait balance of power is shifting towards Beijing.... Chinese air, naval and missile force modernization is increasing demands on Taiwan to develop countermeasures that would enable it to avoid being quickly overwhelmed."
The congressmen said that China's continued deployment of hundreds of ballistic missiles directed toward Taiwan is threatening the security and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

There have been rumblings of impatience and dissatisfaction on Capitol Hill recently that Taiwan lawmakers are using the arms procurement bill as a political power struggle tool. Some have expressed doubts about whether the United States should be committed to Taiwan's defense when the island itself doesn't seem committed to the task.

Some China hands in Washington, D.C. have also said that in the face of the increasing military imbalance across the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan should at least be equipped with proper defense capabilities to allow it to stave off an attack until outside help arrives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERSONALIZED STAMPS FEATURING POPULAR MODEL SELLING LIKE HOT CAKES

TEXT.P: Personalized greeting stamps and postcards featuring popular model Lin Chi-ling were selling like hot cakes after the Taipei 2005 Stamp Exhibition and the 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition kicked off Friday.

A long queue formed outside the Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall before the opening of the exhibition, with the majority of those in line coming for the commemorative silver coins and Lin's personalized greeting stamps and postcards.
Chunghwa Post Co., sponsor of the international event, said that the company has printed Lin's photos taking part in various charity events to produce Lin's public welfare postcards.

Company officials said that 10,000 public welfare postcards featuring Lin will be issued and the expected proceeds of NT$1.2 million (US$37,500) will be donated to help impoverished children in the counties of Chiayi and Yunlin.

There are only a limited number of 2,500 Lin postcards for sale during the inaugural day of the six-day exhibition, so many fans arrived at the Taipei World Convention Center early in the morning of the first day of the exhibition.

Chunghwa Post said that it will offer 30 postcards autographed by Lin Monday. Those who enter the exhibition hall before 11 a.m. that day and obtain a draw ticket will have the chance to win one of the autographed postcards.

One man, surnamed Chu, said that he arrived at the exhibition site at 5 a.m. Chu said that he is not a fan of Lin but that he likes the design of the postcard. Another man, surnamed You, said that he took a day off from work to come and buy Lin's postcards, adding that he also lined up when Chunghwa Post issued Lin's personalized greeting stamps last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: RARE STAMPS ON DISPLAY INSURED FOR OVER NT$2 BILLION

TEXT.P: Sponsors have purchased more than NT$2 billion (US$60.6 million) worth of insurance for the rare and valuable stamps and related collections on display at the Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition which opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Friday.

Among the 1,556 stamps on display, several are deemed "jewels of the nation's stamps" -- including the Flying Geese stamps issued in the early 1950s, the unique Flying Dragon postage stamps for express mail items during the Qing Dynasty, and the rare Red Color revenue stamps currently estimated to be worth around NT$10 million (US$312,500) , according to Chunghwa Post Co., key sponsor of the event.
The exhibition is the first large international stamp show to be held in Taiwan since the Directorate General of Posts became Chunghwa Post in January 2003. It is set to run through Aug. 24.

The event, whose theme is "Tourism and Stamps, " is aimed at promoting Taiwan's stamps as well as tourism. The Formosan black bear, which is indigenous to Taiwan, has been chosen as the mascot of the event.
The logo of the exhibition is the Taipei 101 tower -- the world's tallest skyscraper -- which the sponsor said hopes will demonstrate Taiwan's new vibrancy.

To publicize and celebrate the occasion, Chunghwa Post is issuing a series of eight separate souvenir sheets. The first and second -- No. 1 Taiwan Landscape and No.2 Taiwan Culture -- were released on Aug. 27, 2004, and April 19, 2005, respectively. The third through eighth -- No. 3 Taiwan Conservation, No. 4 Taiwan Technology, No. 5 Taiwan Flowers and Fruits, No. 6 Taiwan Festivals, No. 7 Taiwan Cuisine and No. 8 Marine Taiwan -- will be released one per day during the course of the exhibition.

To commemorate the event, Chunghwa Post is also releasing a set of four "Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition Commemorative Postage Labels, " each of which features a different section of the ancient painting "Taisiantu" from the National Palace Museum collection. The postage labels will be printed with four different designs in consecutive order in a roll. On the lower left corner of each label is a serial number that consists of two letters from the Roman alphabet and four Arabic numerals.

"Taisiantu" was created by the Ming painter Bian Wen-jin. The scroll depicts 136 cranes, flying, making calls, pecking, fighting, swimming -- in every pose imaginable and all rendered beautifully. The crane is a symbol of longevity.
The postage label set is available at the venue of the exhibition and at all locations equipped with postage label vending machines around the island starting Friday.

During the six-day run of the Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition, Chunghwa Post is also offering 10,000 gifts by prize draw, in addition to offering exhibition visitors the opportunity to have their own personal stamps and postcards made digitally.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA OFFICIALLY TAKES OVER KMT HELM

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou officially took over as main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairman from outgoing Chairman Lien Chan Friday, vowing to continue with reform at this historical juncture for the centenarian party.
Speaking at the KMT's 17th plenary session following the changeover ceremony, Ma admitted feeling "strong pressure" but also hopeful about the future.

Ma hailed Lien for his outstanding contribution to the KMT and cross-Taiwan Strait relations over the past five years, saying that Lien will be remembered in history for making a landmark "journey of peace" to China, for allowing for direct election of the KMT chairman, and for his efforts to wipe out the party's moneyed politics and dump its ill-gotten assets.

Ma also thanked Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng for running in "a gentlemen's race" in the KMT chairmanship election, saying it helped a great deal in improving the party's image. The July 16 election was the first time in the KMT's history that two vice chairmen competed for the party's top post through a direct vote by its members.
Ma promised to follow Lien's line and pledged to be open minded and visionary and to make the KMT into a clean party and win back power in 2008.

In his farewell speech, Lien praised Ma as young and savvy and urged Ma to ready himself for the 2008 presidential election and win back power from the Democratic Progressive Party despite all kinds of possible challenges ahead.
Lien also urged Wang to keep on helping Ma lead the KMT, lauding the legislative speaker's participation in the chairmanship election as helping deepen democracy within the party.
Wang has repeatedly turned down Ma's offer to serve as his deputy after losing the KMT chairmanship election but has made it clear that he will always be "a volunteer devoted to the party."

DOC.HEADLINE: STAMP EXHIBITION CLOSING GAP BETWEEN TAIWAN AND THE WORLD: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The holding of the Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition is helping close the gap between Taiwan and countries around Asia, an official from the Presidential Office said Friday.

In his speech to the opening of the exhibition held at the Taipei World Trade Center, James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, offered a hearty welcome on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian to participants at the stamp show coming from 22 Asian countries.

As Taiwan hosted the Asian Stamp Invitational Exhibition in 1993 and the 10th Asian International Stamp Exhibition in 1996, Huang said, it is believed that with the experience that Taiwan gained from the two former shows and the passion and devotion demonstrated by stamp collectors, we will help make the current Taipei 2005 -18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition a huge success.

Noting that many people equate a country's stamps to a country's "visiting or business card, " Huang said that his experience in learning about stamps when he was a child helped him gain more knowledge about the history and culture of many other countries around the world.
Also addressing the opening ceremony, Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Oliver Yu said that learning about and collecting stamps is a common experience among many people.

Yu said that stamp collection has become a hobby full of fun in Taiwan thanks in large part to the efforts of Chunghwa Post, adding that through the holding of the Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition, friendships are expected to be developed further among people from home and abroad.

Samuel J.S. Hsu, chairman of Chunghwa Post Co., key sponsor of the Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition, said that the event, whose theme is "Tourism and Stamps, " is aimed at promoting Taiwan's stamps as well as tourism. The Formosan black bear, which is indigenous to Taiwan, has been chosen as the mascot of the exhibition.
The logo of the exhibition is the Taipei 101 tower -- the world's tallest skyscraper -- which Hsu said demonstrates Taiwan's new vibrancy.

During the six-day run of the event, Hsu said, Chunghwa Post will issue a series of eight separate souvenir sheets, with one sheet to be released on each of the days of the exhibition, to introduce the beauty of Taiwan and its unique characteristics.
Hsu said that of the 1,556 stamps on display, one-third are from Taiwan, indicating that Taiwan has high standards in the area of philately.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush's Aid Cuts on Court Issue Roil Latin America Neighbors
Three years ago the Bush administration began prodding countries to shield Americans from the fledgling International Criminal Court in The Hague. The United States has since cut aid to some two dozens nations that refused to sign immunity agreements that American officials say are intended to protect American soldiers and policy makers from politically motivated prosecutions. Particularly in Latin America and the Caribbean, home to 12 nations that have been penalized, the cuts are generating strong resentment at what many see as heavy-handed diplomacy, officials and diplomats in seven countries said.
Wall Street Journal: As Iraqi Terror Rises, Business Find Niche in Life Insurance
Traditional life-insurance policies available in Iraq don't cover deaths from car bombings, ambushes, suicide attacks and the like. Iraqi insurance companies typically resell policies purchased from foreign conglomerates, and executives say foreign companies aren't willing to include coverage for terrorist attacks in those policies because of Iraq's frequent violence. Sensing an opportunity, five private and two government-owned insurance companies in Iraq recently banded together, jointly offering a life-insurance product that exclusively covers terrorism. The companies keep 10 percent of the money from policies they sell, putting the remaining 90 percent into a shared pool. The pool allows each firm to accept risks it would be unwilling to bear on its own.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Forced pullout in Gaza Strip continues.
Israeli riot police stormed synagogues of Jewish settlements in Gaza Strip Thursday to evacuate hardliners who were resisting forced evacuation from police. The police and unarmed troops have so far cleared 16 of 21 Jewish settlements in the region. The evacuation is expected to be completed by next Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: STAMPS FROM AROUND THE WORLD SHOWN AT TAIPEI EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: Twenty-two countries taking part in the Taipei 2005 and 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition showed off their distinctive colors when the six-day exhibition kicked off at the Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall Friday.
More than 1,500 frames of stamps from 22 countries are on show, with more than 70 booths at the exhibition hall displaying a wide variety of stamps for sale.

Stamp dealers from the United States have set up several booths at the show, promoting items such as stamps featuring Elvis Presley as well as NBA players. One U.S. booth featuring a "large Dragon" set of stamps from the Qing dynasty also attracted a lot of collectors on opening day.

A British booth is showing not only stamps but also many old envelopes, while the Swedish booth is displaying not only stamps from Sweden but also examples from Denmark and Monaco. The representative manning the booth said the display features the work of Czeslaw Slania (1921-2005), considered the world's most famous stamp engraver.
Slania has also left records as the most prolific and quickest engraver, and won numerous awards and prizes around the world, according to the representative.
The Japanese stamps on show tend to follow a cute trend, featuring characters such as Hello Kitty and Piccachio characters with which Taiwan people are familiar.
Mongolian postage stamps rarely seen in Taiwan also feature at the show, along with stamps from Arabian countries, South Korea, Australia and the Netherlands.
The exhibition will run through Aug. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 46.15 points to close at 6,158.94.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,190.33 and hit a low of 6,138.62 during trading. A total of 2.56 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.42 billion (US$1.97 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.1 percent, construction issues at 1 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.7 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.4 percent, cement stocks at 0.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares both at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 680 to 209, with 133 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD TAKES ON KMT COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang challenged major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma ying-jeou right after he took over the party leadership Friday to mean business in his pledge to reform the party, particularly on the issues of "black gold" and vote-buying.
Su also challenged Ma to lead the KMT into what he described as "benevolent competition" with the DPP during the year-end elections of county magistrates and mayors.
During a stumping tour of Taoyuan in northern Taiwan, Su advised Ma to shed his "teflon" image if he wants to wean his party off the so-called "black gold" or money politics and vote-buying.

Su said he understands Ma's ambition to lead the KMT to win back power in the 2008 presidential election but the DPP will do its utmost to get good grades on President Chen Shui-bian's administration, an achievement that he claimed will ensure the DPP continues as the ruling party.
William C.T. Lai, secretary-general of the DPP legislative caucus, criticized Ma's inaugural speech and challenged him to address the questions of party assets and vote-buying.

According to Lai, Ma spent much of his speech attacking the president and his administrative record as if he was delivering a campaign speech in 2008. "Loud criticism of the DPP does not mean the KMT will improve, as that requires concrete strategies," added Lai.
He also ridiculed Ma for "copying what Lien Chan has been doing -- fanning the KMT members' anger over the 319 shooting as the only step to unite the party."

Cheng Chen-lung, secretary-general of the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, said that if Ma wants the "pan-blue alliance" to take power in 2008, he must adequately deal with the baggage of the party's ill-gotten assets, return the party to the middle ground and respect the people's right to choose between unification and independence.

Ma's anti-Taiwan independence remarks show that he does not respect the people, he claimed, adding that Ma should agree to allow the people a free choice between unification with China and Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY HAS MOST BALANCE OF POLITICAL DONATIONS IN 2004

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) topped the other political parties with respect to the balance of political donations, with more than NT$97.31 million (US$3.04 million) as of the end of 2004, the nation's highest watchdog body said Friday.
The Control Yuan said that the DPP was followed by its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, with more than NT$7.18 million, and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) with more than NT$7.05 million.
The People First Party (PFP) , an ally of the KMT, had NT$2.42 million, Non-Partisan Solidarity Union had NT$550,000 and the New Party had NT$9,000.

Hsieh Yu-nan, the director in charge of public functionary assets disclosure in the Control Yuan, noted that after various political parties file their accounting reports of political donations, the Control Yuan must review them in accordance with the law. However, as the confirmation of the new members of the Control Yuan is stalled in the Legislative Yuan, the review will have to wait until their confirmation.

The political donation law was promulgated last year under which the recipients of political donations have to apply to the Control Yuan for approval. Political parties and groups are required to set up special accounts in financial institutions to receive political donations after approval by the Control Yuan, and the recipients are required to report on the balance of their accounts five months after the end of the previous year.
This was the first time that the balance of political donations had been announced.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRUIT EXHIBITION SHOWS GOVERNMENT'S PROMOTION EFFORTS: MAC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The 2005 exhibition of Taiwan's summer fruits and agricultural products kicked off at the Taipei World Trade Center Friday, attracting 23 potential buyers from Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, China, Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore.
More than 300 fruit growers and processors from 21 cities and counties displayed a wide range of fresh and processed fruits.
A total of 101 one-on-one meetings will be arranged between the fruit suppliers and their potential customers, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said.

Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) under the Executive Yuan, said at the opening ceremony that the exhibition demonstrates the government's commitment to facilitating fruit exports and its desire to help farmers.
Under the promotion of the Council of Agriculture and TAITRA, fruit from Taiwan is being sold around the world and has been well-received on the international market, including China, Wu said.

Wu said the government has never placed any barriers to the shipment of fruit from Taiwan to China and that TAITRA has been commissioned to negotiate with China on the issue of quarantine. Wu also appealed to China to launch chartered cargo flights with Taiwan for such shipments.

According to TAITRA, this year's customers include the Union Co. in Tokyo, which bought US$370 million-worth of fruit last year; the Hong Kong-based China Resources Vanguard Co., which sold US$2.96 billion-worth of fruit last year; and Indonesia's largest fruit store, Anugerah Buana Utama, which imports 300-400 containers of fruit every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 26 points to close at 6,164, with 25,114 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved down 31 points to end at 6,160, with 191 contracts traded, while December futures lost 35 points to finish at 6,158, with 31 contracts traded. March futures moved down 39 points to close at 6,147, with five contracts traded, while June futures moved down 49 points to close at 6,146, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,190 for September, 6,191 for October, 6,193 for December, 6,186 for March and 6,195 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
September TE futures moved down 2.05 points to close at 254.55, with 3,768 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for October, December, March and June.

September TF futures lost 3.4 points to finish at 952.6, with 2,724 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved up one point to end at 954, with 20 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 2.4 points to close at 951.4, with four contract transactions, while March TF futures lost 2.6 points to finish at 949.4, with four contracts traded. June TF future moved down 9.4 points to close at 950, with one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.075 to close at NT$32.189.
A total of US$798 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.165 and fluctuated between NT$32.151 and NT$32.190.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC RENEWS CALLS FOR CHINA'S RETURN TO NEGOTIATING TABLE

TEXT.P: An official from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) renewed Friday the MAC's calls for China to return to the negotiating table to facilitate efforts in seeking eternal peace across the Taiwan Strait.

MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung called for the Beijing authorities to resume talks with Taiwan on issues including China's plans to give a pair of pandas to Taiwan and visits to Taiwan by Chinese citizens.

You said that despite Beijing's two-handed maneuvering against Taiwan, the country will stick firmly to the policy of "seeking friendly reconciliation, active cooperation and eternal peace" with China.
This policy is also a reflection of President Chen Shui-bian's oft-repeated advocacy of "negotiation and reconciliation," You said.

He noted that the MAC will work to shelve controversial differences and hard-to-resolve issues, push for cross-strait negotiations and promote exchanges based on the principles of equality and reciprocity.

You said Taiwan needs to adopt new strategies to face the challenges from the other side of the strait because of Beijing's passage of its "Anti-Secession Law" authorizing the use of force if Taiwan edges toward formal independence on the one hand, while on the other putting forward a spate of gestures ostensibly to improve cross-strait interactions, including inviting opposition leaders to visit China, offering pandas to Taiwan, giving duty-free access for Taiwan agricultural produce and agreeing in principle to allow Chinese citizens to make tourism trips to Taiwan.
He warned that China has been using its growing economic prowess to expedite its military build-up, a move that has caused concern in Japan, the United States and many other countries.
You made the remarks during a colloquium sponsored by the Kaohsiung city government titled: "Perceiving China While Being Concerning about the Strait."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAKES 3 CONTRIBUTIONS TO ASIA-PACIFIC REGION THROUGH APEC ROLE

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Friday that Taiwan has made three contributions to the Asia-Pacific region -- trade and investment liberalization, security enhancement and economic and technical cooperation -- through its participation in the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Wu made the remarks when he attended a seminar on 2005 APEC issues sponsored by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), a local think tank.
Wu, who served as TIER president for a long time before taking up the post of vice premier, has taken part in many APEC-related activities over the years.

On trade and investment liberalization, Wu said Taiwan has carried out over 100 liberalization measures on tariffs, non-tariff hurdles, the service sector, investment, standardization, intellectual property rights, government procurement and personnel movement.

On safety enhancement, Wu said that as Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations, it has been unable to take part in anti-terrorism activities under the auspices of the United Nations. Since the APEC started to discuss anti-terrorism and security issues, however, Taiwan has been able to get involved in international anti-terrorism activities, he said.

On economic and technology cooperation, Taiwan has made several major initiatives, he went on, including an IT schools initiative, which has already been implemented, and an APEC Digital Opportunity Center (ADOC) initiative, which is still being implemented.
Wu added that if the number of times "Chinese Taipei" is mentioned in major APEC declarations is any indication of importance, then Taiwan is becoming more important.

He noted that "Chinese Taipei" was only mentioned six times in the major declaration of APEC before 2000. But from 2000 to the present, Taiwan has been mentioned twice in APEC Leaders' Declarations and 23 times in the annual ministers' declaration.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW KMT CHAIRMAN OUTLINES REFORM BLUEPRINT

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou outlined a blueprint for party reforms Friday, suggesting seven measures to carry out the mission by 2008.
Ma outlined the reform plan in a speech in the KMT's 17th plenary session after officially taking over the party helm from his predecessor, Lien Chan.

Stressing that the KMT must stick to its reform promise to garner greater public backing, Ma proposed cementing democracy in the party, expanding the public support base, rejuvenating the party, reaching out to southern Taiwan, handling the issue of the party's assets, consolidating the opposition "pan blue alliance" and taking care of retired and laid-off party workers.

In an effort to strengthen support for the KMT, Ma suggested that the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee (CSC) hold its weekly meetings in various cities and counties in southern regions.
He expressed the hope that CSC members will be directly elected by party delegates in the future, but said that he will respect any final decision to be made with regard to the plenary session.
The KMT must set a clear timetable for dealing with its assets by 2008, the proceedings of which will be used to look after retired and departing party workers, he said.

To meet high supporter expectations for a merger of the "pan blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party, the new KMT boss said that his party will cooperate with its two political allies through crafting common policies, forging mutual trust and building cooperative mechanisms in a three-phase consolidation plan.

The party is determined to sway younger and middle-road supporters with a fresh and clean image and will do its best to check and balance the executive branch in the legislature by putting forward well crafted policies, he said.

Meanwhile, the direct vote proposal for CSC members was approved later that day in the plenary session. A total of 202 CSC members are to be directly elected for a one-year term by attending party delegates the following day.

The KMT was defeated by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for the first time in the 2000 presidential election after ruling Taiwan for more than 50 years since its retreat from China in 1949. President Chen Shui-bian of the ruling DPP was re-elected in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHARTER FLIGHTS FOR MOON FESTIVAL HOLIDAY UNCERTAIN: MAC

TEXT.P: Bilateral talks on keenly awaited direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter services for the coming Moon Festival holiday are being held, but their fate remains unclear, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Friday.

Although Taipei Airlines Association officials representing the government are holding talks on schedule with their Chinese counterparts to arrange the flights, Wu said that further negotiations are needed to reach a final settlement, adding that the MAC will announce the results only when substantial progress has been made.

Wu said that the government will remain flexible to help push for the realization of the Moon Festival holiday charter flights, including considering allowing a broader range of Taiwan people to take the flights beyond Taiwan businessmen operating in China.

Based on the model set early this year in Macau for the Chinese New Year charter flights -- the first direct flights across the strait -- representatives of the two sides are engaged in talks to arrange direct charter flights for the Sept. 18 Moon Festival holiday as the first step toward their efforts to make the services regular on weekends and major holidays prior to an opening of full air links.

Commenting on the issue of repeated intrusions into Taiwan waters by ocean survey research vessels from China, the MAC head described it as an indication of China's growing military expansion, with further evidence in that China and Russia are conducting joint military drills on the Shandong peninsula near South Korea and Japan.

Chinese vessels are not only increasingly entering waters near Taiwan but also waters adjacent to other neighboring countries, he noted, urging the public to support the government's national defense upgrading policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH AUTHORITIES WARN OF POSSIBLE AVIAN FLU OUTBREAK

TEXT.P: An official report suggested Friday that about 5.3 million people in Taiwan would be prone to avian influenza should it become capable of human-to-human transmission and trigger a worldwide pandemic.

The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) released the report at a top-level national security meeting convened by President Chen Shui-bian. It indicates that under a stimulated model set up by the U.S. disease control authorities, an avian flu pandemic could take 14,000 lives in Taiwan, causing an economic impact 10 times larger than that of the 2003 outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome.

The report names the avian flu virus -- most possibly a mutated strain of H5N1 -- as a "killer flu" and "super flu, " which the World Health Organization (WHO) has assessed would kill between 2 million and 7 million around the world should it become as infectious as human flu.

DOH Minister Hou Sheng-mao said at a news conference following the meeting that based on an analysis of experts and scholars, from next January to March will be a critical period for a possible outbreak. He said all public health experts have agreed that there will be an avian flu epidemic sometime in the future. Now, the only question is when the epidemic will occur.
Citing historical records, Hou said the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic killed about 40 million people around the globe and 25,000 in Taiwan, which had a population of only 3 million at that time.
To prevent such a threat from endangering the nation's development, he noted, two packages of plans have been mapped out to deal with a possible avian flu pandemic.

The health minister added that the Executive Yuan has promised to appropriate NT$6 billion (US$186.65 million) for the construction of pharmaceutical factories to produce anti-flu vaccines. He explained that Taiwan has stockpiled about 160,000 doses of "Tamiflu, " the most effective anti-flu medicine in the world, or enough for 0.7 percent of the population. The stocks will be raised to 4 percent by next year, while the government is planning to further increase the stocks to 10 percent, the level suggested by the WHO.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC CENTRAL COMMITTEE CONGRATULATES NEW KMT CHAIRMAN MA

TEXT.P: The Communist Party of China (CPC) Central Committee sent a congratulatory message to the Kuomintang (KMT) Central Committee and new KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou Friday over the convening of a KMT party meeting, according to a Beijing-based Xinhuanet report.
Ma took over the helm of the KMT from Lien Chan, the outgoing chairman who will serve as honorary chairman in the party's 17th plenary session earlier in the day.

The CPC Central Committee said the CPC and the KMT published acommon vision for peaceful development across the Taiwan Strait in Beijing in late April this year during Lien's trip to the mainland, which reflects the will of people on both sides of the Strait and ushers in an historic era of cross-strait party exchanges, the message said.

It expressed hope that both sides can insist on the 1992 consensus, which China deems as the "one China" principle, while Taiwan believes it should be "one China with different interpretation as to its meaning, " and that both sides will also oppose Taiwan independence to safeguard peace in the Taiwan Strait and create a win-win situation for both sides across the Strait.
CPC Secretary General Hu Jintao also sent a message to Lien to congratulate him for serving as the honorary chairman of the main opposition party in Taiwan, the report said.
In the congratulatory message to Lien, Hu said that Lien has contributed a great deal to improving and developing cross-strait relations since he began leading the party in 2000.

Lien, leading a delegation to visit China in late April, conducted exchanges and dialogue with China, the message said, adding that both sides then announced their common vision for the advancement of cross-strait peace, which it said is significant in promoting cross-strait relations toward the direction of peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ON ALERT FOR POSSIBLE MUTATED AVIAN FLU OUTBREAK

TEXT.P: With a health report that suggests millions of Taiwan people could be at risk of avian influenza should it become capable of human-to-human transmission, President Chen Shui-bian told his Cabinet Friday that seven major administrative flaws, which caused outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on the island in 2003, should never happen again.

Chen gave the instruction at a top-level national security meeting he convened at the Presidential Office. He said that the flaws led not only to the fast spread of the highly contagious disease, but also to deaths of many medical and health care personnel.

The flaws included no coordinating mechanism between the central and local governments during the SARS outbreak, which led to different government agencies having different policies and strategies to control and prevent the pandemic.

More problems came from an ill-functioning reporting system on SARS cases and an inefficient diagnosis procedure. Insufficient training of medical and health care personnel resulted in losses of professionals.

Chen mentioned that a serious shortage of anti-pandemic gear and medical supplies and the government's failure to build an "airtight" disease control network in the country was also to blame for the outbreak of SARS, which killed over 70 people beginning in April, 2003.

With the painful "lessons, " the president instructed his Cabinet to be well-prepared for a possible avian flu pandemic, which, according to a report released by the Department of Health (DOH) Friday, could take 14,000 lives in Taiwan, causing economic losses 10 times larger than those caused by the SARS outbreaks.

Besides acting to review the previous flaws and to put right the government's disease control and prevention systems, efforts have also to be made to stockpile enough anti-flu vaccines -- at least reaching the level suggested by the World Health Organization (WHO) at 10 percent of the population.
At present, Taiwan stockpiles about 160,000 doses of "Tamiflu, " the most effective anti-flu medicine in the world, or enough for 0.7 percent of its population, according to DOH statistics.
Chen stressed that encountering a pandemic should be considered like fighting a war, saying well-prepared anti-pandemic procedures and enough medical supplies are the key to winning the war.

The DOH report cited an assessment by the WHO as saying that the avian flu virus -- most possibly a mutated strain of H5N1 -- would kill between 2 million and 7 million people around the world should it become as infectious as human flu.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TO BE FINGERPRINTED BEFORE SETTLING DOWN IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Chinese people who enter Taiwan for settlement or reunion with family members have to be fingerprinted from Sept. 1, the Bureau of Entry and Exit under the National Police Administration said Friday.

Fingerprinting equipment has already been set up at the country's two international airports and the harbors in Kinmen and Matsu which are used for shipping links with the mainland. The equipment has been tested to brace for the new measures aimed at facilitating the identification of Chinese people in Taiwan.
Chinese people already living in Taiwan should have their fingerprints taken while applying for renewal of their residence permits after Sept. 1.
However, Chinese tourists and visitors who come to Taiwan for business and residents of Hong Kong and Macau are exempted from this requirement, according to the Bureau of Entry and Exit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR DISCIPLINED FOR SUBPOENAING PRESIDENT AS WITNESS

TEXT.P: A prosecutor who made headlines for summoning the president as a witness last year in a vote-buying case was disciplined Friday for doing so without first getting the approval of his superiors.
The Committee on the Discipline of Public Functionaries ordered prosecutor Lee Tzu-chun of the Hualien Prosecutors' Office to be demoted to a lower rank and have his salary reduced.
The committee blamed Lee for sending a subpoena by post to President Chen Shui-bian, without informing his superiors at the Hualien Prosecutors' Office, let alone getting their approval as is usual.

In his subpoena, Lee demanded that President Chen give testimony in his capacity as the then-chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the investigation of vote-buying allegations against DPP candidate You Ying-lung in the 2003 by-election of magistrate of Hualien County.

The committee also condemned Lee for prosecuting Yu for vote-buying in December 2004 -- more than one year after You lost the election -- without bothering to notify his superiors at the prosecutors' office or seeking their approval as is necessary.

Instead of having You's indictment examined and approved by his superiors, Lee send it secretly to the Hualien District Court, which accepted it and assigned a panel of judges to look into it despite State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao having denounced it as invalid and having requested its withdrawal.

In his indictment, Lee claimed You's campaign promise to give monthly allowances to chiefs of Hualien's aboriginal tribes if he was elected constituted a form of vote-buying, and asked the court to sentence him to two months in jail.
The president was summoned to give testimony because Yu claimed during the campaign that all his promises had been endorsed by the president and were, therefore, far from empty words.

To the surprise of the country, the lawyer-turned-president showed up in Lee's office in Hualien on time to answer the prosecutor's questions, and successfully turned a potential political embarrassment into personal political capital by waiving presidential executive immunity from criminal investigation.

However, the Committee on the Discipline of Public Functionaries said in its ruling that the elected head of state deserves due respect. By summoning him for questioning recklessly, the prosecutor obstructed the president's work in leading the country and serving the people.

Determining that Lee had acted unethically by avoiding the supervision of his superiors, the ruling said Lee should be disciplined by a demotion, although the indictment he brought without following due process of law had been accepted by the court as valid.
Lee, known as a maverick law enforcement official, was referred to the committee for punishment by his embarrassed superiors at the Hualien Prosecutors' Office.
He was not available for comment Friday and his superiors at the Hualien Prosecutors' Office refused to comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 19 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, August 19:
08:00, The opposition Kuomintang will continues its national congress at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
09:20; President Chen Shui-bian will inspect Changhua City in central Taiwan.
09:30, Vice President Annette Lu will inspect the catchment of the Shihmen Reservoir in Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli from a helicopter.
10:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will open a national debate contest for students of junior vocational schools at the National Kaohsiung Marine University in Kaohsiung City.
10:00, Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen will deliver a speech about the challenges facing the country in diplomacy at the Sun Yet-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
10:00, Former President Lee Teng-hui will preside over the commencement of Lee Teng-Hui Academy at the Civil Service Development Institute in Taipei.
11:45, President Chen Shui-bian will inspect the fishermen's pier of Wankung Harbor in Changhua County, central Taiwan.
18:55, Former Vice Economics Minister Yiin Chii-ming will return to the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport from a visit to Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 20, or the 16th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1741: Danish explorer Vitus Bering discovers Alaska on a mission sponsored by Russia.
1833: Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd president of the United States, is born. The first Pan-American Conference took place (1889) during his administration, which passed the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in 1890.
1860: Raymond Poincare, French statesman and president from 1913 to 1920, is born.
1905: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who had been exiled for his involvement in the anti-Ching movement, organizes the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo. The organization, headed by Dr. Sun, sponsored an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1912: William Booth, British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army in 1878, dies at the age of 83.
1925: Liao Chung-kai, one of a 16-member steering committee that established a national government in July 1925, is assassinated in Canton, five months after the demise of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in Peking. Liao was 47.
1928: Both the Wen River and the Mi River in the province of Shantung overflow their banks, drowning 18,000 people and leaving some 30,000 others homeless.
1940: A total of 153 Japanese military aircraft carry out a heavy bombing raid on Chungking, the war-time capital of the Republic of China.
1940: Radar is used for the first time, with the British employing it during World War II.
1940: Leon Trotsky, one of the leaders of the Russian Revolution, is stabbed to death by a Spanish communist with an alpine ax in his home in Coyoacan, near Mexico City. He was 61.
1944: Representatives of China, the United States, the United Kingdom and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics meet in Washington, D.C., to discuss the establishment of a world organization after World War II.
1944: Rajiv Gandhi, former Indian prime minister, is born. The son of Indira Gandhi was assassinated on May 21, 1991.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a second invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him to come to Chungking for a conference on Aug. 14, 1945.
1955: Gen. Sun Li-jen, chief military aide to the president, submits a request for disciplinary action against himself as a gesture of self-reproach in regard to a communist espionage case involving Kuo Ting-liang.
1967: A total of 247 people, including Taipei City Councilor Lin Shui-chuan, are arrested for attempting to stage an armed rebellion for Taiwan independence.
1968: Soviet and Warsaw Pact troops begin the invasion of Czechoslovakia in an attempt to crush the "Prague Spring" reforms.
1972: The Republic of China Mei Ho baseball team defeats a U.S. team from California 9-0 to win the Senior League world title.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Lugar, chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Lugar says that the U.S. government has not changed its basic support of the Republic of China and that he hopes the ROC will open its markets to reduce the ROC-US trade deficit.
1988: A U.N.-mediated cease-fire between Iran and Iraq takes effect, ending nearly eight years of war.
1995: An express train collides with another train in northern India, killing nearly 300 passengers and injuring more than 200 others.
1999: The Central Bank of China announces that Taiwan's second-quarter balance of international payments surplus amounted to US$5.47 billion, the highest single-quarter total in 12 years.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his delegation arrive in Gambia at the start of his one-week, three-nation African tour which will also take him to Burkina Faso and Chad.
2001: Taiwan's Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation makes its 300th bone marrow donation, with the recipient a college student in Hangzhou City, in mainland China's Zhejiang Province.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to sift out, but when you once try to sift out a thing, you must never give it up until you have sifted it out clearly and distinctly."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PHILATELIST PASSPORT' SIMULATES 'ROUND-THE-WORLD' TRIP

TEXT.P: Visitors to the Taipei 2005-18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition can use a "philatelist passport" to simulate a round-the-world trip if they stop at all the booths of the 22 participating countries.
Veteran stamp collector Ms. Lin spent more than two hours and NT$1,500 (US$46.80) in a tour around all the booths of the 22 countries, purchasing their stamps and acquiring their postmarks.

Chunghwa Post, the key sponsor of the stamp exhibition, has prepared 12,000 copies of the "philatelist passport" at the Taipei World Trade Center. Visitors who purchase NT$100 worth of philatelic items or stamps will receive a passport.

After visiting the 22 countries' booths and having the countries' stamps affixed to passport with their various postmarks, the passport-holder will feel like they have really made a trip around the world, Lin said.
Lin had two other similar philatelist passports that she acquired from the Asian Stamp Invitational Exhibition in 1993 and the 10th Asian International Stamp Exhibition in 1996, both held in Taipei.

Chunghwa Post has opened several temporary post offices to serve stamp collectors and exhibition visitors during the six-day run of the Taipei 2005-18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition, which opened Friday.

Among the 1,556 frames of stamps on display, several are deemed "jewels of the nation's stamps" -- including the Flying Geese stamps issued in the early 1950s, the unique Flying Dragon postage stamps for express mail items during the Qing dynasty, and the rare Red Color revenue stamps currently estimated to be worth around NT$10 million (US$312,500).

To publicize and celebrate the occasion, Chunghwa Post is issuing a series of eight separate souvenir sheets. The first and second -- No. 1 Taiwan Landscape and No. 2 Taiwan Culture -- were released on Aug. 27, 2004, and April 19, 2005, respectively. The third through eighth -- No. 3 Taiwan Conservation, No. 4 Taiwan Technology, No. 5 Taiwan Flowers and Fruits, No. 6 Taiwan Festivals, No. 7 Taiwan Cuisine and No. 8 Marine Taiwan -- will be released one each day during the course of the exhibition.

To commemorate the event, Chunghwa Post has also released a set of four "Taipei 2005-18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition Commemorative Postage Labels, " each of which features a different section of the ancient painting "Taisiantu" from the National Palace Museum collection.

"Taisiantu" was created by the Ming painter Bian Wen-jin. The scroll depicts 136 cranes -- flying, making calls, pecking, fighting, swimming -- in every pose imaginable and all rendered beautifully. The crane is a symbol of longevity. The postage label set is available at the venue of the exhibition and at all locations equipped with postage label vending machines around the island starting Friday.
Chunghwa Post is also offering 10,000 gifts by prize draw, in addition to offering exhibition visitors the opportunity to have their own personalized stamps and postcards made digitally.

The event, whose theme is "Tourism and Stamps, " is aimed at promoting Taiwan's stamps as well as tourism. The Formosan black bear, which is indigenous to Taiwan, has been chosen as the mascot of the exhibition.
The logo of the exhibition is the Taipei 101 tower -- the world's tallest skyscraper -- which the sponsor said hopes will demonstrate Taiwan's new vibrancy.
(By Deborah Kuo)/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: STAMP EXHIBITION VISITORS URGED TO TRY PERSONALIZED STAMPS, POSTCARDS

TEXT.P: Tired of ordinary stamps and postcards? How about having your own personalized greeting stamps and postcards to share with your friends? You can have this and more at the Taipei 2005 and 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition that kicked off Friday.

The exhibition, which will run through Aug. 24, includes a personalized greeting stamp booth and the public is urged to take the memory cards of their digital cameras or have the staff of the Chunghwa Post Co., the sponsor of the event, take their pictures on the spot.
Chunghwa Post has provided three different kinds of backgrounds -- with supermodel Lin Chi-ling, the world's highest skyscraper -- Taipei 101, and one collage image.
There are five machines to produce creative postcards and Chunghwa Post will give the public 20 backgrounds to choose from. Each postcard is NT$20.
Chunghwa Post staff is asking visitors to try the creative postcards, saying that the personalized postcards can be sent just as regular ones.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ATTENDS CEREMONY TO WORSHIP TO THE BUDDHA

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh attended a ceremony to worship to the Buddha Saturday at a temple in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan.
Although he is a devoted Buddhist, Hsieh said this was the first time he has taken part in such a ceremony since assuming the premiership in February.

Among the many precepts written on papers hanged on the walls in the temple, Hsieh said he found "resisting the insult" to be the one that he feels he has done will in, referring to the strong criticism he has received in the legislature from opposition parties.

While expressing gratitude to the Buddhist masters for their preaching, Hsieh urged all the eight million Buddhists around the island to deepen their learning of Buddhism and purify their bodies and minds for the benefit of society.

Noting that social morals have been deteriorating, with the media's frequent coverage of killings among parents and children, Hsieh said the holding of such ceremonies to worship the Buddha and his teachings will help purify society.
Also present at the ceremony were Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, and several renowned Buddhist masters from around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD LAUNCHES CAMPAIGN AGAINST INTRUDING CHINESE SHIPS

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) launched a weeklong "clean sweep" campaign Saturday against Chinese fishing boats and ocean survey ships intruding into waters near Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu.

The campaign was launched in response to a Chinese ocean survey ship, the "Fendou [striving] No. 4, " that has sailed into waters close to the three outlying islands three times since May, and poaching by Chinese fishing boats in Taiwan waters.

"The operation is also aimed at cracking down on human and cargo smuggling across the Taiwan Strait and preventing a possible spread of avian flu into Taiwan as an outbreak of human influenza mutated from bird flu is very likely to emerge in China, " a CGA official explained.

According to a CGA study, locations where Chinese fishing boats have often traversed and converged include the outlying islands of Penghu, Kinmen, Matsu and Wuchiu as well as Keelung, Hsinchu and Taichung on Taiwan proper.

In addition to mobilizing large patrols to beef up its presence, the official said the CGA has also enlisted helicopters and coastal radar systems to facilitate reconnaissance and form a three-dimensional dragnet to enhance operational efficiency.

"We hope such precautionary actions can deter Chinese fishermen from traversing into our territorial waters so that we can better protect our fishery resources, maritime ecology and the safety of local fishermen operating in the areas," the official said.

Amid reports of avian flu outbreaks in certain parts of China and its neighboring countries, Taiwan has stepped up inspection and quarantine work at Kinmen and Matsu where direct shipping services with China's Fujian province have been allowed to prevent the spread of the virus to the two Taiwan-held outlying islands and Taiwan proper.
During the campaign, the CGA official said Chinese fishing boats intruding into Taiwan's restricted waters will be chased away and those that traverse into off-limit areas will be impounded.
