DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIA-CHINA MILITARY EXERCISE A PRETEXT TO SUPPRESS TAIWAN: ENVOY

TEXT.P: Beijing seems to be attempting to use the current Russia-China joint military exercise as a pretext to suppress Taiwan, although it describes the war game as "anti-terrorist and peace-keeping" maneuvers, the Republic of China's top envoy to Russia said Friday.
Chen Rong-jye, Taiwan's representative to Russia, made the comments in an interview with the Central News Agency.

The eight-day exercises started Thursday and involve some 10,000 troops from air, sea and land. They are designed to test the ability of the two countries in the fight against terrorism and separatism.

According to Chen, the drills are not expected to change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, but he warned that all countries concerned should avoid escalating tensions in the region by restraining themselves from taking any irrational actions.

Now is not the right time for Beijing and Moscow to hold such exercises, known as "Peace Mission 2005, " as China has just passed its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, and the European Union has still been discussing whether it should lift its arms sales ban on China, he said, adding that it seems that Beijing is attempting to relate Taiwan to "terrorism" and "separatism, " as well as practicing an invasion of the island by taking part in the exercises.

Pointing out that Russia and China have established a legal basis for them to build a strategic and cooperation partnership since they signed a cooperation treaty in 2001, the envoy said that as a result, military relations between the two countries, including arms sales and military high-tech exchanges and joint military exercises, have particularly been strengthened. "This has also caused concerns in the international community and neighboring countries in particular, " he added.

Commenting on recent media reports that the drills are aimed at Taiwan, Chen said that Beijing seems to use the war games on the Shandong peninsula to reinforce its ability should conflict break out across the Strait.

China also wants to give a warning to Japan and the United States by expanding its navy's "action area" to the region close to the seaboard of Japan, he continued, noting that the selections of scenario and places of the war games can hardly make people turn a blind eye to the drills that are believed to target certain countries in the region.

Saying that Russia wants to lure Chinese buyers by showing its high-tech and modern arms equipment, including T-22 M3, T-95 MS and long-range strategic bombers in the exercises, Chen said that China also wants to use the drills to strengthen its relations with Russia as well as increase its military influence in Central Asia and accumulate experience of holding joint military exercises with Russian troops.

Although a high-ranking Russian defense official has reiterated that the exercises are not aimed at any third country, including Taiwan, Chen, however, said that many media reports have said the exercises are to defy the United States, Japan and Taiwan. "A Russian newspaper even said frankly that the exercises are targeting the island, " he added.

Some Russian analysts consider that the refusal of the Russian government to launch its joint military exercises with China off the area near the Taiwan Strait clearly shows that Moscow does not want to see the war games used by China as an instrument to obstruct Taiwan, he continued.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE HAVING FUN AT STAMP SHOW

TEXT.P: Young and old people alike were enjoying themselves at the Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition Sunday, as a number of activities are taking place at the Taipei World Trade Center.

Exhibition visitors busied themselves searching for and looking at rare stamps; purchasing stamps from foreign countries and commemorative silver coins and stamps issued locally; acquiring postmarks at the temporary post offices; and having their own personalized greeting stamps and postcards made digitally.
The fourth of the series of eight souvenir sheets that Chunghwa Post Co., the key sponsor of the stamp exhibition, has produced were issued Sunday.

Chunghwa Post Co. President Huang Shui-cheng and Microsoft Taiwan General Manager Eunice Chiu and others jointly unveiled the issuing of souvenir sheet No. 4 -- Taiwan Technology -- at the exhibition site.
Following the unveiling, several designers of the souvenir sheet series signed autographs for visitors on their newly purchased sheets.
An elderly gentleman, who bought 100 copies of the souvenir sheet No. 4, was anxious for the designers' autographs.
Long lines formed at a temporary post office where the Lin Chih-ling Benevolent Postage Packages were on sale. Lin Chih-ling is a supermodel in Taiwan.
According to Chunghwa Post authorities, 2,500 sets of the package were sold on the first day of the exhibition Friday. Another 1,500 sets reserved for Sunday are also expected to be sold out quickly.

The exhibition, which will run through Aug. 24, includes a personalized greeting stamp postcard booth, where the public can have their own creative stamps or postcards produced digitally with 20 backgrounds provided by Chunghwa Post for the public to choose from.
Children and adults were having fun at a computerized painting area, where they drew and designed their own stamps.
Chunghwa Post is also offering 10,000 gifts by prize draw.

To make the exhibition more attractive, the sponsors have called in performers and bands, including the Bohemia Ensemble, Taipei Ghi Drum, Centro Flamenco Taiwan, the Happy Children Dance Group and the Cartoon Personage Theatrical Company.

DOC.HEADLINE: MURDER OF TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MALAYSIA MAY AFFECT INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Several recent robberies and murders involving Taiwanese businessmen with operations in Malaysia may affect Taiwan's investment in the country, Taiwan's representative in Malaysia said Saturday.

Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Malaysia representative Wu Wen-ya made the remarks at a memorial service for Taiwanese businessman Ku Li-yen, an executive of the Taiwan-based Hualon Corporation's Malaysia plant, who was killed Aug. 17 in a parking lot after having dinner with colleagues.
According to Wu, this was the second murder of a Taiwanese in Malaysia since he assumed his post three years ago, following the murder of a Taiwanese businessman's wife last year.
Ku's case is being investigated by Malaysian police.

Wu said that these cases could prompt Taiwanese entrepreneurs to reconsider whether they should continue their investments in Malaysia. He urged the Malaysian government to pay more heed to this matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: HELLO KITTY STAMPS POPULAR AT TAIPEI STAMP EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: Hello Kitty stamps from Japan and stamps with distinctive national colors proved to be the most popular during the second day of the Taipei 2005 and 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition Saturday.

Visitor numbers showed a marked increase during the weekend of the six-day event which kicked off Friday. The most gratifying exhibitor must be the one who runs the Japanese booth, seeing one throng of youngsters after another swarming in to buy their favorite Hello Kitty stamps and telephone cards.
The Japanese booth exhibitor noted that Hello Kitty stamps are also popular in Malaysia, Hong Kong and Singapore.

With South Korean actor Bae Yong-joon currently in Taiwan for a three-day visit to promote his new movie, some visitors also came to the South Korean booth to see if there were any stamps related to the immensely popular star in Taiwan.
But the booth mainly offers stamps related to South Korean classic literature and cartoons.
The Singapore booth was also popular, with floral and souvenir sheets being the favorite among visitors.

One of the most bustling booths at the exhibition is the Holland booth with a big poster featuring women in traditional Dutch costumes. There were lines of boxes of floral and animal stamps from the Netherlands, China, Japan, Australia, France, Sweden and Iceland. Staff were offering 50 assorted stamps for NT$100 (US$3.12) and there were plenty of takers.
The U.S. stamp dealers displayed lot of old Chinese stamps, because they know that Taiwan philatelists love them dearly.

Taiwan philatelists also like postcards related to anti-Japanese aggression, and landscape and aboriginal people from the island itself. The price of the anti-Japanese aggression postcards sell between NT$100 and NT$300 depending on their condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES CITES TAIWAN'S INVESTIGATION BUREAU FOR DRUG BUSTING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) has received an award from the Philippine government for its contribution to cross-border crackdowns on drug trafficking and production, a bureau official said Saturday.

The MJIB sent some staff members to take part in a six-country conference on international cooperation in fighting drug trafficking last August. As drug trafficking intelligence provided by the MJIB's drug-fighting center was very useful, Philippine authorities invited the MJIB to take part in its special task force responsible for investigating drug-related crimes.
The MJIB designated Hsueh Pao-shu, an MJIB official posted at Taiwan's representative office in Manila, to serve as a liaison officer.

Between September 2005 and May 2005, MJIB officers joined their American and Philippine counterparts in busting two amphetamine producing facilities on the southern Philippine island of Mindanao and a ketamine facility in Quezon City in Manila.
Philippine Interior Secretary Angelo Reyes presented a citation to the MJIB earlier this week in recognition of its drug-fighting achievements, the official said.

The Philippines was the second foreign country to have recognized the MJIB's accomplishments. Last November, the Japanese customs authorities presented a citation to the MJIB for its assistance in seizing a freighter intending to smuggle 113 kilograms of amphetamines into Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH K0REAN PUSH NEEDED FOR CHEN'S APEC ATTENDANCE: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Support from the South Korean government would help facilitate President Chen Shui-bian's participation in the informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum slated for next month in Busan, South Korea, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Saturday.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is trying its utmost through various channels to make President Chen's dream come true to attend the APEC summit, Tan Sun Chen said.

The foreign minister said that Taiwan is very grateful to the government of the Republic of Korea for its political wisdom and skillful handling in pushing for Taiwan's entry into APEC in 1991 along with China and Hong Kong.

If Seoul, the 2005 APEC summit meeting host, can continue its support for Taiwan, using the same political wisdom and skillful handling to make possible President Chen's participation in the APEC summit, it would be the second South Korean success that would have great historical significance regarding bolstering Taiwan's representation in the international community, Chen said during a colloquium in Taipei sponsored by the Hung Chun-pei Educational and Cultural Foundation.
Taiwan's presidents have been absent from the APEC summits in previous years due to China's opposition.

Tan Sun Chen told the colloquium participants that although everybody in Taiwan is very much looking forward to President Chen's attendance at the APEC summit, Taiwan should also fully understand that Seoul has said that APEC summit representation is an issue to be decided by all APEC member countries but not a matter which can be decided solely by South Korea.
President Chen has not hesitated to show his eagerness to attend the APEC summit meeting on many occasions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA IS NOT RISING PEACEFULLY: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: China is not "rising peacefully" as it claims, which can be evidenced by its increasing annual military budget, ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Tan Sun Chen said Saturday.

In his speech about "new challenge in diplomacy" delivered at a colloquium held at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, Chen criticized China as playing a zero-sum diplomatic war with Taiwan by claiming that Taiwan is part of China and luring Taiwan's diplomatic allies away to squeeze its diplomacy efforts.
Concerning the "peaceful rise" claimed by China, Chen revealed that at a heavyweight forum he attended in the United States in June, no one believed that China is rising peacefully.
Noting that China's military budget tops the list among Asian countries, Chen said China does not need such a large military budget if it is only targeting Taiwan.
Chen stressed that the two atomic bombs dropped on Japan in World War II and the Cuban missile crisis in 1962 involving the United States and the Soviet Union made the world nervous.

Now, China has deployed several hundreds of missiles targeting Taiwan, and the world community seems to pretend that they can't see them, Chen said, adding that it was only after China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law in March this year that the world began to understand that China is not rising peacefully, and it desires hegemony.
The Anti-Secession Law authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island declare formal independence.

Noting that Americans have now realized Beijing's real face, Chen urged Taiwan people not to have any illusions about China's proposals, including its offer to help Taiwan enter the World Health Organization, which has been proven to be a lie.

Chen also expressed the hope that the European Union will not lift its arms embargo against China, which has been imposed since the Tiananmen Square Massacre in 1989. According to Chen, the U.S. and Japan have opposed the lifting of the embargo.

Referring to Taiwan's plan to purchase advanced arms from the United States for the defense of the country, Chen stressed that if the arms procurement budget is not approved in the legislature, Taiwan can be swallowed up by China at any time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEXTILE TRADE SURPLUS FOR FIRST SEVEN MONTHS TOPS US$5.43 BILLION

TEXT.P: The surplus in textile trade for the first seven months of the year reached US$5.43 billion, down US$8.12 percent from the amount of US$5.91 billion registered in the same period of last year, according to tallies recently made public by the Director-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

Under the influence of the removal of import quotas by the United States, European countries and Canada and the appreciation of Taiwan's currency, the export value for textile goods for the first seven months of the year registered US$6.93 billion, down 6.4 percent from the same period last year. The import value during the same period hit US$1.5 billion, down 0.3 percent from the same period last year.

Of all textile goods, which served as one of main foreign exchange earners in Taiwan, gauze absorbed the lion's shares of the total textile export value, with US$5.12 billion or 73.9 percent of the total, down 4.4 percent from the same period last year. Garments, which suffered competition from low-priced products from China and Southeastern Asian countries, registered only US$540 million, down 27 percent from the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ASKS GOVERNMENT TO ADOPT MULTI-PRONGED APPROACH AGAINST BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: The government should adopt a multi-pronged approach to prevent a possible outbreak of human influenza mutated from avian influenza virus and the public should also be vigilant against the disease, a caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday.
William Lai made the remarks one day after President Chen Shui-bian presided over a top-level national security meeting on control contingencies in response to a possible outbreak of avian flu.

Lai said the party is upbeat on the government's early preparations for a possible outbreak. But he also said that a mutated strain of avian flu virus could lead to a global situation, saying that according to a simulation by the U.S. disease control authorities, an avian flu pandemic could infect 5.3 million people, hospitalize 70,000 and take 14,000 lives in Taiwan, causing an economic impact 10 times larger than that of the 2003 outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome on the island.

He pointed out that the avian flu virus could be transmitted from migratory birds to poultry and then to people, and then from person to person, and could also be imported from foreign countries. For this reason, poultry operators and those who have contact with migratory birds should be on guard, he said.

Lai also said that the government should step up cracking down on smuggled poultry, and the health authorities should also work with the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to work out a standard operating procedure as soon as possible.

Meanwhile, a Taiwan Solidarity Union caucus whip said Saturday that the party was happy to see that the government is taking action to plug the loopholes of human and animal smuggling as well as the invasion of infectious diseases.

Ho Min-hao made the remarks after the Coast Guard Administration embarked on a weeklong "clean sweep" campaign earlier in the day against Chinese fishing boats and ocean survey ships intruding into waters near Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu.
Ho expressed the hope that the government will rigorously enforce the law to protect national security.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAD WEATHER HURTS MANGO EXPORTS

TEXT.P: Despite the government's efforts to make inroads in the Japanese market, mango exports from Tainan County still registered a dramatic decline as a result of the typhoons and heavy rains this year, a local official said Saturday.

With the mango crop in the final phase of maturing, the performance of mango exports still remains gloomy in Tainan. According to the Bureau of Agriculture (BOA) under the Tainan County Government, this year's exports to Japan did not even make one-third of the expected growth, totaling 486 tons; exports to South Korea, which has never been a big customer of Taiwan, are also flat at 43 tons this year.

Exports to Hong Kong and China have yet to be estimated by Customs, the BOA added. According to the BOA, the bad weather this year has posed great challenges to the growth of mangoes, whose production has shown an unprecedented downturn this year. Along with the stricter quarantine requirements implemented in Japan, the decline in exports should therefore be understandable to the public.
Aside from doing business with regular buyers, Taiwan has also exported one ton of mangoes to New Zealand as a trial this year, the BOA noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATE PRESIDENT CHIANG'S DAUGHTER-IN-LAW DIES AT 68

TEXT.P: Nancy Chiang, a daughter-in-law of late President Chiang Ching-kuo, died of complications from acquired aplastic anemia at the Koo Foundation Sun Yat-sen Cancer Center in Taipei Saturday at the age of 68.
Nancy Chiang, who was born to a Chinese father and a German mother, was diagnosed with aplastic anemia in late 1999 probably because of long-term use of a drug to treat her chronic headaches.
Aplastic anemia is a disorder in which the bone marrow greatly decreases or stops production of blood cells.
Hsieh Yen-yao, deputy superintendent of the Koo Foundation Sun Yat-sen Cancer Center, said Nancy Chiang had since suffered from relapses of the disease. Her immune system had also been affected.

According to Hsieh, Nancy Chiang had been hospitalized since June after contracting pneumonia. Despite undergoing various kinds of treatments, her condition continued to deteriorate and she died at 2 p.m. Saturday.
Nancy Chiang is survived by an adult daughter. Her husband, Chiang Hsiao-wen, Chiang Ching-kuo's eldest son, died less than two years after Chiang Ching-kuo's death in 1988.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WANTS PEOPLE TO BACK GOV'T PROPOSAL TO BUY U.S. WEAPONRY

TEXT.P: Several ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) officials and lawmakers attended an activity held in Taipei Saturday, soliciting more support from the public for the government's proposal to buy arms from the United States.

The gathering, presided over by DPP Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim, was a warm-up for a mass demonstration organized by the Hand-in-Hand-to-Protect-Taiwan Alliance on Sept. 25 in Taipei, which is aimed at calling for support for the arms procurement to strengthen Taiwan's national defense.

Ng Chiau-tong, chairman of World United Formosans for Independence, Yao Chia-wen, president of the Examination Yuan, and Huang Shih-cho, a legislator from the Taiwan Solidarity Union, were also present.

The DPP government plans to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the U.S. with a special military budget of NT$480 billion.

Hsiao and Yao agreed that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party's (PFP) failure to allow the bill for the arms procurement package to be considered has misled Americans to believe that Taiwan thinks that the U.S. will bail them out of any military problem, when in fact Taiwan should be strengthening its own defense in case of war.
Huang called the KMT and the PFP "pro-China parties" because of the way they have damaged Taiwan's national security.
Facing Beijing's missile threat, Taiwan should maintain a certain level of defense capability -- one month or half a month -- for foreign allies to render help to the island later, Yao stressed.
The march will begin at 3 p.m. on Sept. 25, starting from the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall and proceed through downtown Taipei, ending at Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPONSORING INTERNATIONAL STAMP SHOW HELPS NATIONAL EXCHANGES: MOTC

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Saturday that the sponsoring of an international stamp exhibition will help exchanges between countries.

He made the remarks when he visited the Taipei 2005 and the 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition at the Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall, noting that this was the first time Chunghwa Post has sponsored an international stamp exhibition in nine years, urging Chunghwa Post to solicit more opportunities to host similar events.
Lin was invited to make personalized greeting stamps as a souvenir, to which he gladly accepted, but he decided against the idea after seeing the long line of people waiting to do the same.
Among a great multitude of valuable stamps, Lin said that he wanted most to see a trial print proof of Mauritius double denominations worth NT$96 million (US$3 million).

But the minister stayed the longest at an area that showed stamps of the Republic of China. He was especially interested in a letter sent by the late Academia Sinica President Hu Shih in Taiwan to his father in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO MORE CLOSELY MONITOR RULING PARTY: CHAIRMAN MA

TEXT.P: New Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that his party will strengthen its monitoring role at the Legislative Yuan.
Ma also reaffirmed at the close of the 17th plenary session of the two-day party congress that he will make the KMT a party of integrity and honesty, and return the party to power.

He said that the party has been the opposition for more than five years and that the task of an opposition party is to oversee government operations. Noting that the main stage of the opposition party is the Legislative Yuan, he said that the KMT will step up monitoring of the government in the legislature and lead the passage of major bills.

On issues such as agricultural exchanges with China, Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan and facilitation of cross-strait cargo transportation, he hoped that lawmakers could push for quality legislation and not let Taiwan's economy flounder.
Ma also said that the KMT should be rational when dealing with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's proposed bills and to solicit public support.

Saying that the DPP's flood-control project, arms procurement package and its tendency of making an extraordinary session a common practice are problems, Ma added that this has left ample room for the KMT to play a key role in opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP DELEGATION TO VISIT CHINA FOR DISCUSSIONS ON CROSS-STRAIT FORUM

TEXT.P: A delegation from the opposition People First Party (PFP) will depart for China Sunday to discuss matters with Beijing authorities related to a cross-strait forum and cross-strait charter cargo flights.

Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's policy research center and one member of the delegation, said that the delegation will mainly discuss a cross-strait forum in Shanghai next month. Five seminars will focus on economic issues and avoid politics, and both PFP Chairman James Soong and Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung will attend.
Whether Hu Jintao, general secretary of the Communist Party of China and Chinese president, will attend the forum to meet with Soong will be finalized during the trip.

The forum will invite heads of the chambers of commerce and major enterprises from the United States, Japan and Europe to attend, and will discuss such issues as the impact on foreign investment if direct cross-strait transportation links were to be established, Chang said.

The delegation will also exchange views on matters such as Taiwan banks and insurance companies setting up footholds in the mainland, cross-strait exchange rates and the appreciation of Chinese curreny renminbi.
In addition, to promote cross-strait exchanges, the PFP also hopes to come to an agreement on the formation of a platform to deal with related matters, Chang said.
He also said that before the party sends a delegation to take part in the cross-strait forum, PFP caucus members in the legislature will call on related government agencies to listen to their views.
This will be the first high-ranking PFP delegation since party Chairman Soong's "bridge-building" journey to China in May in which he met with Chinese leader Hu.
The six-member delegation will be headed by Chin Chin-sheng, PFP secretary-general.
Meanwhile, a 2005 cross-strait forum to discuss financial and economic issues planned by PFP Legislator Christina Liu will open in Shanghai Sunday.

The Aug. 21-25 forum will discuss capital market, enterprise globalization and currency markets. The forum will be co-organized by Taiwan's Financial & Economic Bills Research Association, Shanghai's Jiao Tong University and Nanjing University.
Five lawmakers from the PFP and its ally, the Kuomintang, and around 30 academics and businessmen from Taiwan will take part in the forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERMENT OF TWO LATE PRESIDENTS' EMBALMED BODIES MAY BE POSTPONED

TEXT.P: The interment of the The embalmed bodies of the late President Chiang Kai-shek and his son and successor Chiang
Ching-kuo may be postponed further, Vice Minister of the Interior Chien Tai-lang said Saturday.
Chien made the remarks after Nancy Chiang, a daughter-in-law of Chiang Ching-kuo, died of complications from acquired aplastic anemia at the age of 68 earlier in the day.
On behalf of an ad hoc office in charge of preparations for the two late presidents' interment, Chien expressed his condolences over Nancy Chiang's death.
Nancy Chiang, who was born to a Chinese father and a German mother, was diagnosed with aplastic anemia in late 1999 probably because of long-term use of a drug to treat her chronic headaches.
Aplastic anemia is a disorder in which the bone marrow greatly decreases or stops production of blood cells.
Hsieh Yen-yao, deputy superintendent of the Koo Foundation Sun Yat-sen Cancer Center, said Nancy Chiang had since suffered from relapses of the disease. Her immune system had also been affected.

According to Hsieh, Nancy Chiang had been hospitalized since June after contracting pneumonia. Despite undergoing various kinds of treatments, her condition continued to deteriorate and she died at 2 p.m. Saturday.
Nancy Chiang is survived by an adult daughter. Her husband, Chiang Hsiao-wen, Chiang Ching-kuo's eldest son, died less than two years after Chiang Ching-kuo's death in 1988.

The interment of the two late presidents was originally scheduled for July, but was later postponed to September. According to Chien, Nancy Chiang attended the first meeting of the interment preparatory office on June 7, but was absent from the second meeting held on Aug. 10.

"As the Chiang family didn't make a decision on the interment date at the Aug. 10 meeting, I think the previously scheduled September interment may be postponed to a later date. We'll fully respect the Chiang family's opinion," Chien said.

The Chiang family sent a letter to the Ministry of National Defense (MND) last year asking it to help with the relocation of the two Chiangs -- who have been embalmed in interim mausoleums in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan -- to the Wutzushan military cemetery in Hsichih, Taipei County, for permanent interment.

With the consent of President Chen Shui-bian, the MND, the Ministry of the Interior and various other government agencies began to plan for the relocation and burial in line with the state funeral law. The MND has commissioned contractors to build tombs for the two late presidents.

Chiang Kai-shek fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing the Chinese mainland to the Mao Zedong-led communist party in a bloody civil war. He died in 1975 and his remains were embalmed in a temporary mausoleum at Tzuhu in Taoyuan, awaiting a proper burial on the mainland.

Chiang Kai-shek ruled Taiwan with an iron fist, using martial law to suppress democracy. However, some view him as a hero for keeping the island out of reach of the Chinese communists and claim that it was he who fostered Taiwan's freewheeling market economy.

Chiang Ching-kuo is respected for ending martial law in 1987, shortly before his death, thus unleashing the democratic forces that broke his family's vice-grip on power and eventually ended the Kuomintang's half-century of rule over Taiwan.

Chiang Ching-kuo died in 1988 and his remains also lie embalmed in an interim mausoleum at Touliao in Taoyuan. His Russian-born wife died Dec. 15, 2004 and her cremated ashes, which are being kept at Chiang's mausoleum, will be buried along with her husband.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIOXX-SICKENED PEOPLE CAN APPLY FOR DRUG INJURY RELIEF: DOH

TEXT.P: Those who have developed cardiac diseases after using the once-popular painkiller Vioxx can apply for drug injury relief with the Department of Health (DOH) , an official said Saturday.
Liao Chi-chou, director of the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, made the remarks after a Texas jury found pharmaceutical giant Merck & Co. liable for the death of a man who took Vioxx.

Jurors awarded Robert Ernst's widow, Carol, US$253.4 million in damages, which is a combination of his lost pay as a Wal-Mart produce manager, mental anguish, loss of companionship and punitive damages.
Liao said the drug was recalled globally last September after medical studies confirmed that Vioxx could increase the risk of developing heart ailments.
In Taiwan, Liao said, the drug has all been recalled. But those who feel ill after using Vioxx can apply for drug injury relief with the DOH's screening committee.
"If their cases are established or verified, the victims can not only receive injury relief from the committee but can also seek compensation from the pharmaceutical manufacturer," Liao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY UPGRADING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that upgrading of environmental quality and reshaping of Taiwan's landscape have been high on his administration's work agenda.

Speaking at an environmental training camp in the central county of Changhua, Chen said he has been less than satisfied with Taiwan's living environment and urban and rural landscape because both the public and private sectors have previously failed to pay heed to balanced development in economy and environmental protection.
Since assuming office, Chen said he has prioritized tourism development and landscape reshaping.

"Attracting more tourist arrivals has been one of our policy goal. But if we cannot upgrade our environmental quality and beautifying our landscape, we can hardly that goal, " Chen said, adding that he hopes the training camp organized by the Changhua County Government can help enhance local people's environmental awareness and inspire more people to dedicate to the environmental protection campaign.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Aug. 21:
09:00, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a Buddhist ritual at Linko Stadium in Taipei County to pray for the nation's well-being.
10:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend an activity at Kuantu wharf in Taipei County to publicize progress in improving water quality in Shetzu area.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Battered but Unbowed: Can Painkillers Recover?
By deciding yesterday that the Merck drug Vioxx contributed to the death of a Texas man, a jury dealt another punch to the battered class of arthritis painkillers known as cox-2's. Merck withdrew Vioxx from the market last fall over safety concerns, and Pfizer did the same thing a few months later with one of its cox-2 drugs, Bextra. Some companies, including Merck and Pfizer, are still betting on a big cox-2 comeback. Many analysts and doctors predict that the dearth of effective painkillers and the growing ranks of baby boomers suffering from aching joints will drive growth in the market.

Pope Benedict XVI called for the unity and peace when he visited a synagogue in Cologne, Germany Friday. He lamented the rise of a new signs of anti-Semitism and various forms of a general hostility toward foreigners.He reaffirmed that the Catholic church is committed to tolerance, respect,friendship and peace between all peoples, cultures and religions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 21, or the 17th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1754: Scottish engineer William Murdoch is born. He pioneered the use of coal-gas for lighting in 1792 while working with James Watt and Matthew Bouton on their steam engines.
1902: Manufacturer Martin Leland starts his luxury car venture by naming his new automobile after Antoine de la Motte Cadillac, the French colonial administrator and Detroit's founding father.
1908: Orville Wright, American aviation pioneer, and his brother Wilbur make the first military aircraft for the United States.
1930: Princess Margaret, sister of British Queen Elizabeth II, is born.
1944: Representatives from China, Britain, Russia and the United States meet at Dumbarton Oaks near Washington, D.C. to plan for the formation of the United Nations.
1937: The Treaty of Non-Aggression between China and the Soviet Union is signed in Nanking.
1959: The Baghdad Pact is formally renamed the Central Treaty Organization (CENTO) following Iraq's withdrawal earlier in the year.
1959: Hawaii becomes the 50th state of the United States.
1963: South Vietnam declares martial law after raids on Buddhist pagodas and the arrest of hundreds of Buddhist monks.
1976: Prince Maphevu Harry Dlamini, prime minister of the Kingdom of Swaziland, accompanied by Madame Dlamini and a party of eight, arrives in the Republic of China for a seven-day visit.
1982: King Sobhuza II of Swaziland dies at the age of 83. He was one of the world's longest-reigning monarchs, having been on the throne sine 1921.
1982: Republic of China Economics Minister William Y.T. Chao announces the partial lifting of an import ban on 842 types of Japanese consumer goods.
1983: Benigno Aquino, leader of the anti-Marcos faction in the Philippines, is gunned down as he steps onto the asphalt at Manila Airport after returning from a three-year sojourn in the United States. He was 51.
1984: A massive demonstration is held in Manila to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of Benigno Aquino.
1985: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Robert C. Chien as the new finance minister, succeeding Loh Jen-kong who resigned on Aug. 15.
1986: A cloud of toxic gas is released from the volcanic Lake Nyos, near Wum in northwest Cameroon, killing more than 1,200 people.
1990: An ROC Air Force B-1900 air transport plane crashes in Tungshih Village in Yunlin County, killing all 16 people aboard, including three major-generals and nine colonels.
1990: The Indian Parliament approves presidential rule in Jammu and Kashmir and gives the armed forces special powers in the riot-torn state.
1991: President Mikhail Gorbachev arrives back in Moscow after the collapse of a coup attempt by hardliners.
1991: Latvia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
1997: Abdur Rahim Gaffurzai, the newly appointed prime minister of Afghanistan, is killed along with 13 others in a plane crash.
1999: Over 96 percent of the Kuomintang's party delegates vote to support Vice President Lien Chan as the party's candidate in the following spring's presidential election.
2000: Former ROC President Lee Teng-hui proposes the establishment of an Asian monetary fund to promote economic cooperation in Asia.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian and his Gambian counterpart Yahya Jammeh sign a joint communique pledging to continue enhancing close cooperation between the two countries.
2001: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterates while meeting with visiting Paraguayan Foreign Minister Jose Antonio Moreno Ruffinelli that the ROC government will abide by the memorandum of trade and investment signed by the ROC and Paraguay to further cement the established ties between Taipei and Asuncion.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It matters not what you try to carry out, but when you once try to carry out a thing you must never give it up until you have done it thoroughly and well."

DOC.HEADLINE: STAMP PRINTING PROCESS AS RIGOROUS AS PRINTING MONEY

TEXT.P: The postage stamp design and printing process is so rigorous that it can be equated to that for actual money, an official with China Color, which cooperates with the Central Engraving and Printing Plant to print stamps for Chunghwa Post Co., said Sunday.

Despite the fact that many production procedures have been automated due to technological advances, stamp printing is still highly labor-intensive, said Lin Fu-rong, a senior designer with China Color.
The stamp printing process requires a high degree of attention, from the entrance of stacks of white paper sheets to the final separation procedure, Lin said.

Workers at the stamp printing station must count and double check that the number of sheets fed in and the number of stamps printed out match at the end of each production day, Lin said, adding that if the numbers don't add up, the workers have to stay on until the source of the error is discovered.
If stamps with printing mistakes are delivered unnoticedly to the post office, workers face stiff penalties and the even possibility of being fired, she added.

Because the stamp making process is so rigorous, Lin said, stamps with printing flaws or some related unusual feature, such as a part of the print design being upside, are particularly valued by collectors, who are willing to pay thousands of dollars for such stamps.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Pope urges muslims to join anti-terrorism efforts.
Pope Benedict XVI urged muslims Saturday to join anti-terrorism efforts. He said in a meeting with muslim officials in Cologne, Germany that the terrorism is a perverse and cruel decision which shows contempt for the sacred right to life and undermines the very foundation of all civil society.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPLAINT CENTER FOR FOREIGN LABORERS TO BE SET UP AT CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) announced Sunday that it will soon set up a service center at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to handle complaints by foreign laborers.

The announcement comes in the wake of criticism from a labor organization in the Philippines that a Taiwan factory had condoned its security guards using force against four Filipino laborers who organized a strike to protest against the management's unreasonable wage cuts. The laborers were then deported.
Kuo Fong-yu, director general of the CLA's Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training, noted that one cannot listen to only one side of the story during disputes between laborers and management.

Usually, if foreign laborers and employers reach agreement, the CLA will not interfere with employers deporting foreign laborers, Kuo said. However, he continued, in order to avoid a situation where foreign laborers sign agreements under coercion, the CLA has decided to set up the service center at the CKS International Airport to provide the foreign laborers with a last channel to file complaints.
Kuo said the center will be set up at the departure area of the airport with the aim of allowing foreign laborers to freely express their complaints without interference from their employers.
There will be volunteers stationed at the center, and the Philippine, Thai, Indonesian and Vietnamese missions in Taiwan will also send personnel to provide support, Kuo said.

He said that after the service center receives a complaint, the CLA will begin verification work, and if the laborer or laborers are found to indeed have been improperly treated during their stay in Taiwan, then the employers will be disciplined and the deported laborers will be allowed to apply to come to Taiwan again. If the laborer is found to be responsible for a dispute, then the CLA will agree to the deportation, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEEING IDEAS TURNED INTO STAMP DESIGN GRATIFYING: DEBUT DESIGNER

TEXT.P: The designer of the No. 5 souvenir sheet -- Taiwan Flowers and Fruits -- for an international stamp exhibition currently being held in Taipei said Sunday that it is very gratifying to see one of her ideas used as the design for a stamp.
Hsu Yung-hua, 28, made the remarks during an autograph session on the third day of the six-day Taipei 2005 and 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition.

Hsu, who graduated from Ming Chuan University where she majored in business design, said that this is the first time that any of her work has been used as a design for a stamp and that she is very happy.

On the layout of the stamp, she said subtropical Taiwan is blessed with a great variety of fruits and flowers, and that the upper half of the layout is a bamboo basket packed with such common fruits in Taiwan as watermelon, apples, wax apples and grapes, and that there are also sweet melons, peaches, starfruit and the omnipresent fruit in Taiwan -- bananas -- surrounding the basket.
The lower part of the stamp features diverse kinds of flowers, including azaleas, butterfly orchids, roses, hydrangea, and poinsettia, making the stamp both rich and colorful.
Though a wide variety of fruits and flowers have been packed into the stamp, Hsu said that she felt that there were some "jewels" left out, such as the guava, lychee, and plum blossom.
She said that some fruits and flowers had to be left out because she had to consider the overall beauty and harmony of the design.

DOC.HEADLINE: MICROSOFT OFFERS RFID CHIP TO HELP IMPROVE POSTAL SERVICES

TEXT.P: Microsoft is touting its latest radio frequency identification device (RFID) at the ongoing Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition to help post offices and express delivery companies manage parcel tagging and tracking.

The Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition, which opened at the Taipei World Trade Center Aug. 19, has drawn swarms of visitors and stamp collectors, as well as representatives of companies, such as Microsoft, to explore the potentially lucrative market in postal and speedy delivery services.
According to Microsoft Taiwan people, post offices can incorporate RFID into their own mail or parcel management systems for efficient tracking of parcels on the road.

Once the post office counter is equipped with RFID, the entire courier system -- from the first post office where the parcel is received to the destination post office where the parcel is supposed to be delivered to the end receiver, regardless of how many "stops" the parcel must make -- needs only one punch of information about the parcel.

After the information about the parcel is punched into a post office's computer, the computer will print out an RFID tag which contains the parcel's information. Once the post office worker sticks the tag onto the departing parcel, it can tracked digitally wherever it is.

The post office can also contact the parcel senders via MSN or mobile phone messages, allowing the senders to know their parcel's latest whereabouts and exactly when it will arrive, the Microsoft Taiwan people said.
Chunghwa Post Co., the key sponsor of the ongoing stamp exhibition, has yet decide when or if it will sign a contract with Microsoft to use its latest RFID technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: FATHER OF STAMP SHOW SPOKESWOMAN AN AVID STAMP COLLECTOR

TEXT.P: The father of the spokeswoman of the 2005 Taipei and 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition has been an avid stamp collector for more than half a century.

Lin Fan-nan, a former head of the Rotary Club of Taipei Northgate, only spoke about stamps and not about his supermodel daughter, who is still recovering in Taipei after being injured in a horse-riding accident in Dalien, China while shooting an ad there last month.
Lin, who is a businessman, said that whenever he visits other countries, he derives great joy from collecting stamps from those countries.
Lin toured the exhibition Saturday and shared his experiences in collecting stamps for over five decades.
Lin said that he has invested all his pocket money in stamp collecting since his childhood. He said that he was first attracted to stamps in the fourth grade.
Noting that stamps are a way to convey the cultures and arts of a nation, Lin said that he has savored many nation's culture through stamps.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERSONALIZED STAMP AND POSTCARD AREA POPULAR AT STAMP EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: The personalized greeting stamps and postcards area at the Taipei 2005 and 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition has been one of the most popular attractions at the ongoing exhibition.
Chunghwa Post Co., main sponsor of the exhibition, said that on Saturday alone, over 1,000 personalized greeting stamps and postcards were made for visitors to the exhibition.
Chunghwa Post set up the area to cater to those who are tired of ordinary stamps and postcards and want to try something new.

Visitors can use the memory cards of their digital cameras or have their pictures taken for free by Chunahwa Post staff for the postcards or stamps. They can also choose any of the three backgrounds designed by the company -- namely supermodel Lin Chi-ling, the world's highest skyscraper Taipei 101, or a collage image -- for their personalized greeting stamps.
On Saturday alone, more than 400 sets of stamps were produced, with prices ranging from NT$140 (US$4.37) to NT$170, for visitors to the exhibition.

In addition, there are five machines that produce creative postcards at the exhibition site, with more than 20 backgrounds to choose from. On Saturday, more than 600 postcards were produced, each costing NT$20.

Chunghwa Post staff urged visitors to try creative postcards, saying that personalized postcards can be sent in the mail just like regular postcards and that such postcards are very popular in Japan where an estimated 100 million are sent each year.
Chunghwa Post said that it is considering accepting orders for personalized postcards via the Internet after the exhibition closes Aug. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO PURCHASE 1.5 MILLION VACCINES AGAINST POSSIBLE FLU ONSLAUGHT

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control of the Department of Health (DOH) will purchase 1.5 million flu vaccines to cope with the possible threat of a deadly new flu strain that might develop through mutation in the event that the influenza virus combines with that of avian flu.
Shih Wen-yi, deputy director of the center, said Sunday that as Taiwan will soon enter the "flu season" in October, the DOH needs to be well-prepared for a possible flu pandemic.

He added that vaccination will begin in the second half of September, with the high-risk groups given first priority. These groups include people over 65 years old, infants under 2, patients with respiratory problems, health workers, poultry farmers, butchers and transport workers.
Although the vaccines will not be able to prevent a new flu strain or a human strain of avian flu from spreading, they can help reduce the mortality rate among the weak and the old, Shih said.

Shih also said the DOH has stashed enough Tamiflu -- a capsuled medicine said to be highly effective against avain flu -- for 160,000 patients. He admitted that if a human strain of bird flu strikes Taiwan, supply would become a serious problem.

In a report at a National Security Council meeting last week, the DOH warned that an estimated 5.3 million people will be infected if an outbreak of bird flu hits Taiwan. The DOH said its has already mapped out an emergency plan, including requesting the National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) to develop a drug against avian flu.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the NHRI disclosed that research is near completion at the NHRI in the development of a Taiwan version of Tamiflu, and that such technology can be transferred to domestic biopharmaceutical companies early next year.

Avian flu was first known to have jumped from chickens to humans in 1997. The disease has killed millions of birds in Southeast Asia since 2004 and recorded a 70 percent mortality rate in the first 70 people known to have been infected. There are widespread worries in the international community that the next outbreak of a lethal global flu pandemic may kill billions of people.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4,500 SMUGGLED BIRDS FROM CHINA TO BE DESTROYED

TEXT.P: Taiwan coast guard forces confiscated 4,500 birds aboard a fishing boat that was trying to smuggle them from China into the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung Sunday.
As China has been listed as an avian flu affected area, the birds will be destroyed, officials said. Taiwan is currently listed as a non-affected area.

The Kaohsiung-registered fishing boat "Yung Chi Fa" was transporting the birds, including Indian Grackle, song thrush and Red Beak, from a Chinese fishing boat in the Taiwan Strait, according to the Coast Guard Administration.

Coast guard vessels intercepted the "Yung Chi Fa" and arrested its captain, Chen Sze-fu, 37, and fisherman Tseng Man-teh, 24, both of whom were trying to cover the birds' chirping sounds with the boat's loud engines.

In Taipei, the Council of Agriculture (COA) urged the public not to smuggle fowl and poultry, whose illegal importation might deal a severe blow to Taiwan's poultry industry and threaten public health.

A Department of Health report has warned that a mutated strain of the avian flu virus could cause a global outbreak. In one scenario, as many as 5.3 million people could be stricken with the virus in Taiwan, which would have an impact on Taiwan's society and economy 10 times more severe than that of the SARS epidemic in 2003, according to the report.

The COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine said the government has beefed up monitoring of migrant birds and reminded farm workers to step up preventive measures, including vaccination of humans.

Stopping the smuggling of birds and poultry is another way to keep Taiwan from being affected, according to the bureau, which vowed to cooperate with other government agencies in cracking down on illegal imports of birds and poultry.

DOC.HEADLINE: V.P. CALLS ON RELIGIOUS LEADERS TO PROMOTE CONSERVATION

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu appealed Sunday to leaders of Taiwan's religious community to use their influence to raise public awareness of the importance of conserving the natural environment to ensure the country's sustainable development.

Referring to what she saw during a helicopter trip to mountainous areas in the northern counties of Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli as an "environmental nightmare, " Lu called for members of the religious community to help "enlighten" the Taiwan public to become more environmentally friendly.

In a speech to a nationwide convention of vegetarian Buddhist monks held at the Linkou Stadium in Taoyuan County, Lu urged the religious leaders to promote conservation in the spirit of "respecting heaven, cherishing the Earth and loving the people."

Meanwhile, Lu appealed to the Taiwan public to help prevent the outbreak of epidemic diseases, such as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and avian flu, by improving personal hygiene, upgrading public sanitation and conserving the environment.

With global warming and the outbreaks of diseases around the world, Taiwan has been experiencing some "uneasy years, " Lu said, warning that Taiwan will face another severe challenge of the possible outbreak of epidemic diseases this winter and next spring.
Noting that the world was battered by three major epidemics, in 1919, 1957 and 1968, Lu said that avian flu threatens to be the next major scourge.
Lu noted that the World Health Organization has informed Taiwan to prepare itself for any possible outbreak of avian flu in the following months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ASSETS ISSUE TO BE HANDLED BEFORE END OF 2008: CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Newly-sworn in opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou vowed Sunday that the oft-talked about and long-disputed issue of the KMT's assets will be solved before the end of 2008.

Ma said that all KMT assets, including the KMT Central Committee Building, will be handled based on the principles of law, justice and fairness to demonstrate the party's resolve in reforming itself and to win back the hearts and souls of its supporters. He said dealing with the issue is important to re-establish the party's "plain and honest" image from the era when President Chiang Ching-kuo was at the helm.

Ma, who has sworn that the KMT will win back power from the Democratic Progressive Party in the 2008 presidential election, stressed the imperative of delegating power within the party apparatus to the younger generation.
He said that one of his priorities as the KMT leader is to give more opportunities to young party members to take up more important party jobs or to run for public office posts.
Only by continuing to cultivate younger members and injecting new blood into the party can the KMT avoid witnessing a "fault of talent," Ma said.
Ma made the remarks during a speech at the opening of a KMT Central Advisory Committee meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN PEOPLE USE COMPUTER EVERYDAY: POLL

TEXT.P: About 60 percent of all people in Taiwan use a computer every day, with 70 percent of families owning at least two computers, according to a recent survey on the information products consumption patterns of Taiwan people.

The results of the poll, conducted jointly by Shih Hsin University and the magazine PC Home, show that 40 percent of Taiwan's users gave themselves a passing grade of 60 points (out of 100 points) in computer use abilities, while 38 percent gave themselves a score of 80 points or more.

Notebook computers, digital cameras and MP3s are the three most popular items among the Taiwan people, while only 10 percent said that they are attracted to exhibit booths by "show girls" and most of the respondents claimed that they hate large crowds at exposition venues -- a finding that goes against the commonly held view that show girls help lure large crowds and boost sales.
The random survey was conducted on visitors to a computer applications show held at the Taipei World Trade Center from July 28 to Aug. 1. A total of 1,136 valid samples were collected.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIMPLIFIED TAX REBATE MEASURES IN THE WORKS TO ATTRACT MORE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: As part of the government's efforts to double tourist arrivals to Taiwan, relevant agencies are considering allowing foreign tourists to get their tax rebates directly at department stores instead of at airports upon departure.
Council for Economic Planning and Development Vice Chairman Thomas Yeh made the revelation following a Cabinet meeting over the weekend.
According to Yeh, officials of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications suggested the simplification in the existing tax rebate measures for foreign tourists.

To that end, the Ministry of Finance is planning to include Taiwan specialty products, such as ceramics, wooden sculptures, tea and marble items, in the tax rebate list, Yeh said, adding that foreign tourists can enjoy a 5 percent tax rebate as long as their purchases in Taiwan exceed NT$3,000 (about US$95).

In addition, the Ministry of Finance is also considering reducing the minimum amount of capital required to open a duty-free store, from the current level of NT$100 million to NT$50 million, and the minimum amount to open a distribution center, from NT$300 million to NT$200 million, he said.
The ministry will complete the revision of relevant measures within two months in line with the Executive Yuan's plans to boost the domestic economy and tourism, he added.
Vice Premier Wu Rong-i has set an economic growth rate target of at least 4 percent for 2005 and has asked relevant agencies to come up with concrete measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO DISCUSS EXPANSION PLAN FOR CENTRAL TAIWAN AIRPORT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will discuss an expansion plan for Chingchuankang Airport in central county of Taichung Monday in the hope of making the airport suitable for international flights.
The first-phase expansion project, carrying a price tag of NT$1.55 billion (US$48.5 million), is slated for completion in 2008, according to Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) plans.

Both Vice Premier Wu Rong-i and CEPD Vice Chairman Chang Jing-sen, after making inspection tours in June and August, respectively, are supportive of the expansion plan to make the airport a point suitable for international flights.

To meet the growing demand for outbound charter flights from the greater Taichung area, the first-phase expansion includes constructing waiting rooms for increased international charter flights and installing large X-ray inspection facilities.

Taiwan people made a total of 7.78 million visits abroad last year, 18.7 percent of which, or 1.455 million visits, were made by residents from the central region of the country, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
At present, Chingchuankang Airport only offers flights on domestic routes and various charter flights to Japan, Bali and Phuket. The airport began operations early last year.
Taiwan already has two international airports -- Chiang Kai-shek International Airport near Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung International Airport in the south.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOUSING MARKET NOT EXPECTED TO EXPERIENCE BUBBLE: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's real estate market is unlikely to experience a bubble as supply and demand in the domestic housing market has remained within reasonable levels in recent years, experts said at a seminar sponsored by the Taiwan Research Institute over the weekend.

Speaking at the seminar on whether a bubble is forming in the global real estate market, local experts opined that a bubble is unlikely to occur in Taiwan as prices in the domestic housing market have not surged as much as in other countries in recent years.
They predicted that domestic house prices will remain stable in the years ahead on the grounds that supply is on the rise and that house ownership rates have reached around 85 percent.

Pointing out that the domestic real estate market has become quite mature after having gone through a serious recession during the 1990-2002 period, they said that the most recent surge, from June 2003 to May 2004, only saw a hike in housing prices of between 5 percent and 10 percent, which is tiny in comparison to the over 100 percent hikes seen in developed countries over the past five years.

According to a recent report by the Economist, the total value of the housing market in developed countries swelled from US$30 trillion to US$70 trillion in the last five years, the largest real estate bubble in history.

Commenting on the possible impact on Taiwan's housing market of the recent 2 percent revaluation upward of mainland China's currency -- the renminbi, the experts contended that the domestic market will be affected mainly by long-term economic prospects rather than by any short-term fluctuations in currency values.

The small appreciation of the renminbi will have no impact on Taiwan's economy, and foreign hot money is not expected to flow into Taiwan on rampant speculation that the renminbi will further appreciate in the near term, they said, claiming that China's efforts to stem its red-hot economy will likely have a greater impact on Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ARTIFICIAL BIRTHS BILL MAY ALLOW SURROGATE MOTHERHOOD

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) disclosed Sunday that new provisions may be added to the artificial births bill being drafted by the DOH to allow surrogate motherhood under certain conditions.

The DOH said that the draft law would allow a childless couple with infertility problems to use a surrogate mother if they can provide their own egg and sperm for artificial insemination. The law would require that the surrogate mother must be an adult with successful childbearing experience.

The surrogate mother may get paid for her service, and there is no restriction as to her nationality. She will also be entitled to financial compensation to cover her hospital bills, losses of pay from her job due to pregnancy, and expenses for transportation and nutrition, according to the bill.

However, voices from the medical circle warned that if the bill gets passed in its current form, commercial brokers may emerge and try to find foreign women working in Taiwan's factories and households to become surrogate mothers.

While acknowledging the good intentions of the DOH in adding the new provisions, some medical doctors expressed concerns that couples who are unable to bear a child may make use of the law's loopholes and work with crooked brokers to encourage women laborers from southeast Asian countries like the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam to provide the service in exchange for money.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SELLING ASSETS CHEAPLY IS NOT THE SAME AS RETURNING THEM: DPP

TEXT.P: If the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) sells the National Development Institute (NDI) cheaply, this will not be an action that represents returning its "ill-gotten" assets to the people, Su Tseng-chang, chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said Sunday.
Su made the remarks before joining Legislator Wang Toh, DPP candidate for Keelung mayor, for a campaign activity in the northern Taiwan city.

On vows by the new KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou that he will deal with the issue of the party's assets based on "the principles of law, justice, and fairness" by 2008 to show the party's resolve in reforming itself, Su said selling the party's assets cheaply does not equate to returning them to the people.

Su said that the NDI, the KMT's school for nurturing future leaders of the nation, is not a legitimate asset of the KMT's and that it therefore doesn't make sense to consider the KMT selling it as equating to returning it to the people.

The NDI, located in the Wenshan district of Taipei, is made up of 28 land lots totaling 78,541 square meters. The listed value of the land currently stands at more than NT$5.2 billion (US$185.07 million).
Meanwhile, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the DPP, urged Ma not to agree to the selling of the NDI.
Huang Shih-cho, a TSU caucus whip in the legislature, said that the KMT had used the means of threats and intimidation to obtain the NDI land, urging Ma to veto its sale.

Huang made the remarks following reports that a prospective buyer has signed an initial agreement with the KMT for the land and that the formal transaction contract must be signed by Aug. 25. According to the report, former KMT Chairman Lien Chan did not give any instructions as to whether he agreed to the land's sale, and the matter is now in Ma's hands to deal with at his own discretion.

Huang reiterated that the "ill-gotten" assets of the KMT should be returned to the people, especially because the land of the NDI was obtained during the authoritarian era, and that the previous owners of the land are now filing suits to challenge its sale.
He also said that the KMT is anxious to sell the land with the aim of "laundering its ill-gotten wealth and making the property of the people into cash to finance the party's needs."
The TSU condemns the actions of the KMT, Huang said, urging the judicial authorities to intervene in the transaction.
He also urged those conglomerates who intend to buy the NDI land not to act against their conscience and social responsibility, cautioning that they face possible ownership problems after the deal.
Huang also urged Ma to support the passage in the next legislative session of a bill governing the assets of political parties.

The DPP tried to put the bill on the Legislative Yuan's agenda in the last session but failed because the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and its ally, the People First Party, who together command a slight majority, blocked it.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP DELEGATION DEPARTS FOR CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: An opposition People First Party (PFP) delegation led by the party's secretary-general departed Taiwan Sunday afternoon for a visit to China.

PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng said they will meet with their Communist Party of China (CPC) counterparts to work out the details for PFP Chairman James Soong's scheduled visit to China in September.
Soong is expected to preside over the opening of forum between Taiwan and China in Shanghai during his September visit.
Chin said his delegation will also exchange views with Chinese officials on the issues relating to the opening of direct transportation links between Taiwan and the mainland.

The PFP secretary-general said he hopes the talks between his delegation and Chinese officials will help Taiwan's banks and insurance companies to venture into the Chinese market and help build a consensus on the establishment of a cross-strait currency-exchange mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Militias on the Rise Across Iraq; Shiite and Kurdish Groups Seizing Control, Instilling Fear in North and South.
Shiite and Kurdish militias, often operating as part of Iraqi government security forces, have carried out a wave of abductions, assassinations and other acts of intimidation, consolidating their control over territory across northern and southern Iraq and deepening the country's divide along ethnic and sectarian lines, according to political leaders, families of the victims, human rights activists and Iraqi officials, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO SPEND NT$1 B. TO CLEAN UP DANSHUI RIVER

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will spend NT$1 billion (US$31.1 million) over the next three years to clean up Danshui (Tamsui) River that runs through Taiwan's most densely populated area, officials said Sunday.
EPA Minister Chang Kow-Lung said his staff have drafted a plan to build seven waste water processing centers and complete three ecological engineering projects along the northern Taiwan river.
Chang made the remarks during a publicity activity aimed at encouraging more people to volunteer as patrol guards to help prevent dumping on river banks.
EPA statistics show that 12.9 percent of Danshui River are seriously polluted, down from 21.84 percent two years ago. The three-year plan will focus on cleaning up the polluted sections of the river.

Premier Frank Hsieh, who was also attending the activity, used his "Kaohsiung City experience" as an example, saying that increasing water sewages and waste processing facilities had improved the water quality of that city's Love River.

Now Love River no longer smells, along the river real estate prices have gone up, and as a result tourism and leisure industries are booming, a telling example of symbiosis between man and nature, Hsieh added.

Chang said Taiwan's river have been polluted mainly because too few sewage systems and waste processing stations have been installed, and household and farming waste water have been flowing into rivers.
He urged local governments to budget more money for building sewage systems and waste processing centers to stop waste water entering rivers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW KMT CHIEF STRESSES HISTORICAL TIES BETWEEN PARTY AND TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou stressed the close historical ties between KMT and Taiwan Sunday in an attempt to dispel criticism that KMT is an alien regime intruding into Taiwan.
Speaking at a meeting of the KMT Advisory Committee, Ma said , the party should emphasized its historical ties with Taiwan, in addition to its Chinese root.

Citing the story of a late Taiwanese painter Liao Chin-ping as an example, Ma said Liao donated funds to KMT-founder Sun Yat-sen in 1913 when Sun arrived in Taipei on his way to exile in Japan after KMT lost a war against then Chinese President Yuan Shih-kai.

In appreciation of Liao's donation, Sun gave Liao a bottle of whisky which was kept by Liao's son after Liao was killed in 1947 when the KMT-led government cracked down ruthlessly a disturbance in Taiwan known as the 228 Incident.

Liao's son gave the liquor to Ma at a ceremony marking the 228 incident this year in Taipei, and disclosing the friendship between his late father and Sun Yat-sen, Ma said, adding that he was deeply moved by the story which is footnote to the KMT's close ties with Taiwan, Ma said.
"Those who claimed that Kuomintang is an alien regime are just ignorant of the history." Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE PLEASED TO SEE CROSS-STRAIT TIES STABILIZED
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Charles Kang/ S.C Chang)

TEXT.P: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Sunday that as a friend of both China and Taiwan, Singapore was pleased to see that the situation across the Taiwan Strait have stabilized following the successful visits to China by two Taiwan opposition party leaders.
Lee made the remarks during a speech celebrating Singapore's National Day.

He said reduced tension across the strait following the visits to China by Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong in the spring has stabilized regional situation, which is beneficial to all countries.

Lee also cited the examples of Taipei, Shanghai, Hong Kong, and other Asian cities that have been working hard to adapt to new realities, to urge Singaporeans to become the best service providers in the region.

He said a small country like Singapore must try hard to improve its foreign relations, adding that he had the pleasure of telling Singaporeans that bilateral relations with ASEAN, Japan, India and the United States have made substantive progress recently.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Aug. 22, or the 18th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster, according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1834: Samuel Pierpoint Langley, American astronomer and aviation pioneer, is born. He built the first successful heavier-than-air flying machines in 1896.
1849: Amaral, the Portuguese governor of Macao, is assassinated for practicing anti-Chinese politics.
1910: Korea is formally annexed by Japan after five years as a Japanese protectorate.
1911: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa, one of the world's most famous paintings, is stolen from the Louvre in Paris. It was returned two years later.
1919: Some 5,000 Jews are massacred in the Ukraine.
1932: Japanese troops attack Jehol in northern China.
1937: The Chinese Communist Party issues a statement calling on the people to obey the National government and join the War of Resistance Against Japan, and changes its "Red Army" into the Eighth Army.
1941: German troops reach the outskirts of Leningrad.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States for a visit at the invitation of President Franklin D. Roosevelt. FDR announced on March 30 the establishment of the Pacific War Council in Washington, comprised of China, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Australia, Canada and the Netherlands.
1968: Warsaw Pact tanks enter Prague, the Czech capital, to crush the first flowering of Alexander Dubcek's reforms.
1973: Henry Kissinger is named U.S. secretary of state, succeeding William Rogers.
1981: A Boeing 737 passenger plane owned by the Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes near Miaoli in central Taiwan, killing all 110 people aboard.
1983: China Airlines suspends its CI811 flight to Manila on orders of the Philippine civil aviation authorities. Manila had warned international airlines not to allow opposition leader Benigno Aquino to board their aircraft for a return to the Philippines on the grounds that he did not have legal travel papers.
Aquino was gunned down on Aug. 21 while soldiers were escorting him from his China Airlines flight from Taipei upon his return to Manila after three years of self-exile in the United States.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the appointment by President Chiang Ching-kuo of Ronald H. C. Ho (Ho Hsien-chung) as the new finance political vice minister.
1985: A British Airtour Boeing 747 bound for Corfu catches fire at Manchester Airport shortly after engine failure had forced the pilot to abandon the takeoff. The fire killed 54 people aboard.
1986: Francisco Zepeda Andino, the new Honduran ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1986: Wang Han successfully swims across the Strait of Gibraltar, becoming the first Chinese person to do so.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu), killing or injuring 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in the past twenty years. The Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help victims.
1995: The KMT convenes its 14th National Congress and Lee Teng-hui, party chairman, announces he will seek the party's presidential nomination. Lin Yang-kang, a KMT vice chairman, declares his intention not to seek the party's nomination and to instead run as an independent.
1996: The 61-nation Conference on Disarmament in Geneva ends in failure after India blocked an agreement on a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
1999: A China Airlines passenger plane with 315 on board crash-lands at Chek Lap Kok airport in Hong Kong during a typhoon, killing two and injuring 211.
2000: Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong says that it is still too early to talk about overhauling the Guidelines for National Unification as the government has yet to demonstrate consistency regarding its cross-strait policies.
2000: Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore decorades visiting ROC President Chen Shui-bian with the Order of Grande Croix in recognition of his contribution to promoting bilateral ties.
2001: Republic of China Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya, along with a 20-strong delegation, attends the 2001 Women's Leaders Meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Beijing.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If another man succeeds through one effort, use a hundred efforts. If another man succeeds though ten efforts, use a thousand efforts. Let a man really proceed in this manner, and, though dull, he will surely become intelligent; though weak, he will surely become strong."

DOC.HEADLINE: MA SAYS HE CAN HANDLE BOTH ROLES AS MAYOR AND KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that he will be able handle both of his roles adequately.

Ma, who was sworn in as the new KMT chairman Aug. 19, inspected Monday for the first time the KMT Central Committee Building -- the nerve center of the major opposition party -- where he issued brief directives on several KMT party affairs before being whisked back to his another office at Taipei City Hall.
He said that one of his priorities as the KMT leader is to lead the party to win the year-end nationwide mayoral and county chief elections.
Other priorities, he said, include handling the oft-talked about and long-disputed issue of the KMT's assets, accelerating KMT reforms, and nurturing young party members.

Ma reiterated that all KMT assets, including the KMT Central Committee Building, will be handled based on the law and the principles of justice and fairness and will be solved before the end of 2008 to re-establish the party's "plain and honest" image from the era when President Chiang Ching-kuo was at the helm.
He added that the party will accelerate efforts to reform itself so as to win back the hearts and souls of its supporters.

Ma, who has sworn that the KMT will win back power from the Democratic Progressive Party in the 2008 presidential election, also stressed the imperative of delegating more power within the party apparatus to the younger generation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FRUIT TO FACE STIFF COMPETITION IN CHINA: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Taiwan fruits will face stiff competition in the Chinese market once the mainland people's "fever" for them subsides.
President Chen made the remarks on Taiwan fruit exports to China while receiving 10 winners of outstanding agricultural expert awards at the Presidential Office.
The president noted that the government will take good care of Taiwan's farmers. He also suggested that they "look to the future, " instead of focusing on short-term gains.
The farmers should upgrade their competitive edge and target those high income nations such as Singapore, Japan, the United States and those in Europe, the president said.

He said that although Taiwan fruits have enjoyed brisk sales in China since Beijing's announcement to provide zero-tariff treatment for 15 varieties of Taiwan fruits starting this month, the "fever" has rapidly been subsiding and the issue will have to return to market economy fundamentals.

Compared with Japan, China has lower standards in terms of quarantine, inspection and food sanitation, the president said, adding that for this reason, even though Taiwan fruits enjoy duty-free treatment, they still have to face competition from cheap fruits from Southeast Asia.

He pointed out that because Japan has high standards in terms of accepting imports, Taiwan produce will be assured of market share in Japan if it can make inroads into that country. He added that Japanese consumers are willing to pay higher prices for safe, high-quality produce.
