DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS TYCOON DECORATED WITH FRENCH NATIONAL ORDER

TEXT.P: Unipresident Enterprises Corp. Chairman C. Y. Kao was decorated Monday with the National Order of the Legion of Honor -- France's premier order awarded for meritorious service to French society.
Kao has maintained cooperative relations with Carrefour Group, owner of the French hypermarket chain of the same name, for nearly 20 years.
Kao is the second Taiwan businessman to receive the order, following Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Yung-fa.
Carrefour Group Chairman Jose Luis Duran was present at the ceremony marking the event in Taipei.

The Unipresident Enterprise currently owns a 30.5-percent stake in Carrefour's Taiwan business after becoming the French retail giant's partner in 1987. Two years later, it helped open the first Carrefour outlet in Taiwan.
Carrefour has 36 outlets around Taiwan, with annual revenue totalling NT$50 billion (US$1.56 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: STAMP DESIGNER FEELS LIKE A MOVIE STAR AT AUTOGRAPH EVENT

TEXT.P: The designer of the No. 6 souvenir sheet -- Taiwan Festivals -- for the Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition currently being held at the Taipei World Trade Center said Monday that she felt like a movie star when she was giving out her autograph to collectors who waited in a long line to see her.

Chen Yu-wen, 26, said she had the jitters with so many people waiting for her autograph -- the first time this has happened in her young life -- although she said the collectors' enthusiasm boosted her ego tremendously.

Chen said she spent about six months on the design after signing a contract with Chunghwa Post Co., the key sponsor of the exhibition. To stress the significance of Taiwan festivals, Chen said, she picked images of several traditional festivals that she considers as the most representative of Taiwanese culture and religions as the material of her design for the No. 6 souvenir sheet -- the burning of ships for the God of the Plague; the Bunun tribesmen's deer ear shooting ritual; and the Dragon Boat Festival.
Chen noted that as a designer of printed commercial pamphlets, mostly DMs, which have short shelf lives and little artistic value, she was really flattered to be asked to design stamps.

To publicize and celebrate the occasion, Chunghwa Post is issuing a series of eight separate souvenir sheets. The first and second -- No. 1 Taiwan Landscape and No. 2 Taiwan Culture -- were released on Aug. 27, 2004, and April 19, 2005, respectively. The third through eighth -- No. 3 Taiwan Conservation, No. 4 Taiwan Technology, No. 5 Taiwan Flowers and Fruits, No. 6 Taiwan Festivals, No. 7 Taiwan Cuisine and No. 8 Marine Taiwan -- will be released one each day during the course of the exhibition.

To commemorate the event, Chunghwa Post has also released a set of four "Taipei 2005-18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition Commemorative Postage Labels, " each of which features a different section of the ancient painting "Taisiantu" from the National Palace Museum collection.
Chunghwa Post is also offering 10,000 gifts by prize draw, in addition to offering exhibition visitors the opportunity to have their own personalized stamps and postcards made digitally.

The event, whose theme is "Tourism and Stamps, " is aimed at promoting Taiwan's stamps as well as tourism. The Formosan black bear, which is indigenous to Taiwan, has been chosen as the mascot of the exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MTR FOREIGN WORKERS RIOT

TEXT.P: Over 100 foreign workers, mostly Thais, rioted against what they called "unfair and unjust" management in Kangshan, suburban Kaohsiung, by burning houses, cars and facilities, and attacking police Sunday night. No serious injuries were reported.

Police said the incident occurred when several Thai workers returned to their dormitory with liquor and cigarettes, which are banned from the premises. When they were prevented from entering the dormitory, they vented their anger by burning houses, breaking glasses and throwing stones at the management staff, some of whom were beaten up.

Riot police were called in to restore order, and the rioting workers sent delegates to negotiate with the human resources company that brought them to work in Taiwan. The negotiations went on until a little past 7:00 a.m. Monday before breaking down.
The government has dispatched Council of Labor Affairs officials down to Kaohsiung and the Thai representative office came forward to try and mediate.

By noon, peace returned to the Kangshan foreign workers' living quarters that were built to accommodate 3,000 people hired to build Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit system. At present, only 1,700 foreign workers, mostly Thais, are living there.
Thai workers were seen taking the initiative to clean up the mess they had created, but police said they would gather evidence and charge those who led the rioting.

The workers demanded that they be allowed to use cell phones, that food quality at the cafeterias be improved and that a satellite dish be installed so they can watch TV programs from their home country.
They also protested the management company's unreasonable way of payment -- for each 100 hours of overtime, they are only paid for 46 hours.
Another disgruntlement of the workers was that they could not take back food and daily necessities that were not purchased at the dormitory store -- what they called a form of exploitation.
The Huapan Administration Consultant Co. Ltd. would not comment on the accusations as negotiations were continuing.
Some 94,000 Thai workers are currently in Taiwan, the largest foreign group followed by those from the Philippines and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 47.71 points to close at 6,206.65.
The bourse opened at 6,194.89 and fluctuated between 6,207.95 and 6,181.51 during trading. A total of 2.28 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$50.24 billion (US$1.56 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1 percent, cement stocks at 0.8 percent, foodstuff issues and textile stocks both at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent.
Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 499 to 353, with 178 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 94,000 THAI PEOPLE WORKING IN TAIWAN: POLICE STATISTICS

TEXT.P: Workers from Thailand form the largest foreign labor group in Taiwan, with police statistics showing there are now more than 94,000 Thai people working in the country.

The statistics of the National Police Administration showed that as of the end of March, the number of foreign workers legally residing in Taiwan was recorded at 278,566, over 115,000 of whom are male.
In terms of nationality, 94,742 foreign workers were from Thailand, accoutring for 34.1 percent of all foreign laborers in the country.
The number of Philippine workers stood at 85,024, and that of Vietnamese laborers was 82,491, according to the tallies.
The figures also showed that most foreign workers were in Taoyuan County, with 64,847, followed by 36,143 in Taipei County.
As for Kaohsiung County, where a riot involving over 100 Thai workers broke out Sunday night, the number of Thai laborers amounted to 11,492, 1,889 of whom work in construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 51 points to close at 6,215, with 16,456 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved up 45 points to end at 6,205, with 81 contracts traded, while December futures gained 41 points to finish at 6,200, with 34 contracts traded. March futures moved up 32 points to close at 6,190, with three contracts traded, while June futures moved up 42 points to close at 6,194, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,164 for September, 6,160 for October, 6,159 for December, 6,158 for March and 6,152 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

September TE futures moved up 3.05 points to close at 257.6, with 2,224 contracts traded, while October TE futures gained 2.05 points to finish at 257, with 20 contract transactions. March TE futures moved up 4.05 points to end at 257.6, with two contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and June.

September TF futures gained three points to finish at 955.6, with 1,129 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved up 1.6 points to end at 955.6, with 13 contracts traded. March TF futures moved up 3.4 points to close at 955.2, with 14 contracts transactions, while June TF futures gained two points to finish at 955.8, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVERTED 10-STAMP SHEET OF DR. SUN YAT-SEN BIG DRAW AT EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: Rare and valuable stamps were a big draw at the Taipei 2005 and 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition and one of the more fascinating exhibits was the 10-stamp sheet Dr. Sun Yat-sen issue, New York print, on which the image of the founding father of the Republic of China was printed upside down.
Chunghwa Post Co., main sponsor of the six-day event, said that it is the only 10-stamp sheet of this issue in the world.
The sheet is now owned by Huang Ming-fang, president of the Chinese Taipei Philatelic Society, Chunghwa Post officials said.
According to Chunghwa Post, the value of stamps hinges on several factors, and one of them is errors.

The ROC post authorities commissioned American Bank Note Co. to print the Dr. Sun Yat-sen issue, and the stamps were issued in 1941, and the mistake was not found until 1945 when a junior high school student found the image of Dr. Sun was printed upside down.
Huang said that a single Dr. Sun issue could fetch between NT$1.8 million (US$56,250) and NT$2 million, and that the 10-stamp sheet is estimated at NT$25 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 30 AUTOGRAPHED GREETING STAMP SETS BY SUPERMODEL HOTTEST ITEM

TEXT.P: Thirty autographed personalized greeting stamp sets by Lin Chi-ling, spokesman of the Taipei 2005 and 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition, were so hot that around 3,000 lucky draw tickets were issued in a short period of one hour.

Chunghwa Post Co., the main sponsor of the six-day event, handed out the tickets between 10 a.m. and 11 a.m. Monday. To enhance the chance of winning, some visitors had come with their whole families.

Meanwhile, Wu Tzu-mei, the mother of Lin Chi-ling, the spokeswoman of the exhibition who is still recovering at home from a horse riding accident while shooting an ad in Dalien, China, last month, donated the proceeds of the Lin Chi-ling personalized greeting stamp sets to the Yunlin and Chiayi county governments.
Yunlin County Council Vice Speaker Lin Yuan-chuan, in accepting the money on behalf of the 3,800 impoverished children of the county, expressed appreciation to Chunghwa Post and Lin.
Wu also said that her daughter is very honored to be able to speak for the exhibition, and hopes that the proceeds will be able to help the needy children.
To thank the supermodel, Chunghwa Post staff also mobilized a one-postcard-one-person-to-Lin campaign to wish her a speedy recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.071 to close at NT$32.118.
A total of US$651 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$32.210 and hit a low of NT$32.100.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG EXPECTED TO PRESIDE OVER FORUM IN SHANGHAI IN SEPTEMBER
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By C. L. Tseng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong is expected to preside over a cross-Taiwan Strait economic forum next month in Shanghai.

The matter was discussed during a meeting Monday between a visiting PFP delegation led by PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng and Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the Beijing-based State Council. It will be Soong's second visit to China this year following a visit in May.

Speaking following a working meeting between the two parties later the same day, PFP Policy Center Director Chang Hsien-yao said that his party prefers to start engagement with the Chinese side through the most urgent and less complex economic and financial issues, such as cargo and passenger services and financial cooperation, amid highly sensitive cross-strait relations.
The Shanghai forum will only touch on cross-strait trade and economic issues and exclude complicated political issues, he added.

According to Chang, representatives of major trade associations and chief executive officers of various leading enterprises from the United States, Europe and Japan will be invited to take part in discussions centering on the opening of direct cross-strait trade, transport and postal links, and the impact on foreign investment in Taiwan.

The PFP hopes to fully implement the six-point consensus reached in the May 12 meeting between Soong and Communist Party of China (CPC) General Secretary Hu Jintao that calls for an early commencement of cross-strait talks, the ending of hostilities between the two sides, the stepping up of Taiwan-China exchanges and two-way cooperative mechanisms, and the opposing of Taiwan independence, he said.

In the coming PFP-CPC working meetings, the two sides are expected to talk over substantial issues related to mainland-based Taiwan business people and students and the establishment of free trade zones.
Soong is currently in the United States and is slated to return to Taiwan this week.
Meanwhile, a 30-member legislative mission led by PFP lawmaker Christina Y. Liu arrived in Shanghai Sunday to attend a 2005 cross- strait financial forum.

The group will visit the Shanghai stock exchange Monday and will call at the newly inaugurated headquarters of the People's Bank of China -- the Chinese central bank -- in Shanghai Tuesday, where they will hold talks with its vice governors on currency exchange mechanisms between the new Taiwan dollar and the renminbi, Liu said.
According to Liu, they hope to discuss and exchange views with Chinese central bank officials on substantial issues related to Taiwan investors to help protect Taiwan business interest in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE GROUP VISITS JAPAN

TEXT.P: A 10-member group of legislators from Taiwan's major political parties departed for Japan Monday for a four-day visit, where they will exchange views on security issues with Japanese dietmen and think tank members.

The group will first call on Koh Se-kai, Taiwan's top representative in Japan, Tuesday and hear a briefing on Japan's security policies and its relations with neighboring countries. It will also visit dietmen at the Japanese upper house's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee and hold seminars with think tank members attached to the Japanese Defense Agency and retired military generals.
Lee Wen-chung, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said that there has been a nuanced change in Japan's attitude toward Taiwan in the face of a rising China.

Military exchanges between Taiwan and Japan were stalemated for a long time in the past due to Japan's softness toward China, but Japan began to pay greater importance to security in the Taiwan Strait since two or three years ago out of fears that a cross-strait conflict will cut the lifelines of its foreign trade and oil supply, he explained.

Lee described the legislative group's visit to Japan as an "ice-breaking" trip, as it is the first military exchange between National Defense Committee lawmakers and their Japanese counterparts in many years.
The group comprises legislators of the DPP, the main opposition Kuomintang, the People First Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER APPEALS FOR LENIENCY FOR FOREIGN LABORERS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh appealed to relevant government agencies Monday to be lenient with foreign laborers, saying that the country should extend greater hospitality to the foreign nationals who are here doing laborious jobs that many Taiwan citizens would rather not do.

Noting that efforts to protect the foreign laborers' basic human rights and interests should be made regularly, Hsieh said that it would be a "bad thing" if the laborers' dissatisfaction or indignation with their Taiwan managers came to a head to become a riot like what occurred in Koahsiung between late Sunday night and early Monday morning.

The premier said he has already directed the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to look into the latest incident, which was rare since Taiwan began to introduce foreign workers, mostly from Southeast Asian countries, in the early 1990s.

Over 100 foreign workers, mostly Thais, rioted against what they called "unfair and unjust" management at the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit Bureau, southern Taiwan, by burning cars and a makeshift office of the Kaohsiung MRT authorities, as well as attacking police Sunday night. No serious injuries were reported.

Police said the incident occurred when several Thai workers returned to their dormitory with liquor and cigarettes, which are banned from the premises. When they were prevented from entering the dormitory, they vented their anger by setting fire to the MRT office, breaking glass and hurling rocks at the management staff, some of whom were beaten up.

Riot police were called in to restore order, and the rioting workers sent delegates to negotiate with the human resources company that brought them to work in Taiwan. The negotiations went on until a little past 7:00 a.m. Monday.
By noon, peace was restored at the Kangshan foreign workers' living quarters that were built to accommodate 3,000 people hired to build the Kaohsiung MRT system.

Kuo Fang-yu, director-general of the CLA Employment and Vocational Training Administration, said that officials from the Kaohsiung Police Department, the Kaohsiung Bureau of Labor Affairs and the Thai liaison office in Taiwan have begun investigating the incident.

If the investigation results find that the management or the Kaohsiung MRT Bureau, which hired the Thai workers to build a subway line, was at fault, they will be dealt with in accordance with the Employment Law, could have their right to hire foreign workers canceled, Kuo said.
He added that if the Thai workers are found to be guilty of disturbing Taiwan's social order, they could also be punished, including having their work permits nullified.
Meanwhile, acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai expressed concern about the incident, urging all related parties to step forward to resolve the management-labor controversy as soon as possible.
Chen also called for the Thai workers' brokerage firm to mediate so that the laborers can resume their work to prevent the MRT project from being disrupted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Opposition Union's leader Romano Prodi does not have good eyes on third political force.
The opposition Union's leader Romano Prodi expressed his opposition Sunday to the formation of a third political force, claiming that only the bipolarism makes decision in the political field.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN ENGLISH TEACHERS GO THROUGH ORIENTATION IN TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: Twenty-one English teachers from the United States, Canada and Britain went through orientation Monday at the National Academy for Educational Research in Taipei County.

The orientation began that day and will run through Aug. 26, after which the foreign teachers will be sent to elementary schools in Kinmen -- an offshore island, as well as those in Taipei, Hsinchu, Yulin, Changhua, Taichung, Nantou, Chiayi, Kaohsiung and Hualien counties, to teach basic English.
The foreigners will learn about the country's educational profile and living environment, officials of the Ministry of Education (MOE) said.

This was the third batch of English teachers that the MOE has introduced to Taiwan from English-speaking countries since last October as part of its efforts to improve English-language education in the nation.
Besides Canada, the U.S. and England, the MOE also plans to hire qualified teachers in Australia and New Zealand to teach English on the island, MOE official noted.
As of now, 40 qualified foreign teachers have come to Taiwan under the MOE's employment, which lasts for one year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION ADMINISTRATION CELEBRATES 18TH BIRTHDAY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) celebrated its 18th anniversary Monday.
EPA Minister Chang Kuo-lung made three promises at the EPA's birthday party, saying that efforts have being taken to improve environmental quality of the island.
Chang stated that his first and second promises are to ease water and air pollution, while the third is to seek overall garbage reduction.

He said he hopes that residents in the country will cooperate with the EPA in the implementation of the government's "zero waste" policy by practicing garbage classification, adding his biggest wish is for all Taiwan people to protect their living environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN LABORERS ON KAOHSIUNG MRT PROJECT AGREE TO RETURN TO WORK

TEXT.P: The riot by around 100 Thai laborers working on Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit railway project reached a happy ending Monday after their manpower management company agreed to meet most of their demands for better treatment.

Officials from the representative office of Thailand in Taiwan and executives of the Huapan Manpower Consultant and Management Co. entered the dormitory under the protection of riot police to negotiate with the laborers and listen to their complaints.

The foreign workers raised 16 demands, including lifting the ban on drinking alcohol in the dormitory, allowing them to use mobile phones in the dorm, putting up a satellite dish so that they could watch TV programs from their home country, and allowing them to have the full overtime pay they deserve.

The Thai officials and Huapan executives, together with representatives from the local police precinct and the District Attorney's Office, held a meeting Monday afternoon at the cultural bureau of Kaohsiung County, trying to work out solutions to the problems.

The manpower management company eventually agreed to 14 of the 16 demands from the foreign laborers, who then agreed to resume working from Tuesday and allowed sanitation workers to enter the dormitory to clean up the debris from the riot.
By 2 p.m. Monday, most of the police sent to the riot scene had been withdrawn, leaving only a small force to stand guard.
The riot started Sunday evening at the foreign laborers's dormitory in Kangshan when management staff tried to stop some Thai workers from taking alcohol into the living quarters.

Angry foreign workers who had been unhappy for a long time about such rigid treatment set fire to a house and cars, and smashed doors and windows of the manager's office. They even threw stones at the fire fighters who rushed to the scene to fight the flames.
The management estimated that the riot caused a NT$10 million loss to Huapan Co., whose four two-story dormitories provide shelter to 1,720 foreign laborers.

One of the complaints by the Thai workers was that they received only 46 hours of overtime pay for the 100 hours of overtime they worked each month, without a description from the management about how much was withheld and for what purposes.
Meanwhile, Kaohsiung County Police were still collecting evidence in preparation for arrests and prosecution of those who started the riot on charges of arson, damage to cars and office materials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CHINESE EXPAT GROUPS SHOULD GET ALONG WITH EACH OTHER: ENVOY

TEXT.P: As expatriates from Taiwan and China are interacting more and more often, Taiwan's top envoy to South Africa said Tuesday such interactions should aim at increasing goodwill instead of forcing the other side to go against its own principles and interests.

Richard Shih made his comments as some Taiwanese expats in South Africa seem to feel frustrated in the face of a growing and much larger overseas Chinese community that is supported by an economically strong motherland.

Taiwan's expat community in South Africa is estimated to be 8,000-strong, while legal and illegal Chinese immigrants, including refugees, total 300,000, naturally becoming a focus of Chinese language media coverage.

By comparison, Taiwan immigrants appear much "quieter" than their Chinese counterparts. However, Shih said only mature people would remain composed and only when one is calm enough will he see a chance for change.

Analyzing the strengths of both sides of the Taiwan Strait, Shih said China is 265 times larger than Taiwan, and its population is 60 times larger. However, according to APEC data, China's two-way trade of US$850 billion last year was but 2.49 times that of Taiwan, which stood at US$340 billion, he added.

China's GDP, totalling US$1.60 trillion last year, was 5.21 times that of Taiwan, which was US$307 billion. When it comes to per capita GDP, Taiwan's US$14,000 was 12 times that of China's US$1,200, Shih told a group of Taiwan expats attending a volunteers' training session.

He quoted an article by famous critic Lung Ying-tai as saying that a big difference between Taiwan and China was their way of life, as Lung believes Taiwan's way of life will have a positive influence on China, forcing it to uplift itself to the ranks of more liberal and democratic countries.

A Global Visions Monthly article, commenting on a survey of Taiwan's biggest 700 listed companies, indicated that as Taiwan's enterprises become institutionally entrenched, they also become more and more mature, Shih continued.
He went on to quote Commonwealth magazine as reporting that Taiwan's businesses have gradually grown from OEM mode to creating their own brands, another indication of their maturing.

In a letter to the editor, the Democratic Progressive Party's former chairman, Lin Yi-hsiung, stressed the importance of good faith and goodwill if the ruling and opposition parties in Taiwan as well as the governments on the two sides of the Strait are to seek rapprochement.

Shih compared China's rapid economic growth to an adolescent, and Taiwan's growth to a stable and mature grown-up. He estimated that it will take China another 20 or 30 years before its economy reaches Taiwan's current level.

Since the two sides of the Strait are developing at different levels, each searching for a new direction, interactions by their expat communities are unavoidable but should proceed in such as way as to be mutually beneficial.

He said the most basic foundations for such interactions are trust and good faith. "If one side tries to coerce the other to give up its own principles without building mutual trust first, the interactions will become meaningless," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT RANKING OFFICIALS VISIT PFP COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: A group of ranking Kuomintang (KMT) officials, led by Secretary-General Chan Chuen-po, paid a courtesy visit Monday to the People First Party (PFP) in an effort to strengthen bilateral ties ahead of the December city and county chief elections.

Both KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen and PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping confirmed following the 40-minute meeting that it was held in a cordial atmosphere and that the two parties reached a tentative agreement to cooperate in the year-end local elections based on the principles of "respecting public opinion and making good on promises through institutionalized mechanisms."
The principles echo the major direction outlined a few days ago by KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou regarding a "pan-blue alliance" cooperation in the coming elections, Cheng said.

Hsieh said that a wide range of issues were touched upon during the meeting, but added that concrete details are yet to be further worked out when PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng has returned from a visit in China. "Every effort will be done to score victories in the elections," he claimed.
Chan paid the visit to the PFP on behalf of KMT Chairman Ma, who officially took over the baton at the chairman office in the KMT headquarters earlier the same day.

Chan relayed Ma's hope for a meeting with PFP Chairman James Soong to PFP Deputy Secretary-General Liao Tsang-song to forge better interactions between the two parties based on the exiting common ground. Soong is currently in the United States and is slated to return to Taiwan this week.
Liao also expressed the hope for a better PFP-KMT relationship, saying that close cooperation will be the centerpiece when it comes to the future path of the two political allies.

The main opposition KMT, the PFP and the New Party formed the "pan-blue alliance" prior to the 2004 presidential race against the "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union. President Chen Shui-bian of the DPP was re-elected in the fierce race.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO INFUSE NT$20 BILLION INTO DIGITAL CONTENT INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that the Executive Yuan Development Fund will appropriate NT$20 billion over the next five years to boost the development of digital content industries or creative and cultural industries.
Hsieh made the remarks while presiding over a coordination meeting aimed at rejuvenating the nation's stagnant movie industry.

It marked the first time that the Executive Yuan has held such a meeting to accentuate the government's resolve to help promote the development of digital content industries, including the production of visual arts products, such as quality movies and television dramas.

Hsieh said the government is considering emulating South Korea's successful movie industry development formula by setting up a special institute to handle fund-raising, talent cultivation and marketing for movie production.

Hopefully, Hsieh said, the Executive Yuan Development Fund will play a "flagship" role in the development of creative and cultural industries which include advertising, craft, cultural heritage, design, music, performing, literary and visaul arts sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO STEP UP SUPERVISION OF COMPANIES WITH FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will step up its supervision of enterprises hiring 100 or more foreign workers to ensure that the workers are not mistreated, a senior CLA official said Monday.

Lai Chin-lin, deputy minister of the CLA, made the pledge after over 100 Thai laborers working on the mass rapid transit railway project in Kaohsiung City rioted Sunday to protest mistreatment they are alleged to have received from the manpower management company.

The riot was triggered when some Thai laborers were prevented from drinking in their dormitory at Kangshan in Kaohsiung County. They set fire to a house, smashed the management office and damaged four cars, causing NT$10 million-worth of losses to the Huapan Manpower Management Co.
Commenting on the riot, Lai said the incident not only affected social order but also damaged Taiwan's global image.
He said the CLA will invite scholars, experts, officials from the Thai representative office in Taiwan, and representatives from human rights groups to form a task force to investigate the case.

Lai also said that in order to prevent similar incidents from happening again, the CLA will set up a special team to make unannounced checks on companies that employ more than 100 foreign laborers to make sure their living conditions, including food, lodging and other care provided by the management, comply with CLA regulations.
According to statistics compiled by the CLA, there are about 700 companies in Taiwan that employ 100 or more foreign workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALAU'S STATE COUNCILLORS VISIT KEELUNG

TEXT.P: A group of representatives of Ngarchelong State of Palau, led by Governor Browny Salvador, called on Keelung Mayor Hsu Tsai-li Monday at the city hall.

Hsu and the 36-member group from the South Pacific island nation of Palau, which comprises state councillors and local tribal leaders, exchanged views on issues concerning city administration, as well as cultural, fishery and folklore issues.
Keelung formally forged sister-ties with Ngarchelong Aug. 17.
At the meeting, Salvador invited Hsu to visit Palau sometime in the future for a trip aimed at making further exchanges.
The group is scheduled to return home Aug. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO TO APPROPRIATE MONEY TO CHARITY GROUPS THIS MONTH AT EARLIEST

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) will be able to dole out the money donated to charities for tsunami relief late this month or early next month, GIO Minister Pasuya Yao said Monday.

Yao was responding to reports that several months after a charity campaign initiated by the GIO to collect money to help sponsor children after last December's tsunami in Southeast Asia, the money still has yet to reach the hands of charities, which have been commissioned by the government for tsunami relief.
Tsai Sung-lin, a national policy adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, criticized the long-stalled program, believing it will affect the government's image, the reports also said.
Yao clarified that all donations will be put into construction and relief work as planned and will be executed via non-governmental organizations, and there is absolutely no delay.

But he also said that the donations collected by the government or certain enterprises will have to undergo a set of budgetary and appropriation procedures which may take some time to channel the money to the NGOs.
This is not a question of government negligence or efficiency, Yao said, adding that in fact rigorous monitoring procedures will ensure that no money donated will be wasted.

Yao also said that Lin Chia-lung, his predecessor who initiated the sponsoring tsunami-children campaign, had thought about this problem. This is why he had an agreement with the NGOs that they waste no time and work first for disaster relief, according to Yao.
There may be some mistake because some NGOs have waited too long, Yao said, adding, however, that the GIO will definitely appropriate the promised money.
Lin, who quit the job earlier this year to run for Taichung mayor, said Monday that the appropriation of the money was stalled because of procedural questions.
He said that audit authorities have asked that the donated money be first put into national coffers before they can be turned over to the civilian groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINIMUM TAX POLICY WILL NOT BE RETROACTIVE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh told European business leaders based in Taiwan that the government's proposed minimum tax policy will not be retroactive and that all contracts being implemented or having been signed will not be subject to the new measure.

During a meeting with delegates from the European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, the premier reassured them that deals that have been approved for tax benefits will not be affected by the proposed tax reform package.
The government proposal has yet to win Legislative Yuan approval to become law, and Hsieh said he expects the approved version will not be any stricter than the Executive Yuan proposal.

According to a draft law by the Ministry of Finance, businesses with an annual income of NT$2 million or more will be subject to a minimum tax rate of 10 percent, while individuals with an annual income of NT$8 million and above will be subject to a minimum tax rate of 20 percent. The local business community has voiced opposition to the proposed tax rates, which they claim are too high.
A government-commissioned citizens forum agreed that corporate income should be levied a minimum 10 percent tax so as not to cause too great an impact on the country's investment environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MRT RIOT WILL NOT AFFECT TAIWAN-THAI LABOR PACT: THAI OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By S.C. Wu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A riot by around 100 Thai laborers working on the mass rapid transit (MRT) railway project in the southern city of Kaohsiung will not affect labor cooperation between Taiwan and Thailand, a Thai labor administrator said Monday.
Supat Gukun, a Thai Labor and Social Welfare Department division chief in charge of overseas employment affairs, made the remarks after the riot was resolved earlier in the day.

Supat said he was pleased to learn that the incident had come to a satisfactory ending as the disgruntled Thai laborers agreed to resume working from Tuesday after their Taiwan manpower management company assented to meet most of their demands for better treatment.
According to Supat, the Thai labor department has been keeping in close contact with the Taiwan authorities since it was informed of the incident that started late Sunday and ended Monday afternoon.
In the process, Supat said the Thai labor department has asked the Thai laborers to remain calm and has promised them assistance in communicating with their Taiwan employer.

Supat said the incident probably resulted from poor labor-management communications or misunderstanding. Noting that each country has different cultures and mores, Supat said Thai workers should abide by Taiwan law and adapt to Taiwan's work culture and ethics.

On the other hand, he said, Taiwanese employers should also gain a better understanding of Thai culture and lifestyles and refrain from imposing unreasonable restrictions on Thai workers everyday life in Taiwan.
Supat said he believes the incident was instigated by only a handful of Thai laborers. "The riot will not affect cooperative ties between Thai and Taiwan labor authorities," he added.
The riot started Sunday evening at the foreign laborers' dormitory in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County, when management staff tried to stop some Thai workers from taking alcohol into the living quarters.

Angry foreign workers, who had been unhappy for a long time about such rigid treatment, set fire to a house and cars, and smashed doors and windows of the manager's office. They even threw stones at firefighters who came to extinguish the blaze.

Officials from the representative office of Thailand in Taiwan and executives of the Huapan Manpower Consultant and Management Co., together with representatives from the local police precinct and the district prosecutor's ofice, held a meeting Monday afternoon at the cultural bureau of Kaohsiung County, trying to work out solutions to the problems.

The manpower management company eventually agreed to 14 of the 16 demands from the foreign laborers, who then agreed to resume working from Tuesday and allowed sanitation workers to enter the dormitory to clean up the debris from the riot.
By 2 p.m., most of the police sent to the riot scene had been withdrawn, leaving only a small force to stand guard.
The management estimated that the riot caused losses of NT$10 million to Huapan Co., whose four two-story dormitories provide shelter to 1,720 foreign laborers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD BEEF UP COOPERATION TO COUNTER CHINA'S RISE

TEXT.P: In the face of China's rise, which is threatening regional security, Taiwan should step up cooperation with other countries in the areas of energy exploration and environmental protection, a government advisory board recommended Monday.
The Mainland Affairs Council's Advisory Committee said China has tried to reduce international suspicion about its "peaceful rise" by adopting a less threatening phrase -- "peaceful development."
According to the committee, the international community realizes the fact of China's rise, but "is not sure of" China's intentions or how to deal with a rising China.

Except for the United States and Japan, which have adopted a relatively ambiguous attitude toward China's growing power, many other countries have opted to enter into closer cooperation with China, according to the MAC committee.
It warned people not to underestimate the impact of China's rise on the international balance of power and on the world's energy needs as well as ecology.
It also claimed that the economic effects of China's rise have been exaggerated.

The committee suggested that the government pool Taiwan's China study resources and devote more manpower to researching the mid- and long-term development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a means to raise Taiwan's international status in the area of China study.
It said Taiwan could underscore, out of its own experience, the undemocratic nature of China's rise and its lack of human rights protection.
Taiwan should seek reconciliation and dialogue with China as a major step to ensure peace across the strait, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MRT CO. URGES GOVERNMENT NOT TO CUT FOREIGN LABORERS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) Monday urged the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) not to reduce the number of foreign laborers working on the city's mass rapid transit railway project by 800 because it would cause a severe impact to the project.
The US$5.6 billion project, under construction since October 2001, is scheduled for completion in October 2007. The railway network will consist of two lines totaling 42.7 km with 37 stations.

Fan Chen-po, president of the KRTC, said he is extremely worried about the government decision, claiming that if the number of foreign laborers on the project is reduced by 800, it would increase the cost of the project by 50 percent.

Fan admitted that there were some problems with labor management that prompted a riot Sunday by Thai workers at their dormitory in Kaohsiung County. He said the KRTC and the Huapan Manpower Consultant and Management Co. -- contracted by the KRTC to provide service to the foreign laborers -- have agreed to improve treatment of the foreign workers.
The KRTC executive pointed out that at present, 70 percent of the labor force working on the project are domestic workers, including 300 aborigines from Taiwan's mountain tribes.

However, Fang added, these domestic workers are reluctant to work overtime and refuse to go 30 meters underground to tackle difficult jobs for the wages on offer, which is why the project needs cheaper foreign laborers.
He urged the CLA to assess the project's need for manpower so that the scheduled construction progress will not be seriously affected.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTION, NOT DISCOURSE, RELEVANT TO TAIWAN'S DEVELOPMENT: DPP

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should take concrete action instead of recounting its historical ties with Taiwan to prove its true love for Taiwan, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus said Monday.

DPP legislative whip William Lai made the remarks a day after new KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said the KMT should embark upon discourse about its close historical ties with Taiwan to dispel allegations that the KMT is an "alien force" that intruded into Taiwan.

The KMT, or Nationalist, government moved its seat to Taiwan in 1949 after it lost control of the Chinese mainland to the Communist Party of China (CPC) in a bloody civil war, and the party ruled Taiwan uninterruptedly until it was defeated by the DPP in the 2000 presidential election.

"The KMT fled to Taiwan with empty hands, but it managed to accumulated a large stash of ill-gotten assets during its half-century rule of Taiwan. This is one of the reasons that the KMT has been seen as an alien force," Lai said.
In his view, Lai said, the KMT should return its ill-gotten assets to the people of Taiwan instead of selling them cheaply to selected pro-KMT business groups.

Shortly after China passed its anti-secession law targeting Taiwan in March this year, then-KMT Chairman Lien Chan traveled to China to forge cooperative ties with the CPC as a counterweight to the DPP administration in Taiwan, Lai said, adding that under Lien's leadership, the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally, the People First Party, have used their slim majority in the Legislative Yuan to boycott the DPP's policy initiatives at every turn.
"This scorched-earth strategy toward the DPP administration is yet another reason that has prompted its critics to label the KMT an alien force," Lai said.
He also dismissed as a political irony Ma's citing of the story of the late Taiwanese painter Liao Chin-ping to embody the KMT's historical bond with Taiwan.
According to Ma, Liao donated funds to KMT founder Sun Yat-sen in 1913 when Sun arrived in Taipei on his way into exile in Japan after the KMT lost a war against then-Chinese President Yuan Shih-kai.

In appreciation for Liao's donation, Sun gave Liao a bottle of whisky which was kept by Liao's son after Liao was killed in 1947 when the KMT-led government cracked down ruthlessly on a disturbance in Taiwan known as the 228 Incident.
Liao's son gave the liquor to Ma at a ceremony marking the 228 incident this year in Taipei, when he also disclosed the friendship between his late father and Sun.
"Liao's tragic death serves as a reminder that the KMT is an alien force to Taiwan. Liao once lent support to Sun's revolution but died nevertheless as a result of the KMT's persecution," Lai said.
To demonstrate its love for Taiwan, Lai said the KMT need not bother to elaborate its historical bonds with Taiwan as Ma suggested.
"Actions speak louder than discourse. What the KMT needs to do is to take concrete action to boost Taiwan's development and consolidate its survival," Lai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OUTLINES NEW STRATEGIES FOR AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Taiwan should promote the development of "refined" agriculture to ensure the sustainable development of its agricultural sector.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with the winners of the 29th Top 10 Agriculturists Awards at the Presidential Office.
Noting that Taiwan's agricultural sector faces many challenges, Chen said Taiwan farmers must adopt new strategies to survive the ever more intense foreign competition.
"We should development refined agriculture which calls for less quantity but higher variety. By so doing, our farm produce will be able to fetch better prices," Chen said.

Iraqi leaders moved to the brink of agreement on a new constitution on Sunday, solving several contentious issues but still struggling with the potentially explosive questions of Shiite autonomy and the role of Islam in family disputes and the judiciary. The Iraqis said they were hoping to finish the constitution by the end of the day on Monday, a deadline that they have already extended once. They scheduled a meeting of the National Assem
Wall Street Journal: Side Effects, Merck Loss Jolts Drug Giant, Industry
Facing thousands of lawsuits over Vioxx, Merck had built its argument that its painkiller Vioxx couldn't have caused the heart-related death of 59-year-old triathlete Robert Ernst.In the first suit to go to trial, a majority of the jury had in effect dispensed with the science and started a series of 10-2 votes against Merck that would end in a US$253 million verdict against the drug maker. One crucial document was an email from February 1997 -- two years before Merck started selling Vioxx -- in which a top company scientist, Alise Reicin, wrote that "the possibility of increased CV [cardiovascular] events is of great concern." Merck maintained that it didn't know of Vioxx's potential for heart risk until just before it pulled the drug from the market in September 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 23, or the 19th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1305: Sir William Wallace, Scottish patriot who demanded independence for his country, is hung, drawn and quartered in London.
1754: Louis XVI, king of France at the time of the outbreak of the French Revolution, is born.
1818: The first steamship service opens on the Great Lakes in North America.
1821: Mexico gains its independence.
1912: Gene Kelly, American dancer, choreographer, singer, actor and director, is born. He starred in Hollywood musicals, including "Anchors Aweigh," "Singin' in the Rain" and his "Invitation to Dance."
1914: Japan declares war on Germany.
1926: Screen actor Rudoph Valentino, the idol of millions, dies of peritonitis in New York's Polyclinic Hospital. He was 31. The Italian-born American actor was known for his romantic leading roles in silent films such as "The Sheik" and "Blood and Sand."
1927: In one of the most controversial cases in American legal history, Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti are sent to the electric chair. In July 1921, a jury found the two Italian political anarchists and immigrants guilty of the murder of a factory paymaster and a guard during a robbery in South Braintree, Massachusetts.
1928: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung and Chu Teh, and their troops flee to Chingkangshan in Kiangsi Province after being outflanked and besieged by government forces from both the provinces of Hunan and Kiangsi.
1933: Gandhi is released from Poona jail after his hunger strike almost kills him.
1939: The USSR and Germany sign the Molotov-Ribbentropp Non-Aggression Pact, a terrible shock to the Western European leaders.
1940: German bombers begin night raids on London.
1945: Soviet troops occupy Manchuria.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek sends a third invitation to Mao Tse-tung after inviting him Aug. 14 to come to Chungking for a conference and the again Aug. 20.
1958: The Battle of the Taiwan Strait begins with Communist China firing 57,000 rounds in 2 hours at the islands of Kinmen. Many defenders are killed, including Gen. Chi Sing-wen, deputy commander of the Kinmen Garrison Command.
1963: Ambassador to the United States Tsiang Ting-fu signs the nuclear test ban treaty on behalf of the Republic of China.
1981: One hundred and ten people die in the crash of a Far Eastern Air Transport plane. The incident represents Taiwan's worst air disaster.
1990: East and West Germany choose October 3 as the date for reunification.
1990: Amenia declares its independence from Moscow.
1992: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with South Korea.
1998: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks his government and names former premier Viktor Chernomyrdin as acting prime minister.
1999: ROC Premier Vincent Siew is awarded an honorary doctorate in public service by Ohio State University.
2000: Eight mountaineers from Taiwan successfully climb to the 3,776-meter peak of Mount Fuji, thus writing a new page in climbing history.
2001: The 12th Taipei Chinese Food Fair, featuring various kinds of Chinese noodles and delicacies, opens with lively performances at the Taipei World Trade Center.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The Emperor Shun might perhaps be considered in the highest sense of the word a pious man. In moral qualities, he was a saint. In dignity of office, he was the ruler of the empire. In wealth, all that the wide world contained belonged to him."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES TO DISCUSS ARMS PROCUREMENT WITH KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he looks forward to rational and pragmatic discussion with new opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou on the long-stalled arms procurement package and China's ever mounting military threat.

Chen made the appeal while presiding over a ceremony marking the 47th anniversary of the "Aug. 23 Battle" on the outlying island of Kinmen which lies closer to China's southeastern province of Fujian than to Taiwan proper.

Noting that his administration's plan to procure three advanced weaponry systems -- eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft -- from the United States has long been stuck in the Legislative Yuan due to opposition parties' "irrational boycott, " Chen said he earnestly hopes that Ma can demonstrate a different leadership style from his predecessor's.

"Hopefully, Ma will be willing to engage in candid exchanges of opinions and rational cooperation with the government based on the principles of safeguarding national interests and the well-being of the people," Chen said.

Over the past five years, the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally -- the People First Party -- have used their slim majority in the legislature to boycott the Chen administration's policy initiatives at almost every turn.

Now that the KMT has changed its leadership, Chen said, he is hopeful that the Ma-led KMT will demonstrate sincerity and efficiency in dealing with national security and livelihood-related bills and budgetary appropriations.
