DOC.HEADLINE: THAI WORKERS' RIOT A 'OUTRAGEOUS, ISOLATED CASE': CLA OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) official said Tuesday that Taiwan has 13 years of experience in managing foreign workers and that Sunday's riot in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County by Thai workers was an "outrageous isolated case."
Kuo Fang-yu, director general of the CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration, blamed the manpower management company that brought in the Thai workers for causing the problem.

He said Huapan Administration Consultant Co. Ltd. is not among the companies that have been screened by the CLA. He said he was surprised to learn that the Kaohisung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) would delegate responsibility to such a company to hire and manage the labor force needed for building the transit system.
"There has never been any problem when a CLA-approved management company has brought in foreign laborers," Kuo said.

Huapan's poor management of the foreign workers has become a topic in Taiwan, with media digging into more and more stories of workers being maltreated and labor groups criticizing the company's practices.

The International Labor Federation has asked the government to allow foreign workers to form their own unions to fight for members' legal rights, while the Taiwan Labor Front has demanded that the CLA investigate alleged illegal profits made by Huapan and other related groups.

Kuo said that with 13 years of experience, the government has a full set of measures and regulations governing the import, employment, and living conditions of foreign workers. If any foreign laborers feel that they are being treated unfairly, there are several government agency numbers that they can call to file a complaint, he added.
In fact, he said, many businesses have done such a good job in their management of imported workers that many of these workers don't even want to leave when their contracts expire.
Against such a backdrop, Kuo said, he was quite surprised to learn that Huapan may have received kickbacks -- one of the complaints leading to Sunday's riot.
The CLA has pledged to launch an investigation into the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIB PROBING CROSS-BORDER BOGUS PASSPORT SALES RING

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Tuesday that it has been investigating a cross-border "snake-head" ring that purchases national identification cards from aboriginal Taiwan citizens and alters them to apply for ROC passports for sale to mainland Chinese citizens for entrance into Canada or the United States.

Officials from the CIB Department of International Affairs said they suspect that the ring is working in collusion with a travel agency to illegally apply for ROC passports using the altered ID cards obtained from aboriginal citizens residing in Hualien or Taitung in eastern Taiwan.
The ring has been running versatile operations, offering various "products" depending on the amount paid, CIB investigators said.

The investigators have learned that ring members first purchase ID cards from the aboriginal citizens at unknown prices. The ring members then digitally alter the photo on the ID card before applying for an ROC passport from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The illegally obtained passports are then sent to Hong Kong or Thailand where they are sold to mainland Chinese citizens.

If the aboriginal passport holder goes to the American Institute in Taiwan for an interview and successfully obtains a U.S. visa, he will be awarded NT$50,000 (US$1,562.5) by the ring. If such passport carries a forged photo of the end user, it can be sold for NT$150,000, according to the investigators.

Ring members can fetch between NT$600,000 and NT$900,000 for each mainland Chinese citizen they successfully help enter the United States, Canada, Japan or an E.U. country, according to the investigators.
The CIB authorities said they believe that more than 1,000 aboriginal people from eastern Taiwan have sold their ID cards or passports to the ring.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TAKING PRECAUTIONARY MEASURES TO DEAL WITH BOGUS PASSPORT RINGS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) attaches great importance to cracking down on cross-strait criminal rings using the national identification cards of aboriginal people in eastern Taiwan for illegal purposes, a MOFA spokesman said Tuesday.

Michel Lu said the ministry is taking several precautionary measures to deal with the problem, including rigorous verification of passport holders, actions to combat forged or counterfeit passport rings, an upgrading of the anti-forgery features of passports, as well as stepped-up communications with the United States and exchange of information.

He made the remarks amid media reports that cross-border smuggling rings have been obtaining IDs from aboriginal people in Hualien and Taitung and altering them to apply for ROC passports for sale to Chinese citizens wanting to illegally enter the United States or Canada.

Lu said the ministry has heeded the reports, which cited investigation agents as saying that more than 1,000 aboriginal people in Hualien and Taitung might have been involved in selling their IDs for NT$50,000 each to the scam rings over the years.
However, Lu said that "the number of aboriginal people involved in the scam is not as high as the news reports have said."
Lu said that the ministry understands that criminal rings have obtained the IDs of more than 20 aboriginal people in Hualian and Taitung.

He said that the ministry has contacted the Taipei Office of the American in Taiwan (AIT), the de facto American embassy in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, and that the AIT is now turning the case over to investigative authorities in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT ISSUE SHOULD BE DEALT WITH IN LEGISLATURE: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: The best forum for discussions on the government-proposed arms procurement package is the Legislative Yuan, new opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-yeou said Tuesday.

In response to President Chen Shui-bian's proposal earlier in the day for a"rational and pragmatic" discussion between himself and Ma on the long-stalled arms purchase bill, Ma said that any of his views on the issue will only be passed through the legislative channel.
Asked about whether there is no need for him and the president to meet for talks on the arms procurement package, Ma replied: "yes."

Ma said the KMT, which ruled the country for decades before losing power in the 2000 presidential election, does not oppose the plan for no reasons. He said the party will support the project if details like the amount of money, the number of items, and the manner of financing the plan are all worked out.
The KMT will commission its legislative caucus to engage in talks with other political parties including the ruling one, Ma noted.

Ma added, that "it's not absolutely impossible" to arrange a "Bian-Ma" meeting to discuss other issues. Asked what issues they would talk about in such a meeting, Ma answered that "we may hold some discussions on that." Bian is President Chen's nickname.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PHILATELIST WINS TOP AWARD AT STAMP EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: Taiwanese philatelist Fortune Wang won the top award at the Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition and took home two "Large Gold" medals for his extraordinary stamp collections.

Wang, a veteran stamp collector representing the Chinese Taipei team in the competitions at the current stamp exhibition being held at the Taipei World Trade Center, garnered the top honor with two collections, entitled "Shanghai Local Post" and "Tibet."

The Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition, which opened Aug. 19, is scheduled to wrap up Wednesday. A total of 1,556 frames of stamps from 22 countries are being featured at the exhibition, whose theme is "Tourism and Stamps."
Among the 1,556 frames, 1,415 are in the competitive class, while 141 are in the non-competitive class, according to Chunghwa Post Co., key sponsor of the event.

Exhibition sponsors have offered awards and prizes in 12 categories for the competitive class, including the Federation of Inter-Asian Philately (FIAP) Championship Class, Traditional Philately, Thematic Philately -Technology, Youth Philately, Maximaphily, Postal History, Postal Stationery, Aerophilately, Astrophilately, Thematic, Literature and Experimental Class.

Meanwhile, autographed personalized greeting stamp sets by supermodel Lin Chi-ling, the spokeswoman of the Taipei 2005 and 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition, have proved to be the hottest item during the six-day event.

Auction proceeds of the Lin Chi-ling personalized greeting stamp sets, totaling NT$1.2 million (US$37,500), were donated by Chunghwa Post to the Yunlin and Chiayi county governments to help impoverished children in the two counties.

The Formosan black bear, which is indigenous to Taiwan, has been chosen as the mascot of the event. The logo of the exhibition is Taipei 101 -- the world's tallest skyscraper, located near the exhibition venue -- which the sponsor hopes will demonstrate Taiwan's new vibrancy.

James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office; Finance Minister Lin Chuan; and Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Ling-san have visited the exhibition to show their support. Huang and Lin, both of whom used to be avid stamp collectors, said they have special feelings about the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILLING TO DISCUSS FUNDING CHANGE FOR U.S. ARMS PURCHASE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense's plan to include part of the purchase of U.S. arms in its regular budget has met with approval by the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) legislative caucus, with a KMT legislator saying Tuesday that his party is now willing to look at the plan and discuss it within the party's legislative caucus.

Tseng Yung-chuan, also the executive director of the party's Policy Committee, made the remarks one day after Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng revealed that one of the three items in the arms package will be listed under the defense ministry's regular budget.

Tseng said that the KMT has always wanted an arms procurement package that would serve the purpose of defending the nation and one that was not foisted upon Taiwan by the U.S. Also, the KMT does not want to see the bill for the weaponry being passed to future generations to have to pay, he said, adding that in the past, the party was opposed to the package because the defense ministry listed the procurement under a special budget.

The defense ministry's arms procurement package calls for the purchase of eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States at a cost of NT$480 billion (US$15 billion).

The bill has been held up for two consecutive legislature sessions because of opposition by the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and its ally, the People First Party (PFP), which has said that the cost of the weaponry is too high and that any payments ought not come from a special budget.

However, a lawmaker of the PFP said Tuesday that some KMT and PFP legislators have not studied the arms procurement package diligently and have "fallen into the trap" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

PFP Legislator Lin Yu-fang made the remarks following media reports that said Minister of National Defense Lee Jye briefed the DPP legislative caucus the previous day, saying that the budget for the six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries will be funded out of the regular budget.
Lin said that the question surrounding the arms procurement project is not whether it will be paid for by a special or regular budget. They are both funded by taxpayers' money, he said.

What matters is whether it is really necessary to buy outdated military hardware at an inflated price that may or may not meet the needs of the nation to defend itself, Lin said. Moreover, at issue is the question of whether the U.S. will offer reciprocal purchase opportunities for industrial equipment from Taiwan and if buying the weaponry will touch off an arms race across the Strait, negatively impacting cross-strait relations, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP LAWMAKER APOLOGIZES TO PFP CHAIRMAN'S SECRETARY

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chang Ching-fang openly apologized Tuesday to Yang Yun-tai, secretary of People First Party Chairman James Soong, for having made false allegations in November 2003 about the relationship between the two.

Several months before the 2004 presidential election, in which Soong was the running mate of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, Chang alleged that Yang was Soong's mistress. Chang based his allegation on a statement by former Taiwan Provincial Assembly member Wang Chao-chuan.

Yang went to court to demand justice, seeking NT$10 million in compensation for damage to her reputation. The court ruled that Chang must pay NT$800,000 in damages and publish an apology to Yang in three major newspapers -- the China Times, the United Daily News and the Liberty Times.

In the printed apology, Chang said he was issuing the apology for making an "untrue statement" in 2003 concerning Ms. Yang Yun-tai, causing damage to her reputation. He also said that he hopes the public advertisement would clear her name. He did not apologize to Soong.
When faced with media questions, Chang would not comment on why he had made such a groundless statement, responding simply by saying that "it's over."

DOC.HEADLINE: DESIGNER OF SOUVENIR SHEET 'TAIWAN CUISINE' A GOURMET HERSELF

TEXT.P: The designer of the No. 7 souvenir sheet -- Taiwan Cuisine, for the Taipei 2005 - 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition currently being held at the Taipei World Trade Center, is a gourmet herself.
Lin Si-ying, 25, the youngest among all eight designers of the exhibition's eight souvenir sheets, said that designing stamps depicting delicious foods has really been fun.

The souvenir sheet that Lin designed features an array of diverse and representative dishes from Taiwan, including traditional rice cakes and the banquet dish -- "Buddha Jumping over the Wall" -- some Chinese tradition tableware and a bamboo steamer.
Lin said it was a challenge for her trying to condense the rich and immense Chinese and Taiwan cuisine culture into a little square the size of a stamp.
Apparently, Lin has done a good job since people have said that looking at the stamp, they can almost smell the food.

To publicize and celebrate the occasion, Chunghwa Post issued a series of eight separate souvenir sheets. The first and second -- No. 1 Taiwan Landscape and No. 2 Taiwan Culture -- were released on Aug. 27 and April 19, respectively. The third through eighth -- No. 3 Taiwan Conservation, No. 4 Taiwan Technology, No. 5 Taiwan Flowers and Fruits, No. 6 Taiwan Festivals, No. 7 Taiwan Cuisine and No. 8 Marine Taiwan -- have been released one each day during the course of the exhibition, which wraps up Aug. 24.

To commemorate the event, Chunghwa Post has also released a set of four "Taipei 2005-18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition Commemorative Postage Labels, " each of which features a different section of the ancient painting "Taisiantu" from the National Palace Museum collection.
Chunghwa Post is also offering 10,000 gifts by prize draw, in addition to offering exhibition visitors the opportunity to have their own personalized stamps and postcards made digitally.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Israeli pullout from West Bank settlements started.
The forced evacuation of four Israeli settlements in northern West Bank started Monday under a strong resistance from some 2,000 extremists in Homesh and Sanur. Some 10,000 troops, including riot police, have been mobilized to clear out the settlements.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 11.47 points to close at 6,195.18.
The bourse opened at 6,211.15 and fluctuated between 6,234.31 and 6,195.18 during trading. A total of 2.65 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$66.85 billion (US$2.08 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.5 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent.

The other five major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares and construction issues both moving down the most at 0.4 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent and plastics and chemicals shares and paper and pulp issues both at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 556 to 315, with 165 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INSECURE CHINA POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS: U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE RICE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The United States wants to see a "strong and confident China" because a weak and insecure China is potentially much more dangerous, according to U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice.

During an interview with The New York Times on Aug. 17, Rice said the U.S. understands that China is going to be influential in international politics. It also understands it cannot isolate China, she said.

Economically, she said the U.S. expects China's economy to be rules based, with a currency that "makes sense in terms of a flexible market-based exchange rate, " as well as an enforcer of intellectual property rights.
On the issues of human rights and religious freedom, Rice said the U.S. was "capable of having reasonable discussions with the Chinese" and will to continue to press them on those issues.
Turning to China's military power, Rice said it looks oversized to many, "including to me." She noted that the Chinese military modernization looks oversized for its regional interests.

But she said she was not suggesting China is becoming an adversary, but that it is something that has to be watched and that the United States is going to continue to improve its own military capabilities so that the balance in the Asia-Pacific region is maintained.

She acknowledged that there are sometimes "spikes in the temperature" caused by underlying issues in the U.S.-China relationship. But on balance, she said it is a good relationship, with the U.S. benefiting in the war on terrorism and in nuclear proliferation issues.
For the U.S., China's Anti-Secession Law regarding Taiwan has "caused problems for everybody" and its human rights record is "not defensible on many grounds," she pointed out.
Rice said she does not see the State Department's role as somehow minimizing the problems in the complex relationship. "I see the relationship as having all of these sides."

DOC.HEADLINE: 30,000 COMMEMORATIVE FOLIOS PUT ON SALE ON LAST DAY OF STAMP SHOW

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Post Co., the key sponsor of the 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition, will sell a commemorative folio Wednesday when the six-day event comes to a close.

Chunghwa Post officials said that the commemorative folio will contain eight souvenir sheets especially prepared for the international stamp exhibition. The NT$500 (US$15.62) folio will have a limited sale of only 30,000.

To publicize and celebrate the international stamp exhibition, Chunghwa Post is issuing a series of eight separate souvenir sheets. The first and second -- Taiwan Landscape and Taiwan Culture -- were released Aug. 27, 2004 and April 19, 2005, respectively.

The third to the eighth -- Taiwan Conservation, Taiwan Technology, Taiwan Flowers and Fruits, Taiwan Festivals, Taiwan Cuisine and Taiwan Ocean Life -- were released during each day of the exhibition. Each sheet consists of one NT$5 stamp and one NT$25 stamp.
In addition to the issuing of one souvenir sheet each day, Chunghwa Post also arranged the designers of souvenir sheets No. 3 to No. 8 to meet the stamp collectors at autograph sessions.
Chunghwa Post officials said that they hope stamp collectors from home and overseas can savor the rich and diverse features of Taiwan from different angles.

They urged the visitors to the stamp exhibition on the last day to take the opportunity to buy the commemorative folio, noting that the first and second souvenir sheets -- Taiwan Landscape and Taiwan Culture -- are sold out and not available on the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: STAMP DESIGNER WANTS TO BRING UNEXPECTED JOY TO PHILATELISTS

TEXT.P: Ke Hung-tu, designer of the last souvenir sheet issued especially for 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition, said Wednesday that he hopes his creation can bring unexpected joy to philatelists.
Ke made the remarks during an autograph session to promote the souvenir sheet he designed -- Taiwan Ocean Life.

Unlike other stamp designers in the past autograph sessions, several of which won the honor with their debut creations, Ke is actually a seasoned stamp designer with 30 sets of stamps now under his belt.

Ke said that he has broken with tradition and has used an oval-shaped stamp to show one part of the ocean off Green Island, and added the fiery red horny corals and yellow and blue striped royal empress angelfish, which are often found in the area to display the freedom and flamboyancy of the waters in the tropics.
He said that when he designed the stamp he mainly had in mind Taiwan's ocean scenery and geological landscapes and wanted to display them in various shades of blue.
The contents of the stamp mainly comes from a photo by a member of Academia Sinica, the highest research institute in Taiwan, as well as the creativity of other pictures.

Spectators will first look at one corner of Green Island, and then they will immediately turn to the colorful world of the ocean floor, where they can see the frolicking fishes and beautiful coral reefs.

Ke stressed the importance of "story" in a tiny stamp, hoping to transport to those who look at the stamp the rich and interesting material they represent. This and a clear theme as well as a vivacious picture have all been credited with his success over the past years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ID CARD RENEWAL TO BE POSTPONED UNTIL AFTER YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan said Tuesday that identification (ID) card renewal will be postponed until after the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections.
As to the exact date for the start of ID card renewal, Su said it has yet to be decided.

Quoting the results of an opinion survey by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), Su said 14 cities and counties have suggested that ID card renewal be started Jan. 1, 2006, while the remaining cities and counties just recommended that the renewal be kicked off after Dec. 20.
Su said the interior ministry will make a final decision after a further evaluation of various conditions.
The minister made the remarks after presiding over a citation ceremony for 163 outstanding grassroots administrators, agencies and volunteers.

The ministry was originally scheduled to begin issuing new forgery-proof ID cards July 1. But on May 30, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) filed for a Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) ruling on the constitutionality of the existing household registration law that requires local people to be fingerprinted while picking up ID cards. The DPP application was a response to mounting concerns about possible human rights violations.

In view of the limited time available, the CGJ imposed a moratorium June 10 on the fingerprinting provision until it metes out its ruling. The Council of Grand Justices also began a two-day hearing on the request Wednesday. A ruling is expected at the end of September.

Su said the interior ministry will fully respect the CGJ's ruling. If the council rules that fingerprinting is in violation of the constitutional spirit or provision, he said the MOI will not require local citizens to be fingerprinted when they pick up their new ID cards.

Nevertheless, Su said when the CGJ hands down its ruling, local population offices will be busy with preparations for the Dec. 3 "three-in-one" elections for city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors and township chiefs.
At city and county government requests, Su said, the interior ministry has agreed to wait until after the elections to start new ID cards distribution.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATORS ON A VISIT TO CANADA
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By George Wu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan legislative delegation arrived in Ottawa Monday for a visit to strengthen exchanges between the two countries.

Cheng Kuo-chung, chairman of Taiwan-Canada Parliamentary Friendship Group in the ROC legislature, who led the delegation, noted that their visit was conducted at the invitation of the Canada-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group and is aimed at boosting bilateral parliamentary exchanges.

Cheng said friendships and exchanges between the people of Taiwan and Canada have been increasing substantially during the last few years, and during their stay in Canada, the ROC lawmakers will also thank Canadian congressman Jim Abbot, a member of the opposition Conservative Party, for his putting forward the Taiwan Affairs Act for the approval in the Canadian Parliament.
The ROC lawmakers will also visit Canada's Ministry of Social Development to better understand this country's policies in dealing with social welfare and social development programs.
ROC Legislator Chiu Chuang-chin hailed the efforts of Chen Tong-pi, representative of Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada, in strengthening Taiwan-Canadian ties over the years.
Legislator-at-large Chen Chong-hsin, expressed the hope that Taiwan and Canada will have more exchanges in the area of environmental protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT IN KAOHSIUNG EXPORT PROCESSING ZONE BOOMING

TEXT.P: Investment in the Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone in southern Taiwan has been prosperous in July, with new investments or increase of capital worth NT$2.3 billion (US$71.65 million), the highest for a single month since January.

An official of the Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone Administration noted that the processing zone is still attractive to investors, despite the slower-than-expected global economic perspective, rising oil prices and several typhoons that hit the island recently.
The investments included several cases of increase of capital and new investment projects mainly focused on the manufacturing of electronic, semiconductor and liquid crystal display (LED) components.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG RAPID TRANSIT'S FOREIGN LABOR IMPORT QUOTA FROZEN

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has temporarily frozen the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp.'s (KRTC) use of its approved 900-person quota in terms of foreign worker import, Liu Ko-hsiang, an assistant to the KRTC president, said Tuesday.

The authorities promised that the company will not be allowed to import any additional foreign laborers before the demands from the Thai laborers involved in a Sunday riot for better treatment are met, Liu explained.

Around 100 Thai laborers working on the metro line project in the southern city of Kaohsiung set fire to a house and cars, and smashed doors and windows of an office of the Huapan Manpower Administration Consultant Co. Ltd. in protest against the company's unfair treatment.
The protest ended after Huapan accepted 14 of 16 demands from the angry foreign workers.

The KRTC has introduced more than 1,700 foreign laborers after it applied to import over 2,600 workers from overseas countries for its construction projects. After the riot, the CLA decided to cut half of the company's current foreign laborer quota, about 800 people, and at the same time freeze its import of other 900 that it has not yet introduced into Taiwan because of poor management.
The Thais had agreed to resume working from Tuesday, but they changed minds early Tuesday on their way for work after hearing a rumor which said around 800 Thai workers would be sent back home.
They eventually started working later in the day after both the CLA and the KRTC guaranteed no more imports of foreign laborers before their living situation is improved.

Kuo Fong-yu, director-general of the CLA Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training, said that the council will protect the rights of all Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung metro lines, except those who committed arson during the riot, who will be repatriated following a judicial procedure.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET'S TAX REFORM PACKAGE PRO-BUSINESS: 'PAN-PURPLE ALLIANCE'

TEXT.P: The Alliance of Fairness and Justice on Tuesday criticized the government for drafting a tax law that will allow rich business people to enjoy greater tax exemptions and avoid paying tax on their overseas assets.
Alliance president Chien Hsi-chieh said the draft law being discussed at the Cabinet was a sham tax reform proposal that will benefit only businesses, to the disappointment of the public.

He focused his criticism on the shortcomings of provisions governing the minimum tax, including the proposed phase-in measures and the "faith and protection" principle that allows foreign investors to keep enjoying tax benefits after the new law comes into force.

His group, also known as "pan-purple alliance, " in distinction from the political "pan-green" camp and the "pan-blue alliance," said the draft law makes it clear that it will not be able to expand the nation's tax base as it will encourage rich people to invest abroad while they continue to enjoy tax privileges at home.

The alliance also claimed that the proposed reform package fails to reinstate capital gains tax on the stock market, a signal that it would be difficult for the government to achieve its professed goals of reform.

Furthermore, it pointed out that a government plan to lower the gift and heritage tax rates was a clear indication of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government's favor of the rich as well as of its lack of interest in narrowing the gap between the rich and the poor.

Chien claimed that the conclusion of this "tax reform show" is now clear -- that big businesses will be the big winners while people's hopes for increased social rights and greater fairness and justice will have been dashed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 30 points to close at 6,185, with 14,278 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved down 17 points to end at 6,188, with 162 contracts traded, while December futures lost 27 points to finish at 6,180, with three contracts traded. March futures moved down 32 points to close at 6,175, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,215 for September, 6,205 for October, 6,207 for December, 6,207 for March and 6,194 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

September TE futures moved down 1.7 points to close at 255.9, with 2,238 contracts traded, while October TE futures lost 1.4 points to finish at 256.05, with six contract transactions. March TE futures moved down 0.7 points to end at 256.9, with seven contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and June.

September TF futures lost 2.8 points to finish at 952.8, with 813 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 3.8 points to end at 950.8, with 19 contracts traded. December TF futures moved down 2.2 points to close at 953, with one contract transaction, while June TF futures lost 0.8 points to finish at 952.6, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.011 to close at NT$32.129.
A total of US$665 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.140 and fluctuated between NT$32.085 and NT$32.150.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Il-96 Jets Barred From Flying
Aeroflot scrambled to adjust its flight schedule on Monday after the Transportation Ministry indefinitely grounded the country's Ilyushin 96-300 planes for safety reasons.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: No Proof Found of Iran Arms Program; Uranium Traced to Pakistani Equipment.
Traces of bomb-grade uranium found two years ago in Iran came from contaminated Pakistani equipment and are not evidence of a clandestine nuclear weapons program, a group of U.S. government experts and other international scientists has determined.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE TRADE MISSION VISITS FENGYUAN CITY

TEXT.P: A trade mission from Kanazawa, Japan, is currently on a goodwill visit in Taiwan, local officials said Tuesday.
The mission visited the central city of Fengyuan Monday.
Kanazawa and Fengyuan cities established close ties four years ago when Kanazawa first sent a fact-finding group to Fengyuan.
This time, the mission was led by Susumu Adachi, a former speaker of the Kanazawa City Council. He was accompanied by several business and industry representatives.

Adachi and Fengyuan Mayor Chang I-cheng inked a memorandum of understanding creating a Taiwan-Japan Friendship Association. Both sides agreed to promote friendship, peace and prosperity between Taiwan and Japan.

Also present were Chang Jung-i, representing the tourism industry, Yu Hsi-chuan and Li Sheng-hua, representing heavy industry, and Chen Ching-tan, the president of the Provincial Fengyuan Hospital, representing the medical Industry.
They all said that the new association would provide a good platform for both sides to enhance exchanges via non-governmental organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY GOVERNMENT DEMANDS PUNISHMENT OF BROKER

TEXT.P: To prevent a repeat of the riot staged by Thai workers late Sunday in Kaohsiung, a city government official demanded Tuesday that the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) "severely handle" the labor brokerage firm responsible for personnel management if it is to blame for the incident.
Lee Cheng-pin, head of the Kaohsiung Mass Transit Bureau, raised the demand following a municipal meeting. But he fell short of explaining what moves that the city government might take to that end.

Noting that he has clearly requested the KRTC to duly deal with the matter, Lee stressed that the city government does not want to see any similar reoccurrences and that the KRTC must effectively improve its management and step up its inspection after several major public security incidents occurred in construction sites in the city's mass rapid transit system.

Although the overnight riot by more than 100 Thai workers building the Kaohsiung mass transit system came to an end Monday after a settlement on better pay terms and living conditions was reached between the Thai workers and the brokerage company, Lee said that the KRTC must find out the root cause and punish the brokerage firm if necessary.

In the wake of the first foreign worker riot in Taiwan, the Taiwan International Workers' Association (TIWA) issued a statement Sunday night, urging the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to allow foreign workers to form their own unions to protect their rights and interests.

TIWA Secretary-General Ku Yu-ling pointed out that nearly 300,000 migrant workers in Taiwan lack legal protection, as the Labor Union Law clearly stipulates that only persons with Republic of China nationality are permitted to act as labor union officials.

The 16 requests raised by the Thai laborers on work and living condition improvements, including due and full overtime pay and better food are basic labor and human rights, Ku said, adding that the Thai worker protests over such issues has brought an inadequate government labor policy to public attention. The government must provide foreign workers with basic rights, she insisted.

Meanwhile, a draft amendment to the Labor Union Law, pending legislative approval at present, will scrap the ROC nationality requirement, a change that CLA officials said will help facilitate foreign workers put forward their complaints and protect their rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD APPROVES EXPANSION PLAN FOR TAICHUNG AIRPORT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) approved an expansion plan Monday for the Chingchuankang Airport in Taichung county amid high hopes of making the airport a point to ply international flights from central Taiwan.

The expansion, valued at NT$1.55 billion (US$48.5 million) , is slated for completion by late 2007 and should begin operations in May 2008, CEPD officials said, adding that the expansion will help the airport upgrade its capabilities for international flights to meet strong demand from residents in the central region.
The number of residents in central Taiwan is similar to that in southern Taiwan, while average per-household income in the central region exceeds the average in the south, CEPD officials noted.

A Hong Kong-based aviation company has applied with the Civil Aeronautics Administration to operate charter flights between Taichung and Hong Kong, helping to boost the prospects for the airport to be transformed into an international air traffic center in central Taiwan, the officials said.

At present, the airport's existing facilities are only available for domestic routes and some charter flights to Japan, South Korea, Bali and Phuket. The former military base-turned airport began civil aviation services in March 2004.
Taiwan already has two international airport -- Chiang Kai-shek International Airport near northern Taipei and Kaohsiung International Airport in the south.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LARGEST IMPORTER OF THAI WORKERS IN THE WORLD: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By S. C. Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the largest importer of Thai workers in the world, with about 94,000 laborers from Thailand working in Taiwan, according to a report issued Tuesday by the International Immigrants Foundation.

As of the end of last year, a total of 148,600 Thai workers were employed overseas, with the largest number of 94,000 -- 84,000 men and 12,000 women -- staying in Taiwan, well ahead of the 60,000-odd Thai workers in Japan, the report said.

Thai laborers are also the largest migrant worker group in Taiwan, where there are nearly 300,000 foreign workers. Due to their poor English abilities compared to those from the Philippines and Indonesia, most of the Thai workers are in the construction sector in Taiwan.

In addition to higher pay offered by Taiwan businesses, Thai workers are attracted to Taiwan by its warm climate, close distance from home and Buddhist religion, officials of the Thai Ministry of Labor Affairs said, adding that Thai construction workers can earn an average monthly salary of US$460 in Taiwan, twice or thrice the level in Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE STEP UP SEARCH FOR UNACCOUNTABLE ILLEGAL CHINESE IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: An illegal Chinese immigrant has been caught serving as a caregiver at major hospitals in Taipei, police authorities said Tuesday.

The Chinese man told police that he smuggled himself into Taiwan a year ago. He first took odd jobs around Taiwan. In April this year, he began working as a caregiver at major Taipei hospitals, including Veterans General Hospital and Yangming Hospital, on a wage of NT$1,900 per day. He has to pay a 10 percent commission to his manpower broker.
According to police, the 30-something man has been caring for several seriously ill patients for three months through the arrangement of a local manpower agency.

Taipei police authorities informed a special task force under the National Police Administration (NPA) of the case. The "homeland security" task force was founded by the NPA earlier this year to track down unaccountable illegal Chinese immigrants.
The task force checked a temporary caregivers list provided by a health care cooperative founded with the assistance of the Cabinet-level Veterans Affairs Commission.
Police authorities said they discovered that the list included 10 illegal male Chinese immigrants and that all of them are around 30 years of age.
Implying that those illegal Chinese immigrants might be intelliegence agents, NPA officials said they have stepped up search for behind-the-scenes "snake-head" human smuggling rings.

President Chen Shui-bian ordered military, intelligence and police agencies to intensify tracking down on unaccountable illegal Chinese immigrants earlier this year after several outrageous criminal cases involving illegal Chinese immigrants were reported.
Since the establishment of the "homeland security" task force, the NPA has directed city and county police offices to step up searches.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN CAUGHT SMUGGLING HEROIN

TEXT.P: A man has been caught trying to smuggle heroin into the country hidden under his clothes, Kaohsiung customs officials said Tuesday.

The man, surnamed Kang, was caught at Kaohsiung Airport upon arrival on a flight from Macau with 1,258 grams of heroin divided into 13 small packages hidden under his clothes. Customs officials had their suspicions aroused because of the man's unusual gait.

Kaohsiung investigators said that heroin has been in short supply recently and its price has soared. Drug rings have recently taken to using air passenger mules to bring in drugs and the authorities have stepped up their alert level on passengers arriving from Hong Kong and Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC MIGHT COOPERATE WITH QATAR: MOFA

TEXT.P: The state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will actively consider diversifying its oil imports, and cooperation with Qatar is a possibility, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Victor Tseng, director-general of MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs, made the remarks amid reports that the China National Petroleum Corporation, the biggest state-owned company, has agreed to pay US$4.18 billion to buy a Canadian oil company with substantial reserves in Kazakhstan, in what would be the largest foreign acquisition by any Chinese company. He said that the CPC's strategy is to diversify its sources of oil imports. In addition to the Middle East, ROC allies in Africa will also be possible cooperation partners.
In Central Asia, in addition to a cooperation project with Kazakhstan, Qatar in the Middle East is also a new target for cooperation, he said.
Tseng noted that China has an unquenched thirst for oil, and will not let go of any opportunities to cooperate with other countries regarding oil exploration.
In West Asia, China has extended its tentacles into Saudi Arabia, Iran, Kuwait, Kazakhstan, Kuwait, Turkmenistan, Azerbaijan and Armenia, he said.
Taiwan imports well over 90 percent of its oil, and gets 70 percent of this from the Middle East.
"We have a steady supply of oil, and our only worry is soaring oil prices," Tseng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PASSENGERS MAINSTAY OF MACAU AIRPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By C.H. Jen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan passengers made up the bulk of total arrivals at the Macau International Airport in July, as the airport braces for more and more visitors from around the world with the opening of new routes, airport authorities said Tuesday.
The airport received a single-month record high of 416,131 arrivals in July, 59 percent of which were travelers from Taiwan, airport authorities said.

The airport registered 2.46 million arrivals for the first seven months of this year, up by 23 percent year on year. It is estimated that the airport will see 4.2 million arrivals for the whole of this year.
Routes between Macau and China provided the second-largest number of passenger arrivals, while those from Thailand, Malaysia and South Korea followed, in that order.

With Macau well positioned as a preferred entry point to China and the Asia-Pacific region, the 24-hour Macau International Airport is an attractive alternative for the region's increasing airfreight traffic, allowing easy access to numerous destinations in China and other countries, airport authorities said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITIES VOW TO PROTECT HUMAN RIGHTS OF FOREIGN LABORERS

TEXT.P: Authorities in Taiwan at both the central and local government levels said Tuesday that the human rights of all foreign laborers working in Taiwan must be protected and that the employers' management of foreign work forces must be humane.

After a riot Sunday by some 100 Thai workers employed by the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) came to what the authorities claim was a "happy ending," the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) set an investigation in motion. A team comprising human rights experts, scholars, Thai officials and representatives from human rights groups went to Kaohsiung County to talk to the Thai workers and look into the causes of the incident.

The CLA will wait until the team completes its report on the incident before deciding whether to mete out penalties to the KRTC and the Huapan Manpower Consultant and Management Co. it contracted to handle all affairs concerning the foreign laborers working on the project.
The KRTC has applied to the labor authorities to employ some 2,600 foreign laborers to help keep the project on schedule, but so far it has hired only about 1,700, still 900 short of its target.

As a result of the riot, the CLA announced a temporary freeze on the KRTC's planned import of 900 more foreign workers. The CLA also said it would reduce the KRTC's present foreign fork force by half -- about 800 men -- and redistribute them to other construction sites if the investigative report finds that the Thai laborers were mistreated.

The riot at the Thai laborers' dormitories in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County, occurred Sunday evening when some Thai laborers were allegedly mistreated with an electric cattle prod for drinking alcohol in their living quarters. Over 100 fellow workers joined the protest, setting fire to a house and smashed the management office, causing NT$10 million in property damage.

The 1,700 foreign workers living in four crowded two-story dormitories are known to have strong feelings about the many draconian restrictions the management has forced on them, including a ban on smoking and even a ban on the use of mobile phones in the dorm.

The incident has made headlines in newspapers around the world and has attracted world attention to Taiwan's poor treatment of foreign laborers. One Bangkok newspaper quoted Thai Labor Minister Somsak Thepsuthin as saying it was the "most serious incident" in 20 years since Thailand started exporting laborers to Taiwan.

The Thai laborers returned to work Tuesday after receiving promises from the management that none of them will be laid off and sent back to Thailand because of the riot. A day earlier, the management agreed to 14 of their 16 demands for better treatment.

The Labor Affairs Bureau under the Kaohsiung city government also pledged Tuesday that bureau officials will step up inspection on the treatment of foreign laborers until the KRTC has made all necessary improvements in response to their complaints.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU-OKINAWA TWO-WAY CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: Penghu and Okinawa, Japan opened two-way charter flight services Tuesday to expand tourist exchanges.

The first flight on the new route took off at the Penghu airport at 7:55 a.m. with 158 passengers on board. The same airplane, a China Airlines 737-800, flew back to Penghu nearly four hours after its departure from the island, carrying 79 Japanese passengers.
The flight services are part of Penghu's efforts to develop the tourist industry by building international connections. It has so far opened services to Xiamen, China, as well as to Macau and Osaka.

Among the 79 Japanese travelers arriving in Penghu Tuesday was a contingent of tourist operators, commercial groups and the media. They are scheduled to stay four days on the island located in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iraq's Assembly Is Given Charter, Still Unfinished
Iraqi leaders submitted a draft constitution to the National Assembly just before their self-imposed midnight deadline on Monday, but disagreement with Sunni leaders and other secular Iraqis left the document incomplete, with fundamental issues still in dispute. The Iraqis decided to give themselves three additional days to close the gaps, despite the requirement in the country's interim constitution that the document be completed by a deadline, which already had been extended a week. That left some Iraqis on the 275-member National Assembly wondering whether they were still in charge, and some Sunni leaders asserting that the delay was illegal.
Wall Street Journal: Tug of War, On a Busy Inlet, A Dispute Surfaces Over Energy Policy
In Massachusetts the state is enforcing a controversial state law passed in the wake of a devastating oil spill here, which requires ship owners to post steep financial guarantees to insure against accidents. It levies a two-cent tax on every barrel of oil shipped. And it forces most tugboat operators carrying oil up the bay to hire extra "escort" tugs just in case something goes wrong. The Bush administration sued Massachusetts in U.S. District Court in Boston in January, seeking to overturn the law and alleging it infringes on the federal government's role as the regulator of interstate maritime trade. The Coast Guard refuses to enforce the law, and Massachusetts agents say they won't go on patrol until the case is settled. The chaotic situation -- on the water and in the court -- is a small example of the country's big difficulties in crafting a coherent energy policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU COUNTY MAGISTRATE WITHDRAWS FROM DPP TO ASSERT RE-ELECTION BID

TEXT.P: Nantou County Magistrate Lin Tsung-nan quit the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Tuesday and reaffirmed his commitment to run for a second term as an independent.
Lin's move added yet another variable to the outcome of the year-end magistrate election in the central Taiwan county.

Lin lost to former DPP Legislator Tsai Huang-liang in the intraparty primary to decide upon a DPP candidate for the election and DPP heavyweights from President Chen Shui-bian on down had tried but failed to persuade Lin to give up his re-election bid and reduce the chances of the party losing as a result of a split vote.

Lin, a member of the DPP Central Standing Committee (CSC), signed the words "bye bye" on the attendance book before entering a conference room where the weekly CSC meeting was to take place. He bade farewell to the other CSC members at the meeting and then announced his decision to quit the party.
Both Vice President Annette Lu and DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang made last-ditch efforts to talk Lin into changing his mind, but he remained adamant.
An emotional Lin noted that he fought for democracy along with many DPP elders during Taiwan's martial law era.

"Throughout my 40-year political career, I have worked with many DPP stalwarts. Even before the DPP was allowed to form, we fought together for its inception. I treasure our past friendship and comradeship, but the time has come for me to quit. I have many tasks to accomplish and I cannot let down my supporters. I must deliver on my promises to them and thus I have a moral duty to seek re-election," he said.
Lin declined to comment on his DPP rival, Tsai Huang-liang, pointing out that just because he lost the primary does not mean he will lose the election.
"I'm confident of my re-election bid and I stake my political future on the year-end election. If I lose, I will bow out of politics when my current term in office expires," Lin said.
He also urged the DPP headquarters to take steps to improve its primary electoral system to "make it fairer and more just."
He also firmly denied that he is likely to join the DPP's ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
"As a pro-democracy activist during Taiwan's martial law era, I'm no stranger to fighting on my own and I will definitely run for re-election as an independent," Lin said.

Learning of Lin's withdrawal, Tsai said he is not worried about a possible massive defection of DPP supporters to Lin's camp and claimed that Lin's staunch supporters mainly come from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP).
"Lin is not the first to withdraw from the DPP to run on his own. Voting records show that DPP supporters traditionally vote for the party's standard-bearers, not its rebels," Tsai claimed.

However, Nantou Mayor Lee Tsao-ching, who will represent the "pan-blue alliance" in the Dec. 3 Nantou County magistrate election, said Lin's move marks an intraparty division and predicted that it will discourage voters from supporting the DPP nominee.
Su, meanwhile, said he felt deep regret over Lin's departure but added that the DPP will do whatever it can to ensure victory for Tsai in the year-end election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STILL MOST FAVORED CHOICE FOR THAI LABORERS: THAI OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Most Thai laborers in Taiwan hope they can continue their employment here, despite the riot by some of their fellow workers last Sunday in southern Taiwan to protest poor treatment by the management, a Thai official said late Monday.

Supat Gukun, an official at the Thai representative office in Taiwan in charge of labor affairs, claimed to reporters that the riot was started by "a handful" of Thai workers who incited others to resort to violence.
He said he is happy that the incident has ended, with no adverse effect on the labor policies of either Taiwan or Thailand.

The riot by more than 100 Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway project occurred in their living quarters in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County, when some Thai workers were allegedly attacked with an electric cattle prod by Taiwanese management for drinking in their dormitory. In retaliation, they burned down a building and smashed the management office, causing an estimated NT$10 million in damage.

According to a report released jointly by the International Organization for Migration, the International Labor Organization and the U.N. Development Program Tuesday, there are 94,000 Thai workers in Taiwan -- 82,000 men and 11,000 women -- making Taiwan the largest export market for Thai labor.

Labor market analysts say that Taiwan has always been the most favored choice for Thai laborers seeking work opportunities abroad. They believe the latest riot will not affect their preference to work here.

The main reason why Thai workers find Taiwan so attractive is that Taiwan offers them higher wages than other countries. They can earn an average salary of about US$460 -- three or four times the pay in their home country.

In addition, Thai workers are used to the climate in Taiwan, which is similar to that of Thailand. Predominantly Buddhists, Thai workers also feel comfortable because Buddhism is also popular in Taiwan. The close distance between Taiwan and Thailand -- only three-and-a-half hours by plane -- is another favorable factor, according to the analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, CPC BEGIN EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: A delegation of officials from the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) Taichung chapter arrived Tuesday in Xiamen, in China's Fujian Province, ushering in party-level exchanges with the Communist Party of China (CPC), which defeated the KMT in a civil war in China and caused the KMT to flee to Taiwan in 1949.

The four-day visit is a follow-up to a historic visit by KMT Honorary Chairman Lien Chan to China in late April, where he met with CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao and agreed with Hu to strengthen ties between the two sides of Taiwan Strait, despite lacking any government authority to do so.

According to Lien, the exchanges will be in three stages, with the first beginning between KMT cadres in six counties and cities, including Taichung City, Keelung City, Hsinchu City, Changhua County, Tainan City and Kaohsiung County, and CPC cadres from six Chinese cities, including Xiamen, Ningbo, Suzhou, Qingdao, Shenzhen and Fuzhou.
The second stage will include KMT cadres from 10 counties and cities, with the third-stage extending to Taipei City and Kaohsiung City.
The delegation's arrival at Xiamen's Gaoqi International Airport drew coverage by many Chinese media.

Chen Xioumao, deputy director of the CPC's Xiamen Chapter, who was among the Chinese officials to receive the KMT delegation, said this was the first step of regular exchanges between the KMT and the CPC, following the "historic" meeting between Lien and Hu.

At the Lien-Hu meeting, both sides also promised to promote a cross-strait peace accord and a common market, as well as a KMT-CPC cooperation platform with bilateral dialogue every six months in China or Taiwan.

Liao Feng-teh, director of the KMT's Department of Organization and Development, said the exchanges will extend to other cities and counties in the future, in the hope that the KMT can do something for the peace and stability between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Chen noted that Xiamen and Taichung are geographically close, and he expressed hope that both sides can have more discussions on economic, trade, cultural exchanges.
The delegation later visited Xiamen University and had talks with Taiwanese students studying at the university.
The KMT delegation will also have talks with other CPC officials, Taiwanese businessmen with operations in China, and will visit a Taichung food fair in Xiamen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MACHINE TOOL EXPORTS RANK FOURTH IN WORLD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports in machine tools totaled NT$75.2 billion (US$2.34 billion) last year, the fourth-largest in the world, according to statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) Tuesday.
A DGBAS official noted that Taiwan's machine tool exports shrank to NT$45.9 billion in 2001 due to a global economic downturn.
However, exports rose in 2002 thanks to the world economic recovery, with the figure surging to NT$75.2 billion in 2004, a growth of 30.5 percent over the previous year, the official added.
Hong Kong and mainland China were the major markets of Taiwan's machine tools last year, absorbing 45.5 percent of the total, followed by the United States and Turkey.
Taiwan's machine tool imports registered NT$48.6 billion in 2000 largely for semiconductor production.
The figure dwindled to NT$28.5 billion and NT$24.3 billion in 2001 and 2002, respectively, due largely to lower global demand in the information industry and over investment.
Taiwan's machine tool imports recovered in 2003, with the figure rising to NT$29.6 billion in 2003, and NT$66.3 billion in 2004, the third highest in the world.
Among the imports figure in 2004, machine tools for semiconductor production registered NT$42.1 billion, accounting for 63.6 percent of the total.
Japan was the major supplier of machine tools for Taiwan, supplying 52.8 percent of the island's total, followed by the U.S. and Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT AIMS TO BEEF UP DEFENSE, NOT ARMS RACE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday his administration's arms procurement plan is not meant as an arms race with China, but is primarily for beefing up Taiwan's defense capabilities in the face of China's ever growing military threat.

"The proposed arms porcurement is not intended to engage in an arms race with China but to upgrade self-defense capabilities, therefore safeguarding our hard-won democracy and prosperity, " Chen said.
Chen made the remarks at a ceremony on the frontline island of Kinmen, which lies closer to China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan, to mark a battle against China 47 years ago.

The Battle of the Taiwan Strait began with China's shelling of Kinmen Aug. 23, 1958, in a failed attempt to pound Kinmen into submission. China lobbed 480,000 shells in a 44-day barrage, leaving Kinmen pockmarked with craters.
Chen expressed his tribute to those who sacrificed their lives in that battle, saying he admired their selfless patriotism.

Noting that the 1958 battle resulted from a combination of factors, including the Cold War mindset and the historical feud between Taiwan's then-ruling Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China, Chen said it is regrettable that Taiwan still faces China's threat even though the Cold War has ended.
"The Cold War has ended after 47 years... but despite this, Taiwan people are still under threat of more than 700 ballistic missiles deployed by China against Taiwan," Chen said.

He took the occasion to defend his administration's hefty arms package, citing China's passage of an anti-secession law in March that codifies the use of non peaceful means against Taiwan if the island moves toward formal independence.

Chen also cited remarks in July by Chinese General Zhu Chenghu, who said China could use nuclear weapons to retaliate against the United States if Washington attacked China in any conflict over Taiwan.
"Zhu's remarks further highlighted the potential crisis that could be sparked by China's fast arms buildup as it is tipping the cross-strait military balance toward China," Chen said.
Touching on the long-stalled arms procurement package, Chen said he looks forward to rational and pragmatic discussion with new opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou on the issue.

The package calls for the purchase of eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States at a cost of NT$480 billion (US$15 billion).
Chen said the package has long been stuck in the Legislative Yuan due to the opposition parties' "irrational boycott."

Over the past five years, the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally -- the People First Party -- have used their slim majority in the legislature to boycott the Chen administration's policy initiatives at almost every turn.

Chen said he earnestly hopes that Ma can demonstrate a different leadership style from that of his predecessor Lien Chan, who was never able to accept that he was defeated twice by Chen in presidential elections.

"Hopefully, Ma will be willing to engage in candid exchanges of opinions and rational cooperation with the government based on the principles of safeguarding national interests and the well-being of the people," Chen said.

Now that the KMT has changed its leadership, Chen said, he is hopeful that the Ma-led KMT will demonstrate sincerity and efficiency in dealing with national security and livelihood-related bills and budgetary appropriations.
Chen was accompanied by Defense Minister Lee Jye, Chief of the General Staff Li Tien-yu and other senior government and military officials on the visit to Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WANTS NEW KMT HEAD TO SHOW HIS HAND ON ARMS PURCHASE

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said Tuesday that the opposition Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou should express his attitude toward the stalled arms procurement package from the United States.

Chen Ching-chun, the whip of the DPP's legislative caucus, made the remarks after Ma said in response to a call by President Chen Shui-bian for talks on the arms procurement package that there is no need for him to have such a meeting with Chen on this issue, as the procurement bill should be discussed in the legislature.
Ma took the helm of the KMT Aug. 19 from his predecessor Lien Chan.

The legislator noted that the bill has been blocked in the legislature by the opposition for more than a year, due largely to objections from Lien, who was defeated twice by Chen in presidential elections.
Chen said that as Ma might compete in the 2008 presidential election, the public expects to know about his attitude toward national security.
Noting that the cross-Taiwan Strait military balance has been tilting heavily in China's favor, he urged Ma not to shirk "his responsibility" on national security.
Meanwhile, Cho Po-yuan, the whip of the KMT legislative caucus, claimed that the KMT's stonewalling of the arms purchase budget is "rational supervision" with the aim of not wasting taxpayers' money.

In addition, Cho went on, the legislature is the main battleground of opposition parties and it is quite natural in a democratic society that the arms procurement plan will be decided by lawmakers rather than leaders of any political party.
The KMT is most concerned about the welfare of the people and will not bow to pressure from the United States, Cho claimed.
Cho said the KMT caucus will listen to a briefing from the National Defense Ministry on the arms procurement in the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR AUTHORITIES REACTION TO KAOHSIUNG RIOT CRITICIZED

TEXT.P: A leader of the Kaohsiung Chamber of Industry criticized the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) decisions in reaction to Sunday's riot by Thai laborers as "inappropriate and unfair."

Li Wei-ying, general-secretary of the chamber, said the CLA has made an "ill-considered" decision in announcing a freeze on the planned import of an additional 900 foreign laborers by the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) and a plan to reduce the KRTC's current foreign labor force by 800 men and redistribute the workers to other construction sites.

Li claimed that the CLA's usual practice in dealing with disputes between foreign laborers and local employers is to mete out "heavy penalties" to the employers while not allowing them to tell their side of the story.

He admitted that the employers have been harsh in their management of foreign labor forces, but claimed that this is mainly because of the CLA's strict regulations that subject an employer to a fine of between NT$60,000 and NT$300,000 if anything goes wrong with the management.

The companies with foreign laborers are in a dilemma. If they are too strict with the foreign workers, they would be accused of human rights violations, but if they are too lax with them, these foreign workers "would create a lot of trouble," Li said.

Taiwan's foreign labor brokerages used to wield great power in deciding whether a foreign labor should be fired and sent home, but now they and the employers have to prove with concrete evidence that a foreign laborer has committed three serious offenses before the CLA will consider deporting that worker.

DOC.HEADLINE: HYDRAULIC POWER EXPERT TO BE NEW MOEA VICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Hou Ho-hsiung, a Presidential Office national policy adviser who once served as deputy mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, will replace Yiin Chii-ming as an administrative vice minister of economic affairs, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Tuesday.
Yiin, who is versed in industrial development, will be transferred to serve as an adviser to the Executive Yuan, Cho said.

Meanwhile, Cho said that Hsu Hsiang-kun, a specialist with the Legislative Yuan's science and information technology commission who once headed the Ministry of Economic Affairs' water resources bureau, will be new chairman of the state-owned Taiwan Water Corp.
Hsu will fill the vacancy to be left vacant by Lee Wen-liang who has offered to resign to assume political responsibility for the recent water supply crisis in the northern county of Taoyuan.
Cho said Hou and Hsu are scheduled to take over their new posts next month.

Noting that water resources management and hydraulic engineering have become increasingly important in the Economic Ministry's functions, Cho said Hou is expected to oversee the quality of many ongoing and future hydraulic power projects.
Hou is also expected to coordinate operations of the MOEA's Water Resources Agency and the Taiwan Water Corp. so that they can cooperate smoothly and enhance operational efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY TO JOIN FIGHT AGAINST CHINA'S `CHARM OFFENSIVE'

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will join the government's fight against what it claims is China's "charm offensive" targeting Taiwan's farmers by opening its market to Taiwan fruit, according to Gen. Hu Cheng-pu, chief of the department of political warfare under the MND.

Hu told journalists while accompanying President Chen Shui-bian on a visit to the frontline island of Kinmen Tuesday that his department was asked by lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to help with the government's efforts in trying to persuade local farmers that China is not a lucrative market for Taiwan's agricultural products.

Noting that the MND has engaged in political warfare against China for more than five decades, the DPP lawmakers said their experience will be invaluable for the government in "exposing Beijing's lies" about offering Taiwan fruit duty-free access to the Chinese market.

Hu confirmed news reports that he had visited Council of Agriculture head Lee Ching-lung and Joseph Wu, chief of the Mainland Affairs Council, the two Cabinet-level officials spearheading the government's efforts to woo over the farmers, to learn about the government's latest strategy on the issue and to see what the MND can do to help.

The general said the MND has decided to ask the Youth Daily and the Voice of Han Radio -- controlled by the armed forces -- to interview officials responsible for agricultural and China affairs so that they can air the government's stance on the issue and warn the public to guard against what the government claims is China's political scheme behind its overtures to Taiwan farmers.
As a part of the government, Hu said, the MND cannot sit on its hands while the country is taking pains to foil Beijing's scheme aimed at splitting the people of Taiwan.
Beijing promised to open its market to Taiwan fruit in April as a gift to former Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, who visited China at the time.

The move alarmed the DPP, which counts Taiwan farmers among its core supporters. The DPP government has since done all it can to warn farmers of what it claimed Beijing's political motivation behind its promise.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WILL NOT LET KMT CHIEF HEDGE ON ARMS PROCUREMENT: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The U.S. will not let newly inaugurated opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou hedge on the issue of the government's controversial arms purchase from America, Hsiao Bi-khim a lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , speculated Tuesday.

Hsiao made her prediction after Ma spurned President Chen Shui-bian's request Tuesday for a meeting on the NT$480 billion (US$14.92 billion) budget for the arms purchase, which has been bogged down in the opposition-controlled legislature for more than a year. Ma responded by saying it is up to the legislature to deal with the bill.

Hsiao said Ma might turn a deaf ear to the president's request but she claimed he will not be able to escape pressure from the U.S. which knows quite well that it is the opposition parties, not least the KMT, that is stonewalling the deal.

Noting that a group of U.S. congressmen wrote to Ma's predecessor Lien Chan, urging him to give a greenlight to the budget for the purchase, Hsiao predicted that the U.S. would not let Ma dodge the issue, and that officials from the American Institute in Taiwan will ask for a meeting with the new KMT chief soon seeking answers to this question.
As the proposed arms acquirement concerns national security, Hsiao said, Ma has to face up to it and think about how to deal with it rather than pass the buck.

The KMT, under the leadership of Lien, has filibustered the budget on the grounds that it would be financed with a special budget, which the opposition claims will become a heavy financial burden for future administrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 24, or the 20th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: The small but very bitter war being fought between Britain and the United States continues, with British forces razing many Washington, D.C. landmarks, including the White House.
1923: A "Dr. Sun Yat-sen mission" led by Chiang Kai-shek leaves Harbin for Moscow on a fact-finding tour.
1945: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's Nationalist government, signs the ratification instrument of the U.N. Charter.
1945: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China ratifies the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: Communist China sends troops into Tibet.
1954: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs into law the Communist Control Act, outlawing the Communist Party.
1954: Brazilian President Getulio Vargas shoots himself to avoid scandal as well as demands that he relinquish power. He was 71.
1968: Taichung's Golden Dragons baseball team defeats the U.S. West team 5A-0 to win the 23rd Little League World Championship.
1981: A Manhattan Supreme Court judge jails Mark David Chapman for 20 years to life for shooting dead John Lennon the previous December.
1983: The auditorium of Fengyuan High School in Taichung County collapses, killing 27 students and injuring 83 others.
1983: Communist Chinese pilot Lt. Col. Sun Tien-chin, who flew to South Korea from mainland China in a MiG-21 jet fighter Aug. 7, arrives in Taiwan.
1985: Communist Chinese pilot Hsiao Tien-jun, 33, flies an H-5 torpedo attack bomber to South Korea and requests political asylum in the ROC.
1986: The ROC Little League baseball team "Kungyuan" defeats Tucson, Arizona, and recaptures the Little League World Series title after four years.
1991: The Ukraine declares independence from Moscow.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as head of the Soviet Communist Party and urges its leadership to disband the party.
1992: Communist China and South Korea establish diplomatic relations.
1995: President Juan Carlos Wasmosy of Paraguay leads a delegation to Taipei for a four-day visit.
1995: Beijing expels Chinese-American human rights activist Harry Wu shortly after he was sentenced to a 15-year prison term for spying and leaking state secrets.
1996: The ROC wins the 1996 Little League World Series in the U.S. city of Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
1999: A UNI Air plane from Taipei crash-lands at Hualien Airport in flames, injuring 28 passengers.
1999: Ever Decent, a Panamanian-flagged container ship owned by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp., is hit by Norwegian Dream, a Bahamas-registered cruise ship, injuring three people aboard the cruise ship.
2000: ROC President Chen Shui-bian wraps up his visit to Chad ahead of schedule after issuing a joint communique with Chadian President Idriss Deby.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian officiates at the opening of the plenary session of the much-anticipated Economic Development Advisory Conference Friday, a series of meetings and discussions designed to invigorate Taiwan's floundering economy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses great moral qualities will certainly attain a corresponding high position, a corresponding great prosperity, a corresponding great name, and a corresponding great age."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST DECIDE ON ARMS PURCHASE ON ITS OWN: U.S. DEFENSE SECRETARY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld said Tuesday that its up to Taiwan to decide whether to purchase the arms offered by the United States, pointing out that sovereign countries have to make decisions for themselves.

The secretary made the remarks at a regular press conference in response to a reporter's question regarding the arms procurement bill that has been long stalled in Taiwan's legislature due to opposition from lawmaker's of the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party.
"If they decide not to (make the arms purchase) or if they decide to do so, that's up to them, " Rumsfeld said.

"We have made our position known with the Taiwan Relations Act. And we have an obligation under that act to work with Taiwan on fulfilling the security and arms sale provisions of that act, " he further said.

According to Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense, the items on the procurement list include eight diesel-powered submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER URGES SPEEDY APPROPRIATION OF TSUNAMI DONATIONS

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that it is absolutely unacceptable that after nearly eight months, the donations collected by the government from the Taiwan people for tsunami relief has still not reached those in need.

Wang said the long delay in distributing the money to the charities commissioned by the government to help victims of last December's tsunami tragedy in South and Southeast Asia has "hurt Taiwan's international image."
Taiwan citizens opened their hearts to the tsunami disaster victims by donating more than NT$400 million (US$12.5 million) during the Government Information Office-initiated fund-raiser.
Wang said the GIO should have understood clearly the nation's law governing fund-raising and appropriation when it initiated the charity campaign early this year.

Meanwhile, former GIO Minister Lin Chia-lung, who initiated the fund-raising drive, met with current GIO Minister Pasuya Yao Wednesday for "face-to-face" discussions concerning the delay in distributing the funds to the charities.

The two apparently reached a consensus on the appropriation of the funds, saying after their brief meeting that the money will be distributed late this month or early next month at the earliest after the GIO completes some "paperwork" with the bank in charge of dealing with the funds.
The GIO has recently been criticized by the media and several lawmakers for the long delay in distributing the money.

Responding to the criticism, Yao clarified Tuesday that all donations will be put into construction and relief work as planned and will be executed via non-governmental organizations, adding that there has been absolutely no delay.

However, he also said that the collected donations must still undergo a set of budgetary and appropriation procedures, which means that it may take some time for the money to be channeled to the NGOs.
This is not a question of government negligence or inefficiency, Yao said, adding that in fact, the rigorous monitoring procedures will ensure that none of the donated money is wasted.
