DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ASKS FOR PROBE INTO ALLEGED KICKBACKS IN HIRING OF FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday called for an investigation into the alleged kickbacks involved in the hiring of foreign laborers for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC).

William Lai, DPP caucus whip, pointed out that foreign laborers working for the KRTC are in theory introduced through an agreement between the governments of Taiwan and Thailand and that therefore, no brokerage fees should be involved.

Lai's remarks came amid reports that Huapan Manpower Consultant and Management Co., a company in charge of managing foreign laborers working for the KRTC, probably tried to make up its losses from paying kickbacks by exploiting the Thai laborers working on building the Kaohsiung MRT system. The poor treatment allegedly triggered Sunday's riot in which angry Thai worker who had been unhappy about rigid management set fire to a house and cars, and smashed doors and window of the manager's office.

Lai said the DPP legislative caucus will ask the Ministry of Justice to investigate the matter to see if any legislators, officials or other individuals have been lining their pockets as reported in the media.

He also said the management of foreign laborers working for the KRTC has infringed upon human rights and hurt the nation's image, adding that the DPP legislative caucus expresses the strongest possible condemnation.
He also said that the introduction of foreign laborers was a policy under the previous Kuomintang (KMT) administration and that the brokerage companies were run by KMT members then.

On reports that DPP legislators have been involved in receiving kickbacks, Lai said he has confidence in the ethics of the DPP lawmakers and expressed the hope that the truth will be uncovered in the investigation, regardless of who might be involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-RUSSIAN MILITARY EXERCISE POSES NO THREAT TO TAIWAN: RUMSFELD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld said Tuesday that he neither finds the current Chinese-Russian joint military exercise notable nor sees it as a threat to Taiwan or to anyone else.
The secretary made the comments at a joint press conference he held with Adm. Edmund Giambastiani Jr., vice chairman of the Joint Chief of Staffs.
In response to a question regarding whether he is concerned about the first-ever Chinese-Russian joint military exercise, Rumsfeld said that the United States is obviously observing the drills.
Nevertheless, he added that he doesn't see the joint military exercise as particularly significant as "nations have exercises all the time."

"We do with any number of countries, dozens of different countries. And we -- NATO countries, do with Russia on various things, and with India, " he further said, adding that "it is just a fact that countries get together and engage in various types of exercises."
Meanwhile, Adm. Giambastiani said at the press conference that the United States monitors all military exercises, including the ongoing joint Chinese-Russian drills.

The eight-day military exercise, which began last Thursday, involves some 10,000 air, sea and land troops. The drills are designed to test the ability of the two countries's counter-terrorist and counter-separatist capabilities, according to Russian and Chinese officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN TO SUBMIT NEW VERSION OF ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan on Wednesday withdrew its NT$480 billion (US$15 billion) arms procurement draft bill which had been bogged down in the Legislative Yuan for the last two sessions because of opposition from lawmakers of the "pan-blue alliance."

Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai said that in response to lawmakers' demands, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has decided to change the proposed manner of funding the three items in the arms package that the United States has agreed to sell to Taiwan to help beef up the island's self-defense capabilities.

The three items in the package -- eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft -- have a total price tag of US$15 billion.

In the new version of the arms procurement bill, which is expected to be submitted to the Legislative Yuan next week, the MND has listed the six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries, costing NT$100 billion, in its regular budget, instead of proposing that they be funded by a special budget.

The move is expected to significantly improve the arms procurement bill's chances of being passed by the Legislative Yuan as one of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers' main criticisms of the original bill was the funding of all the items through a special budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: IDB TO HELP PROMOTE EXPORT OF GENERIC DRUGS

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) is working to form a pharmaceutical export strategic alliance as part of its efforts to help local manufacturers make inroads into overseas markets, IDB officials said Wednesday.

Ten pharmaceutical companies have expressed a willingness to join the alliance, which will be aimed at seeking generic drug export and overseas OEM orders, as well as at trying to gain market share in the United States and Japan for Taiwan drug makers.
According to the IDB, the total output of the pharmaceutical industries in Europe, Japan and the United States accounts for more than 80 percent of the global total.

As Japan enacted a new law this April regulating the separation of production and sale of pharmaceuticals and as the U.S. government has been encouraging the use of generic drugs, now is the perfect time for Taiwan pharmaceutical companies to make inroads into these markets, the IDB officials said.

The bureau has plans to form three strategic alliances to push for the export of 10 to 15 kinds of generic drugs. It's expected that in five years, Taiwan's pharmaceutical exports will increase NT$10 billion (US$3.1 billion) , posting an annual growth rate of over 20 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSES URGED NOT TO SAVE MONEY BY INTRODUCING FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that businesses should not introduce foreign laborers in order to save money, claiming that this way of thinking is "wrong."

Hsieh made the remarks in an Executive Yuan floor meeting in the wake of Sunday's riot by Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) . The workers have long been unhappy about the rigid and unreasonable treatment meted out by their management.

Hsieh claimed that Taiwan introduced foreign laborers not to save money but because some major construction projects have failed to find local workers who are willing to work or because a steady supply of workers is difficult.

But at present, a great number of businesses use foreign laborers because they will work for lower pay. Some employers try to save even more money through a variety of devices. He described this unfair treatment as a "wrong mindset."
He expressed the hope that businesses who use foreign laborers and the Council of Labor Affairs heed this point, and that they treat the foreign laborers humanely.
He also admitted that management of foreign laborers may have been rigid sometimes, but claimed that this is because of problems with foreign laborers running away from their posts.
"We will instruct the brokerage companies or employers to exercise fairness in management," the premier said.
He said that if work does not need foreign laborers, then it should be done by local laborers and the employers should not hire foreign laborers as a money-saving move.
He also lauded the foreign laborers for the often-dirty and dangerous work they do.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC: CHINA INVESTMENTS COMPLETELY LEGAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) claimed Wednesday that all of its investment projects in China, including transfer of technology, have been done "completely in accordance with the government's laws and regulations."
TSMC, the world's largest made-to-order chip maker, made the statement in response to media reports that the company is planning to invest in a handset IC design house in China.

The design house will be jointly set up by China's heavyweight home appliance maker TCL Corp. and venture capital firms, with Glenda Hu -- who recently quit his post as TSMC vice president for marketing -- in charge of the joint venture, according to the reports.

In a rare step, TSMC Chairman Morris Chang visited the minister of economic affairs and then the premier Tuesday to explain his company's investment plans. The company also took out newspaper advertisements Wednesday stating that all of its China investments are completely legal.
The ads said the company does not plan to build any 12-inch wafer foundries in China, noting that it was expanding two such plants in Hsinchu and Tainan.

The company also pointed out that neither its Emerging Alliance Fund or its VTAF II Fund have invested in China. "If we are to invest in China, we will thoroughly follow the laws and regulations of the government of the Republic of China," it added.

Institutional investors said TSMC took the unusual step to explain itself because it's good image as a law-abiding company might be damaged by the reports, while people might associate TSMC with its rival, United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , which was recently embroiled in alleged illegal investment in China revolving around the He Jian Technology (Suzhou) Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 67.94 points to close at 6,127.24.
The bourse opened at 6,174.25 and fluctuated between 6,174.79 and 6,126.97 during trading. A total of 2.8 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$67.89 billion (US$2.1 billion).

All the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile and construction stocks moving down the most at 2.0 percent each, followed by foodstuff shares at 1.5 percent, machinery and electronics stocks at 0.8 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.4 percent, and cement as well as paper and pulp issues both at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 779 to 147, with 112 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down 38 points to close at 6,147, with 21,670 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December dropped 43 points to close at 6,145, with 178 contracts traded, while December futures lost 35 points to finish at 6,145, with nine contracts traded.
March futures moved down 34 points to close at 6,141, with four contracts traded, while June futures dropped 24 points to close at 6,140, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,185 for September, 6,188 for December, 6,180 for December, 6,175 for March and 6,164 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
September TE futures moved down 1.8 points to close at 254.1, with 2,823 contracts traded, while October TE futures lost 0.6 points to finish at 255.45, with one contract traded.
March TE futures moved down 1.45 points to close at 255.45, with five contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December and June.
September TF futures lost 7.4 points to finish at 945.4, with 1,901 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 7.4 points to end at 943.4, with 48 contracts traded.
December TF futures moved down 4.6 points to close at 946.4, with five contract transactions, while March TF futures dropped 3.6 points to close at 948, with five contracts traded.
June TF futures dropped 9.4 points to close at 945, with two contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.151 to close at NT$32.280.
A total of US$1.06 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$32.174 and fluctuated between NT$32.160 and NT$32.280.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETIRED DIPLOMAT TIPPED AS NEW AIT CHIEF

TEXT.P: Raymond Burghardt, a former head of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , has been tapped to serve as AIT chairman, reliable sources said Wednesday.
Burghardt, a retired career diplomat, will fill the vacancy that has been left vacant by the resignation of Therese Shaheen in April 2004.
Burghardt's new appointment has yet to be officially confirmed. He did not return phone calls from reporters.

Burghardt served as the AIT Taipei office director, or the de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan, from 1999 to 2001. He then took over as U.S. ambassador to Vietnam until last year. He assumed his current post as a department chief at the East-West Center in Hawaii early this year.
Sources said Burghardt will retain his East-West Center post after assuming the AIT chairmanship.

The AIT, which has offices in Arlington, Virginia, and in Taiwan, is a nonprofit, private corporation established in 1979 to handle U.S.-Taiwan relations in the absence of diplomatic ties. The U.S. State Department provides a large part of the institute's funding and guidance.

Apparently because its function as an intermediary body between Taiwan and the United States has gradually diminished, the sources said Burghardt will continue to reside in Hawaii and that the day-to-day affairs at the AIT headquarters in Arlington will be handled by Deputy Managing Director Barbara Jane Schrage.

Before taking up his AIT Taipei post, Burghardt served as consul-general in Shanghai and as deputy chief of the U.S. embassies in Manila and Seoul. He has also worked in Beijing, Hong Kong and the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa.

Burghardt ended his Taipei tenure at a time when Taiwan-U.S. relations were in the best shape for many years. President Chen Shui-bian decorated him with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon in recognition of his contribution to the promotion of Taiwan-U.S. relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Chinese Detainees Are Men Without a Country; 15 Muslims, Cleared of Terrorism Charges, Remain at Guantanamo With Nowhere to Go.
In late 2003, the Pentagon quietly decided that 15 Chinese Muslims detained at the military prison in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, could be released. Five were people who were in the wrong place at the wrong time, some of them picked up by Pakistani bounty hunters for U.S. payoffs. The other 10 were deemed low-risk detainees whose enemy was China's communist government -- not the United States, according to senior U.S. officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKERS' RIGHTS GROUPS VOICE SUPPORT FOR THAI WORKERS

TEXT.P: Three workers' rights groups in Taiwan voiced their support Wednesday for the Thai laborers who staged a riot last Sunday in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, to protest their poor treatment by their employers and a manpower brokerage company.

Members of the Taiwan International Workers' Association, the Workers' Legislative Action Committee, and the Catholic Hope Workers' Center clashed with police when they tried to enter the office building of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to deliver a statement.

The groups claimed it is a basic human right to rise up against oppression and that the riot by Thai workers was a "resistance against tyranny." Therefore, they said, the CLA should not deport any of the Thai workers because of their involvement in the riot.

In their statement to the CLA, the groups urged the council to trace the real cause of the riot and punish the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. and Huapan Manpower Consultant and Management Co. for their violations of human rights and their "enslavement" of the Thai laborers.

The groups also want labor affairs officials in Kaohsiung County to be penalized because they received the complaints about the inhumane treatment of Thai laborers more than a year ago but have done nothing. The complaints include overcrowded living quarters, poor-quality food, mandatory use of vouchers in lieu of money in the dormitory area, overtime pay not paid in full and no detailed explanation of money withheld from their monthly wages.

The CLA must face squarely the fact that its current policy on the introduction of foreign labor into Taiwan has resulted in a "new system of slavery, " the statement said, adding that the CLA should institute reforms, such as removing the limit on the number of years a foreign laborer is allowed to stay in Taiwan, lifting the ban on foreign laborers switching to another employer, and abolishing the private foreign labor brokerage system.
The human rights groups also want the CLA to publicize the names of those who profit from exploitation of foreign laborers.
Some 1,700 foreign laborers -- mostly Thais -- are employed to work on greater Kaohsiung's rapid transit railway project. They live in four two-story dormitories at Kangshan in Kaohsiung County.

The Sunday riot occurred when a staff member of the management office allegedly used an electric cattle prod to stop some Thai workers from drinking in the living quarters. About 100 Thai workers joined the protest by setting fire to their dormitory and the management office. The riot caused NT$10 million in property damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Peruvian plane crashes, 41 killed, two Italians among passengers.
A Peruvian airliner crashed near Pucallpa, a jungle town in the Amazon area, Tuesday while attempting an emergency landing in a storm. At least 41 people were killed. The TANS plane, carrying 92 passengers and eight crew, was on a domestic flight from Lima to Iquitos via Pucallpa. Among the passengers, two are Italian.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP APOLOGIZES TO THAI WORKERS FOLLOWING RIOT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu offered an apology Wednesday to the foreign workers affected by the recent riot in Kaohsiung, saying that it is regrettable that such a thing could have happened in Taiwan, a nation she described as being committed to human rights protection.

Lu, who traveled to the southern port city in her capacity as the head of a Presidential Office human rights advisory panel to look into the repercussions of the riot, called for the country to treat foreign laborers fairly.
She said the country should treat the foreign laborers, who are here helping Taiwan with its construction, as kin.

Lu added that at a time of increasing globalization, when Taiwan is endeavoring to develop its businesses and industries so they can link up with the world, the country is becoming increasingly reliant on foreign nationals working in Taiwan to help bolster national construction and infrastructure development.
As to who or which agency is to blame for the incident, Lu said the police and prosecutors should look into the case impartially to find out who should be held responsible.

The riot at a Thai laborers' dormitory in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County, occurred Sunday evening when some laborers were allegedly attacked by a Taiwanese manager with an electric cattle prod for drinking alcohol in their living quarters. Over 100 workers joined the ensuing protest, setting fire to a house and smashing up the management office, causing an estimated NT$10 million in property damage.

The Thai laborers returned to work Tuesday after receiving promises from the management that none of them will be laid off and sent back to Thailand because of the riot. A day earlier, the management agreed to 14 of their 16 demands for better treatment.
Thai nationals comprise the largest group of foreign laborers currently working in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: Russia Rethinks Its CIS Policy In an apparent attempt to prevent more former Soviet republics from slipping from Russia's orbit of influence, Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said Tuesday that Moscow would abandon its tacit agreements with its neighbors in favor of relations based on international standards.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH SET TO REGULATE HARMFUL FOOD ADDITIVES

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Wednesday that it will formally regulate, with immediate effect, foods and related products that contain polychlorinated biphenyl, which can be harmful to the health if ingested over the long term.

The polychlorinated biphenyl control program will target all foods and related products on the domestic market, including dairy products and drinks, meat products, eggs, seafoods, baby foods and paper food containers, said Chen Lu-hung, director of the DOH Bureau of Food Sanitation.

Violators of the regulation, if found to be continuing to contaminate their products with polychlorinated biphenyl after being advised, will face fines ranging from NT$30,000 to NT$150,000, depending on the seriousness of the offenses, said Chen.

According to DOH researchers, polychlorinated biphenyl accumulates in the body if ingested over a long period, causing skin rashes, respiratory problems, damage to the immune system, gout, anemia and liver lesions.
The government promulgated a similar regulation in 1985 but has not implemented the restrictive policy concretely, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KRTC SHOULD BEAR RESPONSIBILITY FOR RIOT: LABOR OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC), which hires Thai laborers for MRT construction work, should bear responsibility for the riot Sunday, Lai Chin-lin, vice minister of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), said in Kaohsiung Wednesday.
Lai made the remarks when he led an investigation team comprising human rights experts, scholars, Thai officials and representatives from human rights groups, to inspect the KRTC.
Lai said the CLA wants to investigate the responsibility of the KTRC in the riot because it is the employer of 1,728 foreign laborers, more than 100 of whom took part in the riot.
KRTC officials should deal with the issue and report to the public about the incident, Lai said.
As for whether the KRTC is involved in the exploitation of the foreign laborers for its own profits, the CLA will also look into the issue, Lai said.

Lai rebutted reports that foreign laborers hired by the KRTC had come under an agreement between the governments of the two countries and that no brokerage companies were involved, saying that the foreign laborers had come to Taiwan via brokerage companies.

The team is now closely watching if Huapan Manpower Consultant and Management Co., which is in charge of providing services to the foreign laborers for the KRTC, is involved in the labor recruiting process, he added. Reports have said that Huapan might resort to exploitation of the laborers because it has to make up for losses incurred by the kickbacks it has to pay to corrupt officials and lawmakers.

He said that if Huapan, registered as a life management company with the Ministry of Economic Affairs, is involved in manpower brokerage, it will be fined between NT$300,000 (US$9,375) and NT$1.5 million.
Also, if the KRTC is not paying foreign laborers for overtime work, it will be fined between NT$60,000 and NT$300,000 in line with the Labor Standards Law, he added.
Lai earlier listened to a briefing by the KRTC on the management of foreign laborers at the KRTC.
Lai said that on an tour of the foreign laborer center, he found the place so cramped that after no more than 30 minutes, it gave a sense of suffocation.

On the management regulations formulated by the KRTC and Huapan, Lai also described many of them as unreasonable and unbearable. The regulations state that "those who jump over walls" will be fined NT$3,000, gamblers will be fined NT$1,000, and those filing complaints directly to the Thai mission in Taiwan will be fined NT$1,000.

Wu Jen-hao, a member of the investigation team and president of the Taiwan Human Rights Association, said that Huapan is confining or disciplining the foreign laborers, which he pointed out is not management.

Lai demanded that the problem of insufficient restrooms and cramped living spaces be improved in between three and seven days. The KRTC has also promised to give some relief to the overcrowded dormitory situation by the end of September. The 1,700 foreign workers currently live in four crowded two-story dormitories.
The KRTC promised to establish a complaint-handling system for foreign laborers within three days and said the foreign laborers will be allowed to form their own meals committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT MUM ON NEW HEAD REPORT

TEXT.P: The Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) refused to comment Wednesday on reports that one of its former heads has been tapped to serve as AIT chairman and managing director.

According to the reports, Raymond Burghardt, who served as the AIT Taipei office director -- the de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan -- from 1999 to 2001, will be named to head the AIT, the quasi-official U.S. organization authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Responding to a press inquiry about the reports, a spokesman for the AIT Taipei office said: "We don't have anything to say."
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) also refrained from commenting on the reports.

"We are not in a position to comment on any unconfirmed U.S. personnel reshuffle reports, " said MOFA spokesman Michel Lu. While fully respecting U.S. personnel arrangements, Lu said, the MOFA is hopeful that a new AIT chief will work toward improved Taiwan-U.S. relations.
According to the reports, Burghardt, a retired career diplomat, will fill the vacancy that has been left vacant by the resignation of Therese Shaheen in April 2004.

After ending his AIT Taipei office director tenure in 2001, Burghardt took over as U.S. ambassador to Vietnam until last year. He assumed his current post as a department chief at the East-West Center in Hawaii early this year.
Sources said Burghardt will retain his East-West Center post after assuming the AIT chairmanship.

Apparently because its function as an intermediary body between Taiwan and the United States has gradually diminished, the sources said Burghardt will continue to reside in Hawaii and that the day-to-day affairs at the AIT headquarters in Arlington will be handled by Deputy Managing Director Barbara Schrage.

Before taking up his AIT Taipei post, Burghardt served as consul-general in Shanghai and as deputy chief of the U.S. embassies in Manila and Seoul. He has also worked in Beijing, Hong Kong and the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa.

Burghardt ended his Taipei tenure at a time when Taiwan-U.S. relations were in the best shape for many years. President Chen Shui-bian decorated him with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon in recognition of his contribution to the promotion of Taiwan-U.S. relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG PEOPLE AROUND THE WORLD SHARE EXPERIENCE IN TAIWAN TOUR

TEXT.P: A total of 51 young people from around the world gathered Wednesday at the Ministry of Education (MOE) to share their travel experiences at the end of a two-week visit to Taiwan.

These young people from France, Germany, Spain, Italy, Great Britain, New Zealand, Australia, the United States and Canada were chosen by the MOE this year to participate in an in-depth Taiwan travel program to promote tourism.
Most of the travelers, aged between 18 and 35, said they were deeply impressed by Taiwan's beautiful scenery and the hospitality of its people.

A young man from France described Taiwan culture as a kind of mixture of Chinese and Japanese culture and a showcase of Asian culture. He added that it was fascinating for him to experience the whole Asian culture in Taiwan in just two weeks.
Another French youth said he was most impressed by the public facilities in Taiwan offered to the handicapped, which he said are insufficient in France.

The Canadian representatives said they were very much attracted by Taiwan's mountains and temples and will share their travel experiences in Taiwan with Canadian university students after returning home.

Tal Gory from Australia, who has studied Chinese for two years and lived in Shanghai for six months last year, said he thought originally that Taiwan was just a small place and did not know there is such beautiful scenery and wonderful food here.

Noting that his Australian classmates studying Chinese all put China as their top travel and study priority, Gory said he has discovered the beauty of Taiwan, which he said is also cleaner, in better order and more hospitable than China.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE NAB DRUG DEALER IN TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: A mobile squad of the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) arrested a drug dealer in Taoyuan Wednesday, seizing 2kg of heroin with a street value of over NT$100 million (US$3.1 million).
The squad captain, Tsai Yuan-ching, said they had been stalking the dealer, identified as Chen Yen-chun, 25, for three months. Chen owns a mansion and four expensive cars.

Chen allegedly delivered drugs to his distributors twice a week, according to the squad. A preliminary investigation shows that most of Chen's heroin was smuggled from China in deals that could involve millions of NT dollars.
Over 30 CGA officers were mobilized for the arrest.
A further investigation aimed at tracing other drug sources is now underway.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GRABS OVER 100 MEDALS IN ASIAN STAMP EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: The Taipei 2005 -- 18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition, which opened Aug. 19, ended Wednesday, with Fortune Wang, a Taiwanese veteran philatelist, winning two "Large Gold" medals and the "Grand Prix National," one of two grand prizes for the show.

Taiwan took 10 of 38 golds in the competition class of the event. In total, Taiwan competitors grabbed over 100 medals in the contest, in which the organizers awarded 380 medals for outstanding philatelic research or originality.

The other grand prize -- the Grand Prix International -- was won by Charnchai Karnasutau, a collector from Thailand, while the only award in the championship class -- the Grand Prix d'Honneur -- was presented to Mohamad Sayeed from Saudi Arabia, who has won three "Large Gold" medals in previous Asian International Stamp exhibitions.

At the six-day exhibition, held at the Taipei World Trade Center, a total of 1,556 frames of stamps from 22 countries were on display. One third of the frames were from Taiwan, according to Chunghwa Post Co., the key sponsor of the event.

Autographed personalized greeting stamp sets by local model Lin Chi-ling, the spokeswoman of the Taipei 2005 exhibition, were the hottest item during the show. The NT$1.2 million (US$37,500) Chunghwa Post raised by selling the stamp sets will be donated to the Yunlin and Chiayi county governments to help impoverished children in those counties, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCIL OF AGRICULTURE RECRUITING ANIMAL SHELTER VOLUNTEERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) is recruiting volunteer workers for animal shelters throughout Taiwan and welcomes animal lovers who are 15 or older to donate their free time to the care of stray animals.

A spokesman for the COA said Wednesday that the volunteers will be given appropriate training to enable them to know the daily routines in the care of pets, such as how to walk a dog, bathe a dog and make a stray animal look more attractive for adoption.

The volunteers will also be required to do some paperwork, including taking pictures of stray animals, building a file for each of them and publicizing the information on the Internet. Occasionally they will also need to assist in the education of the public about animal protection and support inspectors in enforcing animal protection law.
The spokesman said that those between 15 and 18 who wish to become volunteers must have the approval of their guardians.
So far, more than 250 animal lovers have answered the COA's call. A ceremony will take place Sept. 3 at the Taipei Zoo for the volunteers to be sworn in.
People who are interested in becoming volunteers can get more detailed information from the Animal Protection Information System at http://animal.coa.gov.tw/index/index.asp. (By Han Nai-kuo

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO SIMPLIFY PROCEDURE FOR USING CHARITY FUNDS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that charity funds should not be blocked by bureaucratic procedures on the way to benefiting the needy.

Hsieh made his remarks as criticism was mounting as to why a Government Information Office-initiated fund for Southeast Asian tsunami victims has been lying dormant in a bank account without ever reaching those it was intended for.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said the long delay was absolutely unacceptable.

Hsieh said that if the government cannot speedily hand out the money raised from the public, people naturally will be suspicious as to where the NT$400 million (US$12.5 million) raised for the tsunami victims has gone.

In fact, he claimed, the money is still there and he urged the media not to "distort the facts, " saying that what is precious about Taiwan society is that there are a lot of kind and loving people who are willing to help the less fortunate.
If there are legal or institutional stumbling blocks to using the donated funds, then officials must figure out ways of solving the problem, he said.

In order to prevent a similar fiasco from happening again, Hsieh said the government has drafted a new law to govern funds raised for public good, which will be discussed at a Cabinet meeting later this month before being sent to the legislature.
The draft law governs only raising funds for "public good" purposes and does not cover political or religious donations.
The proposed law bans government agencies from initiating a fund-raising activity, an improvement from the current law that was last amended in 1953 and does not ban the government from doing so.
Rather, it allows the government to collect donations from government employees and to handle donations that have been made voluntarily by non-government employees.

Under the proposed law, a fund-raising activity can last no more than a year, and within a month of its conclusion, a report must be sent to the responsible government office. When the funds have been used up, another report must also be filed.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: 9 States in Plan to Cut Emissions by Power Plants
Officials in New York and eight other Northeastern states have come to a preliminary agreement to freeze power plant emissions at their current levels and then reduce them by 10 percent by 2020, according to a confidential draft proposal. Enforcement of emission controls c ould potentially result in higher energy prices in the nine states, which officials hope can be offset by subsidies and support for the development of new technology that would be paid for with the proceeds from the sale of emission allowances to the utility companies.
Wall Street Journal: Course Correction, Behind Citigroup Departures: A Culture Shift by CEO Prince
A series of departures of executives of the Citigroup over the past weeks. People inside and outside the firm are asking: What is going on at Citigroup? The answer, in brief, is that it's being remade. Charles O. Prince, the lawyer who took over two years ago has replaced Citigroup's focus on fast growth, acquisitions and year-to-year earnings gains with a longer-term perspective: shoring up the firm's reputation and regulatory relations with a new concentration on internal controls and ethics.

DOC.HEADLINE: RED CROSS CHIEF DEFENDS USE OF DONATIONS FOR TSUNAMI RELIEF

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the ROC on Wednesday denied that it has been slow in distributing donations for tsunami relief, saying that the money has been earmarked for release over five years. C. V. Chen, president of the Red Cross Society of the ROC, said that the society has collected around NT$730 million (US$22.81 million) for relief, and that NT$150 million, 22 percent, had been spent thus far.

Chen was responding to allegations made by Lin Cheng-hsiu, a former chief of the Bureau of Civil Affairs of the Taipei City Government who leads a team called "Concern for Aceh, Indonesia." Lin said that eight months after the disastrous tsunami in South Asia, the ROC Red Cross Society has shown poor implementation in providing relief.

Chen vehemently denied the charges, adding that the society has cooperated with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent societies to use the money in Indonesia, Sri Lanka and Myanmar for five-year assistance projects. By then, the money used will have reached NT$680 million, or about 93 percent of the donated money.
Chen did not address the issue of the interest the money would have made over that time and where it would go.

The issue of public donations for tsunami relief was put under the spotlight recently after reports revealed that not one NT dollar of the NT$400 million donated to a campaign initiated by the Government Information Office to sponsor children in the tsunami-affected areas has been distributed to the charity groups it commissioned to do the relief work.

Chen went on to point out that a sewage disposal project in Indonesia, the establishment of a shipbuilding factory and a fishing boat construction project in Sri Lanka cannot be completed in a short time.
The assistance to tsunami-affected areas requires long-term work, Chen stressed, and "should not be gauged by the speed of spending money."

Chen also explained that setting aside 2 percent of the donations to use as administrative management fees is in line with the law. If public welfare organizations want to do a good job, they should have the necessary finances to do charity work responsibly, he said. All the fees are spent on air tickets and accommodations for relief workers, as well as communications between the society and the disaster-affected areas.
Chen said that the 100-year-old Red Cross Society will not tolerate unfounded criticism.

Chen also said that there is absolutely no such thing as the Red Cross Society's Taipei branch deducting 15 percent of the donations as a commission, saying that donors receive a receipt for their donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT COOL TO CHINA'S INCENTIVES TO TAIWAN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education reaffirmed the government's stance of dissuading people from studying in China, in spite of Beijing's offer Wednesday of tuition and scholarship incentives to Taiwan students.
China's Ministry of Finance announced that starting next semester, which begins this fall, Taiwan students will only have to pay the same tuition as their mainland Chinese counterparts.
Beijing is also offering 7.2 million yuan (US$864,000) in scholarships to 20 percent of Taiwan students studying in China.
Currently, Taiwan students have to pay much higher tuition to study in China.
In Taipei, Vice Minister of Education Lu Mu-lin repeated the government's policy of not encouraging students to study in China because its diplomas and degrees are not accredited.

Besides, he said, there are no official exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. "If something happens to our students there, it will be very difficult for the government to offer any help," he added.

Therefore, in spite of the many incentives being offered by China, he advised Taiwan students against "the adventure of going to China." However, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) took credit Wednesday for winning the preferential treatment for the people of Taiwan.
KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung welcomed the Chinese announcement, saying China was making good on its word to a KMT delegation that visited Beijing in March.

The KMT delegation, led by Vice Chairman Chiang Ping-kun, reached a 12- point consensus with Taiwan Affairs Office Director Chen Yun-lin that included allowing Taiwan students to pay the same tuition as mainland Chinese students and offering scholarships to Taiwan students.
According to China's statistics, from 1985 to 2000, Chinese colleges and universities recruited 2,895 undergraduate and 864 graduate students from Taiwan.

Between 2001 and 2004, 2,875 Taiwan students attended Chinese higher education institutions while 2,766 others sought master's and Ph.D. degrees. In 2004, the number of Taiwanese students seeking degrees in China reached a high of 1,777.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PACKAGE SHOULD ENTER DISCUSSION STAGE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday he thinks that now is the time for lawmakers to start screening a long-stalled U.S. weapons procurement package.

Wang, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) heavyweight, made the remarks after the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration decided earlier in the day to withdraw the special arms procurement statute and come up with a revised one for legislative approval.

"It's a goodwill response to opposition parties' demands, " Wang said, adding that the move may make it easier to get the opposition-controlled legislature to begin a rational debate on the long-delayed package.

For more than a year, the KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally -- the People First Party (PFP) -- have used their slim majority in the legislature to hold up the special NT$480 billion arms procurement bill, saying that the purchase would spark an arms race with rival China that could bankrupt Taiwan.
Included in the package are eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries.
At its weekly meeting Wednesday, the Cabinet approved a new proposal to finance the arms package, divided between a modified special budget, and the regular defense allocation.

Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said the Ministry of Defense is still working on the details; however, he said the general direction was to move the Patriot missile allocation of more than NT$100 billion from the special budget to the regular defense budget.

Both come from state coffers, but the regular defense budget carries more rigorous oversight provisions, suggesting the DPP administration believes that the new transparency will convince the opposition to drop its long-standing objections to the package.
"The defense ministry will present a new proposal which will promote harmony between the government and the opposition, " Cho quoted Premier Frank Hsieh as saying at Wednesday's Cabinet meeting.

Wang said he is pleased to see the DPP administration finally responding to the opposition camp's call for changing the way the arms package will be funded. Nevertheless, Wang said he is not sure whether the Cabinet's revised funding proposal can receive majority support in the legislature, which will open its new session in mid-September.

Responding to the DPP administration's new funding proposal, both KMT and PFP legislative caucuses said they agreed to let the legislative defense committee begin substantive screening of the arms package during the next legislative session.
Nevertheless, they stressed that they would not necessarily accept all of the DPP-proposed terms.
PFP Legislator Lin Yu-fang, who is a co-convener of the legislative defense committee, said the Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries are still undergoing modifications.

"Is it too much for Taiwan to purchase six sets at one time? Moreover, the United States is now developing a high-altitude intercept system. Is it wise for us to purchase Patriot missiles? As far as arms procurement is concerned, we must also consider our financial structure and whether the United States will offer technological transfers and make reciprocal purchases from Taiwan, " Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MRT COMPANY SUSPECTED OF FALSIFYING DOCUMENTS: CLA

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) is suspected of having falsified documents when it applied to the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to import Thai laborers for its railway project, a senior CLA official said Wednesday.

Kuo Fang-yu, a CLA department chief in charge of occupational training, who is a member of the human rights task force formed by the CLA to investigate the causes of the riot by Thai workers Sunday, told a news conference that KRTC's application shows that the company was going to import the Thai laborers itself.
However, Kuo pointed out, the contract signed between KTRC and Huapan Manpower Consultant and Management Co. shows that the Thai laborers were brought in by Huapan.

This means that KTRC might have falsified the information and that Huapan -- an illegal company not registered with the CLA -- might have violated regulations of the Employment Services Act by importing foreign laborers illegally for KRTC, Kuo said.

Lai Chin-lin, deputy minister of the CLA, who spent Tuesday in Kaohsiung heading the human rights task force that is investigating the riot, confirmed that Huapan is an illegal broker that imports and manages foreign laborers for local companies.
Lai said the task force has asked authorities in Kaohsiung County to collect more concrete evidence before recommending legal action.

Meanwhile, speculation is rife that some heavyweight legislators used their pull to help Huapan get the lucrative contract to import and manage foreign laborers for the MRT construction project and that these legislators and KRTC have been receiving kickbacks from Huapan. Some local newspapers are calling these alleged exploiters "blood suckers."
Tang Chin-chuan, vice minister of the Department of Justice, told news media Wednesday that an investigation will begin to find out whether there is a profiteering racket exploiting foreign laborers.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVIAN FLU TEST REAGENT DEVELOPED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A reagent that can detect the presence of the avian flu virus in 50 minutes has been developed in Taiwan, agriculture official said Wednesday.

Soong Hua-chung, director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the Council of Agriculture (COA), said the reagent, developed jointly by the COA Animal Health Research Institute, the National Chung Hsing University in Taichung County and his bureau, has successfully made sample tests and is ready for commercial production.

The advantage of this new reagent is that it takes only 50 minutes to get results, which is much shorter than with existing methods; therefore, it is an invaluable weapon in the fight against the disease, not to mention that it is more accurate, sensitive and easier to use.

The two methods available now in detecting the avian flu virus are to separate the virus, which takes days, or to use the reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction to find the virus, which takes about four hours.
Both methods need costly equipment and skilled technicians which are affordable only by a few big hospitals, Soong said.
The newly developed reagent can be transported and stored at room temperature and can be used by medical workers easily without the support of sophisticated equipment, Soong said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE ORDERS PROBE INTO KAOHSIUNG MRT RIOT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice has ordered an investigation Wednesday into the riot by some 100 Thai laborers working on the mass rapid transit (MRT) railway project in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Lin Ching-tsung, a prosecutor from the Kaohsiung District Prosecutors' Office, which is responsible for the probe, said his office will also investigate whether kickbacks are being paid in the process of hiring foreign laborers or if the workers are being exploited by labor agents.
The riot began late Aug. 21 at a foreign laborers' dormitory in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County, when MRT management tried to stop some Thai workers from bringing alcohol into the dormitory.
The Thai workers, already dissatisfied with the management, set fire to part of the dormitory and the management office, and attacked policemen and firefighters with stones.

Kaohsiung MRT officials and executives of the Huapan Manpower Consultant and Management Co., which is responsible for the management of these laborers, came to the dormitory Monday morning with the escort of policemen to hold talks with the workers.
The tumult was smoothed over Monday afternoon after the management agreed to many of the demands of the Thai workers.
The riot was covered by several foreign wire services, with Vice President Annette Lu offering an apology for the incident Wednesday.
In addition to the probe on whether government officials were involved in kickbacks, the authorities will also investigate whether the workers were under orders by Thai gangsters or others.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW WTO DEPUTY REPRESENTATIVE NAMED

TEXT.P: Liao Sheng-hsiung, deputy minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, will be transferred to serve as Taiwan's deputy representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Wednesday.
Liao, who has a doctoral degree in political science from Florida State University, will be responsible for political affairs at Taiwan's WTO mission, the ministry said.
Liao will fill the vacancy that has been left for more than a year. Liao said he will do his utmost to fulfill his duty of protecting Taiwan's interests in the WTO.
Taiwan's WTO mission has two deputy representatives. The sitting senior deputy representative is Deng Chen-chung, who is versed in international trade affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF'S 'TAISHANG' SERVICE CENTER TO BE INAUGURATED AUG. 30

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will open a new service center for Taiwan businessmen operating in China, known locally as "taishang, " on Aug. 30, SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General You Ying-lung said Wednesday.
You said the new center will provide all-aspect services for "taishang," including trade, legal, cultural and travel counseling.
Premier Frank Hsieh and Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu will attend the inaugural ceremony to accentuate the government's resolve to strengthen services for "taishang," You said.
The SEF is a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle exchanges with China in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONEY FOR TSUNAMI VICTIMS WILL BE APPROPRIATED AUG. 26: GIO

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao said Wednesday that the first lot of money donated to tsunami victims in Southeast Asia will be appropriated Aug. 26.

Yao made the remarks after visiting two non-governmental organizations -- World Vision Taiwan (WVT) and the Chinese Fund for Children and Families/Taiwan (better known as CCF/Taiwan) -- which are responsible for distributing the donated money to the needy.

A campaign initiated by former GIO Minister Lin Chia-lung to donate money to tsunami victims collected NT$400 million (US$12.5 million) since January, with several NGOs in Taiwan promising to each support 3,000 children in tsunami-affected countries.

However, the GIO has been criticized for the delay in appropriating the money to the NGOs, with Yao denying the inefficiency of the government and claiming that the money has to go through certain appropriation procedures both in government agencies and the private enterprises that made the donations.

WVT President Tu Ming-han and CCF/Taiwan Director Chou Hui-shiang agreed that reports about the delay in money appropriations for so many months after the disaster occurred in late last year were mistakes.
Chou and Tu said their plans to financially support 3,000 tsunami-affected children each have not been affected as claimed by the reports, and other relief work has never stopped.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Aug. 25, or the 19th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1718: The city of New Orleans, named in honor of the Duke of Orleans of France, is founded.
1819: Allan Pinkerton, Scottish-born founder of the famous Pinkerton National Detective Agency in the United States, which specialized in railroad theft, is born.
1822: Sir William Herschel, the German-born English astronomer who discovered the planet Uranus in 1781, dies at the age of 84. He also cataloged more than 800 double stars and 2,500 nebulae.
1825: Uruguay declares independence from Spain.
1867: Michael Faraday, the English chemist and physicist who invented the first electrical cell (battery), dies at the age of 76.
1875: Englishman Matthew Webb makes history by becoming the first person to swim the English Channel. The 27-year-old master mariner covers the 34-km stretch from Dover to Calais in 21 hours 45 minutes.
1900: Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the German philosopher whose written works include "Thus Spake Zarathustra," dies at the age of 55. He reasons that Christianity's emphasis on the afterlife makes its believers less able to cope with earthly life.
1912: The Chung-kuo ke-ming tung-meng hui (Society of the Common Cause) is reorganized as the Kuomintang (Nationalist Party) and holds its inauguration meeting in Beijing.
1917: Dr. Sun Yat-sen forms a military government in Canton, southern China.
1919: The first scheduled international air service begins between Paris and London.
1921: Germany and the United States sign a peace treaty ending the state of war between them.
1930: Sean Connery, the Scottish actor who played the leading role as "007" in seven James Bond movies and won an Oscar for best supporting actor in "The Untouchables," is born.
1940: Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania are incorporated into the Soviet Union.
1943: Lord Louis Mountbatten is appointed Supreme Allied Commander in Southeast Asia.
1944: Paris is liberated when the local German commander, General von Choltitz, surrenders to the Allies, ending a four-year long ordeal that Paris and her citizens suffered at the hands of the Nazis.
1945: Vietnamese communist leader Ho Chi Minh announces the formation of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (DRV).
1989: The spacecraft Voyager 2 beams back to earth pictures of Neptune.
1960: The Republic of China Olympic team carries a large sign reading "Under Protest" in the opening procession of the Olympic Games in Rome to protest the International Olympic Committee's ruling compelling ROC athletes to compete under the name of "Taiwan" instead of the "Republic of China."
1961: The second phase of the Yangmingshan Forum opens to study the ROC's educational and cultural issues.
1968: Lesotho Premier Leabua Jonathan arrives in the ROC for an official visit.
1986: ROC-US trade talks on wine and tobacco imports open in Taipei. Both sides failed to settle disagreements on pricing and advertising for American products during the nine-day talks, and a new round of negotiations was planned.
1991: Byelorussia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1992: Niger's Prime Minister Amadou Cheiffou arrives in the ROC to advance mutual understanding between the two countries.
2001: The opposition People First Party (PFP) unveils the theme of "respect for history, acknowledgment of reality and joint efforts for peace" as the guidelines of its mainland China policy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "For God in giving life to all created things is surely bountiful to them according to their qualities. Hence the tree that is full of life He fosters and sustains, while that which is ready to fall He cuts down and destroys."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAISHANG' TO CELEBRATE MID-AUTUMN FESTIVAL IN TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: A Mid-Autumn Festival gathering for Taiwan businesspeople operating in China will be held at a resort in northern Taiwan next month, You Ying-lung, vice chairman and secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , said Thursday.

You said that the gathering of China-based Taiwan businesspeople, known locally as "taishang," will take place at the Ta Shee Resort in Taoyuan County Sept. 20-21. In addition to the usual golf match, other activities are being planned by the SEF for the two-day event.

The response to this year's gathering has been enthusiastic, You said, adding that between 450 and 500 presidents and officials of taishang associations are expected to attend. This year's Mid-Autumn Festival falls on Sept. 18.
The SEF is a quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle exchanges with China in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREIGHTER RUNS AGROUND OFF PENGHU

TEXT.P: A cargo ship ran aground in waters off Makung Seaport, Penghu County early Thursday morning, with no causalities or damages to the ship reported, a Port of Kaohsiung spokesman said.

The 480-ton freighter "Yenyu," which shuttles between Anping, Tainan, and the outlying island carrying construction materials and daily necessities, encountered heavy fog on its way to Makung Wednesday night and deviated from its set course. The ship ran aground on a reef during its final approach to Makung, according to the spokesman.

Although the strike raised one-third of the ship's hull above the water's surface, it did not cause any injuries to the eight crew aboard or damage to the structure of the ship, the spokesman said, adding that no fuel pollution has been detected so far.

According to a security guard who witnessed the grounding, poor visibility was to blame for the accident. He also suggested that the global positioning system installed onboard the ship might not have been working properly as the ship was well off its set course.

The Port of Kaohsiung will send vessels to help release the stranded ship during flood tide, the spokesman said, adding that it will also carry out further investigations into the cause of the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE ARE 'MASTERS OF TAIWAN, NOT GUESTS': PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian waded into a linguistic debate Thursday by declaring that all of the 23 million on Taiwan are "the masters of Taiwan, not the guests of Taiwan, or Taike."
The term Taike has become the focus of a heated debate in Taiwan as a group of local pop and rock singers prepare to stage a big concert that they have named "Taike Rock and Roll."

Pro-Taiwan independence scholars and experts have denounced the term as derogatory because it was first used by "mainland Chinese gangs" many years ago to describe what they thought to be "uncouth Taiwanese and their culture."

Others have disagreed, claiming that the meaning of a term changes with the times and that Taike has now acquired the meaning of the free-wheeling style of Taiwanese youth, who adore multicultural values and therefore have adopted the term to describe the spirit of their new music, which is intrinsically Taiwanese.
Meeting a group of overseas Taiwanese business leaders, Chen said that instead of being Taike or the guests of Taiwan, "we are brave Taiwanese, hard-working Taiwanese, and dignified Taiwanese."
He urged people to feel proud of being the masters of Taiwan, which is "the root and mother of all Taiwanese businesspeople."

"Only when Taiwan exists can Taiwan businesspeople have a future; only when Taiwan develops can Taiwan businesspeople be protected. This is apparent not only for the businesspeople, but also for all the 23 million people of Taiwan," Chen said.
