DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN URGES KMT TO ABANDON 'ONE CHINA' MYTHOLOGY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged Taiwan's largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), Thursday to abandon its "one China" mythology and bravely embrace the mainstream values of Taiwan identity and the concept of Taiwan above all else.

Chen, meeting a group of overseas Taiwanese business leaders, put forward three proposals for KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to consider. Ma has pledged to rekindle the historical ties between the party and Taiwan before expounding on the party's ideals for all of China.
First, Chen said the KMT should abandon its "one China" mythology entirely if it really wants to relate to Taiwan.
Second, he advised the KMT to give up its tactic of "ruling-opposition struggle" so that cross-Taiwan Strait peace can enter a new phase.
Third, the KMT should squarely face up to its party assets controversy if it is to do justice to society.

Chen said he hopes Ma keeps these proposals in mind while leading the KMT onto a "totally new path" toward a united Taiwan that will be better able to resist China's ambition to annex the island country.
On a practical level, Chen said national defense and cross-strait relations are the two most important areas of policy initiatives for Taiwan that require ruling and opposition cooperation.

At a time when the military balance is tipping in China's favor and when China is unrelentingly launching one after another united-front offensives against Taiwan, ruling and opposition parties in Taiwan must sit down and discuss a common strategy and pass major bills, including one that authorizes the government to buy critical defensive weapons, he pointed out.
A national consensus is also badly needed to establish a "code of conduct" for both the ruling and opposition parties to follow when dealing with China, he added.

He said he does not know what Ma meant when he said the KMT needs to "link up with Taiwan before embarking on discussing its China connection, " but he lauded Ma for promising to "have meaningful dialogue with all the people of Taiwan."
As Taiwan's largest opposition party, Chen warned, if the KMT does not identify itself with Taiwan, it will create a crisis not only for the KMT itself, but also for Taiwan society as a whole.

In the face of China's rapid rise, Chen said Taiwan's real challenge is not the threat from China, but whether domestic unity can be established and maintained. "If we don't unite, and instead create chaos as a result of fighting for partisan interests, we will be giving China more chances to carry out its divide-and-conquer strategy against us," he said.
He emphasized that the transfer of power from one political party to another is neither the result of armed revolution nor a change of dynasties.
Therefore, he added, "Partisan competition is nothing but a democratic choice inside Taiwan, not a power struggle that is often seen as a zero-sum game."

The president said he understands that the KMT, which was formed more than 100 years ago, has its historical legacy, but its leaders must show great determination to reform and transform the party into one that truly dovetails with the sentiments of the majority of people on Taiwan.
"If the party leadership cannot choose to stand on the right side of history, its promise to 'link up with Taiwan' will end up being just empty words," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S PROPAGANDA DRIVE AIMS TO FOOL AMERICANS: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday that by hiring four public relations companies in the United States to improve China's image, Beijing is merely trying to fool the American people.

In an interview with Radio Taiwan International, Chen noted that after Taiwan hired the U.S. PR firm Barbour Griffith & Rogers in March to lobby the U.S government on behalf of Taiwan's interests, Beijing copied Taiwan's strategy and signed contracts with four U.S. PR companies recently, paying these firms large sums of money.

These four PR companies will launch a propaganda drive in the United States to improve China's image by fooling the American people into thinking that China has religious freedom, economic equality and respect for human rights, Chen said, adding, "All these are China's weaknesses."
Taiwan agreed to pay Barbour Griffith & Rogers US$4.5 million for its lobbing services from 2005 to 2008. The PR firm is said to be in good terms with the Republican Party and the White House.

The foreign minister explained that Taiwan needs to make use of lobbing services because unlike China, Taiwan does not have diplomatic relations with the United States. He acknowledged that it remains to be seen how effective the lobbing will be.

Chen said that with full diplomatic ties between China and the United States, China's foreign minister can speak to his counterpart directly on the phone. "The real purpose of China stepping up its propaganda in the United States is to fool the American people, " he reiterated.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL IN U.S. IN SEARCH OF NEW 'STAR INDUSTRY'
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, Texas, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Chang Hui-yen and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The telecommunication sector has the potential to become the next "star industry" in Taiwan following the semiconductor and panel display industries, the director of the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) said Wednesday.

Chen Chao-yi, who is in the U.S. to attend a board meeting of a Taiwan-U.S. joint venture in Texas, noted that his U.S. visit is also aimed at seeking multinational cooperation for Taiwan's future "star industry."

Under the "two-trillion, two-star" project initiated by the ROC government, Taiwan hopes the production value of the semiconductor and display industries exceeds NT$1 trillion (US$31.15 billion) by 2006 and also wants to promote the digital content and biotechnology sectors as "star industries."

Chen noted that the production value of semiconductors in Taiwan has exceeded NT$1 trillion, and that of the display sector is expected to reach NT$1 trillion next year, and now he is searching for the third industry whose production value could also reach NT$1 trillion.

According to Chen, the telecommunication sector may become the next booming industry, as the island has an excellent wireless telecommunication environment, with the mobile phone penetration rate reaching 111 percent.

With its quick development in wireless broadband networking, Taiwan has attracted many global telecommunication giants to consider the island as the best partner in research and development and a good place to use as a test base.
During his stay in Texas, Chen has visited several globally well-known telecommunication companies, and will focus his fact-finding visit on the biotechnology sector in the next few days.

Meanwhile, Chen also revealed that the U.S.-Taiwan joint venture -- Sino Swearingen Aircraft Corp. (SSAC) -- will deliver the first of its orders for SJ30-2 twin engine light business jets by the end of this year.
The SSAC, established in 1995 and headquartered in San Antonio, Texas, has so far received orders for 190 SJ30-2 jets, each worth US$6 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES PRESIDENT TO HONOR HIS OATH TO ROC CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: In response to President Chen Shui-bian's three proposals to Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou urging him to end the party's "one China" mythology, the KMT urged Chen Thursday to honor his oath to the Constitution of the Republic of China which implies the "one China" principle.
Chen also urges the KMT to quit power struggle in parliament and to return it's allegedly ill-gotten assets to the people of Taiwan.

Cheng Li-wen, KMT spokesperson, said since Lien Chan was chairman, the KMT has done its best to handle the party assets issue, and "an absolute majority of the party assets" have already been taken care of.
She reiterated the party's sincerity and determination in handling what remains as questionable assets.

On the president's second proposal, Cheng said the power struggle in the legislature actually originated from "President Chen's style" -- a style that has been formed by Chen's not respecting the Constitution, not respecting the majority in the legislature, and his penchant for inciting ethnic division.
"The ethnic strife that has been fanned before and after President Chen obtained ruling power is a problem that he himself must face candidly," she said.
She said Ma does not feel flattered by Chen's advice, which was conveyed through the media. "If the president continues this mode of communication, the KMT will refuse to respond," she added.
Ma himself thanked Chen for making these suggestions, but also said he will not respond to similar messages in the future that are forwarded by the media.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH DEPARTMENT LOOKING INTO POSSIBLE POISONOUS FAKE RICE WINES

TEXT.P: In response to the recent coverage of fake wine in Hualien County, staff from the county's Department of Health (DOH) brought four bottles of rice wine from the eastern township of Yuli for laboratory tests Thursday.

According to the media, 18 visitors and a number of aboriginal seniors suffered from temporary sight loss and other symptoms after drinking the rice wine offered at different Harvest Festivals in Hualien, where cases of possible fake wine have started to emerge since Aug. 13.
The victims suspected what they had was methanol, a poisonous liquid used as an antifreeze and known to cause blindness, instead of ethanol, the common intoxicating element in beverages.
Liao Chien-chih, a DOH technical specialist in Hualien County, said the bottles had legitimate labels, but that only a laboratory test can determine whether the samples are authentic.

To avoid being victims of the fake wine, consumers should always go to legal retailers and check if the labels on the bottles are clear and intact, Liao suggested. He also asked consumers to stay alert should any of these bottles be sold at an unreasonably low price.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CONFIRMS LAND SALE TO CONSTRUCTION COMPANY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou confirmed Thursday that the party will soon sign a contract to sell land occupied by the KMT's National Development Institute (NDI), the party's school for nurturing future leaders.

Ma made the announcement when pressed by the media about reports that the KMT will soon sell a NT$4.3 billion (US$134.37 million) plot of land to Yuan Lih Construction under the condition that the KMT is responsible for re-zoning the lots so that they can be used for housing. Currently the land is zoned for organizational use.
Ma added that the party has "sufficient reasons" to sell the land at that price.
The NDI, located in the Wenshan district of Taipei, is made up of 28 lots totaling 78,541 square meters. The listed value of the land currently stands at more than NT$5.2 billion (US$185.07 million).
Ma said that he will ask Chang Tze-cheng, the director of KMT's Administration and Management Committee, to report on the details of the sale.
Ma recently said that he will deal with the issue of the party's assets based on "the principles of law, justice and fairness" by 2008 to show the party's resolve in reforming itself.
On what other party assets are to be dealt with and the purpose of their use, Ma only said that the party will make further assessments, and "we'll deal with them when the time is ripe."
He said that the proceeds of the NDI land will first be used for pensions and layoff payments of party workers.
Chan Chuen-po, KMT secretary-general, also said Thursday that the NDI land must be sold, adding, "If we don't sell it now, what are we going to do if we need money."

Chan refuted reports that the NDI land will be sold cheaply, saying that re-zoning the land will require approval from the Urban Planning Commission of the Taipei City Government, and similar commission of the Ministry of the Interior, and that the re-zoning is not a sure thing. "The buyer will have to take this risk," he said.

Chan said that the land transaction was largely a done deal before Ma assumed the party chairman Aug. 19, adding that the party needs money to pay retired party workers and monthly salaries for party workers.
Chan also said that "the transaction has been obstructed all along the way," adding that five open bids had fallen through because no one dared bid.
On the lower than expected money offered for the land, Chan said "If people know you are in dire need of cash, they will certainly not give a good price; this is how the market works."

DOC.HEADLINE: RIOT WILL NOT AFFECT TIES WITH THAILAND: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday that he believes the riot last Sunday in southern Taiwan by Thai laborers will not affect relations between Taiwan and Thailand.

Interviewed by a reporter of Radio Taiwan International, Chen said that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will instruct Taiwan's representative office in Bangkok to tell the government of Thailand the whole truth about the incident and what the government of Taiwan will do to resolve the problems.
Chen acknowledged the contributions by laborers from southeast Asian countries, especially those from Thailand, to Taiwan's important construction projects.

He expressed the belief that Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs, will rally all the details of the riot, so that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs can adequately brief the Thai government via Taiwan's representative in Bangkok.

The Aug. 21 riot at the living quarters of 1,700 Thai laborers in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County, occurred when some 100 Thai workers set fire to a dormitory building and a management office in protest of the harsh restrictions placed on them and the poor living conditions. The incident attracted the attention of news media around the world.

Vice President Annette Lu, in her capacity as head of the Human Rights Advisory Panel of the Presidential Office, went to Kaohsiung County personally and apologized to the Thai laborers for their poor treatment. She urged local police and prosecutors to find those responsible and have them punished according to the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: RANKING POLICE OFFICERS TO GO TO CHINA TO DISCUSS COMBATING CRIME

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said Thursday that ranking police officers will travel to China next month to discuss issues on cross-strait cooperation in combating crime.

Su said that cross-strait cooperation in combating crime is urgent and he believes that China will also be supportive. If the meeting takes place as schedule next month, it will be "the first step toward cross-strait cooperation in combating crime," Su added.
He said both sides of the Taiwan Strait are still discussing which person to send to the meeting and the time and venue.
Su made the remarks when he handed over cash rewards to policemen at Taichung Police Station for helping solve a kidnapping case.

Su said the case involved criminals on both sides of the Taiwan Strait. Su was referring to the abduction of a 10-year-old son of the well-to-do owner of a construction company in Taichung, central Taiwan Aug. 17. Taichung police rescued the hostage and arrested six suspects in a morning raid Thursday. The prime suspect, Chuang Ming-yen, who called the family of the victim in Zhuhai, Guangdong, and asked for a large random, was also said to have been targeted by public security officers in Guangdong.
After kidnapping the boy, Chuang went straight to Guangdong the next day and called from a Zhuhai hotel, thinking that he would not be caught for the crime committed in Taiwan.
Su said criminals might not know that both sides of the Taiwan Strait have established channels to jointly crack down on crime, if no political factors are involved.

Meanwhile, Pingtung County prosecutors said Thursday that when investigating abduction cases committed by Chinese criminals, they unexpectedly found that the criminals had 370 "fake" accounts in Taiwan's financial institutions.
The prosecutors believe that some of the accounts are currently being used for fraud.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TUITION NOT NECESSARILY CHEAPER THAN IN TAIWAN: TU

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng urged Taiwan students Thursday to understand the real reason behind China's offer of tuition incentives, noting that Chinese tuition may in fact not be cheaper than in Taiwan.

Tuition at some Chinese universities exceeds 20,000 yuan or NT$80,000 a semester -- almost double what a Taiwan student pays at a national university -- so people in Taiwan had better wake up from the myth of low education costs in China, he said.
He said he would not claim that the quality of education in Taiwan is better than in China, but he would like people to "see clearly" for themselves.

Tu made the remarks one day after Beijing announced that Taiwan students can pay the same tuition and boarding fees as their Chinese counterparts starting next semester, which begins in the fall. Hong Kong and Macau students are not eligible for the preferential treatment.
He did not specify what China's "real purpose" was in making the announcement, saying "we all know in our mind."

Media handouts given by ministry officials show the number of students attending China's higher education institutes rose rapidly from 1.08 million in 1998 to 4.2 million in 2004, indicating that the quality of education "varies from school to school in such a wide range that Taiwanese students studying there may not be able to enjoy quality services."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD REVIEW ITS FOREIGN LABOR POLICY: KMT LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: An aboriginal legislator from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) on Thursday urged the government to review its foreign labor policy, following the riot caused by Thai laborers working on the mass rapid transit (MRT) railway project in the southern city of Kaohsiung.

Liao Kuo-tung, a convener of the hygiene, environment and social welfare committee in the legislature, suggested the government employ more aborigines in large-scale infrastructure construction projects.
Liao noted that under the country's foreign labor policy, the introduction of foreign workers is to offset the labor shortage in lower levels of work on the island.

However, Taiwan's unemployment rate has been relatively high in recent years, but the number of foreign laborers has been increasing significantly, reflecting the absurd foreign labor policy, Liao said.

For example, he went on, there are more than 10,000 aborigines living in Kaohsiung, but the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) has only employed fewer than 500 aboriginal workers in its construction programs.
Liao said he wondered whether the aborigines do not want to take the job, or if the KRTC just wanted to introduce the foreign workers at a lower cost.

Noting that aboriginal workers have contributed significantly to the island's economic development in the past, Liao expressed the hope that the government can give them another chance to work for that goal.

Meanwhile, an official of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said the agency found that the Huapan Manpower Consultant and Management Co., which is responsible for the management of the Thai laborers, is to blame for improper management.
The official noted that the Huapan, which does not deem itself a labor brokerage firm, did not receive a license from the CLA, resulting in many problems.

Following the incident in Kaohsiung, the CLA decided that such foreign laborers management companies should obtain their permits from the CLA and should be subject to the country's Employment Services Act by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SCIENTISTS USING HERBS AGAINST FISH DISEASES

TEXT.P: Scientists at the Fisheries Research Institute under the Council of Agriculture disclosed Thursday that they have found 15 herbal extracts that can curb marine vibrio bacteria -- a risk to both salt-water fish and humans.

The scientists said they have conducted a series of tests using numerous herbs produced under good manufacturing practice (GMP) regulations promulgated by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, to see if they are effective against vibriosis, pasteurellosis and streptococcicosis -- diseases that are common among groupers, cobia and salt-water shrimps.
So far, the tests have proved that 15 herbs can effectively control vibrio bacteria.

They said that developing herbal medicines to treat fish diseases is the right approach for the fishing industry because of the need to reduce the widespread over-use of antibiotics and chemical drugs.

Some countries have already begun to use herbs to treat animal diseases. For example, in the United States, extracts of garlic and onion are being used to prevent parasites growing in salmon and trout, they pointed out.
The scientists said Taiwan must also pursue this avenue if it wants to make its agriculture safe.

DOC.HEADLINE: `EQUAL TREATMENT' KEY TO FOREIGN LABOR MANAGEMENT: FPG

TEXT.P: Treating foreign laborers "the same" as their local counterparts and establishing smooth communication channels are the keys to foreign laborer management, an official of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) said Thursday.
Wu Hsin-tze, an FPG manager at the group's sixth naphtha cracker in the Mailiao Industrial Zone in Yunlin, southern Taiwan, made the remarks when he briefed Yunlin Magistrate Lee Chin-yung.

Lee was inspected the industrial zone out of concern for the conditions endured by foreign laborers and their management in the zone in the wake of the riot by Thai laborers working for Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. Sunday over their grossly inhumane treatment.
Wu noted that the FPG has eight years of experience in hiring foreign laborers, and based on its experience, humane management is paramount, he said.

Wu noted that Mailiao is quite windy and that working conditions are too harsh for most local workers. If the government had not allowed the introduction of foreign laborers to help the construction of the sixth naphtha cracker, it could not have been completed as scheduled, he said.
The contribution of foreign laborers to the sixth naphtha crackers is enormous, he added.
Wu claimed that the group manages its foreign laborers fairly, saying it provides air conditioning in their dormitories, separate shower rooms, familiar food of high quality, and regular outings.

Mailiao currently has more than 4,800 foreign workers, with 1,700 Filipinos and 3,100 Thai workers. The FPG respects their customs and religious beliefs, invites priests to preside over worship for Filipino workers, and sets up Buddhist altars for Thai laborers, he said.
The FPG also explains the details of pay to foreign laborers, in English to Filipino laborers and in Thai to the Thai workers, Wu said.

The Maoliao Industrial Zone only has needs for foreign laborers when it is undergoing expansion. The foreign laborers stay in the zone mainly for the 4th stage of expansion work, After its completion, the foreign laborers will have to return home. It is expected that all of them will return by the end of next year, he added.
Mailiao Industrial Zone saw its peak of foreign laborer employment in 1998, when the number of foreign laborers employed reached more than 20,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO ROOM FOR REVALUATION OF TAIWAN'S CURRENCY: CENTRAL BANK

TEXT.P: Taiwan recorded a much smaller trade surplus for the first seven months of this year than neighboring countries, leaving no room for its currency to be revalued, a spokesman for the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) said Thursday.

Statistics released by the CBC show that Taiwan's trade surplus for the January-July period totaled only US$751 million, much less than Japan's US$50.35 billion, China's US$50 billion, the US$14.42 billion for South Korea and the US$8.6 billion for Singapore.
The spokesman pointed out that in July alone, Taiwanese tourists spent US$924 million abroad, exceeding the nations's trade surplus for the first seven months of this year.
As a result, there is simply no room for the new Taiwan dollar to be revalued against other currencies, he said.
The exchange rate of the NT dollar dropped 1.3 cents against the greenback Thursday to close at NT$32.293.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PROSPECTS WILL IMPROVE THIS YEAR: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic prospects in the second half of the year will be better than the past half-year in view of the nation's sound economic structure, President Chen Shui-bian predicted Thursday.
Chen made the remarks at the Presidential Office while receiving a group of representatives from companies that have received awards for excellence.

Noting that Taiwan, which depends on foreign trade, has enjoyed a high trade surplus during previous years, Chen said a slight decrease in trade surplus in the first half of this year has attracted much attention from the public.
He said the decrease in trade surplus was not because of the decline in exports, but due to the considerable increase in the value of imports as a result of rising oil prices.
Stressing that Taiwan's economic structure is sound, Chen said the economy will grow moderately in the second half of the year, barring drastic changes in the international situation.
However, he said economic development and even national security will hinge on obtaining a secure and stable energy supply, as more than 95 percent of Taiwan's energy is imported.

Citing a report prepared by the United States about China's military power, Chen said China's consumption of crude oil and natural gas only accounts for 26 percent of its total energy, with its imported oil accounting for only 40 percent of its total petroleum consumption.
Despite this, the Chinese government still warned its people that the shortage of petroleum and natural gas has limited its economic and social development, Chen added.
In comparison, Chen said, it is more urgent for Taiwan to review its energy policy in order to reduce the negative impact of possible energy price fluctuations.

In addition to increasing the efficiency of energy available, the government should offer incentives for prive enterprises to develop renewable energy sources such as hydro, wind and solar power in order to make Taiwan a real "green silicon island," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. BID PUBLICITY FOCUSES ON TAIWAN STRAIT PEACE: GIO

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) said Thursday that an international publicity blitz will be launched next Monday to drum up support for Taiwan's bid to re-join the United Nations.
GIO Minister Pasuya Yao said at a news conference that the publicity campaign will focus on two themes -- Taiwan's participation and peace in the Taiwan Strait.
The GIO has designed two posters -- "The U.N. can bring peace in the Taiwan Strait" and "UNHappy 60th Birthday" -- for advertising in foreign print media and on billboards, Yao said.

The "UNHappy 60th Birthday" poster carries a subtitle "Can a family be happy with one member missing? " to symbolize that the United Nations is "unhappy" on its 60th birthday because of Taiwan's expulsion from the world body, Yao explained.

When the United Nations was founded in 1945, the Republic of China was one of its founding members. However, the ROC has been shut out of the body since 1971 when U.N. Resolution No. 2758 gave the "China" seat to the People's Republic of China at the ROC's expense.
"Taiwan has no way of participating (in the U.N.'s 60th birthday Sept. 13), even though it has more inhabitants than 140 U.N. members, " Yao said.

Since 1993, Taiwan has tried every year to ask the U.N. Steering Committee, through its diplomatic allies, to place Taiwan's U.N. bid on the General Assembly agenda. Taiwan has been unsuccessful every time because of the PRC's obstruction.

Yao said the two posters will form the backdrop for newspaper and magazine ads to be debuted in New York, Washington, Tokyo and Brussels from Aug. 29 and he added his hope that world leaders attending next month's U.N. General Assembly session will take notice.
This year, Yao said, the GIO will cooperate with Time Magazine for the first time in publishing "coverwrap" ads to promote Taiwan's U.N. bid.
Moreover, Yao said, the GIO has produced two 30-second broadcast ads to be aired on New York's WABC radio station from early September for two weeks.
In the "U.N. can bring peace in the Taiwan Strait" poster, the GIO points out that the founding of the United Nations in 1945 was a commitment to peace after years of war, referring to World War II.

"Now China openly threatens Taiwan by passing its anti-secession law, which sets the conditions for the use of force against Taiwan. Only the U.N. can act as a forum for maintaining security and peace," the poster reads.
Meanwhile, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said earlier in the day that 14 of the ROC's diplomatic allies have lent support behind the nation's U.N. bid this year.

With a view to attracting more international attention to China's threat to Taiwan, Chen said the ROC's allies have presented two cases to the U.N. Secretariat this year -- Taiwan's U.N. membership and the Taiwan Strait peace.
Chen said the "peace" case calls for the U.N. to take precautionary measures to prevent any conflict in the Taiwan Strait for the sake of maintaining regional security and stability.
Chen said the government is seeking U.S. and Japan support for this new case in hopes that the U.N. General Assembly will formally discuss the Taiwan Strait issue during its upcoming meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN LAWMAKERS TO MEET REGULARLY TO DISCUSS SECURITY ISSUES

TEXT.P: A convener of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee said Thursday that its counterparts in the Japanese Diet have agreed to have regular exchanges of visits.
Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lee Wen-chung made the remarks after an eight-member delegation led by him returned to Taiwan after concluding a four-day visit to Japan.

The delegation also included DPP legislators Sheng Fa-hui and Tang Huo-sheng, opposition Kuomintang legislators Ker Chun-hsiung, Liao Wan-jui and Ting Shou-chung, People First Party Legislator Ku Chung-lien, and Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Ho Min-hao.

Lee said the delegation met with key members of the Japanese Lower House Security Committee and the Upper House Foreign and Defense Affairs Committee and they agreed to have regular annual meetings to discuss security issues involving the two countries.
The delegation also met with more than a dozen retired generals from Japanese think tanks.
Noting that military exchanges between Taiwan and Japan have been suspended for some time, Lee said the visit has reopened the door for mutual exchanges.
He said earlier that Japan's attitude toward Taiwan has undergone subtle changes in the face of a rising China.

Japan has been "soft" toward China in the past and only began to attach greater importance to security in the Taiwan Strait in the last two or three years, out of concern that a cross-strait conflict would cut the lifelines of its foreign trade and oil supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT 'WILL NOT CREATE TENSION' WITH CHINA: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh claimed Thursday that the government "will not create tension" while seeking rapprochement with China, a move he said will create a win-win situation for both Taiwan and China.

Hsieh made the remarks at a ceremony citing outstanding exporters and importers. He said that since he became premier, he has been advocating the concept of rapprochement and symbiosis for domestic politics and cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

He said he has also emphasized the idea that once you are in charge, you are not supposed to be a troublemaker -- even if the government is condemned, government officials must show patience in order to maintain political stability, he said.
He added that the government needs to improve on many fronts and he expressed hope that the public will support a government that knows how to improve itself.
The government must not create tension but must instead maintain peace across the Taiwan Strait so that businesses can prosper in a stable environment, he added.

Hsieh said the government has offered to lend NT$200 billion (US$6.19 billion) to the nation's small- and medium-sized businesses, in addition to encouraging banks to extend loans to them, as part of the government's program to revive the economy.
For individuals, the government has set up a NT$300 billion fund from which first-time home buyers can borrow money at low interest rates, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER CALLS FOR CLOSER TAIWAN-FRANCE TIES

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday he looks forward to improved relations between Taiwan and France for mutual benefits.
"France has been forging closer ties with China in recent years. I hope Taiwan-France ties can grow at a pace parallel to that of Chinese-French relations," Chen said.
The minister made the remarks while presiding over a swearing-in ceremony for Taiwan's new representative to France, Yang Tzu-pao, and several other foreign mission chiefs.

Yang, who has a doctoral degree in civil engineering from a French national university, has been secretary-general of the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and deputy minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.

During his ICDF tenure, Chen said, Yang initiated many new programs and injected new vitality to the fund, which is dedicated to offering aid and promoting agricultural and technological cooperation with other developing countries.
Noting that France is a key member of the European Union, Chen said he is hopeful that Yang can formulate new strategies to boost exchanges and cooperation with France.
Yang, who speaks fluent French and has extensive ties with France, said Taiwan-France ties are in good shape. Nevertheless, he added, there is still ample room for improvement.
Given the fact that Taiwan is France's fourth-largest trading partner in Asia, Yang said he will do his utmost to push France to further strengthen cooperative ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE EDUCATION MINISTER VISITS POLAND FOR EDUCATIONAL EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Education Fan Sun-lu visited Poland's Ministry of Education Thursday, and agreed with her Polish counterpart to strengthen educational and cultural exchanges.

Fan, who arrived in Poland Aug. 23, said her visit is also aimed at giving moral support to Taiwanese students who were participating in the 17th International Olympiad in Informatics held in Nowy Sacz Aug. 18-25.

During her stay, Fan also met presidents of several Polish universities, including Warsaw University, with both sides agreeing to strengthen various cooperation projects in view of the increasing number of Taiwanese students studying in Poland.

The Taiwanese and Polish governments have offered scholarships to each others' students for many years. This year, a total of 15 Polish students have obtained scholarships from the Republic of China government, focusing on economics.
The Polish government offers scholarships to eight Taiwanese students each year, according to Fan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR OFFICIAL APOLOGIZES TO NATION OVER THAI LABORERS' RIOT
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's highest labor affairs official apologized Thursday to the nation for failing to do a good supervising job, resulting in Sunday's riot by Thai laborers in protest of their maltreatment by their employers and a brokerage company.

Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), made the apology when she was addressing a gathering in a village for foreign laborers in Taoyuan County owned by Golden Brother International Co., a foreign labor brokerage firm.
Although she claimed the riot was a "single, isolated incident," she admitted the incident has damaged Taiwan's image around the world in the area of human rights.

Chen, who has served in her current post for five years, said the CLA has begun a nationwide review of the treatment of foreign laborers and will send inspectors all over Taiwan to examine the living and working environments of foreign laborers.
"We hope to protect the foreign workers and make sure that similar incidents do not happen again," she said.

Chen declined to comment on speculation that there is an illegal profiteering racket between the employer -- Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. -- and the brokerage firm Huapan Co., that exploits the Thai laborers, saying only that local prosecutors are looking into the allegations.

Meanwhile, Ling Po-chih, chief prosecutor of the Kaohsiung District Attorney's Office, reported to State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao that his office has finished the initial round of investigation and will next week begin to interview those suspected of being responsible for the inhumane treatment of the Thai laborers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS WIN 3 SILVER MEDALS IN INFORMATICS OLYMPIAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan students won three silver medals and one bronze medal in the 17th International Olympiad in Informatics (IOI) held in Nowy Sacz, Poland, Aug. 18-25.
The IOI is an annual computer science competition for talented senior-high school students.
This year, Taiwan sent four senior high students to the competition in which 276 students from 70 countries participated.

The three silver medalists are Lin Chun-ta from National Tainan First Senior High School, and He Yu-fan and Feng Chun-sun from Chienkuo High School in Taipei, and the bronze medalist is Su Hsin-hao from Kaohsiung Municipal Senior High School.
Lin and Su, who participated in the 2004 IOI, have been admitted to National Taiwan University and National Tsinghua University, respectively, due to their excellence.
The four students will visit various other Polish cities for educational exchanges before returning home Aug. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: PICKING HEIR NOT DEMOCRATIC: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the popularly elected head of state in a democracy does not hand-pick an heir or successor.

"The issue of a popularly elected president picking an heir does not exist in democratic politics. In a democracy, the ruling mandate comes from the people. While I am in office I must fulfill my duty. I cannot let down our voters," Chen said.

The president made the remarks while meeting with members of a youth camp organized by the Ketagalan Institute, which he founded in 2003 as an independent educational institution for promoting civic values through education and policy research.
Noting that he still has more than two years left in office, Chen said he will not be remembered as a lame-duck president.

"Instead, I'll remain active and diligent. I have many visions and programs to accomplish. I won't let down my supporters, " Chen said as he assured his young guests of his resolve to push for Taiwan's further advancement.

Speculation about the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidate for the 2008 presidential election has been rife since the popular mayor of Taipei, Ma Ying-jeou, decisively won the chairmanship of the main opposition Kuomintang to emerge as the party's most likely candidate for the next presidential election. Chen's remarks were seen as part of his efforts to alleviate pressure on him to delegate more power to DPP hopefuls ahead of the 2008 race.

DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB BEGINS PROBES INTO THREE RECENT SCANDALS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) said Thursday it has begun probes into three high-profile scandals that have grabbed media attention.

The three cases are Sunday's riot by Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit system, a water supply crisis in the northern county of Taoyuan and a delay in the distribution of donations to tsunami victims.

MJIB officials said the bureau's Kaohsiung office has been investigating who instigated Sunday's riot and allegations that there is an illegal profiteering racket between the employer -- Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. -- and the brokerage firm Huapan Co., that exploits the Thai laborers.

In the case of the Taoyuan water crisis, the officials said, the MJIB's Taoyuan office will look into whether anybody should be held responsible for the excessive land exploitation that resulted in high turbidity in the Shihmen reservoir -- Taoyuan's main water supply source -- and rendered the reservoir's water treatment facilities inoperable.

As for the seven-month delay in tsunami fund distribution, the officials said, the MJIB will probe whether any irregularities were involved in appropriations of funds raised by the Government Information Office early this year to help tsunami victims in South and Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO HELP RETURNING BUSINESSMEN INVEST IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday it has forged a new mechanism to help returning entrepreneurs invest in Taiwan again.

Officials from the MOEA's Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) Administration said they have found a new trend that some local businessmen who relocated their production facilities to China or other countries around the world a decade ago have returned to Taiwan to find new investment opportunities.
While some of this group of businessmen are successful abroad, others have suffered setbacks in their overseas business adventures, the officials said.
Those who have succeeded abroad mainly want to take advantage of the incentives offered by the government to upgrade their operations and expand their global market niches, the officials said.
As for those who suffered setbacks abroad, the officials said, they hope to get a new start at home.

Noting that Taiwan has transparent regulations, skilled work force, efficient factory management, stringent quality control and convenient infrastructure, the officials said many overseas Taiwan businessmen are more than willing to return so long as they can find attractive investment opportunities.

Against this backdrop, the officials said, the MOEA's SMEs department has fleshed out a new service mechanism to offer professional assistance to returning entrepreneurs, including land acquisition and legal counseling.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Rents Head Up as Home Prices Put Off Buyers
Rents are rising again across the United States, squeezing tenants who are already coping with high gasoline prices and improving returns to landlords after a deep five-year slump. The tu rnaround appears to be another sign that the boom in house prices and sales is finally slowing, as homes have become so expensive in many metropolitan areas that some people have decided to rent instead. Rents in about 85 percent of large metropolitan areas have climbed in the last year.
Wall Street Journal: Hard Lessons, As Teachers Sock Money Into 403(b)s, Few Defenses Exist
Around 1.9 million public-school employees across the United States, mostly teachers, have 403(b) retirement plans, which provide investors far fewer protections than 401(k) plans. Weakly regulated and frequently saddled with high fees, the 403(b) market is now the scene of numerous fights over alleged wrongdoing by the plans' private vendors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Aug. 26, or the 22nd day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: The French Assembly adopts the Declaration of the Rights of Man.
1850: Louis Philippe, the "Citizen King" of France who abdicated rather than face a middle-class revolt, dies.
1858: Britain and Japan sign the Treaty of Edo (Tokyo), opening up Japan to British trade.
1873: Lee De Forest, American radio and television pioneer and inventor of the Audion vacuum tube, which made broadcasting possible, is born.
1906: Albert Bruce Sabin, American microbiologist and physician, is born in Poland. He developed a live-virus vaccine against polio in 1957, replacing the killed-virus vaccine invented by Jonas Salk.
1910: American physicians verify that the X-ray, discovered in 1895 by German physicist Wilhelm C. Roentgen, can help detect lung disease.
1920: The US legislature ratifies the 19th Amendment, giving American women the right to vote.
1926: Warner Brothers, an American movie company, is successful with its premiere sound picture.
1936: Egypt and Great Britain agree to a treaty that reaffirms Egypt's independence. This treaty also reduces the number of British troops stationed in Egypt and restricts them to the Suez Canal region.
1952: The Soviet Unions announces that the first successful Intercontinental Ballistic Missile (ICBM) tests have taken place.
1961: Burma becomes the world's first Buddhist republic.
1972: Sir Francis Chichester, English yachtsman who was the first senior citizen to sail around the world alone in his 53-foot yacht in 1966, dies at the age of 71.
1974: Charles Lindbergh, American aviator who made the first solo non-stop flight across Atlantic in 1927, dies at the age of 72.
1977: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo receives Richard Holbrooke, US assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific affairs, at the Executive Yuan for a briefing on Secretary of State Cyrus Vance's trip to Peking.
1978: Cardinal Albino Luciani of Venice is elected as Pope John Paul I. He died of a heart attack on Sept. 28.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo decorates visiting vice president of the Republic of Costa Rica Jose Miguel Alfaro Rodriguez with the Order of the Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon.
1987: A sex-crazed elephant "urgently in search of a mate" runs amuck in Bangkok, killing two people and flattening a radio center.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin signs a friendship treaty with the Czech Republic after condemning the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.
1996: Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, formally divorces Princess Diana Frances Spencer, ending 15 years of marriage.
1996: A court in Seoul sentences former President Chun Doo Hwan to death on charges of masterminding a 1979 coup and his successor, Roh Tae Woo, is sentenced to 22 years and six months in prison for playing a supporting role. Their prison terms were reduced later.
2001: Seven Democratic members of the U.S. House of Representatives write a letter to State Secretary Madeleine Albright, requesting that the State Department "take the necessary steps to end the inappropriate ban on high-level visits between elected Taiwanese officials and U.S. officials, including the democratically-elected president of Taiwan."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "He who possesses exceedingly great moral qualities will certainly receive the divine call to the Imperial throne."

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC MANUFACTURERS MORE OPTIMISTIC IN JULY

TEXT.P: Despite skyrocketing oil prices, the percentage of domestic manufacturers in July who had a positive view of Taiwan's business conditions was up significantly over the level seen in June, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) reported Friday.

The results of a TIER survey released Friday show that 41 percent of domestic manufacturers had a positive view in July, up 17 percentage points over the figure seen in a similar survey a month earlier.
Only 27 percent of respondents in the July survey said they have a negative view of Taiwan's business conditions, down 3 percentage points from June's survey.
Meanwhile, 45 percent of domestic manufacturers in the July survey said they are optimistic about their business prospects over the next six months, up from 41 percent in June.
However, 20 percent of the respondents expressed a negative view, up from 13 percent in the June survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STATE DEPARTMENT MUM ON AIT HEAD APPOINTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department on Thursday refused to comment on media reports that a former director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) will serve as its chairman and managing director.

The Central News Agency has learned from a reliable source that Raymond Burghardt, who served as AIT Taipei office director from 1999 to 2001, is expected to become the new head of the institute, a quasi-official U.S. organization handling exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two countries.
But a State Department official said in response to the reports that the department has no announcement about Burghardt's new job, saying only that the appointment should come from the AIT.

Burghardt, a retired career diplomat, who has served as U.S. consul-general in Shanghai as well as deputy chief of the U.S. embassies in Seoul and Manila and U.S. ambassador to Vietnam, became earlier this year a department head at the East-West Center in Hawaii.
The AIT chairmanship vacancy has yet to be filled following the resignation of Therese Shaseen in April 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC PRESIDENT'S UPCOMING U.S. VISIT 'NOT A STATE VISIT': WHITE HOUSE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The White House reiterated Thursday that the upcoming visit of People's Republic of China President Hu Jintao to the United States is not a "state visit."
Beijing announced the same day that Hu is scheduled to visit the United States Sept. 5-8.
In response to a question regarding Hu's visit at a regular press briefing, White House deputy spokesman Trent Duffy said that "it is not a state visit; it is not an official state visit."
Some Washington-based think tanks have said that Beijing cares greatly about how Washington defines Hu's first visit to the United States since assuming the Chinese presidency in 2003.

According to the think tanks, the White House's reiteration of not recognizing Hu's upcoming U.S. visit as an official state visit is related to the current anti-Chinese sentiments in the United States and Beijing's passage in March of an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN HOPES TO MEET PFP COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Chan Chuen-po, secretary-general of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , on Friday conveyed to his People First Party (PFP) counterpart that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou hopes to meet with PFP Chairman James Soong.

Chin Chin-sheng, PFP secretary-general, said that it is only "natural" for the two chairmen to meet, adding that after Soong's return from his visit to the United States, both sides can start to discuss and arrange the matter.

Chin, accompanied by his deputy, Liao Chang-sung, and Hsieh Kung-ping, director of the PFP's Department of Culture and Information, called on Chan at the KMT headquarters. Also on hand to welcome Chin were Liao Feng-teh, director of the KMT Department of Organization and Development, and Cheng Li-wen, director of the Department of Culture and Information.
Chin said that he had come to congratulate Ma and Chan on behalf of Soong.
Chan, a veteran KMT official, was appointed by new KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou last week. He expressed appreciation for Chin's visit, saying that they used to be colleagues and had cooperated closely.
Chan served as campaign office director when former KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong formed a ticket to run in the 2004 presidential election.

Chan said after the meeting that both sides exchanged views on possible communications and cooperation, stressing that there should be a mechanism for bilateral cooperation and that both sides will honor their promises.

For his part, Chin said that the two sides exchanged views on a wide range of issues and that it is hoped that the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP will win the year-end city and county head elections as well as the hearts of the people.

Chin also said that the PFP will sponsor a cross-strait forum in Shanghai Sept. 14-16, expressing the hope that Chan and scholars of related think tanks will contribute valuable views to the participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: MATSU RESIDENTS CONCERNED ABOUT PLANNED TROOP REDUCTION

TEXT.P: Residents of Matsu are concerned about a Ministry of National Defense (MND) plan to cut the number of troops stationed on the outlying island to less than 5,000 by 2008, local government sources said Friday.
The planned cut is part of the MND's second-stage military restructuring project aimed at establishing an elite deterrent force in the face of China's threat.

According to the MND's newly sanctioned restructuring plan, the total number of military personnel stationed on the three outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu will be trimmed to about 10,000 by 2008.

Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Tsao Erh-chung from the Matsu constituency has on many occasions voiced his opposition to any plan for major troop cuts on Matsu which lies closer to China's southeastern province of Fujian than to Taiwan proper.

"Unless China renounces the option of using force against Taiwan, we should not unilaterally disarm ourselves. Without adequate defense deployment, Matsu's security will be at stake, " Tsao said at a Legislative Yuan news conference earlier this week.

Chen Shu-lien, president of the Matsu Chamber of Commerce, and several senior executives of the organization paid a visit to Lienchiang County Magistrate Chen Shui-sheng Thursday to express their concern about the MND's troops reduction plan.

"Because of the government's gradual reduction of garrison troops in Matsu in recent years, Chinese fishing boats have often poached in waters near Matsu or even come ashore for illegal trading. If the number of troops is cut further, the security situation will get even worse," Chen Shu-lien said.
Worse still, he said, Matsu's economic development will also be seriously affected if the number of garrison troops is further trimmed.

The Matsu island group is under the jurisdiction of the Lienchiang County Government. It has only a limited number of civilian residents. For years, its economy has relied heavily on garrison troops' consumption.
For security and economic well-being, Chen Shu-lien urged the county government to push the central government and the MND to rethink the Matsu troop reduction plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOOD EXPORTS TO SOUTH KOREA ON FAST TRACK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports of foods and related products to South Korea are now on a fast customs and quarantine track after the Korean Food and Drug Administration (KFDA) struck an agreement with the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs for cooperation.

After recognizing Taiwan's food inspection standards, the KFDA agreed recently that imports of Taiwan foods and related products to South Korea need not to be re-inspected at customs so long as those products come with inspection certificates issued by the BSMI and three other BSMI branches in Keelung, Tainan and Kaohsiung, a bureau spokesperson said Friday.

Taiwan is currently one of the few countries, including Australia, Finland and the United States, whose food exports to South Korea enjoy fast track customs and quarantine inspection procedures, the BSMI official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD SAYS MEETING WITH PFP CHIEF SHOULD TAKE PLACE AT RIGHT TIME

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that he would like to meet with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong but that such a meeting should only take place "when the time is right."

Noting that Soong has yet to return to Taiwan from his trip to the United States, Ma said he feels there is no need to press the matter. When "everyone feels the time is right," then "we can meet and work something out," he added.
Ma's words came against the background that supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP hope that the two parties can work closely, if not to integrate soon.

Asked about the content of Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun's recent call to him to solicit support for the arms procurement package, Ma said the matter involves a budget and a bill and must be left for the Legislative Yuan to discuss.
The arms procurement bill has been stalled in the legislature for two consecutive sessions because of the opposition of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and PFP.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SUPPORTS PROBE INTO THAI LABORERS' RIOT

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office issued a statement Friday expressing support for a probe into Sunday's riot by Thai laborers in protest of maltreatment by their employers and a brokerage company.

In the terse statement, the Presidential Office said the incident involved not only a labor-management dispute and infringements on the rights of foreign laborers, it has also affected social order and the national image.

It noted that the prosecutors have started the investigation, that both President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu have attached great importance to the incident and that they support the probe, believing that the deficiencies should be improved upon and that the irregularities must be exposed and addressed.

The statement came amid media reports that Chen Che-nan, a national policy adviser to the president, is involved in an illegal profiteering racket between the employer -- Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. -- and the brokerage firm Huapan Co., that exploits the Thai laborers.
Chen is a former deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office as well as father of acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai.

Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said Friday that the law enforcement authorities should get to the bottom of the incident and not flinch because of the so-called "heavyweight" stature of the alleged culprit.

TSU Legislator Kuo Lin-yung said it was Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu who first mentioned that an unidentified political heavyweight might be involved in the brokering of foreign laborers, but she later dodged questions on the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAWMAKERS VISIT U.S. NUCLEAR WASTE DUMP
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan legislators paid a visit to a permanent nuclear waste storage facility in Nevada Thursday in an effort to collect useful tips on Taiwan's handling of radioactive waste.

Accompanied by officials from the U.S. Department of Energy, the lawmakers, headed by Legislator Chiu Yung-jen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, spent several hours touring the Yucca Mountain Repository, located about 160 km northwest of Las Vegas, and being briefed by the facility's authorities.

According to these authorities, the nuclear waste dump is built in an area not only far from densely populated cities but also an area where geological conditions is stable, making it suitable for storage of hazardous materials.

So far, they said, the Department of Energy has spent US$8 billion developing the underground dump, which is planned to be fully completed in 10 years. After it is finished, the Yucca Mountain Repository will be used to store all nuclear reactors and radioactive waste that is currently stored in 131 smaller facilities scattered across America. It is estimated that it will remain safe for 10,000 years.
Nuclear power plants provide about 20 percent of the electricity used in the United States.

Chiu said the visit by the legislators, all members of the Legislative Yuan's Science and Information Technology Committee, is aimed at emulating the U.S. experience and working out a policy that will solve Taiwan's nuclear waste problems once and for all.

State-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) has in recent years prepared to remove over 97,000 barrels of low-level radioactive waste from Lanyu, which lies off the southeastern Taiwan coast, as the lease on its storage site has expired.
The waste, produced by Taipower's three nuclear power plants over 20 years, is scheduled to be inspected and repacked by the end of 2010.

Taipower has contacted authorities from home and abroad for the treatment and disposal of its nuclear waste over the past several years, including Russia, North Korea and Taiwan's offshore islet of Wuchiu.

After the visit to Yucca Mountain, Chiu and his group proceeded to the Hoover Dam, also in Nevada, to see whether Taiwan can borrow any ideas from the dam that can help Taiwan streamline water conservation and related efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON DISASTER PREVENTION HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A seminar on disaster prevention, co-organized by the National Disaster Prevention and Relief Commission under the Executive Yuan and the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, was held in Taipei Friday.
The one-day event was held to bring together private and governmental disaster relief experts to exchange views on how to step up disaster prevention and emergency rescue efforts.
During the seminar, Chen Wu-hsiung, deputy chief of the National Fire Administration under the Ministry of the Interior, offered ideas for private rescue teams when they carry out relief work.
Meanwhile, a Red Cross program manager from Denmark, Leif Dierks, shared his experience of coordination between private rescue teams and governmental rescue teams.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER OFFICIAL DENIES INVOLVEMENT IN FOREIGN LABOR KICKBACKS

TEXT.P: A former deputy secretary-general to the Presidential Office denied vehemently Friday that he was involved in any kickbacks in the supply of foreign laborers for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC).

Chen Che-nan issued an angry statement amid media reports that he was involved in the illegal profiteering racket between the employer -- KRTC -- and the brokerage firm Huapan Co., that exploits Thai laborers.
Chen, father of acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai, claimed that the reports were "unfounded."

The reports noted that Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit system was inaugurated in March 2001. As the project requires a large number of foreign laborers over a long period, brokerage operators had solicited hard for the chance to share a piece of the pie.
KRTC Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien later decided to handle the matter himself, shutting out other brokerage firms.
Chen denied media reports that he was involved in the profiteering racket, claiming that the media did not verify their reports properly.

On reports that he went with a brokerage operator to Thailand on luxury trips, Chen claimed that he only went to Thailand once in recent years and that was with a friend last November during which he paid his own expenses.
He denied trying to use his influence to sway anything during his entire career and that if there is "any trace of truth in the outrageous reports," he is willing to accept the harshest punishment.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT URGES PUBLIC TO BE KIND TO FOREIGN LABORERS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged the public Friday to "be kind" to foreign laborers in Taiwan.

The vice president, a longstanding advocate of human rights, made the appeal while attending a seminar with county magistrates on Sunday's riot by Thai laborers working for Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corporation who finally snapped as a result of the gross and inhumane treatment by their management company.

Calling for the public to disregard national boundaries and to be kind to foreign laborers, Lu said the Taiwan people should feel thankful for the foreign laborers, who have made great contributions to the country, and should treat them "as compatriots."
Pointing out that Taiwan does not show sufficient concern about foreign laborers and that they are heavily discriminated against, the vice president said that "we must undergo self-examination."
Furthermore, she admitted that Taiwan needs foreign laborers to do the jobs Taiwanese do not want to do in the manufacturing and infrastructure sectors.

Lu expressed hope that the riot by Thai laborers in Kaohsiung was a "unique case" and called for the authorities to deal with it, including the allegations of official corruption surrounding the hiring of the laborers.
She also said Taiwan should take action to protect foreign laborers and foreigners married to Taiwanese spouses.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 26.89 points to close at 6,136.55.
The bourse opened at 6,130.83 and fluctuated between 6,148.95 and 6,107 during trading. A total of 2.66 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$62.95 billion (US$1.94 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 2.1 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.4 percent, textile stocks at 1.2 percent, banking and financial shares and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.5 percent and plastics and chemical shares at 0.2 percent.
The other two categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down at 0.2 percent and foodstuff issues losing 1.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 521 to 359, with 154 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI CONGRESSMEN VISIT TAIWAN OVER WORKER RIOT

TEXT.P: A delegation from Thailand's House of Representatives arrived in Taipei Friday to get more information about the recent riot by around 100 Thai laborers working on the mass rapid transit (MRT) railway project in the southern city of Kaohsiung.
The parliamentary delegation went to the site of the riot to get more details about the riot and to give moral support to the Thai workers.
During their four-day visit, the Thai congressmen will meet officials from Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) for more talks about bilateral laboral affairs.

The riot began late Aug. 21 at a foreign laborers' dormitory in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County, when MRT management tried to stop some Thai workers from bringing alcohol into the dormitory, allegedly attacking them with an electric cattle prod.

The Thai workers, already dissatisfied with the grossly inhumane treatment they were forced to endure at the hands of their Taiwanese management, set fire to part of the dormitory and the management office, and attacked police and firefighters with stones.

Kaohsiung MRT officials and executives of the Huapan Manpower Consultant and Management Co., which is responsible for the management of the laborers, later agreed to many of the demands of the Thai workers.
The riot was covered by several foreign wire services and has caused great concern on the part of the Thai government.

Meanwhile, a Thai official Nakorn Silapa-Archa, who is chief of inspector general of Thailand's Ministry of Labor, visited Kuo Fong-yu, director-general of the CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration earlier Friday. Silapa-Archa arrived in Taiwan Wednesday to look into the riot.

Vice President Annette Lu offered an apology for the incident Wednesday and the Ministry of Justice ordered a thorough investigation of the incident, focusing on whether kickbacks are being paid in the process of hiring foreign laborers or if the workers are being exploited by labor agents, as well as whether the workers were under the control of "Thai gangsters or others."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE SNACKS DEBUT IN XIAMEN

TEXT.P: A promotion of sun cakes and pineapple tarts, two famous Taiwanese snacks, was held in the southeastern Chinese city of Xiamen Friday.

The promotion, which was organized by the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) Taichung chapter, was aimed at facilitating social exchanges across the Taiwan Strait and to mark the end of a visit by a chapter delegation.

Taichung Pastry Trade Association President Yu Yu-i said 10,000 sun cakes and pineapple tarts, which were chosen from the best pastry shops in Taichung in central Taiwan, were available for people to sample at the event. If they are well-received by consumers, Yu noted, the association will consider establishing a manufacturing base in Xiamen for the Chinese market.
Seeing the popularity of the snacks, Xiamen Deputy Mayor Huang Ling also expressed hope that Xiamen pastries can be introduced to Taiwan.

Mu Kuei-hsin, chief of the KMT's Taichung chapter, said the event's success proves the need for more interaction across the Taiwan Strait and said such interaction should not be restricted to the economic field.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
