La Repubblica: Last year's hostage deal by Italian Red Cross in Iraq sparks row.
Former commissioner of Italian Red Cross Maurizio Scelli revealed in an interview with a local newspaper La Stampa Thursday that his organization had treated presumed terrorists in exchange of the release of two kidnapped Italian aid workers in Iraq last year and that the government was informally advised. Scelli's remarks sparked a political storm in Italy with calls from the opposition for a detailed explanation from the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ENDORSES EX-OFFICIAL OVER BROKERING OF FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh claimed Friday that a former deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office had not used his influence to sway the brokerage of Thai laborers for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) during Hsieh's six years as a Kaohsiung mayor.

Hsieh, who left his mayoral post in his second term to assume the premiership in February, made the remarks amid reports that Chen Che-nan was a "high-ranking official" involved in the brokering of Thai laborers, whose riot Sunday to protest mistreatment by their employer and a brokerage company brought to light a series of problems, including infringements on the rights of foreign laborers and a possible illegal profiteering racket between the KRTC and the brokerage firm Huapan Co.

Hsieh noted that the NT$190 billion (US$5.93 billion) mass rapid transit (MRT) system in Kaohsiung requires a great number of foreign laborers over a long period of time, and that the foreign labor brokerage operators naturally wanted a piece of the lucrative pie.

But he claimed Chen had absolutely not used his influence to try to sway the brokering of the foreign laborers for the MRT system, adding that if there was any shady practice, it would have come to light earlier.

Chen had denied vehemently that he was involved in the introduction of the Thai laborers working for the MRT system, saying that if there is any truth in the reports, he is willing to take the harshest punishment. Chen is the father of acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai.
The premier also claimed that if Chen had used his influence during his time as Kaohsiung mayor, China Steel would not have won the bid to supply steel products to the KRTC.

Hsieh recalled that he came under a lot of pressure in the construction of the MRT system, saying that 26 Kaohsiung city councilors had petitioned that a company other than China Steel be awarded the bid, but he overrode their request because China Steel offered a bid that was cheaper by NT$20 billion.

He added that Wang Chung-yu, currently an opposition Kuomintang legislator and then-chairman of China Steel, would have long ago blown the whistle if he had taken any kickbacks in the open bidding process.

On criticism that he turned a blind eye to the maltreatment of the Thai workers for the KRTC, he also said that during his term as mayor, the KRTC had only introduced the first group of 800 Thai laborers.
He said he inspected the living quarters of the Thai workers with city government officials, and found the situation to be "satisfactory."
Following this, Thai laborers were banned from Taiwan until this May, whereupon the KRTC introduced a second group of 900 Thai workers, by which time their quarters had become overcrowded.

He said that the Council of Labor Affairs has stationed inspectors in every city and county to monitor the living environment of foreign laborers, but the inspectors have failed to fulfill their duties, for which Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu has apologized to the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up 24 points to close at 6,150, with 16,495 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for October moved up 18 points to end at 6,152, with 90 contracts traded, while December futures gained 23 points to finish at 6,150, with 35 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,126 for September, 6,134 for October, 6,127 for December, 6,124 for March and 6,115 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

September TE futures moved up 0.95 points to close at 254.55, with 2,817 contracts traded, while October TE futures gained 0.9 points to finish at 254.15, with eight contract transactions. March TE futures moved down 0.15 points to end at 254.25, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and June.

September TF futures gained 5.6 points to finish at 946.6, with 1,291 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved up 4.8 points to end at 945, with 142 contracts traded. December TF futures moved up 3.8 points to close at 945, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.017 to close at NT$32.310.
A total of US$955 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.350 and fluctuated between NT$32.280 and NT$32.381.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMY IN JULY RATED YELLOW-BLUE

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Friday that Taiwan's economy was given a yellow-blue light in July, meaning the economy was "sluggish."
It was the fifth month in a row the economy has been rated yellow-blue.
The composite economic index in July dropped to 18 points, while the leading index slid 0.7 percent and the coincident indications moved down 0.9 percent, according to the CEPD report.

According to the five-color rating system devised by the CEPD to gauge Taiwan's economy, red means an overheated economy, yellow-red represents a heating-up economy, green reflects stability, yellow-blue stands for sluggishness and blue points to recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Political Violence Surges in Iraq; Two-Day Toll Reaches 100; Third Charter Deadline Missed.
Political violence surged Thursday along many of Iraq's ethnic and sectarian fault lines, while Shiite and Sunni Arab political leaders haggled past a third deadline without reaching accord on a draft constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: Kazan Set for 1,000th Birthday Tatarstan's capital made last-minute finishing touches and security sweeps Thursday as organizers prepared for the tens of thousands expected to take part in Kazan's millennial birthday celebrations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT FRAUD RING MEMBERS NABBED IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung police raided a fast food restaurant in Taichung City, central Taiwan Friday, nabbing six people believed to be members of a cross-Taiwan Strait fraud ring that has swindled money from Taiwan citizens by sending fraud messages or kidnapping.

Investigators with the Kaohsiung Police Department found that the ring, led by a man surnamed Shih, had six key operators in the ring, which has extorted at least NT$100 million (US$3.1 million) over the past year in Taiwan by kidnapping people or by operating a variety of fraud schemes, including sending fraud messages saying that people's credit cards had been stolen and that thieves had spent a fortune on the stolen cards or saying that the card holders have outstanding debts to pay for.
The police also found that Shih and his men regularly met at fast food restaurants in southern and central Taiwan to map out the day's operations.
Five of the ring members, including Shih, were apprehended in a restaurant in Taichung City, while the sixth man was arrested in Hsihu township, Changhua County.

Almost all the fraud messages that the ring sent out to Taiwan victims were from China. The victims were fooled into remitting money to the fraudsters' accounts opened at banks around the island with counterfeit IDs.
The ring members used leased cars as transportation and they changed their mobile phone numbers and SIM cards often, the police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS PLAN LAW AMENDMENT TO PROTECT FOREIGN LABORERS

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of Taiwan's second-largest opposition party -- the People First Party (PFP) -- plan to push for an amendment to the law to provide better protection for foreign laborers' rights by allowing them an appropriate channel to vent their complaints, the PFP caucus at the legislature said Friday.

Legislator Sun Ta-chien, deputy convener of the PFP legislative caucus, told a news conference at the Legislative Yuan that the Thai laborers who rioted last Sunday in southern Taiwan to protest their inhumane treatment had been exploited by their employers and employment brokerage firms in both Taiwan and Thailand.

Sun said the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) must investigate each case thoroughly in the future when a foreign laborer is to be laid off and deported to ascertain that the worker did not receive inhumane and unfair treatment.
The PFP legislator also urged Premier Frank Hsieh to punish the government officials whose negligence resulted in the inhumane treatment that triggered the Aug. 21 riot in Kaohsiung County.
Specifically, Sun said, the government should find out within seven days the identity of who the media have claimed is an "influential figure" involved in the illegal brokerage of foreign laborers.

He urged the premier to make Chen Min-hsien, vice chairman of the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) -- the employer of the Thai workers -- suspend a trip abroad and come home to explain how, as a shareholder owning only 7 percent of the total investment, he is able to control KRTC, in which public funds account for more than 80 percent of the company's total capital.

Also speaking at the news conference, Legislator Lin Hui-kuan, a whip of the PFP caucus who is also president of the Chinese Federation of Labor Unions, said the riot has dented Taiwan's international image as a nation that champions human rights.

Lin said that CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu, the highest labor affairs official, must shoulder her share of the "political responsibility" for the incident, or the PFP caucus will not rule out the possibility of blocking the CLA's budget for next year in the new legislative session that begins in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-RUSSIAN DRILL AIMED AT POSSIBLE CROSS-STRAIT WAR: MAC

TEXT.P: A just-concluded Chinese-Russian joint military exercise was apparently aimed at a possible conflict across the Taiwan Strait, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Friday.
Wu made the remarks after attending a seminar on legal problems faced by local small- and medium-sized enterprises.

Noting that the eight-day Chinese-Russian drills included a naval blockade, an amphibious beach landing and an invasion by paratroopers on China's east coast, Wu said the maneuvers were apparently aimed at preparing for a possible cross-strait war.
"The unprecedented Chinese-Russian joint military drills embody the continuously escalating Chinese threat to and suppression of Taiwan, " Wu said.

Since Chinese President Hu Jintao took power, Wu said, China has adopted a "carrot-and-stick" strategy toward Taiwan. While offering ostensibly attractive terms for Taiwan fruit imports and students intending to study in China, the Beijing government has on the other hand stepped up diplomatic suppression and saber-rattling against Taiwan.
"Even more frustrating and outrageous is that China's 'carrots' are largely lip service paid for political purposes, while its 'sticks' mostly come without explanation," Wu said.

For instance, Wu said, Taiwan has not imposed any restrictions on fruit exports to China. However, he said, Beijing leaders have engineered a media hype over its "duty-free and fast-track customs treatment" in recent weeks to sow discord in Taiwan society and even alienate local farmers from the Democratic Progressive Party administration.

At a time when Taiwan's university education system faces heavy strain, China announced recently that it will offer scholarships to Taiwan students who wish to study in China and will charge them the same tuition fees as Chinese students.
"I'm afraid that China's 'cajoling strategy' could eventually have a grave impact on Taiwan's university education system, " Wu said.

While China is relentlessly propagating its so-called "one China" principle around the world, Wu said, Beijing's attempt to treat Taiwan students as their Chinese counterparts is yet another of its tricks to substantiate its "one China" principle.

"In the future, China is likely to treat Taiwan businessmen as their Chinese counterparts. By then, its current investment incentives could be canceled. Should that be the case, its impact could be felt in every Taiwan social quarter. This is an issue we cannot afford to ignore," Wu warned.

With the year-end elections for city mayors and county magistrates approaching, Wu said, China has also stepped up its "united front" tactics by inviting Taiwan's city and county governments to organize delegations to visit China for negotiations on agricultural and technological exchanges.

Warning that such exchanges could lead to Taiwan to lose its competitive edge, Wu said he hopes local politicians will refrain from pursuing personal political interests at the expense of Taiwan's overall national interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT HOLDS TALKS WITH COUNTY, CITY ADMINISTRATORS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu hosted a meeting with administrators of counties and cities around the country Friday to exchange opinions on a wide range of issues such as how to prevent an outbreak of avian influenza and ways to save the island from natural disasters.

All but Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chih-mai attended the meeting. Ma had his deputy Yeh Chin-chuan show up on his behalf, while no-one representing the southern city of Kaohsiung was present.

Lu claimed during the meeting that Taiwan will enter an era that will see the land devastated by storms and people living in insecurity if preparations are not made, referring to floods that have affected the country, "destroying the fruits of the people's labor in one second."

She said the damage will be caused by natural and man-made calamities, underscoring the importance of disaster control and prevention. The vice president described the matter as the most important challenge facing all county and city administrators.
She stressed the need for cooperation between local and central governments for the preservation of the island's water and land.
Lu also mentioned the problems of illegal immigration, preservation of energy resources and the national financial deficit.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Charter Talks in Iraq Reach Breaking Point
Talks over the Iraqi constitution reached a breaking point on Thursday, with a parliamentary session to present the document being canceled and President Bush personally calling one of the country's most powerful Shiite leaders in an effort to broker a last-minute deal. At day's end, American officials in Washington declared that the Iraqis had made "substantial and real progress" toward a deal on the constitution. And senior Iraqi leaders said they would make a last-ditch effort on Friday to strike a deal.
Wall Street Journal: Market for Internet Calling, Once Tiny, Gets Crowded Fast
Inexpensive phone service -- is no longer s o special. Verizon Communications Inc. and AT&T Corp. have started their own Internet-based phone operations, as have a slew of cable companies and small start-ups. Within the next year, nearly every major player in the communications world will offer an equivalent service. After years of hype, Internet phone calling has finally caught on, but the technology's very success is threatening to turn the multibillion-dollar phone business into a cheap commodity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUCCEEDS IN CLONING 'ECONOMIC ANIMAL': COA

TEXT.P: Taiwan has scored a major breakthrough in animal cloning by successfully cloning a special kind of "economic animal, " Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Lee Chin-lung claimed Friday in an interview with the Central News Agency.
After years of assiduous efforts, Lee said, the COA has succeeded in using somatic cells to clone the animal that has both economic and medicinal value.

Lee claimed that the COA-developed cloning technology is unique in the world. However, he would not reveal what animal has been cloned. He only said that President Chen Shui-bian will formally "decode the riddle" early next month.
According to Lee, the COA has done all the research itself, but some of the team members traveled to Britain for training.
"It took seven to eight years to come to this point at a cost of less than NT$100 million. Thanks to the correctness of our research direction, we have made tremendous headway," Lee said proudly.

Since Scottish scientists at the Roslin Institute created the much-celebrated "Dolly" sheep in 1996, other scientists have also succeeded in cloning rabbits, pigs, cattle and horses. But the health and life spans of the cloned animals remain highly uncertain. South Korea announced its achievements earlier this month in creating the world's first cloned dog. U.S. scientists have succeeded in having cloned wild cats give birth naturally.
Lee said Taiwan is second to none in the field of animal cloning. The newly cloned animals are neither dogs nor cats, he said; they are of great economic value.
"The cloned animals have survived for a certain period of time. After several generations of reproduction, they still possess identical genetic material with the original animal," Lee claimed.
He further said the cloned animals are edible and safe. They are not genetically modified and have instead been reproduced from somatic cells, he added.
The cloned animals can also be used for medical purposes by implanting anti-lactoferrin into the animals for mass reproduction.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICS MUST TAKE BACK SEAT TO PROBE ON THAI WORKERS' RIOT: DPP

TEXT.P: The chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (PFP) said Friday that there should be no political considerations whatsoever in the investigation of an alleged racket between government officials and a foreign labor brokerage company that profits by exploiting foreign workers.

Su Tseng-chang made the remarks at a news conference when asked to comment on ongoing speculation about allegations of racketeering that have become the focus of national attention following the Aug. 21 riot in southern Taiwan by Thai workers in protest of their inhumane treatment by their employer, the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC), and an employment brokerage company.
Su said that the DPP's way has always been to face the facts unflinchingly and to review the situation with candor and accept any consequences honestly.

He declined to comment on speculation that the issue has triggered infighting between the factions within the DPP, saying only that the most important thing now is to reform the nation's system governing the employment of foreign laborers to ensure their rights are protected.

Legislator Lin Shu-fen, a member of the New Tide Faction of the DPP, told the Central News Agency in an interview that the riot by Thai workers was not the only case of protest and these foreign workers had been subjected to exploitation and inhuman treatment for a long time.
She said the government must do something about the current labor system which allows influential figures close to the power center to profit from importing foreign laborers.
Lin said that the riot shows that KRTC Vice Chairman Chen Min-hsien and the manpower management company Huapan Co., as well as the Kaohsiung City Government, were "obviously at fault."
As to whether acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai's father, Chen Che-nan, is involved in the scandal, Lin said the evidence will do the talking.
"If the evidence implicates Chen Che-nan, Chen Chi-mai should also be held responsible, " she said, adding, "For those who deserve to step down, let their heads roll."
The DPP legislator said that the entire truth about the riot must be unearthed, but stressed this situation has nothing to do with any infighting within the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT WANTS TRICOLOR FOOD SAFETY ALERT SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A tricolor alert system for food safety is in the works by the Department of Health (DOH) , a DOH official said Friday.

Under the DOH's preliminary plan, the system will work with red, yellow and green lights to indicate what foods are safe to eat, the DOH's chief of food sanitation, Chen Lu-hung, said at a news conference.

Red-lighted foods are unsafe to eat, such as pork from swine that have died of disease before being slaughtered, what the Chinese call "black heart" food. Yellow suggests the food in question is possibly unsafe, while green mean the food is fine, Chen explained.
The official noted that the planned system will help assure consumers of the safety of the foods they buy by providing professional assessment and examination.

A team made up of consumers, food industry representatives and government officials will make the ratings, then release the results within six to eight hours after concerns over a certain food have been raised.
Chen said that a complete plan on the establishment of the system is expected to be ready in three months before being implemented by the end of this year.
The DOH will also try to ensure that consumers can always get correct information on the ingredients and nutritional value of food products, Chen added.
Meanwhile, the DOH has opened a hotline for those wishing to inform on people providing unsafe foods. The number is 080-062-5748.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90% OF FARMERS DON'T DEEM CHINA AS PRINCIPAL MARKET: COA POLL

TEXT.P: A majority of Taiwan farmers responding to a recent survey don't consider China as a principal market for their produce, Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Lee Chin-lung said Friday.

The COA conducted the telephone survey on randomly chosen adult farmers Aug. 4-8 to explore their views on agricultural exports issues after Beijing leaders engineered a media frenzy over its "duty-free and fast-track customs treatment" for Taiwan fruit imports in recent weeks to sow discord in Taiwan society, Lee said.
A total of 1,077 valid replies were collected, with a margin of error of 2.98 percent.
According to the survey results, 60.1 percent of the respondents said they are aware that the government has not imposed any restrictions on fruit exports to China.
As to China's unilateral offer of duty-free treatment for 15 kinds of Taiwan fruits, 75.4 percent said the listed items are not what they most want to export.
Despite China's zero-tariff offer, 89.5 percent said they are not prepared to deem China as their principal export market, while the remaining 10.5 percent gave a positive answer.

The survey also found that 38.4 percent most like to sell their produce in Taiwan; 21.4 percent said Japan is their most favored export outlet, followed by the United States, Europe and Canada; 4.4 percent said China is their most preferred export market.

Meanwhile, 63.7 percent said they don't think China's duty-free offer would help increase their incomes; 20.3 percent said they think the offer will contribute to their incomes; and 16 percent did not answer the question.

The poll further showed that 52.7 percent would not like to see the government let local farmers freely discuss fruit trade with China, but 22.4 percent said the government should adopt a laissez faire attitude toward fruit exports to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC CHINESE STUDENTS TO BENEFIT FROM DONATIONS TO TAIPEI CITY: MA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that the money donated to tsunami victims in Southeast Asia will largely go to ethnic Chinese students in Indonesia and the establishment of classrooms with computers in tsunami affected areas.

Ma made the remarks in response to criticism by Taipei City Councilor Lee Wen-ying that the NT$37 million (US$1.15 million) collected by the Taipei City Government for tsunami relief in several Southeast Asian countries has not yet been used.

Lee blasted Ma for not having convened any meeting on the issue, not having appropriated any money, and not having chosen the recipients for the donations, adding that Ma owes the citizens an apology.
Ma explained that a medical team sent by the Taipei City Government to Southeast Asian nations suggested that the money be prudently used since they do not know into whose hands the money will go.

The city government focused on two educational projects after municipal officials meeting a dozen ethnic Chinese students from Indonesia June 16. The students expressed the wish to be able to study in Taiwan.
According to an estimate, these students could spend NT$10 million to study in Taiwan from junior high school through university.
In addition, the city government will establish classrooms with computers in the tsunami-affected areas with the rest of the limited money, Ma added.

Meanwhile, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao said the same day at a news conference that it appropriated NT$36 million that day to each of the two non-governmental organizations -- World Vision Taiwan (WVT) and the Chinese Fund for Children and Families/Taiwan (better known as CCF/Taiwan) -- which are among the organizations responsible for distributing the donated money to tsunami-affected people.
Another NT$48 million will be appropriated to the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation next week, Yao added.

A campaign initiated by former GIO Minister Lin Chia-lung to donate money to tsunami victims has collected NT$400 million since January, with several NGOs in Taiwan promising to each support 3,000 children in tsunami-affected countries.

However, the GIO has been criticized for the delay in appropriating the money to the NGOs, with Yao denying that the government has been inefficient and claiming that the money has to go through certain appropriation procedures both in government agencies and the private enterprises that made the donations.
At the news conference, Yao thanked Lin for his efforts in collecting money, saying that relief work is ongoing.

In contrast to GIO officials' endeavors, Yao stressed that the Taipei City Government has not yet sent receipts to those who donated money, not to mention making concrete plans, saying that the money collected by the Taipei City Government is really "just lying there."

DOC.HEADLINE: COA MINISTER WILLING TO DISCUSS CHINA'S PANDA GIFT WITH TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Lee Ching-lung said Friday that he is willing to discuss with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou about importing a pair of pandas that Beijing may offer Taiwan as a gift.

At an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency, Lee said the introduction of pandas from China to Taiwan is a conservation and academic issue, and the COA will not attach any political preconditions to the possible transfer.
The Chinese government said after then-opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan visited China in late April that it would offer two pandas as gifts to Taiwan.
Noting that Taiwan is a member of the global village, Lee said the island should abide by international animal conservation regulations.

If the Chinese government officially proposes to send its pandas to Taiwan, the COA will demand from Beijing a panda export permit issued by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), Lee said.

As Taiwan has never taken care of pandas, the COA has maintained a prudent attitude toward the issue, and has invited animal and conservation experts from within and without the country to form an evaluation team to study which local organization or zoo has the capability to take good care of the pandas.

As soon as Beijing applies to export the pandas to Taiwan, the evaluation team will begin its work, and if necessary, Taiwan officials could visit China to better understand the current health of the pandas.
Noting that Taipei City has been making a great deal of effort to secure the right to house the pandas, Lee stressed that he would be very glad to discuss the issue with Ma.

Officials from a KMT think tank and the Taipei Zoo left for Sichuan province, China, Friday to attend a symposium on pandas, triggering a battle between Taipei and Taichung City over which city is better suited to house the animals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TARGETS ADVANCED COUNTRIES FOR FARM PRODUCE EXPORTS: COA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will target rich countries for its farm produce exports, Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Lee Chin-lung said Friday.

Noting that the production costs of Taiwan's high-quality farm produce are relatively, Lee said the COA will focus efforts on tapping markets in high-income countries, such as the United States, Japan, the European Union, New Zealand and Australia. Singapore and Hong Kong are also priority markets because they don't produce agricultural goods.
Through vigorous efforts, Lee said Taiwan has successfully sold mangoes to New Zealand. Next year, he added, Taiwan will be able to export papaya and lichee to New Zealand.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR FUMING OVER MAC'S CHINA PERMIT DENIAL TO CITY OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) was slammed Friday for refusing to allow an animal health official from Taichung City to visit China to attend a seminar about pandas.

Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, who is trying hard to have his city win the right to house the pandas that may be given to Taiwan by China, said he was baffled by the MAC's decision and can't but wonder whether the MAC would let any Chinese pandas enter Taiwan.

Hu said he was especially embarrassed because he asked the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , which was invited by China to the seminar, to allow Taichung's animal health chief, Wu Lung-tai, to join its delegation, only to see Wu's application for permission to visit China denied by the MAC.

Hu said the KMT initially only relayed Beijing's invitation to the Taipei City Government, which is also vying for the chance to house the island's first pandas, but offered Taichung a place on its delegation only after Hu protested.

The KMT delegation headed for China Friday evening without Wu, who was informed by the Taiwan Provincial Government early Friday that his application for permission to visit China, which is necessary for senior government officials, was rejected by the MAC because "the theme of the Chinese seminar doesn't fall within his authority."

Hu said the reason is unacceptable and that government officials of Wu's rank had been allowed to visit China before; the only reason that Wu was forbidden to go along with the KMT delegation is that the MAC considers China's offer a Trojan horse aimed at making the people of Taiwan drop their guard against China.
If that is the case, the mayor claimed, the MAC has underestimated the political wisdom of Taiwan people because many Taiwanese have already seen pandas in various Chinese zoos.
Furthermore, Hu said, the seminar Wu was intending to attend has nothing to do with China's decision to send a pair of pandas to Taiwan, and the MAC is being overly cautious.

Meanwhile, Legislator Shen Chih-hui from the opposition People First Party, who has announced her candidacy to run for mayor of Taichung, also criticized the MAC for ignoring Taichung people's hope to have the pandas in their city.

Noting that Takung in Taichung is well known for its bamboo, which is the staple food of pandas, Shen claimed Taichung is an ideal place to accommodate Chinese pandas, and that the MAC's decision runs counter to the desire of local people.

China offered a pair of pandas to Taiwan during former KMT Chairman Lien Chan's visit to the mainland in April, but Taiwan authorities frowned on Lien's Chinese trip and are reluctant to accept the offer on the grounds that it could justify the KMT's outreach to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-RUSSIAN MILITARY DRILL TARGETED TAIWAN: VICE DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Vice Defense Minister Tsai Ming-hsien said Friday the just-concluded Chinese-Russian joint military exercise were apparently targeting Taiwan.

Noting that the eight-day Chinese-Russian military drill included a naval blockade, an amphibious beach landing and an invasion by paratroopers on China's east coast, Tsai said all the skills demonstrated in the maneuvers were options that China could use against Taiwan.

"We should not have an ostrich mindset to play down the implications of the unprecedented joint exercise. The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has consistently closely monitored the exercise, " Tsai said, adding that he hopes local people can heighten their psychological defense in the face of China's mounting military threat.
Tsai further said he is cautiously optimistic about the possibility of a long-stalled arms procurement package clearing the legislative floor during the soon-to-opened legislative session.

In a goodwill response to opposition parties' demands, Tsai said in an interview with the Central News Agency that the MND will come up with a revised arms procurement bill next week for Cabinet endorsement. The bill will then be referred to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation and approval at its new session scheduled to open in September.
At its weekly meeting Wednesday, the Cabinet approved a new proposal to finance the arms package, divided between a modified special budget and the regular defense allocation.

For more than a year, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party has used its slim majority in the legislature to hold up the special NT$480 billion arms procurement bill, saying that the purchase would spark an arms race with rival China that could bankrupt Taiwan.
Included in the package are eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries.
Tsai said the six Patriot batteries will be funded by the MND's regular budget, while the remaining two items will be funded by a special budget.
Both come from state coffers, but the regular defense budget carries more rigorous oversight provisions. By so doing, Tsai said, the MND hopes opposition parties can stop boycotting the package.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SETS UP SERVICE CENTER FOR TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN OPERATING IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) opened a liaison and service center Friday in Taipei for Taiwanese business people operating in China to safeguard their rights and benefits.

KMT Deputy Chairman P.K. Chiang was designated to serve as the head of the center, the Chinese counterpart of which will be the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs under the Communist Party of China, according to the largest opposition party in Taiwan.

Chiang said that the new facility will help Taiwanese living and working in China deal with matters that involve government policy, as well as matters like cross-strait talks, which are beyond the government's capability to address.

Meanwhile, the liaison and service center's operational secretary, Chang Jung-kung, announced that the KMT has reached an agreement with the Chinese side to hold a meeting in Beijing in late October to discuss improving the rights of Taiwanese in China.

The KMT held a meeting Friday in Taipei with leaders of several Taiwan businessmen associations in China. At the event, the service center was established with the full support of Taiwanese business people.
The new facility's telephone number is 02-2343-4870.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRUIT EXPORTS TO CHINA RISE SLIGHTLY IN AUGUST: AGRICULTURE CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's fruit exports to China increased only slightly despite China's much-hyped announcement of duty-free access to 15 kinds of Taiwan fruits beginning this month, Council of Agriculture Minister Lee Ching-lung said Friday.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, Lee said a total of 80 tons of Taiwan fruits were sold to China in the first 20 days of August, which is only a little more than the average of 86 tons sold every month, even before China announced the duty-free treatment, Lee said.
Noting that China's huge population of poor farmers has been a political burden to Chinese leaders, Lee said it is doubtful that the mainland could be a lucrative market for Taiwan's fruit.

Among the 15 kinds of Taiwan fruits to which China has opened its market, most are not produced in China and have already been imported from southeast Asian states. Imports of these fruits from Taiwan will not have a significant impact on Chinese farmers.
The other fruits are not grown in great quantities in Taiwan and only a few Taiwan farmers can enjoy the duty-free access for these fruits, Lee said.
Citing as an example, Lee said the staple of Taiwan's fruit exports is bananas, followed by mangoes and lychees, but mangoes were listed among the 15 kinds of fruit to be brought into China.
For these reasons, Lee said, Taiwan's farmers should not have illusions about China's market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Aug. 27, or the 23rd day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1813: France's Napoleon Bonaparte, with a force of 130,000, wins his last great battle at Dresden, Germany, against a superior Austrian, Prussian and Russian allied force of 200,000.
1859: The world's first oil well is drilled by Edwin L. Drake at Titusville, Pennsylvania.
1883: The 1,800 meter Krakatoa on the Indonesian island of Rakata erupts with a fury that is heard in Australia, more than 3,541 km away, and gigantic tidal waves of up to 36 meters devastate the coastal towns of Java and Sumatra, leaving an estimated 36,000 people dead, and making the eruption the most catastrophic volcanic event ever recorded.
1891: Russia and France sign an entente cordiale.
1908: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th president of the United States, is born. He succeeded to the office after John F. Kennedy was assassinated. He won the 1964 election but faced increasing criticism over the mounting US involvement in Vietnam, and did not stand for reelection in 1968.
1910: Thomas Alva Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, shows his "talking picture" for the first time at his New Jersey laboratory.
1910: Mother Teresa of Calcutta, the Yugoslavian-born Albanian nun dedicated to the poor and sick, particularly in India, is born. She won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, in an attempt to impose dictatorial rule after assuming the provisional presidency in Beijing in March, 1912, orders the arrest of eight members of a constitution-drafting committee.
1916: Italy declares war on Germany.
1916: Romania declares war on Austro-Hungary, thus entering World War I.
1928: The Kellogg-Briant Pact, or Pact of Paris, an international agreement to condemn all war as a means of settling dispute, is signed by representatives of 15 nations.
1939: The world's first jet-propelled aircraft, the He-178 developed by German manufacturer Ernst Heinkel, makes its first flight at Marienehe, in northern Germany.
1946: A pilot's ejector seat prototype is successfully demonstrated at Wright Airport in the United States.
1946: France and Laos conclude an agreement establishing a kingdom under French domination.
1952: Israel and West Germany reach agreement in their negotiations on Nazi war crime indemnity. Under the agreement, the West German government will pay 3 billion Reichsmarks in 12 years to compensate Israeli people for their loss of lives and properties caused by the Nazi regime during World War II.
1962: The International Amateur Athletic Federation issues statement revoking its ratification for Indonesia to hold the Fourth Asian Games following the southeast Asian country's rejection of the Republic of China delegation to the games.
1972: The Taipei Little League baseball team wins the world title.
1977: The ROC's Lih Teh Little League baseball team wins the world title. Both Senior League and Big League baseball teams from Taiwan also won the 1977 world titles in earlier competitions.
1979: Lord Louis Mountbatten, former admiral and viceroy of India, is murdered by a bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army as he and members of his family enjoy an outing on his 30-ft. fishing boat off Mullaghmore, County Sligo in the Irish Republic. He was 79.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Finance decides to lower the highest tariff rate to 57.5 percent and reduce duty rates on products with high import tariffs but limited import volume.
1987: A 13-year-old Chinese girl who was left to live with a family of pigs returns to normal life after three years of special training.
1991: Moldova declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1995: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization sign an agreement in Cairo to expand Palestinian autonomy from Gaza to the West Bank.
1999: Actress-singer Bai Guang dies at her home in Kuala Lumpur at the age of 79.
2003: A three-day six-nation meeting on North Korean nuclear weapon program opens in Beijing.
2004: Taekwondo athlete Chen Shi-hsin wins the ROC's first-ever Olympic gold medal in the Athens Olympic Games.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The power of spiritual forces in the Universe -- how active it is everywhere! Invisible to the eye and impalpable to the sense, it is inherent in all things, and nothing can escape its operation."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO ANNOUNCE NAME OF NEW AIT CHAIRMAN: ROC ENVOY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top envoy in the United States said Friday that Washington will soon announce the name of the new chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).
David Lee, ROC representative to the United States, made the remarks at a press conference in Washington.

According to Lee, one of the reasons the U.S. will make a quick announcement about the chairmanship is that the new head of the institute will have to represent the U.S. in receiving President Chen Shui-bian during his upcoming transit stay in the United States en route to visit Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America next month.
The AIT chairmanship vacancy has yet to be filled following the resignation of Therese Shaheen in April 2004.
Raymond Burghardt, who served as AIT Taipei office director from 1999 to 2001 and as U.S. ambassador to Vietnam, is reported to have been tipped for the post but this has not been confirmed.

The report also said that Burghardt, who became a department head at the East West Center in Hawaii earlier this year, will continue to work in the center if he becomes the new AIT chairman and managing director.

Capping nearly a decade of debate, state regulators voted to create California's first area code overlay, in the 310 region, meaning that phone customersin the South Bay and Westside will have to dial 11 digits for all calls beginning next summer.

DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Seoul ups ante on war crimes Tokyo 'legally responsible' for sexual slavery, forced labor The Japanese government is obliged to take leg- al responsibility for crimes committed during its 1910-45 colonial rule of the Korean Peninsula, including conscripting Koreans into sexual slav- ery and forced labor, Seoul declared Friday.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA warns vs prolonging crisis
President Arroyo warned yesterday that the longer the current political turmoil lasts, the deeper the hurt it will inflict on the people. In a statement issued yesterday morning, the President called for a "determined consensus among our national leaders, regardless of party, sector and persuasion -- to get on the same boat and steer it forward, not pull in different directions or worse, boring holes in the hull."

THE NUMBERS game continued to be played in the House yesterday, with two more lawmakers endorsing the amended impeachment complaint against President Macapagal-Arroyo.

A veil of mystery shrouds an unannounced visit by a group of congressmen to Malacanang Friday that reportedly prompted the President to cancel a trip to Malabon City.

DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: 20,000 retail workers lead way to top service.
It's time to ditch the abrupt 'What you want?' for a polite 'How may I help you?'.
Over the next few months, store assistant Zalinza Abdul Mubin, 27, and her 200 colleagues at the Metro department store will be drilled in proper shop-floor communications.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT DEMANDS FAST, STRICT PROBE INTO THAI LABORER RIOT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu reiterated Saturday her concern over the Aug. 21 Thai laborer riot and the subsequent allegations of racketeering involving government officials, saying a fair and just probe into the case is needed.
Lu noted that prosecutors are obliged by law to conduct a fast and strict investigation into the incident that developed as a result of an alleged racket of unlawful exploitation of foreign workers.
Over 100 angry Thai workers on the Kaohsiung mass rapid transport project set fire to their manager's office Sunday in protest over what they called inhumane treatment meted out by their employers.

Lu said that the government is responsible for dealing with the case transparently as it has caused deep concern in the international human rights sector. She also noted she will meet with a group of Thai congressmen Monday for further talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ATTENDS APEC WOMEN LEADERS' NETWORK MEETING IN SOUTH KOREA
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Minister without Portfolio Fu Li-yeh introduced Saturday Taiwan women's participation in a wide range of efforts to promote social and economic development during the 10th Women Leaders' Network Meeting (WLN) of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, held Aug. 24-27 in Daegu, South Korea.

Fu led a 22-member delegation that attended the four-day event. She said that by attending the meeting, female entrepreneurs in Taiwan could share their experience with their counterparts from other countries.
Fu added that the contribution of the event's organizer -- the Korean Women Entrepreneurs Association -- to enhancing Korean women's economic capacity is a good reference for Taiwan.
Representatives of non-profit organizations, academic circles and government officials from 19 APEC members took part in the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOUGH PROBLEMS STILL EXIST BETWEEN U.S., TAIWAN: ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Representative to the United States said Friday that the United States and Taiwan have resolved many thorny problems between them but still have to solve their toughest problem -- how to upgrade Taiwan's self-defense ability.

David Lee made the comments at a press conference while explaining the Bush administration's reaction to the Taiwan government's recent efforts to push for the passage of a U.S. arms procurement package that has been stonewalled in the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.

The Executive Yuan has recently suggested that some of the items on the procurement list could be funded from the regular budget rather than a special budget that was originally proposed to and rejected by the legislature.
According to Lee, the United States considers the arms procurement issue to be Taiwan's own business but that it should improve its defense ability.

Saying that he has reported the U.S. stance on the arms deal to his superiors as well as opposition and legislative leaders during recent consultations in Taiwan, Lee noted that the government's stance on the purchase of diesel-electric submarines, anti-submarine aircraft and PAC III anti-missile batteries is very clear, but he admitted that such stance still needs the legislature's support.
The U.S. government has grown frustrated with Taiwan's inability to come to an agreement on the arms procurement package.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA PROTESTS ROC ENVOY'S PARTICIPATION IN 'JOURNEY OF AMBASSADORS'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: David Lee, the Republic of China representative to the United States, said Friday he regrets the Chinese ambassador's protest over his participation in a "journey of ambassadors" activity organized by Senator Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa).

Grassley, who concurrently serves as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, has customarily organized a "journey of ambassadors" every other year for members of the diplomatic corps in Washington, D.C. to visit his home state.

The Chinese embassy lodged a protest with Grassley's office upon learning that Lee was on the guest list. An embassy staff member claimed that Taiwan's representative was not qualified to take part because he is not an ambassador.
In response, Grassley told the Chinese official that both Taiwan's representative and the Chinese ambassador to the United States are his friends and are welcome to take part in the activity.
The Chinese embassy later informed Grassley's office that in protest over Lee's invitation, Chinese Ambassador to the United States Zhou Wenzhong would refuse to go on the trip.

Annoyed by China's puerile fit of pique, Grassley issued a public statement at the Senate, contemptuously criticizing Zhou's move as "childish." Grassley further said that if China likes to think of itself as a rising great power and wants to be an important member of the international community, it should follow the basic norms and principles of international engagements.

Speaking to Chinese-language media journalists stationed in Washington Friday, Lee said that because of his busy schedule, he originally planned to just take part in the first three days of the "journey of ambassadors."
"Moved by Grassley's moral courage in criticizing the Chinese ambassador's protest, I changed my mind and decided to take part in the whole five-day event," Lee said.

More than 70 foreign ambassadors stationed in the United States participated in this year's "journey of ambassadors, " the theme of which was focused on getting a better understanding of U.S. rural life.
"Each night we stayed at the ranch of a different farmer. I was impressed by the high quality of U.S. farmers," Lee said.
He said that whenever he gave his namecard to his American hosts, they tended to ask what the "Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office" stands for.
"Each time, I felt a bit embarrassed, " Lee said, adding that the experience has made him feel that the campaign to change the names of Taiwan's overseas representative offices is necessary.

Since the United States switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, the ROC's representative offices can neither bear its formal national title nor the word "Taiwan." China is utterly sensitive toward any move or designation implying a separate Taiwan identity.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Shiites and Kurds Halt Charter Talks With Sunnis
Shiite and Kurdish leaders drafting a new Iraqi constitution abandoned negotiations with a group of Sunni representatives on Friday, deciding to take the disputed charter directly to the Iraqi people. With the American ambassador, Zalmay Khalilzad, standing by, Shiite and Kurdish representatives said they had run out of patience with the Sunni negotiators, a group that includes several former members of Saddam Hussein's Baath Party. The Shiites and Kurds said the Sunnis had refused to budge on a pair of crucial issues that were holding up completion of the constitution. The Shiites and K urds reached their decision in meetings that ran late into Friday night, disregarding the Sunnis' pleas for more time.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Bank of Italy governor Fazio fails to convince Minister of Finance and Economics Siniscalco.
Bank of Italy Governor Antonio Fazio said in his report to an interministerial panel on the saving and trust Friday that his bank observed all of the rules of Italy and the European Union in the take-over bids for Banca Antonveneta and Banca Nazionale del Lavoro. However, his remarks failed to convince Minister of Finance and Economics Domenico Siniscalco who insisted that there are problems on the country's and the bank's credibility. Fazio's relations with the government is expected to be decided in the Sept. 2 Cabinet meeting in which Siniscalco will express his opinion on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., TAIWAN AGREE ON PRESIDENT'S TRANSIT ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in the United States said Friday that Taipei and Washington have reached a consensus on issues related to President Chen Shui-bian's forthcoming transit stays in the United States.

Revealing at a press conference that the agreement was reached a month ago on Chen's transit stops en route to Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America in September, David Lee said that the agreement "shows mutual trust between the two countries."
He also claimed that U.S.-Taiwan relations have improved since he became Taiwan's representative to the United States in July 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 'STORY FATHERS,' FOUR GROUPS DECORATED

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng decorated 12 "story fathers" and four non-profit groups from all over the country Saturday to award their long-term involvement in a program to tell stories to middle and elementary school students living in remote areas.

Describing the individuals and groups as "gardeners in story parks, " Tu said they have spared no efforts to take care of and educate those children who enjoy fewer educational resources than their urban counterparts.

Tu urged the public to join the "reading for children" activity as volunteers and expressed hope that more "story fathers and mothers" will join the Ministry of Education's (MOE's) efforts to promote reading.
The minister also called on the public to support the MOE's "You Buy, I Donate" activity to collect 50,000 books for 300 elementary schools located in remote areas.

The awarded fathers, aged from 25 to 60, are Kuo Ming-yi from Keelung City, Tsai Shan-lin from Taipei County, Huang Chung-lin from Taoyuan County, Chen Wen-pin from Hsinchu County, Chen Shuo-ping from Taichung County, Liu Shiu-chun from Nantou County, Lee Chi-an from Chiayi County, Lin Chin-huei from Kaohsiung County, Wang Ming-chung from Pingtung County, Chen Chun-lang from Taitung County, Chiang Pang-lin from Hualien County and Lin Hsin-teh from Ilan County.

The four story groups are the parents association of Penglai Elementary School in Hualien, the parents association of Hoshun Elementary School in Chiayi, the Kaohsiung County-based Mingchia Cultural and Educational Foundation and the Pengtung County Story Society.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE DELEGATION TO VISIT PANAMA AUG. 28-31
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A delegation of foreign trade officials and representatives of 39 Taiwan businesses is scheduled to pay a four-day visit to Panama that will begin Aug. 28, Republic of China embassy officials in Panama said Friday.

According to the itinerary, the group will host a trade workshop with businessmen in Panama City Monday, followed the next day with a visit to Colon, the country's second-largest city, to visit a free trade district and manufacturers based there.
During their stay in Colon, the delegation will also take part in a trade conference to be held by the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in Panama.
The group is organized by the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council to seek trade opportunities in the Central American region.

According to Taiwan customs statistics, two-way trade between Taiwan and Panama reached US$269.36 million in 2004, posting a remarkable growth of 111.8 percent over the level of a year ago. The performance was helped by the implementation of a Taiwan-Panama free trade accord at the beginning of that year.
Panama is now Taiwan's third-largest market in Central and South America, and its sixth-largest trade partner in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT'S 'FOUR PROVINCES' PROPOSAL NOT CABINET POLICY: MOI

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu's proposal to restructure the nation's administrative districts into "four provinces and two special administrative regions" does not represent the Executive Yuan's policy or stance, a senior official said Saturday.

"The proposal was only Lu's personal opinion. We respect her personal views about the administrative districts restructuring issue, but her opinions do not represent the government's policy or stance," said Vice Interior Minister Chien Tai-lang.

Addressing a seminar on administrative districts restructuring and capital relocation earlier in the day, Lu said she felt compelled to come up with "audacious and forward-looking" ideas regarding the theme of the meeting.

"After years of development, many of Taiwan's existing systems and institutions require a comprehensive review because they have become outdated and can no longer cope with the changing political, social and economic situations," Lu said.

With improved traffic convenience, for instance, Lu said Taiwan's administrative districts need not be classified into so many levels -- from province/special municipalities to counties/provincial municipalities to county municipalities to townships and villages.

At present, Lu noted, Taiwan boasts a four-level bureaucratic hierarchy that comprises the central government, the marginalized provincial government, two special municipalities, 16 counties and five provincial municipalities plus many county municipalities, townships and villages.
"This bloated hierarchy only increases red tape and dampens government efficiency," Lu said.

Taiwan, she went on, should scrap its special municipalities and provincial municipalities while instituting two special administrative regions -- the mountainous special administrative region and the outlying islands special administrative region -- to accentuate its determination to better protect the environment.
Specifically, Lu said, the nation should be restructured into four provinces -- Taipei, Taichung, Tainan and Taitung -- along with the mountainous and outlying islands special administrative regions.

Furthermore, she continued, Taipei's role as the nation's capital should be reconsidered. With a view to promoting balanced development in northern and southern Taiwan, Lu said the government should weigh the possibility of relocating the capital or study the feasibility of having "two capitals" to narrow the gap between regional developments.
According to Article 108 of the Constitution, Lu said administrative district restructuring needs only legislation and does not require constitutional amendments.
Commenting on Lu's proposals, Chien said it was the first time he had heard of such far-reaching restructuring ideas.
Noting that administrative district restructuring is the Ministry of the Interior's duty, Chien said the ministry respects Lu's personal opinions.

"As the issue involves many complicated problems, including revisions to various self-governance laws and administrative district demarcation laws, such a move would need extensive discussion. At the moment, Lu's proposals do not represent the government's policy or stance, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPARENCY INTERNATIONAL REGIONAL MEETING TO KICK OFF IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Taiwan chapter of Transparency International (TI), a non-governmental organization (NGO), will host the TI's East Asian meeting Aug. 28-30 at the Howard International House in Taipei.

It will be the first TI meeting to take place in Taiwan, according to TI-Taiwan executives and will take the form of a series of seminars on the topic of incorruptibility in the commercial sector, with the aim of attracting the attention of Taiwan entrepreneurs.

TI, founded in 1993, is the only international NGO devoted to combating corruption in any form. It works by bringing society, business and government together in a global coalition. TI-Taiwan is one of the more-than 85 national chapters around the world.
Thanks to the organization's efforts to create a collective power against bribery, TI Chairman Peter Eigen was selected by Reader's Digest magazine in 2004 as its person of the year in Europe.

The Taipei meeting, to be presided over by David Nussbaum, the TI chief executive, will review regional anti-corruption campaigns and operations of regional chapters. Participants will include staff of the TI headquarters in Berlin and 30 representatives of TI groups in East Asian countries, including Japan, South Korea, China and Mongolia.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG TAIWAN VIRTUOSO WINS TOP HONOR IN ISRAEL PIANO FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Tel Aviv, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Yang Yi-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A young pianist from Taiwan has won the top prize in the Tel-Hai International Piano Festival in Israel, organizers said Saturday.

Yang Chien-ying, who is now studying at Moscow State Tchaikovsky Conservatory on a scholarship from Taiwan's Ministry of Education, was one of 75 pianists from around the world to be invited to take part in the Tel-Hai festival.
After more than two weeks of intensive training, performances and contests, Yang emerged as the top winner, capturing the award in memory of Israeli musician Marina Bonderenko.

Yang was the only Taiwan piano student to be invited to compete. She charmed and surprised many Israeli music fans by performing famous contemporary Israeli pieces in a unique style and even outperformed her Israeli competitors in her readings of contemporary Israeli masterpieces, according to music critics.
In recognition of her accomplishments, the organizers also invited her to take part in the 2006 Tel-Hai piano festival.
Yang won the top award in the Taipei Chopin piano contest earlier this year, securing her a chance to join Poland's Chopin piano competition scheduled for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONCERT HELD IN TAICHUNG CITY

TEXT.P: The Taichung city government held a concert Saturday to allow young people to present their work in the central city.

The show featured professional bands, as well as amateur offerings from junior and senior high schools and colleges. There was also a Q&A activity dedicated to preventing young people from falling victim to violence and drug abuse.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU INTERNATIONAL ART FESTIVAL OPENS

TEXT.P: The Penghu International Art Festival opened on the outlying island of Penghu Saturday.
The opening ceremony was presided over by Penghu County Magistrate Lai Feng-wei, who welcomed visitors by encouraging them to pay attention to the arts.
The exhibits include stone sculptures, basketwork and hand-made sails, the organizers said.
During the festival, the organizers will single out six of the 50 exhibits for special awards.

DOC.HEADLINE: WAR IN IRAQ GRAVELY AFFECTS TAIWAN-FRANCE TIES: OUTGOING ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Y.S. Luo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The war in Iraq has had a grave direct impact on relations between Taiwan and France, the outgoing Republic of China representative to France said Saturday.

Chiou Jong-nan, a career diplomat who will step down from his current post as the top Taiwan representative to France in the absence of formal diplomatic ties at the end of this month, told the CNA that as French President Jacques Chirac differed with the United States on the war in Iraq, he had to seek the support of other big powers in the world.

Back in 2003, Chiou said, China was a ready choice, as its new president, Hu Jintao, was eager to expand China's external relations. In order to cajole China, Chiou said, Chirac did not hesitate to make unfriendly comments on Taiwan, hurting Taiwan-France relations.

Chiou took over his current post in November 2002. It marked the second time that he has served as the de facto ROC ambassador to France. Ten months after he assumed office, he originally arranged for the French foreign trade minister to visit Taiwan. As Chinese President Hu was scheduled to visit France in January 2004 to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the establishment of China-France diplomatic ties, France later canceled its minister's Taiwan travel plan.
Afterwards, Chirac's criticizing Taiwan's decision to hold a referendum simultaneously with its 2004 presidential election during his face-to-face talks with Hu drew backlash in Taiwan.

Because of the changing international political situations, Chiou said relations between Taiwan and France have been in a low ebb in the past two years. "I feel sorry and uneasy for this trend, " he said.
In his 40.5-year diplomatic career, his tenure as the top ROC envoy to France totaled nine years.
He said diplomatic work with countries that do not maintain formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan relies heavily on person-to-person relations that require long-term cultivation.

According to Chiou, Chirac's blunt opposition to democratic Taiwan's referendum program has also drawn harsh criticism in France. "I hope both Taiwan and France can forget this unpleasant episode as soon as possible," he added.
Chiou further said the new director of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs's Asia-Pacific department once told him that Taiwan and France should enhance mutual understanding.
Noting that China has continued its "strongarm" diplomatic offensive against Taiwan, Chiou said Taiwan should not let down its alert and efforts in forging extensive foreign relations.
"China's diplomatic work is now run by a new generation of well-trained professional diplomats. We should devote even more resources and manpower in diplomatic work," he suggested.
Chiou's successor, Yang Tzu-pao, is scheduled to arrive in Paris Sept. 5 to assume his new post. Yang has a doctoral degree from a French engineering university.

Chiou's first term as the top envoy to France, running from November 1990 through January 1997, marked a height in Taiwan-France relations. After the 1989 Tiananmen massacre in Beijing, the then-French leftist government known for its emphasis on human rights actively expanded relations with Taiwan. During the period, France won contracts to build Taipei's Mucha mass rapid transit line, signed an aviation rights pact with Taiwan for direct air links and sold Lafayette-class frigates and Mirage jet fighters to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-CENTRAL AMERICA SUMMIT SCHEDULED FOR SEPT. 26

TEXT.P: The fifth summit meeting between the Republic of China president and his counterparts from the ROC's Central American allies is scheduled to take place in Nicaragua Sept. 26, according to Nicaraguan authorities.
Nicaraguan Vice President Jose Rizo Castellon told the CNA in a written interview that Nicaragua will host the fifth ROC-Central America summit Sept. 26.
ROC President Chen Shui-bian will attend the biennial meeting in person. The ROC government has not yet announced Chen's travel itinerary.

The biennial ROC-Central America summit offers a forum for Taiwan to strengthen strategic alliances with its allies in the region and to accentuate its willingness and capability to be a competent and responsible member of the international community.

The first ROC-Central America summit was held in El Salvador in 1997, with then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui traveling there to attend. In 2001, Chen traveled to El Salvador to attend the third such meeting. The second and fourth summits took place in Taipei in 1999 and 2003.

In his recent interview with the CNA, Rizo said relations between Taiwan and Nicaragua have been steadfast and will not be affected by his country's recent political instability resulting mainly from conflicts among its three government branches.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN INSPECTS SHUEISHAN TUNNEL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made an inspection tour of the soon-to-be-completed Shueishan Tunnel Saturday to boost the morale of all those who are working hard for one of the world's most challenging road construction projects.

It was Chen's fifth visit to the tunnel construction site. He was accompanied by Premier Frank Hsieh, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu shyi-kun, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san and other senior officials. "You have come a long way and now only a small step short of completing this challenging project. I admire your perseverance and appreciate your devotion," Chen told engineers and workers at the construction site.
The 12.9-kilometer tunnel, the centerpiece of the 34-km Peiyi freeway project, is also known as a "passage beneath troubled waters" for its engineering difficulties.

Construction on the Peiyi freeway, the first east-west freeway to pass through Mount Snow (Shueishan in Chinese) that spans from Taipei's Nankang district to Toucheng in the northeastern county of Iland, began in 1991. After repeated cave-in and groundwater flooding, construction lagged far behind the schedule.

Stressing that construction didn't get a major breakthrough until after his Democratic Progressive Party took power in 2000, Chen said the completion of the Shueishan tunnel accentuates the significance of the transition of power between different political parties.

The Shueishan Tunnel is Asia's longest highway tunnel and the world's fifth longest. By mid-August, the tunnel's civil engineering work was 98.8 percent complete, its electric engineering work was 69 percent complete and its traffic control engineering was 53.8 percent complete. Workers are now work at three shifts with an aim to complete the project as scheduled at the end of this year.
Noting that the government has spent more than NT$90 billion and 10-plus years building the Peiyi freeway, Premier Hsieh said he hopes the project can be completed smoothly as schedule.

Nevertheless, Hsieh said safety remains the government's top concern. "We'll respect engineering experts' opinions and will open the new freeway to traffic only after it passes the most stringent safety tests," Hsieh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR CHIEF REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO PROTECTING LABOR RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The nation's top labor affairs administrator reaffirmed the government's commitment Saturday to protecting local and foreign laborers' rights and interests.

Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), made the assurance during an inspection tour of the living quarters of Thai laborers working for the mass rapid transit system in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaoshiung.

The inspection tour came after the Aug. 21 riot at the living quarters of 1,700 Thai laborers in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County, in which some 100 Thai workers set fire to a dormitory building and a management office in protest of the harsh restrictions placed on them and the poor living conditions. The incident attracted the attention of news media around the world.

Chen said the incident was an isolated case. She has apologized for the incident and has assured the Thai government that Taiwan has traditionally been kind and humane toward foreign laborers and that the CLA will make every possible efforts to prevent recurrence of similar incidents.

Chen told Thai laborers Saturday that the CLA has long formulated a mechanism encouraging workers, including foreign laborers, to report any maltreatment by their employers. Informers can receive a maximum cash reward of NT$100,000.
Chen further said the CLA will send inspectors to examine the living and working environments of foreign laborers around the country.
Chen was accompanied by acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai and Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing on the inspection tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Aug. 28, or the 24th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: The Scots defeat royalist English forces at the Battle of Newburn, near Newcastle.
1774: Elizabeth Ann Seton, American educator and religious leader who founded the Sisters of St. Joseph, is born. She was canonized as the first US-born saint in 1975.
1828: Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy, also known as Count Leo Tolstoi, Russian writer and philosopher, is born. His great novels "War and Peace" and "Anna Karenina" offer extraordinary detail and profound psychological insights. His later theories of ethics and morality recommended non-participation in and passive resistance to evil.
1830: Peter Cooper, American inventor who built the first American locomotive, displays his latest creation, a steam-driven locomotive called Tom Thumb.
1849: Venice surrenders to the Australians, having been under siege since July 20 after proclaiming independence from Austrian rule.
1884: Peter Fraser, prime minister of New Zealand from 1940 to 1949 , is born in Scotland.
1910: Montenegro proclaims independence from the Ottoman empire.
1916: Germany declares war on Romania.
1919, Sir Godfrey Hounsfield, British inventor of the EMI medical scanner, is born. He was winner of the Nobel Prize for Psychology in 1979.
1927: The Eighth Far East Games is held in Shanghai.
1929: The Kuomintang (KMT) branch in Shanghai asks the Nanking government to punish Professor Hu Shih, a former student of John Dewey, for publishing an article criticizing Dr. Sun Yat-sen and the KMT.
1931: The Mexican government orders all ethnic Chinese to leave Mexico before Sept. 2.
1945: Mao Tse-tung, accompanied by US Ambassador Patrick Hurley, arrives in Chungking from Yenan to hold a meeting with the KMT to discuss such issues as national unity.
1963: US civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "I have a dream" speech to some 200,000 people after an interracial march on Washington, a peaceful demonstration in favor of furthering the cause of civil rights.
1973: Princess Anne arrives in Kiev for an equestrian event, becoming the first member of the British royal family to visit the Soviet Union.
1974: The Republic of China and Thailand conclude a maize trade agreement.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Bolivian Vice Foreign Minister Hernando Garcia Vespa and his wife.
1980: Premier Y.S. Sun leaves for Costa Rica, Panama and the Dominican Republic for official visits.
1983: Menachem Begin resigns as prime minister of Israel.
1988: Three jet planes belonging to an Italian Air Force aeronautics display team collide during an exhibition in front of a crowd of 300,000 at the US Air Force base at Ramstein in West Germany, killing 47 people and injuring some 500 others.
1990: Iraq declares Kuwait the 19th province of Iraq.
1993: Ong Teng Cheong, chairman of the ruling People's Action Party, is elected president of Singapore.
1996: El Salvador President Armando Calderon Sol visits the Republic of China.
1999: The ruling Kuomintang convenes the second plenary session of its 15th National Congress to formally approve Lien Chan and Vincent Siew as the party's nominees for the 2000 presidential election of the Republic of China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Like the rush of mighty waters, the presence of unseen powers is felt -- sometimes above us, sometimes around us. Such is the evidence of things invisible that it is impossible to doubt the spiritual nature of man."
