DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VISITS BEEP BASEBALL WORLD SERIES CHAMPIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh visited the Taiwan Homerun beep baseball team Sunday to congratulate them on winning this year's World Series for the blind in Houston, Texas.

Hsieh spent Sunday morning watching members of the team training at a baseball field at the Riverside Park in Taipei County. He was impressed to see how the visually impaired players could hit a ball that emits a beeping sound.
The team beat the Kansas All-Stars 9-8 July 30. They also won the championship in 2004 in Columbus, Ohio.
To experience how the game is played, Hsieh tried twice to hit a ball while blindfolded, but he failed both times.

The premier expressed his admiration for the team and praised the player for overcoming their physical obstacles to capture the highest honor in two consecutive world events. He presented a red envelope with cash to the team as a token of his appreciation for the players to carry on with the sport.
Beep baseball is adapted from standard softball, with all six players at bat blindfolded. The ball they try to hit gives off an audible beep and the base gives off a buzzing sound.

Each team may use two sighted spotters when playing defense and all players must be blindfolded when batting. The batting side is allowed three outs. In order to score, a ball must travel 40 feet or more to be fair; if it flies more than 180 feet in the air, it is a home run.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Transport Minister calls for banning unsafe airlines.
Commenting on an European Union proposal for blacklisting airlines which do not meet safety requirements, Transport Minister Pietro Lunardi said Saturday that Italy wants more than a mere blacklist. It wants a systematic safety checks at an EU level with a single list of airlines allowed to fly in Europe, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BECOME OBSERVER AT OECD STEEL COMMITTEE
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is soon to become an observer at the Steel Committee under the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), enabling it to take part in certain OECD-related meetings upon invitation under the title of "Chinese Taipei, " OECD sources said Saturday.
Should everything go smoothly, according to an official with the OECD Steel Committee, Chinese Taipei is expected to become an official observer at the Steel Committee in September.
The official added that he does not expect any opposition to the notion and Taiwan will become an official observer, rather than an "ad hoc observer" at the committee.

The OECD Steel Committee currently has 29 member countries and five official observers: Bulgaria, India, Romania, Russia and Ukraine. The countries represent 81 percent of global steel production and command 86 percent of the world's steel trade.
Late last year Taiwan became an official observer at the OECD Competition Committee and an ad hoc observer at the OECD Trade Committee.
Taiwan has also made progress in its efforts to be admitted into the OECD Fisheries Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU OPPOSES USING PARTY POSITIONS ON PUBLIC SERVANT EXAMS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Sunday it opposes asking prospective public servants questions concerning political parties' positions in national examinations.

Meanwhile, the minor opposition party denied that Chang Cheng-hsiu, a commissioner of the Examination Yuan, who has made controversial statements about the exams, has been trying to promote TSU ideology in national exams.

Newspaper reports said people attending a national exam for lawyers are required to answer questions surrounding President Chen Shui-bian's address at the TSU anniversary on Aug. 6. They are also asked to write an article on the topic of "Lawyers' personalities and national leadership." President Chen is a former lawyer.

Cheng Chen-lung, TSU secretary-general, said prospective public employees should be tested on "subjects that they must know, " and whether a speech by the president should be included in these exams ought to be judged from this perspective.
For its part, the TSU opposes any subject that may be suspected of "containing political considerations," Cheng said.

One of the questions on the lawyers' exam asked on what occasion was the president making the address, and the correct answer apparently was "at a TSU function, " triggering criticism that Chang was trying to use the national test to promote the green camp's ideology.

To this, Cheng responded by saying that Chang is no longer a TSU member and that he was not responsible for writing the test questions. He was just the chief commissioner for organizing the exam, and so the controversy "has nothing to do with the TSU."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 10,000 RALLY IN TAICHUNG TO SUPPORT CPC RENUNCIATIONS

TEXT.P: Nearly 10,000 people turned out at a rally held in Taichung City, central Taiwan, Sunday to support those wishing to renounce their membership in the Communist Party of China (CPC).

Ever since the Epoch Times publishing on its Web site a denunciation of the CPC in what it called the "Nine Commentaries, " Chinese people have increasingly been giving up their membership in the party, with the number of withdrawals expecting to top four million soon, said Chen Chang-hui, a spokesman for the Global Alliance to Say Goodbye to the CCP (Chinese Communist Party) , the sponsor of Sunday's activity.
The alliance is a private Washington, D.C.-based organization established by 91 smaller Chinese groups across America in December 2004.
Waving banners and shouting slogans, the marchers, who came from around the island, encouraged more people to help more people give up their CPC membership and accelerate China's democratization.
Among the supporters were former Government Information Office Minister Lin Chia-lung and Huang Kun-hu, chairman of the pro-independence Friends of Lee Teng-hui.

Lin and Huang said that the nature of Chinese Communism is no longer applicable in today's world and it is detrimental to human rights protection, adding that it is meaningful for Chinese people to denounce Chinese Communism by turning their back on the party.

Meanwhile, Chen Rongli, a Chinese dissident and promoter of Chinese democracy who also appeared at the rally, openly announced that he quit the Chinese Communist Youth League (CCYL) as a member, starting from Sunday.
Chen Rongli said that the Chinese Communists have continued to jeopardize human rights and hinder the progress of democratization in China, which are not conducive to China's development.

He stressed that he not only quit the CCYL, a spin-off of the CPC, as a gesture to oppose the Chinese Communists himself, but he will also continue to encourage other CCYL members to withdraw from the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHYSICAL APPEARANCE AN IMPORTANT FACTOR IN JOB HUNTING: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly 70 percent of respondents to an online survey released Sunday believe that physical appearance is important when looking for a job.
The study, conducted Aug. 5-25 by the Chinese Personnel Executives Association, interviewed 1,200 people, with two-thirds of respondents being human resources workers.

Statistics show that about 70 percent of the respondents believe that while education, work experience and the ability to perform required duties account for 60 percent of the evaluation by an interviewer, the remaining 40 percent depends on a job seeker's physical appearance.
Nearly 40 percent of respondents indicated that they would like to improve their looks through plastic surgery to increase their chance of being hired by a prestigious company.

The findings also showed that 84 percent of the human resources workers acknowledged that they would like to make use of methodologies for analyzing attitudinal factors in the hiring process to help employers find dependable workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TOUGHENS INSIDER TRADING LAW

TEXT.P: The government has decided to expand the definition of "insiders" to include board members who have quit in the last six months and representatives sent to a board by institutional investors as part of its effort to crack down on insider trading.

Officials at the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said amendments to the Stock Transaction Act will also include banning insiders from trading within 12 hours after a major news regarding a company has been publicized.

As to the definition of "major news regarding a company" and how it is to be made public, this will be the job of responsible government agencies which will establish guidelines based on the principles of "strict legal provisions" and "clear and unambiguous violations" while also taking into account changes in the market.

In addition, compensation in civil disputes will be changed from the current "limited maximum amount" to "compensation amount, " meaning the difference between the selling or buying price on the disputed day and the average price of the closing price in the 10 days after the company news became public.

Regarding the punishment for criminal offenses, FSC officials said violators will be punished by a sentence of three to 10 years in jail plus a fine of between NT$10 million and NT$200 million (US$9.3 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY BE GLOBAL LEADER OF LAPTOP COMPUTER BATTERIES BY 2006

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to replace Japan in 2006 as the world's largest supplier of laptop computer battery packs, with the island's manufacturers of the lithium batteries gaining an increasing share of the world market, market analysts said Sunday.
Taiwan has 11 technology companies that produce battery packs for laptop computers. Together they hold about 40 percent of the world market, second to Japan's 60 percent.

The analysts said that with the Taiwanese manufacturers' orders steadily on the increase, they expect Taiwan's share of the world market to exceed 50 percent in 2006, replacing Japan as the world's largest supplier of laptop PC battery packs.

Of the 11 companies that produce battery packs for laptop computers, Simplo Technology Co. is the leader with more than 20 percent of the world market. The company expects to receive orders for 15 million battery packs next year, increasing its world market share to 25 percent and replacing Japan's Sanyo Corp. as the No. 1 supplier.
Other leading manufacturers of the battery packs in Taiwan include Dynapack International Technology Corp., Gallowire Enterprise Co. and Celxpert Energy Corp.
The analysts noted that both Simplo and Dynapack are expanding their facilities to increase production capacities to cope with increasing demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPANIES FACE FINE FOR POLLUTING IF NO CLEAN-UP AFTER CHEMICAL FIRE

TEXT.P: Companies that don't clean up the water used to put out a chemical fire will soon face stiff fines with the introduction of amendments to anti-pollution regulations, an Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) official said Sunday.

Wang Yue-bin, an EPA official, said the new rule will affect all petrochemical and mining companies; those who do not install the pollution-preventing facilities could be fined between NT$60,000 (US$1,860) and NT$600,000 (US$18,600) and, when necessary, have their permits to dispose of waste water revoked. In a worst case scenario, the company could even be ordered to close.

The proposed amendments were prompted by a recent incident in which a Taichung petrochemical company was accused of polluting a nearby river after firefighters extinguished a fire that burned sodium nitrite and other chemicals.

As the company did not address the issue of the polluted water in time, the water used by firefighters flowed into the Nanbian River, turning it yellow. However, the government was unable to prosecute the company since the chemicals were not toxic.

To avoid a similar embarrassing situation in the future, the EPA is changing the regulations so that companies must install intercepting, collecting and temporary storage facilities for water used in putting out a fire that burns not only toxic chemicals but also non-toxic ones.
Within one hour after an incident that may affect water safety, companies must inform all potential victims of the situation to minimize the damage, according to the amended rule.
The new measures also aim to improve the protection of water resources for water companies, households, irrigation and aquaculture.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL TAIWAN KEY BATTLEFIELD IN DECEMBER ELECTIONS FOR DPP

TEXT.P: With fewer than 100 days remaining until the December "three-in-one" elections, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has its eye on wresting control of some key areas in central Taiwan that are traditionally bastions for opposition "pan-blue alliance" supporters.

According to an internal assessment by the DPP, the party's chances in central cities and counties will be vital to expanding its power base, and the December elections for city and county chiefs and councilors as well as town and village heads will be a litmus test for the political climate in the run-up to the next presidential election in 2008.

To that end, the DPP has fielded various appointed government officials affiliated with the party and with nationwide fame to run for city mayors and county magistrates in the central region in the hope of securing larger numbers of votes in the upcoming elections.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang has started an islandwide campaign tour to drum up support for party candidates, including the hopeful for mayor of Taichung, Lin Chia-lung, a former director-general of the Government Information Office, and the aspirant for Taichung magistrate, Chiu Tai-san, a former vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council.

The DPP is dead set on regaining power in Taichung city and county -- a prosperous business and industrial center in central Taiwan. Taichung is Taiwan's third-largest city after Taipei and Kaohsiung, while Taichung County is home to many factories and small businesses.

Except for Taipei and Kaohsiung cities -- Taiwan's two special municipalities -- the DPP currently is in power in nine counties and two cities out of a total of 23 around the country; namely, the counties of Taipei, Ilan, Nantou, Yunlin, Changhua, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung; and in the cities of Chiayi and Tainan.

As the DPP traditionally enjoys strong public support in southern Taiwan, the central region thus will be the key battlefield for the ruling party to expand its power at the local level toward northern Taiwan, observers said.
Although Su has begun mobilizing the party machine to campaign for DPP candidates, observers said that it is still too early to say that the party is sure to win the elections due to a "Ma frenzy."

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who recently became chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , is exceptionally popular in the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party, and among unaffiliated voters.
As Ma has yet to come up with a strategy to deal with the December elections, it remains unclear to what extend the popular new KMT chairman will exercise his influence over voters, observers said.

Nevertheless, the year-end "three-in-one" elections are set to be a showdown between the KMT and the DPP and between Ma and Su, both of whom could be rivals in the 2008 presidential race amid increasingly bipartisan politics in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, THAILAND LABOR AFFAIRS COOPERATION TO CONTINUE: COUNTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Thailand will continue to facilitate labor affairs cooperation between the two countries despite the recent riot by Thai workers in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing said Sunday.

Yang made the remarks after meeting with Pimpa Chanprasong, chairwoman of the Thai Congressional Labor Affairs Committee, who is currently leading a 20-member Thai group in Taiwan mainly to gain further understanding of the recent labor disputes involving Thai workers.

Yang accompanied by Kaohsiung County Government officials met with Pimpa and her group Sunday to discuss the impact of the recent riot, in which some 100 Thai workers set fire to a KRTC dormitory building and a management office in protest of what they claimed were harsh restrictions placed on them and the poor living conditions there.

Speaking at the discussion, Yang apologized to Thailand and the Thai workers over the recent riot. Describing the incident as an "isolated case, " Yang said that Taiwan appreciates the Thai nationals for their help in Taiwan's infrastructure development.
Yang promised that he will see to it that Taiwan adopts higher standards in examining labor management to help protect the Thai laborers' rights and interests.

The Kaohsiung County chief also told Pimpa that Taiwan needs the assistance from the Thai government to find who was behind the Aug. 21 riot and those who are found to be innocent will be spared punishment.

For her part, Pimpa also apologized and said she regretted the Aug. 21 incident, saying that the crux of the problem, which she found out after arriving in Taiwan, was the labor broker and management.
Pimpa, who is representing the Thai government on her current trip to Taiwan, said that she will have relevant brokerage companies disciplined after she returns to Thailand.

Later in the day, Pimpa and her group also visited the Kaohsiung County Police Department, where she demanded that there should be Thai representatives present at the police station or at the Thai workers living quarters when Taiwan policemen are investigating the case so as to protect the Thai nationals' human rights.
Kaohsiung County Police Department Commissioner Yuan Hsing-i responded to Pimpa by saying that the case will be handled impartially without any abuse of rights.
Yuan stressed that the Kaohsiung police need the help of the Thai authorities so that the case can be solved as quickly as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA FORUMS TO BE HELD BY OPPOSITION PARTIES LATER THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Following visits to China by the Chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) earlier this year, the two parties are planning to separately sponsor economic and trade forums in China.

PFP Secretary-General Ching Chin-sheng, who visited Beijing Aug. 22 along with PFP policy center chief Chang Hsien-yao to work out the details for a forum to be jointly organized by the PFP and the Communist Party of China (CPC) , said in Taipei Sunday that the planned forum will open in Shanghai and be attended by PFP Chairman James Soong in the middle of September.
Although Ching has not revealed the date of the forum, the Hong Kong-based Ta Kung Pao newspaper quoted Chang Hsien-yao as saying the previous day that the forum will be held from Sept. 14 to 16.

According to Ching, four topics will be discussed at the forum, including the role of Taiwan businessmen in the economic development of Taiwan and China, problems surrounding direct transportation between Taiwan and the mainland, issues brought about by bilateral agricultural exchanges, and the normalization of bilateral trade.

Ching said the forum will provide a chance for bilateral leaders to exchange views on trade and economy in the absence of official contacts, and more than 60 Chinese academics and 30 to 40 Taiwanese academics will take part.
During the forum, the PFP will push for the establishment of arbitration of commercial disputes between Taiwan and China, Ching went on.

Ching said the forum is part of the PFP's efforts to formalize the consensus reached between PFP Chairman James Soong and CPC Chairman Hu Jintao during their meeting in Beijing on May 12 and could be developed into a regular event held every three months.
The KMT is also working on a forum with the CPC, but no date has been fixed, nor have topics been selected or who might attend.
A KMT official said it would be easier to hold the forum in China because Beijing is willing to host the event; however, it would have more political impact if it takes place in Taipei.
The official said the forum will be organized no later than the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE' COOPERATION CENTRAL TO DECEMBER ELECTION VICTORIES

TEXT.P: Chances for "pan-blue alliance" cooperation in the December "three-in-one" elections are looking better after ranking officials of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) met last week to hammer out how to fully work together.

The PFP has called for joint electioneering and coalition rule at the local government level, after KMT Secretary-General Chan Chuan-po paid a visit to PFP and had a talks with PFP Deputy Secretary-General Liao Tsang-song, early last week to relay KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's hope for close inter-party cooperation in the elections -- the city mayors and county magistrates elections and those for city and county councilors and for township and village heads.
The Chan-Liao meeting marked the first step toward the mobilization of a set of comprehensive negotiations between the two parties in light of supporters' high expectations, observers said.

Joint campaigning to win the elections and create substantial power-sharing following the elections at the local government level will help lay a solid foundation for full KMT-PFP cooperation in the future, PFP aides said, adding that the two parties must deal with a set mechanism to put forward just one common candidate in each constituency.

The two parties hope to forge a "comprehensive cooperation" plan for across Taiwan, rather than focusing on just various areas, PFP Organizational Affairs Department Director Huang Pan-kung said during the Chan-Liao meeting.
Despite initial bilateral efforts, Ma still faces a host of difficulties in consolidating the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party ahead of the elections, analysts said.

Although Ma has repeatedly called for fielding joint KMT-PFP candidates to secure wins in the elections, the PFP has nominated its own hopefuls in 10 constituencies -- a situation that Ma has to carefully deal with in conjunction with PFP Chairman James Soong.

For the time being, the KMT has set its key tone for the election -- safeguarding power in central Taichung city and county, regaining power in Taipei county and seizing victories in two or three southern cities or counties.

The KMT is particularly keen to win back power in northern Taipei county, which is Taiwan's largest constituency with a population of 3.5 million, KMT aides said, adding that winning or losing in Taipei County will have a direct impact on the "pan-blue" chances in the 2008 presidential election.

"If the KMT can win in Taipei county this time after DPP's 16-years rule, it can be viewed as a victory for the party as a whole," KMT aides said, pointing out that Ma, who assumed the KMT chairmanship in the middle of this month, cannot afford to suffer a defeat in the year-end elections.
Meanwhile, the results of several public opinion polls showed that the KMT is gaining greater public backing after former KMT Chairman Lien Chan visited China in spring this year.

Some political analysts attributed the KMT's rising popularity to a shift of supporters away from the PFP to the KMT amid anxiety over the "pan-blue" desire for a merger among the three parties to battle against the "green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
Despite the KMT's surge in public support, the 50 percent voter base enjoyed by the two camps remains little affected in Taiwan's polarized political spectrum, they said.

DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Constitution Committee Signs Draft Despite Sunnis' Objections
Iraq's parliament convened Sunday to receive the country's draft constitution after members of the committee that created it signed the charter, but Sunni members of the team said they had rejected the final draft.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDICAL SOCIETY ENCOURAGES WOMEN TO DONATE EGGS

TEXT.P: As donated eggs fall far short of actual needs in Taiwan, the Taiwanese Society for Reproductive Medicine (TSRM) is calling on married couples to think about the concepts of "sharing eggs" and "exchanging eggs for sperms."

"Sharing eggs, " TSRM President Liu Chih-hung said, means that a woman receiving in vitro treatment, who usually could produce eight to 10 eggs in order to increase her chance of getting pregnant, could donate the extra eggs to other women who need them.

As to "exchanging eggs for sperms, " he said TSRM encourages infertile couples to donate good sperms or eggs for other couples seeking to become fertile. For instance, he noted, if a couple is infertile because the husband's sperms are not good enough, the wife, who is receiving donated sperms to become fertile, can donate her eggs to other infertile couples.
Both "egg sharing" and "exchanging eggs for sperms" programs should be carried out in accordance with the National Health Administration's principle of "not assigning a certain receiver," Liu said.

Statistics show that every year, some 7,000 people in Taiwan are seeking medical assistance for infertility problem, of whom around 1,000 cannot produce healthy eggs. But only three percent of eggs for this group are donated, disappointing many other couples seeking to raise a family.

Besides "egg sharing" and "exchanging eggs for sperms, " the TSRM also encourages young women, particularly those aged between 20 and 35, to donate eggs to help infertile couples realize their dreams of having their own children.

The TSRM is drafting "standard contracts" for the three programs of promoting egg donation, which it says will be completed within a year. The society is planning to reward an egg donor with NT$50,000-100,000 in "nutrition" subsidy.
Unlike the NHA, whose draft law on artificial insemination limits a woman's donation of eggs to only once in a lifetime, the TSRM is recommending six times throughout a women's life.

The TSRM bases its suggestion on a Dutch study which shows that a woman who has donated eggs ten times through her reproductive years will see a chance of less than one millionth that her offspring will marry each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND AFFAIRS OFFICIAL: NO COMMENT ON LIEN'S PROPOSED FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) refused to comment on reports Sunday that former Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman is trying to set up a foundation to promote peace between Taiwan and mainland China.
MAC Vice Minister You Ying-lung who doubles as MAC spokesman said the his office has no knowledge of Lien's idea and won't comment on it until action was taken by Lien to realize the idea.

You was asked to comment on a story carried on Sunday's China Times Express which said Lien who retired from his post as KMT chief on Aug. 19 was trying to raise NT$300 million (US$9.3 million) for the establishment of a foundation for the cause of promoting peace between Taiwan and China.

The story said Lien has decided to devoted his time after retirement to improving Taiwan's ties with China which is part of his agreement with Chinese Communist Party chief Hu Jintao during their historical meeting in Beijing on April 29.

Although Lien will keep his job as head of KMT think tank, the Institute on Policy Research and Development, after stepping down as KMT chairman, the limited budget of the think tank won't give him the necessary means to fight for his cause of peace across the Taiwan Strait through organizing seminars or promoting exchanges with China, the China Times Express said.

Knowing that the KMT which has difficult raising enough funds to lay off its redundant employees won't be able to give him any financial help in this regard, Lien decided to set up a foundation of his own to push his work, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEA WARNING FOR TYPHOON TALIM COULD BE ISSUED TUESDAY: CWB

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Monday that it will probably issue a sea warning for Typhoon Talim Tuesday morning.

As of 11 a.m. Monday, Typhoon Talim was located about 85 kilometers northwest of Guam, moving in a west-northwest direction at a speed of 22 km per hour, with maximum wind speeds of 130 km per hour, CWB meteorologists reported.
Talim, the 13th typhoon reported in the Pacific this year, could affect Taiwan in the next few days if it continues gaining strength and moving in the same direction, they said.

There is also a chance that the typhoon will lose strength over the following two days if a high pressure system in the Pacific Ocean weakens. If this is the case, the meteorologists forecast, the typhoon will shift to a more northward direction, thus sparing Taiwan from being directly affected.

Meanwhile, the weather bureau forecast that hot summer weather will continue around the island over the next couple of days, while eastern Taiwan could see sporadic rains beginning Tuesday as the outer rim of Typhoon Talim moves closer to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT PEACE FORUM TO BE HELD IN CHINA BEFORE YEAR'S END: KMT

TEXT.P: A forum on cross-strait peace, being organized by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , will be held in China sometime later this year, Chang Jung-kung, deputy executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, announced Monday.

Chang made the announcement one day after a local newspaper reported that former KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who passed the KMT baton to Ma Ying-jeou 10 days ago, is planning to set up a foundation to promote peace between Taiwan and China.

The report said that Lien has decided to devote his time after stepping down as KMT chairman to improving Taiwan's ties with China -- part of his agreement reached with Chinese Communist Party chief Hu Jintao during their historic meeting in Beijing April 29.

According to Chang, his office has submitted applications to relevant government agencies for approval for the establishment of the Cross-Taiwan Strait Peace Foundation, a brainchild of Lien envisaged to work as a KMT think-tank.

There is only one "platform" on which the KMT and the Communist Party of China can communicate, but that platform needs the support of several "columns" to make it solid and firm, Chan said, adding that the Cross-Taiwan Strait Peace Foundation is expected to serve as one of these supporting columns.

Chang also disclosed that the NT$300 million (US$9.3 million) needed for the establishment of the foundation has already been raised without any problems. He categorically denied news reports that Lien would ask for a loan of the same amount, in his capacity as an honorary KMT chairman, from the KMT headquarters.

Meanwhile, Chang added, the KMT-initiated cross-strait economic and trade forum originally planned for August or September of this year to help accelerate commercial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait has been postponed due to the absence of consensus on several issues.
He said that the cross-strait economic and trade forum will be held as soon as the KMT reaches consensus with the Chinese authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP REMINDS KMT, PFP NOT TO HURT TAIWAN IN CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the two main opposition "pan-blue alliance" parties Monday to exercise prudence in their engagements with China in order not to hurt Taiwan's national interests.

DPP legislative whip William Lai made the appeal against the backdrop of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) rushing to engage in personnel exchanges with the Communist Party of China (CPC) and joining forces with it to hold various cross-strait forums.

Noting that cross-strait exchanges should move "in a goodwill direction, " Lai said the KMT and the PFP should avoid jeopardizing Taiwan's survival and sustainable development in their engagements with the CPC.
Lai said he frets that the two opposition parties may use their slim majority in the Legislative Yuan to pressure the government to accept all the consensuses or conclusions reached at those forums.

Just last week, Lai said, party executives of the KMT's Taichung chapter reached a consensus with the CPC's grass-roots units on promoting cross-strait agricultural exchanges during their China visit.

"I'm afraid that Taiwan's advanced agricultural technology and fine-quality plant seedlings may flow into China through such exchanges. Should that be the case, the competitive edge of our farmers and agriculture could be at stake," he said.

According to Lai, China has stepped up its "united front tactics" toward Taiwan. He said China has invited a large number of Taiwan's university students, among others, during this summer vacation to visit the mainland in the name of academic exchanges.
In his view, Lai said, Beijing is taking an increasingly hard line against Taiwan while concealing its intentions from the public.
"And these strong arm tactics are posing an increasingly grave challenge to Taiwan," he added.

Lai further pointed out that China is now using different strategies at different times. While the "soft strategies" it has adopted are much softer than before, Lai said, the "hard strategies" it has adopted are much harder. Worse still, Lai said, the Beijing government tends to pay lip services to Taiwan opposition figures but then delay putting them into effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE OFFICIAL INVITED TO PARTICIPATE IN KMT FORUM
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By C.H. Jen and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A senior Chinese official in charge of Taiwan affairs confirmed Monday that the island's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has invited him to participate in a forum to discuss issues related to the proposed "three links" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

J.C. Chen, director of the Research Bureau of Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council of China, made the confirmation while attending a seminar held in Macau on the prospects concerning cross-strait relations.

The KMT is currently planning to hold a forum in Taipei to allow ranking officials from the KMT and the Communist Party of China to discuss issues related to the proposed "three links" -- which refers to direct shipping, transportation and postal links between the two sides of the Taiwan strait.

Chen said that he has received an invitation from the KMT and has made contact with KMT officials to arrange matters, adding however that further consultations are needed to work out the details of his participation in the forum.
He also expressed the hope that the CPC, KMT and government of Taiwan can work together to push for the holding of the forum.

Meanwhile, People First Party (PFP) Legislator Ku Chung-lien, who also attended the seminar, confirmed that PFP Chairman James Soong will preside over the opening ceremony of a cross-strait forum scheduled to be held in Shanghai Sep. 14-16.
According to the legislator, the forum, which is jointly being organized by the PFP and the CPC's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs,
is designed to promote agricultural, economic and cultural exchanges and cooperation between Taiwan and China.

During the event, four main topics, including the impact of China's economic strategy and development on Taiwan business investment in China, cross-strait agricultural exchanges and cooperation, direct cross-strait charter flight services, and the normalization of cross-strait economic and trade relations, will be discussed, Ku said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISHIN BANK-CHINA EASTERN AIR COOPERATION UNDER SCRUTINY: MAC

TEXT.P: The business tie-up between Taiwan's Taishin Bank and the mainland's China Eastern Air has been looked into by the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) under the Executive Yuan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman (Johnnason) Liu said Monday.

Taishin Bank has been promoting its credit cards via TV commercials, offering 10-percent cash returns to those who purchase China Eastern Air plane tickets for flights to and from China with Taishin Bank credit cards.
The television ads have stirred up questions about direct trade across the Taiwan Strait, which is currently still prohibited by law.

Responding to these questions, Liu said that the Taishin Bank-China Eastern Air case is currently being examined by the FSC, adding that the MAC will offer its opinions on the matter if the FSC authorities request it in writing.

Regarding the airing of the Taishin Bank commercials on local television, Liu noted that as this is an issue involving the Statute Governing Relations of People from the Taiwan Area and the Chinese Mainland Area, it falls under the jurisdiction of the FSC, which he said is currently dealing with the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL WRANGLING NOT BEHIND SERVICE FOR TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN: MAC

TEXT.P: The quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) is slated to open a service center for Taiwan businessmen operating in China Tuesday, with Premier Frank Hsieh and Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu taking part in the inaugural ceremony.

The event will be the second of its kind within a week after the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) inaugurated a similar center last Friday, spurning speculation that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the KMT, driven by fierce political wrangling, are in high gear to lure support from the many Taiwan businesspeople operating in China.

MAC Vice Chairman Michael You, who concurrently serves as SEF vice chairman and secretary-general, said that such speculation is totally unnecessary as the government is fully open to any group willing to offer service and assistance to China-based Taiwan businesspeople amid frequent and close cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges.
However, You stressed that the SEF, the only organization authorized by the government to deal with cross-strait affairs, is irreplaceable in this regard thanks to its longstanding creditability.

Claiming that the SEF's move to set up the center has nothing to do with competing with the KMT, You said that the SEF is planning to further step up its services for Taiwan businesspeople with operations in China.
The Cabinet-level MAC, Taiwan's top agency in charge of China policy, oversees SEF operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DELIBERATIVE DEMOCRACY MAKES UP FOR DEMOCRATIC SHORTFALLS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that deliberative democracy, which enables people to participate in policy-making, can make up for the shortfalls of representative democracy.

Deliberative democracy refers to any system of political decisions based on some trade-off of consensus decision-making and representative democracy. In contrast to the traditional theory of democracy, which emphasizes voting as its linchpin, deliberative democracy says that legitimate lawmaking can only come after the public deliberates on the issues.

The nation's top leader in the representative institute, President Wang Jin-pyng of the Legislative Yuan, agreed that through such channels as citizens' forums, people can express their opinions about local and national affairs, indicating that Taiwan's democracy is continually maturing.

The two national leaders made the remarks at an international seminar on deliberative democracy that attracted professional NGO (non-governmental organizations) delegates, scholars and officials from 20-odd countries including Belgium, Denmark, Japan, South Korea, Switzerland and the United States.

Hsieh said that in addition to the legislature and local councils, deliberative democracy and citizens' forums are another channel for people to participate in the government's decision-making process.

For example, he said, the government has held a citizens' forum on tax reform, a national youth conference and a public forum on whether Kaohsiung City should set up a cable car system. He noted that citizens' participation is both a right and an obligation.

Wang said Taiwan people are having more and more chances to express themselves, and ethnic groups have engaged in rational and peaceful dialogues and built mutual trust through NGO forums and academic platforms.
As the nation's legislative speaker, Wang said he was delighted to hear "true and quality voices from the grassroots" that have been made through deliberative democracy.
His and Hsieh's remarks pointed to the shortfalls of Taiwan's "official democracy" and the need to supplement it with deliberative democracy.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of Taiwan Thinktank, which co-sponsored the event, blamed the problems of Taiwan's democracy on "constitutional defects" and the lack of a democratic culture, as shown in many people not thinking over a lot of topics and forming their views based on political and ideological preferences.
He expected more public views will be incorporated in the nation's decision-making process to improve the quality of its democracy.
