DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TRYING TO TACKLE ILLEGAL FACTORY DUMPING OF WASTE AT THE SOURCE

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has been making spot-checks on factories in Taipei and Tainan counties since July in a comprehensive crackdown on illegal waste dumping.

The EPA is also enlisting the help of experts and scholars in environmental protection for the inspections, and they are also offering suggestions to the companies and consulting with them on how to meet EPA requirements.

EPA officials said that illegal waste dumping has become far too prevalent in Taiwan. Among recent major incidents, the illegal dumping of solvents into the Kaoping River, which affected drinking water in the greater Kaohsiung area in 2000, was a low point.

The officials said that although most of the waste dumping is due to wanton violation of the law, some producers of factory waste do not properly manage their affairs and their waste is often turned over to rogue waste disposal companies.

The EPA crackdown will continue until the end of September. About 100 factories and recycling plants have so far been visited to measure the efficiency of their production processes, waste management, disposal facilities maintenance, waste reduction efforts and recycling.
The EPA has another 100 factories on its list for inspections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PARTICIPATE IN BICYCLE TRADE FAIR IN GERMANY

TEXT.P: Taiwan will participate in EUROBIKE, Europe's largest bicycle trade fair scheduled to open Sept. 1 in Friedrichshafen, Germany, an official from the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Monday.

EUROBIKE is a first-rate international stage for major European and American brands to display their latest technology in bicycle-making, and it has also become a source of inspiration for the global bicycle industry. The 2005 exhibition has attracted more than 800 manufacturers and retailers from 72 countries, with half of them from outside Germany, the official noted.

Sixteen bicycle and sports gear manufacturers from Taiwan will take part in the exhibition, the official said, adding that the council will also set up a Taiwan pavilion to showcase Taiwan's award-winning products and to gain more international exposure by advertising the slogan "Think Bicycle, Think Taiwan."

Taiwan has been an active participant of the annual EUROBIKE exhibition, the TAITRA spokesman said, and he urged Taiwan's bicycle manufacturers to seize the opportunity to promote their new models and high-end products.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANCIENT CHINESE ANTI-CANCER FORMULA TO BE CLINICALLY TESTED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) is sponsoring a clinical research program on an ancient Chinese medical formula that has been used to cure intestinal cancer but that has no scientific backing.

The program is targeting a 1,800-year-old formula containing four traditional Chinese herbal ingredients -- which is being called PHY906 -- and at securing clinical data proving that it is effective in the treatment of cancer of the rectum and large intestines, said Lai Chi-ming, a section chief with the National Health Research Institute (NHRI) under the DOH.

The clinical study on PHY906 -- proved in animal tests to be effective in the reduction of chemotherapy side effects and delaying the growth of cancer cells -- is being jointly sponsored by the NHRI, the DOH Committee on Chinese Medicine and Pharmacy and PhytoCeutica, Inc., a U.S.-based bioscience company established by Cheng Yung-chi, a Yale professor who is also an academician with Academia Sinica.
PHY906's anti-cancer efficacy is particularly strong when it is used together with five certain chemotherapy applications, Lai said.
Fifty rectum and large intestines cancer patients will receive the first and second-phase clinical tests of PHY906 to be conducted at Taipei Veterans General Hospital shortly, according to Lai.

The PHY906 clinical research program is meaningful because in the West, there has been a lack of systematic research on the efficacy of traditional Chinese anti-cancer medicines, while in the traditional Chinese medical circles, there has been a lack of clinical testing with scientific data proving that certain formulas can cure certain kinds of cancer, said officials from the DOH Committee on Chinese Medicine and Pharmacy.

Cheng, also the faculty founder of the U.S.-based biomedical company Achillion, which is developing a drug to treat the AIDS virus and hepatitis B, established the Consortium for Globalization of Chinese Medicine -- an organization that now groups 50 international research organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU PROFESSOR NAMED NEW AVIATION SAFETY COUNCIL MANAGING DIRECTOR

TEXT.P: Yang Hung-chih, a mechanical engineering professor at National Taiwan University (NTU) , was named managing director of the Aviation Safety Council (ASC) Monday, an ASC spokesman said.

The position has been vacant since Kay Yong, who concurrently served as former ASC chairman and managing director, tendered his resignation in April this year. To keep the ASC running, the Executive Yuan had appointed former Deputy NTU President Wu Jing-shown as the new ASC chairman, who soon nominated Yang to fill the other vacant post two weeks after he assumed office.

Yang is an NTU alumni and has a Ph.D in mechanical and manufacturing engineering from the University of New South Wales in Sydney, Australia. He was also a visiting professor at Cranfield University in England, and a director of a training program for civilian pilots.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF IN S. KOREA TO BOOST BILATERAL FILM INDUSTRY EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, South Korea, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Yao is currently on a visit here to study the country's film and TV industry and promote bilateral exchanges in the sector.

Yao called on the state-run Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation (MBC) Monday, and chatted with MBC Vice President Shim Jong-in on the MBC's strategies of producing one of its most popular TV drama series, "Dae Jang Geum" or "Jewel in the Palace, " which has been very popular in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Japan.

Yao invited Shim, as well as Lee Yeong-ae, the actress who played the leading role in "Dae Jang Geum, " to visit Taiwan in November for an unprecedented "three-in-one" award presentation ceremony for Taiwan's top film award -- the Golden Horse Awards, the Golden Bell Awards -- Taiwan's highest honor for TV and radio broadcasting programs and professionals -- and the Taipei TV Festival.

Sunday, the GIO chief attended a Taiwan film festival in Seoul and delivered a speech on Taiwan's planned policy for the development of the island's film industry. He told the audience that his office plans to allocate NT$20 billion (US$616.4 million) to the development of the so-called cultural innovation and digital content industries in Taiwan.

Yao said that efforts will be made to learn from South Korea and France to help with Taiwan's movie industry development. The efforts include subsidizing South Korean film producers who shoot their films in Taiwan, he noted.

The minister also urged both Taiwan and South Korea to jointly organize movie festivals dedicated to film makers from the two countries as part of efforts to boost bilateral cultural and industry exchanges.

Two noted, award-winning Taiwanese directors, Hou Hsiao-hsien and Tsai Ming-lian, also delivered speeches at the event. Hou and Tsai spoke on the topics of film education and transnational cooperation in business.
Yao and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taiwan Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Hurricane Katrina to hit New Orlean, more than one million people evacuated.
Hurricane Katrina, which caused a great damage to Cuba, is to hit New Orlean Monday. More than one million of people have been evacuated. The city's landmark SuperDome has become a refugee shelter.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Hurricane Bears Down on Gulf Coast; Thousands Flee Area as Vulnerable New Orleans Braces for Direct Hit.
This could be the storm that everyone feared. Hurricane Katrina, one of the strongest storms ever to threaten the United States, carved a path toward the Gulf Coast yesterday, packing 165-mph winds and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of thousands of residents of New Orleans and the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Leaders in Iraq Sending Charter to Referendum
Iraqi leaders presented a disputed constitution to the country's parliament on Sunday, overriding the objections of Sunni negotiators, sending the document to voters and setting the stage here for a protracted period of political conflict. The Iraqi leaders, a group of mainly Shiite and Kurdish representatives, said they had decided to push ahead with the constitution after Sunni leaders submitted a new list of demands.
Wall Street Journal: Why Oil's Surge Hasn't Damped Global Growth, Prices, Interest Rates Stay Low, While Property Boom
The near-doubling of oil prices -- to US$70 in the past 24 months -- has had surprisingly little impact on the pace of global growth, as other broad economic factors have helped damp the damage inflicted by previous oil-price shocks. The global real-estate boom and a flood of cheap goods from Asia have enabled consumers, particularly in the U.S., to continue spending despite higher energy prices. In contrast with past episodes, this surge in oil prices stems more from global economic vigor -- the strong demand for oil from China and the U.S. -- rather than producers' manipulative tightening of supply or fears about Middle East conflicts disrupting supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTIES BLAST 'SYCOPHANTIC CULTURE' IN DPP GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: Two major opposition parties Monday severely criticized the "sycophantic culture" within the government bureaucracy after learning that NT$1.5 million had been spent to build a bridge just to facilitate President Chen Shui-bian's inspection of the construction project of a tunnel on the Taipei-Ilan Freeway.

Chen, accompanied by Premier Frank Hsieh, inspected the tunnel project Aug. 27. To avoid his motorcade making a detour, the National Highway Bureau of the RSEA Engineering Corp. built a steel-supported bridge, which the opposition claims will soon be torn down at a cost of NT$15 million.

Sun Ta-chien, deputy convener of the legislative caucus of the People First Party (PFP), urged the transportation and communications committee of the Legislative Yuan to make an in-depth investigation into the issue.

He said that if it is proven true that the bridge was built specifically to facilitate the president's inspection, then the Presidential Office should pay for the cost of the bridge and the expense of tearing it down. In addition, the PFP legislative caucus would propose a drastic reduction of the budget of the Department of Transportation of Communications (DTC) next year.

Legislator Chou Hsi-wei, a candidate of the Kuomintang running for Taipei County magistrate in the year-end election, criticized the "sycophantic culture" within the government bureaucracy and blamed DTC officials for wasting taxpayers' money.

Legislator David Huang, deputy convener of the legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, said if it is true that the bridge had been built just for the president's inspection, the bureaucratic system will have to be reformed thoroughly to get rid of the "sycophantic culture."
The dispute over the bridge's construction flared Sunday when TV media, tipped by angry local residents, found the bridge was closed to traffic after the president's inspection.
Reacting to the criticisms, Premier Hsieh promised Monday that he would look into the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WARNS ROTARIANS OF CHINA'S STRONGARM TACTICS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian warned Monday that China would definitely intensify its suppression against Taiwan in Rotary International when its clout in the non-government world organization increases.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with participants in the 2005 Asia-Pacific Regional Rotaract Conference being held in Taipei.
Even though China has more than 700 missiles targeting Taiwan, Chen said the 23 million Taiwan people will never be daunted.
"We'll never be demoralized by the 700-plus missiles that China has aimed at Taiwan. We'll remain unflinching. We'll never forsake our sacred mission of protecting our homeland," Chen said.
Noting that China is taking an increasingly hard line against Taiwan, Chen said China has spared no efforts to squeeze Taiwan's international presence.

Rotary International is expanding its ranks in China and has set up provisional Rotary clubs in Shanghai and Beijing. Chen said that when Rotary clubs spring up in large numbers in China, Beijing's leaders will definitely begin to use their new-gained clout to suppress Taiwan in the Rotary International organization.

China still imposes restrictions on the establishment of Rotary clubs, but with its economic policy being increasingly liberalized, Chen said, the number of Rotary clubs is expected to mushroom in the years ahead to meet the demand of commercial social functions.

Given China's consistent strategy of using its ever-growing economic clout to denigrate Taiwan's international status, Chen said, Taiwan must be prepared for China's strongarm tactics against its participation in Rotary International activities.
"We should stay alert and begin charting response strategies as soon as possible," Chen said.

Because of China's diplomatic embargo of Taiwan, Chen said the annual conference of Rotaract, a Rotary International division with clubs around the world for people aged 18-30, is one of the few international occasions on which the Republic of China's national flag can fly.

Chen expressed his admiration and appreciation for Taiwan Rotaract members for winning the right to host the 2005 Asia-Pacific Regional Rotaract Conference. More than 600 Rotaractors and Rotarians attended the Aug. 26-29 conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LU CALLS ON MEDIA TO PROMOTE BRIGHT SIDE OF LIFE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called on the nation's media Monday to help cultivate love and faith and report more about the bright side of life so that every member of society will manage to survive all difficulties in life.
Lu made the comments during a seminar on the media's coverage of suicides, to which media executives were invited to sign a self-disciplinary declaration.
Lu said life is extremely precious, and those choosing to end their own lives are not only making a grave mistake but also acting out a tragedy.
If the media plays up suicide stories, sanctifies them or treats them as gossip, they are not doing a job that would please a majority of the people, she added.
She warned that committing suicide has in recent years become almost fashionable in Taiwan, posing a great social and psychological challenge to society.

"Making our world beautiful and harmonious is our common wish, " she said, adding that those killing themselves are making a mistake, but the media would be adding even more mistakes by playing up such tragedies.
Lu urged the media to inspire love, faith and goodwill and report more about the bright side of human nature so that each and every one in society will live on in spite of any difficulty.

Media leaders were asked to endorse an eight-point declaration advising them not to make suicides a lead story, not to use excessive space to report on suicides, not to detail how a person commits suicide, and not to carry sensational photos or the wills of the victims.

The media was also advised against beautifying or glorifying suicides, giving simplified explanations about the reasons for such acts, or exploring such incidents from the perspective of superstition.
The electronic media, meanwhile, were advised not to broadcast suicide stories live.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP ANNOUNCES FORMATION OF TASK FORCE ON FOREIGN WORKERS' HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Prompted by a recent riot by Thai workers, Vice President Annette Lu announced Monday that a task force has been created to look into the situation surrounding the human rights of foreign laborers.

Lu, the chairman of a human rights advisory committee under the Presidential Office, made the announcement when she met with Pimpa Chanprasong, chairwoman of the Thai Congressional Labor Affairs Committee.

Lu apologized for the inhumane treatment suffered by Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC), who were protesting harsh management and poor living conditions. She said hopefully that the "single incident" will not affect friendly relations between Thailand and Taiwan.

Lu said the task force will study Taiwan's foreign labor policy and consult with the Council of Labor Affairs to see if the policy violates human rights and whether it adheres to international convention.
The task force will also call on the Ministry of Justice to learn about its investigation into the riot and visit private enterprises that employ foreign laborers, she said.
The vice president also said that a human rights legal team will be put together to defend Thai laborers on a pro bono basis, noting that no one is above the law in Taiwan.
She urged Kaohsiung lawyers who have high sense of justice and respect human rights to contact her committee to be part of the team aiding the Thai laborers during questioning.

She also said that Taiwan and Thailand must work closely to improve the situation, noting that the media has reported that brokerage companies and ranking officials from both countries have been involved in the introduction of Thai workers. Given this, Lu said that the Thai parliament should also look into possible flaws in exporting laborers to Taiwan.

Pimpa thanked the vice president for her concern for her compatriots, saying that her government was surprised to hear about the riot and regretted that such a thing could happen. It also came as something of a surprise to learn about the conditions that the Thai laborers had to work under, and she said that the laborers should be afforded their human rights and not be exploited.
She also said that Thai representatives should be present when the Thai laborers are questioned.

Lu recalled that when she served as Taoyuan magistrate, she attached much importance to the care of foreign laborers, and that President Chen Shui-bian was also concerned about foreign laborers when he was Taipei mayor.

The nation's top labor official, Chen Chu, chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs, was sentenced to 12 years in prison because of her dedication to human rights and democracy during the Kaohsiung Incident in 1979, Lu said, adding that foreign laborers have contributed a lot to Taiwan's development.
In addition, Lu asked Pimpa to take care of Taiwan people in Thailand as well as the human rights of Taiwanese serving terms in Thai prisons.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STEPS UP ANTI-CORRUPTION CAMPAIGN: JUSTICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said Monday that Taiwan has stepped up efforts to combat official corruption through legislation, crackdowns on shady links between politics and organized crime and upgrading political transparency.

Shih made the remarks in a keynote speech delivered at a regional meeting of the Transparency International (TI) , a non-governmental organization (NGO) dedicated to boosting political accountability and transparency as well as fighting bribery in international business transactions.
According to Shih, previous political corruption in Taiwan could be attributed to a combination of factors, including a lack of the concept of rule of law.

Against this backdrop, Shih said, the government has drawn up a comprehensive basket of measures to wipe out links between politics and organized crime through legislation to enhance political transparency and establish clean politics.

As Taiwan is one of the world's major trading powers, Shih said the government has also added provisions to its anti-corruption statute in line with the Convention on Combating Bribery in International Business Transactions initiated by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).
Under Taiwan's anti-corruption statute, Shih said, local businessmen are banned from bribing foreign public officials.

According to the 2004 TI global corruption perceptions index, Taiwan ranked 35th among the 146 countries around the world subject to the survey. Among Asian countries, Taiwan only lagged behind Singapore, Japan and Hong Kong while ranking far ahead of China, which ended 71st.

The three-day TI East Asian meeting that began Sunday is being organized by the TI's Taiwan chapter. In addition to reviewing the operations of various TI chapters, the participants will focus discussions on the formulation of indexes to gauge corruptibility, promotion of anti-corruption education and civic society values, and mechanisms to prevent corruption in public procurement, as well as other relevant topics.
TI Chief Executive David Nussbaum, TI Asian Director Peter Rooke and many TI members from China, Japan, South Korea, Mongolia and other countries have traveled to Taipei to attend the meeting.
It marks the first time Taiwan has hosted a TI activity to enhance Taiwan's visibility in the global anti-corruption campaign.

TI, founded in 1993, is the only international NGO devoted to combating corruption in any form. It works by bringing society, business and government together in a global coalition. TI-Taiwan is one of the more-than 85 national chapters around the world.
Thanks to the organization's efforts to create a collective power against bribery, TI Chairman Peter Eigen was selected by Reader's Digest magazine in 2004 as its person of the year in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF TO OPEN TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN'S SERVICE CENTER

TEXT.P: The quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will open a service center for China-based Taiwan businessmen Tuesday, an SEF spokesman said Monday.
Premier Frank Hsieh and MAC Chairman Joseph Wu will address the occasion, while SEF Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung and MAC Secretary-General Michael You will preside over the ceremony.

The center originates from an idea by Chang, who has been very attentive to cross-Taiwan Strait affairs and the protection of Taiwan business interest in China since assuming the SEF chairmanship in June to act as the front-runner in dealing with China and providing high-quality services to Taiwan people, the spokesman said.

According to the SEF official, the Taiwan businessmen's service center will be a network comprising 84 Taiwan trade associations across China to offer professional and real-time consultations as well as personal and efficient services on a case-by-case and cross-region basis.

The center will be the second of its kind in just a week after the largest opposition Kuomintang (KMT) inaugurated a similar center last Friday, stirring up rumors that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the KMT are in high gear to win support from the many Taiwan businesspeople operating in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP STRUGGLING TO KEEP POWER BASE THROUGH YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) , considered a powerful upstart party following the 2000 presidential election, is trying hard to maintain its power base in various key areas amid dwindling popularity ahead of the December local elections.

Although the PFP and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) have discussed cooperating in the coming city mayor and county magistrate elections as well as those for city and county councilors and for township and village heads, chances seem slim that the two parties can work out a platform upon which they can fully collaborate, while a much-reported merger is even further off, according to analysts.

PFP Deputy Secretary-General Liao Tsang-song and KMT Secretary-General Chan Chun-po met last week to talk over the issue, marking an initial effort toward eventual consolidation of the opposition "pan blue alliance" of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party. But observers said that a positive result remains remote due to a lack of substantial progress.

The PFP has nominated its own candidates for city mayors and county magistrates in Keelung, Taichung and Chiayi cities and in Hualien, Changhua, Lienchiang, Yilan and Hsinchu counties, in the hope of pressuring the KMT to give way on the issue of shared candidates.

PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung urged KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to open his mind and brace for KMT-PFP cooperation based on mutual respect and leniency. "The KMT is bigger, stronger and richer, and it should make a concession to the PFP, " he claimed, in a reference that the KMT should at least allow several PFP nominees to run in certain areas as joint "pan blue" candidates.
PFP lawmaker Liu Wen-hsiung, who has been nominated by the party to run for Keeling mayor in northern Taiwan, said that it will be all "empty talk" if the KMT shows no willingness to do so.

Should the two parties fail to come up with a joint strategy, the performance of the "pan blue alliance" in the elections will be much affected in the face of neck-and-neck competition from the "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, Liu said.

After Ma became KMT chairman in the middle of this month, the KMT pledged to conduct pre-election negotiations with the PFP based on the principle of "respecting public opinion and making good on promises through institutionalized mechanisms."

Despite the KMT pledge, prospects for KMT-PFP negotiations appear dim owing to the lack of mutual trust and the PFP's failure to come up with a key election strategy, analysts said, pointing out that the PFP hopefuls might have to help themselves if they want to score "pan blue" representation in the elections.

PFP officials have proposed joint electioneering and coalition rule at the local government level as the party's basic tone for cooperation with the KMT, but all relevant issues must be settled between Ma and PFP Chairman James Soong, who is in the United States.

In sharp contrast to rising popularity enjoyed by the KMT after former Chairman Lien Chan returned from a visit to China in spring this year, the PFP has seen a rapid decrease in public support in recent months.

Watchers have attributed the change to the KMT's leadership role in the opposition camp thanks to Lien's China visit and to a charismatic Ma, who is extremely popular among "pan blue" backers and middle-road voters.

Apart from these two factors, Soong's meeting with independence-leaning President Chen Shui-bian in late February also has widely been viewed as a serious blow to PFP backers, seriously eroding public support for the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRENUOUS EXERCISE ON WEEKEND ONLY DOES NOT IMPROVE HEALTH: DOCTORS

TEXT.P: It is not a good habit for busy people to skip exercise on weekdays and do strenuous exercise on weekends only, doctors claimed Monday.

Chen Chih-hung, president of National Cheng Kung University Hospital, and Yang Jui-cheng, director of the Department of Exercise Medicine of Kaohsiung Medical University, made the remarks at a seminar on the right ways to exercise.
Chen said most people are afraid of cancer, while ignoring cardiovascular diseases that do not show evident symptoms but can be fatal.
In order to avoid a heart attack caused by cardiovascular disease, he advised people who do not exercise daily not to concentrate their "weekly exercise volume" on the weekend.
Huang Shu-min, a fitness company's general manager, said some people will try to finish a week's exercise hours on Saturday or Sunday, becoming a "weekend zealot."
She advised those who have not exercised for a long time to take a physical checkup before engaging in a strenuous exercise program, making sure about the body's water, protein, fat and bone density.
One needs also to understand the fat ratio and its distribution throughout the body before doing heavy sports, she added.
Yang said correct exercise must be done regularly and persistently, in accordance with a good schedule. Otherwise, he claimed, it will not be beneficial to one's health.
Huang said exercise, proper diet, rest and stress management are essential to good health.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP SUPPORTS REGULAR BUDGET, OPPOSES SPECIAL BUDGET FOR ARMS PURCHASE

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said Monday that it supports the Ministry of National Defense idea of listing one item of an arms procurement package under the regular annual budget, but will not agree to listing two other items of the arms procurement project under a special budget.

Minister of National Defense Lee Jye called on the PFP legislative caucus to communicate with them on the change of the funding for the purchase of three major categories of arms from the United States, originally listed under a special budget.

The PFP legislative caucus said it will support six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries being listed under the regular budget at around NT$130 billion (US$4.06 billion), but will continue to oppose the listing of eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft under a special budget for a total of around NT$330.3 billion.
Daniel Huang, PFP caucus whip in the legislature, described the ministry's new version of the arms procurement project as "old wine in a new bottle" and offering nothing new.

He said the caucus opposes the financing of the procurement under a special budget because the government has bloated its funding, adding that the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the PFP and the Kuomintang has in the past blocked the arms procurement package via special budget several times, supposedly "with the support of the public."

Sun Ta-chien, another PFP caucus whip in the legislature, also said the party has conveyed to Lee its wish not to leave debts to future generations through the special budget and its opposition to voting on the whole package instead of on each individual item, saying that the arms procurement project should consider defense needs, urgency and price.

He stressed that if the Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries are listed under the annual budget, the caucus will approve a screening, although he added that this does not mean the caucus will accept it all, or be lax in screening.

Since President Chen Shui-bian has promised to upgrade the defense budget to 3 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) , he suggested to the ministry that it had better put the procurement of submarines and anti-submarine planes under the regular budget.

Both Huang and Sun cited Lee's remarks in which he said the U.S. has sent a message to the ministry expressing concern about the progress of the arms procurement deal and that the ministry is under tremendous pressure.

If the special budget for arms procurement is not passed, the defense capability will not be upgraded, Lee was quoted as saying, and he was also pessimistic about raising the national defense budget to 3 percent of the GDP, saying that "the Executive Yuan will not necessarily agree to it."

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS GATHER TO FIND WAYS TO IMPROVE TAIWAN'S SPORTS PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: Sport experts, scholars and coaches from around Taiwan attended a forum Monday in Taipei to discuss ways for the nation to get rid of its sporting weakness.

Tsai Chen-wei, chairman of the Republic of China Sports Federation (ROCSF), said he hopes Taiwan will win at least seven gold medals in the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing after it took two golds in the Athens event last year, a record in Taiwan's sporting history.
Tsai made the remarks in his address to the one-day forum, titled "Taiwan's Project Hope in Sport."

A wide range of discussions were conducted on three major topics, including pooling industrial, government and academic power to produce sports resources, enhancing athletic skills and taking more part in international sporting events, and increasing the number of athletes.

One of the most attractive issues at the event was a project to set up a national fund for sports development. Kao Chun-hsiung, president of the Taiwan Society of Sport Management, described the fund as the best way to use financial resources effectively.

Kao said that via the fund, money could be more efficiently spent on sports affairs. He noted that compared with neighboring countries, such as Japan and South Korea, Taiwan's general sports development was not enhanced at all, despite it's Olympic success in Athens.

The forum also saw the participation of Minister of Education Tu Cheng-shen, who announced the ministry's seven sport policy goals at the event, including increasing physical exercise in schools, attaching greater importance to athletes' development, constructing a sports "damage control mechanism" and building a national sports university.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW DORMITORIES IN KAOHSIUNG TO ACCOMMODATE 1,000 THAI LABORERS

TEXT.P: Two dormitory buildings in the Hsiaokang District of Kaohsiung City currently being refurbished will soon be ready for Thai laborers working on greater Kaohsiung's rapid transit railway project to move into, acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai said Monday.

Chen gave the assurance to news media when he made an inspection tour of the dormitory area. He said the first group of 150 Thai workers will be able to move in Tuesday and that the two dormitories eventually will accommodate a maximum of 1,000 people.
The acting mayor said that he would spend a night in one of the rooms to "experience what it feels like to live there."

The two buildings, owned by the city government, will be leased to the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) for NT$300,000 per month. They consist of living quarters, dining rooms, shower rooms, lavatories and a canteen -- all equipped with air-conditioners.
Adjacent to the dormitories is a playground with basketball courts surrounded by trees and bushes.
Chen said that "satisfaction will be guaranteed" and that the Thai workers will have a comfortable living environment.

The 1,700 Thai laborers working on the Kaohsiung rapid transit railway currently live in four two-story dormitories at Kangshan in Kaohsiung County. The living quarters are crowded, without air-conditioning. The poor living conditions and the harsh restrictions placed on the workers by a brokerage agency triggered a riot Aug. 21 that caused NT$10 million-worth of property damage.

As a result of the incident, the authorities have been criticized severely for subjecting the Thai workers to inhumane treatment. Under mounting pressure, the Kaohsiung city government and KRTC promised to improve the living conditions of the laborers until they are totally satisfied.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1ST DETECTOR DOG TRAINING CENTER INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first detector dog training center was inaugurated at National Pingtung University of Science and Technology Monday.
The Council of Agriculture (COA) said the university has helped train 12 teams of detector dogs and handlers over the past two years.

With the completion of the new training center, COA officials said, the ranks of detector dogs and their handlers will continue to expand to contribute to the campaign against animal and plant smuggling.
Taiwan began using detector dogs in 2002 when the United States assisted in training three teams of detector dogs and handlers.
The teams have since been posted to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Kaohsiung International Airport and the post of Shuitou on the outlying island of Kinmen, respectively.

The officials said the dogs have helped uncover more than 20,000 cases of passengers bringing in banned livestock products and farm produce. The seizures have amounted to 27 metric tons, according to COA tallies.

"It is hoped that the new training center can train more detector dogs to contribute more to the protection of our agriculture and environment, " said Sung Hua-tsung, director of the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Inspection and Quarantine.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES SOUTH KOREAN LAWMAKER TO HELP HIM ATTEND APEC FORUM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope Monday that South Korean parliamentarian Lee In-je will help him attend this year's informal leadership meetings of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Busan.
The president made the remarks when receiving Lee at the Presidential Office.

The president noted the 2005 APEC summit will be held in South Korea's second largest city Busan in November. Saying that Taiwan, Hong Kong and China became APEC members in 1991 due to the assistance of the South Korean government, he urged the South Korean government and its leader to use "political wisdom" to help him attend the summit in his capacity as Taiwan's leader.
Lee agreed to do his best, saying that if Chen can attend it will have a positive impact on peace, prosperity and stability in Asia.

The president noted that Taiwan-South Korea relations have been improving over the years, citing as examples the mutual waiving of visas, the resumption of air links and the establishment of a Taiwan representative office in Busan.

Bilateral trade has grown in recent years at a pace of 30 percent annually, reaching US$16.9 billion in 2004, with South Korea enjoying a trade surplus of US$6.3 billion, becoming the second-largest country with which Taiwan suffers from a trade deficit.

On civilian exchanges, people from both countries made a total of 450,000 visits in 2004, two-thirds of which were Taiwanese visiting South Korea, while the remaining third were South Koreans visiting Taiwan, up 60 percent from the previous year.

In view of the close trade exchanges, Chen said he hopes Lee will help resume economic ministerial-level consultations between the two countries and promote the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between the two countries.
Lee said Chen has a lot of supporters in South Korea, adding that he and many others in his country have read the South Korean-version of "Taiwan's Son," written by Chen.
Lee also said that the signing of an FTA will boost bilateral economic interests and the progress of substantial relations and he is willing to promote it.

APEC is one of the few international organizations that admit both Taipei and Beijing. Because of Beijing's opposition, the Republic of China's head of state has been unable to attend previous APEC annual informal leadership meetings and has instead had to name a proxy to attend on his behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET FINALIZES MINIMUM TAX DRAFT BILL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet finalized a draft bill Monday on the minimum tax system, marking a step forward toward much-anticipated income tax reforms.
The final version of the draft bill was approved at a coordinating meeting of the Cabinet and the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

According to the draft bill initiated by the Ministry of Finance, businesses with an annual income of NT$2 million or more will be subject to a minimum tax rate of 10 percent, while individuals with an annual income of NT$8 million and above will be subject to a minimum tax rate of 20 percent.
The draft bill will be referred to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation and approval in its soon-to-open new session.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-JUDGE ORDERED TO PAY PROSECUTOR FOR AFFAIR WITH PROSECUTOR'S WIFE

TEXT.P: A former judge of the Hsinchu District Court was ordered by the courts Monday to pay a prosecutor NT$1.7 million (US$523,351)in damages for committing adultery with the prosecutor's wife, who was then a judge of the Hsinchu District Court.
The defendant, Chang Yu-shu, served at the Hsinchu District Court as did the plaintiff, Chiu Chao-chih and his wife, Lei Ya-wen.
Chang and Lei fell in love with each other when they both enrolled in a master's program at the National Chiao Tung University in Hsinchu and had sex in California in 2002.

Lei gave birth after returning to Taiwan and her husband became suspicious of the daughter's parentage after finding the baby girl did not resemble him and the defendant, who frequented his house to look the baby after returning from California, fueled his suspicion.
The plaintiff subjected the baby to a DNA test, which proved that he is not the girl's father.
Both Chang and Lei quit their posts at the court after Chiu brought a action against Chang and divorced his wife.

Although the Taipei District Court ordered Chang to pay Chiu damages, it threw out the criminal charge of adultery against Chang on the grounds that as it occurred overseas, it did not fall under the court's jurisdiction.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR AUGUST 30 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, August 30:

10:00, Premier Frank Hsieh and Mainland Affairs Council Minister Joseph Wu will jointly inaugurate a service center for Taiwan businessmen set up under the auspices of the Straits Exchange Foundation.
10:00, A seminar on Taiwan's hi-tech industries organized by the Ketagalan Institute will open in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.
10:00, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan will honor temples that have donated generously to charities at a ceremony hold at the Taipei County Hall in Panchiao.
13:30, The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold its weekly meeting.
16:00, The Ministry of Economic Affairs will hold a news conference at its Taipei headquarters.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at its Taipei headquaters.
17:00, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at its headquaters in Panchao, Taipei county.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Aug. 30, or the 26th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
30 B.C.: Mark Antony, the ruler of the eastern part of the Roman Empire, commits suicide at the court of his lover, Cleopatra, queen of Egypt, who later commits suicide by allowing an asp to bite her breast.
1483: Louis XI, king of France who was responsible for the unification of his country after the Hundred Years War, dies and is succeeded by his son, Charles VIII.
1862: Thomas Jonathan Jackson, known as "Stonewall," American Confederate general, leads his forces to victory against the Union Army at the Second Battle of Bull Run in Virginia. He was accidentally killed by his own troops at Chancellorvile in 1863.
1901: The vacuum cleaner is patented by Scotsman Hubert Cecil Booth.
1916: Turkey declares war on Romania.
1918: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, known as "Nikolai Lenin," first head of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is shot and wounded by Fanya Kaplan and her sister Dora in Moscow.
1928: Jawaharlal Nehru founds the Independence of India League.
1932: Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Nazi politician and military leader, is elected president of the German Reichstag. He was responsible for the buildup of the German air force, directed Germany's wartime economy and was designated Hitler's successor in 1939.
1937: American boxer Joe Louis flattens Britain's Tommy Farr to win the heavyweight title at Madison Square Garden in New York.
1940: Sir Joseph John Thomson, British physicist, dies at the age of 84. He won a Nobel Prize in 1906 for investigating the electrical conductivity of gases.
1945: Hong Kong is liberated when the British Navy under Rear Adm. Cecil Harcourt sails into Victoria harbor to accept the Japanese surrender.
1949: The Southeast China Governor's Office, which was established in Taipei on Aug. 15, appoints Gen. Sun Li-jen as commander-in-chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command.
1958: Mainland China's Resolution Concerning the Establishment of People's Communes in the Rural Areas is promulgated. In a period of less then three months, 26,578 people's communes involving 127 million peasant household were established all over the mainland.
1963: The "hot line," a direct telephone line between the White House and the Kremlin linking the US president with the Soviet leader, becomes operational.
1974: A bomb planted by leftist guerrillas explodes in the main office of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries at Marunouchi in Tokyo, killing eight people and injuring 376 others.
1979: Ding Mou-shih, former vice minister of Foreign Affairs, leaves for Seoul to assume his post as ROC ambassador to the Republic of Korea.
1981: Muhammad Ali Rajai, president of Iran, and his prime minister, Mohammed Javad Bahonar, become victims of a bomb planted in the premier's office in Teheran.
1981: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives US Senator John Glenn.
1988: Republic of China-US talks on finance and banking open in Washington. The ROC negotiators agree to open the Taiwan market to credit card companies and to expand credit for foreign banks.
1989: Guatemalan President Marco Vincicio Cerezo Arevalo arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1990: Chien Mu, a great master in the study of Chinese classics, dies in Taipei at the age of 96.
1991: Azerbaijan declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1999: New Salvadoran Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew leaves Taipei for Los Angeles en route to Panama to attend the inauguration of President-elect Mireya Moscoso on Sept. 1 as the special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian receives Brisbane Mayor Jim Soorley, and welcomes his visit aimed at strenthening exchanges between the ROC and Australia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is truth, there is intelligence; where there is intelligence, there is truth."

Prime Minister and Liberal Demoratic Party President Junichiro Koizumi stresssed Monday he will step down immediately if the ruling coalition fails to win a majority in the 480-seat House of Representatives in the Sept. 11 election.

The Straits Times: Petrol soars to $2 a litre as oil output is hit.
Petrol shot up to almost $2 a litre yesterday as fears that Hurricane Katrina would cripple US refining capacity sent crude soaring past US$70 (S$117) a barrel.
The price hike is the fourth to hit Singapore motorists in less than three months and means they are now paying over 20 percent more for a litre of petrol than just six months ago.
