DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION HELPING PROMOTE TAIWAN-PANAMA TIES: PANAMANIAN F.M.
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 29 (CNA) (By M.H. Huang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Panamanian Foreign Minister Samuel Lewis Navarro said Monday that the current visit to Panama City by a Republic of China trade delegation will certainly lead to an increase in employment opportunities in his country and promote trade and investment relations between Taiwan and Panama.
The minister made the comments while attending the opening ceremony of a workshop held by the delegation for Panamanian businesses.

The delegation, consisting of 58 foreign trade officials and representatives from 42 companies, is currently on a three-day visit in Panama. It will also visit Argentina, Uruguay, Peru and Mexico during its two-week tour in Latin America.

Lewis, who also serves as Panamanian first vice president, said that the current Panamanian government, which will soon mark the first anniversary of the inauguration of President Martin Torrijos Espino, attaches great importance to activities that attract foreign investment and create employment opportunities for Panamanian citizens.

Pointing out that Panama and Taiwan have traditionally maintained very friendly relations and strong diplomatic ties, the minister said that further steps are needed to translate this strong relationship into improvements in the Panamanian people's wellbeing.

Panama's foreign policy is aimed at boosting the nation's development and creating trade and employment opportunities as well as improving the living standards of the people, he further said. "That is why I'm here to attend this ceremony," he added.

Lewis also refuted media reports about the inconvenience to the the Panamanian government of receiving ROC President Chen Shui-bian if he visits Panama in September, saying that he does not know why the media "makes such fabricated reports."
"The reports are totally groundless, and my presence at this ceremony proves that Taiwan and Panama maintain cordial relations, " the minister continued.

Addressing the ceremony, Hou Pin-fu, ROC ambassador to Panama, said that trade between Taiwan and Panama amounted to US$270 million in 2004, with Taiwan exporting a total of US$246.7 million worth of goods to Panama and importing US$23 million worth of products from the country. Panama is now Taiwan's sixth largest trade partner and third largest export market in Central and South America, he added.
Besides Lewis, Panamanian Vice Minister of International Trade Carmen Gisela Vergara also attended the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB ISSUES SEA WARNING FOR TYPHOON TALIM

TEXT.P: With Typhoon Talim gaining in strength and heading directly toward Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea warning for the typhoon Tuesday morning.

Packing winds of up to 184 kilometers per hour, Typhoon Talim was centered 840 kilometers east of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi as of 11: 30 a.m. Tuesday, moving west-northwestward at a speed of 21 kilometers per hour, according to the latest CWB data.

Since a high pressure system in the Pacific Ocean shows no signs of weakening, Typhoon Talim is likely to hit Taiwan directly, the CWB meteorologists said, adding that the bureau will also issue a land warning for Talim later Tuesday if its current course and speed remain unchanged.
The CWB appealed to the public to avoid any seaside activities, noting that waters along the northeast and southeast coasts of Taiwan will be affected by the approaching typhoon.
Meanwhile, hot weather and afternoon thundershowers are forecast to continue around the island until Wednesday, when sporadic downpours are expected as Taiwan comes under the influence of Talim.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Hurricane Katrina battered southern United States, killing at least 70 people.
Devastating Hurricane Katrina dealt a massive blow in Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama, killing at least 70 people and causing property losses of more than US$30 billion. Winds tore off parts of the roof of famous Louisiana Superdome in New Orlean where sheltered some 10,000 people. U.S. President George W. Bush declared a state of emergency for Louisiana and Mississippi.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERVICE CENTER FOR 'TAISHANG' LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: A center to serve Taiwan businesspeople operating in China, known locally as "taishang," was launched Tuesday under the auspices of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Premier Frank Hsieh, SEF Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung, SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General You Ying-lung, and Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu jointly presided over a plague-unveiling ceremony for the service center.
Hsieh said the inauguration of the service center is a "historic step" toward demonstrating the government's determination to take care of the interests of taishang.
It is the first official center to serve Taiwan businesspeople based in China, the premier added.

He also said that since Chang took over the helm of the SEF in June, he has learned in depth the needs of taishang and has several times spoken with them about the importance of increasing staff for the SEF and upgrading service quality at the quasi-official institution.

For this reason, the Executive Yuan has appropriated NT$100 million (US$3.07 million) for the SEF despite the central government's decreased budget for next year, hoping that this will make more resources available to serve Taiwan businesspeople operating in China.

SEF Chairman Chang, speaking on the same occasion, said that it is hoped the opening of the service center will make the public feel that the government is taking substantive steps to take care of the interests of the people.

He said the service center plans to work closely with Taiwanese associations in China to provide them with professional and real-time service, including emergency assistance services, assistance in dealing with trade disputes, and business information services, to name a few.
The center is the second of its kind to be established in just one week after the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) inaugurated a similar center last Friday.
The KMT caucus in the legislature said that the party is happy to see the inauguration of the service center, although it was hastily launched and its effectiveness is questionable.

Cho Po-yuan, a KMT whip in the legislature, said that a communications platform between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has yet to established and that the government's promise to cater to China-based Taiwan businesspeople may be more symbolic than substantive.

For his part, Chang said that he is happy to see more taishang service centers being launched, but he added that if the service has too many political ends, then the quality of service might be negatively affected, which he said would result in the center not obtaining the support of the taishang.

He denied that the SEF is simply following in the footsteps of the KMT by establishing the center, saying that the SEF broached the idea of such a service center when it convened a provisional director and supervisor meeting Aug. 11. Afterwards, he heard that the KMT was planning a similar center.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN FOR TAIWAN REPUBLIC CONVENER SNUBBED BY KUOMINTANG

TEXT.P: The convener of the "908 Campaign for the Republic of Taiwan" was kept from entering the Kuomintang (KMT) headquarters Tuesday when he tried to deliver an invitation to KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to attend a flag hoisting ceremony on Sept. 8.

Wang Hsien-chi said he was delivering the invitation in the hopes that the KMT leader, who has pledged "to connect the KMT's history to that of Taiwan, " will stand along with Taiwan's mainstream public opinion and support his cause to build a new nation called the Republic of Taiwan.

Wang said that it is wrong for Ma to try to "connect to Taiwan before connecting to China." Rather, he said he would advise Ma to "connect to the people of Taiwan first and join in building the Republic of Taiwan before making friends with China."
He also suggested that the KMT donate one-thousandth of the NT$4 billion obtained from selling a piece of KMT real estate toward his campaign.

Wang was not invited into the KMT office to communicate his ideas. Hsieh Wen-huang of the KMT Policy Committee greeted Wang at the door, telling him that the KMT respects his ideology but does not agree with his Taiwan independence position.
Wang said his campaign is a reflection of grass-roots voices that should not have been stopped at the KMT entrance.

He urged Ma to be a co-sponsor of the Sept. 8 activity which aims to highlight "the memorial day of Taiwan independence." Ma should realize that the sovereignty of Taiwan belongs to the people of Taiwan, he added.
Ma is not expected to respond directly to Wang's invitation as Hsieh has already made clear the party's position.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIPLOMATIC WORK NOT ALL POLITICS: ROC ENVOY TO EU

TEXT.P: Diplomacy must include promoting better relations with cultural exchanges as well as establishing the concept of common values with other nations, Taiwan's European envoy in Belgium said Monday in Brussels.

Chen Chien-jen, Taiwan's representative to the European Union (EU) and Belgium, made the remarks while attending an activity to thank Belgian Catholic fathers and sisters who have retired from their longtime service as missionaries in Taiwan.

The event, organized by the Taiwan Representative Office in Brussels, was held at a center run by the CICM (Congregation of the Immaculate Heart of Mary) , a missionary institute of priests and brothers for retired Belgian Catholic missionaries in Louvain, a city some 25 kilometers east of Brussels.

Noting that mutual understanding between two nations can at times be improved by exchanges that are not directly related to diplomatic work, the envoy said that no matter how good or bad political relations between two countries are, they have to promote cultural, educational, scientific and religious cooperation as well.
According to the representative, the CICM, which was founded by Belgian Reverend Theophile Verbis in 1862, began to send missionaries to Taiwan in 1955.
Chen also promised that he and his colleagues will visit the retired Belgium Catholic fathers and sisters on a regular basis in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 17.32 points to close at 6,032.12.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,087.86 and hit a low of 6,021.97 during trading. A total of 2.67 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$65.88 billion (US$2.01 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.9 percent, textile stocks at 0.6 percent, cement stocks at 0.1 percent.

The other four major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 0.9 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.4 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 515 to 349, with 176 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, TSU LAWMAKERS SUPPORT CABINET'S MINIMUM TAX PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lai Shyh-bao and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator David Huang voiced their support Tuesday for the government's minimum tax proposal that is expected to be approved in a Cabinet meeting Wednesday.
Under the Cabinet proposal, which has to win Legislative Yuan approval to become policy, the minimum tax rates will be 10 percent for businesses and 20 percent for individuals.

However, companies whose investment plans were approved before the new measure goes into effect will not be bound by the new rate if the new investment project starts within one year and is completed within three years of the new rule. These companies will continue to enjoy a five-year tax exemption as part of the government's incentives to encourage business investment.
Lai said some people might think that a 20 percent minimum personal income tax rate is too high, but compared with other advanced countries, the rate is quite low.
He said he will support the Executive Yuan proposal and hopes that the Cabinet will "persist to the end" in the face of possible pressure from the private sector.
Huang, who is also the minor opposition party's legislative caucus deputy convener, said he supports the Cabinet's policy initiative to push for a minimum tax system and to make it a fair one.
Huang suggested that once the new rule has been implemented, the government's increased revenue should go to balancing the budget and financing more social welfare programs.
He advised the government not to count small- and medium-sized business owners as "rich people, " whose earnings are subject to the 20 percent minimum income tax rate.
The government has set a threshold of NT$2 million for small- and medium- sized enterprise owners, a standard that Huang said is too low and should be raised. He did not suggest a number.

Christina Liu, a lawmaker of the People First Party, said there is still room for discussion with regard to the "trust and protection" clause in the tax reform proposal guaranteeing a five-year tax holiday for business investors.
The legislature should also debate whether the tax base should be expanded, she said. If the tax base is to be enlarged, then tax rates can be lowered, she added.

For instance, Liu said, the tax base for collecting business income tax includes the stock transaction tax; if the government is to levy capital gains tax on businesses, should they be exempted from paying the stock transaction tax?
The government should also try to solve the problem of the unfair tax burden for people with the same earnings but who are taxed differently, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPES LOCAL GASOLINE PRICES WON'T BE HIKED

TEXT.P: With crude oil prices hitting new record highs in recent days, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that he hopes domestic gasoline prices won't be hiked despite the situation.
However, he added that as free market forces largely determine prices, the most the government can do now is to monitor the situation closely.

Nevertheless, Hsieh noted he has instructed the Ministry of Economic Affairs not to adjust prices based on the simple formula of the price of a barrel of oil, which has hit US$70 in recent days. He said that any gasoline price adjustments should take all factors into consideration, including amount of oil stocks, contracts, and sustainability.
The premier made the remarks in reply to questions by reporters about whether the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. will hike gasoline prices amid rising crude oil prices.

Hsieh cited a foreign wire report Tuesday as saying that oil prices are expected to fall to US$67 per barrel as the United States has moved to release oil from stockpile. Nevertheless, Hsieh urged the public to try to reduce gas consumption and to conserve energy, saying that this is "good for the world and good for Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN PEOPLE UNHAPPY, HOPING FOR BETTER ECONOMY, MEDIA: POLL

TEXT.P: Most of the people in Taiwan do not feel happy, with many of them hoping for a better economy and media self-discipline, according to the results of a recent survey released Tuesday.

According to the survey by the local monthly Common Health, nearly 25 percent of the Taiwan people have problems sleeping, while 43 percent get vexed easily, and 73 percent complain about social injustice in terms of fame and fortune. More than 50 percent are pessimistic or feel uncertain about the future.

Less than 20 precent believe that the existing social welfare system is sufficient to help them get through their difficulties, while only 33 percent know where to look for help when they are in trouble, according to the survey.
Some 73 percent of the respondents complain about social injustice, while 22 percent acknowledge that they do not lead a good life compared to those of celebrities.
A better economy, more job opportunities and a self-disciplined media are the top three wishes of the Taiwan people, according to the survey.

The counties of Kinmen, Hsinchu and Taipei registered the highest percentages of people who feel happy, while the counties of Yunlin and Taitung had the highest ratios of unhappy people among the country's 25 cities and counties due to poor economic situations and inadequate medical-care facilities.

Kinmen residents sleep better than people living in the rest of Taiwan, and they save more money and enjoy excellent public order, according to the survey. Kinmen's suicide rate is the second lowest in Taiwan.
A total of 3,990 valid samples were collected in the survey carried out between June 23 and July 8 on Taiwan citizens over the age of 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TAKING WAIT AND SEE STANCE ON RAISING DOMESTIC FUEL PRICES: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) is playing a waiting game on whether to raise fuel prices in the face of a recent spike in international crude oil prices that topped US$70 a barrel a couple of days ago, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Tuesday.

On Monday, futures jumped to a record US$70.80 a barrel in Asian trading because of fears that Hurricane Katrina, that swept over the Gulf of Mexico and into the states of Louisiana and Mississippi -- major oil refining and offshore drilling areas -- would damage facilities and bottleneck production output.

Ho said that it is uncertain if oil prices will remain at their current high levels seen in concert with Katrina hitting the U.S., adding that the state-run oil corporation has made no move to raise domestic fuel prices.
Hurricane Katrina has left a million without power and killed at least 55, with the death toll expected to climb.
Ho also said the ministry is waiting for the CPC to make an assessment of the situation before commenting on the possibility of higher costs at the gas pumps.

The CPC raised wholesale gasoline prices by 7.64 percent Aug. 3, when international oil prices stood at around US$61 to US$62 a barrel. If oil hovers at US$70 a barrel for the remainder of the year, Ho said, the CPC will face a loss of NT$20 billion (US$612.74 million) . This would eat up all the corporation's profits for the first half of the year, Ho added.
Raising domestic prices will be a matter of how long the CPC is willing to absorb losses, she said, noting that the corporation is striving to maintain normal operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEAM TO INVESTIGATE ALLEGATIONS REGARDING TEMPORARY BRIDGE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that he has asked Minister-without-Portfolio Lin Sheng-feng to head a seven-member team to investigate the controversy surrounding the construction of a makeshift bridge on the Taipei-Ilan Expressway that has been criticized as symbolizing "sycophantic culture" within the government.

Hsieh is under mounting pressure to clarify the situation after media reports revealed that construction of the steel bridge joined to one end of the Snow Mountain Tunnel was completed within two days of President Chen Shui-bian's Aug. 27 inspection at a cost of NT$1.5 million, and that it would cost another NT$15 million to tear the bridge down.

Queried by reporters about the controversy at a news conference, the premier said that a report submitted by the Department of Transportation and Communications gives a different version of the story from that of the media.
He added that since he is not in a position to say which version of the story is correct, he has decided to send a team of experts to investigate the matter.

According to the premier, the team will include four civil engineers and two university professors. They are on their way to the Snow Mountain Tunnel to investigate whether it was necessary for the RSEA Engineering Corp. to build the bridge.

Hsieh said that if it is proven that the construction of the bridge was done purely to "flatter the president, " then those held responsible must be punished. Otherwise, he added, the media has a lot to answer for.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG EXPRESS ALLOWED TO OPERATE HK-TAICHUNG CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Hong Kong Express airline company was given the go-ahead Tuesday to operate charter flight services between Hong Kong and Taichung, central Taiwan.

Mainland Affairs Council Minister Joseph Wu made the announcement after inspecting facilities at the Chingchuankang Airport in Taichung with Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Chang Chia-juch and Civil Aeronautics Administration Director-General Billy K.C. Chang.
Wu said that in principle, Hong Kong Express can fly the route Wednesday at the earliest if enough passengers sign up for the flight.
Hopefully, more Hong Kong tourists will visit the central area of Taiwan with the new charter flights in place, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT ABOUT BREAKTHROUGH IN VATICAN-CHINA TIES NOT TRUE: MOFA

TEXT.P: Reports about a breakthrough in relations between the Vatican and China are not true, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday.

Antonio Hsieh, deputy director-general of the foreign ministry's Department of European Affairs, was responding to a report in De Morgen, a Belgian daily, that quoted Cardinal Godfried Danneels of Belgium as saying that there could be a breakthrough in setting up diplomatic ties between China and the Vatican.

Hsieh said that as far as the foreign ministry understands, the cardinal does not participate in Chinese affairs at the Vatican, and his comments must be his own feelings on the matter. The ministry will keep tabs on the situation, he added.
He pointed out that this must be some media gambit of China's to try to obstruct Taiwan.
He also said that Taiwan will continue to strengthen cultural and academic exchanges with the Holy See and take part in international projects to cement bilateral friendships.
Danneels broke off a visit to China in April when Pope John Paul II died, but plans to go back next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEARING IS BELIEVING WITH NEW COMPUTERS FOR THE BLIND

TEXT.P: Newly designed computers for the visually- impaired have been tested recently by students, who gave the thumbs up Monday to the " talking computers, " according to the Ministry of Education which finances the program.

Chen Kuo-shih, who recently received his Ph.D. in English from National Sun Yat-sen University and the author of a Braille English-Chinese dictionary, recalled that more than 20 of his classmates would take turns reciting English books for him every week when he was still an undergraduate. To complete his Ph.D. thesis, Chen "read" voraciously by hiring some of his classmates to read aloud his textbooks for him, at a cost of over NT$50,000.
Chen noted that a computer reading machine, which caters to the needs of blind people, would be a great help to visually- impaired students of literature or history.

Elementary school student Wang Shih-ming received training in using a special computer for blind people and had a much easier life at school. Aside from being a straight-A student, he also used the Internet to collect information, book train tickets, or even arrange his travel itinerary online.

The new computers for the blind were designed by Tamkang University under the sponsorship of the education ministry. Compatible with Windows operating systems, these computers also have Chinese interfaces and can read aloud every word in a document or on a Web page. The education ministry hopes visually-impaired students can utilize the new machines for studying and to enjoy the benefits of the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE RESTAURANTS IN HUALIEN COUNTY ARE NOW SMOKE-FREE
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien County, eastern Taiwan Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of smoke-free restaurants in Hualien County has increased ninefold since the Health Department of the county government launched a campaign in 2003 to encourage eateries in the county to offer diners a clean environment to enjoy their meals.

Shih Jen-hsin, head of the Health Department of Hualien County, quoted statistics as showing Tuesday that the number of smoke-free restaurants in the county has grown from 16 in 2003 to 160 at present.
He said that an additional 90 or so restaurants have expressed interest in joining the ranks of the smoke-free eateries.

According to Shih, a survey conducted by his department showed that about 80 percent of restaurant diners support the smoke-free campaign. This overwhelming support by consumers, in his view, has been a big encouragement for restaurants to become smoke-free.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved up nine points to close at 6,055, with 16,584 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for October moved up 23 points to end at 6,058, with 157 contracts traded, while December futures gained 13 points to finish at 6,058, with six contracts traded. March futures moved up seven points to close at 6,060, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,046 for September, 6,035 for October, 6,045 for December, 6,053 for March and 6,041 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, mixed.

September TE futures moved down 0.85 points to close at 247.95, with 2,918 contracts traded, while October TE futures lost 0.8 points to finish at 248, with 20 contract transactions. December TE futures moved down 3.7 points to end at 248, with two contracts traded, while March TE futures moved up one point to close at 248.6, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for June.
September TF futures gained 5.6 points to finish at 935, with 1,165 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved up three points to end at 932.6, with 147 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December, March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.170 to close at NT$32.657.
A total of US$1.25 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.507 and fluctuated between NT$32.492 and NT$32.700.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE BUDGET CHANGES 'A GRUELING DECISION': DEFENSE MINISTER LEE

TEXT.P: Minister of National Lee Jye said Tuesday it has been a "grueling" experience for him to decide to use the regular budget to purchase badly needed Patriot III anti-missile batteries from the United States.

He warned that the decision, which has yet to win Legislative Yuan approval, will exclude a total of 53 new investment projects that his ministry had planned for fiscal 2006, thus delaying the implementation of a pivotal ministry program to raise the armed forces' combat capability.

The opposition parties' obstinate resistance was behind Lee's painful decision to remove the purchase of the anti-missile weaponry from a special budget bill that still includes funds for the other two big-ticket items -- submarines and anti-submarine aircraft.

The initial special budget, totalling NT$610.8 billion, has been lowered to NT$480 billion to placate the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party. With the latest changes, NT$340 billion remains in the special budget to buy submarines and anti-submarine aircraft, according to the minister.

The budget for the anti-missile batteries, totalling around NT$140 billion, will be evened out over the next six to eight years in the ministry's annual budgets, official sources said. An assistant to defense critic Lin Yu-fang, a PFP lawmaker, would not comment on this on the grounds that his office has not seen the budget details for the ministry.

Lee told the media on the eve of Reporters' Day, which falls on Sept. 1, that if he had decided to move one more of the two remaining items to the regular budget, Taiwan's armed forces would not be able to carry out any new projects in the next eight years; if all three items were to be financed by the regular budget, the same thing would be true over the next 10 years, "causing irreversible damage to our national defence."

He said the biggest threat that Communist China poses to Taiwan is "missile attacks plus a submarine blockade, " which is also the most economic and effective way for China to conquer Taiwan. The three new weapons that his ministry has been asking the legislature to help acquire are exactly aimed at ensuring that Taiwan will not be paralyzed by China's missile attacks or sealed off by a submarine blockade, he said.

He cited U.S. and Japanese concerns about China's rising military power to try to convince his fellow countrymen that China's growing military threats, backed by its rising economic strength, are real and that his ministry's decision to purchase the three defensive weapons was made through "very strict" assessments and evaluations.

The defense ministry managed to cut NT$21.8 billion from the budget from land procurements, back-up parts and components, infrastructure building, telecommunications equipment, maintenance of transport vehicles and other transportation costs. More substantive cuts come from cancelling a project to cooperate with foreign countries in building new navy ships worth NT$71.93 million and another project to install a telecom system for the Patriot III package, valued at NT$50 million.

The ministry has also moved NT$19.82 billion in "domestic payments" from the special budget to the regular budget, bringing the total cuts to the special budget to US$135.6 billion, so that it now stands at NT$475.2 billion.

Even with that figure, the Legislative Yuan would not bother to put the special budget bill through the Procedure Committee, Lee said. For the sake of "political harmony and the overall interests of the country, " Lee said his ministry has taken the initiative to move the budget for purchasing Patriot III batteries to the regular budget in a gesture of sincerity and goodwill.
The move has apparently improved the atmosphere in ruling-opposition relations, as can be seen from the opposition's willingness to talk with the Ministry of National Defense, Lee said.

The PFP is still not happy that the government will use a special budget to buy submarines and anti-sub aircraft. However, Lee noted that there has been progress from the previous impasse at the legislature. He said his personal future is not important as long as the opposition is willing to discuss the budget at the legislature.

He pledged that once the budget has passed the legislature, "there will absolutely be no scandals" involving the arms procurement and the ministry will "very carefully" use the arms in defense of the nation.
If Taiwan gives up its efforts to boost its defense capability, it will "end up in a dead end" as China has never renounced the option of a military takeover of Taiwan, Lee said.
"Boosting our defense capability is aimed at keeping the cross-Taiwan Strait military imbalance from worsening and protecting our hard-won democratic achievements and economic prosperity, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES ASSESSMENT ON ENGLISH PROFICIENCY INCENTIVE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh instructed government agencies Tuesday to "cautiously assess" the ramifications of a program to encourage public functionaries to study English.

The premier made the remarks after the Central Personnel Administration (CPA) announced recently that English proficiency test institutes for civil servants will be increased to eight from the current one from Sept. 1 and that civil servants getting good grades in tests administered by the eight institutes be given preference in promotion.

Those who have passed the test will be awarded between two and seven points according to their score, the CPA said. As a civil service "big merit" is worth only 1.8 points, the English test has thus become a short cut for civil servants seeking promotion.
The premier noted that to upgrade the English proficiency of civil servants overall by 2008 was a policy set during the term of his predecessor, Yu Shyi-kun, and that the goal remains unchanged.
Hsieh said that upgrading English proficiency will help people get in touch with the world and enhance national competitiveness.

He instructed all government agencies to formulate their own promotion and incentive guidelines based on the consideration of their own operations and service targets and to encourage civil servants to take on-the-job training and upgrade service quality.

He said the government agencies have to cautiously assess the impact brought by the English learning incentive program on the promotion of civil servants so as to avoid "unnecessary trouble for the people."

CPA Deputy Director-General Lee Jo-i had said that although passing an English proficiency test will be a boost to promotion, it is not the only criterion, pointing out that under current regulations, other factors affecting promotion include academic and career background, training, potential and leadership.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COMPANIES WITH OVER 100 FOREIGN WORKERS TO BE PROBED

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai ordered a sweeping probe Tuesday into Kaohsiung-based companies that employ more than 100 foreign workers in the wake of the Thai labor riot that occurred more than a week ago.

Speaking at a news conference following a municipal meeting, Chen said that all Kaohsiung-registered companies with more than 100 foreign laborers must be checked, adding that the Kaohsiung plant of the Formosa Plastics Group also will be inspected, although its 4,800-odd foreign workers now work in its Mailiao plant in Yunlin County.

The Kaohsiung city government has set up a task force to investigate the riot that occurred late Aug. 21 and the ad hoc group will complete a report on the incident within a week, Chen said, adding that the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) -- which employs the workers -- will be told to reshuffle its board members if the company is found to be responsible for the riot.
The KRTC has also been instructed to step up public security inspections of the city's mass transit system construction sites to fend off re-occurrences of the rioting.
Chen also claimed that he will not shun any responsibility if the city government has to shoulder administrative responsibility.

According to Chen, the city government has fined the KRTC NT$300,000 for violating the Employment Services Act due to its poor management of foreign workers. The KRTC was fined a further mere NT$20,000 for unreasonable and overdue overtime pay for the Thai workers building the Kaohsiung mass transit system, hundreds of whom rioted to demand better working and living conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFUNDS TO BE PAYABLE FOR SERIOUS TRAIN DELAYS FROM MID-SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Passengers will be entitled to a full refund of train ticket prices in the event of delays lasting more than 80 minutes from mid-September, Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) Deputy Director-General Chen Feng-nan said Tuesday.

Chen made the promise at a news conference held by Legislator George Hsieh of the opposition People First Party after trains plying the Western Railway were hit with serious delays during the rush hour that morning, generating a chorus of complaints from commuters.

The delays were caused by a construction incident on the railway between Hsichih in Taipei County and Chitu in Keelung City, northern Taiwan when the Reconstruction Bureau of the Taiwan Railway (RBTR) was working on an elevated rail project.
The incident led to the Hsichih-Chitu line being severed for nearly three hours, affecting 56 commuter trains.
Hsieh said that he urged the TRA and the RBTR to address the problem of frequent train delays two weeks ago and he found it "hard to believe" that the same mistake happened again so quickly.
According to TRA statistics, more than 2,400 passengers suffered from train delays lasting over one hour and 20 minutes in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Hurricane Katrina Slams Into Gulf Coast; Dozens Are Dead
Hurricane Katrina pounded the Gulf Coast with devastating force at daybreak on Monday, sparing New Orleans the catastrophic hit that had been feared but inundating parts of the city and heaping damage on neighboring Mississippi, where it killed dozens, ripped away roofs and left coastal roads impassable. Officials said that according to preliminary reports, there were at least 55 deaths. Emergency workers feared that they would find more dead among people who had been trapped in their homes and in collapsed buildings.
Wall Street Journal: Tangled Web, For Entrepreneur, Online Drug Sales Meant Fast Profits
Though Viagra and other anti-impotence remedies are available with a prescription at legitimate pharmacies, there's a thriving online market for these drugs, where customers can obtain the pills anonymously and with ease. But online pharmacies are largely unregulated and unmonitored by health authorities. In many cases, site operators are unlicensed to sell or prescribe prescription medications. Since October 1999, the FDA's Office of Criminal Investigations has made about 180 Internet drug arrests, most of which have resulted in convictions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON MAY LEAVE TAOYUAN COUNTY WITHOUT TAP WATER AGAIN: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taoyuan County residents, troubled by tap water stoppages in the past two years whenever a typhoon strikes northern Taiwan, may be out of running water yet again for up to eight days as a result of Typhoon Talim's forthcoming onslaught, a senior government official warned Tuesday.

Water Resources Agency Director-General Chen Shen-hsien said that if turbidity in Shihmen reservoir reaches 60,000 degrees because of the heavy rain brought by the typhoon, the Taiwan Water Corp. may be forced to stop its water supply to Taoyuan County for six to eight days.

Chen accompanied Vice Economics Minister Ho He-hsiung on an inspection tour of the reservoir -- the source of tap water for Taoyuan County. The management at the reservoir was instructed to open the dam floodgates at 2 p.m. Tuesday to adjust the water level in preparation for expected heavy rainfall from Typhoon Talim.
Meanwhile, an executive of the water company urged residents in Taoyuan County to store enough water for one week so as to avoid an expected repetition of the nightmare of days without running water.

The Central Water Bureau issued a land warning for northern and eastern Taiwan at 8:30 p.m. Tuesday against Typhoon Talim. The eye of the typhoon was located 660 km east of Oluanpi, Taiwan's southernmost tip. With maximum center winds of up to 191 kph, Talim's 250 km radius was moving west-northwest toward Taiwan at 21 kph.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEFENDS BOT DECISION FOR KAOHSIUNG MRT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh defended Tuesday the decision to adopt the "build, operate and transfer" (BOT) mode for building Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit (MRT) system, saying it is no more prone to corruption than any other system and pointing out that many corruption cases occurred during the 60 years of Kuomintang (KMT) rule that did not involve BOT projects.

He was responding to media criticism that the cost of building Kaohsiung's MRT is too expensive, a criticism that was triggered by a riot by Thai workers last week in protest over their inhumane treatment by their Taiwanese employers.
Hsieh said it cost Taipei City NT$440 billion to build its 88 km MRT. By comparison, he said, Kaohsiung will be spending a total of NT$180 billion to build a 42-km system.
Hsieh said the labor riot should not have been used as an excuse to imply that the BOT mode for the project is wrong.

Tsai Yu-chen, a TV critic, claimed that the Kaohsiung city government is paying a "whopping" NT$150.8 billion, or 83.2 percent of the total price for building the MRT system, and yet is not in charge of building it.

She said the city government has allowed a minority investor, Chairman Chen Min-hsien of Southeast Cement Corp., to control the use of the huge construction fund, which she claimed led to the riot and revealed poor management on the part of the company that hired the workers and negligence of duty by responsible government agencies.

Tsai also claimed that the people have reason to worry about the construction quality of the MRT and the safety of the trains if the system is operated by who she claimed is "such a questionable businessman."

DOC.HEADLINE: RISING OIL PRICES WILL IMPACT TAIWAN ECONOMY: ECONOMIST

TEXT.P: Soaring oil prices are expected to have a big impact on Taiwan's economy, prompting shrinkage in exports this year, an economist predicted Tuesday.

Yang Chia-yen, a researcher at the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said that if crude oil prices average US$55 per barrel this year, it will subtract NT$20.55 billion from Taiwan's gross domestic product and drag down investment, leading to an annual reduction of 0.16 percentage points in exports but an annual import increase of 0.21 percentage points.

He estimated falls in outbound shipments of NT$11.11 billion, with increases in inbound shipments at NT$13.73 billion, on an average import oil price of US$55 per barrel -- a 49 percent growth over the 2004 average.

A recovering U.S. economy and voracious demand for crude oil from China and India have made a reduction in global oil consumption impossible, he said, adding that high oil prices will also make it very difficult for the government to improve upon a 4 percent economic growth rate this year, as oil prices exceeded US$70 per barrel for the first time Monday on the world market.
According to Yang, China consumes 6.9 million barrels of oil per day, second only to the U.S.' 20.9 million barrels. China's oil import is expected to grow to 2.9 million barrels per day.

Citing information provided by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, Yang pointed out that the world's daily oil consumption this year is expected to increase from the current level of 82.5 million barrels to 84.28 million barrels.

Meanwhile, the new Taiwan dollar continued a losing streak that has lasted for more than a week, with the local currency finishing at 32.657 against the U.S. dollar Tuesday on the Taipei foreign currency exchange market, down by NT$0.167 from Monday's close.

Despite the fact that world oil prices keep setting fresh highs, it remains too early to talk about inflation in the short term, economists said, adding that the effect for the time being has mainly been a "psychological impact."

They forecast that the Taiwan currency will further slide to 32.8 against the greenback amid new oil price highs, but added that the situation should be observed for at least three months before talking about inflation.

A cheaper local currency means that imported product prices will surge, but this is only a small segment of overall wholesale prices and will have only limited impact on consumer product prices as a whole, they said, adding that the central bank may seek to help boost Taiwan's exports through currency devaluation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DEMANDS SIMPLER WELCOMING CEREMONIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has instructed that ceremonies welcoming him during inspection tours be simplified, an official of the Presidential Office said Tuesday.

Chen Wen-tsung, director-general of the Department of Public Affairs, made the remarks after reports that Hsinchu air base officials canceled leave for servicemen and instead made them practice songs and drills to welcome the president.

The president had originally planned to visit the base Tuesday to record a tape of a message to be delivered for the Sept. 3 Servicemen's Day. But after reports said some military officers had to give up their leave to practice songs in the welcoming ceremony, he called off the trip.

The reports cited an air force spokesman as saying that the base was honored to receive the president on the eve of Servicemen's Day. The spokesman said the base followed the strict protocol of a host and denied media claims that the leave-canceling was an example of "sycophantic culture." He added that servicemen who had their leave canceled will have it made up later.

The president expressed concern about the "rights" of the servicemen being affected because of his visit and instructed his aides to have prior communications in arranging future itineraries to avoid similar incidents from happening again, Chen Wen-tsung said.

The president attaches more importance to substance than formality, and has often thought that a lot of protocols should be scrapped. This, the aide said, is why it is no longer necessary for high-ranking officials to show up at the airport when the president or vice president leave for overseas trips and when they return.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO MAKE TAIWAN ONE OF TOP THREE COMPETITIVE STATES

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh vowed Tuesday to make Taiwan the best in Asia and one of the top three countries in the world in terms of competitiveness.

In a statement presented by the Executive Yuan to the Legislative Yuan Tuesday on administrative plans for next year, the premier said his administration will continue its policy of developing the economy and carrying out reforms by pressing ahead with 10 major projects and the 2008 National Development Program.
The statement said Taiwan has come a long way in terms of its competitiveness in recent years.

Citing a competitiveness report compiled by the Lausanne-based International Institute for Management Development, the statement said Taiwan had moved up from 17th place among 60 economies covered in the report in 2003 to 12th place in 2005, and was in second place in Asia behind only Singapore.

In a competitiveness index authored by the Geneva-based World Economic Forum, the statement said, Taiwan's ranking advanced from 10th spot in 2000 to 4th in 2005, and was listed as the best in Asia for three consecutive years.

In order to cushion the impact of the country's membership of the World Trade Organization and the international trend of globalization, the premier said in the statement that his administration will promote economic and trade exchanges with China with the purpose of setting up a labor-division framework with China.
Hsieh said his administration will continue its efforts to resume dialogue and set up an inter-action framework with China to ensure peaceful development across the Taiwan Strait.

In order to build up mutual trust between the various domestic political parties, he said his administration will continue its pursuit of political stability through negotiation and dialogue with the opposition, as instructed by President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON WARNING ISSUED FOR NORTHERN, EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau issued a land warning against Typhoon Talim for northern and eastern Taiwan Tuesday evening, 12 hours after a sea warning was announced.
Weather forecasters estimated that the storm, packing winds of 191 kph, will made landfall on eastern Taiwan sometime between Wednesday afternoon and Sept. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEXTILE INDUSTRY ATTEMPTS REVIVAL WITH INTERNATIONAL EVENTS

TEXT.P: Facing fierce competition from China, Taiwan's sagging textile industry is trying to polish up its image by staging two international events in the next two months, industry sources said Tuesday.
The first is the 2005 Taipei Innovative Textile Application Show (TITAS) , which is slated to open Sept. 29 and last until Oct. 1 in Taipei.

The show is inviting leading manufacturers locally and from overseas to exhibit fibers, yarns and fabrics, and to introduce new products employing nanotechnology, with bamboo charcoal and many more new materials.
The other will be the Textile International Forum and Exhibition 2005, which will be held in Taipei from Oct. 12-14.

Contrary to the TITAS, which targets buyers and manufacturers, the forum is expected to bring together textile-related industrialists, officials and academics to exchanges views in 18 seminars and panel discussions, hopefully giving the world a better understanding of the country's textile industry.

The two events are vital to the revival of the textile industry, which has seen many small- and middle-sized textile factories forced to downsize or close in the face of China's competition, while the end of a global quota system this year will unleash an era of complete open worldwide competition, according to industry sources.

In order to reinvigorate the once-flourishing industry, the sources said, the government should intervene to push the reorganization of the industry and the consultation of the up- and middle-stream factories that are in disarray after the relocation of many textile factories to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Aug. 31, or the 27th day of the seventh month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
12AD: Caligula, originally Gaius Caesar, Roman emperor remembered for his murderous reign, is born. He succeeded his adopted father Tiberius. After a severe illness, he displayed the ruthlessness, extravagance and megalomania that led to his assassination.
1422: Henry V, King of England, who reopened the Hundred Years' War, defeating the French at Agincourt in 1415 and capturing all of Normandy by 1419, dies of dysentery in France at the age of 35. His son Henry VI accedes to the throne at the age of nine months.
1907: The Anglo-Russian Convention is signed in St. Petersburg, settling differences between the two over Tibet, Afghanistan and Persia.
1907: Ramon Magsaysay, president of the Philippines from 1953 to 1957, is born.
1939: Adolf Hitler announces the invasion of Poland. Three days later, both Britain and France declared war on Germany, marking the outbreak of World War II.
1945: The Nationalist government divides the three northeastern provinces in Manchuria into nine provinces.
1957: Malaysia achieves independence from Britain with Tengku Abdul Rahman as its first president.
1961: President Chiang Kai-shek tells 70 visiting American reporters that Kinmen and Matsu "are as important as West Berlin."
1962: The former British possessions of Trinidad and Tobago become an independent nation.
1962: The Republic of China recognizes the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago.
1965: Pakistan and India threaten war over Kashmir.
1968: A strong earthquake rocks northeastern Iran, killing 12,000 people and injuring over 100,000 others.
1974: The first plant to produce high-density polyethylene resins in the Republic of China is dedicated at Toufen in Miaoli County.
1976: Little League, Big League and Senior League teams return to Taipei after winning world titles in the United States.
1980: The ROC Mulan soccer team wins the championship at the first International Women's Soccer Tournament held in the United States.
1989: Buckingham Palace officially confirms that the marriage of Queen Elizabeth II's daughter, Anne, and Captain Mark Phillips is on the rocks.
1990: Premier Hau Pei-tsun advises the Legislative Yuan that ROC relations with mainland China will operate under the concept of "one country, two areas."
1992: Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher expresses support for the ROC's entry into the GATT during her visit to Taipei.
1993: Beijing makes public a white paper reiterating its position of solving the Taiwan problem by "peaceful reunification" and "one country, two systems," while refusing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
1994: Russian President Boris Yeltsin and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl jointly preside over a farewell ceremony marking an end to half a century of military presence on German soil by troops of the former Soviet Union.
1994: The IRA declares an unconditional end to its 25-year armed struggle for a united Ireland and its war against British rule of Northern Ireland.
1995: The ruling Kuomintang nominates incumbent President Lee Teng-hui as its presidential candidate.
1997: Britain's Princess Diana and her millionaire companion Dodi Al Fayed are killed in a Paris car crash.
1999: Raymond F. Burghardt, the newly appointed director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
2000: ROC Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen says that the military will continue to try to obtain an early warning system after recent war games revealed Taiwan's limited means to counter mainland Chinese missile attack.
2001: Compaq Computer Inc. and Taiwan's Academia Sinica, the highest academic researrch institute in Taiwan, sign a cooperative memorandum to engage in gene and biotechnology research in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only he, in the world, who possesses absolute truth who can get to the bottom of the law of his being. He who can get to the bottom of the law of his being will be able to get to the bottom of the law of being of other men."
