DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BRACES FOR TYPHOON TALIM

TEXT.P: Taiwan is bracing for strong winds and torrential rainfall as Typhoon Talim heads directly toward the island, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) Wednesday.

Talim, the 13th typhoon reported in the Pacific area this year, has a radius of 250 kilometers and a "solid" structure. It is forecast to make landfall in eastern Taiwan, probably between the counties of Ilan and Hualien, sometime between Wednesday afternoon and Thursday morning, CWB meteorologists said.

Packing winds of up to 184 kph, Typhoon Talim was located some 370 kilometers east-southeast of Hualien, moving in a west-northwest direction toward the island at a speed of 21 kph as of 9 a.m. Wednesday.

Speaking at a Cabinet meeting Wednesday morning, Premier Frank Hsieh directed all relevant government agencies to take precautionary steps to deal with the approaching typhoon, saying that "past mistakes should not be repeated."
Hsieh was referring to the prolonged water supply problem in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, following landslides and flash floods triggered by two typhoons in July and August.

Meanwhile, the weather bureau called for the public to be on heightened alert against possible landslides and flash floods in mountainous areas and sudden rises in sea-water levels in low-lying coastal areas.

Officials from the Environmental Protection Administration called for the public to store sufficient amounts of water at home in case of water shortages caused by any failures in reservoir operations.

With eastern and northeastern Taiwan expected to come under the influence of Typhoon Talim by nightfall Wednesday, the local governments of Ilan, Hualien, Taipei, Miaoli and Changhua counties, as well as Taichung City have announced that schools and some public offices will be closed beginning noon Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WANTS CLEAR LINE DRAWN BETWEEN RIGHT AND WRONG IN RIOT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that it is necessary to review the reasons behind the recent riot by Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp., but he also insisted that the actions of a few Thai laborers damaging property and burning vehicles are still unlawful.
The premier made the remarks while commenting during a floor meeting of the Executive Yuan on the Aug. 21 riot by Thai laborers protesting poor living conditions and treatment by management.

Noting that there are multi-level questions in the incident, Hsieh said that there have "indeed been errors and negligence in the treatment of Thai laborers on a human rights level, and an improvement should be made in this regard."

However, he added that, on the legal level, if the government cannot deal with such unlawful acts as drinking alcohol in company living quarters, burning vehicles, and creating public disturbances, then there is no public authority.
He expressed the hope that the Ministry of Justice will deal with the matter according to the law quickly so as to draw a clear line between right and wrong.

On the incident's impact on Taiwan's image, Hsieh said that the riot was an isolated case. Noting that there are around 300,000 foreign laborers in Taiwan and around 15,000 in Kaohsiung alone, the premier said that "one must not say that Taiwan is a country without human rights just because of this isolated incident."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS OFFICIAL TO SPEAK AT APEC SME MINISTERIAL MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, Aug. 31 (CNA) (By Y.C. Chiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting ROC Vice Economic Affairs Minister Shih Yen-shiang is scheduled to speak at the APEC Small and Medium Enterprise (SME) Ministerial Meeting to be held Sept. 1-2 in Taegu, South Korea.
Shih, who arrived in South Korea's third largest city at the head of a Taiwan delegation Tuesday night, will speak on the strategy on industrial clustering for SMEs.

As Taiwan's establishment and operation of science-based industrial parks and industrial zones is the paradigm of industrial clustering for SMEs, Shih said, he wants to share Taiwan's experience with many other nations, including the new trend of Taiwan's science-based industrial parks and industrial zones and their new strategies.

The theme of the 12th APEC SME Ministerial Meeting is "Promoting Innovation of SMEs, " and SME ministers from 21 Asian-Pacific economies will discuss ways of encouraging business-academic cooperation, fund raising, and information and business networking of small businesses.
APEC SME ministers are expected to adopt the "Taegu Initiative on SME Innovation Action Plan" at the close of the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL NEGOTIATIONS NEEDED FOR OPENING OF CROSS-STRAIT FLIGHTS: MAC

TEXT.P: Official negotiations between Taiwan and China are definitely required for the opening of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, Mainland China Affairs (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday.

The opening of regular cross-strait charter flights, even if only for weekends, would be difficult if only advocated by private sector individuals and without official negotiations across the strait, Wu stressed.

Commenting on a recent suggestion by Kuo Tai-chiang, chairman of Taiwan's Council for Industrial and Commercial Development, that Taiwan and China open direct cargo/passenger charter flights between Taipei and Shanghai on weekends for six months on a trial basis, Wu said that such flights can only be implemented after officials from the two sides reach a consensus on the matter.

Kuo suggested that the two sides open cargo/passenger charter flights between Taipei and Shanghai on a trial basis to allow Taiwan businesspeople operating on the Chinese mainland to return to their Taiwan homes on weekends.

Kuo said that it could be decided after the six-month trial basis whether the Taipei-Shanghai weekend charter flight services should continue or should even be expanded to become regular cross-strait charter flights.

The business tycoon also cited the results of a recent Gallop Poll as indicating that 70 percent of the Taiwan public believe that regular cross-strait cargo/passenger charter flights should be launched.
According to the poll, most of the respondents think that ideology is the major obstacle preventing cross-strait charter flight services from being implemented.
The poll also found that 70 percent of the Taiwan public agree that authorities from the two sides of the strait should resume official negotiations on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY BUDGET UP NT$7.2 BILLION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense's (MND's) annual budget is projected at NT$265.7 billion for next year, marking an increase of NT$7.2 billion from the 2005 level, according to the central government's 2006 budget bill unveiled Wednesday.
The Cabinet referred its 2006 budget bill to the Legislative Yuan earlier in the day for deliberation and approval.
MND officials said the increase in the ministry's budget for 2006 will mainly finance the planned procurement of six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries from the United States.

The Patriot anti-missile batteries are one of the three weaponry items included in the MND's long-stalled arms procurement package. The two other big-ticket items are eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft.

For more than a year, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party has used its slim majority in the legislature to hold up the special NT$480 billion budget bill for the three-item arms procurement package, claiming that the purchase would spark an arms race with rival China that could bankrupt Taiwan.
With an aim to placate opposition parties' boycott, the MND finally decided to adopt a new funding approach by dividing between a modified special budget and the regular defense allocation.
While the six Patriot batteries will be funded by the MND's regular budget, the remaining two items will be funded by a special budget estimated at NT$340 billion.

Both come from state coffers, but the regular defense budget carries more rigorous oversight provisions. By so doing, MND officials said, they are hopeful that opposition parties can approve the package as early as possible.

According to the MND's 2006 budget plan, the ministry's confidential budget will amount to NT$48.2 billion, up NT$6.5 billion from the 2005 level. Its missile unit's funds for arsenal renewal will also increase by more than NT$300 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: New Orlean inundated, a total evacuation ordered.
New Orlean was inundated in the wake of devastating Hurricane Katrina, leaving two million people without power and water. Looting apparently went out of control. Louisiana governor ordered a total evacuation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Looting, Fires And a Second Evacuation. This exodus was even more desperate than the first.
As murky water surged around their homes from levee breaks undetected in the immediate aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, families that had hunkered down for Monday's storm were forced Tuesday to climb first to their attics and then to their roofs in the hope of rescue by boat or helicopter.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Solons vote 52-2 at hearing
The House of Representatives Committee on Justice bucked a stormy panel hearing and opposition walkout to vote last night to treat the amended impeachment complaint filed by the opposition as a "separate and new case."
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo foes stage walkout
AS THOUGH foreshadowing a reprise of then President Joseph Estrada's aborted impeachment trial, pro-impeachment lawmakers yesterday walked out of the House justice committee hearing, claiming the proceedings were being railroaded.
The Philippine Star: House opposition walks out
Pandemonium broke loose in the House of Representatives late yesterday afternoon as impeachment petitioners and endorsers walked out on their colleagues in the committee on justice before the panel could take a vote on their amended complaint seeking the removal of President Arroyo.
The Manila Times: Impeach hearing ends in a walkout
Saying they were disgusted with the way the House Committee on Justice has been conducting impeachment hearings, congressmen seeking the ouster of President Arroyo walked out of the session hall Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT DEMANDS INVESTIGATION REPORTS ON KAOHSIUNG RIOT

TEXT.P: Investigations into the Aug. 21 riot of Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) has begun, and the government requires the investigative reports to be published quickly to clearly define those who should be held responsible, Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Wednesday.
Cho said the Cabinet will assign Minister-Without-Portfolio Hsu Chi-hsiung to decide whether the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) should take responsibility.

He also cited Premier Frank Hsieh's remarks in a floor meeting of the Executive Yuan that the human rights violations of foreign laborers has already been investigated by the CLA and a private task force.

Prosecutors have already begun investigating whether the riots were triggered by improper management or kickbacks, while local governments are looking into whether the contract between the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) and its foreign laborers is "reasonable."

Meanwhile, the task force headed by CLA Deputy Minister Lai Chin-lin gave a report on its finding to the Executive Yuan, in which it suggests that in the future employers of foreign laborers should face criminal charges if they exercise improper management.

Lai's task force also includes scholars, experts and representatives of Buddhist and human rights groups, as well as Deputy Director of the Thailand Trade and Economic Office in Taipei Manopchai Vongphakdi.

The report said that the riot by around 100 Thai laborers working for the KRTC was mainly due to the basic rights of foreign laborers being infringed upon, their working conditions not protected, improper management by the employers and poor living environment.

The report suggests that the CLA revise the employment services law to stipulate that employers who exercise improper management resulting in the freedom, lives and property of foreign laborers being threatened or infringed upon will face criminal charges.
It also suggests that employers should report to local authorities for approval on the working rules and management regulations for foreign laborers.

The report also asks the Executive Yuan to address the problem of increasing the full-time staff for foreign laborer management so that the management of foreign laborers in local governments can move in a healthy direction.

On the responsibility of the central and local governments, the report says that the labor departments in the Kaohsiung city and county governments both failed to act either before or after the riot, resulting in controversy on who should be in charge of foreign laborer management.
Both Kaohsiung city and county governments should take responsibility and the CLA must also be responsible for failing in its duty of supervision, according to the report.
Lai said that the report does not stand for the stance of the CLA and that the CLA will use the report as the basis for improvement of the foreign laborer system.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN PASSES NEW VERSION OF ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved Wednesday a new NT$340 billion (US$10.46 billion) arms procurement draft bill submitted by the Ministry of National Defense to replace a previous one that has been continuously stonewalled by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.

Premier Frank Hsieh appealed to the Legislative Yuan to pass the new arms procurement draft bill as quickly as possible, stressing that the country cannot afford to procrastinate on efforts to beef up its defense capabilities any longer.

Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai said that in response to lawmakers' demands and under pressure from home and abroad, the Defense Ministry changed the proposed manner of funding the three items in an arms package that the United States has agreed to sell to Taiwan.

The three items in the package -- eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft -- have a total price tag of NT$480 billion (US$14.77 billion).

In the new version of the arms procurement bill, which is expected to be submitted to the Legislative Yuan in a few days, the Defense Ministry lists the six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries, costing some NT$130 billion (US$4 billion), in its regular budget, while the eight diesel-electric submarines and the squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft are listed under a special budget for a total of around NT$340 billion.

Cho said that listing the NT$130 billion budget for the six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries under the regular budget means that it will have a crowd-out effect in other Cabinet budget plans next year. To help offset this effect, he said, the premier said at Wednesday's meeting that an extra budget of NT$3.5 billion will be allocated to the ministry in the next fiscal year.

Meanwhile, Cho noted, the special funding of NT$340 billion will be executed over 15 years, through methods including borrowing from banking institutions and selling off public-run company shares or state-owned land.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose slightly Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 1.35 points to close at 6,033.47.
The bourse opened at 6,041.86 and fluctuated between 6,078.17 and 5,976.40 during trading. A total of 2.9 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$73.60 billion (US$2.25 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.5 percent, and cement issues at 0.2 percent.

The other four categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.9 percent, banking and financial stocks at 0.4 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 678 to 211, with 154 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BOUGHT US$1.1 B. WORTH OF CONVENTIONAL ARMS LAST YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 30 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan imported US$1.1 billion-worth of conventional arms in 2004, ranking seventh among the developing nations, while China imported US$2.7 billion-worth, or third in value, according to a newly released United States Congress report.

The Congressional Research Service's "Conventional Arms Transfers to Developing Nations, 1997-2004" report shows that in 2004, the United Arab Emirates (UAE) led the pack of developing nations by importing US$3.6 billion-worth of conventional arms, surpassing Saudi Arabia, which imported arms worth US$3.2 billion.

China was the third-largest importer of conventional arms last year, paying US$2.7 billion, followed by India (US$1.7 billion) , Egypt (US$1.7 billion) , Israel (US$1.5 billion) , Taiwan (US$ 1.1 billion), Pakistan (US$0.9 billion), South Korea (US$0.8 billion) and South Africa (US$0.5 billion).

During the 1997-2000 period, the report says, Taiwan imported US$7.3 billion-worth of conventional arms, next only to Saudi Arabia's US$35.7 billion among the developing nations and ahead of South Korea's US$5.1 billion.
They were followed by Israel (US$5 billion) , UAE (US$4.8 billion) , China (US$4.2 billion) , Egypt (US$3.8 billion), Kuwait (US$2.9 billion) , Pakistan (US$2.8 billion) and India (US$2.2 billion).

For the period of 2001-2004, Taiwan's imports of conventional arms dropped to the sixth in ranking at a value of US$3.9 billion, contrasted with China's US$8.8 billion, which was second only to Saudi Arabia that took delivery of US$19 billion-worth of arms.

During those four years, UAE was the third-largest importer of conventional arms at a value of US$6.8 billion, followed by India (US$6. billion), Egypt (US$5.9 billion) , Taiwan (US$3.9 billion) , Israel (US$3.4 billion) , South Korea (US$2.6 billion) , Pakistan (US$2.4 billion) and Malaysia (US$1.4 billion).

For the period of 1997-2004, Saudi Arabia was the No. 1 importer of conventional arms with a value of US$54.7 billion, with China ranked second with US$13. billion and UAE ranked third with US$11.6 billion.

They were followed by Taiwan (US$11.2 billion) , Egypt (US$9.7 billion), Israel (US$8.4 billion), India (US$8.2 billion), Pakistan (US$8.2 billion) , South Korea (US$7.7 billion) and Malaysia (US$3 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS WANT FREE HAIRSTYLES, NO UNIFORM SHOES, SOCKS: POLL

TEXT.P: A great majority, or 94 percent of Taiwan students aged under 18, want the removal of restrictions on their hairstyles, while 91 percent of them hope uniform shoes and socks will also be scrapped, according to the results of an online poll released Wednesday.
The poll, conducted by the Yahoo! Kimo portal, found that 62 percent of the respondents aged 18 or below favor the notion that they should vote to decide what they should wear at school.

A high of 94 percent of the respondents aged under 18 want no restrictions on their hairstyles, meaning that in addition to long hair, they could also have their hair dyed or fashioned as they choose, the poll found.
A total of 91 percent said they prefer that school authorities would impose no restrictions on the type or style of shoes and socks worn to school, the poll found.

The poll also found that 88 percent of the respondents aged between 19 and 22 favor students wearing uniforms, which they consider as an effective way of demonstrating the students' status and their schools' tradition and spirit.
A total of 66 percent of this group were opposed to hair restrictions on students, the poll found.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for September moved down five points to close at 6,050, with 29,590 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for December dropped eight points to close at 6,050, with 389 contracts traded, while December futures lost eight points to finish at 6,050, with 34 contracts traded.
March futures moved down 77 points to close at 5,977, with seven contracts traded, while June futures dropped 37 points to close at 6,013, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,055 for September, 6,058 for October, 6,058 for December, 6,054 for March and 6,050 for June.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
September TE futures moved down 0.05 points to close at 247.9, with 5,045 contracts traded, while October TE futures lost 0.1 points to finish at 247.9, with 36 contract transactions.
December TE futures moved down 0.6 points to close at 247.3, with two contracts traded, while March TE futures moved up 1.7 points to close at 249.3, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.
September TF futures lost 2.2 points to finish at 932.8, with 1,622 contracts changing hands, while October TF futures moved down 3.2 points to close at 929.4, with 117 contracts traded.
December TF futures moved down 8.6 points to close at 925.2, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.094 to close at NT$32.751.
A total of US$1.11 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$32.718 and fluctuated between NT$32.650 and NT$32.800.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS GROUPS TO SUPPORT THAI WORKERS INVOLVED IN RIOT

TEXT.P: The Taiwan International Workers' Association and several other human rights groups formed a support group Wednesday with the aim of providing legal assistance to the Thai laborers who were involved in the Aug. 21 riot.

The groups noted that the riot by around 100 Thai laborers working for the Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) to protest against inhumane management and poor living conditions has aroused public attention to the dire human rights violations suffered by some foreign laborers in Taiwan.

Kaohsiung prosecutors have already looked into the riot and have interviewed those they claim were the ringleaders who led the riot, the groups said, adding that this is why they decided to form a support group that can speak up for them before the Ministry of Justice.

They said that many Thai laborers have been unfairly treated by their employers and have no other recourse but to fight back. For this reason, they said, the workers should not be held criminally responsible.
They also expressed hope that President Chen Shui-bian will give the Thai laborers amnesty.

Liao Yuan-hao, convener of the legal assistance support group, said the group will have lawyers and translators assist the foreign laborers and that they will accompany the laborers during the litigation process.
The groups also urged prosecutors to acquit the Thai laborers for "reasonable defense."
In addition, the Legal Aid Foundation said it will act on behalf of the Thai laborers to demand that the employers pay back-wages and provide civil litigation assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$240 MILLION BUDGET INCREASE FOR CONTROL YUAN WITHOUT MEMBERS

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, has been without members since Feb. 1 because the legislature has refused to approve the nominations submitted by President Chen Shui-bian, but this has not stopped the Executive Yuan from proposing a massive NT$240 million increase for the Control Yuan's fiscal 2006 budget.

According to the central government's overall budget submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval, the Control Yuan's share amounted to NT$2.26 billion, an increase of NT$240 million over fiscal 2005.

The proposed budget covers all normal expenditures of the Control Yuan, including salaries for 24 members and staff, administrative expenses and allowances for members to make inspection tours abroad.

However, the prospects appear dim of the Democratic Progressive Party-led government breaking the deadlock unless the president agrees to submit a new list of nominees matching the expectations of the legislature.

Chen first submitted the names of his nominees in January for the previous legislature's approval, but the opposition legislators refused to approve them, maintaining that most of the nominees were not up to the expectations of the public.

In February, the two major opposition parties -- the Kuomintang and the People First Party -- which hold a small majority in the new legislature, asked Chen to submit a new list of nominees on the grounds that his original list to the previous legislature was invalid in the new legislature, but he resubmitted the same list, which the opposition legislators refused to endorse.

The president indicated earlier this week that if it is necessary for him to submit the names of the nominees to the Legislative Yuan again, he will send exactly the same name list as the one he submitted early this year.

With the Legislative Yuan opening its next session Sept. 13, it is expected that the legislative caucuses of the opposition parties are unlikely to reverse their positions and give the nod to the nominations.

According to the Constitution, the Control Yuan has the powers of impeachment, censure and audit, and may take corrective measures against government organizations. Its members may also accept people's petitions with regard to central and local government performance.
At present, over 9,000 petitions have accumulated in the offices of the Control Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA, INDIA TOP WEAPONS BUYERS OF DEVELOPING WORLD

TEXT.P: China topped the world in terms of the value of arms transfer agreements with other nations during the 2001-2004 period, a newly released United States Congress report shows.

The Congressional Research Service's "Conventional Arms Transfers to Developing Nations, 1997-2004" report says China signed a total of US$10.4 billion in arms transfer agreements during 2001-2004, followed by India with US$9.7 billion and Egypt with US$6.5 billion.

For 2004, India topped Saudi Arabia and China to become the No. 1 country in the value of arms transfer agreements among developing nations, concluding $5.7 billion in such agreements. Saudi Arabia ranked second with $2.9 billion and China ranked third with $2.2 billion. Taiwan ranked eighth with US$0.6 billion.
In 2004, the value of all arms transfer agreements worldwide was US$37 billion, the highest total for worldwide arms transfer agreements, in real terms, for any year since 2000.

Last year, the United States was the leader in arms transfer agreements, making US$12.4 billion-worth, or 33.5% of all such agreements. Russia ranked second with US$6.1 billion-worth, or 16.5% of all arms transfer agreements. The United Kingdom ranked third with US$5.5 billion.
Sean McCormack, spokesman for the U.S. State Department, noted that under the Arms Export Control Act, arms transfers worth over US$14 million are approved only after notification to Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR CARRIERS CHANGE FLIGHT SCHEDULES DUE TO TYPHOON

TEXT.P: Two major domestic air carriers have either changed or canceled their international flights due to approaching Typhoon Talim.

The typhoon was located 200 km east of Hualien and moving west north-west at 21 kph, with meteorologists warning people on Taiwan and the outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu to be on guard against gusting wind and torrential rain.
EVA Airways announced that its Taipei-Vancouver, Taipei-Los Angles and Taipei-Paris flights scheduled for 11: 50 p.m. Wednesday would be brought forward to 9:30 p.m.

EVA Airways also canceled its Hong Kong-Taipei and Macau-Taipei flights that were originally scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Wednesday night. Its Tokyo-Taipei flight will be postponed until Thursday afternoon.
Its Hawaii-Taipei, San Francisco-Taipei, Los Angeles-Taipei and New York (Seattle) -Taipei flights that are scheduled to arrive Thursday morning have been changed to Thursday afternoon.

China Airlines decided to cancel all flights departing from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport before noon Thursday, and flights returning from Europe and the United States Thursday morning will be postponed until after noon.
All CAL flights departing for Amsterdam, Rome, Sydney, San Francisco, and Los Angles Wednesday night were brought forward by one hour, CAL also announced.
Airline officials urged passengers to check with their carriers to confirm their flights.
Meanwhile, swells formed off Hualien and fishing ships operating in the area began to enter harbors to take shelter Wednesday afternoon, with 82 Chinese fishermen coming ashore for the duration.
City and county governments announced the closure of offices and schools Wednesday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE FISHING VESSEL BEING HELD BY SOMALI REBELS

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing vessel, the "Chung Yi No. 318," has been held by Somali rebel militiamen since Aug. 13 for allegedly fishing illegally in Somali waters, the Kaohsiung Fishermen's Association confirmed Wednesday.

A spokesman for the association said that the rebels are demanding US$90,000 in ransom for the release of the deep-sea tuna long-liner, although the captain paid application fees for fishing rights as required by local authorities.
The 100-ton fishing vessel has 20 crew members from Taiwan, China, Indonesia and the Philippines. They were arrested when they were trying to steer the ship into a Somali port.
Attempts to negotiate with the Somali rebel militia for the vessel's release are difficult because Taiwan has no diplomatic relations with Somalia.

The Kaohsiung Fishermen's Association said it is seeking help from human rights organizations in the United States through the Council of Agriculture and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to obtain the release of the "Chung Yi No. 318."

Somalia, with the longest coastline in Africa, is surrounded by waters ideal for tuna fishing. The country has been troubled by factional fighting since the overthrow of military ruler Mohamed Siad Barre in 1991.
Since there is no one particular political entity that controls Somali waters, each coastal region has self-promoted militia, led by a faction leader, which controls its own area.

Foreign fishing vessels operating in Somali waters are at risk of being boarded by militia and having their boats seized. In March 1999, Somali gunmen hijacked a Taiwanese fishing vessel off Somalia's east coast, taking 30 Taiwanese crew members hostage.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS AWARD-WINNING MASTER TAILORS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he was moved when he came to learn that two Taiwan tailors had defeated their peers from many Western countries to capture the top honors in a recent global contest of master tailors.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with Chen Yung- jen, the gold medalist of the Golden Thread Awards, and Wu Ping-nan, the silver medalist of the Golden Needle Awards, at the Presidential Office to express his admiration for their professional achievements.

The Golden Thread Awards and the Golden Needle Awards are part of the events of the biennial World Congress of Master Tailors. The Golden Thread Awards honor outstanding women's suit tailors while the Golden Needle Awards commend brilliant men's suit tailors.

President Chen said it was a moving and glorious moment when the Republic of China's national flag was raised amid the magnificent melody of the ROC national anthem at the conference hall of the 31st World Congress of Master Tailors in Berlin Aug. 9 after Chen Yung-jen and Wu Ping-nan received their medals.
Because of China's strongarm diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, it has not been easy for the ROC's national flag and anthem to be featured at international occasions.
"You have brought great honor to our country, " Chen told his guests, both of whom are in their early 30s. "I admire your creative talent and skilled workmanship."

Thanks to concerted efforts of Taiwan tailors and the ROC's overseas representative offices, Chen said, Taiwan has won the right to host the next World Congress of Master Tailors in 2007. Taiwan will be the second Asian country ever to host such a world event after South Korea.

Chen also took the occasion to thank the Taiwan team's marvelous performance at the recent World University Games held in Turkey, in which Taiwan athletes won six gold, two silver and four bronze medals.

"Among the 130-plus participating countries, Taiwan ranked ninth in terms of medal count. It was the best rating Taiwan has ever achieved in a world sports event. The top seven medal winning countries were all big sports powers. The host, Turkey, ranked eighth," Chen said, adding that he was proud of Taiwan athletes' achievements.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES DRAFT BILL ON MINIMUM TAX

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved a draft bill on minimum tax system Wednesday, a move which forms part of the government's tax reform.

Minister of Finance Lin Chuan said the new system will focus on people who did not have to pay taxes or pay only an unreasonably small amount of income tax under current investment initiatives, and is designed to ensure that wealthy taxpayers do not use loopholes to escape paying taxes.
Lin stressed that the new system will only involve 0.2 percent of the country's taxpayers.

According to the draft, which will be sent to the legislature for approval, businesses with an annual income more than NT$2 million and above will be subject to a minimum tax rate of 10 percent; otherwise, they will be subject to the current income tax rates, while individuals with an annual income more than NT$8 million will be subject to aminimum tax rate of 20 percent; otherwise, they will be subject to the current income tax rates.

The Cabinet also sets up a "trust and protection" clause in the tax reform proposal, in which the industries obtaining the tax-free permission in advance from the government will enjoy a five-year tax-free privilege in their corporate income as long as the new projects will be started within one year and be completed within three years after the new regulations take effect.

Minister of Finance Lin Chuan estimated that once the new regulations go into effect, the tax income for the government is expected to increase by NT$10 billion (US$5 million) in the first year, with more increases in the future.
The implementation of minimum tax rates will be the first step of the government's tax reform, and will be prioritized by the Cabinet in the next session of the Legislative Yuan.

Premier Frank Hsieh has said that Taiwan's tax burden is relatively low as compared with other countries, with the average personal income tax reaching only 13.6 percent in 2004, much lower than the average of 27 percent registered by countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SYCOPHANT' JIBE UNCALLED FOR AND SHOWS LACK OF CIVILITY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh called on the public Wednesday to show civility and wait until all the facts are in before branding engineers or soldiers who are doing their duties "sycophants."

Hsieh was responding to media criticisms about a makeshift bridge on the Taipei-Ilan Expressway and about Hsinchu Air Force Base troops practicing songs and dances in preparation for a visit -- now canceled -- by President Chen Shui-bian.

The bridge outside the Hsuehshan Tunnel on the expressway, costing NT$1.5 million, was reportedly built in a hurry for Chen and other government officials who were going to visit the tunnel on Aug. 27. The media has coined it "the sycophants' bridge" and many suspect that the bridge has no other use. It has been estimated that the cost of tearing the bridge down will be as high as NT$15 million.

Media exposure of the soldiers' song and dance rehearsals led to Chen cancelling his visit, scheduled for Tuesday, during which he was supposed to have taped a speech to be aired on Soldiers' Day on Sept. 3.

Hsieh, a former lawyer, said he is not an expert in engineering, so he sent a team of people to determine if the makeshift bridge was needed for the construction of the tunnel or if, in fact, the media is right.

"So why is everyone jumping to conclusions and claiming that the bridge was constructed to toady up to the president? Worse still, people have come up with such names as 'a culture of sycophants, ' 'sycophant troops' and 'sycophant country.' What are they basing these on?" he asked.
"If [the bridge] was indeed a waste, useless or something used purely to flatter somebody, then criticisms would be justified, " he said. "Otherwise, some civility should be shown here."
Troops were in high spirits when they were preparing for the presidential visit, but now they feel frustrated and even depressed after being ridiculed by the media, Hsieh claimed.

"If these sorts of criticisms are not nipped in the bud, people will be labeled sycophants for giving their superiors a flower or a cake, and then people will be wary of each other, resulting in alienation," he said.
He accused critics of being part of a political smear campaign aimed at stripping the government of its authority and making it look incompetent.
Political struggles should not sink to the level of dehumanization, he said, adding, "It's pointless to go against human nature. " He called on the media not to take things to the extreme.

If Taiwan is to make real progress and become a civilized country, its citizens must learn how to respect professionalism, evidence, each other and talk reason, instead of simply satirizing issues or individuals, the premier said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAPER NAPKINS IN SOME CHAINS COULD BE HARMFUL: CONSUMERS' FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation checked paper napkin samples in Taipei from 18 chain outlets of restaurants, coffee shops and convenience stores and found that they all contained fluorescent penetran -- a whitening agent that may endanger human health, a spokesman for the foundation said Wednesday.
Among the chain stores are noted names like Starbucks and McDonalds.
The spokesman said its experts conducted tests using ultraviolet light and found that all the napkins tested showed florescent reaction.
He said that the tests also showed that the napkins from Starbucks and McDonalds contained "migratory fluorescent substances," an even bigger hazard to consumers if absorbed into the body.
The spokesman warned that these migratory fluorescent substances could cause skin allergies and even cancer. He suggested that consumers try to avoid using these napkins whenever possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY TAIWAN PEOPLE EQUATE JOURNALISTS TO PAPARAZZI: POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan people tend to hold negative perceptions of journalists, with more than 50 percent of salaried people responding to a recent online survey equating them to "paparrazi" or "cultural bullies," pollsters said Wednesday.

Internet Job Bank 1111 conducted the survey Aug. 20-30 to explore local salaried people's perceptions of journalists as part of its Sept. 1 Journalists' Day celebrations. A total of 1,122 valid samples were collected, with a margin of error of 2.9 percent.

According to the survey, 39.84 percent said they considered journalists as "paparrazi"; 13.9 percent said they thought journalists had "a highly stressful job"; and 13.37 percent said they perceived reporters as "cultural bullies."
Asked whether they had ever intended to pursue a journalistic career, 75.4 percent said no, and 24.6 percent said they once had such an idea.

As to problems with local media, 53.48 percent cited media outlets' fascination with violence and sensational news as the most serious; 41.18 percent said they felt that voyeurism is rampant; and 33.16 percent said they thought that "political interference" is serious.

Meanwhile, 40.37 percent said local journalists should enhance professionalism; 27.81 percent said they should improve ethical and moral standards; 13.1 percent said they should upgrade their investigative reporting capability and detect problems in the dark side of news events.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAR ASSOCIATION UNHAPPY OVER CONTROVERSIAL QUESTIONS ON BAR EXAM

TEXT.P: If some questions on exams for civil servants are politically charged, the test will be nothing more than a test for examinees' political orientation, the Taiwan Bar Association said Wednesday.

The association said in a statement that it regrets that the government's bar exam had a question on it about President Chen Shui-bian's speech to the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in the Chinese-language section that also required examinees to write a short article on "how the skills of a lawyer could be applied to running the country."
President Chen, who used to be lawyer before entering politics, is often criticised or praised for the way he tends to deal with situations in the same manner a lawyer would.

The association said government examinations, which are used in Taiwan to recruit government employees or qualify professionals, should steer clear of political issues and should not force examinees to tip their political hand.
Furthermore, the association said, examinees should never be asked to comment on politician's remarks or deeds in such a way that their political stance will be revealed.

In order to be fair to the examinees in the bar exam, the association recommended that the Examination Yuan, which administers the bar exam, assess the examinees' writings regardless of the test-takers' political views, and give all examinees full marks in the reading comprehension section for Chinese language as long as they put something down in that section.
The fairness of the exam, which took place on Aug. 26, was called into question after the United Daily News published complaints on Saturday from people who had taken the test.

The newspaper said Chang Cheng-hsiu, the official who presided over the bar exam, owes his post as a member of the Examination Yuan to the TSU, a political ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
An editorial in Wednesday's China Times called the controversial question "political product placement" and urged the Examination Yuan to invalidate the Chinese language reading proficiency section.

The newspaper also took a jab at the TSU for being reckless in naming a controversial figure like Chang to the Examination Yuan, and urged President Chen to end any form of nepotism in political circles by stopping rewarding people who shamelessly fawn over him.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Much of Gulf Coast Is Crippled; Death Toll Rises After Hurricane
Water broke through two levees in New Orleans o n Tuesday and virtually submerged and isolated the city, causing incalculable destruction and rendering it uninhabitable for weeks to come. As rising water and widespread de vastation hobbled rescue and recovery efforts, the authorities could only guess at the death toll in New Orleans and across the Gulf Coast. In Mississippi alone, officials raised the official count of the dead to at least 100.
Wall Street Journal: Storm Leaves Gulf Coast Devastated; New Orleans Fights Floods after Breaks in Levees
Amid wreckage and flooding that strenched undreds of miles, residents of shattered New Orleans and devastated cities along the Gulf Coast began to grapple with the death and damage wrought by Hurricane Katrina. While many areas w ere beginning to assess damages, New Orleans faced a worsening crisis Tuesday night, with at least two of its protective levees broken and waters from Lake Pontchartrain pouring into the city. Though hundreds of trapped residents were rescued from their flooded homes, many were believed to remain marooned.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT MAY VISIT U.S. IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: If all goes well, former President Lee Teng-hui will visit the United States in early October, sources close to Lee said Wednesday.
According to the sources, Lee's close aides are currently in the United States to flesh out details of his itinerary.

The sources said a pro-Taiwan U.S. state governor, who forged a cordial friendship with Lee during Lee's 12-year presidency, is assisting in arranging Lee's planned U.S. visit. Lee plans to visit Los Angeles, Washington, D.C. and New York, the sources said, adding that Lee most looks forward to making his mark by visiting the U.S. capital.

If the travel plan is realized, it will be Lee's first trip to the United States since his retirement in May 2000. Lee, an outspoken critic of China's threat to Taiwan and an ardent advocate of Taiwan's separate identity from that of China, has had difficulties visiting countries that do not maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan even after his retirement.
In addition to meeting with Taiwan expatriates, the sources said, Lee will also meet with U.S. politicians, including congressional leaders.

The sources said Lee may also visit his alma mater, Cornell University, during his planned U.S. visit which may last for two weeks. Lee made a rare visit to Cornell University in 1995 which drew a strong backlash from China as Beijing leaders regarded the trip as a move to promote formal Taiwan independence.
According to the sources, Lee's itinerary will be finalized after his aides' return from the United States in the coming days.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PURCHASE TO BE STRATEGIC DETERRENT: VICE DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The proposed purchase of Patriot missiles, submarines and anti-submarine aircraft from the United States will serve as a deterrent against possible Chinese military adventurism against Taiwan, Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Ming-hsien said Wednesday.

In an interview with the Tokyo-based newspaper Asahi Shimbun, Tsai said the proposed purchase of the Patriot missile batteries, at NT$140 billion (US$4.27 billion) , was given the go-ahead by the Cabinet Wednesday to be included in the ministry's regular budget.

The vice minister said that China, with obvious superiority over Taiwan in its numbers of missiles and submarines, is not amenable to peaceful settlement of its disputes with Taiwan unless Taiwan can strengthen its defense against these missiles and submarines.

With the acquisition of the Patriot system, submarines and anti-submarine aircraft, Taiwan will be able to foil China's attempts to cordon off Taiwan at sea or invade Taiwan, giving Taiwan valuable time to respond effectively.

Noting that the arms purchase proposal had been rejected by the opposition-controlled legislature many times when it was included in a special budget, the vice minister said he hopes the opposition will reverse its stance now that part of the purchase is included in the regular budget, warning that stability across the Taiwan Strait will be in danger if the military imbalance between Taiwan and China is not addressed by the arms purchase.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAILIM EXPECTED TO LEAVE TAIWAN THURSDAY EVENING

TEXT.P: The outer rim of Typhoon Talim is expected to leave Taiwan Thursday evening, and high winds and heavy rain will begin to subside the same afternoon, the Central Weather Bureau said Wednesday.
Weather forecasters said the island will suffer the worst of the storm between Wednesday night and Thursday morning, with the island's coastal areas bearing the brunt.

By Thursday night, the center of Talim, which is packing winds of 184 kph, was located at about 100 nautical miles east-southeast of Hualien in eastern Taiwan, and is moving west-northwestward at 21 kph.
